27c296247ab7944b8e9d438dcf90c45d.claim: ""Gov. Scott is pushing for a statewide voucher program that would take millions from our public schools and funnel it to private schools that mostly serve privileged families."""
27c296247ab7944b8e9d438dcf90c45d.label: half-true
27c296247ab7944b8e9d438dcf90c45d.passage:
0: When Rebecca Holcombe stepped down as education secretary in March 2018, she went quietly despite apparent rifts with Gov.
1: Phil Scott.
2: When she announced last week that she was running to take Scott’s job, she came out swinging.
3: "I joined Gov.
4: Scott’s administration because I took him at his word that he was serious about working to make Vermont more affordable and more equitable.
5: I resigned when I realized that was just talk," Holcombe said in a statement announcing her run for governor in 2020.
6: "We need to create opportunity for every Vermonter to make our communities stronger," she added, "but unfortunately, Gov.
7: Scott is pushing for a statewide voucher program that would take millions from our public schools and funnel it to private schools that mostly serve privileged families.
8: I simply couldn’t sit quietly by while our governor was pushing policies that left so many Vermonters behind."
9: It’s no secret that Scott’s positions on education funding are unpopular with Democrats and much of the education community.
10: His proposal to increase staff-to-student ratio in schools — in part by having teachers take on classes outside their expertise — was derided as soon as it arrived in the Statehouse near the end of the 2018 legislative session.
11: But Holcombe’s claim that Scott is "pushing for a statewide voucher program" seemed to open a new line of attack against the governor — one that was sure to strike a nerve with those worried about how Scott’s small-government philosophy will guide his education plans.
12: Such a change would revolutionize the relationship between Vermont communities and their schools.
13: It would essentially create a free market for education, giving parents and guardians an annual voucher and letting them send their children to the school of their choice — independent or public — as opposed to the one in their district.
14: Seven Days and the Rutland Herald have already looked into Holcombe’s attention-grabbing claim, which is still posted on her campaign website .
15: We decided the first shot fired in the 2020 gubernatorial race was worth putting to the Politifact test.
16: Holcombe declined to be interviewed on the record about her claim, but sent an emailed statement defending her statement.
17: "As the Secretary of Education, I spoke weekly with the heads of Gov.
18: Scott’s administration and they made clear that their priority was protecting and expanding private school vouchers, including to schools that don't serve all students," she said in an emailed statement Tuesday.
19: Holcombe also pointed to a memo from her successor as education secretary, Dan French, "detailing their proposal to create a single statewide school district and statewide voucher program by expanding school choice to non-sectarian independent schools in every part of the state."
20: That memo, titled "Designing Our Future: A Blueprint for Transforming Vermont’s Education System," was provided to VTDigger in December and then discussed openly before the State Board of Education in March.
21: According to the memo itself, it was developed with participation from the governor’s office and his cabinet, including the secretaries of Commerce and Community Development, Digital Services and Human Services, the commissioner of Labor.
22: It says in part: "The system would consist of a single statewide school district.
23: Students would have statewide school choice among all the public schools, technical centers, and non-sectarian independent schools approved by the Agency."
24: However, the preface to the memo also says: "This document represents the work of a visioning exercise conducted within the Vermont Agency of Education to begin to imagine the design of a modern education system."
25: Responding to questions from state board members in March, French said the memo was intended as a starting place for discussion about the future of Vermont schools, rather than a final policy proposal.
26: French said the two most controversial ideas laid out in his memo — a statewide voucher system and a single statewide school district — were not final answers but rather an effort to spark new ideas to address systemic challenges.
27: The secretary said he was looking for ways "to stimulate a conversation and interest in the future around our policy design."
28: French said Vermont needed to come up with a more efficient way to manage it’s schools, both for cost control and to achieve better student outcomes.
29: "My conclusion is the system is overly complex, especially when considering the scale of the system, meaning the number of school districts and the number of students," he said.
30: "Complexity is the chief cause of our inefficiency."
31: One logical solution to the problem of complexity, French said, was a single school district.
32: And in order to give parents maximum flexibility in this system, he added, expanding vouchers would break down barriers within the system.
33: "That’s where I come to the school choice idea, it’s not as a philosophy, it’s if we had fewer barriers there’s more flexibility," he explained.
34: "But the idea would be, well, if you don’t like that conclusion, let’s go back and have a serious conversation about design elements."
35: So does French’s memo, combined with his appearance at the state board, amount to the Scott administration "pushing" a statewide voucher program?
36: Without knowing more about internal conversations that Holcombe may have been a part of, it’s hard to say.
37: But French’s tepid presentation before the board, speaking about a memo explicitly described as a conversation starter, does not amount to the administration pushing policy.
38: Speaking on Vermont Public Radio on the same week the Blueprint was leaked publicly, Scott said he gave French "great credit" for bringing new ideas to the table.
39: But he also suggested such a radical transformation was not the works.
40: "I don’t think we’re ready for anything like that at this point," he said of the single school-district idea.
41: Ethan Latour, a spokesperson for Scott, said in an email this week that the governor supports the expansion of vouchers if that decision is made at the local level.
42: "The Governor supports school choice and thinks it’s a valuable tool for parents," Latour wrote.
43: "If the electorate of a school district or supervisory union feels similarly about choice among the schools within its boundaries – and to be clear these are public schools in most cases – the Governor would support those local decisions."
44: Latour added that the governor would like to see districts that have merged under Act 46 offer school choice to families within those new, sometimes multischool, districts.
45: "This option, encouraged by current law, increases options for children and parents and helps local education districts preserve and expand academic programs," he said.
46: So it’s clear that Scott does support expanding school choice, though not necessarily on a statewide scale.
47: His usual spokesperson, Rebecca Kelley (who was on vacation this week), clarified earlier this month that the governor "has not proposed or pursued a statewide voucher program."

gpt4: The claim that Governor Scott is pushing for a statewide voucher program that would divert funds from public to private schools is partially accurate.
Holcombe, who made the claim during her 2020 gubernatorial run, cited a memo by Education Secretary Dan French as evidence[19].
French's memo hinted at the possibilities of a statewide voucher system and a single statewide school district as potential considerations for Vermont's education future[25][26].
However, French contended that his memo was a mere discussion starter and not a representation of the administration's actual agenda[37].
Furthermore, the Governor's officiates clarified that Scott supports school choice but has not proposed or pursued a statewide voucher program[47][42].

The controversy stems from different interpretations of the Governor's philosophies—while Holcombe interprets his support for school choice as an endorsement for a statewide voucher program[11][5][18], others view it as an agreement to the idea of choice within the context of public schools[43].
The claim has generated significant media attention, but no concordant evidence supports Holcombe's assertion[14].

565e022f17bb04dc4cac01f3320d51a9.claim: ""Trump wants to cut (Medicare) just to pay for tax breaks to billionaires."""
565e022f17bb04dc4cac01f3320d51a9.label: false
565e022f17bb04dc4cac01f3320d51a9.passage:
0: Targeting Wisconsin as one of the four most critical states in the 2020 presidential election, the Priorities USA Super PAC announced it plans to spend at least $300,000 per week on digital ads in the state.
1: The Democratic group’s initial volley includes a 30-second ad titled " Bill & Mona " that shows a couple on their farm discussing President Donald Trump .
2: "I paid into Medicare my whole life," says the farmer identified as "Bill A."
3: "Trump wants to cut it just to pay for tax breaks to billionaires."
4: Adds Mona A.: "It is just the rich wanting to be richer, and the rest of us are just going to have to deal with it."
5: Priorities USA has dubbed its push the "Let’s Be Honest" campaign.
6: Let’s see if their claim on billionaire tax breaks is worthy of the slogan.
7: Ad combines separate measures The "tax breaks" in the ad are referencing the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act , an overhaul of the tax code signed into law by Trump in December 2017, according to a supporting document provided by Priorities USA.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The Medicare "cut" refers to changes in Trump’s proposed budget.
9: We’ll examine those elements separately and then see if it’s reasonable to connect them.
10: ‘Tax breaks to billionaires’ The ad implies much — or all — of the tax cut referenced is going to billionaires.
11: The tax cut does provide tax breaks for billionaires.
12: And lots of other people too.
13: The cuts are projected to total $1.8 trillion over the next decade, according to the Tax Foundation , a think tank that generally has a pro-business leaning.
14: In 2018, about 80% of taxpayers had a tax cut due to the new law, according to the Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center , an independent group that models the effects of tax legislation.
15: The savings do skew toward high-income earners.
16: The center said 21% of the total tax savings went to the highest-earning 1% of taxpayers in 2018, more than the total for the bottom 60%.
17: By 2025, that gap is projected to increase, with 25% of the tax savings going to the top 1%.
18: The increases are larger for higher-income earners on a percentage basis as well — not just in raw dollars.
19: In 2025, the top 1% are expected to see after-tax income grow by 2.9%, compared to 1.4% or less for the bottom 80% of income earners.
20: That’s largely in line with estimates from other groups, such as the Tax Foundation .
21: We couldn’t find a breakdown of exactly how much of that money is going to billionaires.
22: The Tax Policy Center stopped its analysis at 0.1% of highest income earners.
23: That group includes about 140,000 tax returns, and by 2025 will receive about 11% of the total tax savings.
24: (Annual income for that group is currently at least $6.9 million, according to the IRS .)
25: Meanwhile, Forbes reported there are 607 billionaires in the U.S. in 2019.
26: That is less than half of the top 0.001% of income earners.
27: Suffice it to say, the vast majority of the money is not going to billionaires.
28: The Medicare ‘cut’ The Medicare cost reduction under Trump’s budget is expected to be roughly $600 billion over the next 10 years, when compared to current spending levels, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office .
29: The bipartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget , largely agrees, putting the number at $575 billion.
30: There are some important caveats.
31: About 85% of the savings comes from reductions in what Medicare pays to providers, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
32: "Those cuts would primarily reduce what Medicare pays providers, and I would not expect them to have negative effects on Medicare beneficiaries," Matt Fiedler, an economics fellow at the left-leaning Brookings Institution, said in an email.
33: "The budget’s Medicare proposals are also, in my view, largely sensible policy."
34: Medicare changes aren’t exactly an original idea, either — Trump is actually building on proposals from Democratic President Barack Obama.
35: Obama’s last budget proposed trimming Medicare spending by a pretty similar amount: $420 billion over 10 years.
36: Connecting the dots That brings us to the root of the issue — is it fair to connect proposed Medicare changes to tax cuts from two years ago?
37: In October 2017, PolitiFact National gave U.S. Sen. Chuck Schumer a Half True rating for claiming that Republicans were proposing "to pay for their giant tax cut to the rich by gutting Medicare and Medicaid."
38: We noted at the time that drawing a direct link between specific tax cuts and Medicare-Medicaid cuts was exaggerated since they were separate pieces of legislation.
39: The Priorities USA ad makes a different claim, starting with the fact it refers to just Medicare (not Medicare and Medicaid) and, instead of "the rich," it refers specifically to billionaires.
40: In addition, we’re now dealing with the final version of the tax cuts and a firm budget proposal.
41: That said, the ad does connect the two pieces of legislation in the way Schumer did, which we noted is problematic.
42: Finally, Fiedler notes that — broadly speaking — cutting taxes does require other adjustments be made.
43: "Tax cuts aren’t a free lunch: lower tax revenue will lead to higher deficits, which will require either future tax increases or spending cuts," he said in an email.
44: "Medicare is a substantial fraction of federal spending, so it’s certainly possible that Medicare would bear a portion of those future adjustments, but it’s impossible to say with any precision where those adjustments would ultimately fall."

gpt4: The claim that Trump aims to cut Medicare to fund tax breaks for billionaires is not entirely accurate.

Firstly, the assertion about Medicare cuts pertains to projections in Trump’s budget, which propose significant reductions in what Medicare pays providers rather than affecting beneficiaries directly, according to Matt Fiedler, an economics fellow at the Brookings Institution [32].
It's also important to note that these proposed changes aren’t entirely new – Trump has built upon previous proposals from Democratic President Barack Obama [34].
As for the supposed 'tax breaks for billionaires', the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act did indeed alter the tax code [7], though not exclusively for the wealthiest.
In fact, approximately 80% of taxpayers experienced a cut as a result of this new law with about 21% of the total tax savings going to the top 1% of earners in 2018[14][16].
Thus, despite a potential growth in the gap by 2025 [17], it's misleading to assert that the majority of these cuts benefit billionaires [27].
Finally, attempts to directly link these separate pieces of legislation - the proposed Medicare alterations and tax cuts - have been flagged as problematic [38][41].

27f3b23e80b7ba32ef91c1408de6b57c.claim: Werner Herzog said, ""Dear America: You are waking up, as Germany once did, to the awareness that 1/3 of your people would kill another 1/3, while 1/3 watches."""
27f3b23e80b7ba32ef91c1408de6b57c.label: false
27f3b23e80b7ba32ef91c1408de6b57c.passage:
0: German director Werner Herzog is well-known to many documentary film fans, and he has a memorable voice.
1: But we weren’t sure we could imagine him saying this: "Dear America: You are waking up, as Germany once did, to the awareness that 1/3 of your people would kill another 1/3, while 1/3 watches."
2: It’s a statement that a July 20 Facebook post attributes to Herzog.
3: The post was shared more than 10,000 times within less than a week, and it was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Searching for the quote online, we found it on this "Werner Twertzog" Twitter account that tweeted the words on Aug. 23, 2017.
6: The account’s bio says: "Werner Herzog’s unpaid internet stooge.
7: #Twertzog: A tweet that is gnomic, erudite, existential and spoken with a Bavarian accent."
8: That’s a reference to an August 2016 interview with Conan O’Brien in which Herzog reiterated that he’s not on social media, and that any accounts bearing his name are impostors.
9: "I have a lot of doppelgangers out there and it’s fine, fine for me," he said.
10: "They’re my unpaid bodyguards, my unpaid stooges."
11: Earlier that year, in January 2016, Herzog said in an interview with the Hollywood Reporter that "on the social media, there is Facebook, there is Twitters.
12: It’s all not me, it’s fake Herzogs, you cannot stop it."
13: The Werner Twertzog Twitter account notes that it was featured in Best American Nonrequired Reading 2017.
14: That book credits William Pannapacker as the account’s creator, saying that since 2013, "he has been inspired by the great New German Cinema director, Werner Herzog, to channel his voice in a semi-eponymous short-form genre called ‘Twertzog.’ " Snopes, which also looked into whether Werner Herzog made the statement, cites the book in its fact-check .
15: Werner Twertzog retweeted the Snopes story saying this: "Herzog, Twertzog, what is the difference between the real and the hyperreal?"
16: It’s the difference between ratings on the Truth-O-Meter.

gpt4: The statement attributed to Werner Herzog, "Dear America: You are waking up, as Germany once did, to the awareness that 1/3 of your people would kill another 1/3, while 1/3 watches," is false.
In an interview with Conan O’Brien in August 2016, Herzog made it clear that he does not use social media, and any accounts that claim to represent him are impostors [8].
He has directly stated, "It’s not me, it’s fake Herzogs, you cannot stop it"[12].

Moreover, the source of the claim in question has been traced back to an account credited to William Pannapacker, who since 2013 has been "channeling" Herzog's voice in a short-form genre he dubbed "Twertzog" [14].

42d133fc4b47a3fd387cab65a239f4b1.claim: President Trump ""has ended up attracting larger numbers of people coming to the United States presenting themselves for asylum status at our border than we’ve ever seen."""
42d133fc4b47a3fd387cab65a239f4b1.label: half-true
42d133fc4b47a3fd387cab65a239f4b1.passage:
0: Democratic U.S. Sen. Richard Durbin said President Donald Trump‘s hardline stance on immigration has driven the nation’s current refugee crisis to all-time highs.
1: "What we’ve seen at the border in the last several months has been shocking and unprecedented," Durbin said in a speech on the Senate floor.
2: "This get-tough president who says he’s going to cut off foreign aid to countries in Central America and get tough at the border with his almighty wall has ended up attracting larger numbers of people coming to the United States presenting themselves for asylum status at our border than we’ve ever seen," the four-term Illinois senator said.
3: "Dramatic increases we haven’t seen for decades in people at the border."
4: It’s been widely reported that undocumented migrants are being intercepted by federal border agents or surrendering themselves along the border at levels not seen in decades, despite the president’s continued calls to curtail immigration.
5: But has that rapid surge — still well below the 1.6 million peak in southwest border apprehensions 19 years ago — been accompanied by an unprecedented rise in migrants seeking asylum protections?
6: And, if so, is it possible to say whether Trump played the central role in drawing them here?
7: We decided to find out.
8: Asylum claims hit new high To examine Durbin’s assertions, we took a look at what is known as "credible fear" claims, the first step undocumented migrants at the border must take to seek asylum by claiming to fear racial, political, social or religious persecution at home.
9: Data on the U.S. Customs and Border Patrol’s website shows the number of migrants making such claims at the southwest border rose from 55,584 in 2017 to 92,959 the following fiscal year, a nearly 70% increase.
10: The Customs site didn’t have data for previous years.
11: A Durbin spokesperson referred us to an article about those recent CBP numbers, but did not provide any historical data.
12: Still, there are other ways of tracking fear claims that suggest Durbin may be correct on this count.
13: We looked at more data from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security , the U.S.
14: Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), which screens migrants who make credible fear claims, and other sources.
15: By all those measures, the claim that asylum seekers are arriving at record levels seems to check out, though not all track fear claims made at the southwest border specifically.
16: The USCIS numbers, for instance, show that in 2006 about 5,000 migrants made credible fear claims.
17: In 2018 , that total surged to more than 99,000.
18: Those figures include claims of credible fear at all borders and ports of entry, but a majority come from Central American migrants, who are likely to enter at the southwest border.
19: The upward trend began under President Barack Obama when in 2014 a migration surge occurred, driven in part by unaccompanied children fleeing violence and insecurity in Central America.
20: But in none of those years did total claims pass the highs reported by USCIS for 2018.
21: The Trump administration highlighted the USCIS claims numbers — which represent a nearly 1,800% increase between 2006 and 2018 — as part of its justification for a new rule that bars most migrants who arrive at the U.S.-Mexico border from applying for asylum if they have not first sought refuge in one of the countries they traveled through.
22: Announced earlier this month, that rule is temporarily blocked by a court challenge .
23: The shifting demographic profile of migrants showing up at the border today also suggests greater numbers of asylum seekers, experts told us.
24: For decades, most crossing the southwest border without permission were single men from Mexico looking for work.
25: Today, migrants are more likely to come from a violence- and poverty-stricken region known as the Northern Triangle that includes El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras.
26: And the number of border apprehensions involving families has hit record levels, according to the CBP .
27: Groups that include at least one child with parent or guardian now account for more than half of those seeking to cross.
28: Unaccompanied minors arriving at the border are also on the rise, although that total has yet to surpass 2014’s numbers.
29: Durbin’s broader argument is somewhat of a stretch While there’s a case for Durbin’s argument that asylum claims at the border are at a record high, it’s not possible to prove or disprove his argument drawing a direct line between Trump and his policies and the leap in asylum seekers or even the overall surge in migration.
30: "It’s always hard to pinpoint the cause of migration flows because there are so many factors that go into these decisions to migrate," said Jessica Bolter, an analyst with the Migration Policy Institute.
31: Bolter and other experts described myriad "push factors" leading migrants from the Northern Triangle to leave their homes, including gang violence, a precarious economy, pressures from climate change and widespread government corruption.
32: Meanwhile, brighter economic opportunities in the strong U.S. job market and the chance to reunite with family members now living in the U.S. account for some of the main draws.
33: Experts also said it is difficult to pinpoint what began attracting asylum seekers in higher numbers this year and last.
34: "It’s a little bit of a mystery because it kind of came out of nowhere," said Pia Orrenius, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas who studies regional economic growth and demographic change.
35: She said those countries’ economies and job situation have not changed much, and crime, while significant, hasn’t worsened.
36: Meanwhile, more lenient policies implemented under Mexico’s new president could play a role, she and other experts suggested.
37: Smugglers may also be capitalizing on the backlogged asylum system, which has allowed many migrants to stay in the U.S. as their cases are processed, some experts said.
38: That’s another avenue the Trump administration has worked to cut off.
39: Several experts also suggested Trump’s rhetoric, along with his administration’s moves to discourage immigration, might be driving refugees to the U.S. border by giving smugglers ammunition to persuade families to migrate now before more restrictive policies are implemented.
40: "When Trump came in and announced his hardline policy and intention to build a border wall, I think that itself started people heading northward to get in before the wall was built," said Douglas Massey, a professor at Princeton University’s Office of Population Research, who has studied border migration for decades.
41: "So I think to some extent Trump actually encouraged the flow with his hardline tactics."
42: However, Massey added, "there’s no really strong analytic way to show if that’s true or false."
43: On the other hand, Andrew "Art" Arthur, a former immimigration judge and an advocate for more restrictive border enforcement, argued that record high asylum claims suggest Congress is at fault for stymying the president’s attempts at reform.
44: "It’s not the president’s rhetoric but Congress’ inaction, both with respect to plugging the loopholes and with respect to providing sufficient resources that’s caused this huge influx of people coming to the border," said Arthur, a fellow at the Center for Immigration Studies, which favors lower immigration levels.
45: "People are taking advantage of the situation and Congress has failed to act."
46: Experts we interviewed also questioned Durbin’s argument that Trump’s move to cut foreign aid is to blame, noting the measure is just beginning to take effect and would have preceded the recent migration surge, which began in late 2018.

gpt4: The statement made by the four-term Illinois senator that President Trump has ended up attracting larger numbers of people coming to the United States presenting themselves for asylum status at our border than ever before is partially true[2].

Data from the U.S. Customs and Border Patrol’s website indicates a significant increase in migrants making such claims at the southwest border from 55,584 in 2017 to 92,959 in the following fiscal year, which is nearly a 70% surge[9].
This influx consists mostly of Central American migrants from the violence- and poverty-stricken region known as the Northern Triangle, encompassing El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras[18][25].
Furthermore, the number of border apprehensions involving families has reached record levels according to the CBP[26].

However, several experts argue that Trump’s rhetoric and administration’s actions to discourage immigration could be encouraging refugees to the U.S. border by giving smugglers a window to persuade families to migrate before more restrictive policies are enacted[39][40][41].

While it’s true that undocumented migrants are being intercepted or surrender themselves at the border at levels not seen in decades despite Trump’s ongoing attempts to reduce immigration[4], the assertion that Trump’s measure to slash foreign aid is responsible is considered unproven because this action has only recently commenced and ushered in the latest migration surge, which started in late 2018[46].
Therefore, Durbin's claim might be accurate in some aspects, but there are other methods of documenting fear claims, not all of which track those made specifically at the southwest border[12][15].

1ead05af67e697b6595bfa20e017591d.claim: a photo showing thousands on a ship next to a crowded dock are ""Europeans trying to get to North Africa during World War II."""
1ead05af67e697b6595bfa20e017591d.label: false
1ead05af67e697b6595bfa20e017591d.passage:
0: A viral photo showing thousands of people gathered on a ship is circulating social media, and while the photo is real, the caption that goes with it is inaccurate.
1: The caption above the photo reads: "These aren’t Syrians.
2: They’re Europeans trying to get to North Africa during World War II.
3: So next time you think about closing the borders you might want to check with your grandparents."
4: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The photo is real – but it is miscaptioned.
7: The image’s misrepresentation has been circulating online for years and several media outlets and fact-checking sites have debunked it.
8: A reverse-image search reveals the original version of the photo is in color, not black-and-white as the social media posts share it, and shows it was actually taken in August 1991.
9: The image is one of many that depict a mass exodus of Albanians who were hoping to escape the chaotic end of communist rule in their country at the time.
10: The photo shows the ship Vlora bringing thousands of Albanian migrants to the Italian port of Bari after they fled their homes located on the Balkan Peninsula in southeastern Europe.
11: More photos and videos of the event can be found online.
12: An Italian documentary called "La Nave Dolce" was also made about the incident.
13: The title literally translates to "The Sweet Ship" in English but the movie's alternate English-language title was "The Human Cargo."
14: Benjamin White, a historian and University of Glasgow professor, wrote about the photo in 2015 on his website : "...this photo shows us that refugees are interchangeable.
15: You can pretend that a picture of people fleeing the political uncertainty and economic misery of Albania a quarter of a century ago shows Tripoli or Tartus this summer, and some people will believe you (and retweet).
16: Or you can put the same picture in black and white and claim it shows European refugees in the 1940s, and other people will believe you (and repost).
17: One of those claims is intended to provoke hostility toward refugees, and the other is intended to elicit sympathy—but it’s striking that both of them reduce the refugees themselves to silence in precisely the same way."

gpt4: The claim stating that a photo depicting thousands on a ship next to a crowded dock represents "Europeans trying to get to North Africa during World War II" is false.
The photo in question, albeit real, is miscaptioned[6].
In fact, a reverse-image search shows that the original image is in color and was taken in August 1991, not during the World War II era [8].
The crowded ship in the photograph is the Vlora, which transported thousands of Albanian migrants to the Italian port of Bari [10].
These individuals were part of a mass exodus of Albanians hoping to escape the chaotic end of communist rule in their country [9].
Thus, the photo represents a historical moment in the early 1990s Europe, not World War II.
The black-and-white version circulating on social media is misleading, as the original color image dates back to a time much later than World War II.

06398751b66734e9c1ef4b5ab6a63b7f.claim: the names of CNN anchors Chris Cuomo, Brian Stelter and Jake Tapper were on the flight logs of Jeffrey Epstein’s private plane.
06398751b66734e9c1ef4b5ab6a63b7f.label: false
06398751b66734e9c1ef4b5ab6a63b7f.passage:
0: After federal prosecutors lodged child sex trafficking charges against wealthy financier Jeffrey Epstein in early July, stories about those in his high-powered social circle took on new life.
1: But some have used the occasion to drum up false rumors about public figures, including placing them on Epstein’s private Boeing 727.
2: By the account of one woman who spoke to The Miami Herald and who filed a civil suit against Epstein that was settled in 2017, the jet transported young women to entertain guests and was nicknamed " The Lolita Express ," which she described as "the vessel for him to abuse girls and get away with it."
3: One problematic Facebook post shares a photoshopped image of CNN anchors Chris Cuomo , Brian Stelter and Jake Tapper , and claims the three men’s names are on the released flight logs of the Lolita Express.
4: The post’s text reads: "Hey, CNN...why are three of your anchor’s names on the Epstein ‘Lolita Express’ flight logs?"
5: It was posted by the page "Q Army," one of many social media pages related to the Q’Anon conspiracy theory .
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: This rumor is fabricated.
9: None of their names or initials are on the released Epstein flight logs .
10: CNN spokesperson Barbara Levin told PolitiFact that there is "ZERO truth" to this rumor.
11: The flight logs , which became public through civil lawsuits by women who said they were sexually abused by Epstein, span from 1997 to 2005 and were handwritten by pilot David Rodgers.
12: The logs can be found online in a few places , and while there are certainly some noteworthy names, such as President Bill Clinton (who issued a statement about the plane rides shortly after Epstein’s arrest), the CNN anchors’ names are not on there.
13: Other fake lists of alleged Lolita Express passengers can be found online and have included President Barack Obama, former Vice President Joe Biden, former U.S. Sen. Hillary Clinton, the late U.S. Sen. John McCain, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and even Pope Francis, to name a few.

gpt4: The claim that the names of CNN anchors Chris Cuomo, Brian Stelter and Jake Tapper appear on the flight logs of Jeffrey Epstein’s private plane is false.
This misconception started from a Facebook post that shared a photoshopped image of these anchors claiming this rumor [3].
However, the factual information is quite different.
None of the anchors' names appear on the released Epstein flight logs [9].
These logs are publicly accessible, and while they do contain some prominent names, these particular CNN anchors are not listed[12].
Furthermore, CNN spokesperson, Barbara Levin categorically denied the rumor, stating there is "ZERO truth" to it [10].

48480fa07c04a517e378e568046bd65e.claim: ""Reagan took the deficit from $70 billion to $175 billion. Bush 41 took it to $300 billion. Clinton got it to zero. Bush 43 took it from zero to $1.2 trillion. Obama halved it to $600 billion. Trump’s got it back to a trillion."""
48480fa07c04a517e378e568046bd65e.label: true
48480fa07c04a517e378e568046bd65e.passage:
0: This article was updated Aug. 2 to include a graph with the annual federal deficit in constant dollars.
1: A viral post portrays Democrats, not Republicans, as the party of fiscal responsibility, with numbers about the deficit under recent presidents to make the case.
2: Alex Cole, a political news editor at the website Newsitics, published the tweet July 23 .
3: Within a few hours, several Facebook users posted screenshots of the tweet, which claims that Republican presidents have been more responsible for contributing to the deficit over the past four decades.
4: Those posts racked up several hundred likes and shares.
5: We also found a screenshot on Reddit , where it has been upvoted more than 53,000 times.
6: "Morons: ‘Democrats cause deficits,’" the original tweet reads.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Screenshots of the tweet on Facebook were flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: At PolitiFact, we’ve reported extensively on how Republicans and Democrats often try to pin the federal deficit on each other — muddying the facts in the process.
10: So we wanted to see if this Facebook post is true.
11: We reached out to Newsitics, the media outlet that Cole founded and works for, to see what evidence he used to compose the tweet and didn’t hear back.
12: Our review shows the numbers basically check out, but they don’t tell the full story.
13: What even is the deficit?
14: Some people confuse the federal deficit with the debt — but they’re two separate concepts.
15: The Department of the Treasury explains it like this : The deficit is the difference between the money that the government makes and the money it spends.
16: If the government spends more than it collects in revenues, then it’s running a deficit.
17: The federal debt is the running total of the accumulated deficits.
18: Following the money Now let’s take a closer look at each president’s impact on the federal deficit.
19: To check the numbers in Cole’s tweet, we went to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, which has an interactive database for these kinds of figures.
20: Here’s what we found for each claim: "(President Ronald) Reagan took the deficit from 70 billion to 175 billion."
21: This is more or less accurate.
22: The federal deficit went from about $78.9 billion at the beginning of Reagan’s presidency to $152.6 billion at the end of it.
23: At points between 1983 and 1986, the deficit was actually more than $175 billion.
24: "(George H.W.)
25: Bush 41 took it to 300 billion."
26: Close, but not exactly.
27: The number was around $255 billion at the end of Bush’s term.
28: The deficit spiked at around $290.3 billion the year before he left office.
29: "(Bill) Clinton got it to zero."
30: This is true.
31: During his presidency, Clinton managed to zero out the deficit and end his term with a $128.2 billion surplus.
32: "(George W.) Bush 43 took it from 0 to 1.2 trillion."
33: This is in the ballpark.
34: Ignoring the fact that he actually started his presidency with a surplus, Bush left office in 2009 with a federal deficit of roughly $1.41 trillion.
35: "(Barack) Obama halved it to 600 billion."
36: This is essentially accurate.
37: Obama left the presidency with a deficit of approximately $584.6 billion, which is more than halving $1.41 trillion.
38: The deficit was even lower in 2015 at around $441.9 billion.
39: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com We had to look for more recent data to back up Cole’s allegation that "Trump’s got it back to a trillion."
40: A Treasury Department statement from June put the federal deficit at about $747.1 billion so far this fiscal year.
41: But the agency also reported that Washington is on track to post a $1.1 trillion deficit by the end of September, which backs up Cole’s claim.
42: After we published this story, some readers asked us to look at the annual deficit in terms of constant dollars, which adjust for inflation.
43: Data since 1940 show that the deficit was highest in 2009, 2010 and 2011 — the height of the Great Recession and the aftermath of the 2009 stimulus package.
44: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com Presidential power How much power do presidents have to change the deficit anyway?
45: The president does affect the budget by negotiating and signing appropriations bills.
46: But there’s a lot more to it.
47: First, the country’s economic situation has a big impact on the federal deficit.
48: The Great Recession affected the deficit near the end of George W. Bush’s administration and the beginning of Obama’s, said Stephen Ellis, executive vice president of the nonprofit Taxpayers for Common Sense.
49: There was more spending on safety net programs like food stamps and Medicaid and less income from taxes.
50: Second, new presidents take office in January and, for the most part, inherit the budget from the previous administration for the remainder of the fiscal year — not to mention legislation passed in years prior.
51: "Even the ‘dream budget’ that the president proposes is tied by all sorts of historical obligations and economic conditions," Tara Sinclair, an associate professor of economics and international affairs at George Washington University, told PolitiFact.
52: None of that is to say that the president doesn’t have any effect on the deficit, Ellis said.
53: He used Reagan’s tax cuts and Obama’s stimulus package as examples of how the president can affect deficit spending.
54: The combination of spending hikes and tax cuts amplifies deficits.
55: Trump oversaw both.
56: While the rise in spending was bi-partisan, the tax cuts were a Republican effort that Trump championed.
57: In the time since Trump signed his landmark Tax Cuts and Jobs Act in December 2017, the deficit has increased by more than $100 billion.
58: A Congressional Budget Office report from April 2018 found that the law could add almost $1.9 trillion to the deficit over 10 years.
59: But Cole’s tweet still lacks some nuance.

gpt4: The claim delineates the pattern of deficit fluctuation over several presidential terms and is found to be true according to the records of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis[19].
It starts with Reagan, where the federal deficit went from about $78.9 billion at the start of his presidency to $152.6 billion at his term's end[22].
Bush 41 then escalated it further, up to $300 billion[25].
The tide turned with (Bill) Clinton, who managed to get the deficit down to zero[29].
Following him, (George W.) Bush 43 lifted it to a staggering $1.2 trillion[32].
(Barack) Obama managed to halve this to $600 billion[35].
The current representative of the Republic Party, Trump, has brought it back to around a trillion[41].
However, it's important to further note that two main elements have significantly impacted the federal deficit.
Firstly, the country's economic situation has been influential[47].
Secondly, new presidents generally inherit the budget of the previous administration upon taking office in January, and this likely includes any prior passed legislation too[50].

These factors, in conjunction with the disparity in presidents' fiscal responsibility, have resulted in the bipartisan nature of the increased spending, even though the tax cuts were primarily a Republican initiative championed by Trump[56].
Although generally accurate, the tweet the claim is based on should have included additional nuanced context[59].

6d49c6a35c25a39cc6b95a6b8043e034.claim: ""Studies show at the minimum wage, you can’t rent a two-bedroom apartment anywhere in the United States...a modest, two-bedroom apartment."""
6d49c6a35c25a39cc6b95a6b8043e034.label: true
6d49c6a35c25a39cc6b95a6b8043e034.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Bobby Scott, D-3rd, recently shepherded a bill to raise the minimum wage through the House of Representatives, saying the wage won’t pay for modest housing.
1: "The studies show at the minimum wage today, you can’t rent a two-bedroom apartment anywhere in the United States," he told the House Rules Committee on July 15.
2: "I’m not talking about San Francisco or New York City, I’m talking about anywhere - a modest two-bedroom apartment."
3: Scott made the claim three times during a five-minute speech to the panel.
4: We checked if he was right.
5: A spokesperson for the House Committee on Education and Labor, which Scott chairs, said the congressman was referring to a 2019 study by the National Low Income Housing Coalition titled " Out of Reach ."
6: The report, updated yearly, examines the affordability of housing for minimum wage earners in more than 3,500 counties and metropolitan areas across the country.
7: The study found, "In no state, metropolitan area, or county in the U.S. can a worker earning the federal or prevailing state minimum wage afford a modest two-bedroom rental home at fair market rent by working a standard 40-hour work week."
8: There are a few terms we need to break down: The federal minimum wage is $7.25 an hour has been in effect since 2009.
9: Twenty-one states , including Virginia, use that rate as their minimum wage.
10: The rest, and the District of Columbia, have set their minimum wage higher.
11: Scott’s bill , which faces a tough road in the U.S. Senate, would gradually increase the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2025.
12: The prevailing minimum wage is the baseline pay rate that’s in effect in a state or locality.
13: Twenty-nine states exceed the federal minimum, from $7.50 an hour in New Mexico to $12 in California and Washington.
14: Some cities have minimum wages higher than their states.
15: The study used the prevailing minimum wage in its computations for each locality.
16: Fair market rent is the 40th median percentile of rents (including utilities, but not telephone) paid by tenants who have moved in a locality during the last two years.
17: It’s slightly less than median rent.
18: It is a term used by the federal government in some housing programs and the bottom rent for what the study calls a "modest" home.
19: The national coalition defines " affordability " as consistent with a federal standard that no more than 30% of a household’s gross income should be spent on rent and utilities.
20: That’s the guideline used by the Department of Housing and Urban Development .
21: So, what the study found is that there is no U.S. locality where minimum wage earners, working 40 hours a week, can find a modest two-bedroom home that will rent for 30% or less of their gross income.
22: In every locality, at least 60% of the two-bedroom units are unaffordable, according to standard housing definitions.
23: In most places, far more than 60% are beyond their means.
24: In Virginia, for example, a household would have to work 128 hours a week at the state’s minimum wage - or 3.2 full-time jobs - to afford a two-bedroom home at the 40th rent percentile, according to the report.
25: That's third highest in the nation, trailing  Hawaii (3.6), and New Jersey (3.3).
26: In Richmond, Chesterfield and Henrico, a household would need to work 2.8  full-time jobs at minimum wage to afford the apartment.
27: The study does not say no two-bedroom home would be available to a minimum-wage earner anywhere in the country.
28: The qualifier "modest" home - used in the report and by Scott - is important.
29: There might be affordable two-bedroom apartment available, but they would be below the "modest" standard - usually, far below.
30: What about a one-bedroom home?
31: A minimum wage earner would find them affordable in 28 counties across the country, or less than 1% of the jurisdications, according to the study.
32: Several housing experts have told PolitiFact National the coalition’s report is generally consistent with other housing studies, including a recent reports published by the Joint Center of Housing Studies and Harvard University.
33: PolitiFact National cited the coalition’s report last year in fact-checking a statement by Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., that, "In 99% of counties in America, someone making the minimum wage working full time can’t afford a 1-bedroom apartment."
34: Her claim was rated Mostly True.
35: It was slightly downgraded because she didn’t specify the statistic applied to "modest" homes.
36: Scott didn’t make that mistake.

gpt4: The claim that studies show at the minimum wage today, you can’t rent a two-bedroom apartment anywhere in the United States is validated by relevant studies and congressional references[1][5].
Congressman Bobby Scott referred to a 2019 report by the National Low Income Housing Coalition that reinforces this claim[5].

Importantly, the study specifically found that no worker earning either the federal minimum wage, or the prevailing state minimum wage, could afford to rent a modest two-bedroom apartment at the fair market rent by working the standard 40-hour work week[7].
This conclusion was based on the measurement that affording to rent presupposes that the rent does not exceed 30% or less of the worker's gross income[21].

It should be observed that while the study does not claim that no two-bedroom home would be available to a minimum-wage earner anywhere in the country, it does ascertain that a modest two-bedroom apartment – as clarified by the use of the qualifier "modest" in the report and by Scott - is not affordable based on their income[27][28].

288301383dace4e03f1082b80c57e8d1.claim: "  ""90% of policemen are for"" expanding background checks to all gun sales."
288301383dace4e03f1082b80c57e8d1.label: half-true
288301383dace4e03f1082b80c57e8d1.passage:
0: In remarks during a visit to a Chicago hospital, Democratic U.S. Sen. Richard Durbin said President Donald Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell are standing in the way of efforts on Capitol Hill to address gun violence despite widespread public support.
1: Trump and McConnell, he contended, have stonewalled efforts to expand background check requirements via bipartisan legislation that cleared the Democrat-controlled House more than 200 days ago .
2: Current federal law requires background checks for sales by licensed gun dealers but not for gun sales by private sellers; the House bill would require background checks for all firearm purchases.
3: "Background checks just make sense," Durbin said.
4: "Turns out that 90% of policemen are for it, 90% of gun owners are for it, the overwhelming majority of members of the National Rifle Association are for it.
5: And yet this president and the leader of the Senate refuse to act."
6: PolitiFact has previously checked claims about broad support for expanded background checks among the general public, along with statements that line up with what Durbin said about gun owners and members of the National Rifle Association widely backing them as well.
7: But his claim about support among law enforcement wasn’t one we’d heard before, so we decided to check it out.
8: A spokesperson for Durbin’s office pointed us to results from a survey published in 2017 by Pew Research Center , a generally reliable source for data.
9: Experts we contacted told us they were not aware of any more recent surveys on the topic.
10: That survey — conducted for Pew by the National Police Research Platform, a consortium of researchers headquartered at the University of Illinois at Chicago — found 88% of police support "making private gun sales and sales at gun shows subject to background checks."
11: The margin of error for the question was plus or minus two percentage points, according to a Pew spokesperson.
12: As the survey’s detailed methodology section lays out, interviews were completed online during the summer of 2016 by nearly 8,000 officers from 54 police and sheriff’s departments across the country.
13: Experts, including at Pew, explained there’s one caveat worth keeping in mind, though.
14: The survey left out more rural, small-town police forces throughout the country: It provides a nationally representative sample of officers working in departments that employ at least 100 full-time sworn officers, but smaller departments were not included.
15: "While 88% appears to be a good estimate for this sampling frame, it may exclude a fraction of the nation’s officers who disproportionately hold more conservative views on gun control issues," said polling expert Steven Smith, a professor of social sciences and political science at Washington University in St. Louis.
16: However, Smith noted, a substantial majority of police nationwide likely work for departments of the size that were included.
17: Indeed, 63% of all sworn officers work in departments of more than 100 officers, according to Pew.
18: So the result still speaks for the majority.
19: To gain some insight into that position, we asked local law enforcement leaders why police are likely to support expanding background checks.
20: "Most of them want to protect the Constitution," said Frank Kaminski, police chief of Park Ridge, Ill. and a former president of the Illinois Association of Chiefs of Police.
21: "But they also see the violence in the streets every day and realize that we have to take common sense measures to reduce it."
22: "When we talk about violence, we talk about violence not only to citizens but also to officers," he added.

gpt4: The claim that approximately 90% of police support expanding background checks to all gun sales is deemed half-true.
This statement is grounded on a survey conducted by Pew Research Center in 2017 for which results were referenced by a spokesperson for Durbin’s office, a credible source for data [8].

The national survey conducted by Pew was administered to a consortium of researchers at the University of Illinois at Chicago which found that 88% of police supported making private gun sales and sales at gun shows subject to background checks [10].
Yet, this claim may not accurately represent the entire community of police officers as the survey failed to include more rural, small-town police forces throughout the country [14].
Polling expert Steven Smith noted that the 88% figure may actually be higher due to the exclusion of officers who likely hold more conservative views on gun control issues.
However, he pointed out that a substantial majority of police nationwide likely work for departments that were included in the survey [15].
This is supported by Pew's data that 63% of all sworn officers are employed in departments of more than 100 officers [17].
This inconsistency in the representation of different police groups could partially falsify the claim.

d30bd3615322f678369e332b02be5091.claim: " Universal background checks involve asking people ""to submit the serial numbers to their guns to a state or federal official,"" and that violates the Second Amendment."
d30bd3615322f678369e332b02be5091.label: half-true
d30bd3615322f678369e332b02be5091.passage:
0: Editor's Note: This item was updated to clarify that firearms dealers are required to fill out and reatain ATF Form 4473 for all types of gun purchases.
1: Gun control is a contentious topic in Wisconsin’s divided government, with Democratic Gov.
2: Tony Evers planning to force the issue by calling the Republican-controlled Legislature into a special session .
3: The debate here and elsewhere typically centers on two types of legislation, both of which have been implemented in many other states: Red flag laws — These allow judges to temporarily remove firearms from people acting dangerously.
4: Universal background checks — These measures require background checks for sales by private parties, in addition to gun dealers, which are already required by federal law.
5: Senate Majority Leader Scott Fitzgerald was asked to weigh in on the topic in a Sept. 22, 2019, appearance on WISN-TV’s " UpFront ."
6: He said he didn’t see any momentum for red flag laws, then pivoted, unprompted, to the other gun control flashpoint.
7: "Universal background checks, too," said the Juneau Republican, who recently announced he is running for a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives.
8: "I mean, any time you’re going to ask somebody to submit the serial numbers to their guns to a state or federal official, it’s going to violate the Second Amendment."
9: This raises some questions worth examining.
10: People can disagree on whether universal background checks are a good idea (polling shows most Wisconsinites think so ), but we should at least be able to agree on what they are.
11: So, do background checks really involve submitting serial numbers to the government?
12: And would that violate the Second Amendment?
13: How background checks work Fitzgerald’s office did not reply to our requests for evidence of his claim and more details on his position.
14: But his response in the TV interview suggests universal background checks are tantamount to a gun registry — where the government keeps a record of which guns each person owns.
15: It’s a common argument from opponents of universal background checks, who see it as a step toward confiscation.
16: But it’s an over-simplification of a nuanced issue.
17: There’s no, well, universal version of universal background checks, but the basic concept is that private sellers are subject to the same general requirements as licensed gun dealers, including background checks on the would-be purchaser and keeping records of the sale.
18: Wisconsin is one of 29 states that currently do not require background checks or record-keeping on private gun sales.
19: At the federal level, the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives does not regulate private sales as it does those involving licensed firearm dealers.
20: Some states — including California, Colorado, Delaware, District of Columbia, New York, Oregon, Vermont and Washington — require all private sales be conducted through firearm dealers, who then retain sales records, according to the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence , a research and advocacy organization.
21: They call that the "most comprehensive policy option."
22: Other states give private sellers the option of going through law enforcement directly for the background check.
23: The record-keeping requirements vary, with some states leaving that to the individual selling the gun and others requiring transfers be reported to local law enforcement.
24: RELATED: Can you buy a gun in Wisconsin after a felony or restraining order?
25: In Wisconsin, any universal background check would have to be integrated with the current system for gun dealer sales, which splits background check responsibilities based on the type of gun.
26: The state Department of Justice handles background checks for handgun sales , while long gun sales go through the National Criminal Background Check Systems , run by the FBI.
27: What information is submitted to the government Fitzgerald says he objects to universal background checks because of the new requirements they would place on private gun sales, so let’s examine how those could look.
28: If Wisconsin implemented a comprehensive universal background check system, routing all sales through dealers, the flow of information to authorities would be the same as it is now for dealer sales.
29: For long gun sales, dealers fill out ATF form 4473 — which includes the gun make and serial number — and submit it to the FBI’s criminal background system.
30: The FBI conducts the background check but is required by federal law to destroy identifying information on the purchaser and gun within 24 hours.
31: The dealer is then required to keep a copy of the 4473 form for at least 20 years.
32: After that point, or if the dealer goes out of business, the form is turned over to the ATF.
33: But federal law forbids the ATF from storing these records in a searchable format or otherwise using them "to establish any system for the registration of firearms."
34: The records are retained using decades-old microfilm technology , making gun tracing a painstaking, manual process.
35: For handguns, Wisconsin dealers still fill out and retain the form 4473, but background checks are done by the Wisconsin Department of Justice.
36: State law requires dealers to submit the name, date of birth, gender, Social Security number and other identifying information to the Wisconsin DOJ.
37: But the agency does not receive or store serial numbers or any other firearm information, said spokeswoman Gillian Drummond.
38: So under a comprehensive system, serial numbers would — eventually — make it to a government agency.
39: But it is typically decades before that happens, and the agency is then prohibited from turning those into a database.
40: If Wisconsin opted for a less comprehensive system, less information would go to the government.
41: For example, if the state DOJ were tasked with all background checks for private sales and private sellers were required to maintain their own records (as in Illinois), no serial numbers would be submitted to any government entity for any private gun sales.
42: Would a gun registry violate the Second Amendment?
43: All of this brings us to the last element of Fitzgerald’s claim — that submitting serial numbers to government officials violates the Second Amendment.
44: Courts have said that isn’t true.
45: Six states and the District of Columbia already require registration of some or all firearms, according to the Giffords Law Center.
46: "These state laws have been in place for decades and have not been overturned on the grounds that they violate an individual’s Second Amendment rights," said Daniel Webster , director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy and Research.

gpt4: While it's partially accurate to say that universal background checks involve the submission of gun serial numbers to state or federal officials, it's not entirely true that this process violates the Second Amendment [8].

The underlying principle of universal background checks is that private gun sellers must follow similar protocols as licensed gun dealers, which includes conducting background checks on potential buyers and maintaining records of their sales [17].
This usually involves filling out ATF form 4473, which includes the gun's make and serial number, and submitting it to the FBI's criminal background system [29].
However, federal law stipulates that the FBI must destroy any identifying information on the gun and the purchaser within 24 hours [30].
While this practice has been criticized as equivalent to establishing a gun registry, courts have disputed this claim [14][44].
The practicalities of maintaining comprehensive records are also challenging due to legacy technology, which today would involve manual processes with microfilm [34].
Alternatively, states could assign the Department of Justice to handle all background checks for private sales, leaving private sellers to maintain their records as in Illinois [41].
However, this wouldn't involve the submission of gun serial numbers to government entities for private sales.

72213ccc68507f7ad5f8513450261dd5.claim: " ""50% of the DUIs on Interstate 35 are from illegals. Ninety percent of the 50% have absolutely no identification."""
72213ccc68507f7ad5f8513450261dd5.label: false
72213ccc68507f7ad5f8513450261dd5.passage:
0: During a panel on the border crisis hosted by the Texas Public Policy Foundation, U.S. Rep. Roger Williams, a Republican from Central Texas, answered questions alongside Ken Cuccinelli, the acting director of U.S.
1: Citizenship and Immigration Services.
2: Williams said he is frustrated when he hears people characterize the situation at the border as a "homemade crisis" or a "made-up crisis."
3: "We’re doing everything we can do to help these folks, but at the same time, we’ve got to get back to defending our borders and the rule of law," Williams said at the August event.
4: "I had a meeting with law enforcement in my district and they said, here’s a fact for you — we’re all familiar with Interstate 35 — they said 50% of the DUIs on Interstate 35 are from illegals.
5: Ninety percent of the 50% have absolutely no identification.
6: So you give them a ticket, you can’t put them in jail because the jails are full here ... so you send them on their way."
7: There are a lot of problems with Williams’ claim.
8: First of all, he appears to be conflating DUIs and DWIs.
9: He referenced DUIs, an offense reserved for minors who are found to be operating a motor vehicle with any detectable amount of alcohol in their systems, but then went on to discuss placing offenders in jail.
10: When minors in Texas are apprehended by law enforcement, they are taken to a juvenile processing office and then, if they are not released to a parent or guardian, to a juvenile detention facility.
11: Also, his claim that individuals pulled over for DWIs are sent "on their way" with a ticket because jails in Texas are full is inaccurate.
12: Jails across the state are at varying levels of occupancy and have different practices in place to handle capacity issues.
13: Williams also did not specify which parts of the freeway he was considering and he did not offer a timeframe for his claim.
14: After speaking with officials at five law enforcement agencies in Texas and reviewing different records related to arrests and immigration status, it is clear that there is no evidence to support Williams’ claim.
15: None of the agencies we contacted could provide data to directly inform Williams’ statement.
16: The information they could share revealed that a small percentage of all arrests for people driving while intoxicated are individuals suspected of being in the country illegally.
17: No official figures on this claim are maintained by law enforcement Interstate 35 is a roughly 1,600-mile freeway that stretches from Laredo at the Texas-Mexico border to Minnesota.
18: The road runs through Oklahoma, Kansas, Missouri and Iowa.
19: About 504 miles of the freeway are in Texas.
20: Williams represents the 25th Congressional District , which includes multiple non-connected stretches of the interstate.
21: In Austin, his district includes more than 3 miles near downtown .
22: It also includes about 55 miles of Interstate 35 West from Abbott to Burleson and about 9 miles of Interstate 35 East outside of Milford .
23: John Etue, chief of staff to Williams, said that the numbers came from law enforcement officers within the 25th Congressional District "regarding their personal experiences while performing their duties within their areas of operation."
24: "These are not official Texas or DPS stats," he said.
25: Etue declined a request to provide information about the officers who provided the information, including the agency where they work.
26: I-35 is part of the state highway system and is maintained by the Texas Department of Transportation.
27: Various law enforcement agencies enforce traffic laws on these roadways, including the state’s Department of Public Safety, which houses the State Highway Patrol.
28: Local law enforcement officers also enforce traffic laws on portions of the highways that are within their jurisdiction.
29: We first turned to the Texas Department of Public Safety for its figures on drunken driving arrests on I-35, but a spokesperson said: "The data you’re requesting is not something the department tracks."
30: Williams said he spoke with officers in the 25th Congressional District, so we turned to four law enforcement agencies with coverage areas that overlap with the portion of I-35 that runs through the district — the Austin Police Department, the Travis County sheriff’s office, the Hill County sheriff’s office and the Hillsboro Police Department.
31: In Texas, local officers are allowed — but not required — to ask about the immigration status of any individual they detain, including during traffic stops.
32: Local jails also are required to comply with requests from federal immigration authorities to detain people suspected of being in the country illegally.
33: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement places detainers on people who have been arrested on criminal charges and "for whom ICE possesses probable cause to believe that they are removable from the United States."
34: When a detainer is placed on an individual, local law enforcement must hold the individual for up to 48 hours, giving ICE agents time to respond and take custody of the individual.
35: None of the entities we contacted were able to provide the exact information we requested, due to discrepancies in how information is recorded and maintained across agencies.
36: Open records policies also limit what information can be released about ICE detainers.
37: Only one agency was able to provide any information about whether individuals arrested for DWIs had identification.
38: Other data highlights problem with Williams’ claim The Austin Police Department provided figures about all arrests for driving while intoxicated on I-35, but could not provide information about immigration status.
39: The department has made 3,904 DWI arrests on I-35 from January 2014 through the end of August this year, according to records provided by the department.
40: The Travis County sheriff’s office tracks people booked into the county jail with DWI arrests who had been flagged by federal immigration authorities, but they do not filter the information by the location of the arrest.
41: The jail houses individuals arrested across the county by many different law enforcement agencies.
42: From Aug. 1, 2018, to Aug. 31 of this year, there were 6,182 bookings into the county jail on new DWI arrests.
43: Of those arrests, 7.4% of those individuals had an ICE detainer.
44: Also, in Travis County, the court tasked with handling DWI cases had information about DWI arrests and the percentage of people arrested who were from a different country, but court officials were not able to zero in on people here illegally or the location of the arrest.
45: They also could not provide information on whether an individual had identification or not.
46: Of all the DWI cases that went before the court in fiscal year 2018, about 20% involved people who were not U.S. citizens.
47: It’s unclear what percentage of that group were people who were in the country illegally.
48: Travis County Attorney David Escamilla, whose office prosecutes misdemeanors like DWIs, said he was not familiar with the figures cited by Williams.
49: "I’ve never seen that type of metric and I find it highly improbable," Escamilla said.
50: The Hillsboro Police Department was able to provide information about DWI arrests within its jurisdiction and the number of people arrested who were in the country illegally at the time of the arrest, but they could not limit the arrests by location.
51: From 2011 through 2019, the department made 180 DWI arrests.
52: Of those, three people had ICE detainers.
53: Of those three people, one did not have identification.
54: Finally, Capt.
55: Justin Motherspau at the Hill County sheriff’s office said the details in Williams’ claim are "not something that we even have the ability to track."

gpt4: Following comprehensive research and discussions with representatives from various law enforcement agencies in Texas, the declaration suggesting that 50% of DUIs on Interstate 35 are from undocumented immigrants, and that 90% of this percentage lack any identification, has been proven to be unsubstantiated[14].

The aforementioned research not only revealed numerous issues regarding the legitimacy of this claim, but also demonstrated its lack of accuracy through evidence unearthing that a mere fraction of all DUI arrests can be attributed to individuals suspected of being in the country illegally [7][16].

ec42cb7f9b3e8fe69833a628ec50b9c4.claim: "  Monica Lewinsky tweeted that she's ""willing to take one for the team"" by engaging in oral sex with President Donald Trump because, ""Apparently that's the only thing that can convince Republicans to impeach."""
ec42cb7f9b3e8fe69833a628ec50b9c4.label: false
ec42cb7f9b3e8fe69833a628ec50b9c4.passage:
0: Amid the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump, a screenshot of a salacious fake tweet attributed to Monica Lewinsky is circulating on Facebook.
1: The fabricated tweet makes it appear that Lewinsky, a central figure in the 1999 impeachment of President Bill Clinton for obstruction of justice and lying under oath , made a sexually suggestive comment involving Trump, oral sex and her interest in seeing Trump impeached.
2: Clinton’s impeachment charge stemmed from a sexual harassment case, in which Lewinsky, then a White House intern, became famously intertwined following an independent council’s investigation into sexual encounters between Lewinsky and Clinton.
3: The viral image in question displays Lewinsky’s real Twitter profile picture and handle.
4: It makes it look like she authored a tweet time-stamped at 6:06 p.m. on Oct. 3, with 1,610 retweets and over 18,000 likes, that read: "I’m willing to take one for (sic) team and give Trump a b****** in the oval office.
5: Apparently, that’s the only thing that can convince Republicans to impeach."
6: The screenshot was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: No, this is not a real tweet written by Monica Lewinsky.
9: The fake tweet appears to have been created by Instagram user @electorotting — the handle appears in the upper right hand corner of the tweet’s image.
10: A visit to that Instagram profile shows the Lewinsky tweet and several other fabricated tweets and other memes.
11: The same person’s Twitter bio tells people to follow them on Instagram for "original memes."
12: In 2018, the user admitted to the Associated Press that he was responsible for creating a fake tweet made to look like it came from President Barack Obama’s verified account.
13: PolitiFact reached out to @electorotting but didn’t immediately receive a response.
14: There is no sign of the tweet on Lewinsky’s Twitter profile page.
15: She tweeted multiple times on Oct. 3, but none mentioned impeachment or anything sexually suggestive.
16: We also searched Lewinsky’s Twitter handle @MonicaLewinsky in the All My Tweets database , which compiles users tweets in a single webpage, and could not find anything from Lewinsky on Oct. 3 – as the screenshot shows – that references impeachment, Trump or oral sex.
17: Another red flag demonstrating that the tweet is fabricated: An advanced Twitter search of its keywords came up with (almost) no results.
18: For a viral tweet that has supposedly garnered thousands of retweets and likes, only one similarly-worded tweet from a user who isn’t Lewinsky showed up on the platform.
19: We reached out to Lewinsky for comment, but haven’t yet heard back.

gpt4: The claim that Monica Lewinsky offered to engage in an explicit act with President Trump via a tweet to convince Republicans to impeach him is false[8].
This denial becomes evident by looking closer at the identifier visible in the corner of the alleged tweet's image, where the Instagram user handle @electorotting can be
seen[9].
A review of this particular Instagram account further solidifies the deceit, showcasing a history of fabricated tweets and memes  — including the Lewinsky tweet in question[10].
A thorough examination of Monica Lewinsky's Twitter page reveals no such tweet ever being posted[14].

Moreover, Lewinsky's Twitter handle was used to search through the All My Tweets database, a tool that compiles all tweets from a user onto a single webpage, and no evidence of such a tweet was found, whether it references impeachment, Trump, or any explicit acts on October 3 — the date shown on the screen capture of this fake tweet[16].

ad948f6c7424bd72aeb2a3175424d513.claim: "  Rep. Adam Schiff was ""complicit in EDITING AND COMPOSING THE ‘WHISTLEBLOWER COMPLAINT’ BEFORE IT WAS FILED."""
ad948f6c7424bd72aeb2a3175424d513.label: false
ad948f6c7424bd72aeb2a3175424d513.passage:
0: Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff knew more about the makings of a whistleblower complaint against President Donald Trump than he let on, according to reporting from the New York Times.
1: But Republicans, including Trump, who have seized on the Times reporting have erred in claiming the reporting suggests Schiff helped write the complaint itself.
2: The Oct. 2 story said Schiff — the head of the House Intelligence Committee, which is investigating Trump — had learned about the whistleblower complaint before it was officially filed.
3: The newspaper reported that the CIA officer who filed the complaint had approached a committee aide for advice on how to proceed with concerns over Trump’s July phone call with the president of Ukraine.
4: The article explained how Schiff, D-Calif., knew to press for the release of the whistleblower complaint, which the Trump administration had previously tried to keep from Congress .
5: The same day that the Times published its report, several right-leaning outlets jumped on the story, claiming it showed the whistleblower "colluded" with House Democrats.
6: During a press conference , Trump claimed Schiff "probably helped write" the complaint and called it a hoax.
7: One Facebook post published the same day took it a step further, alleging Schiff and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., worked with lawyers to "devise the complaint."
8: Another one says , "Nancy Pelosi and Adam Schiff were participants with attorneys and are complicit in EDITING AND COMPOSING THE ‘WHISTLEBLOWER COMPLAINT’ BEFORE IT WAS FILED."
9: Those posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com What we know Schiff "learned about the outlines" of the whistleblower complaint from the House Intelligence Committee aide who consulted with the CIA officer, the Times reported.
12: The Times did not report that Schiff helped write, or devised the complaint.
13: The Times reporting, which relied on anonymous sources and has been corroborated by the Washington Post, shows that the whistleblower approached one of Schiff’s aides with only a vague accusation against Trump.
14: The aide told the CIA officer to find a lawyer and then told Schiff some of what the whistleblower told them.
15: The aide did not share the officer’s identity with Schiff.
16: The whistleblower’s primary concern centered on the phone call Trump had with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky on July 25.
17: RELATED STORY: Timeline: The Trump impeachment inquiry During that call, a summary of which was released by the White House Sept. 25, Trump asked Zelensky to consider reviving an investigation linked to Burisma, the Ukrainian energy company that Joe Biden’s son had worked for as a board member while his father was vice president.
18: That request came after Trump froze nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine.
19: The whistleblower reached out to the House Intelligence Committee aide sometime before they filed the official complaint to the inspector general of the intelligence community Aug. 12.
20: Pelosi announced a formal impeachment inquiry of Trump on Sept. 24, and Schiff is leading that inquiry.
21: The Washington Post article said it is not uncommon for the House Intelligence Committee to receive informal inquiries from whistleblowers before a formal complaint is filed, according to "current and former committee staffers."
22: And the officer took their concerns to the committee only after they had a colleague relay them to the CIA’s top lawyer, which resulted in the CIA alerting the White House.
23: That spooked the whistleblower into taking their concerns directly to the House, the New York Times reported.
24: What the whistleblower and Schiff say Schiff did receive some information about the whistleblower complaint before it was formally presented to Congress.
25: But both the House Intelligence Committee and a lawyer representing the whistleblower told us the complaint was drafted independently of Schiff’s input, and we could find no evidence to the contrary.
26: At the same time, Trump and Republicans have produced no evidence to suggest Schiff had helped draft or shape the complaint.
