27: We asked the House Intelligence Committee what Schiff learned from the aide about the whistleblower complaint.
28: A spokesman declined to comment on the particulars of that interaction, but he denied that Schiff had any contact with the whistleblower directly.
29: "As Chairman Schiff has made clear, he does not know the identity of the whistleblower, has had no communication with them or their attorney, and did not view the whistleblower’s complaint until the day prior to the hearing with the (Department of National Intelligence) when the (Office of the Director of National Intelligence) finally provided it to the Committee," the committee spokesman said in an email.
30: RELATED STORY: PolitiFact's Trump-Ukraine-Biden coverage in one place We also reached out to Mark Zaid, the attorney representing the CIA officer.
31: He said he also can’t comment on what Schiff knew about the whistleblower’s concerns, but that the officer "drafted the complaint entirely on their own."
32: "In fact, none of the legal team saw the complaint until it was publicly released by Congress," Zaid said in an email.
33: "To be unequivocally clear, no member or congressional staff had any input into or reviewed the complaint before it was submitted to the intelligence community inspector general.
34: Nor has the whistleblower or the legal team met with or even discussed this complaint with congressman Schiff."

gpt4: The claim that Rep. Adam Schiff was complicit in editing and composing the whistleblower’s complaint before it was filed is false.

A New York Times story reported that Schiff, head of the House Intelligence Committee, had prior knowledge of the outlines of the complaint but clarified that Schiff did not help write or devise it[2][12].
Assertions by Republicans, including President Donald Trump, that Schiff was involved in the formation of the complaint appear to be based on a misinterpretation of the Times report[1].

Confirming this, both the House Intelligence Committee and a representative for the whistleblower stated the complaint was drafted independent of Schiff’s input, with no evidence found to contradict this[25].
A spokesman for the House Intelligence Committee denied Schiff having had direct contact with the whistleblower[28].

Furthermore, Schiff himself professed ignorance of the whistleblower’s identity, denying any communication with either the whistleblower or their attorney, and maintaining he had not viewed the complaint prior to the day before the hearing with the Department of National Intelligence[29].
This claim stands in contrast with the assertion that Schiff had a hand in crafting the complaint[33].

e7389561eac2cfd1ab2f83a5327df55d.claim: " ""We have not spoken directly with the whistleblower."""
e7389561eac2cfd1ab2f83a5327df55d.label: false
e7389561eac2cfd1ab2f83a5327df55d.passage:
0: Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., said in September that the House Intelligence Committee had not communicated with the whistleblower before the complaint about President Donald Trump’s phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was filed.
1: But recent reporting from the New York Times revealed that Schiff, the committee chairman, had indeed learned about the outlines of the whistleblower’s concerns days in advance.
2: Seeking guidance, the whistleblower turned to a House Intelligence Committee aide, who advised the whistleblower to get a lawyer and file a complaint with the intelligence community inspector general, per committee procedures.
3: The aide shared some of that information with Schiff.
4: As the Washington Post’s Fact Checker first noted , this revelation flies in the face of Schiff’s public comments during the month of September, when he dodged questions about whether he or his committee had talked to the whistleblower and, in one case , denied that they had.
5: On Sept. 17, more than a week before the whistleblower’s complaint was made public, MSNBC’s Sam Stein asked Schiff if he had heard from the whistleblower and if he wanted to.
6: "We have not spoken directly with the whistleblower," Schiff said .
7: "We would like to.
8: But I’m sure the whistleblower has concerns that he has not been advised, as the law requires, by the inspector general or the director of national Intelligence just as to how he is to communicate with Congress, and so the risk for the whistleblower is retaliation."
9: RELATED: What the whistleblower law says about sharing complaints with Congress The New York Times report, which quoted Schiff spokesman Patrick Boland acknowledging that "the whistle-blower contacted the committee for guidance," shows that this statement was inaccurate.
10: While it was not publicly known that Schiff’s committee had communicated with the whistleblower ahead of the complaint’s filing, Schiff knew the truth.
11: When given the chance to say that the whistleblower had reached out to a committee aide, he did not.
12: Schiff’s comments The New York Times reported that the committee aide received only a vague outline of the whistleblower’s concerns.
13: Without revealing the whistleblower’s identity, the aide then told Schiff "some of what the officer conveyed," the report said.
14: Other outlets reported similar details.
15: Previously, Schiff had given the impression that his committee never spoke to the whistleblower.
16: Before Schiff’s MSNBC interview — in which he flatly stated, "We have not spoken directly with the whistleblower" — Schiff also evaded a question from CNN’s Anderson Cooper about whether he’d been contacted by the whistleblower or the whistleblower’s legal representation.
17: "I don’t want to get into any particulars," Schiff said during the Sept. 16 interview.
18: "I want to make sure that there’s nothing that I do that jeopardizes the whistleblower in any way."
19: Schiff has since clarified his remarks.
20: He told the Daily Beast that until recently, he did not know for certain whether the complaint detailing the Trump-Zelensky call was submitted by the same whistleblower who contacted his staff.
21: He also said he thought the questions asking if the committee had heard from the whistleblower were focused on whether the whistleblower had testified privately in Congress.
22: "I was really thinking along the lines of wanting to get him to come in to testify,"  Schiff told the Daily Beast.
23: "I regret that I wasn't much more clear."
24: In a statement to PolitiFact, a spokesperson for the House Intelligence Committee said Schiff’s comments on MSNBC were "intended to answer the question of whether the committee had heard testimony from the whistleblower, which they had not."
25: "Nonetheless, he acknowledges that his statement should have been more carefully phrased to make that distinction clear," the spokesperson said.
26: Mark Zaid, the whistleblower’s counsel, declined to comment on the whistleblower’s outreach to committee staff but stressed that the whistleblower wrote the complaint "entirely on their own."
27: We addressed the false claim that Schiff helped write the complaint in a separate fact-check .

gpt4: The claim that "We have not spoken directly with the whistleblower" is false.

This is reportedly contradicted by recent reporting from the New York Times, which revealed that Committee Chairman Schiff had learned about the outlines of the whistleblower’s concerns several days in advance [1].

As part of the process for dealing with the concerns, the whistleblower had reportedly sought guidance from a committee aide in Schiff's team, who advised the whistleblower to seek legal representation and submit a formal complaint to the intelligence community inspector general [2].
This information was then relayed to Schiff [3][13].

This development directly contradicts Schiff's previous statements during September wherein he carefully avoided answering queries about whether he or his committee had ventured into discussions with the whistleblower and, at one point, completely denied any such occurrence [4].

Despite the initial lack of public knowledge on Schiff’s committee interacting with the whistleblower prior to the filing of the complaint, it has emerged that Schiff was aware of the true situation [10].

152484c8f6079c674dea664bf942767b.claim: " ""Republican policies have led to business investment growth that’s 10 times"
152484c8f6079c674dea664bf942767b.label: half-true
152484c8f6079c674dea664bf942767b.passage:
0: Republicans love praising the Trump economy.
1: With one of the lowest unemployment rates in years and steady job growth, there’s a lot to boast about.
2: But just how well does the Trump administration’s overall economic performance compare to his predecessor Barack Obama?
3: And how has the business climate fared under the two presidents?
4: Here’s what U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wisconsin, claimed in a July 15, 2019 tweet : "Republican policies have led to business investment growth that’s 10 times faster than what we saw under President Obama."
5: The numbers don’t lie, he says.
6: But how exactly is he measuring them?
7: Although the tweet is a bit old, the issue will be an important one in the coming election, so we decided to take a look.
8: The data To come to his conclusion, Johnson’s staff told us he used data from the Bureau of Economic Analysis -- an agency within the U.S. Department of Commerce that measures economic growth.
9: Johnson pointed to statistics measuring "private fixed investment, nonresidential" which show how much businesses invest in structures, equipment and intellectual property, such as software and research and development.
10: Johnson broadly said growth has been 10 times faster under Trump than Obama in his tweet.
11: Those who read it would, presumably think it took in Obama’s entire eight year tenure.
12: But in the data Johnson used, he only compared the final two years of the Obama administration, 2015 and 2016, to a little over the first two years of data for the Trump administration.
13: That approach often signals cherry-picking.
14: Let’s dig deeper.
15: "We use the final two years of the Obama administration for comparison because it constitutes a comparable length of time with the two years of data for the Trump administration," said Ben Voelkel, a spokesman for Johnson.
16: "It is a time adjacent to, rather than remote from, the Trump years."
17: According to Johnson’s data points, Obama had an average of 0.6% growth in that period, compared to 6.4% under Trump.
18: The Bureau of Economic Analysis updated the data shortly after Johnson made the statement.
19: In doing so, figures for some of the quarters were slightly adjusted, but the overall trend was largely the same.
20: The new numbers showed between 2015 and 2016, the Obama administration had an average business investment growth of 0.7%.
21: Meanwhile, between 2017 and 2018 (and the first quarter of 2019), the Trump administration had a growth of about 5.5%.
22: That’s not far off from the original numbers, though quite not as strong.
23: The full picture Of course, Obama’s term did not start in 2015.
24: Under the full eight years of the Obama administration, the rate of business investment growth was about 3.7%.
25: When bringing Trump’s term to the overall latest numbers, overall growth has been about 4.9%.
26: So, looking at all of Obama’s tenure, the numbers are much more comparable.
27: What about the beginning of Obama’s term.
28: How does it compare to the beginning of Trump’s term?
29: In Obama’s first two years plus an additional quarter -- the period cited by Johnson -- the business investment rate actually declined by 0.3%.
30: This was the period immediately after the Great Recession.
31: That underscores the volatility of the numbers -- and how the timeframe you pick can make a major difference.
32: Other measures, other factors There are other ways to examine business growth -- and another part of the claim to consider: Johnson asserts the growth was caused by GOP policies.
33: Tara Sinclair, an economics professor at George Washington University, said average growth rates for business investment look stronger in recent years, but when measured as a share of Gross Domestic Product the picture is very similar under both administrations.
34: Why?
35: The nation’s GDP -- a conventional measure of the size of the economy -- has also grown over time.
36: "The share of GDP going to ‘private fixed investment, nonresidential’ is below the peaks seen in the 1980s and 2000s," Sinclair said in an email to PolitiFact Wisconsin.
37: Sinclair said GOP policies that cut regulations may have helped lead to stronger business investment under the Trump administration, but it’s hard to blame or credit a presidential administration for most economic outcomes.
38: Indeed, as we have noted time and again in fact checks, experts say it is wrong to attribute too much to individuals or particular policy changes.
39: There are simply too many factors in the economy to boil it down to one.
40: "As you can see from the data, the quarterly growth rates are quite volatile, so more data to identify a clear trend will be helpful," Sinclair told us.

gpt4: The claim that Republican policies have led to business investment growth that's 10 times faster under Trump than Obama is half-true.
Tara Sinclair, an economics professor at George Washington University, confirmed that average growth rates for business investment have been stronger in recent years [33].

However, suggesting this is due to Republican policies is contentious, as Sinclair also mentioned that it's difficult to attribute most economic outcomes to a specific presidential administration[37].
Johnson made the claim that growth was 10 times faster under Trump, but the comparison he made was based on a limited timeframe [10][12].
In comparing the last two years of Obama's administration to the first two years of Trump's, Johnson showed an average growth of 0.6% for Obama and 6.4% for Trump [17][20].
However, looking at the full eight years of Obama's administration, the rate of business investment growth was about 3.7%, which goes up to 4.9% under Trump [24][25].

Therefore, while it's true that business growth investment has been faster under Trump than Obama in a limited analysis, attributing it directly to Republican policies lacks sufficient empirical evidence.

fd27129beda861e4c197e330156d99fa.claim: " ""About 95 percent of America’s production of ethylene is produced on the Gulf Coast in Texas and Louisiana."""
fd27129beda861e4c197e330156d99fa.label: true
fd27129beda861e4c197e330156d99fa.passage:
0: Three U.S. House members from West Virginia have proposed creating an Appalachian Storage Hub to store and transport large amounts of natural gas liquids in the region.
1: One of those House members is West Virginia Republican David McKinley.
2: In a news release announcing House Resolution 4433 -- the Appalachian Regional Energy Hub Initiative -- McKinley said he backs the effort and cited Hurricane Harvey, the 2017 storm that shocked coastal Texas and Louisiana, as evidence that a more reliable storage system is needed.
3: "Developing such a ‘Hub’ in Appalachia would bring significant investment and jobs to the region," McKinley said in his op-ed for the Fairmont News.
4: In his news release, McKinley wrote that the danger for the nation is that today, "about 95% of America’s production of ethylene is produced on the Gulf Coast in Texas and Louisiana — a region exposed to major storms like Hurricane Harvey."
5: Is he right about that percentage?
6: We took a closer look.
7: What is ethylene?
8: First, let’s explain what ethylene is.
9: Ethylene is commonly used to produce polyethylene, which is one of the most commonly produced plastics in the world.
10: Food packaging and containers, bottles, and housewares are among the products manufactured from polyethylene.
11: McKinley’s District of Columbia office pointed us to a report to Congress by the U.S. Energy Department released in November 2018.
12: The report includes a line that says that "ethylene production capacity is highly concentrated in the United States Gulf Coast; over 95% of U.S. ethylene production capacity is located in either Texas or Louisiana."
13: The figure below illustrates the total capacity in million metric tons that each region produces, the majority of which comes from Texas and Lousiania.
14: Documented Ethylene Production Capacity in the U.S. (Source: Ethane Storage and Distribution hub in the United States ) After Hurricane Harvey hit the U.S. in Texas and Louisiana, 60% of the production capacity in America went offline, causing problems for industry, at least in the short term.
15: It’s worth noting that these numbers can be expected to shift once a major "ethane cracker" plant in Monaca, Pa., comes online in another year or two.
16: Crackers are facilities that break down ethane into multiple byproducts, including ethylene.
17: The Shell Chemicals facility in Monaca is expected to produce 1.6 million metric tons per year of ethylene.
18: The Energy Department report cites two additional ethylene facilities in the Appalachian region that are on the drawing board, though they are slated to come online after the Monaca plant.
19: They are in Washington Bottom, W.Va., and Shadyside, Ohio.

gpt4: The claim that about 95 percent of America’s ethylene production is on the Gulf Coast in Texas and Louisiana is true.

This has been verified in a news release by McKinley, stating that these regions, which are known to be exposed to major storms like Hurricane Harvey, are responsible for the vast majority of the country's production of this essential hydrocarbon compound [4].

The concentration of ethylene production in these states is further corroborated by a report that explicitly indicates that over 95% of U.S. ethylene production capacity is situated in either Texas or Louisiana [12].

e84cede78e8395bacc1735a6ca479f0c.claim: " ""A study shows that households neighboring West Virginia could be on the hook for upwards of $70,000 in the first year alone under the Green New Deal!"""
e84cede78e8395bacc1735a6ca479f0c.label: half-true
e84cede78e8395bacc1735a6ca479f0c.passage:
0: Republicans have focused their attacks on a congressional Democratic proposal known as the Green New Deal.
1: The proposal, whose highest-profile champion is Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., is aimed at curbing climate change, but Republicans counter that its associated costs will wreck the economy.
2: The House version of the proposal has far-reaching environmental goals, including "eliminating pollution and greenhouse gas emissions as much as technologically feasible."
3: It reaches into other domestic policy areas, as well.
4: One of the GOP lawmakers who took a shot at the Green New Deal is West Virginia Sen. Shelley Moore Capito.
5: Capito took the proposal to task in an Aug. 20 Facebook post : "Democrats are desperate to implement their Green New Deal.
6: They care little about the cost and will leave you with the bill!
7: A study shows that households neighboring West Virginia could be on the hook for upwards of $70,000 in the first year alone under the Green New Deal!
8: This doesn’t sound like much of a deal to us!"
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Capito’s congressional and campaign offices declined to comment for this article, but her Facebook post linked to a Fox Business article that, in turn, cited a study by the Competitive Enterprise Institute on the household effects of the Green New Deal, or GND.
10: "At a minimum, the GND would impose large and recurring costs on American households," the study said.
11: "We conclude that in four of the five states analyzed — Florida, New Hampshire, New Mexico, and Pennsylvania — the GND would cost a typical household more than $70,000 in the first year of implementation, approximately $45,000 for each of the next four years, and more than $37,000 each year thereafter."
12: Pennsylvanians could expect a $72,439 hit.
13: In the fifth state, Alaska, the costs would be the highest of all.
14: Travis Burk, a CEI spokesman, said Capito’s Facebook statement "accurately described" the study.
15: "The study looked at the available data in those states and estimated increased costs for electricity production, upgrading vehicles and housing, and elements of shipping," Burk said.
16: "In the interest of fairness, the study is transparent about the inability to estimate a price tag for several of the more costly but vaguely-worded elements of the plan, including a universal job guarantee and guaranteed retirement security for all."
17: Adding in those other elements would mean that Capito was "underestimating the potential costs," Burk said.
18: There is little doubt that a proposal as sweeping as the Green New Deal would come with a significant price tag.
19: Where Capito’s assertion falls short is in its specificity.
20: The Competitive Enterprise Institute is "dedicated to advancing the principles of limited government, free enterprise, and individual liberty," according to its website — so it’s not surprising that the group would be skeptical of a pro-regulatory plan like the Green New Deal.
21: More to the point, Capito glosses over some of the study’s shortcomings.
22: The Green New Deal is an aspirational blueprint rather than a binding piece of legislation.
23: The proposal doesn’t lay out any cost figures.
24: And it has not received a cost estimate by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office — the gold-standard source on such estimates.
25: As a result, the details of the proposal are vague and open to a range of interpretations.
26: The study itself acknowledges that its calculations require "a considerable number of assumptions" — assumptions that other policy specialists say will make specific figures hard to pin down.
27: We have previously fact-checked a statement that, "at $93 trillion, the Green New Deal would cost more than the entire recorded spending of the U.S. since the Constitution went into effect in 1789."
28: The $93 trillion figure comes from a high-end estimate by a conservative group, the American Action Forum .
29: The CEI study that Capito relied on cited the American Action Forum as a "key source" for its own calculations.
30: As we noted at the time, the American Action Forum report described its estimates as an "initial foray," filled with assumptions and caveats.
31: The Green New Deal "lacks too many details to seriously model," Howard Gleckman, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center, told PolitiFact West Virginia.

gpt4: While a study does suggest that households neighboring West Virginia could incur significant costs under the Green New Deal, the specific amount of $70,000 in the first year alone is neither substantively supported nor completely discounted by available data.

It is worth noting though that the source of this claim is the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a group known for being skeptical of regulatory plans such as the Green New Deal due to its dedication to principles of limited government, free enterprise, and individual liberty [20].
Therefore, the tone and implications of the study may be colored by these underpinnings.

0d95a596dc3c3c5be975b2926ce9ee67.claim: " Del. Debra Rodman ""opposes adoption as an alternative to abortion in event of unplanned pregnancies."""
0d95a596dc3c3c5be975b2926ce9ee67.label: false
0d95a596dc3c3c5be975b2926ce9ee67.passage:
0: State Sen. Siobhan Dunnavant, R- Henrico is denouncing her challenger, Democrat Debra Rodman, as a "liberal activist" who has shown a "lack of judgement" during her two years in the House of Delegates.
1: Dunnavant made the charges in a Sept. 30 mailer that criticizes Rodman on six issues.
2: One particularly caught our attention.
3: She said Rodman "opposes adoption as an alternative to abortion in unplanned pregnancies."
4: We fact-checked her statement.
5: Dunnavant’s mailer cites an unsuccessful 2018 bill Rodman co-sponsored that would have changed state mandates for family life education in public schools.
6: It would have abolished what many Democrats said were biased standards calling for "teaching the social, psychological and health gains to be realized by teenagers’ abstaining from sexual activity before marriage."
7: The bill also would have removed the requirement to teach "the benefits of adoption as a positive choice in the event of an unwanted pregnancy."
8: In place of the mandates was a requirement that students get teaching "that is medically accurate."
9: The bill died in a partisan 12-10 vote in the House Education Committee on Feb. 5, 2018.
10: Rodman voted in the minority with Democrats for the measure.
11: Marshall Moreau, Dunnavant’s campaign manager, says Rodman’s support of the bill justifies the mailer claim.
12: "The only inference to be drawn is that Rodman is opposed to adoption as an alternative to abortion in the event of unplanned pregnancies," he wrote in an email.
13: Dunnavant saidin the email, "For Delegate Rodman to say she doesn't oppose adoption but doesn’t want to teach about it, is like saying ‘I want you to get out of the burning building but I’m not going to tell you where the fire escape is.’" The bill Rodman backed was silent about adoption.
14: Rodman and other Democrats say the bill wouldn’t have barred instruction about adoption; it would have required that if taught, it be in a neutral, factual way when discussing pregnancy, Rodman says her position has been contorted by Dunnavant.
15: "I believe in a woman’s right to choose," Rodman said in an email.
16: "Adoption is a wonderful choice women can and should make if it’s right for them.
17: Politicians should not interfere in this personal choice."

gpt4: The claim that Del. Debra Rodman opposes adoption as an alternative to abortion in the event of unplanned pregnancies is false.
What sparked this misinformation was Dunnavant's mailer referencing a 2018 bill that Rodman co-sponsored.
The bill aimed to alter state mandates for family life education in public schools, but it did not passed [5].
It's noteworthy that the bill did not prohibit teaching about adoption, rather it proposed that if adoption were taught, it should be done in a neutral, factual manner when discussing pregnancy [14].
Additionally, the said bill sought to eliminate the requirement to teach "the benefits of adoption as a positive choice in the event of an unwanted pregnancy"[7].
This doesn't mean though that Rodman opposes adoption.
Adoption, as a matter of fact, is perceived as a wonderful choice women can and should make if it’s right for them [16].
Interpreting the bill as Rodman's opposition to adoption is a distortion of her stance [14].

c9eefbcf598e7b64bcdce9bc831255e2.claim: " Minneapolis ""city government preemptively informed the Target Center that it would be responsible for $530,000 in security and other costs"" related to a Trump rally, ""more than 26 times the estimated security costs for a 2009 Target Center health care rally held by President Barack Obama."""
c9eefbcf598e7b64bcdce9bc831255e2.label: true
c9eefbcf598e7b64bcdce9bc831255e2.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s campaign has threatened to sue the city of Minneapolis over the security costs related to a campaign rally.
1: The Trump campaign said in a statement to the press three days before the rally that the mayor of Minneapolis, Democrat Jacob Frey, had conjured a "phony and outlandish bill for security" for the Oct. 10 Target Center rally.
2: "Frey’s city government preemptively informed the Target Center that it would be responsible for $530,000 in security and other costs related to the event," the campaign wrote.
3: "The Target Center attempted to pass the costs on to the Trump campaign under threat of withholding the use of the arena."
4: The statement said that the $530,000 is more than 26 times the estimated security costs for a 2009 health care rally held by President Barack Obama at the Target Center.
5: Minnesota has voted for Democrats for president for decades , but Trump has his eye on it because he narrowly lost to Hillary Clinton by about 1.5 percentage points.
6: Minneapolis is a liberal bastion in a blue state.
7: Trump tweeted a response targeting Frey and U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar , a Minneapolis Democrat whom he has attacked before .
8: "The lightweight mayor is hurting the great police and other wonderful supporters.
9: 72,000 ticket requests already.
10: Dump Frey and Omar!
11: Make America Great Again!"
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Frey responded on Twitter : "Yawn...
13: Welcome to Minneapolis where we pay our bills, we govern with integrity, and we love all of our neighbors."
14: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com PolitiFact reached out to multiple city and police department officials as well as the Target Center and its manager, AEG Facilities, and did not receive any responses to our questions.
15: However, we did obtain a letter from AEG that cited an estimated $530,000 cost.
16: Target Center cited a $530,000 cost Hugh Lombardi, AEG Facilities’ general manager, sent a letter to the Trump campaign’s director of advance, Bobby Peede, on Oct. 7.
17: The letter states: "The City of Minneapolis has presented a preliminary estimate of additional security and related costs associated with the October 10, 2019 Event at Target Center.
18: These estimated additional expenses total $530,000."
19: The letter states it is the licensee’s responsibility "to coordinate through the Secret Service and pay for any law enforcement services necessary for the event."
20: The letter states that if these arrangements are not confirmed by 8 a.m. Oct. 8, then the agreement will be terminated "for breach of the Event Security provision."
21: The campaign wrote in a letter to AEG that the campaign and AEG are not required to pay for security and threatened to sue.
22: (We have not seen a copy of the agreement.)
23: Casper Hill, a city spokesman, told PolitiFact that the public safety costs are expected to be around $400,000 and there are an additional $130,000 costs for lane closure fees and traffic control, among other things.
24: The city examined the costs for other major recent events to determine the costs, including the Super Bowl in 2018, which was roughly $6 million, and $1.5 million for the Final Four men’s college basketball tournament earlier this year.
25: Minneapolis City Attorney Susan Segal told the Star Tribune that "it’s not fair" for residents to shoulder the costs.
26: Segal told the Star Tribune that the city has been having conversations with organizations including the Twins, the Vikings and the Minnesota Ballpark Authority about sharing costs of events.
27: Those discussions started before the Super Bowl in 2018, she said.
28: Minneapolis’ estimate, however, appears far higher than what it cost other cities to host Trump rallies.
29: The Star Tribune reported that Trump’s rally in Rochester in 2018 cost the city government $76,138 while a rally in Duluth cost the city more than $69,000.
30: A national investigation by the Center for Public Integrity found that among local governments that invoiced the Trump campaign, the amounts ranged between $8,000 to $82,000 for public safety costs related to rallies.
31: The highest bill was from the city of El Paso for about $470,000.
32: On the day of the 2009 Obama rally, the Minneapolis police chief estimated the department’s costs to top $20,000 including for 50 officers on overtime at the 20,500-seat Target Center arena, the St. Paul Pioneer Press reported.
33: We tried to confirm if that was the actual cost with police officials but did not get a response.
34: It isn’t unusual for local law enforcement agencies to be asked to swallow security costs, and Trump’s is not the only campaign to do so.
35: The Center for Public Integrity found that Obama’s campaign didn’t always pay for security.
36: Some 2020 Democratic presidential candidates didn't respond to the Center when asked about security bills while others said they will pay or had paid certain bills.
37: No FEC requirement for candidates to pay security There is no specific requirement within the provisions of the Federal Election Campaign Act or Federal Election Commission regulations for congressional or presidential campaign committees to pay for expenses incurred by a state or local government for campaign events, said Myles Martin, an FEC spokesman.
38: That means that campaigns can choose to reimburse governments for security costs, but they are not required.
39: A Secret Service spokesman told PolitiFact that it is not funded to pay police overtime and doesn’t have a mechanism to do so.
40: "This is a blank spot in campaign finance laws and campaigns often take advantage of it, as the Trump campaign is in Minneapolis this week," said Carleton College political science professor Steven Schier.
41: "It's a low priority for Congress because it does not affect legislators' campaigns in a significant way."
42: There is, however, a mechanism for local law enforcement to seek reimbursement for protecting Trump’s residences in Florida, New York and New Jersey .

gpt4: In 2009, during an Obama rally held at the Target Center, the Minneapolis police chief estimated that the department’s costs would peak at approximately $20,000, including expenses for 50 officers on overtime[32].
In contrast, in 2019, ahead of a Trump rally at the same venue, the city government directed the Target Center to shoulder a hefty sum of $530,000 for security and other associated costs[2].
This figure, which was confirmed in a letter from AEG[15], represents a 26-fold increase in security costs compared to the 2009 Obama rally.
The Trump campaign claimed that the mayor of Minneapolis, Jacob Frey, had contrived this "phony and outlandish bill"[1].
The Target Center also tried to transfer these costs to the Trump campaign, threatening to disallow the use of the arena if it refused to pay[3].

The city’s spokesperson, Casper Hill, informed PolitiFact that such costs were anticipated to amount to around $400,000 for public safety, with another $130,000 accounting for expenses related to lane closure, traffic control, and other items [23].

In computing these costs, officials had reviewed the expenditures for other major events in the city, such as the 2018 Super Bowl that cost roughly $6 million and the Final Four men’s college basketball tournament from earlier in the year that had cost around $1.5 million[24].

725f7f5ce5f9481b66c6fdd6f59b868f.claim: "  Joe Biden ""said he never spoke to the Ukrainian company, and then the picture came out where he was playing golf with the company boss and Hunter"" Biden."
725f7f5ce5f9481b66c6fdd6f59b868f.label: false
725f7f5ce5f9481b66c6fdd6f59b868f.passage:
0: President Donald Trump is doubling down on a photo he says shows Joe Biden and his son posing with a Ukrainian gas executive as evidence Biden knows more than he has let on.
1: "The Biden family was PAID OFF, pure and simple!
2: The fake news must stop making excuses for something that is totally inexcusable," he tweeted .
3: "Sleepy Joe said he never spoke to the Ukrainian company, and then the picture came out where he was playing golf with the company boss and Hunter."
4: The photo, which was first aired by Fox News on Sept. 30, shows Joe and Hunter Biden playing golf in the Hamptons in 2014.
5: According to Trump, one of the men is the "company boss" of Burisma, the energy company where Hunter served as a board member while his father was vice president.
6: Trump tweeted a doctored Nickelback music video Oct. 2 that includes the image juxtaposed with an interview in which Joe Biden says he had never talked to his son about his business dealings abroad.
7: That video was quickly removed from both Twitter and YouTube due to a potential copyright infringement for the Nickelback music.
8: But now Trump is re-upping the claim amid an ongoing impeachment inquiry against him for his own dealings with Ukraine.
9: We reached out to the White House for more information about the source of Trump’s claim, but they did not comment on the record.
10: Trump’s tweet is misleading on two fronts.
11: • The photo shows the Bidens with another American board member of Burisma.
12: • Biden hasn’t said whether or not he’s spoken with Burisma officials.
13: Who’s really in the photo Trump claimed that the photo of the Bidens shows them posing "with the company boss" of Burisma.
14: Our research shows otherwise.
15: In a previous story , we found that the man on the far left of the frame is Devon Archer.
16: In 2008, Hunter Biden joined with Archer — a former senior adviser for the presidential campaign of John Kerry in 2004 — in a string of investment and consulting firms.
17: The Wall Street Journal reported in May 2014 that the two had joined Burisma as board members.
18: That role is different from "boss" or "executive," as Trump has claimed in separate tweets about the photo of Archer.
19: Board members are not typically involved in day-to-day operations of a company.
20: While Joe Biden was vice president, firms run by his son and Archer "pursued business with international entities that had a stake in American foreign policy decisions, sometimes in countries where connections implied political influence and protection," the New York Times reported in May.
21: The fourth man in the photo that Trump tweeted is Ralph Pascucci, founder of Netrex Capital Markets LLC, a New York investment banking firm.
22: He is also a principal of Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y., where the Bidens spent a week in August 2014.
23: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshots from Twitter and Netrex) We reached out to Joe Biden’s presidential campaign for more details, but they did not comment on the record.
24: Taras Burdeinyi is the current CEO of Burisma and Mykola Zlochevsky is the founder and owner.
25: In 2014, Alan Apter was the chairman of the board of directors and reportedly brought on Biden and Archer.
26: What Biden said In his tweet, Trump claimed that Joe Biden said he "never spoke to the Ukrainian company" where his son served as a paid board member.
27: But that mischaracterizes what the Democratic presidential candidate actually said.
28: In his Nickelback video, Trump showed a clip of Biden saying he had "never spoken to my son about his overseas business dealings," contrasting that with the photograph of the golf group.
29: That’s different than claiming he had never spoken to Burisma.
30: RELATED STORY: Trump’s Ukraine call, a whistleblower and the Bidens: What we know, what we don’t Biden knew his son worked for the Ukrainian energy company.
31: Beyond that, there’s little we know.
32: Hunter Biden told the New Yorker magazine in July 2019 that he discussed Burisma with his father one time in December 2015.
33: The Biden campaign says the discussion was not substantive.

gpt4: The claim that Joe Biden stated he had "never spoken to the Ukrainian company" and the subsequent release of a photograph showing him play golf with the company boss and his son, Hunter, is not entirely accurate.
Our research has shown that Joe Biden's actual statement was that he had "never spoken to [his] son about his overseas business dealings" [26].
This is a different claim from what President Trump suggested in his tweet [10].
Additionally, the photograph displayed in Trump's tweet did not show Joe Biden with the "boss" of the Ukrainian company.
In reality, the individual being referred to is Devon Archer, who acted as business partners with Hunter Biden in a myriad of investment and consulting firms [16].
Archer's role within these firms was different from that of an executive or boss, as trump had falsely claimed in separate tweets [18].
Therefore, the assertion that Joe Biden was golfing with the Ukrainian company's boss is misleading [14].

03b95ef5a70f8fc7968ee0a39b0a2890.claim: " Del. Danica Roem ""supported a controversial bill that would have allowed abortion up until the moment of birth."
03b95ef5a70f8fc7968ee0a39b0a2890.label: false
03b95ef5a70f8fc7968ee0a39b0a2890.passage:
0: Republican challenger Kelly McGinn is sending mailers saying Del.
1: Danica Roem, D-Prince William, backed controversial legislation early this year that would have eased Virginia’s abortion laws.
2: "Diane Roem supported a controversial bill that would have allowed abortion up until the moment of birth," the mailer says.
3: Roem says the claim is untrue, so we fact-checked it.
4: McGinn cites as evidence an unsuccessful bill introduced in January 2019 by Del.
5: Kathy Tran, D-Fairfax.
6: It would have removed a requirement that women undergo an ultrasound and be presented with materials on fetal development and adoption before an abortion.
7: It would have eliminated a mandate that second-term abortions be performed in hospitals.
8: Most of the debate, however, focused on the bill’s provisions for rare third-trimester abortions, which are allowed if three physicians certify that a continued pregnancy would "likely" kill a woman or "substantially and irremediably" impair her mental or physical health.
9: The legislation would have lowered the threshold from three physicians to one.
10: That doctor would only have to certify that the pregnancy would damage a woman’s health.
11: The "substantial and irremediable" test would have been repealed.
12: Tran, under tough questioning by Republicans during a Jan. 29 hearing, acknowledged that her bill would allow an abortion when a mother is dilating.
13: Many Republicans claim the bill shows that Democrats - as McGinn says - support "abortion to the time of birth."
14: But Roem, as first reported by the Prince William Times , has no direct connection to the bill.
15: She was not among 21 Democratic cosponsors of the legislation and she was not a member of a House subcommittee that killed the measure on a partisan 5-3 vote.
16: Roem never voted on the bill.
17: We found no record of her endorsing the bill.
18: Roem says that’s because she never did.
19: Why does McGinn say she supported it?
20: Zac Obermiller, McGinn’s campaign manager, told us the campaign made what it thinks is a safe assumption.
21: "The McGinn campaign has simply taken Del.
22: Roem at her word regarding her heretofore unqualified and full-throated support for abortion rights throughout all nine months," he wrote in an email.
23: Obermiller noted that Roem is among 40 legislators endorsed in August by Planned Parenthood Advocates of Virginia for having "a 100% voting record in support of sexual and reproductive health and rights."
24: He also noted that Roem has received $12,000 in campaign contributions since 2017 from Emily’s List, a pro-abortion rights PAC, according to records of the Virginia Public Access Project.
25: But Roem told us told us she would have voted against Tran’s bill if she’d had a chance because, when she went back to her district after the measure died, voters told her they disliked the legislation.
26: "That’s what you do as a legislator; you represent your constituents," she said.
27: Obermiller said Roem is being disingenuous.
28: "The bottom line is that Delegate Roem wants to have her cake and eat it too," he said.

gpt4: The claim that Delegate Danica Roem supported a controversial bill allowing for abortion up until the moment of birth is false.
First and foremost, Roem had no direct involvement with the bill, as reported by the Prince William Times [14].
Moreover, she was neither among the 21 democratic cosponsors nor a member of the House subcommittee that eventually resulted in the bill's failure on a 5-3 vote [15].
Roem never cast a vote on the bill [16], and there's no record of her endorsing it [17].
In fact, Roem confided that she would have voted against it had she been given the chance, as she acknowledged the bill was unpopular among her constituents [25].

e0f61c67fcff382bc34eb4237fc30412.claim: The first so-called second hand information ‘Whistleblower’ got my phone conversation almost completely wrong.
e0f61c67fcff382bc34eb4237fc30412.label: false
e0f61c67fcff382bc34eb4237fc30412.passage:
0: When President Donald Trump heard that a second whistleblower was in the wings, he quickly dismissed the news.
1: "The first so-called second hand information ‘Whistleblower’ got my phone conversation almost completely wrong, so now word is they are going to the bench and another ‘Whistleblower’ is coming in from the Deep State, also with second hand info," Trump tweeted Oct. 5 .
2: "Meet with Shifty.
3: Keep them coming!"
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We compared the whistleblower complaint with the White House memorandum of the July 25 call between Trump and Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky.
5: What we found is Trump’s wrong: The whistleblower got just about everything right.
6: Here are the excerpts from the whistleblower’s filing (in bold), followed by whether the information is confirmed.
7: Early in the morning of 25 July, the President spoke by telephone with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
8: — Confirmed by the memorandum of the call .
9: After an initial exchange of pleasantries, the President used the remainder of the call to advance his personal interests.
10: — Setting aside the characterization of the purpose as "personal interests," the allocation of the number of words between pleasantries and a request for help with investigations accurately reflects the memorandum.
11: The complaint then describes what Trump wanted Ukraine to do.
12: Initiate or continue an investigation into the activities of former Vice President Joseph Biden and his son, Hunter Biden.
13: — Confirmed, according to the memorandum that quotes Trump as saying the following: "The other thing.
14: There’s a lot of talk about Biden’s son, that Biden stopped the prosecution and a lot of people want to find out about that so whatever you can do with the Attorney General would be great.
15: Biden went around bragging that he stopped the prosecution so if you can look into it...
16: It sounds horrible to me."
17: Assist in purportedly uncovering that allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election originated in Ukraine, with a specific request that The Ukrainian leader locate and turn over servers used by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and examined by the U.S. cyber security firm Crowdstrike.
18: — Confirmed, according to the memorandum .
19: Trump is quoted as saying: "I would like you to do us a favor though because our country has been through a lot and Ukraine knows a lot about it.
20: I would like you to find out what happened with this whole situation with Ukraine, they say Crowdstrike...
21: I guess you have one of your wealthy people...
22: The server, they say Ukraine has it.
23: There are a lot of things that went on, the whole situation.
24: I think you’re surrounding yourself with some of the same people.
25: I would like to have the Attorney General call you or your people and I would like you to get to the bottom of it.
26: "As you saw yesterday, that whole nonsense ended with a very poor performance by a man named Robert Mueller, an incompetent performance, but they say a lot of it started with Ukraine.
27: Whatever you can do, it’s very important that you do it if that’s possible."
28: Meet or speak with two people the President named explicitly as his personal envoys on these matters, Mr. Giuliani and Attorney General Barr, to whom the President referred multiple times in tandem.
29: — Confirmed, according to the memorandum : Zelensky is the first to bring up Giuliani’s name.
30: As for what Trump said, he did mention both men several times and in tandem.
31: Trump: "Mr. Giuliani is a highly respected man.
32: He was the mayor of New York City, a great mayor, and I would like him to call you.
33: I will ask him to call you along with the Attorney General.
34: Rudy very much knows what’s happening and he is a very capable guy.
35: If you could speak to him that would be great."
36: Trump: "I would like to have the Attorney General call you or your people."
37: Trump: "I will have Mr. Giuliani give you a call and I am also going to have Attorney General Barr call and we will get to the bottom of it."
38: The President also praised Ukraine’s Prosecutor General, Mr. Yuriy Lutsenko, and suggested that Mr. Zelenskyy might want to keep him in his position.
39: — This is ambiguous.
40: Trump made no reference to Lutsenko by name.
41: What he said was, "I heard you had a prosecutor who was very good and he was shut down and that’s really unfair.
42: A lot of people are talking about that, the way they shut your very good prosecutor down and you had some very bad people involved."
43: Trump might have been thinking of the previous prosecutor general Viktor Shokin; that would fit more with a prosecutor who had been "shut down."
44: The current prosecutor at the time, however, was Lutsenko.
45: From the memorandum, which indicates that certain sections were left out and doesn’t name the prosecutor, we can’t tell for sure.
46: I was told by White House officials that no other (corruption) "cases" were discussed.
47: — The memorandum shows that only the DNC server and the Bidens came up.
48: I was told that a State Department official, Mr. T. Ulrich Brechbuhl, also listened in on the call.
49: — Unconfirmed.
50: One news report based on an unnamed source said Brechbuhl wasn’t on the call.
51: We reached out to the White House and did not hear back.

gpt4: Contrary to the claim, the whistleblower’s account of the phone conversation between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was largely corroborated, not contradicted.
This was determined after comparing the whistleblower complaint with the White House memorandum of the said call[4].

Several key details pointed out by the whistleblower were confirmed by the memorandum, such as the subject of discussion concerning the DNC server and the Bidens [47], as well as the proportional distribution of words between pleasantries and a request for help with investigations[10], effectively contradicting the assertion that the conversation was inaccurately reported.
Further examination of the whistleblower's filing in comparison to the contents of the memorandum confirms the same[13][18][29].
Thus, it is inaccurate to claim that the whistleblower got the phone conversation 'almost completely wrong'.

dc4da834652b40291343a98cd246bee0.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi’s ""legislative aide … is from the Ukraine and is connected to the Ukrainian Embassy, the Ukrainian military, the Ukrainian government and Ukrainian party life"""
dc4da834652b40291343a98cd246bee0.label: false
dc4da834652b40291343a98cd246bee0.passage:
0: After House Democrats moved forward with an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump over a phone call with Ukraine’s president, a photo of a woman shaking hands with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi circulated as supposed evidence of Pelosi’s own connections with Ukraine elite.
1: In reality, the rumor is an attempt to smear Pelosi using an American college student only because she was an intern of Pelosi's for a semester and is of Ukrainian descent.
2: The photo, shared here Oct. 1 , has appeared all over social media with text around it that says: "Nancy Pelosi’s legislative aide, Ivanna Voronovych, is from the Ukraine and is connected to the Ukrainian Embassy, the Ukrainian military, the Ukrainian government and Ukrainian party life … How did this Ukrainian get cleared to work in the office of the person third in line to the U.S.
3: presidency?"
4: Another image laid over the photo in the upper left hand corner shows a man and a woman along with more text that says, "Patriarch Filaret Head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church" and "Mom’s Ukraine Order of Merit for Military & Political Activity."
5: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: This claim is inaccurate.
8: PolitiFact found that Ivanna Voronovych did serve as an intern in Pelosi’s district-focused office in Washington, D.C., for a college semester, but did not (and does not currently) work for Pelosi as an aide, nor does she hold any other position in Pelosi’s office.
9: (Also, the Speaker of the House is second in line to the presidency not the third, as the post states.)
10: The rumor appears to have originated with a Sept. 30, 2019, story by right-leaning website the Gateway Pundit.
11: That story says Voronovych "started her career working at the US Embassy in the Ukraine in Kiev" and that "she worked for Roman Woronowycz, the Kiev Bureau Chief, who is connected to Nancy Pelosi."
12: It goes on to claim that, "Voronovych’s parents are well connected.
13: Her mom worked with the Ukrainian Army, and even received the Ukraine Order of Merit for military and political activity.
14: Yoronovych’s [sic] father worked in the Ukrainian Foreign Service and he’s also connected to the Ukrainian government."
15: Something to note: Roman Woronowycz is Voronovych’s father and is not listed as the bureau chief for the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine, though he does work at the U.S. Agency for International Development in Kiev, according to an agency spokesperson.
16: PolitiFact reached out to Voronovych about the rumors.
17: She responded by email, explaining that she is a U.S. citizen and has lived in Ukraine as well as other countries due to her father’s employment with USAID.
18: She said that she interned for Pelosi in the spring of 2018 while a sophomore at Northeastern University in Boston and when Pelosi was the House minority leader.
19: Voronovych said her father is a Michigan native and is not chief of the Kiev bureau of the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine, as the post states.
20: Voronovych is now a senior at the University of Michigan, where, as a transfer student, she is studying political science and philosophy.
21: "Since finishing my internship I have not had any contact with the Speaker, as I imagine she is occupied with more important things than keeping tabs on her previous interns," Voronovych said.
22: She said she has spent the last five years working as a summer hire at the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine but never worked with the Ukraininan Embassy in the United States or elsewhere.
23: "I have no ties to the Ukrainian government or military outside of the work that I did while employed with the State Department."
24: Ivanna Voronovych’s mother, Viktoria Voronovych, is a Ukrainian-born American citizen and co-founder of the nonprofit International Alliance for Fraternal Assistance, which has helped raise money to deliver medical supplies, gear, equipment and other items to Ukrainian soldiers who were fighting against Russia-backed rebels, according to an interview she gave in 2015 to the Macomb Daily, a newspaper in Detroit.
25: The photo in the upper-left corner of the viral Facebook post shows Viktoria Voronovych receiving a medal from the patriarch of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church for her conflict zone volunteer work, according to Ivanna Voronovych, who also sent PolitiFact an image of the medal, which indicates it was presented in 2015.
26: Ivanna Voronovych said that the organization, which appears to be based in Kiev , raised money from other Ukrainians now living in the United States, most notably Michigan, Illinois and North Carolina.
27: These days, Ivanna Voronovych said, her mother’s work involves supporting people with disabilities sustained either at birth or by way of involvement in the conflict.
28: "This story is a hoax and an outlandish compilation of twisted lies," Voronovych said.
29: "I have received disturbing messages from people that choose to believe this disinformation, making me feel unsafe and as a possible target.
30: The comments under some of the Facebook posts alone are enough to make one worry.
31: I am a private citizen and should not be subject to such an invasion of privacy, libel and defamation of my character."
32: On Oct. 3, Woronowycz also posted a response to the rumors surrounding his daughter on his Facebook page , saying she is an American citizen who interned with Pelosi while also working at the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine during summers.
33: He wrote that the rumors have even resulted in death threats: "My daughter, Ivanna Voronovych, was hit hard two days ago by bots with stories that contain outright lies and twisted facts.
34: She is an American citizen, an honors student and a social activist who also interned with Speaker Pelosi, while also working at the US Embassy in Ukraine during summers.
35: She has no connections to the Ukrainian military or the Ukrainian Embassy.
36: Dozens of pieces by fly-by-night sites are sharing these gross and dangerous lies.
37: The results have been death threats and lurid comments made by obviously deranged, heartless, soul less, and morally empty a*******.
38: No one deserves this."
39: Drew Hammill, Pelosi’s deputy chief of staff, confirmed to PolitiFact that Voronovych was an intern in Pelosi’s personal office in Washington, which works solely on representational issues for Pelosi’s congressional district, the 12th District of California.
40: "This individual was an intern in our personal office (meaning CA-12 not leadership office).
41: She was an unpaid intern in the spring of 2018 who answered phones and performed other administrative duties," Hammill wrote in an email.
42: "The Speaker takes a photo with every intern during their time in Washington."
43: On May 31, 2018, in that same time period, Voronovych posted the photo of herself shaking hands with with Pelosi on her own Facebook page.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi's legislative aide is from Ukraine and has connections with the Ukrainian Embassy, military, government, and politics is false.

In reality, Ivanna Voronovych, the person referred to in the claim, was an intern in Pelosi's district-focused office in Washington D.C. for a college semester but did not, and does not currently, work for Pelosi as an aide nor does she hold any other position in Pelosi's office [8].
She undertook this internship in the spring of 2018 while studying at Northeastern University and during Pelosi's term as the House minority leader [18].
Voronovych states that following her internship, she had no further contact with Pelosi [21].
The allegation also wrongly suggests that Voronovych has connections with the Ukrainian military and embassy.
She confirmed that she has spent the last five years working as a summer hire at the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine but never worked with the Ukrainian Embassy in the United States or elsewhere [22].
Additionally, she has no connections to the Ukrainian military [35].
The rumor is nothing more than an attempt to smear Pelosi using an American college student simply because she interned for Pelosi and is of Ukrainian descent [1].

d9c18ea20cfbeeb5784ae4ad705d0516.claim: Meth production in MO has cratered over last decade. MO Hwy Patrol reported 1,326 meth lab seizures in 2006, only 50 in 2018.
d9c18ea20cfbeeb5784ae4ad705d0516.label: true
d9c18ea20cfbeeb5784ae4ad705d0516.passage:
0: In a recent Twitter conversation, Sen. Josh Hawley was accused of scapegoating Mexico for Missouri’s meth problem.
1: "Don’t blame Mexico for what is produced in our own state under your watch," the tweeter, identified as Conrad Hake, wrote.
2: Hake was responding to Hawley’s demand that Democratic presidential hopefuls should declare whether there’s a security threat at the border.
3: Hawley responded: "Wrong.
4: Meth production in MO has cratered over last decade.
5: MO Hwy Patrol reported 1,326 meth lab seizures in 2006, only 50 in 2018.
6: But meth addiction & overdoses are skyrocketing.
7: DEA’s 2018 Threat Assessment Report says most of meth in U.S. made in Mexico & smuggled over border."
8: That would be a huge decrease, and the DEA report does say meth in the United States is made in Mexico and transported into the United States, so we decided to do some digging on the numbers of meth production.
9: Missouri State Highway Patrol’s report holds up The numbers are correct, according to a Missouri State Highway Patrol report.
10: Incidents in Missouri for methamphetamine chemical/equipment/glassware seizures, laboratories and dumpsites was 1,326 in 2006.
11: The most incidents were in St. Charles, at 125 in the same year.
12: In 2018, Missouri had 50 methamphetamine incidents, the report said.
13: "The key factor for the decrease in methamphetamine laboratories is the transportation of crystal methamphetamine into the state," said Sgt.
14: Shawn Griggs, Missouri State Highway Patrol spokesman.
15: Missouri production is down, but consumption of meth is still here.
16: Methamphetamine is still being used Hawley cited the 2018 National Drug Threat Assessment released by the DEA.
17: It reports that most methamphetamine in the United States is being produced in Mexico.
18: In 2006, federal and state laws restricted the sale of an over-the-counter cold medicine, pseudoephedrine, that was essential to home-cooked meth.
19: Griggs said 75 communities in the state have created prescription-only ordinances for pseudoephedrine products.
20: In 2017, Missouri joined an electronic system that tracks and limits the sale of over-the-counter cold and allergy medications containing pseudoephedrine, ephedrine or phenylpropanolamine.
21: As pseudoephedrine became harder to get in Missouri, production shifted to Mexico, which now manufactures more meth than the United States.
22: Chris Twitchel, a captain in the Camden County Sheriff’s Department and an adjunct professor of criminology and sociology at Columbia College, said nine years ago a big drug bust would be getting a few ounces.
23: In the middle of September, the drug task force in Camden County got 2 pounds from a guy.
24: "I think it’s less risk to buy it from a source than try to make it on your own," Twitchel said.
25: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Missouri’s drug-related deaths increased 18.1% from February 2018 to February 2019.
26: Delaware is the only state with a higher increase at 18.6%.
27: Meanwhile, nationally the amount of drug-related deaths decreased 3.9%.
28: According to data from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, from 2012 to 2016 people seeking treatment for meth addiction in Missouri increased 52%.

gpt4: The claim that meth production in Missouri has significantly decreased over the last decade is indeed true.
This conclusion is substantiated by a report from the Missouri State Highway Patrol, which showed a drastic reduction in meth lab seizures, from 1,326 in 2006 down to 50 in 2018[5][9].
This data highlights the substantial decline in methamphetamine incidents in the state[12].

c528f5e53e029fee09e6d1c0fb03078a.claim: "  Republican Dan Bishop was ""down by 17"" points in NC congressional race and then won ""by a lot."""
c528f5e53e029fee09e6d1c0fb03078a.label: false
c528f5e53e029fee09e6d1c0fb03078a.passage:
0: President Donald Trump recently cast himself as the hero in a story about a congressional race in North Carolina, according to a speech recently obtained by Bloomberg News.
1: The congressional race was in North Carolina’s 9th district, where Republican Dan Bishop defeated Democrat Dan McCready in a special election on Sept. 10.
2: Trump’s comments came during a private event in New York on Sept. 27.
3: Trump told the crowd that Bishop was behind in the race until he visited North Carolina and tweeted about the race.
4: "But the candidate, Dan Bishop, won — by a lot.
5: He was down by 17, and they had lines a mile long.
6: I mean the lines going into those voting booths were unbelievable," Trump said, according to Bloomberg’s transcript of the speech .
7: This is at least the second time Trump has claimed that Bishop was down 17 points.
8: The first came on the night of the election.
9: "Dan Bishop was down 17 points 3 weeks ago.
10: He then asked me for help, we changed his strategy together, and he ran a great race.
11: Big Rally last night.
12: Now it looks like he is going to win," he tweeted .
13: PolitiFact looked at publicly available polling, as well as the race results, to see whether Trump was correct about its competitiveness.
14: We couldn’t find any public poll that showed Bishop behind by 17 points, or even double-digits.
15: And we found his description of the election results to be exaggerated.
16: WHAT POLLS REPORTED The website FiveThirtyEight tracked some of the polling of the district .
17: No public poll had McCready up by 17.
18: The most favorable poll for him had him up five points, and the poll most favorable to Bishop had him up four points.
19: A Co/Efficient poll published three days before the election had McCready up three points.
20: Public Policy Polling, known as PPP , conducted a private poll of District 9 residents about two weeks prior to the election.
21: That poll showed Bishop up, said Tom Jensen, the company’s director.
22: Vox, an online news source, conducted a similar fact-check and couldn’t find a poll to support Trump’s claims, either.
23: The piece of polling that comes close to supporting Trump’s claim was tweeted by Jim Blaine, a campaign consultant for Bishop.
24: An internal campaign poll showed McCready up 14 percentage points on Bishop.
25: But that poll is an outlier.
26: And details — such as who conducted the survey, who responded to the survey, the date — aren’t available to the public.
27: PolitiFact contacted Blaine and Samantha Cotten, a regional communications director for Trump’s campaign, but didn’t receive a response by the time this fact check was published online.
28: THE RESULTS Most experts considered the race a toss-up , a surprise given the district’s history.
29: "While we’ve thought the Republicans were better positioned to win the NC-9 do-over special election — and that may end up being the case — the latest data, and the latest circumstances, suggest that the race is close enough that we should make it a Toss-up with less than a week to go until Tuesday’s election," Kyle Kondik, managing editor of Sabato’s Crystal Ball, wrote on Sept. 5 .
30: Trump won the district by 12 points in 2016.
31: No Democrat had won the congressional race since 1963, according to the Charlotte Observer .
32: It didn’t happen this year either.
33: Bishop beat McCready by 3,788 votes — 96,573 to 92,785.
34: That breaks down to 50.69% of the vote for Bishop and 48.70% of the vote for McCready, a difference of 1.99 percentage points.
35: Not exactly a blowout.

gpt4: The claim that Republican Dan Bishop was "down by 17" points in the North Carolina congressional race and then won "by a lot" is false.
PolitiFact checked the publicly available polling data, along with the race results, and found no evidence to support this assertion[13].
None of the uncovered public polls showed Bishop lagging by 17 points, or even by double digits[14].
The most favorable poll for Bishop had him leading by four points, while the poll most favorable to his opponent showed Bishop ahead by a mere five points[18].
This fact-checking process was corroborated by Vox, an online news source, which was unable to identify a poll supporting the claim in question[22].
It should be noted that this result doesn't entirely rule out the existence of a poll depicting a larger gap, but any such poll would be an outlier[25].
In actuality, the final vote saw Bishop secure 50.69% of the vote compared to his opponent McCready's 48.70%, translating to a modest winning margin of 1.99 percentage points[34].

617ee43646d2e313d79ef2c297f97293.claim: "  the sons of Nancy Pelosi, Mitt Romney and John Kerry are all on the boards of ""energy companies doing business in Ukraine."""
617ee43646d2e313d79ef2c297f97293.label: false
617ee43646d2e313d79ef2c297f97293.passage:
0: Hunter Biden isn’t the only politician's child who’s been scrutinized in the past few weeks for his work overseas.
1: On Facebook, several widely shared posts claim the sons of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., and Mitt Romney, R-Utah, are also on the boards of energy companies linked to Ukraine.
2: Other posts add former Secretary of State John Kerry to the mix.
3: "Biden’s son, Pelosi’s son, Romney’s son (are) all on the board of director (sic) for energy companies doing business in Ukraine," one post reads.
4: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: And they’ve collectively reached thousands of users, so we wanted to check them out.
7: The source material of the posts appears to be a viral tweet published Oct. 6 by Jack Murphy, co-founder of conservative news site TrendingPolitics.com.
8: "Biden's son, Pelosi's son, Romney's son, Kerry’s son," he tweeted.
9: "All are on the board of directors for energy companies doing business in Ukraine… Coincidence?
10: No."
11: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) We reached out to Murphy for the source of his post, but we haven’t heard back.
12: Several conservative publications had reported on the allegations about Pelosi’s son, Paul, days before Murphy made that assertion.
13: We looked into the business dealings of Pelosi, Romney and Kerry’s sons.
14: Claims about Pelosi’s son are misleading Paul Pelosi Jr. once served on the board of an American energy company, Viscoil, that dissolved and re-formed in Singapore under a different name.
15: But Paul Pelosi had no part in the new entity, and it’s unclear to what extent the company has done business in Ukraine.
16: Reports of the connection appeared in One America News Network and other conservative outlets, the source of which appears to be an Oct. 3 tweet from Patrick Howley, a writer for The Epoch Times.
17: The pro-Donald Trump website has been known to publish conspiratorial content.
18: "BOOM: Nancy Pelosi's son Paul Pelosi Jr. (who went to Ukraine in 2017) was a board member of Viscoil and executive at its related company NRGLab, which DID ENERGY Business in UKRAINE!"
19: Howley said in the tweet, which has been retweeted more than 12,000 times.
20: "And Nancy Pelosi appeared in a promotional video for the company!"
21: As evidence, Howley linked to two YouTube videos published March 5, 2013.
22: The first shows Paul Pelosi speaking at an event in Washington.
23: The video opens with clips of a speech from Nancy Pelosi and then shows Paul at an XPRIZE Foundation competition in September 2010.
24: The nonprofit group organizes public competitions with businesses to encourage their technological development.
25: RELATED STORY: PolitiFact's Trump-Ukraine-Biden coverage in one place "My name’s Paul Pelosi, of course I’m on the board of Viscoil, and Viscoil’s here today to talk about accelerating the future," he says during the video.
26: Viscoil was a California-based holding company that dissolved in 2010.
27: An old version of the company's website said the company was created to "engage in research and in the commercial development of hydrocarbon production methods and technologies."
28: After it shuttered, Viscoil was folded into NRGLab, a Singapore-based company "specializing in different areas of scientific research."
29: It appears to have published the YouTube videos.
30: The second video Howley posted shows Walter Afanasieff, a Brazilian-American musician, talking about how technology could improve oil extraction.
31: The caption lists other artists that had promoted Viscoil’s work, including Mika Newton, a Ukrainian singer and actress.
32: "Mika Newton helped to secure the rights to build a plant for the production of SH-boxes in Ukraine," the caption reads.
33: An SH-box is a kind of environmentally friendly generator, according to NRGLab .
34: We found a Facebook page on which Newton has promoted NRGLab’s work, but we could find no news coverage about the company's dealings in Ukraine.
35: NRGLab does not mention the country on its website.
36: We reached out to the company for more information but did not get a response.
37: To sum it up: Paul Pelosi served on the board of Viscoil.
38: At one point, a Ukrainian singer is alleged to have promoted the company.
39: But Pelosi was off the board before that happened.
40: That’s the connection people have identified.
41: Drew Hammill, a spokesman for Nancy Pelosi, told PolitiFact that Paul Pelosi worked for Viscoil for a short time.
42: He denied that it had any dealings in Ukraine at the time.
43: "The company was based in Southern California and focused solely on U.S. business," he said in an email.
44: "The company later reorganized under a different name, but Paul Pelosi Jr. played no role in the new entity."
45: What we know about the other lawmakers’ sons Hunter Biden did serve as a board member for a Ukrainian energy company, from 2014 until the spring of 2019.
46: As for the sons of Kerry and Romney, there is no evidence to suggest that they ever held similar positions.
47: Burisma Holdings appointed Hunter Biden to its board of directors in 2014 to help the energy company improve its corporate governance and adopt Western-style transparency.
48: His father, the former vice president and Democratic candidate running for president in 2020, has faced criticism for the appointment over a conflict of interest.
49: Kerry has three stepsons from his marriage with Teresa Heinz, heiress to the H.J.
50: Heinz ketchup fortune: John IV, André and Chris.
51: John is an educator, while André is an environmentalist.
52: RELATED STORY: Ask PolitiFact: Answers to reader questions about the Trump impeachment inquiry, Hunter Biden Chris is a businessman with extensive experience in private equity and venture capital — including pursuing a string of investment and consulting firms with Hunter Biden and Devon Archer, another businessman who was Chris Heinz’s roommate at Yale University.
53: He co-founded Rosemont Seneca Partners , a Washington investment fund, in 2009 with Biden and Archer.
54: Biden and Archer would later serve on the board of Burisma, but Chris Heinz never did.
55: In fact, he advised Archer against joining the board and, when both he and Hunter didn’t heed the warning, Heinz ended his business relationships with them.
56: "Chris has never been on the board of any energy company; nor has he ever traveled to or worked in Ukraine," a spokesman for John Kerry told PolitiFact in an email.
57: All the Heinz children are board members of the Heinz Endowments, the philanthropic arm of their family’s estate, but we could find no evidence that any have served on the board of an energy company linked to Ukraine.
58: Romney has five sons who work in a variety of different fields: Tagg, Matt, Craig, Josh and Ben.
59: We could find no evidence that any of them have served on the board of an energy company with ties to Ukraine.
60: Tagg Romney runs a private equity firm called Solamere Capital.
61: Matt Romney runs a firm called Excel Trust, which owns shopping centers across the United States.
62: Craig Romney works in real estate .
63: Josh Romney is the founder and president of The Romney Group , a real estate company based in Salt Lake City.
64: Ben Romney is a radiologist in Utah.
65: We reached out to a spokeswoman for Romney for more details about his sons’ business dealings, but she declined to comment on the substance of the Facebook posts.
66: "We don’t comment on fake news from random online trolls," Romney spokeswoman Liz Johnson said in an email.

gpt4: The claim that the sons of Nancy Pelosi, Mitt Romney, and John Kerry all served on the boards of energy companies doing business in Ukraine is false.
In fact, Hunter Biden, son of another lawmaker, was the one who served as a board member for a Ukrainian energy company from 2014 until spring 2019[45].
Information regarding the sons of Kerry and Romney shows no evidence of them holding similar positions [46].

With regards to Pelosi’s son, claims suggest that Paul Pelosi Jr. served on the board of an American energy company, Viscoil, which later dissolved and was re-formed in Singapore under a different name [14].
However, there is no clear evidence indicating that this company, in its new form, ever did business in Ukraine, with Paul Pelosi Jr having no part in the new entity [15].

According to a spokesman for John Kerry, Chris Kerry has never been on the board of any energy company or worked in Ukraine [56], and no evidence was found to suggest that any of them have served on the board of an energy company with ties to Ukraine [59].
During its existence, Viscoil was solely based in Southern California, focusing its business within the United States [43].

9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.claim: " Millionaires are eligible for food stamps, but ""Donald Trump came along and decided to put a stop to it."""
9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.label: true
9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.passage:
0: In July 2019, the U.S. Department of Agriculture issued a news release about proposed new rules for the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps.
1: The release said the proposed rule "would fix a loophole that has expanded SNAP recipients in some states to include people who receive assistance when they clearly don’t need it."
2: What does that mean, exactly?
3: Here’s how U.S. Rep. Glenn Grothman, R-Glenbeulah, framed it when backing the plan in an Oct. 2, 2019 article in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel : "A lot of people didn’t know that millionaires are eligible for food stamps," he said.
4: "I’m glad Donald Trump came along and decided to put a stop to it."
5: The article noted nearly 40,000 Wisconsinites would lose food benefits under the proposed changes.
6: The state would also have to upgrade its computer systems, retrain workers and make other changes that would cost millions of dollars a year.
7: But let’s return to Grothman and his claim.
8: Is he right that millionaires are eligible for food stamps?
9: Let’s take a look.
10: How the program works According to the Journal Sentinel article: Nearly 40 million people, including about 644,000 Wisconsinites, received food stamps in 2018.
11: Like most states, Wisconsin provides food benefits to people who qualify for other government programs without performing additional income and asset tests.
12: The proposed rule would bar people in other programs from automatically qualifying for food stamps.
13: Reviews of their income and assets would need to be conducted to ensure that, in most cases, their income is at or below 130% of the federal poverty level and they do not have liquid assets worth more than $2,250.
14: For a family of three, 130% of the federal poverty level is about $2,250 a month.
15: Nationwide, the proposal is expected to save $2.5 billion and cut benefits to about 3 million people.
16: As the Journal Sentinel article noted: In Wisconsin, about 39,600 people in about 24,100 households would lose more than $11 million in benefits a year, according to estimates from the state Department of Health Services.
17: Of those, about 13,000 are children and about 11,000 are senior citizens.
18: So, where do the millionaires come in?
19: The back door, apparently.
20: The evidence When asked to provide backup, Grothman’s staff pointed us to several news articles, including a Sept. 16, 2019 report from the Washington Examiner that reminded readers about the case of Leroy Fick who continued to receive food stamps after winning $2 million in the Michigan State Lottery in 2010.
21: "Fick used his winnings to buy a new home and an Audi convertible, all while continuing to receive SNAP benefits," the Examiner article said.
