20: Troops began withdrawing to Iraq on Oct. 21, per the Wall Street Journal .
21: Experts told us it’s difficult to determine how U.S. forces are distributed in the Middle East, in part because of changes former Defense Secretary James Mattis made to reduce transparency.
22: According to June data from the Pentagon — which omits numbers for countries with ongoing operations such as Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan — there were at that time 283 total U.S. forces in Egypt, 76 in Israel, 20 in Lebanon, 1,750 in Turkey, 84 in Jordan, 2,077 in Kuwait, 535 in Saudi Arabia, 19 in Yemen, 17 in Oman, 374 in the United Arab Emirates, 636 in Qatar, and 4,865 in Bahrain.
23: Those numbers include active duty personnel, national guard and reserve personnel and civilian personnel.
24: According to the Royal Institute of International Affairs , a London think tank, they do not include temporary forces or classified special forces operating in secret.
25: The June numbers are also outdated.
26: The Pentagon told us it would not identify the recently deployed personnel by country, but it said more than 6,500 of the 14,000 soldiers sent out since May are at sea as part of the Abraham Lincoln Carrier Strike Group.
27: Still, experts told us the largest numbers of U.S. forces currently stationed in or near the Middle East are likely in Bahrain, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar and Afghanistan.

gpt4: The assertion that President Trump has dispatched 14,000 American soldiers to the Middle East, thus contradicting his own pledge to withdraw troops from protracted conflicts, is not entirely accurate, given the information available.
The Pentagon did confirm the reshuffling of about 1,000 American soldiers from Syria to western Iraq [2].

Additionally, an October 11th press release from the Department of Defense reported that it had "increased the number of forces by approximately 14,000 to the U.S. Central Command area of responsibility" since May, which included the deployment of 3,000 U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia [8][9].
These figures were also repeated by Defense Secretary Mark Esper [10].
However, a recent reduction in U.S. troops in Afghanistan may indicate that the overall number of soldiers deployed to the Middle East is not as high as the initial count suggests [13].
The assertion that President Trump sent 14,000 troops, or 14 times more than he had promised to withdraw, is thus not entirely accurate [14].
Nevertheless, the redeployment of troops within the region is indeed a deviation from his original promise to withdraw troops [1].

4d74e871e8b730bdd3f4d5413530d3bd.claim: Trump is now suing CNN over ‘pro-impeachment bias’ and he demands a ‘substantial payment.’
4d74e871e8b730bdd3f4d5413530d3bd.label: half-true
4d74e871e8b730bdd3f4d5413530d3bd.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post criticizes President Donald Trump for "a uniquely American take on dictatorship."
1: "Wow," begins the Oct. 20 post , a screenshot of this Oct. 18 tweet .
2: "Trump is suing CNN over ‘pro-impeachment bias’ and he demands a ‘substantial payment.’ So basically the news can’t report the news because if it does, the president of America will sue."
3: This post, which has been shared more than 8,900 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: That’s because Trump hasn’t sued CNN — but he’s threatened to .
6: In an Oct. 16 letter, lawyers for Trump and his re-election campaign threatened "to sue CNN for what they said was the network falsely advertising itself as a news organization," Reuters reported.
7: The letter calls on executives to "discuss an appropriate resolution of this matter" that would include a "substantial payment" to cover damages.
8: "Never in the history of this country has a president been the subject of such a sustained barrage of unfair, unfounded, unethical and unlawful attacks by so-called ‘mainstream’ news, as the current situation," the letter says .
9: "My clients intend to file legal action against you to seek compensatory damages, treble damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, reimbursement of legal costs, and all other available legal and equitable remedies, to the maximum extent permitted by law."
10: The letter doesn’t mention "pro-impeachment bias" though the Washington Examiner among others described the president’s charges against CNN that way.
11: The letter to CNN was signed by attorney Charles Harder, who represented Hulk Hogan in the lawsuit that took down Gawker and who has sent similar threats to other media for Trump.
12: Last year, Harder suggested the president would sue the New York Times for what he called a "highly defamatory" story.
13: He threatened to sue author Michael Wolff for libel over Wolff’s book, "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House."
14: So far, though, no lawsuits have been filed.
15: And Rebecca Tushnet, a professor of false advertising law at Harvard Law School, told Reuters that Trump’s latest salvo has "no merit" and that she doubted a lawsuit would ever be filed.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump is currently suing CNN over 'pro-impeachment bias' demanding a 'substantial payment' is only half-true.
On Oct. 16, Trump's lawyers did send a letter to CNN threatening to sue them over what they claimed was false advertising of itself as a news organization [6].
However, the key detail that makes the claim only partially accurate is that, as of now, Trump has not followed through with his threat to file a lawsuit [5][14].

d94c85b67f3047725424a82baef3744b.claim: Most of the requests for records possessed by the Attorney General’s Office are from private law firms and companies.
d94c85b67f3047725424a82baef3744b.label: false
d94c85b67f3047725424a82baef3744b.passage:
0: Vermont Attorney General T.J. Donovan began enforcing a new public records rule this month that sparked criticism from transparency advocates and politicians on both sides of the aisle.
1: The rule prevents members of the public from photographing records they are examining unless they pay a fee to reimburse staff for the cost of preparing the documents.
2: Gov.
3: Phil Scott and Secretary of State Jim Condos have said that there is no legal basis for the government to charge members of the public to take photos of records.
4: The attorney general says he interprets the law differently.
5: Defending his new policy, Donovan has argued that taxpayers should be reimbursed for the time it takes his staff to locate, scrutinize and redact records before inspection—particularly when the majority of requests don't come from members of the public, or the press, but private entities.
6: "Most of the requests for records possessed by the Attorney General’s Office are from private law firms and companies," Donovan wrote in an op-ed published by VTDigger last week.
7: "There is a cost to Vermonters associated with diverting attorney time and resources from my office’s mission," he added.
8: "More to the point, should we provide free legal work to law firms and companies that may take an adverse position to the policies of our state?"
9: VTDigger has already asked Donovan’s office to reverse its policy on photographing records.
10: But his justification for it raised even more questions.
11: Do "most" requests to his office really come from companies and law firms?
12: On Thursday, a day before Donovan's op-ed was published, his office reported that 49% of the public records requests the attorney general's office received this year have come from companies.
13: As of Monday, the office said that number had dropped slightly, to about 45%.
14: Out of the 126 requests submitted to the attorney general this year, 32 came from members of the press, and 37 came from citizens acting independently, according to a review of the requests submitted to the office which are publicly available online .
15: The remaining 57 requests—45.2%— came from companies, law firms and non-profits, which the attorney general's office lumps into one category, "firms," when it tracks incoming records requests, according to Charity Clark, Donovan's chief of staff.
16: Within this category, it’s true that law offices and private companies filed most of the requests.
17: But nine of the requests in this category came from non-profits, interest groups and, in one case, a law school.
18: Four of the requests came from Energy Policy Advocates, a conservative-leaning non-profit dedicated to bringing "transparency to the realm of energy and environmental policy."
19: Also among the requesters categorized as "firms" were the National Consumer Law Center, a non-profit that focuses on legal and policy work for low income citizens; the Public Rights Project, an organization that advances civil rights and economic justice policies; and Judicial Watch, another right-leaning non-profit focused on government transparency.
20: A request from Vermont Legal Aid and another from a student at the University of Chicago School of Law were also included in the "firms" category.
21: Clark said that the attorney general's office has been tracking public records requests like this for years, starting before Donovan took office.
22: "Something that's not a citizen and not a member of the press is going to be in this other group," she said.
23: However, Donovan referred to this entire class of requesters as "private law firms and companies," a description that should not encompass universities, non-profit public interest groups and legal support clinics.
24: If the "firms" category excluded non-profits, there would be nine fewer requests: meaning the total number of from private law firms and companies would only be to 38% of all requests.

gpt4: The claim that private law firms and companies make up the majority of requests for records held by the Attorney General’s Office is false.

Although Attorney General Donovan has stated that most incoming requests are from these sectors, his office reported that only 49% of the public records requests they received this year have come from companies [12].

Further clarification of these figures showed that 45.2% of these requests came not only from companies and law firms, but also from non-profits, which are grouped together under the term "firms" by Donovan's office [15].

It’s true that within this category, law offices and private companies filed most of the requests, however this also encompasses requests from non-profits, interest groups, and even a law school[16][17].

Thus, Donovan's characterization of all these incoming requests as being solely from "private law firms and companies" is inaccurate, as this label should not extend to universities, non-profit public interest groups, and legal support clinics[23].

855d3bf4d33a690c887226977e1aa38e.claim: I entered as one of the poorest men in Congress, left one of the poorest men in government, in Congress and as vice president.
855d3bf4d33a690c887226977e1aa38e.label: true
855d3bf4d33a690c887226977e1aa38e.passage:
0: In challenging President Donald Trump to release his tax returns, Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said he had released 21 years of his returns and then claimed relative poverty for himself.
1: "I entered as one of the poorest men in Congress, left one of the poorest men in government — in Congress and as vice president," Biden said.
2: Biden, who turns 77 on Nov. 20, was born into a working-class family in Scranton, Pa.
3: He entered Congress in 1973 after being elected to represent Delaware in the U.S. Senate at the age of 29.
4: He served there until becoming vice president under Barack Obama , a post he held until January 2017.
5: Modest assets To back up Biden’s first claim, that he "entered as one of the poorest men in Congress," Biden’s campaign sent us a 1974 Delaware newspaper article.
6: It has incomplete figures on Biden’s finances, and they compare him only to the two other members of the state’s congressional delegation at the time.
7: We looked for outside data on this point and did not find much, but indications are Biden didn’t have much wealth.
8: Roll Call, the Capitol Hill newspaper, has done wealth rankings , but only for members of Congress and dating back only to 1990.
9: The Center for Responsive Politics provided us a 1973 summary of financial disclosures made by only some members of the House and Senate; it was published by Congressional Quarterly.
10: "Unfortunately, it’s hard to say anything concrete about his actual net worth in 1973, because all we have to go off of is this summary" and not the actual disclosure documents, said Center for Responsive Politics researcher Alex Baumgart.
11: "There's no listed securities here for Biden like there are for other members.
12: From that, it’s reasonable to infer he had no major investments listed on his financial disclosure."
13: The summary Biden reported outside income in 1973 of $6,050, all from speeches.
14: On Biden’s second claim about leaving as one of the poorest officials in government, Biden’s campaign sent us rankings from 2005, 2006 and 2007.
15: Those rankings don’t account for the fact that Biden remained in government for another decade.
16: The rankings are from the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics, which annually ranks the wealth of government officials including members of Congress and top officials in the executive and judicial branches.
17: Biden ranked near the bottom in the center’s data in the years before he became vice president: Biden ranked 570th of 585 officials in 2005; 614th of 636 officials in 2006; and 626th of 639 officials in 2007.
18: Because officials report their assets and liabilities on official forms as ranges, the rankings use estimates.
19: Biden’s estimated net worth was -$47,494 in 2005; -$12,492 in 2006; and -$52,493 in 2007.
20: In other words, it appeared that his debts outpaced his cash and other assets.
21: The center’s rankings only go back to 2004.
22: (Biden’s campaign also sent us reports indicating that Biden’s net worth when he left office as vice president was far less than that of former vice president Al Gore and Dick Cheney , and less than current Vice President Mike Pence .
23: Biden’s original statement did not compare himself to other vice presidents.)
24: Latest ranking We looked for the latest rankings by the Center for Responsive Politics to get a sense of where his wealth ranked when he left the White House.
25: In the latest data that include Biden, Biden again ranked near the bottom: 577 of 581 officials in 2014.
26: His estimated net worth was -$947,987 , based on official reports filed in 2015.
27: Since leaving the White House, Biden has reaped millions.
28: CNBC reported in June 2019 that Biden and his wife, Jill, made more than $15 million combined in 2017 and 2018.
29: And the same month, the Washington Post reported that Biden has made millions of dollars largely from book deals and speaking fees for as much as $200,000 per speech.
30: The Center for Responsive Politics estimates Biden’s net worth , as of July 2019, at between $2.14 million and $7.92 million.

gpt4: Joe Biden's statement, that he entered and left Congress and the vice presidency as one of 'the poorest men in government' is indeed true.
Discussing his financial position, Biden stated, "I entered as one of the poorest men in Congress, left one of the poorest men in government — in Congress and as vice president"[1].
His claim of being one of the poorest men when he entered Congress is backed up by a 1974 Delaware newspaper article provided by his campaign [5].
Limited available data supports the understanding that Biden did not possess substantial wealth during this period [7].
Biden's second claim, about leaving Congress and the vice presidency as one of the poorest men, is substantiated by financial rankings from 2005, 2006 and 2007 sent by his campaign [14].
In fact, Biden consistently ranked near the bottom in these reports [17], with an estimated net worth of -$47,494 in 2005, -$12,492 in 2006, and -$52,493 in 2007 [19].
Moreover, his financial status remained weak as late as 2015, with an estimated net worth reported at -$947,987[26].

407fd53c3a664c6ac52e3c7f2673bfeb.claim: Antifa Fascist Fangirl Tulsi Gabbard posing with Evan Duke, leader of Portland Antifa and Occupy ICE.
407fd53c3a664c6ac52e3c7f2673bfeb.label: false
407fd53c3a664c6ac52e3c7f2673bfeb.passage:
0: A Facebook post portrays Democratic presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard as a supporter of the anti-fascist movement, claiming that a photo shows her posing with someone who leads the movement.
1: "Antifa Fascist Fangirl Tulsi Gabbard posing with Evan Duke, leader of Portland Antifa and Occupy ICE," said an Oct. 22 Facebook post that’s been shared more than 100 times.
2: (The post says "antifa fascist" — yet antifa is short for anti-fascist.)
3: The picture used in the post does include a man named Evan Duke who appears to support the antifa movement.
4: But Duke and an antifa group in Portland, Ore., told PolitiFact that Duke does not lead antifa nor Occupy ICE.
5: The photo circulating on Facebook was taken in North Dakota when Gabbard went there to support veterans and others protesting the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline and its potential impact on water safety and tribal lands.
6: The Facebook post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: PolitiFact requested comment from Gabbard’s congressional office and presidential campaign.
9: Her congressional office referred us to her campaign, which did not respond to our queries.
10: What is antifa and Occupy ICE?
11: Antifa is a term used for a collection of far-left, anti-fascist groups across the country that rally against white supremacy and other causes, at times resorting to violence.
12: The antifa movement goes back decades , but regained attention after antifa groups counterprotested white nationalists in Charlottesville, Va., in August 2017.
13: Conservative group Turning Point USA in August 2019 asked Gabbard if she would be willing to denounce antifa.
14: "I have denounced antifa," Gabbard said .
15: Occupy ICE is a movement that protests and wants the abolishment of the federal immigration agency Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE.
16: The movement gained traction in June 2018 with protests of the Trump administration’s "zero-tolerance" immigration policy.
17: Origin of the picture in the Facebook post The Facebook photo features Gabbard and seven other people.
18: Gabbard, a congresswoman from Hawaii and a major in the Hawaii Army National Guard, posted a similar picture of the group on her Facebook page on Dec. 10, 2016.
19: She described the people in the image as a group of veterans helping with safety and security operations at a camp protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline .
20: "I'm honored to have met these incredible veterans, who inspire as they continue their mission of service," Gabbard’s post said.
21: "They are in this for the long haul, planning to stay until the drilling pad and construction equipment are removed.
22: #nodapl #mniwiconi #waterislife #veterans."
23: The photo in the Oct. 22 Facebook post also appears on a website called Hallwalls, on a page that promoted a January 2017 event by a group called VeteransRespond.
24: The group planned to present a "storytelling event featuring United States military veterans who stood at Standing Rock."
25: The page describes VeteransRespond as a national service organization formed by veterans who went to the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota.
26: The Hallwalls caption for the photo identified one of the men as "Evan Duke (Occupy Wall St.)" Who is Evan Duke?
27: Snopes.com found a Facebook account for someone named Evan K Duke III, who on Dec. 9, 2016, posted a picture similar to the one posted by Gabbard and to the one now circulating on Facebook.
28: Duke’s post said: " #NoDAPL #StrengthAndHonor Occupy/Veterans camp built an HQ and barracks for incoming vets at Standing Rock with donations from people across the United States.
29: We processed and housed as many people as we could on the ground during the blizzards.
30: We were invited to be Tulsi Gabbard's security detail during her stay at camp.
31: Before she left she came to our little plywood and 2x4 HQ to tell us how proud of us she was.
32: With tears in her eyes she told us we were on the right path to creating the change this nation needs.
33: We shed tears with her and said our Alohas.
34: We taught her the Lakota word Doksha (until we see you again).
35: Farewell relative.
36: You are one of us!"
37: PolitiFact reached out to that account, and the user confirmed he was in the picture being shared on Facebook.
38: Duke’s account includes antifa-related posts, but he said he was not the leader of antifa nor of Occupy ICE.
39: "Whoever made such claims clearly has no understanding of how de-centralized movements work," Duke said.
40: "There are no leaders, there is no formal organization, their (sic) are no meetings, plans, rosters.
41: Within those movements there are simply autonomous activists organizing as they see fit."
42: Duke’s Facebook account also posted a detailed message on Aug. 26, 2016, to actress Shailene Woodley’s Facebook page.
43: Duke wrote that he was with "Occupy Inauguration Planning Committee," a mass rally scheduled for Inauguration Day in January 2017 in D.C.
44: He asked Woodley for her endorsement and participation.
45: (Woodley had supported protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline.)
46: PolitiFact reached out to a group called Rose City Antifa (whose website said it was founded in 2007 in Portland, Ore.) asking if Duke was the "leader of Portland Antifa and Occupy ICE," as the Facebook post claimed.
47: "Evan Duke is not the leader of Portland Antifa, he is not a member of our organization, and he is not the leader of Occupy ICE," the group responded in an email.
48: They said he had never been the leader of the groups, either.

gpt4: The claim that Tulsi Gabbard is an Antifa supporter who posed with Evan Duke, alleged leader of Portland Antifa and Occupy ICE, is false.

The photo that is being circulated on social media was actually taken when Gabbard was in North Dakota supporting veterans and others protesting against the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline, highlighting potential risks to water safety and tribal lands [5].
Furthermore, Gabbard has openly denounced Antifa [14].
Regarding Evan Duke, both Duke himself and an Antifa group in Portland have confirmed that he is not the leader of either Antifa or Occupy ICE [4][38][47].

2e91a6e4c38b4d8f6d651479e6d60020.claim: "  Hillary Clinton ""paid for a Russian dossier to win an election,"" her husband ""made $500k for a Russian speech,"" ""sold 20% of US Uranium to Russia"" and her foundation ""received $150M from Russia."""
2e91a6e4c38b4d8f6d651479e6d60020.label: false
2e91a6e4c38b4d8f6d651479e6d60020.passage:
0: Hillary Clinton’s comments about Jill Stein and Tulsi Gabbard inspired a raft of Facebook posts that revived misleading claims about Clinton’s relationship with Russia.
1: One post published Oct. 21 and shared more than 1,300 times says the following: "Does anyone else find it strange: The same woman who paid for a Russian dossier to win an election; Whose husband made $500k for a Russian speech; Who sold 20% of US Uranium to Russia; Whose foundation received $150M from Russia; Keeps calling others Russian assets?"
2: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: As evidence, the post cited Charlie Kirk, founder of the conservative nonprofit Turning Point USA.
5: We found an Oct. 20 tweet from Kirk that makes the same claims as the post.
6: It was retweeted more than 26,000 times.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) PolitiFact has investigated four of these claims in the past.
8: We summarized our findings to address each of the post’s claims.
9: The post contains a hint of truth, but it paints an inaccurate picture of Clinton’s ties to Russia.
10: Hillary Clinton "paid for a Russian dossier to win an election" This contains an element of truth, but it isn’t the full picture.
11: The dossier that the Facebook post is referencing was written by former British spy Christopher Steele about President Donald Trump’s ties to Russia.
12: Many of the details included in the dossier were salacious but unverified.
13: It was not written by Russian officials, as the Facebook post seems to claim.
14: In September 2018, we fact-checked a claim from Rep. Mark Meadows, R-N.C., about the dossier, Fusion GPS (the opposition research firm that created it) and how the Clinton campaign was involved.
15: We found that Fusion GPS was hired to work on behalf of the Clinton campaign, but the firm was already investigating Trump at the time.
16: Fusion GPS was originally hired by the Washington Free Beacon, a conservative media website.
17: The Democratic National Committee, through its law firm Perkins Coie and for the benefit of the Clinton campaign, hired the opposition research firm to collect information after Trump won the Republican nomination.
18: Then, Fusion GPS hired Steele to produce memos on Trump’s ties to Russia.
19: Bill Clinton "made $500k for a Russian speech" This is accurate.
20: The source of the claim is the 2015 book "Clinton Cash" by author and political consultant Peter Schweizer.
21: During an April 2015 interview about the book on Fox News Sunday, he said something that caught our eye: "Of the 13 (Bill) Clinton speeches that fetched $500,000 or more, only two occurred during the years his wife was not secretary of state."
22: We rated that claim True .
23: And in the course of our investigation of Clinton’s federal financial disclosure forms , we found that former President Clinton gave a talk in 2010 to a Russian finance corporation.
24: He was compensated $500,000.
25: Hillary Clinton "sold 20% of US Uranium to Russia" This is misleading.
26: We rated a similar claim Mostly False.
27: The claim also stems from Schweizer’s "Clinton Cash."
28: A chapter of the book suggests a pay-for-play scheme between the Clintons and Russia, accusing them of transferring uranium in exchange for donation money.
29: Part of that chapter stems from a 2007 deal between Clinton Foundation board member Frank Giustra’s company, UrAsia, and Uranium One, a Canadian mining company.
30: Uranium One has mines, mills and land in U.S. states equal to about 20% of the American uranium production capacity.
31: Its actual production, though, is a smaller portion of the uranium produced in the United States, at 11% in 2014, according to Oilprice.com.
32: RELATED: In context: Hillary Clinton on Tulsi Gabbard, the Trump campaign, Russia In 2009, Russia’s nuclear energy agency, Rosatom, bought a 17% share of Uranium One.
33: A year later, it bought enough shares to give it a 51% stake.
34: Since a foreign entity was taking a majority stake in a uranium operation, several U.S. government regulators had to approve the deal.
35: They did, and in 2013, Russia assumed 100% ownership of Uranium One and renamed it Uranium One Holding.
36: In our previous fact-check , we noted that Clinton sat on the committee that approved the sale — but the decision was not hers alone.
37: She also did not have the power to veto the committee’s decision.
38: The Clinton Foundation "received $150M from Russia" This is exaggerated.
39: We rated a similar claim Mostly False.
40: Nine people related to Uranium One donated to the Clinton Foundation.
41: But the bulk of the money, about $131 million, came from Giustra — a businessman from Canada, not Russia.
42: Giustra said he sold off his entire stake in the company in 2007, three years before the Russia deal and about 18 months before Clinton became secretary of state.
43: We haven’t independently verified Giustra’s claim, but if he is telling the truth, the donation amount to the Clinton Foundation from Uranium One investors drops significantly — from $145 million to $4 million.

gpt4: The claim that Hillary Clinton paid for a Russian dossier to win an election, while possessing an element of truth, does not render a complete image of the scenario [10].

Fusion GPS, an opposition research firm, was hired by the Democratic National Committee via its law firm Perkins Coie to collect information on Trump, however, this took place after Trump had secured the Republican nomination and Fusion GPS was already probing Trump at that juncture [17][15].
The dossier itself was not penned by Russian officials as might be construed from the claim [13].
Arguably, the claim about Bill Clinton making "$500k for a Russian speech" is accurate, with him being compensated with that amount [19][24].
The statement that Hillary Clinton sold "20% of US Uranium to Russia" is misleading[25].
Notably, Clinton was a part of the committee that assented to the sale but the decision was not solely hers, and she lacked the power to annul the committee’s decision [36][37].
Additionally, the precise date of Giustra, a significant investor in the deal, selling his entire share in the company does affect the claim considerably [42][43].
Lastly, the assertion that the Clinton Foundation received "$150M from Russia" is overstated [38].
Among the reviewed claims, several are deemed mostly false in our previous fact-check [26][39].

dc1f24a9c2312fe8abe2a5dbdf6f35b9.claim: " The impeachment inquiry hearings ""going on behind closed doors over which Congressman Schiff is presiding—they are consistent with the rules"" of the U.S. House of Representatives."
dc1f24a9c2312fe8abe2a5dbdf6f35b9.label: true
dc1f24a9c2312fe8abe2a5dbdf6f35b9.passage:
0: Republicans recently stormed a hearing in the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry targeting President Donald Trump to protest the fact that witnesses are being questioned in private.
1: The next day, Fox News political commentator and legal analyst Andrew Napolitano sought to correct them.
2: Before even being asked a question, Napolitano began his Oct. 24 appearance on "Fox & Friends" with a statement about the hearings being led by U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., chairman of one of three House committees holding the hearings.
3: "I read the House rules," the former New Jersey judge said.
4: "And as frustrating as it may be to have these hearings going on behind closed doors — the hearings over which Congressman Schiff is presiding — they are consistent with the rules."
5: He’s right.
6: Impeachment 101 Democrats launched the impeachment inquiry following a whistleblower’s report suggesting that Trump withheld U.S. military aid from Ukraine to pressure the country into investigating his political rival, 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.
7: A president can be impeached if his or her acts are inconsistent with their presidential duties, whether or not it violates criminal law.
8: It is the job of the House to decide whether there’s enough evidence to show that Trump committed an impeachable offense.
9: First, articles of impeachment would have to pass the full U.S. House of Representatives with a simple majority.
10: Those articles would then be sent to the Senate for a trial.
11: A two-thirds Senate vote is required to convict — that is, remove — the president.
12: Impeachment is part of the U.S. Constitution.
13: But the rules and procedures for an impeachment are not written in the Constitution, or in a statute; they depend largely on historical precedent.
14: Napolitano’s position After making his statement on "Fox & Friends," Napolitano went on to explain that the impeachment inquiry rules were adopted in 2015 by House Republicans and allow for initial interviews of witnesses to be done in secret, much like a criminal case is presented to a grand jury.
15: Any formal impeachment hearing, he added, would have to be done in public, as would a Senate trial.
16: When we asked a Fox News representative for information to support Napolitano’s statement, she sent the following from Napolitano: "The House rules permit committee chairs to hold closed hearings on matters of national security or intelligence.
17: Diplomatic matters implicate both national security and intelligence.
18: The rules also permit standing committees – as opposed to the full House – to issue subpoenas.
19: As well, they permit interviews of witnesses in secret in order to determine if they are credible enough to present in public."
20: Heritage Foundation senior legal fellow Hans von Spakovsky told us that according to the House of Representatives’ House Practice book , "an impeachment is normally instituted by the House by the adoption of a resolution calling for a committee investigation of charges."
21: And no such resolution was done in this inquiry.
22: But the day after Napolitano’s interview, a federal judge in Washington ruled that the impeachment inquiry is legal .
23: And Napolitano’s statement was not about in the inquiry generally, but whether interviews can be done in private.
24: Experts agree with Napolitano Frank Bowman , a University of Missouri professor of law and author of " High Crimes and Misdemeanors: A History of Impeachment for the Age of Trump ," told us the hearings are not "secret" in that they are open to members of the three House committees (roughly 100 lawmakers), along with their staff.
25: Bowman pointed us to the 2015 House rules that allow for the private questioning of witnesses in impeachment inquiries.
26: The rules say House meetings shall be open to the public except when a committee or subcommittee, in open session and with a majority present, "determines by record vote that all or part of the remainder of the meeting on that day shall be in executive session because disclosure of matters to be considered would endanger national security, would compromise sensitive law enforcement information, would tend to defame, degrade, or incriminate any person, or otherwise would violate a law or rule of the House."
27: Jeffrey Engel , founding director of the Center for Presidential History at Southern Methodist University and co-author of "Impeachment: An American History," underscored the House’s wide latitude.
28: He told PolitiFact that from a constitutional standpoint, "the House can choose whatever rules it wants for impeachment hearings—just as the Senate will be able to do the same for its trial, relying on precedent but not bound by it."
29: One more point before we close.
30: When Republicans controlled the House, its Benghazi committee held nearly all of its hearings behind closed doors, Allan Lichtman , American University history professor and author of " The Case for Impeachment ," noted to us.
31: He also pointed out that in the final House report on the matter, then-Rep. Trey Gowdy , a South Carolina Republican, said: "The committee’s preference for private interviews over public hearings has been questioned.
32: Interviews are a more efficient and effective means of discovery.
33: Interviews allow witnesses to be questioned in depth by a highly prepared member or staff person.
34: In a hearing, every member of a committee is recognized — usually for five minutes — a procedure which precludes in-depth in-depth focused questioning.
35: Interviews also allow the committee to safeguard the privacy of witnesses who may fear retaliation for cooperating or whose work requires anonymity, such as intelligence community operatives."

gpt4: The claim that the closed-door impeachment inquiry hearings presided over by Congressman Schiff are consistent with the rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, is indeed true.
This statement was made by former New Jersey judge, Napolitano, who affirmed his understanding of the House rules [3].
Napolitano reinforced that despite potential frustrations resulting from the lack of public access to these hearings, they are being conducted in accordance to established protocols [4].
These protocols were enacted by House Republicans in 2015 and permit initial witness interviews to be conducted privately, akin to how cases would be presented to a grand jury [14].
This understanding aligns with Bowman's assertion where he referenced the same 2015 House rules that accord the rights for private witness interrogation during impeachment inquiries [25].

The rules stipulate that House meetings are normally open to the public, but exceptions are allowed if a committee or subcommittee, with majority presence during an open session, decides and records a vote indicating that the rest of the meeting will be in executive session.

This is usually permitted in scenarios where public disclosure could pose risks to national security, comprise sensitive law enforcement information, or in situations that could potentially be defamatory, degrading or incriminating, among others [26].

520d516ab00c156c492b5fd1e45d2ff3.claim: "  House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry are ""denying President Trump basic fairness and due process accorded every American."""
520d516ab00c156c492b5fd1e45d2ff3.label: false
520d516ab00c156c492b5fd1e45d2ff3.passage:
0: Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., introduced a resolution Oct. 24 to condemn House Democrats’ impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump.
1: The resolution rebuked the Democratic-led House for interviewing impeachment witnesses behind closed doors and not holding a formal vote to initiate the inquiry.
2: It also argued that Trump, who faces impeachment for urging Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a potential challenger in the 2020 election, has not received "fundamental constitutional protections."
3: "The House of Representatives is abandoning more than a century’s worth of precedent and tradition in impeachment proceedings and denying President Trump basic fairness and due process accorded every American," Graham wrote in the resolution.
4: But Graham’s claim that Trump has been denied due process — a claim he has repeated on Twitter and in Congress — does not square with the law or the way impeachment works.
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We looked into the same "due process" claim when it showed up in a White House letter indicating that Trump would not be cooperating with the inquiry.
6: At the time, constitutional scholars told us that complaint lacks legal footing.
7: The House impeaches, the Senate holds the trial In his resolution, Graham wrote that due process for Trump would mean "the right to confront your accuser, call witnesses on your behalf, and challenge the accusations against you."
8: Graham spokesman Kevin Bishop pointed to a presentation Graham showed during a press conference listing rights Graham said President Bill Clinton had when he was impeached, such as the right to have counsel at hearings and the right to challenge evidence, among others.
9: (The House Judiciary Committee did hear testimony from Clinton’s White House counsel , but there’s no constitutional provision requiring it to do so.)
10: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., speaks about his resolution during a news conference in Washington on Oct. 24, 2019.
11: (AP/Applewhite)â€‹ But when we checked out the White House’s letter, Vanderbilt University law professor Suzanna Sherry told us "there is nothing that requires Congress to give the president any of the opportunities" that Graham, like the White House attorney before him, described.
12: If such rights apply at all, they would be granted to Trump during the trial phase, which the Constitution says takes place in the Senate.
13: The House’s job is to determine whether there’s enough evidence to show that the president committed an impeachable offense.
14: Sherry told us that "an impeachment investigation is analogous to a criminal investigation or inquiry by the police, prosecutor or grand jury" and that "the accused has none of the rights" that White House counsel Pat Cipollone listed in the White House’s letter and Graham listed in his resolution.
15: "In particular, neither the accused nor his or her lawyer are present at a grand jury hearing, nor is the accused permitted to present witnesses or other evidence or see a transcript," she said.
16: "It is only after charges have been filed and the case has reached the trial stage that criminal defendants have the right to cross-examine witnesses, call witnesses, have access to evidence, and have counsel present," said former federal prosecutor and Stanford Law professor David Sklansky, adding that the due process complaint is "not a good argument."
17: "The role of the House of Representatives in an impeachment proceeding is to investigate and charge, not to try," he said.
18: "The trial comes later, in the Senate."
19: Even in the Senate, however, it’s not clear that impeachment proceedings require due process protections, because conviction results only in removal from office, experts said.
20: Writing for Reason , Ilya Somin, a law professor at George Mason University, said due process rights are protected in "situations where an individual stands to lose her ‘life, liberty, or property,’ none of which is at risk here."
21: "To suggest that due process requires that a president facing only loss of office get more rights at the accusatory stage than a criminal defendant facing loss of liberty or even life is not only constitutionally unsupportable, but ludicrous," said Frank O.
22: Bowman III, professor of law at the University of Missouri and the author of a book on impeachment.
23: The Constitution lets the House set the rules Graham’s resolution criticized House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s handling of the impeachment inquiry and the fact that she has not held a formal vote to authorize the inquiry.
24: The Constitution says that the House "shall have the sole Power of Impeachment" and the Senate "shall have the sole Power to try all Impeachments."
25: In the past, the full House has authorized impeachment inquiries, and then the House Judiciary Committee has taken the lead in conducting the investigations, holding hearings on proposed articles of impeachment, and voting on whether to approve them.
26: The final vote on impeachment is by the full House before it moves to Senate for trial.
27: Pelosi has not held a vote to authorize an impeachment inquiry ( a majority say they approve of an inquiry ), but instead instructed three committees — Intelligence, Oversight and Foreign Affairs — to carry out an investigation that Judiciary will use to draft any articles of impeachment.
28: While her process has been different , historians told us Pelosi does not need to hold a full House vote.

gpt4: The claim that House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry are denying President Trump basic fairness and due process does not align with the law or the way impeachment works[4].
Constitutional scholars have stated that such a complaint lacks law-based validity[6].
Suzanna Sherry, a Vanderbilt University law professor clarified that there's no requirement for Congress to provide the president with the opportunities that Senator Graham has described[11].

Former federal prosecutor and Stanford Law professor David Sklansky elucidated that if any such rights were to be granted, they would occur during the trial phase in the Senate as per constitution[12], at which point a criminal defendant is granted the right to cross-examine witnesses, call witnesses, have access to evidence, and have counsel present[16].

Nancy Pelosi’s handling of the impeachment inquiry and the perceived necessity of a formal vote to authorize the inquiry has been critiqued in Graham’s resolution[23], however, the Constitution grants the House with the unique power of impeachment and the Senate with the power to try all impeachments[24].

Furthermore, while Pelosi has not held a formal vote and has instructed three committees to undertake the investigation which will be used by the Judiciary to draft any articles of impeachment[27], historians have stated that she is not obliged to hold a full House vote[28].

bd6dcf0720a26c12e216a50db17f7c5b.claim: "  in his 2000 book ""I was talking about Osama bin Laden. I said, ‘You have to kill him. You have to take him out.’"""
bd6dcf0720a26c12e216a50db17f7c5b.label: false
bd6dcf0720a26c12e216a50db17f7c5b.passage:
0: After President Donald Trump announced that terrorist leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was dead, Trump repeated an inaccurate boast that he called for taking out Osama bin Laden before the Sept. 11 attacks.
1: Trump said that he made the warning in his January 2000 book "The America We Deserve."
2: Speaking to reporters Oct. 27, Trump said that he doesn’t get credit for warning that bin Laden should have been taken out.
3: "You know, if you read my book — there was a book just before the World Trade Center came down.
4: And I don’t get any credit for this, but that’s okay.
5: I never do.
6: But here we are.
7: I wrote a book — a, really, very successful book.
8: And in that book, about a year before the World Trade Center was blown up, I said, ‘There is somebody named Osama bin Laden.
9: You better kill him or take him out.’ Something to that effect.
10: ‘He’s big trouble.’" Trump continued, saying that he said to people, "Take out Osama bin Laden," although "nobody ever heard of Osama bin Laden until, really, the World Trade Center.
11: "But about a year — you’ll have to check — a year, year and a half before the World Trade Center came down, the book came out.
12: I was talking about Osama bin Laden.
13: I said, ‘You have to kill him.
14: You have to take him out.’ Nobody listened to me."
15: Trump made a similar statement in a speech as a presidential candidate in Virginia in 2015.
16: We rated that statement Mostly False .
17: At other speeches in 2015, Trump went further and said he "predicted" bin Laden and terrorism.
18: Trump did write about bin Laden critically in his book, but he did not suggest that he be taken out.
19: What Trump actually wrote about bin Laden Bin Laden is mentioned once in the book, specifically in a passage criticizing President Bill Clinton’s approach to national security: "Instead of one looming crisis hanging over us, we face a bewildering series of smaller crises, flash points, stand offs, and hot spots.
20: We’re not playing the chess game to end all chess games anymore.
21: We’re playing tournament chess - one master against many rivals.
22: One day we’re assured that Iraq is under control, the UN inspectors have done their work, everything’s fine, not to worry.
23: The next day the bombing begins.
24: One day we’re told that a shadowy figure named Osama bin Laden is public enemy number one, and U.S. jet fighters lay waste to his camp in Afghanistan.
25: He escapes back under some rock, and a few news cycles later, it’s on to a new enemy and a new crisis ."
26: (Emphasis in bold is ours.)
27: Trump’s reference to bin Laden relates to the Aug. 20, 1998, U.S. bombing of his camps in Afghanistan and Sudan .
28: Clinton said they were in retaliation for terrorist bombings earlier that month on U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania which killed 224 people , including 12 Americans , and wounding thousands.
29: Clinton said the goal of the U.S. strikes was to "disrupt bin Laden’s terror network."
30: Trump devoted a chapter to terrorism and warned broadly that America could be attacked, but he did not call for taking out bin Laden.
31: He wrote that the U.S. "must prepare for the real possibility that somewhere, sometime, a weapon of mass destruction will be carried into a major American city and detonated."
32: Trump acknowledged that this was not his original thought, noting that ABC-TV’s "Nightline" had aired a series of shows about the threat.
33: In his comments to the media Oct. 27, Trump also said that "al-Baghdadi everybody hears because he’s built this monster for a long time.
34: But nobody ever heard of Osama bin Laden until, really, the World Trade Center."
35: The United States government was aware of bin Laden a few years before the Sept. 11 attacks.
36: The CIA established a unit in 1996 , Alec Station, to hunt bin Laden when he was calling for global jihad.
37: The station was disbanded a decade later.

gpt4: The claim that in his 2000 book, Trump said about Osama bin Laden, "You have to kill him.
You have to take him out," is false.
In reality, Trump did write about bin Laden critically, however, he didn't specifically suggest that he be killed or "taken out"[18].
The book also included a chapter on terrorism where he broadly warned that America could be attacked, but again, he did not advocate for the assassination of bin Laden [30].

d88e9532b4922da6ecb543c4e4bc828f.claim: "  that Olive Garden is ""funding"" President Trump's 2020 re-election campaign."
d88e9532b4922da6ecb543c4e4bc828f.label: false
d88e9532b4922da6ecb543c4e4bc828f.passage:
0: Unlimited soups, salads and breadsticks are what Olive Garden is known for (especially the breadsticks).
1: But is the restaurant also "funding" President Donald Trump’s 2020 re-election campaign?
2: That’s what one viral Facebook post claims: "Olive Garden is funding Trump's re-election in 2020.
3: It would be terrible if you shared this and Olive Garden lost business."
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: But it isn’t true.
7: A quick Google search into the rumor turns up several news articles and fact-checks that debunk the claim.
8: We also previously fact-checked an Instagram post that inaccurately included Olive Garden on a list of companies that allegedly donated to President Donald Trump’s re-election campaign.
9: The rumors started to circulate on social media in late August after that list went viral.
10: Shortly after a #BoycottOliveGarden hashtag began trending on Twitter, the restaurant’s official account stepped in: "We don’t know where this information came from, but it is incorrect.
11: Our company does not donate to presidential candidates."
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com When a user responded to the tweet and asked whether Olive Garden’s parent company, Darden Restaurants , donated to PACs, the restaurant responded that Darden "does not donate to any federal or presidential candidates."
13: Darden owns multiple restaurant chains, including LongHorn Steakhouse, Yard House, Cheddar’s and The Capital Grille.
14: We went to OpenSecrets.org, a campaign finance database run by the Center for Responsive Politics research group, to examine the numbers.
15: The database shows that Darden Restaurants itself has not donated to Trump’s re-election campaign, nor has it made any contributions during the 2020 election cycle.
16: (The same goes for the 2018 and 2016 election cycles.)
17: That’s because corporations are prohibited from making contributions to candidates and party committees, according to the Federal Election Commission .
18: Open Secrets includes a similar disclaimer that reads: "Organizations themselves cannot contribute to candidates and party committees.
19: Totals include subsidiaries and affiliates."
20: But donations can be made from PACs affiliated with the company, from the organization’s employees, owners or those individuals’ immediate family members.
21: All the money associated with Darden that’s been donated so far in the 2020 cycle has come from individuals, the database shows.
22: Those donations have totaled $17,332, with $11,899 of that going to candidates, all of them Democrats, and $5,000 going to a PAC that says it supports Democratic leadership .
23: Trump is not among the recipients so far, according to the database.
24: In recent election cycles, however, contributions associated with the organization went to both Republican and Democratic candidates and committees, and came from both individuals and PACs.
25: In the 2016 election , individuals affiliated with Darden – again, not the organization itself – donated $8,407 to Hillary Clinton and $886 to Donald Trump.

gpt4: The claim that Olive Garden is financially supporting President Trump's 2020 re-election campaign is false[6].
Upon investigating, multiple news articles and fact-checks found through a Google search refuted this allegation[7].
Moreover, the track record shows that Darden Restaurants, the parent company, does not contribute to any presidential candidates, making the claim highly unlikely[11].
This is further confirmed by a database which shows that neither Darden Restaurants specifically nor its higher-ups have extended any financial support to Trump’s 2020 campaign[15].
Additionally, the same database also emphasizes that Trump is not among the recipients of any such donation[23].
Thus, the claim lacks merit.

b69148936c89df5c36baf3cad7b5aa18.claim: " Quotes Trump as saying, ""Fine you boo me DC? Go #Astros, Texas loves me, I get the best kind of love there. I’ll be renaming the White House the Orange House."""
b69148936c89df5c36baf3cad7b5aa18.label: false
b69148936c89df5c36baf3cad7b5aa18.passage:
0: After a day in which he announced the death of terrorist leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi , President Donald Trump attended Game 5 of the World Series in Washington where he was met with some loud boos and taunts of "lock him up!"
1: The booing occurred at the end of the third inning when the Jumbotron showed Trump, wife Melania and other guests at the game.
2: On the same night, a viral screenshot of a tweet purportedly written by Trump rhetorically punched back with allegiance to the red state of Texas and its baseball team.
3: "Fine you boo me DC?
4: Go #Astros, Texas loves me, I get the best kind of love there.
5: I’ll be renaming the White House the Orange House," stated the Oct. 27 post , which was posted on Facebook.
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Trump didn’t really write that.
9: We looked through Trump’s tweets on Oct. 27 and found he did not tweet about being booed at the game.
10: We also searched through deleted tweets on ProPublica’s Politwoops website and didn’t find it there either.
11: The screenshot appears to be created using a fake tweet generator , which mimics real accounts but is most definitely not.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump allegedly tweeted, "Fine you boo me DC?
Go #Astros, Texas loves me, I get the best kind of love there.
I’ll be renaming the White House the Orange House" is false.

Evidence to support this statement includes the fact that a careful review of Trump's tweets on October 27 showed that he never made any mention of this quote, therefore asserting that Trump didn't write that [8][9].
Further investigation through deleted tweets on ProPublica's Politwoops website also did not uncover the alleged statement [10].
Furthermore, the origin of the screenshot appears to be a fake tweet generator, a tool designed to fabricate and mimic real-account tweets but is not real or factual[11].

b631e9316fc0bceee1773079e9871c7b.claim: Say Sen. Lindsey Graham supports the Green New Deal.
b631e9316fc0bceee1773079e9871c7b.label: false
b631e9316fc0bceee1773079e9871c7b.passage:
0: A tiny progressive advocacy PAC with less than $500 on hand bought an ad on Facebook as a media stunt.
1: The Really Online Lefty League’s ad falsely showed Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., endorsing the broad climate change policy known as the Green New Deal .
2: The Green New Deal calls for pretty much the entire country to mobilize and bring the United States to net-zero emissions by 2050 –– the point where it adds no more carbon to the atmosphere than is captured.
3: Government action would be massive.
4: Graham, a firm conservative, has railed against the idea.
5: But in the ad , he says, "We believe in the Green New Deal."
6: The man behind the ad, Adriel Hampton, a communications strategist in San Francisco, said he got the idea from a House hearing when Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., pressed Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.
7: "Could I run ads targeting Republicans in primaries saying that they voted for the Green New Deal?"
8: Ocasio-Cortez asked.
9: Zuckerberg said, "Probably."
10: Here’s what viewers of the ad see and hear, and then, we provide what Graham actually said.
11: The ad The ad’s headline is "Conservatives for a Green New Deal," and it displays in a corner throughout the minute-and-a-half long ad.
12: It begins with video of Republican Presidents Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon talking about the need to protect the environment.
13: Nixon oversaw the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency and major amendments to both the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, two pillars of American environmental legislation.
14: The ad then shifts to a news conference with Graham at the podium.
15: "I’m Sen. Graham of South Carolina," Graham says.
16: "I’m here to announce with my colleagues that we care about conservation."
17: Graham’s voice continues as images of wind turbines and pine branches gently swaying in the breeze fill the screen.
18: "We care about the environment," Graham continues.
19: "From a Republican point of view, I think we need to look at the science, admit that climate change is real.
20: Simply put, we believe in the Green New Deal."
21: For good measure, the ad shows a picture with Graham and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a prime author of the Green New Deal, shoulder to shoulder at a rally, arms raised in victory.
22: The photo of Graham and Ocasio-Cortez is faked, as is his stated support for the Green New Deal The reality The original photo was of Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez, taken in 2018.
23: Graham’s head replaced Sanders’.
24: The audio editing of Graham’s news conference was masked by cutting away from the video of the event to add new images.
25: Here are key excerpts from Graham’s event .
26: "From a Republican point of view I think we need to showcase that we care about conservation –– we care about the environment," Graham said.
27: And then he went on : "We have innovative solutions that are not top-down regulatory solutions," he said.
28: "We believe that you cannot have a healthy environment and destroy the economy and we believe that our friends on the other side care about the environment, but they care so much, they're going to destroy the economy."
29: Graham did say, "When nine out of ten scientists say that CO2 admissions are creating a greenhouse gas effect, that the planet is warming up, I believe the nine not the tenth."
30: He did say "look at the science, admit that climate change is real," but here’s what he said about the Green New Deal.
31: "There's not one Republican going to vote for anything coming out of the Green New Deal ‘cause it’s  crazy."

gpt4: The claim that Sen. Lindsey Graham supports the Green New Deal is untrue.
The Really Online Lefty League's ad, which gave rise to this claim, was found to be deceptive and a manipulation of original content [1].
It portrayed Graham, a known conservative, endorsing the Green New Deal, which is against his established stand on the policy [4].
In fact, he has publicly criticized the Green New Deal, calling it "crazy" and has stated that no Republican would vote for it [31].
Moreover, the ad used a doctored photo showing Graham with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a key advocate of the Green New Deal.
In reality, the original image was of Ocasio-Cortez with Sen. Bernie Sanders, taken in 2018 [22].
Similarly, the supposed audio of Graham's support in the ad was doctored too.
The audio editing was masked cleverly by cutting away from the original footage of the news conference and overlaying fabricated images [24].
Thus, the claim about Sen. Lindsey Graham's support for the Green New Deal is clearly a fabrication.

fe2d75787f4c5a4d1a99c7c6c409f016.claim: " Schuyler VanValkenburg co-sponsored a bill that would have ""allowed abortion until the moment of birth."""
fe2d75787f4c5a4d1a99c7c6c409f016.label: false
fe2d75787f4c5a4d1a99c7c6c409f016.passage:
0: Republican GayDonna Vandergriff has turned to abortion in her effort to portray Democrat Del.
1: Schuyler VanValkenburg as "too extreme" for the 72nd House District in wetern Henrico County.
2: Vandergriff recently sent voters a mailer with a colored picture of a mother nuzzling a newborn, and a black and white shot of VanValkenburg in the background.
3: "Did her life have value 10 minutes before she was born?"
4: the capitalized print asks.
5: "Socialist Democrat Schuyler VanValkenburg says no."
6: The flip side says "Schuyler VanValkenburg was the co-sponsor of the Democratic bill that would have allowed abortion until the moment of birth."
7: We fact checked this statement.
8: Vandergriff’s mailer erroneously cites as its source a bill that made no mention of abortion.
9: It would have required health insurers to cover pasteurized, donated human breast milk, which in rare instance is needed for infants.
10: The measure never came up for a vote and died.
11: Matt Williams, spokesman for Vandergriff’s campaign, said the correct source is an unsuccessful bill that would have eased the state abortion restrictions.
12: It was introduced in January 2019 by Del.
13: Kathy Tran, D-Fairfax.
14: VanValkenburg was among 21 Democratic co-sponsors .
15: Debate focused on the bill’s provisions for rare third-trimester abortions, which are allowed if three physicians certify that a continued pregnancy would "likely" kill a woman or "substantially and irremediably" harm her mental or physical health.
16: The legislation would have lowered the threshold of certifying physicians to one.
17: That doctor would have to attest that the pregnancy would damage a woman’s health.
18: The "substantial and irremediable" test would have been repealed.
19: Tran, under tough questioning by Republicans during a Jan. 28 hearing, acknowledged her legislation would allow an abortion when a mother is dilating.
20: Many Republicans claim the bill shows Democrats support "abortion to the time of birth."
21: The bill died on a partisan 5-3 vote in a House subcommittee VanValkenburg doesn’t sit on.
22: Third trimester abortions are extremely rare; the state Department of Health has recorded two this century.
23: But even with failure of Tran’s bill, they are legal in Virginia.
24: The Supreme Court ruled in its 1973 Roe v Wade decision that states may prohibit an abortion after fetal viability if there are exceptions to protect the life or mental or physical health of the mother.
25: This undercuts Vandergriff’s claim that the bill would have "allowed abortion until the moment of birth."
26: That possibility already existed.
27: Virginia law allows third-trimester abortions if three doctors certify that "the continuation of the pregnancy is likely to result in the dealth of the woman or substantially and irremediably impair the mental or physical health of the woman."
28: Tran’s bill would have eased those requirements.
29: Vandergriff is not the only candidate misstating the bill.
30: During the course of writing this fact-check, Sen. Siobhan Dunnavant, R-Henrico, began making similar charges against her opponent, Del.
31: Debra Rodman.
32: Rodman also co-sponsored Tran’s bill and next to Tran while she was testified in the January hearing.
33: Dunnavant has sent a mailer saying Rodman "proposed legalizing abortion in the ninth month."
34: Dunnavant is also running a TV ad saying, "Debra Rodman’s bill would allow late-term abortions for any reason up to the moment of birth."

gpt4: The claim that Schuyler VanValkenburg co-sponsored a bill that would have "allowed abortion until the moment of birth" is false.

While it's true that VanValkenburg was a co-sponsor of a Democratic bill related to abortion[6], Vandergriff’s campaign seems to have inaccurately cited its source, referring to a bill that doesn't mention abortion[8].
According to Matt Williams, a spokesman for Vandergriff’s campaign, the correct source of the claim is an unsuccessful bill aimed at easing state abortion restrictions[11].

However, the debate around the bill was centred on its provisions for rare third-trimester abortions, which could be performed if three physicians certified that continuing the pregnancy would either "likely" result in the woman's death or "substantially and irremediably" harm her mental or physical health[15].
Current Virginia law already allows such third-trimester abortions under these stringent conditions[27].
This context undermines Vandergriff's claim that the bill would have permitted abortions "until the moment of birth"[25].

9268e416f5a9768d6f5b7de6e596b083.claim: there is a 4,250% increase in fetal death from the flu shot.
9268e416f5a9768d6f5b7de6e596b083.label: false
9268e416f5a9768d6f5b7de6e596b083.passage:
0: As flu season begins, some Instagram users are posting photos with misinformation about vaccines.
1: In one post published Oct. 22, an account called Holistic Health & More, which has more than 165,000 followers, claimed the flu shot can lead to the death of fetuses.
2: "4250% increase fetal death from flu shot," the photo reads.
3: "CDC failed to tell pregnant mothers of the increase (sic) chance of miscarriage & stillbirth after receiving CDC recommended flu vaccine."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook , Instagram’s parent company.)
6: It has more than 1,700 likes, and PolitiFact found several copies of the post elsewhere on the internet.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Instagram) As evidence for its claim, Holistic Health & More linked to a website called VacTruth.com, a known publisher of anti-vaccine misinformation .
8: The site requires a password to enter, so we were not able to locate the article in question.
9: Holistic Health & More did not respond to a message requesting more evidence.
10: We found one study that did observe a spike in "spontaneous abortion," or miscarriage, among women who had been vaccinated for the flu — but the bulk of research has found no link between the vaccine and infant mortality.
11: Importantly, medical officials still recommend pregnant women get the flu shot because they can be more prone to severe illness from the flu, as can their babies.
12: Where the post came from We traced the Instagram post to an anti-vaccine blog entry from November 2016.
13: The blog, Health Freedom Idaho, is part of a libertarian movement that opposes health regulations and advocates for nontraditional care.
14: The blog post links to a 2013 study published by the journal Human & Experimental Toxicology.
15: It looked at miscarriages and stillbirths listed in the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), a database of reported vaccine side effects maintained by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration.
16: RELATED: No, you’re not an ‘active, live walking virus’ for 2 weeks following a flu shot The study found an increase in "fetal loss reports" among pregnant women who received the flu shot during two consecutive seasons, from 2008 to 2009 and from 2009 to 2010.
17: (The season typically spans from fall to spring.)
18: Approximately 587,600 pregnant women were vaccinated with the standard flu shot in 2008-09, and about 2,236,000 pregnant women were vaccinated with the standard flu shot and/or the swine flu vaccine the next year.
19: The study noted a jump in fetal loss reports from four in 2008-09 to 174 in 2009-10.
20: That’s a 4,250% increase — but it doesn’t mean you should interpret it the way this blogger did.
21: The researchers did not prove that the flu shot was the cause of the uptick.
22: The CDC lists several limitations of this data.
23: The reason why it’s unreliable has to do with the fact that health care providers are encouraged to report any health problems following the administration of vaccines — even if they don’t believe the vaccine was the cause.
24: "Reports may include incomplete, inaccurate, coincidental and unverified information," the CDC’s list of limitations reads.
25: "The number of reports alone cannot be interpreted or used to reach conclusions about the existence, severity, frequency, or rates of problems associated with vaccines."
26: Experts concurred with those limitations.
27: "The study you cite is trying to do something with VAERS data which is not valid," said Daniel Salmon, director of the Institute for Vaccine Safety at Johns Hopkins University’s School of Public Health, in an email.
28: "The results of this study do not contribute to our scientific understanding of the issue."
29: Other research shows no link The study cited by the Instagram post isn’t the only one to link the flu shot with miscarriages.
30: But most research shows that the vaccine is safe, and the CDC recommends it for all pregnant women so they can avoid complications caused by flu infections.
31: One study , which was published in the journal Vaccine in September 2017, compared nearly 500 pregnant women who had miscarriages during the 2010-11 and 2011-12 flu seasons to the same number of women who had normal deliveries during the same period.
32: Researchers found that, of the women who miscarried, 17 had received the flu shot within a month of miscarrying and also received the vaccine the year prior.
33: However, the study’s authors warned that the results did not suggest a causal link between the flu vaccine and miscarriage — and they still said pregnant women should receive the flu shot.
34: On its website , the CDC also doubts the study’s results.
35: RELATED: Bloggers poison truth in claim about flu shot dangers The CDC says the bulk of research supports the notion that the flu shot is safe for pregnant women and that the risk of miscarriage is low.
36: It cites several studies that have found no increased risk of miscarriage as a result of receiving the flu shot.
37: • A 2013 study published in the journal Obstetrics & Gynecology did not find an increased risk of pregnancy loss within four weeks of receiving the flu vaccine.
38: • A 2014 study published in the Journal of Pediatrics found that, among 57,554 vaccinated and unvaccinated women, the flu vaccine did not lead to an increased or decreased risk of "preterm birth."
39: • A 2017 review of reports to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System between 2010 and 2016 found no evidence to suggest a connection between the flu vaccine and pregnancy complications.
40: • A 2017 study found that, even when it is administered during the first trimester of pregnancy, the flu vaccine was not associated with structural birth defects.
41: In addition to the CDC, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists also recommends that pregnant women receive the flu shot.
42: "In evaluating all of the available scientific information, there is insufficient information to support changing the current recommendation which is to offer and encourage routine flu vaccinations during pregnancy regardless of the trimester of pregnancy," Haywood Brown, former president of the professional association, wrote in September 2017 .

gpt4: The claim that there is a 4,250% increase in fetal death from the flu shot is false.

While one study did observe an increase in spontaneous abortions among women who had been vaccinated for the flu, the authors of the study warned that the results did not suggest a direct causal relationship between the flu vaccine and miscarriages [33][10].

Moreover, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) expressed doubts about the study's results, listing several limitations including the potential for incomplete, inaccurate, coincidental, and unverified information being included [22][23][24].
Multiple other studies have found no increased risk of miscarriage or other pregnancy complications as a result of receiving the flu shot [36][37][39][40].
For instance, a 2014 study involving over 57,000 women didn't find an increased or decreased risk of preterm birth from the flu shot [38].
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists concurs with the CDC's position, recommending the flu shot for all pregnant women [41][42].
Lastly, the source where the claim originates from, VacTruth.com, is a known publisher of anti-vaccine misinformation, further undermining the claim's credibility [7].

9d297e57c5a58599a68033e3af37e721.claim: If folks are vaping a legal medical cannabis product that comes from any of the New York state operators, they will not have to worry about the negative impacts on their lungs.
9d297e57c5a58599a68033e3af37e721.label: half-true
9d297e57c5a58599a68033e3af37e721.passage:
0: Vaping-related illnesses have vexed public health officials and prompted state policymakers to consider banning e-cigarettes .
1: The Centers for Disease Control cited 1,888 reports of lung injuries associated with e-cigarettes or vaping and 37 deaths as of Oct. 29.
2: Those who vape use an electronic cigarette product, such as a vape pen or e-hookah, to heat a liquid to produce an aerosol that they inhale into their lungs.
3: The liquid can contain nicotine, tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), cannabinoid oils (CBD)  and other substances and additives.
4: Most electronic cigarette products contain a battery to heat the liquid.
5: In New York, approved providers offer medical marijuana in several forms, including vape pens and cartridges, and offer THC and CBD in different concentrations, according to a 2018 report from the state Department of Health.
6: In an interview on WBEN radio on Oct. 9, Assembly Majority Leader Crystal Peoples-Stokes assured listeners that vaping medical marijuana from an approved dispensary is safe.
7: "If folks are vaping a legal medical cannabis product that comes from any of the New York state operators, they will not have to worry about the negative impacts on their lungs," Peoples-Stokes said.
8: But is that true?
9: We reached out to Peoples-Stokes’ spokesman, Kevin Jolly, who said that the Majority Leader was following guidance from the state Department of Health.
10: Jolly said the public health concern stems from recent cases of lung injuries from vaping products purchased informally on the street.
11: Peoples-Stokes does not approve of vaping, he said.
12: State urges caution The state Department of Health, however, cautions users of state-approved medical marijuana vape products, even though it has no reports of problems with them.
13: On Sept. 7 , Health Commissioner Dr. Howard Zucker released a statement urging "New Yorkers to stop using vape products while the investigation into the definitive cause of reported vaping-associated illnesses nationwide can be better determined."
14: That statement was also posted on the department’s web page for medical marijuana users .
15: Medical marijuana products are "rigorously tested for contaminants, pesticides and concentration of cannabinoids," the department advised , but it warned that "out of an abundance of caution, we are also urging patients in the medical marijuana program to consult with their health care providers on potential alternatives to vaping products while the investigation continues."
16: There are reasons Peoples-Stokes declared regulated medical marijuana safe for New Yorkers to use.
17: An earlier notice from the state Department of Health, dated Sept. 5, 2019, asked everyone except medical marijuana users to consider not using any vape products.
18: And on Sept. 9, two days after the department cautioned medical marijuana users to consider alternatives to vaping, Gov.
19: Andrew Cuomo said in a news conference about vaping illnesses that "this does not include the medical marijuana products.
20: Those are regulated, and those are safe."
21: At the federal level, the CDC is also investigating the cause of the lung injuries and has  recommended that no one use e-cigarette or vaping products that contain THC, according to Cassie Brailer, press officer for lung injury response at the CDC.
22: The agency knows that THC is present in most of the samples that have been tested and that most lung injury patients report using products that contain THC, Brailer said.
23: National and state findings "suggest products containing THC, particularly those obtained off the street or from other informal sources," are linked to most of the cases, Brailer said.
24: "Since the specific cause or causes of lung injury are not yet known, the only way to assure that you are not at risk while the investigation continues is to consider refraining from use of all e-cigarette and vaping products," Brailer said.
25: Mixed opinions on safety In interviews with four researchers who study public health or cannabis use, we found mixed opinions on whether vaping even a regulated substance such a medical marijuana can have a negative impact on a patient’s lungs.
26: Two experts said that it is too early to tell.
27: One said that vaping any substance can be harmful.
28: And one said that those vaping regulated medical marijuana in New York state should not fear the marijuana but said there are unknowns about the vaping device itself.
29: Mitch Earleywine, a psychology professor at the University at Albany who studies marijuana policy and advocates for reform of cannabis laws, said that flavor-free vape liquids, such as those used in the medical marijuana program in New York, remain under-investigated.
30: He has done research on the vaporizer, which he said appears safe, but there is no long-term data on the vape oil.
31: Ana Maria Rule, an assistant professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, agreed there is not enough data to declare vaping medical marijuana "safe."
32: Another expert, Ilias Kavouras, a professor at the City University of New York Graduate School of Public Health and Health Policy, said that lung damage can be caused by medical marijuana and vaping, including those formed during the process of smoking marijuana or vaping.
33: "There is evidence in the scientific literature that toxic and carcinogenic species are formed during vaping," Kavouras said.
34: A professor of public health at Syracuse University offered a different opinion.
35: Dessa Bergen-Cico, who is coordinator of addiction studies programs at Falk College at SU, said that people who purchase medical marijuana vape cartridges from registered state dispensaries "should not have problems with product safety because the products are highly regulated and tested."
36: However, "it is still unknown if there is something in the vaping devices that is a catalyst for the lung injuries," Bergen-Cico said.

gpt4: While some contend that legally obtained medical cannabis product when vaped, does not harm the lungs, this claim is only partially true.

According to Ilias Kavouras, a professor at the City University of New York Graduate School of Public Health, lung damage can be induced by both medical marijuana and vaping which includes those involved in the smoking or vaping process[32].
The Centers for Disease Control documented 1,888 incidents of e-cigarette or vaping-related lung injuries and 37 deaths as of Oct. 29[1].
Kavouras also pointed out to scientific literature demonstrating the formation of toxic and carcinogenic particles during vaping[33].
Regarding these concerns, the CDC is probing the causes of these lung injuries and has advised against the use of e-cigarettes or vaping substances that have THC[21].
