With many uncertainties still present, refraining from using all vaping products and e-cigarettes was suggested as the only assured method of risk avoidance[24].
Though differing perspectives on safety are found amongst researchers studying public health or cannabis use[25], with some endorsing the view that inhaling any vaped substances can be harmful[27].

A researcher has cited the absence of long-term data regarding vape oils[30] and an assistant professor from Johns Hopkins School of Public Health concurred, indicating that there is not enough data to certify vaping medical marijuana as "safe"[31].

409feeaecc5b9c3471a7e1e60d5ec9f5.claim: Over the last two years, the number of murders in America and America’s major cities has dropped, unlike here (Chicago), by more than 10%.
409feeaecc5b9c3471a7e1e60d5ec9f5.label: false
409feeaecc5b9c3471a7e1e60d5ec9f5.passage:
0: During his first visit to Chicago since taking office, President Donald Trump took aim at one of his favorite targets: the city’s violence.
1: While criticizing Chicago Police Supt.
2: Eddie Johnson for boycotting his speech to the International Association of Chiefs of Police Monday, Trump again repeated a Pants on Fire!
3: claim about the city having the nation’s strictest gun laws , compared violence in Chicago to Afghanistan — as he has in the past with Baltimore — and contended reductions in crime here are failing to keep pace with those being made nationally.
4: "Over the last two years, the number of murders in America and America’s major cities has dropped, unlike here, by more than 10%," Trump said .
5: "And if we ever took the Chicago numbers out of our total numbers, the numbers would be incredible — and they already are, even including Chicago."
6: Nationally, murders have not decreased by quite as much as the president said.
7: What’s more, his Chicago comparison is contradicted by city and federal data.
8: Not only has Chicago seen murders fall by significantly more than 10% in recent years, its decline is rivaled by few other large cities.
9: Press officers at the White House did not respond to our request for comment.
10: Chicago taking a lead, not falling behind Chicago has seen 27% fewer murders so far this year than it had at this time two years ago, Chicago Police Department data for mid-October show.
11: Preliminary federal data for 2019 is not yet available, however, so we compared the latest federal data — from 2018 — with figures for 2016 .
12: That’s the year Johnson became the city’s top cop .
13: It’s also a year that saw a significant spike in Chicago murders, ending with 765 in all, a total greater than the tallies for New York City and Los Angeles combined.
14: Those figures, which are reported by local law enforcement agencies to the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting program, show Trump missed the mark on multiple counts.
15: First, the number of murders reported nationwide for 2018 was 6.9% lower than it was in 2016 — not more than 10%, as he claimed.
16: Second, the declines experienced by Chicago during the same period — from 765 murders to 563 — were larger than those seen in all but three of the nation’s 30 largest cities: San Antonio, San Diego and San Jose.
17: It’s a turnaround that’s garnered considerable news coverage over the past two years.
18: In 2018, for instance, the Chicago Sun-Times reviewed FBI data for the previous year and found Chicago alone accounted for 86% of the net decrease from 2016 in murders nationally.
19: That marked decline is also something Johnson turned to in defense when responding to Trump’s attack.
20: "The president is right about one thing: Violent crime in the United States declined last year for the second consecutive year," Johnson said at a news conference Monday .
21: "But it was Chicago that set the table for those reductions."
22: Ames Grawert, who leads the quantitative research team at the New York University School of Law’s Brennan Center for Justice, said that although Chicago’s per capita murder rate is still more than four times higher than the national average, the city has made considerable progress in recent years — something Trump’s comments ignore.
23: "He’s dead wrong on Chicago," Grawert said.
24: "The city’s gotten a lot safer in the past two years and it’s not right to say Chicago’s lagging the national trend … It’s one of the cities that’s led the downward trend of the last two years."

gpt4: The claim that the number of murders in America and its major cities, excluding Chicago, has dropped by over 10% in the past two years, is false.
Statistics show that nationwide, the reduction of murders reported for 2018 was 6.9% lower than the figure for 2016, not in excess of 10% as the claim posits [15].
However, Chicago defies this trend, as it has seen a decrease in homicides.
Chicago Police Department data for mid-October show the city has experienced a 27% reduction in murders compared to the same period two years prior [10].
Furthermore, Chicago's decline in the murder count, going from 765 to 563, is larger than the declines experienced by all but three of the United States' 30 largest cities [16].
Therefore, these facts contradict the assertion that Chicago has seen less of a decrease in murder rates compared to other major American cities.
Instead, it suggests that Chicago is taking a lead in crime reduction, not falling behind as the claim insinuates [6].

cd863936f42859a7408abfccac2e6c7f.claim: "  House Democrats’ impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump ""doesn’t feature the opposition party, it doesn’t feature cross-examination."""
cd863936f42859a7408abfccac2e6c7f.label: false
cd863936f42859a7408abfccac2e6c7f.passage:
0: Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh wrongly claimed that House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump are keeping Republicans out of their hearings.
1: More than 40 Republican lawmakers disrupted witness testimony on Oct. 23 by storming a secure room and chanting, "Let us in!"
2: Many news outlets and top Democrats quickly pointed out that roughly a dozen of the protesting Republicans already had access to the depositions they were demanding to hear.
3: Still, Limbaugh and others have charged that Republicans have been shut out of the House’s impeachment inquiry into Trump’s actions on Ukraine.
4: "The thing that, of course, is top-drawer today and has been all week is what little Adam pencil-neck Schiff is doing behind closed doors in a so-called impeachment inquiry that doesn’t feature the opposition party, it doesn’t feature cross-examination, no transcripts are released, everything’s being done in private, only selected leaks, you know the drill," Limbaugh said Oct. 25 on his radio show.
5: Limbaugh’s comments were made before House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s decision Oct. 28 to bring the probe to a more open phase, starting with an Oct. 31 vote on a resolution to affirm the ongoing investigation and start public hearings.
6: Limbaugh, who did not respond to requests for comment, has a point that the impeachment hearings have so far taken place behind closed doors, without transcripts being formally released.
7: (News outlets have obtained transcripts of prepared witness remarks in some cases.)
8: But he is wrong that the hearings have excluded House Republicans, 47 of whom sit on the three committees that have been leading the investigation.
9: Participation is based on committee, not party The Constitution says little about procedures for impeachment: The House "shall have the sole Power of Impeachment" and the Senate "shall have the sole Power to try all Impeachments."
10: In three previous impeachments , the full House authorized inquiries and the House Judiciary Committee took the lead in conducting investigations, holding hearings and voting on whether to approve articles of impeachment.
11: This time around, Pelosi opened the inquiry without a formal vote, a move Republicans criticized .
12: She instructed three House committees — Oversight, Intelligence and Foreign Affairs — to carry out an investigation that the House Judiciary Committee will use to draft any articles of impeachment.
13: There are nine Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee , 17 are on the House Oversight Committee , and 21 are on the House Foreign Affairs Committee .
14: By contrast, those three committees feature 13, 23 and 26 Democrats, respectively, with four Democrats sitting on two of them at the same time.
15: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com All 47 of those Republicans have been able to participate and ask questions in the interviews and depositions held to this point, said Ashley Etienne, Pelosi’s communications director, in an email.
16: Experts told us the same thing.
17: Other House members, such as Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz, who organized the Oct. 23 protest, have been kept out of the hearings not because they are Republicans, but because they are not on the relevant committees.
18: And some, such as Rep. Ted Yoho of Florida, have chosen not to attend despite being able to.
19: There is no constitutional provision that says a president or his allies must be allowed to cross-examine witnesses during a House impeachment inquiry.
20: "Nothing in either the Constitution or House rules requires public hearings and/or cross-examination at this stage," said Ilya Somin, professor of law at George Mason University.
21: When Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., said the inquiry was denying Trump "due process accorded every American," we rated his statement False .
22: If such rights apply at all, they would be granted during the Senate’s trial phase.
23: "The House impeachment inquiry is equivalent to a grand jury investigation in a criminal case," said Suzanna Sherry, professor of law at Vanderbilt University.
24: "And there is no opportunity for cross-examination when evidence is presented to the grand jury."
25: Republicans also have the ability to ask questions of witnesses at hearings, Sherry said, which is "more opportunity for cross-examination than is given to a target of a grand jury investigation."
26: "By any ordinary definition, that would amount to ‘cross-examination,’" said Frank O.
27: Bowman III, professor of law at the University of Missouri and the author of a book on impeachment.

gpt4: The claim that the House Democrats' impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump doesn't feature the opposition party or cross-examination is false.

This claim is contradicted by the fact that there are 47 House Republicans who sit on the three committees leading the investigation, thereby invalidating the assertion that the inquiry doesn't feature the opposition party [8].

Moreover, all 47 of these Republicans have been participating and asking questions during the interviews and depositions so far, debunking the claim that there is no facility for cross-examination [15].

It is noteworthy that some Republicans, like Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz, who organized a protest demanding access to the depositions, were excluded from the hearings not because they belong to the opposition party, but because they weren't part of the relevant committees [17].
Further, it was pointed out that many news outlets and top Democrats that about a dozen of the protesting Republicans already had access to the depositions they were demanding to hear [2].

Furthermore, it has been observed that Republicans do have the ability to ask questions to witnesses at hearings, representing even more opportunity for cross-examination than is given to a target during a grand jury investigation [25].

dd4b69fe6031518d2900e1fcb180c548.claim: giving Motrin and Robitussin together can cause heart attacks in children.
dd4b69fe6031518d2900e1fcb180c548.label: false
dd4b69fe6031518d2900e1fcb180c548.passage:
0: Dubious medical advice is not only plentiful on social media – it’s persistent.
1: Such is the case for a decade-old email chain that warns against giving children a combination of Motrin and Robitussin, because they may have a heart attack.
2: One example of the claim, which has been popping up in email inboxes since at least 2008 , has gotten over 115,000 shares on Facebook and says that an 8-year-old girl named Madison passed away after she was allegedly given both medications: "This was sent to us from a nurse in our district  … thought I’d pass along just as an FYI.
3: Motrin and Robitussin don’t mix!!!
4: Madison, age 8, passed away just a few days ago.
5: We’ve been asked to pass this on.
6: Doctors told her family that there have been quite a few children Madison’s age that have died recently the same way that she did.
7: The only common link between them was that they were given Motrin (ibuprofen) and Robitussin together, this caused a heart attack.
8: They believe this is what happened to them.
9: They told her to alert everyone to this.
10: ‘Do not give children both of these medicines together.’ You can give them one or the other but not both.
11: When Madison collapsed she suffered a heart attack and they were able to revive her but the loss of oxygen damaged her brain and she was put on the respirator.
12: After this she had four strokes before she died after being taken off the respirator.
13: Please pass this on !!!!!!!!!"
14: The bottom of the post has the email signature: "Lisa Lopez M.A.
15: Children’s Medical Center of Dallas Pulmonary Clinic."
16: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
17: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
18: This rumor is just that –– a rumor.
19: There is no evidence to suggest that a Motrin-Robitussin combination causes heart attacks in otherwise healthy children.
20: The Children’s Medical Center in Dallas, Texas, that appeared in the email signature came out to dispel the rumor in 2010, roughly a year after it started being shared.
21: The hospital’s announcement said the following: "In 2009, a Children’s employee received the e-mail from a friend and inadvertently forwarded it from a work account.
22: Because the employee’s professional signature was included at the bottom of the e-mail, the information appeared to come from a reliable source at Children’s Medical Center.
23: This is not the case."
24: All medications have side effects, the hospital noted, and "parents of children with underlying medical conditions must always be vigilant about the medications their child is taking."
25: The hospital statement advised parents to consult with their children’s doctor or a pharmacist before mixing any over-the-counter drugs.
26: The Children’s Medical Center also addressed the rumor in a tweet on Dec. 22, 2014 : "Facebook post about Motrin & Robitussin is not correct & was not posted by one of our employees."
27: The tweet linked to a 2009 fact-check by Snopes on the topic.
28: It’s important to note that the Food and Drug Administration does not recommend children under the age of two be given cough-cold medications.
29: But the agency has not issued any warnings that the ingredients in Motrin (which contains ibuprofen) or Robitussin (which contains dextromethorphan and/or pseudoephedrine or sometimes chlorpheniramine) could cause heart attacks in children when combined.
30: These ingredients are also in many other medications on the market, yet the chain email only singles out Motrin and Robitussin.
31: If the danger of heart attacks, strokes or death was prevalent in the combination of two commonly used medications, health officials would have issued widespread public health warnings.
32: Motrin alone is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, and according to the FDA, the labels of over-the-counter versions warn that for adults and children "(nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), except aspirin, increase the risk of heart attack, heart failure, and stroke.
33: These can be fatal.
34: The risk is higher if you use more than directed or for longer than directed."
35: Ashley Turney, an FDA spokesperson for over-the-counter drugs, told PolitiFact that "use of Robitussin products, with or without Motrin, is not associated with heart attacks."
36: She described Robitussin as an umbrella brand containing a series of children’s cough and cold products that may contain a single ingredient or combinations of dextromethorphan hydrobromide, guaifenesin, phenylephrine hydrochloride, or chlorpheniramine maleate.
37: "The recommended use, dosing, and warnings vary amongst the seven Robitussin products that are intended for use in children over 4 or 6 years," she said.
38: Turney noted that it’s important for people to read the drug facts label directions for all over-the-counter medications.

gpt4: The claim that giving Motrin and Robitussin together can cause heart attacks in children is unfounded and has been categorically dismissed by various trustworthy sources.

Shortly after the rumor began circulating online, the Children’s Medical Center in Dallas, Texas, whose name was falsified in the email chain perpetuating this misinformation, expressly refuted the allegation in 2010[20][18].
Ashley Turney, an FDA spokesperson for over-the-counter drugs, also confirmed that using these products in combination has never been linked to heart attacks[35].

Furthermore, it was emphasized that no evidence supports that a Motrin-Robitussin combination (where Motrin contains ibuprofen and Robitussin contains dextromethorphan and/or pseudoephedrine or sometimes chlorpheniramine) can spark heart attacks in healthy children[19][29].
Despite these clarifications, parents are still urged to discuss potential medication combinations with a healthcare provider or pharmacist[25].

e313c7b5cd275bc567887d274ae0503b.claim: As we have learned, the Intel Inspector General (IG) changed the rule after the complaint was known in order to allow hearsay complaints, but the IG dishonestly backdated the rule change so that damage could be done to President Trump.
e313c7b5cd275bc567887d274ae0503b.label: false
e313c7b5cd275bc567887d274ae0503b.passage:
0: In an op-ed written for The Daily Caller, U.S. Rep. Louie Gohmert repeated a false claim about the whistleblower complaint behind the ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump.
1: "As we have learned, the Intel Inspector General (IG) changed the rule after the complaint was known in order to allow hearsay complaints, but the IG dishonestly backdated the rule change so that damage could be done to President Trump," wrote Gohmert, a Republican from Tyler.
2: The claim is similar to a False statement circulated by Trump at the end of September, with some different details.
3: But the same truth remains: No rules regulating whistleblowers were changed.
4: The form for submitting a complaint was altered, but the rules stayed the same.
5: Trump’s tweet, original theory In September, Trump shared a tweet (in all capital letters) that suggested questionable bureaucratic changes allowed the whistleblower complaint to be accepted, when it normally would not have met the threshold for a complaint.
6: "Who changed the long standing whistleblower rules just before submittal of the fake whistleblower report?"
7: Trump said.
8: "Drain the swamp!"
9: We rated Trump’s claim False .

gpt4: The claim that the Intel Inspector General (IG) altered rules to permit hearsay complaints after the complaint was made public, and dishonestly backdated this change to damage President Trump, is unfounded.
The actual change was made on the form used to submit a complaint, not the rules themselves, retaining the requirement for firsthand information [4].
Therefore, the rules governing the admissibility of complaints were not revised retrospectively or altered to permit hearsay.
Based on this, the assertion suggesting any manipulation or dishonesty by the IG to harm President Trump is without evidence.

bddbb16d7f0f1189e10c31c8d7eb219f.claim: "  CNN called Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi an ""unarmed father of three."""
bddbb16d7f0f1189e10c31c8d7eb219f.label: false
bddbb16d7f0f1189e10c31c8d7eb219f.passage:
0: A viral photo of a CNN chyron makes it look like the network sympathized with Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the former Islamic State leader, after he died in an American raid.
1: But the image is fake.
2: The post was published on Facebook Oct. 27 — the day after the raid on Baghdadi’s compound in northwestern Syria.
3: It has been shared more than 2,500 times.
4: "Trump Kills Unarmed Father of Three," reads the chyron.
5: "President calls brave ISIS fighter a ’coward & dog’ … credits Russia in brutal slaying."
6: The post, which has been published by several other pages and users, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Some commenters took it as a joke, and others thought it might be real.
9: CNN never aired a chyron calling Baghdadi an "unarmed father of three."
10: The pieces of the image were manipulated.
11: The image of Don Lemon, host of "CNN Tonight," has been online since at least January , according to a Google reverse image search.
12: The photo of Baghdadi is real — it was taken from a video posted by the Islamic State’s propaganda arm in April.
13: It could have aired on CNN during Baghdadi coverage, albeit not with this chyron.
14: We checked CNN captions since the raid was carried out Oct. 26.
15: We could find no mention of the word "unarmed."
16: We also checked "CNN Tonight" archives and could not find a chyron that matched the one in the viral photo.
17: Then there’s the timing of the chyron.
18: "This is fake," said Christal Jones, a senior public relations manager at CNN, in an email.
19: "Don’s show airs weeknights 10pm to midnight.
20: The clip shows a time of 9:01pmET."
21: The Facebook post is not accurate and makes a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that CNN labeled Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi as an "unarmed father of three" is false.
In examining the validity of the image behind this claim, it was established that it was doctored and therefore not authentic[1].
Furthermore, the elements of the said image were found to be manipulated[10].
Comprehensive reviews of CNN's broadcasts in the "CNN Tonight" archives did not show any instance where such a chyron was aired, thus further refuting the claim[16].
Consequently, CNN has never referred to Baghdadi as an "unarmed father of three"[9].

cbeffeb04a7144de4d8bf272873abfa6.claim: "  Barbara Walters said Jane Fonda ""betrayed not only the idea of our country, but specific men who served and sacrificed during the Vietnam War."""
cbeffeb04a7144de4d8bf272873abfa6.label: false
cbeffeb04a7144de4d8bf272873abfa6.passage:
0: Actress Jane Fonda was recently arrested during a climate change protest, perhaps inspiring Facebook users to share an old message about her history as a Vietnam War objector.
1: The long Aug. 13 post , which details allegations about Fonda that other fact-checkers have debunked , begins: "Barbara Walters writes: Unfortunately, many have forgotten and still countless others have never known how Ms. Fonda betrayed not only the idea of our country, but specific men who served and sacrificed during the Vietnam War."
2: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The text in the post has, with some variations, been circulating online for about two decades.
5: FactCheck.org fact-checked it in November 2010.
6: Snopes tackled it in June 2000.
7: That’s about a year after Barbara Walters hosted a special for ABC News that aired on April 30, 1999, called, "A Celebration: 100 Years of Great Women."
8: Fonda was one of the women selected by the Ladies Home Journal as one of the 100 most important women of the 20th century.
9: Walters described Fonda at different points in her life as a sex kitten, an activist and a wife.
10: She said Fonda stopped acting in the 1990s and "now spends much of her time on her favorite cause, preventing teenage pregnancy."
11: She doesn’t say what the Facebook post attributes to her.
12: She also didn’t say it in 1988, when she interviewed Fonda, who apologized for her participation in being photographed while seated in a North Vietnamese anti-aircraft gun in 1972, according to an ABC News transcript we found in the Nexis news archive.
13: "Jane Fonda told me that she now realizes in her urgent desire to end the war, she unthinkingly caused pain to many Americans who fought in Vietnam," Walters said.
14: "In our interview tonight, she speaks directly to former prisoners of war, to Vietnam veterans and their families.
15: And confronting her past, she then apologizes."
16: Searching Nexis further, we couldn’t find evidence that Walters said or wrote the statement that appears in the Facebook post.
17: There were no results when we searched Newspapers.com .
18: Looking online we couldn’t find a credible source connecting Walters to the viral message either.

gpt4: The claim that Barbara Walters stated Jane Fonda "betrayed not only the idea of our country, but specific men who served and sacrificed during the Vietnam War" is false.
The assertion made in the Facebook post cannot be attributed to Walters as there is no evidence of her making such a statement[11].
Extensive searches on Nexis, a comprehensive database of news and legal information, failed to provide any supporting evidence[16].
Furthermore, an independent online search did not reveal any credible sources linking Walters to the viral message[18].
Therefore, the statement that Walters made these comments about Jane Fonda's actions during the Vietnam War is not substantiated by the available data.

d04b95aee316ff794f7ab76fcab638f4.claim: "  drinking cream of tartar mixed with orange juice daily will help people quit smoking because it ""flushes the nicotine"" out of the body."
d04b95aee316ff794f7ab76fcab638f4.label: false
d04b95aee316ff794f7ab76fcab638f4.passage:
0: Quitting smoking is hard.
1: Over the years, ex-smokers have sworn by a myriad of methods: pills, patches, cold turkey.
2: The list goes on.
3: But one cheap and easy quit-smoking-fast tactic making the rounds on Facebook sounds too easy to be true.
4: And that’s because it is.
5: According to a viral Facebook post that’s been shared over 300,000 times since Oct. 14, simply mixing cream of tartar powder with orange juice will "flush the nicotine out of your system."
6: The post features a picture of cream of tartar with a lengthy caption that says: "Go to your favorite grocery store and buy Cream of Tartar Seasoning and a gallon of Orange Juice.
7: Mix 1 teaspoon in a glass and drink once a day.
8: I recommend when you get up and another glass halfway through your day.
9: I know this sounds too simple, but it really works!
10: The Cream of Tartar flushes the nicotine out of your system and blocks it from receiving it again!
11: After about two days, smoking tastes like s***, you're blocked from the nicotine rush and the desire is gone!"
12: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
13: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
14: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that drinking cream of tartar and orange juice rids the body of nicotine and thus helps people quit smoking.
15: We found a detailed example of the claim in a May 2018 article by Shareably, a lifestyle and entertainment website.
16: But the article lacks credible sources, instead citing dubious health websites "Natural Health and Healing 4U" and "Organic Health."
17: It also lists Providr.com as its primary source –– a clickbait mill that the fact-checking website Snopes exposed for fraudulent Facebook practices in 2018.
18: The basis behind the claim is problematic because it relies on unsupported theories about detoxifying the body through various diets or cleanses.
19: The National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health , an office of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, says that a variety of detoxification diets, regimens and therapies "have been suggested as ways to remove toxins from your body, lose weight, or promote health."
20: However, the center warns that some of these programs can be unsafe and falsely advertised, and said a 2015 review concluded "there was no compelling research to support the use of "detox" diets for weight management or eliminating toxins from the body."
21: The Shareably article alleges that the way cream of tartar helps "flush" nicotine out of the body is by getting "your adrenal glands working in conjunction with the rest of your body... Then your body naturally decides which toxins to eliminate through bowel movements, urine, and sweat."
22: But it is unclear how that could even work.
23: While potassium-rich cream of tartar has a diuretic effect , meaning it increases urine production, this doesn’t explain how it would somehow impact metabolism.
24: "I know of no biological mechanism by which cream of tartar would get the adrenal glands working," Neal Benowitz, professor emeritus at the Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education at the University of California, San Francisco, told PolitiFact in an email.
25: "The vast majority of nicotine is eliminated by liver metabolism, and only a small fraction excreted unchanged in the urine."
26: Benowitz said he knows no "biologically plausible argument" for why this drink mixture should work.

gpt4: The claim that drinking cream of tartar mixed with orange juice daily helps people quit smoking because it "flushes the nicotine" out of the body is false.
First and foremost, there is no scientific evidence to back up this claim [14].
The claim lacks credible sources, and instead, references doubtful health websites such as "Natural Health and Healing 4U" and "Organic Health"[16].
Additionally, the Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education warns that such programs can often be unsafe, falsely advertised, and not supported by robust research [20].
Neal Benowitz, a professor emeritus at the Center, stated that there is no known biological mechanism whereby cream of tartar could stimulate the adrenal glands to effect this claimed outcome [24].
Furthermore, he articulates that there is no "biologically plausible argument" for the effective role of this drink mixture in helping people quit smoking [26].

b7a9234c14898272be77bbd584f0d207.claim: Starting January 1, 2020, California will tax legal citizens if they don’t have health insurance. Why? The state needs to come up with $98,000,000 to pay for free health insurance for illegal aliens.
b7a9234c14898272be77bbd584f0d207.label: half-true
b7a9234c14898272be77bbd584f0d207.passage:
0: A leader of a student group that supports President Donald Trump claimed that California is "putting illegals first" when it comes to health care.
1: "Starting January 1, 2020, California will tax legal citizens if they don’t have health insurance.
2: Why?
3: The state needs to come up with $98,000,000 to pay for free health insurance for illegal aliens.
4: Why do Democrat’s (sic) keep putting illegals first?"
5: tweeted Ryan Fournier, founder and co-chairman of Students for Trump .
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A screenshot of the tweet was posted on Facebook Oct. 21.
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: Fournier told PolitiFact his claim was based on two June articles, one from a TV station in Los Angeles and the other from USA Today.
10: The KTLA article said the California legislature voted to tax Californians who don’t have health coverage starting Jan. 1, 2020.
11: The USA Today story said California would become the first state to offer health coverage to low-income adults living illegally in the country and that the plan would cost $98 million.
12: Overall, the state does plan to impose a tax penalty on people without health care insurance, and it also plans to expand coverage for immigrants living illegally in the state.
13: But the two moves aren’t directly related.
14: Revenues from the tax will go toward subsidies to help Californians reduce the cost of their health care coverage.
15: Other revenues are being used to pay for health care for unauthorized immigrants.
16: California’s health care mandate A new mandate in California, effective Jan. 1, 2020, will require Californians to have health insurance throughout the year.
17: Californians who don’t have health coverage in 2020 — and who don’t qualify for exemptions — would have to pay a penalty in 2021 when they file their 2020 state income tax return.
18: The requirement is modeled after the individual mandate that was included in the federal Affordable Care Act, but effectively eliminated by Congress after Trump took office.
19: California’s penalty is expected to generate about $317 million beginning in 2020-2021, said an Oct. 17 report from the Legislative Analyst’s Office, the California legislature’s nonpartisan fiscal and policy advisor.
20: Those revenues will help offset the cost of new state subsidies that will be available to Californian households with incomes up to 600% of the federal poverty level, said the report.
21: The subsidies were created to help households reduce the cost of health care coverage bought through the state’s health insurance marketplace, Covered California.
22: "To the extent that any penalty is collected, all of that money is going to fund additional affordability assistance in Covered California," said Anthony Wright, executive director of Health Access California, a health care consumer advocacy coalition.
23: The subsidies will go "to legally residing Californians up and down the income stream, including those above 400% of the poverty level that otherwise would not qualify for assistance," Wright said.
24: The vast majority of the new subsidies will benefit Californians with incomes between 400% and 600% of the poverty line, said Scott Graves, director of research for California Budget and Policy Center.
25: "These residents — unlike people with lower incomes — do not qualify for any federal financial assistance even though they often face high monthly premiums as well as large out-of-pocket costs," Graves said.
26: The new state subsidies sunset after 2022, but the mandate and related penalty will continue.
27: Covered California’s website said that immigrants not lawfully present in the United States do not qualify for a health plan through Covered California (though they may qualify for the state’s Medicaid program, Medi-Cal).
28: Coverage for immigrants in the country illegally Another portion of California’s 2019-20 budget expands health coverage for young adults in the country illegally.
29: Medi-Cal, funded by state and federal taxes, offers free or low-cost health care coverage for low-income children and adults in California.
30: The state has "restricted scope" and "full-scope"  Medi-Cal; the restricted version covers emergency and pregnancy-related services, and the full-scope is more comprehensive, including medical, dental and eye care.
31: California in 2016 began offering full-scope Medi-Cal to all children under 19 years old, regardless of immigration status.
32: This year, the state expanded full-scope Medi-Cal to adults 19 to 25 years old who are illegally in the country and meet the income requirements.
33: In 2019-20, this expansion is expected to cost California about $98 million, with an estimated $74 million coming from the state’s general fund.
34: The state funds will support the full-scope Medi-Cal services ineligible for federal aid, Graves said.
35: The additional funding, beyond the approximately $74 million from the state’s general fund, will come from the federal government and be used to pay for emergency and pregnancy-related services, he said.
36: "As with the prior expansion, the general fund cost of this new expansion will be paid for with tax revenues that are generated by California’s current tax system, with no tax increase," Graves said.
37: Almost all tax revenue that flows into the state’s general fund comes from the personal income tax, the sales and use tax, and the corporation tax, he said.
38: The Legislative Analyst’s Office projected that on an ongoing basis, the Medi-Cal expansion for young adults would increase general fund spending by around $225 million annually across the Medi-Cal and In-Home Supportive Services program.
39: The full-scope expansion is expected to benefit about 100,000 people.
40: Some California state lawmakers and immigrant advocates wanted to offer health coverage to all immigrants living illegally in the state, but those broader plans were curtailed during budget negotiations.
41: California’s budget has a surplus of more than $20 billion.

gpt4: While it is true that California is planning to impose a tax penalty on individuals without health insurance starting January 1, 2020, this new policy isn't connected to the provision of free health insurance for illegal immigrants [12][13].
The revenues obtained from this tax are earmarked to fund subsidies aimed at reducing healthcare costs for Californians [14], to the tune of an estimated $317 million from 2020-2021[19][20].

Subsidies will extend to Californian households with incomes up to 600% of the federal poverty level, regardless of their position on the income continuum, but will exclude immigrants who are not legally present in the U.S.[22][23][27].

On the other hand, the state of California has indeed expanded full-scope Medi-Cal to include adults aged 19 to 25 who are illegally in the country and meet the income requirements, a move that is expected to cost the state around $98 million[32][33].
This amount, however, will be sourced principally from the state's general fund, which is sustained mostly by personal income tax, sales and use tax, and corporation tax [37].
Hence, the claim only presents a half-truth due to its conflated presentation of two distinct state healthcare policies.

4e68e3e30f56e97b251a93476daa7550.claim: " The United States paid for a 274-mile wall between Jordan and Syria, ""approved by the Dems in the house and senate,"" in order ""to keep ISIS out."""
4e68e3e30f56e97b251a93476daa7550.label: false
4e68e3e30f56e97b251a93476daa7550.passage:
0: A Facebook post claims the United States built a massive wall in the Middle East to block the ISIS terrorist organization.
1: Below a map showing Jordan and Syria, the post says: "This is a wall.
2: Between Jordan and Syria.
3: Why?
4: To keep ISIS out.
5: Want to guess who paid for it?
6: The US.
7: Yup, the US built a wall in Jordan.
8: 274 miles worth.
9: This was approved by the Dems in the house and senate.
10: But, a Wall for the US is immoral.
11: Apparently it’s not immoral in Jordan.
12: Well well isn’t that interesting."
13: The post didn’t provide any source information.
14: A reader asked us to check it out.
15: We found there is no end-to-end physical wall across the Jordan-Syria border, and certainly none like President Donald Trump has advocated for on the U.S.-Mexico border.
16: There are what amount to a series of barriers largely funded by the United States that were approved with bipartisan support.
17: They were erected to block incursions by Islamic State terrorists, but also to block refugees.
18: Jordan: Key U.S. partner Jordan is considered a key U.S. partner in the Middle East, according to an April 2019 paper by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service.
19: "Jordan’s strategic importance to the United States is evident given ongoing instability in neighboring Syria and Iraq, Jordan’s 1994 peace treaty with Israel and uncertainty over the trajectory of Palestinian politics," the paper says.
20: "Jordan also is a longtime U.S. partner in global counterterrorism operations.
21: U.S.-Jordanian military, intelligence and diplomatic cooperation seeks to empower political moderates, reduce sectarian conflict and eliminate terrorist threats."
22: ‘Sophisticated electronic fence’ A detailed Vice News article in 2016 reported that the administration of President Barack Obama was allocating funds "to build a sophisticated electronic fence along Jordan's northern and eastern borders, a wall which U.S. strategic planners hope will stem the flow of refugees."
23: The effort began as a $20 million project in 2008 to erect a set of surveillance towers along a 30-mile stretch of Jordan’s border with Syria.
24: But it expanded into what became known as the Jordan Border Security Program, running some 275 miles along the entire Jordan-Syria border and costing $500 million, according to Vice.
25: (Jordan’s border with Syria runs 234 miles .)
26: Since 2013, the barrier "has refocused on detecting Islamic State fighters and arms smuggling, as well as refugees, on both sides of the border," the article says.
27: Other sources Experts we contacted largely confirmed Vice’s account, with some clarifications.
28: The State Department describes the Jordan Border Security Program as an "integrated border security surveillance, detection and interdiction system along Jordan’s land borders. "
29: "It’s not a wall, and I don’t think any part of it could be described as such," said Ben Fishman , a senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
30: "The U.S. funded a series of border security systems to Jordan as part of our long-standing bipartisan security cooperation with Jordan."
31: GlobalSecurity.org director John Pike said "there are all kinds of radars and observation towers and other such anti-infiltration measures, but no wall."
32: Congress increased defense appropriations to Jordan to counter ISIS , including for enhancing border security, Jeffrey VanDenBerg , director of Middle East Studies at Drury University in Missouri, told us.
33: "But it wasn’t specifically for a wall, and it is not specified what portion of the increased funds were intended for border security."
34: Some of Jordan’s barriers on its border with Syria predated any recent U.S. appropriations, he added.
35: The major funding, although U.S. money was provided previously, was supported by Democrats in an omnibus spending bill, said Valens Global chief executive officer Daveed Gartenstein-Ross .
36: He cited a 2017 appropriations measure providing up to $500 million that, the law says, "may be used to provide assistance to the Government of Jordan to support the armed forces of Jordan and to enhance security along its borders."

gpt4: The claim that the United States allocated funds for a 274-mile wall between Jordan and Syria as an effort to keep ISIS out is not entirely true.

Firstly, the structure funded by the Obama administration was not a physical wall as it is commonly perceived, or as proposed by President Trump for the U.S-Mexico border, but rather a 'sophisticated electronic fence'[22][15].
This project, known as the Jordan Border Security Program, runs for approximately 275 miles along the Jordan-Syria border[24].
Secondly, it is not specified how much of this $500 million allocation was intended specifically for border security, and the funds were not strictly dedicated to the construction of a wall[33].
Furthermore, according to Ben Fishman, a senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, none of this structure can be classified as a 'wall'[29].
This is supported by GlobalSecurity.org director John Pike who distinguishes the structure as a security measure including several radars and observation towers[31].

7abb74b10fa13ee9ff6ef557b28eca07.claim: "  he is ""cutting illegal immigration in half."""
7abb74b10fa13ee9ff6ef557b28eca07.label: false
7abb74b10fa13ee9ff6ef557b28eca07.passage:
0: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com President Donald Trump launched a high-profile re-election ad during Game 7 of the World Series, claiming that he’s delivered on a signature issue of his administration by "cutting illegal immigration in half."
1: "President Trump is changing Washington, creating 6 million new jobs, 500,000 new manufacturing jobs, cutting illegal immigration in half, obliterating ISIS, their caliphate destroyed, their terrorist leader dead," the ad narrator says, going on to attack Democrats for impeachment inquiry proceedings as well as Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
2: This fact-check will focus on the immigration portion of the Oct. 30 ad — whether Trump has cut illegal immigration in half.
3: That part of the ad shows Trump at the southwest border, standing in front of border fencing and shaking hands with Border Patrol agents.
4: We did not hear back from the White House nor from Trump’s re-election campaign by publication time.
5: But the ad cites "Fox News, 9/10/2019" as the source for his claim about immigration.
6: An immigration official in September spoke of a drop of more than 50% in southwest border apprehensions in a three-month period.
7: But that snapshot creates the wrong impression.
8: On average, apprehensions under Trump have been higher than under his predecessor, Barack Obama.
9: Also, apprehensions have more than doubled in fiscal year 2019, compared to fiscal year 2018.
10: Ken Cuccinelli’s Fox News interview In a Sept. 10 interview, Ken Cuccinelli, the acting director of U.S.
11: Citizenship and Immigration Services, appeared on Fox News’ "Fox & Friends" and spoke about a drop in border apprehensions in August, the latest monthly tally available at the time.
12: (Apprehension data is commonly used as a tally of illegal immigration.)
13: "The president has literally thrown every domestic and international effort he can at this and it’s paid off," Cuccinellli said to Fox host Brian Kilmeade.
14: "As you noted Brian, we are down more than 50% since May in just three months."
15: U.S. Customs and Border Protection data shows that in May there were 132,856 apprehensions at the southwest border.
16: In August, there were 50,684.
17: That’s a nearly 62% decline in apprehensions.
18: Evaluating apprehension data A three-month period is a relatively short period of time to know whether any changes are long-term or temporary, said Theresa Cardinal Brown, director of immigration and cross-border policy at the Bipartisan Policy Center.
19: "You can only look at trends at the border in longer time spans," Brown said.
20: It's also important to analyze how various factors affect any immigration changes, she said.
21: Trump’s ad claiming he cut illegal immigration in half was also presented without any context, ommiting the time period, Brown said, which might lead people to wrongly presume that the comparison is before and after Trump took office.
22: But the claim takes a period of time when illegal immigration increased under Trump and decreased under Trump, said Alex Nowrasteh, director of immigration studies at the libertarian Cato Institute.
23: "It's just a silly claim, it's comparing Trump to Trump," he said.
24: To evaluate whether Trump is "cutting illegal immigration in half" one should look at data on apprehensions before and during his time in office, experts said.
25: Southwest border apprehensions during Obama’s tenure on average were around 400,000 a year.
26: That average is higher for Trump.
27: Apprehensions declined about 26% from fiscal years 2016 to 2017, but picked up again in 2018 and 2019.
28: (2017 included about four months of Obama’s presidency.)
29: There were roughly 548,000 more apprehensions in 2019 than there were in 2017 .
30: Border Patrol agents recorded a total 851,508 apprehensions in fiscal year 2019.
31: That is nearly a 115% increase from the 396,579 apprehensions in 2018.

gpt4: The claim that Trump has "cut illegal immigration in half" has been found to be false.
This statement was made in an advertisement which referenced "Fox News, 9/10/2019" as its source [5].
However, experts clarify that to accurately determine whether illegal immigration has been cut in half one should assess data regarding apprehensions both before and during Trump's presidency [24].
While apprehensions decreased by about 26% between fiscal years 2016 and 2017, they ultimately surged upward in 2018 and 2019[27][29][31].
The advertisement's impression is misleading as it neglects to provide context, such as time frames, skewing the viewer's understanding of the issue [7][21].
Additionally, the claim relies on a period of both increased and decreased illegal immigration during Trump's tenure, rather than comparing his term to his predecessor's [22].
Alex Nowrasteh, director of immigration studies at the libertarian Cato Institute, characterized this as comparing "Trump to Trump" [23].
Ultimately, the average number of apprehensions has in fact been higher under Trump's presidency in comparison to Obama's [8][26].

b4148c64908a5314ee3a659faf3f9316.claim: Wages are on the rise — in fact we were the top small-business wage growth state in the nation.
b4148c64908a5314ee3a659faf3f9316.label: half-true
b4148c64908a5314ee3a659faf3f9316.passage:
0: During his recent election announcement for governor of Missouri, Mike Parson trumpeted a strong economy in the state, taking particular care to highlight increases in small-business wages.
1: "With record lows in unemployment, more people are going back to work in Missouri," Parson said Sept. 8.
2: "Wages are on the rise — in fact we were the top small-business wage growth state in the nation."
3: Does the governor’s comment check out?
4: We wanted to investigate.
5: By the numbers A spokesperson for Parson’s campaign cited an April 2019 article from St. Louis Business Journal that used numbers from an April 2019 report from Paychex/IHS Market Small Business Employment Watch to show Missouri ranked first in the country in hourly wage growth for small businesses.
6: At $25.55 per hour, Missouri small business wages were up 3.48%, or 86 cents, that month.
7: The Show-Me State finished first ahead of California, New York, Arizona and Illinois in small-business wage growth.
8: According to the Small Business Employment Watch’s September report, Missouri now ranks third in the country in hourly wage growth increase at 3.38% (New York is second at 3.53% and Illinois is first at 4.11%).
9: If assessing for weekly wage growth rise, Missouri is second at 3.83%.
10: Illinois comes in at 3.84%, just .01% better than Missouri.
11: Overall, Missouri has been a top-five small business wage growth state (by weekly earnings) every month this year, according to Paychex’s analysis.
12: So what is Paychex, and how does it calculate its data for the Small Business Employment Watch?
13: Paychex is a human resources and payroll company with over 600,000 clients nationwide.
14: According to a media spokesperson for the company, it "uses up-to-date, aggregated payroll data from approximately 350,000 of Paychex's small business clients with fewer than 50 workers" to keep its data current.
15: All businesses whose wage data is included in the report must have run payroll for the month that the data is being compiled and the three months prior.
16: According to a Paychex spokesperson, the sample includes millions of small-business workers.
17: How many small-business workers are there in Missouri and in the United States?
18: It depends what you consider a small business.
19: Paychex defines a small business as a firm with fewer than 50 workers, but the U.S. Small Business Administration defines small businesses as firms with less than 500 workers.
20: According to the SBA’s 2019 profile for the state of Missouri, there are 1.2 million small business employees in the state of Missouri alone, and 58.9 million in the country.
21: In other words, while Paychex represents a significant portion of small businesses, it’s not the whole pie.
22: The company itself claims to work with one in 12 private sector employees.

gpt4: While it is true that wages in Missouri have been on the rise and the state has recorded significant growth in small-business wages, it is only partially accurate to claim that Missouri was the "top small-business wage growth state in the nation" as suggested by the claim[1][2].
The claim is supported by a report from an April 2019 article from the St. Louis Business Journal, which cites data from the Paychex/IHS Market Small Business Employment Watch.

According to the report, Missouri ranked first in hourly wage growth for small businesses in the country in that month, with the small business wages up by 3.48% and averagely standing at $25.55 per hour[5][6].
Missouri surpassed a number of other states including California, New York, Arizona and Illinois in terms of small-business wage growth[7].
However, by September of the same year, Missouri's ranking dropped to third place on the list, receding behind New York and Illinois in terms of hourly wage growth increase, which was at 3.38%[8].
If considering weekly wage growth, Missouri also ranked second with a growth increase of 3.83%, just slightly behind Illinois[9][10].

In spite of the fluctuations, Missouri has maintained a position within the top five small business wage growth states (measured in weekly earnings) every month of that year, according to an analysis by Paychex[11].
Therefore, the context of the time-frame must be taken into account when evaluating the claim, as it is not entirely false but lacks comprehensive truth.
Hence, the claim can be considered as half-true.

e0da0d51ba76160dd875b795590726e0.label: true
e0da0d51ba76160dd875b795590726e0.passage:
0: California’s homeless crisis now ranks as one of the top concerns in the state, tied for first with jobs and the economy in a recent survey .
1: Sacramento Mayor Darrell Steinberg, who chairs the governor’s commission on homelessness, has taken notice and promised greater urgency.
2: He recently called for his city to spend $30 million to jump-start the mass production of tiny homes, structures 500 square feet or less.
3: Steinberg said these no-frills structures could house thousands of homeless people in Sacramento and elsewhere, and help ease the state’s crisis, claiming "90,000 Californians are unsheltered and homeless."
4: That’s nearly the population of medium-sized cities, from Santa Barbara to Livermore to Redding.
5: Is the state’s homeless crisis really as severe as Steinberg claimed?
6: We set out on a fact check.
7: Our research This isn’t the first time we’ve looked at Steinberg’s statements on homelessness.
8: In July, during his push for a statewide ‘right to shelter’ law, we examined his claims about the share of unsheltered homeless people in California compared with New York City — and on the soaring rate of homeless deaths in two major cities in the state.
9: We found his assertions were generally correct, but needed a few clarifications.
10: To verify Steinberg’s statement about 90,000 unsheltered people, we reviewed a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development study called the 2018 Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress .
11: Housing experts consider it the most comprehensive and current set of estimates for homeless populations nationwide.
12: Released in December last year, the report shows California had nearly 130,000 homeless people both sheltered and unsheltered, a tally from a point-in-time count conducted in January 2018.
13: That was the most of any state, far ahead of second-place New York with about 92,000 homeless people.
14: Of course, more people live in California than any other state.
15: Of California’s total, 89,543 were unsheltered, meaning they were not living in an emergency shelter or similar residence.
16: Instead, they were found on the street, in a vehicle or abandoned building.
17: This matches Steinberg’s statement.
18: At nearly 69 percent, California’s share of unsheltered homeless people was the highest in the nation, the report found.
19: Oregon had the second-highest share at about 62 percent.
20: Steinberg’s spokesperson said the mayor relied on the HUD report.
21: California has the nation's highest rate of unsheltered homeless people, according to the 2018 Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress.
22: ‘Double digit increases’ in homelessness Chris Martin, a legislative advocate on homelessness at the nonprofit Housing California, said Steinberg used the best figure available.
23: He said a new HUD report is expected in December.
24: Based on early survey results around the state this year, Martin said he anticipates at least a 10 percent jump in California’s overall homeless population when the report comes out.
25: He did not have an estimate on how the unsheltered population might change.
26: "It’s bad," Martin said, of the overall totals.
27: "I’d say most communities around the state are seeing a double-digit increase."
28: Martin pointed to one research group, HUB for Urban Initiatives, that estimates there’s been a nearly 24 percent spike in homelessness statewide from 2017 to 2019.
29: He noted that the federal homeless counts represent a snapshot-in-time of a community’s homeless population.
30: "We usually estimate that two to three times the point-in-time number are homeless during the course of the year," added Sharon Rapport, director of the California State Policy Corporation for Supportive Housing, develops housing policy and makes housing loans.
31: While the federal reports are issued each year, Rapport said the odd year counts are more comprehensive because not every jurisdiction did a survey in 2018.
32: She said she expects the 2019 report to show a larger overall number of homeless people.
33: "Despite these flaws, it is the best data we have at this point," Rapport added.

gpt4: Steinberg's statement that around 90,000 Californians are unsheltered and homeless is indeed accurate.
Verification for this claim has been conducted through an assessment of the 2018 Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development[10].

The study revealed that out of the total homeless population in California, 89,543 individuals were unsheltered, which means they were not accommodated in emergency shelters or other similar residences[15].
This data corroborates Steinberg’s pronouncement[17].

2f6d84eb102eaf47833b3ff481bd1fb4.claim: There’s more African American males in the penal system right now than there were (enslaved) at the height of slavery.
2f6d84eb102eaf47833b3ff481bd1fb4.label: half-true
2f6d84eb102eaf47833b3ff481bd1fb4.passage:
0: It’s not uncommon for CEOs of top corporations to give speeches.
1: It is uncommon for them to make the African American incarceration rate the focus of those speeches.
2: Yet, that’s what American Family CEO Jack Salzwedel did Oct. 8, 2019 , at an event honoring the Deloitte Wisconsin 75, a list of the top privately and closely held companies in the state.
3: Madison-based American Family is fourth on the list, with revenue of about $10.2 billion in 2018.
4: "There’s more African American males in the penal system right now than there were at the height of slavery," Salzwedel said.
5: "And it’s something that needs to be addressed because as a business this is an important issue for us, not just as a feel good.
6: This is an important issue for us we think about our markets, demand for our products, the workforce, all of these things."
7: Salzwedel acknowledged that his speech could be controversial, adding: "I truly believe that if people will be looking back 50 years from now at this time right now, that they’ll look at what’s going on with the mass incarceration movement right now and they'll look at us the same way we look back 100 years and look at slavery."
8: Salzwedel’s entire statement is interesting, but we decided to focus on the imprisoned-enslaved comparison.
9: Is he right that there are "more African American males in the penal system right now than there were (enslaved) at the height of slavery"?
10: The background The 13th Amendment to the United States Constitution was passed by Congress on Jan. 31, 1865, declaring , "neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction."
11: Although slavery was abolished in the 19th Century, the long-term ramifications of the practice, which persisted for three centuries, continues to reverberate in public discourse, classrooms and even amongst the highest levels of corporate America.
12: For instance, the board of the Metropolitan Milwaukee Association of Commerce has identified "racial disparity/inequity" as the region’s top liability.
13: "Business leaders are by nature forward looking -- they can see that to be successful we need to be a region of choice for all-inclusive of diverse talent," said Tim Sheehy, MMAC president.
14: On Sept. 26, 2019, the MMAC announced that 65 employers with 130,000 workers had signed a pledge to increase the diversity of their managers and workforce.
15: Those companies included Harley-Davidson, MillerCoors, the Milwaukee Bucks and Johnson Controls.
16: "AmFam was not approached in the original outreach as their corporate footprint is relatively small in Milwaukee -- though that will be changing," Sheehy said.
17: "They are very supportive."
18: Now, what about Salzwedel’s incarceration vs. enslavement claim?
19: The evidence When asked to provide backup, American Family spokesman Ken Muth pointed us to " The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness ," a 2010 book by civil rights lawyer Michelle Alexander.
20: In the introduction to the book, the author writes "we have not ended racial caste in America; we have merely redesigned it."
21: Alexander goes on to say : "More African American adults are under correctional control today—in prison or jail, on probation or parole — than were enslaved in 1850, a decade before the Civil War began."
22: As evidence, though, that quote simply mirrors what Salzwedel said.
23: What about the numbers?
24: In 2014, PolitiFact Rhode Island fact-checked a similar claim : "There are more African American men in prison, jail, on probation or parole than were enslaved in 1850."
25: That item noted: "The U.S. Census Bureau records for 1850 showed that 872,924 male African American slaves over age 15 lived in the United States at that time.
26: (The same Census found that there were a total of 3.2 million African American slaves of all ages, at a time when the total U.S. population, including slaves and "free coloreds" was 23.2 million.)"
27: Meanwhile, federal Bureau of Justice statistics statistics showed about 1.68 million African American men were under state and federal criminal justice supervision.
28: Salzwedel’s statement was worded a bit differently, in that it referred broadly to the "penal system."
29: When taken broadly, we think that takes in those on probation and parole, as well as those in the nation’s local jails.
30: The latest available nationwide data on parole and probation is from 2016, so we’ll zoom in there.
31: At the end of 2016, there were 487,300 black men serving time in state or federal prison and about 200,000 serving time in local jails, according to the BJS report " Jail Inmates in 2016 ."
32: The agency also recorded 771,355 on probation and 289,000 on parole.
33: That means about 1.75 million black men were under federal, state and local criminal justice supervision.
34: That is about double the 872,924 black men who were enslaved in 1850.
35: Considering population growth Of course, the nation’s population has grown a lot since 1850.
36: Indeed, there are far more black residents in the United States now — about 40 million -- than the 23.2 million total residents in 1850.
37: In 2016, the total U.S. population stood at 308,745,538 .
38: By that comparison, black enslaved males tallied 3.7% of the population in 1850, while  African American males imprisoned today represent about 0.6% of the population.
39: Reggie Jackson, head griot/docent at America’s Black Holocaust Museum in Milwaukee and a consultant at Nurturing Diversity Partners, also pointed to the issue of population growth "Obviously, there are over 10 times more blacks today than there were then, so it would only make sense that more are incarcerated now," Jackson said in an email.

gpt4: The claim that there are more African American males in the penal system right now than there were enslaved at the height of slavery is somewhat accurate, but it requires contextual understanding and involves different scopes of comparison.

As per the records of 2016, the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) indicated that 487,300 black men were serving time in state or federal prisons and approximately 200,000 were serving time in local jails[31].
In addition to this, some 771,355 black males were on probation, and further 289,000 were on parole[32].
Collectively, this places around 1.75 million black men under various forms of criminal justice supervision[33].
This figure represents a significantly larger number of black men controlled by penal mechanisms nowadays compared to the 872,924 black men who were enslaved in 1850[34].

However, the statement inherently compares two distinct states: being under criminal justice supervision, which includes being in prison, jail, probation, and parole, to the singular condition of being enslaved.
Therefore, while the raw numbers may support this claim, the context and nature of the two situations are dramatically different which makes the claim half-true.

4aae07bc93f168cdca5fb2034e272525.claim: This decision is an unfortunate example of why those of us in Montpelier need to work together to make Vermont a more affordable place to do business and make sure our policies help businesses thrive rather than creating unique burdens and barriers to growth that make us less competitive with other states.
4aae07bc93f168cdca5fb2034e272525.label: false
4aae07bc93f168cdca5fb2034e272525.passage:
0: Last week, the Missouri-based battery company Energizer announced plans to close its factory in Bennington .
1: The company said it was shuttering the Vermont plant, which manufactures hearing aid batteries, and moving the operation to a new facility in Portage, Wisconsin, following a $2 billion deal to purchase Rayovac.
2: The Energizer closing in Bennington will eliminate about 100 jobs.
3: The layoffs are expected to deepen financial strain in the Southwest region of the state, which has seen a sharp decline in employment opportunities since the Great Recession.
4: Gov.
5: Phil Scott called Energizer’s plans "disappointing" in a statement released last week.
6: And he blamed the company’s move on larger problems with the state’s business climate.
7: "This decision is an unfortunate example of why those of us in Montpelier need to work together to make Vermont a more affordable place to do business and make sure our policies help businesses thrive rather than creating unique burdens and barriers to growth that make us less competitive with other states," Scott wrote in a statement last week.
8: The governor’s statement draws a direct connection between the state’s business climate and Energizer’s plans to shutter the factory.
9: We wondered: Are Vermont’s policymakers to blame for Energizer’s pending departure?
10: Energizer has said it is closing the Bennington factory — which was downsized in 2015— to consolidate operations in the Wisconsin Rayovac factory, which also produces hearing aid batteries.
11: The only public statements Energizer has made on the decision indicate it is making the move because it would be more efficient for the company to produce the hearing aid batteries in one factory.
12: The Portage plant employs more than twice as many workers than the Bennington facility (about 225 compared to 90).
13: It’s also slightly larger.
14: "In order to be successful as a larger company, we are making significant investments to better utilize our existing manufacturing facilities, reduce complexity in our operations, and enhance service to our customers," Marcus Boolish, Energizer’s director of government affairs wrote in a letter to Sen. Dick Sears, D-Bennington, last week.
15: Nikki Eaves, an Energizer spokesperson, offered a similar explanation to the Bennington Banner, saying that the facility in Wisconsin is equipped to handle the company’s hearing aid production.
16: "As part of the integration," she said, "we reviewed our combined manufacturing footprint and determined the total demand for specialty batteries can be produced more efficiently in one facility."
17: The company did not respond to questions from VTDigger about whether the state’s business climate contributed to its decision to leave the state.
18: But Rebecca Kelley, a spokesperson for Scott, said that it was "self-evident" that Energizer is moving out of state because Vermont’s business environment isn’t competitive.
19: She said that if it was "advantageous" for Energizer to ramp up its production in Vermont, the company would have kept operations here.
20: Kelley pointed to the fact that Vermont has among the highest power costs in the nation and some of the highest corporate and property taxes, according to the Tax Foundation’s latest business tax climate index .
21: In 2018, Forbes ranked Vermont 47th in its U.S. "Best for Business" rankings and said that the cost of doing business in the state is 12% higher than the national average.
22: "Businesses are going to do what’s in the best interest of the business," Kelley said.
23: "If their decision is to leave the state for another state, that indicates it is more advantageous and more competitive in that other state."
24: Kelly did not, however, provide any additional evidence that Vermont’s business climate contributed to Energizer’s factory consolidation.
25: Sears, the senator from Bennington, said it would be hard to evaluate whether the governor’s statement is true, unless the company provided more information about its decision.
26: "I think it’s unclear what the reasons are for them not investing in Vermont," he said.
27: "You can generalize and say it’s anti-business and Wisconsin’s more business-friendly.
28: I don’t know if that’s true or not."
29: The senator said he couldn’t recall the company lobbying legislators on business issues in the Statehouse, except on one occasion.
30: About a decade ago, when Vermont banned mercury in batteries, the company asked lawmakers for a period of time to phase-out use of the chemical instead of an immediate ban.
31: Sears said he worked to get that language written into the bill.
32: Kelley said the governor’s office was seeking more information from Energizer about its reasons for leaving Vermont.
33: Sen. Brian Campion, D-Bennington, said Scott should have that conversation with Energizer before he "speculates" on its motivations.
34: "I think it’s important to hear directly from Energizer on what kind of things would have or even could keep them here," Campion said, noting that the company doesn’t plan to fully shutter its doors in Bennington until 2021.
35: "Are there things that could be done between now and then that could keep Energizer here?"

gpt4: The claim that Energizer's decision to close its Bennington factory in Vermont and move to Wisconsin is due to the state being less affordable and competitive for doing business is false.
The reasons for this decision are purely operational and strategic for the company, and not related to the business environment in Vermont.
Energizer announced they were closing the Bennington factory after purchasing Rayovac in a $2 billion deal [1].
The move is to consolidate their operations in the newly acquired Wisconsin factory, which also produces hearing aid batteries [10].
By producing the batteries in one location, Energizer maintains the operation will be more efficient[11].

The company's aim is to make significant investments to improve the utilization of present manufacturing facilities and reduce complexity, revealing a strategic motive to boost service to customers [14].
Lastly, Energizer’s spokesperson confirmed the Wisconsin facility is equipped to handle the company’s hearing aid production needs [15].
Thus, their decision does not draw direct correlation with the business policies or affordability of operating in Vermont.

89d71943b387e6d5b70438ffa3dd8925.claim: "  Sen. Kamala Harris said Democrats are ""coming for"" Trump supporters if they win the White House in 2020."
89d71943b387e6d5b70438ffa3dd8925.label: false
89d71943b387e6d5b70438ffa3dd8925.passage:
0: A quote from Sen. Kamala Harris attacking supporters of President Donald Trump has been widely shared on social media.
1: But it’s made-up.
2: The quote, which was published Oct. 29  and Nov. 2 on Facebook, makes it look like Harris, a Democratic senator running for president in 2020, threatened people who voted for Trump in 2016.
3: The quote reads: "And once he’s gone and we have regained our rightful place in the White House, look out if you supported him and endorsed his actions, because we’ll be coming for you next.
4: You will feel the vengeance of a nation.
5: No stone will be left unturned as we seek you out in every corner of this great nation.
6: For it is you who have betrayed us."
7: The post, which has been shared more than 700 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: Harris is not shy about her disdain for the Trump administration.
10: But the popular Facebook quote is fake.
11: The bottom of the Facebook image has "Warriorcode.us" written across it.
12: Warriorcode.us is a website that sells pro-gun apparel.
13: One of the site’s Facebook pages published the same photo Oct. 24.
14: It later edited the post to acknowledge that the quote was made-up.
15: It appears the post originated in an Aug. 7 story from Bustatroll.org, a satirical site known for publishing made-up political stories.
16: Its owner, Christopher Blair, operates several similar sites with the goal of fooling conservatives into sharing bogus content.
17: The article fabricated a speech in which Harris said she would round up Trump supporters if Democrats won the White House in 2020.
18: We could find no evidence that Harris ever made such a speech.
19: While the Bustatroll.org story includes several disclosures that its content is satirical, the Facebook post does not.
20: Commenters took the quote at face value.
21: The Facebook post is inaccurate and makes a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that Sen. Kamala Harris stated that Democrats would target Trump supporters should they win the White House in 2020 is baseless and false.
There is no evidence to support that Harris ever delivered such a speech[18].
The statement supposedly made by Harris first appeared in a post on Bustatroll.org - a site known for crafting and propagating made-up political stories[15].
The fabricated quote was then popularized through a fake Facebook post[10], which eventually amended its content to reveal that the quote attributed to Harris had indeed been concocted[14].
Therefore, the claim is inauthentic and merely a fabrication[1].

410292d6ea737352774849baf70c48ed.claim: " Candidates who are supporting the Green New Deal are ""promoting abortion in third world countries to control the population!"""
410292d6ea737352774849baf70c48ed.label: false
410292d6ea737352774849baf70c48ed.passage:
0: Attacks on the Green New Deal include claims that it would cost $93 trillion ( False ), "put a $600,000 tax burden on every household" ( False ) and do away with commercial air travel ( False ).
1: A new attack on the climate change measure and its supporters connects it to abortion.
2: Republican Nikki Haley , the former United Nations ambassador under President Donald Trump and former South Carolina governor sent an email Oct. 26 from Stand for America , a policy group she launched in February.
3: The email says the following: "Liberals continue to go around the country touting their radical climate change agenda.
4: "Front and center was their ‘Green New Deal.’ Or as we at Stand For America have come to call it, the ‘Green New Scam.’ The candidates touted everything from putting limits on red meat consumption, to promoting abortion in third world countries to control the population!
5: "We must stand up to these liberals, and let them know that we don’t support this radical agenda!"
6: The email then links to a petition that seeks to stop the Green New Deal, saying it would "promote abortion."
7: Broadly, the Green New Deal is a resolution first proposed by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez , D-N.Y., that would address ways to curb climate change and protect the environment, with measures on emissions, water, infrastructure and scientific research.
8: The words abortion and population are not mentioned in the text of the Green New Deal resolution.
9: With regard to other countries, the resolution says only that the Green New Deal would promote "the international exchange of technology, expertise, products, funding and services, with the aim of making the United States the international leader on climate action, and to help other countries achieve a Green New Deal."
10: So what is Haley talking about?
11: We repeatedly emailed, called and messaged Stand for America, and we reached out to the publisher of Haley’s forthcoming book.
12: But we did not receive any replies to our requests for information to support Haley’s statement.
13: Population control Haley’s email about "the candidates" pushing red meat and abortion agenda does not specify which candidates she alluded to.
14: But conservatives accused 2020 presidential candidate Bernie Sanders of wanting to use abortion for population control in order to fight climate change, based on his answer to a question at a Sept. 4 CNN town hall  focused on climate change.
15: Here was his exchange with an audience member (in which neither mentioned the Green New Deal): Question: "Human population growth has more than doubled in the past 50 years.
16: The planet cannot sustain this growth.
17: I realize this is a poisonous topic for politicians, but it's crucial to face.
18: Empowering women and educating everyone on the need to curb population growth seems a reasonable campaign to enact.
19: Would you be courageous enough to discuss this issue and make it a key feature of a plan to address climate catastrophe?"
20: Sanders: "Well, Martha, the answer is yes.
21: And the answer has everything to do with the fact that women in the United States of America, by the way, have a right to control their own bodies and make reproductive decisions.
22: And the Mexico City agreement, which denies American aid to those organizations around the world that allow women to have abortions or even get involved in birth control to me is totally absurd."
23: The agreement prohibits U.S. foreign aid not just directly for abortions, but for any organization that provides abortion or abortion-related services.
24: It was rescinded under President Barack Obama and reactivated by Trump.
25: Among the critics was U.S. Rep. Steve Scalise , R-La., who tweeted , "Bernie Sanders said YOUR tax dollars should be used to fund abortions in foreign countries to reduce population size."
26: Sanders did say population control should be part of addressing climate change.
27: And he brought up the Mexico City agreement and said women should have the right to "reproductive decisions."
28: But he did not explicitly promote the use of abortion for population control.
