28: That means the administration has to take money from dozens of projects, such as a fire and crash rescue station at Tyndall Air Force Base in Florida, a dining facility at Joint Base San Antonio in Texas, and a small arms range at Truax Field in Wisconsin.
29: NC to lose $80 million The Pentagon listed each project affected by the national emergency at the southern border.
30: It includes four at North Carolina military bases, and they do in fact total $80 million as the DSCC claims.
31: The North Carolina projects are a new battalion complex and ambulatory care center at Camp Lejeune, an elementary school at Fort Bragg, and a tanker storage facility at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base.
32: None of the projects were scheduled to break ground until 2020.
33: But while the DSCC’s statement is accurate, there’s an important caveat.
34: Almost $33 million of the $80 million would have been reallocated anyway because the $32.9 million Fort Bragg school project had already been canceled "due to declining enrollment."
35: The construction of the school would have been canceled regardless of Trump’s emergency declaration and its funding could have been reallocated to other projects in North Carolina or elsewhere.
36: (Fort Bragg has several urgent needs , including a $21 million fire station.)
37: In a September town hall , Tillis acknowledged the $80 million shift in funding but said, "Half of that was for a project at Fort Bragg that was not moving forward."
38: Funding for the other three projects remains uncertain, but Tillis has given assurances that Congress can replenish the money.
39: In an op-ed in the Greensboro News & Record, Tillis wrote that Congress "has plenty of time to re-allocate funding" and called on other members of Congress to vote for the National Defense Authorization Act.

gpt4: The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) accused Senator Thom Tillis of supporting President Trump's emergency declaration which diverts $80 million from North Carolina to fund the border wall[7].
Indeed, Tillis voted against the attempt to block this declaration by siding with Trump[6][16][17].

That said, there's a crucial point to consider - almost $33 million of the total $80 million was initially allocated for a Fort Bragg school project that has been cancelled due to falling student numbers[34].
Therefore, this portion of the fund would have been repurposed anyways.

The claim is hence regarded as half-true since although Tillis voted for the emergency declaration that diverts $80 million from North Carolina, a part of this money was already set to be shifted due to separate reasons, rendering the 'raid' phrasing not completely accurate.

35054e8285636c8d9d94f73635f3fad2.claim: People with pre-existing mental health conditions have access to firearms and not health care.
35054e8285636c8d9d94f73635f3fad2.label: half-true
35054e8285636c8d9d94f73635f3fad2.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post with a hashtag indicating support for U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders’ presidential bid argued this point in favor of the candidate’s signature healthcare plan, Medicare for All : "Just so we’re clear: people with pre-existing mental health conditions have access to firearms and not healthcare."
1: This post, which has been shared more than 58,000 times since it was published on Aug. 4, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: First, let’s look at whether people with pre-existing mental health conditions can access guns.
4: Federal law prohibits the purchase and possession of firearms by people with felony convictions, domestic abusers, and people with specific kinds of mental health histories.
5: The Gun Control Act prohibits transferring a gun to a person who "has been adjudicated as a mental defective or committed to a mental institution," according to the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics .
6: Such people are also prohibited from possessing a gun.
7: The Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence — which advocates for a more comprehensive system for reporting mental illness and conducting background checks — states on its website that while such checks have blocked more than 3 million people in those categories from getting firearms, federal gun law generally doesn’t affect other people who public health researchers have identified as having a higher risk of being dangerous, including other people who have suffered from severe mental illness.
8: "The system intended to limit access to firearms for individuals experiencing a mental health crisis still includes dangerous loopholes," the center says.
9: The law center also points to a 2012 Mother Jones story .
10: It reported that among 62 people accused in mass shootings in recent years, 38 "displayed signs of possible mental health problems prior to the killings."
11: Nearly 80 percent of the perpetrators obtained their weapons legally, according to the publication.
12: In 2016, the New York Times detailed how people with mental illness are able to get guns.
13: They can buy them from private sellers because federal law doesn’t require background checks for such transactions.
14: Or, they fall under a broader category of mental illness and skirt the restrictions federal law has for people who have been involuntarily committed to a mental hospital or deemed a "mental defective" by a court or other authority.
15: Plus, mental health records are "overwhelmingly under-reported to federal and state databases scanned during a background check," the story says.
16: So while federal law prohibits people with certain kinds of mental health histories from owning a gun, there are gaps that leave room for people with severe mental illness to buy guns.
17: Next, let’s look at whether people with pre-existing mental health conditions can’t access health care.
18: The Affordable Care Act requires health plans in individual and small group markets to cover 10 essential benefits.
19: Among them: mental health and substance use disorder services including behavioral health treatment like counseling and psychotherapy.
20: "Pre-existing mental and behavioral health conditions are covered, and spending limits aren’t allowed," reads a page on healthcare.gov covering mental health and substance abuse coverage.
21: "Marketplace plans can’t deny you coverage or charge you more just because you have any pre-existing condition, including mental health and substance use disorder conditions."
22: Other health plans characterized as "short-term, limited duration insurance" — often purchased to fill in coverage gaps such as when a person is between jobs — are not required to include Obamacare’s essential benefits and can exclude pre-existing conditions from coverage or reject people entirely.
23: The Obama administration limited these policies to just three months and regulated them so they couldn’t be renewed, NPR reported in October , but the Trump Administration has changed that; in some states, people can buy such policies that last a year and can renew them twice.
24: The National Alliance on Mental Illness has decried these short-term plans, saying they discriminate against mental illness .
25: But they’re not sold on the health insurance marketplace and people can’t use federal subsidies to help pay for them.
26: For very healthy people, these plans can be cheaper than what’s available on healthcare.gov, said Linda Blumberg an institute fellow at Health Policy Center at the Urban Institute, but it’s a small segment of the overall insured population.
27: Job-based coverage from large employers — meaning those with more than 50 employees -— could also limit mental health coverage, Blumberg said.
28: But since the passage of federal mental health parity laws and the Affordable Care Act, plans that offer mental health benefits must do so in a way comparable to the other medical services they cover.
29: Today, there are still problems with accessing mental health care, Blumberg said.
30: Some areas have a shortage of providers, for example, or providers who aren’t covered by certain insurance plans.
31: Plus, if the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals sustains a lower court’s decision to overturn the Affordable Care Act, she said, this Facebook post could be more meaningful.
32: But with the exception of short-term plans, Blumberg said the claim that people with pre-existing mental health conditions don’t have access to health care isn’t correct.

gpt4: People with pre-existing mental health conditions do technically have access to health care, as stated by experts and the information provided on healthcare.gov; these individuals are covered by marketplace plans which do not allow for spending limits and cannot deny coverage or charge higher rates due to pre-existing conditions, including mental and behavioral health issues [32][20][21].
However, issues do hamper their ability to receive adequate care, such as provider shortages or exclusions from specific insurance plans [29][30].

Furthermore, although the Trump administration expanded short-term health plans that, according to the National Alliance on Mental Illness, discriminate against mental illness, these are exceptions rather than the norm [23][24].
On the other hand, certain individuals with mental health conditions can indeed obtain firearms.
Federal law bans those adjudicated as mental defectives or committed to a mental institution from owning guns, but there are loopholes.

These individuals can purchase firearms through private sellers not required to run background checks or may not meet the specific criteria of mental illness outlined by federal law [4][5][13][14][16].
The claim is thus partially correct but does not revolve around the complexity of accessing both mental health care and firearms for people with pre-existing mental conditions.

787039e86c44e09ee62ea8a52febdb05.claim: " Murray Energy is ""the largest coal company in the United States."""
787039e86c44e09ee62ea8a52febdb05.label: false
787039e86c44e09ee62ea8a52febdb05.passage:
0: Murray Energy Corp., a major player in the coal-mining industry, declared bankruptcy in late October, sending shockwaves across coal-dependent regions of West Virginia and neighboring states.
1: In addition to putting coal employment at risk, the company is the last major employer contributing to the United Mine Workers of America’s pension plan.
2: With such a big development, it was no surprise that Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., quickly weighed in on Twitter .
3: "Murray Energy, the largest coal company in the United States, filed for bankruptcy," Manchin tweeted on Oct. 29, 2019.
4: "If Murray rejects the UMWA pension plan obligations in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the UMWA pension fund will be insolvent by 2020.
5: Before last night it was projected to be insolvent by 2022."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com However, we noticed a problem with how Manchin described Murray Energy.
7: Is it really the largest coal company in the United States?
8: Manchin’s office pointed us to a New York Times article published about the bankruptcy the same day as his tweet.
9: The article includes this sentence: "Murray, the nation’s largest privately held coal company, has nearly 7,000 employees and operates 17 mines in six states across Appalachia and the South as well as two mines in Colombia."
10: Manchin’s office also cited a CNN article from the same day that used similar language.
11: "The slow death of the American coal industry has forced Murray Energy, the largest private coal miner in the United States, to file for bankruptcy protection Tuesday," CNN’s article said.
12: Manchin’s tweet glossed over a phrase repeated in both articles -- "privately held."
13: So where does Murray rank among all coal companies?
14: Murray Energy pointed us to data from the Energy Information Administration, a division of the federal Department of Energy.
15: Here’s a table drawn from the agency’s statistics.
16: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com This shows that Murray Energy ranks fourth, behind Peabody Energy Corp. , Arch Coal Inc. , and Cloud Peak Energy .
17: We confirmed that each of the three companies ahead of Murray are publicly held, making Murray the largest private coal company but not the largest coal company overall.

gpt4: The claim that Murray Energy is the largest coal company in the United States is not true.
An analysis of coal industry ranking as seen on PolitiFact.com shows that Murray Energy ranks fourth, behind Peabody Energy Corp., Arch Coal Inc., and Cloud Peak Energy[16].
Furthermore, confirmation shows that each of the three companies ahead of Murray Energy are publicly held.
This means that while Murray Energy may rank as the largest private coal company, it does not hold the position of the largest coal company overall in the United States[17].
Therefore, in answer to the query raised about where Murray Energy ranks among all coal companies in the US, the company does not lead the pack[13].
Following the attempt to ascertain whether Murray Energy is indeed the largest American coal company, the response would be in the negative[7].

0eb69b5181fbfb55f7db70a5a435d0c0.claim: On average, one person dies by suicide every 22 hours in West Virginia.
0eb69b5181fbfb55f7db70a5a435d0c0.label: true
0eb69b5181fbfb55f7db70a5a435d0c0.passage:
0: Sen. Shelley Moore Capito, R-W.Va., recently sought to raise awareness about suicide, focusing on its toll in her home state.
1: "On average, one person dies by suicide every 22 hours in West Virginia," Capito said in a Facebook post on Sept. 19.
2: She went on to note her efforts with two Senate colleagues, Cory Gardner, R-Colo., and Doug Jones, D-Ala., to pass the Suicide Training and Awareness Nationally Delivered for Universal Prevention, or STANDUP, Act, which would expand efforts to educate young people about mental health resources.
3: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Is Capito correct about the frequency of suicide in West Virginia?
4: Capito’s office did not respond to an inquiry for this article, but we were able to find statistics that backed up her assertion.
5: We turned to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s WISQARS database , which includes data as recently as 2017.
6: The database shows that there were 393 suicides in West Virginia.
7: With 8,760 hours in a year, that comes out to about one suicide every 22.3 hours, making Capito’s statistic correct.
8: According to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, suicide is the 10th most common cause of death in West Virginia.
9: It ranks even higher for certain age groups, ranking second among those between 15 and 34 and fourth among those between 35 and 54.
10: On a per capita basis, West Virginia has the eighth-highest rate of suicide in the nation.
11: We checked with both the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and University of Denver associate professor of social work Stacey Freedenthal, a specialist in suicide, and both agreed that there are no complications with the data that would undercut Capito’s statement.

gpt4: The claim that on average, one person dies by suicide in West Virginia every 22 hours is indeed true.
Statistical data found supports this assertion; the database records showed a total of 393 suicides in the state [6].
Taking into account that there are 8,760 hours in a year, this data means that there is approximately one suicide every 22.3 hours[7], thereby validating Senator Capito's statistics.
Furthermore, while Capito's office did not directly respond to an inquiry for this article, the statistics found do align with her claim [4].

af989e0baaf6608b259c7b39a001418f.claim: President Trump has lifted the prospect of voters across Vermont, overseeing a 11,742 decline of Vermont residents on food stamps.
af989e0baaf6608b259c7b39a001418f.label: half-true
af989e0baaf6608b259c7b39a001418f.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s campaign announced in an email to Vermont media this week that it will be deploying resources to Vermont to help elect Republicans up and down the ballot in 2020.
1: In the email, the campaign took credit for the economic improvement the state has seen under Trump’s presidency.
2: It said that since he took office in 2017, Trump has added thousands of jobs across the state and given Vermonters an average tax cut of about $1,500.
3: It also claimed that under Trump, fewer Vermonters have had to rely on food stamps.
4: "President Trump has lifted the prospect of voters across Vermont, overseeing a 11,742 decline of Vermont residents on food stamps," the campaign wrote.
5: We know that Trump is in favor of restricting food stamp eligibility, and has even proposed a rule change that would cut benefits worth $7.5 million to about 5,200 households in Vermont.
6: But has his presidency really led to reduced demand for the benefits?
7: Trump’s campaign, which did not respond to a request for comment, is correct that since the president took office, Vermont has seen about 12,000 fewer people using food stamps.
8: When he entered the White House in January 2017, Vermont had 78,878 residents receiving benefits through the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) program, according to data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
9: In August 2019, the last month for which public data was available, that number was 67,195 — representing a drop of 11,683.
10: But data also show that the demand for food stamps in Vermont has been falling consistently since around 2013, when Vermont’s economy started turning a corner after the Great Recession.
11: At peak demand in 2013, about 100,000 Vermonters were using food stamps.
12: By January 2017, when Trump took office, that number had already fallen to about 79,000.
13: Sean Brown, deputy commissioner of Vermont’s Economic Services Division, said that since 2013, when the economy took a turn for the better and jobs started returning to the state, food stamps in Vermont have seen steady decline in use.
14: "That’s just been a trend that we’ve been experiencing for the last six years as the economy has improved and stayed strong," Brown said.
15: Since 2014, the steady decline in demand for SNAP benefits has been a national trend, according to Elaine Waxman, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute’s Income and Benefits Policy Center.
16: She said that Trump deserves some credit for the drop in Vermont and around the U.S., because the economy during his time in office has remained strong.
17: But she said it can’t all be pinned on his presidency.
18: "It’s been a continuation of a trend that’s already begun," Wexler said.
19: "Certainly the continued improvement of the economy contributes to that because more people are working and more people may have income available that would put them above that cutoff but it wouldn’t solely be related to one administration or the other."
20: Erin O’Brien, an associate professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts Boston who specializes in  U.S. social welfare policy, said that it may not just be the economy that’s leading fewer Vermonters to use food stamps.
21: Trump’s proposed cuts to SNAP may also be discouraging more people from using the program, she said.
22: And she added that undocumented immigrants may be avoiding signing up for food stamps , fearing Trump’s hard-line immigration policies.
23: "It’s not necessarily that people are being lifted out of poverty," she said.
24: "It’s that they’re increasingly afraid to use a government program, or they think it might be cut."
25: She said that "correlation isn’t causation," and that just because the demand for food stamps has fallen under Trump doesn’t mean he’s responsible for the trend.
26: "Sitting presidents like to take credit for trends that predate them when they’re positive, but when it’s bad news sitting presidents are very good at blaming the last guy in office," she said.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump oversaw an 11,742 decrease of Vermont residents using food stamps is partially true, given the numbers from Trump's campaign indicate that the state has seen about 12,000 fewer people using food stamps since the start of his presidency[7].
However, these numbers don't tell the full story.
Data shows that the use of food stamps in Vermont has been decreasing consistently since around 2013, following a boost in the state’s economy after the Great Recession [10][13].
While the strength of the economy during Trump's tenure may have contributed to this decline [16], it can't all be attributed to his presidency [17].

Other factors, such as Trump's proposed cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and his hard-line immigration policies, have possibly discouraged some people, including undocumented immigrants, from signing up for food stamps [21][22].

4b559fa967918ba975c4d7b4d73c3c67.claim: All the Democrats on the entire stage — every Democratic candidate said they want to give free health care to illegals.
4b559fa967918ba975c4d7b4d73c3c67.label: false
4b559fa967918ba975c4d7b4d73c3c67.passage:
0: The leaders of Florida’s two major political parties squared off less than a year before Election Day, throwing partisan jabs over health care and immigration.
1: Florida Democratic Party chairwoman Terrie Rizzo called out Republican efforts to undermine the Affordable Care Act established under former President Barack Obama.
2: Republican Party of Florida chairman Joe Gruters said it is Democrats with a health care problem.
3: Gruters, a state senator from Sarasota, referenced the first presidential primary debate in June , in which moderators asked the crowded field to raise their hands if they supported certain positions.
4: "All the Democrats on the entire stage — every Democratic candidate said they want to give free health care to illegals," Gruters said during a Tampa Bay Times forum Nov. 6.
5: "That’s them saying, that’s what they said in the debate.
6: It wasn’t me saying it.
7: They raised their hands — every single one of them — free health care for illegals."
8: In the middle of his reply, Rizzo said: "Fact-check it!"
9: It wasn’t the first time PolitiFact heard this claim.
10: President Donald Trump used a similar attack in a July ad for his re-election campaign, and it rates Mostly False .
11: Gruters’ statement is not more accurate, and here’s why.
12: What happened with the Democrats in June At the first Democratic presidential debate in Miami in June, NBC debate moderator and Today show cohost Savannah Guthrie asked a group of candidates to "raise your hand if your government plan would provide coverage for undocumented immigrants."
13: All candidates on stage raised their hands.
14: They weren’t all the candidates, because the first presidential debate was split into two nights.
15: On the stage were author Marianne Williamson, former Colorado Gov.
16: John Hickenlooper, entrepreneur Andrew Yang, South Bend, Ind.
17: Mayor Pete Buttigieg, former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Sen. Kamala Harris of California, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, Sen. Michael Bennet of Colorado, and Rep. Eric Swalwell of California.
18: (Hickenlooper, Gillibrand and Swalwell have dropped out.)
19: The candidates were not asked if that coverage would be free.
20: Guthrie then asked two candidates — Buttigieg and Biden — to comment.
21: Neither one said they would give "free" health care to undocumented immigrants.
22: Buttigieg spoke about people buying into a system and said that undocumented immigrants pay certain taxes.
23: "This is not about a handout," Buttigieg said.
24: "This is an insurance program."
25: Biden agreed, and spoke about the contributions by undocumented immigrants, including paying taxes.
26: So the debate Gruters mentioned doesn’t actually support what Gruters claimed.
27: But there is some question about how Medicare for All, a proposal some of the Democratic candidates support, would treat health care costs for undocumented immigrants.
28: Sanders’ version is a single, national health insurance program that would cover everyone who lives in the United States.
29: There would be no out-of-pocket costs to individuals — no deductibles, no copays or coinsurance — but anyone with a job or self-employed would pay into the system through taxes.
30: In that sense, coverage would not be free for anyone who works.
31: (Some immigrants in the country illegally pay income taxes .)
32: Sanders’ 2019 Medicare for All bill states that all residents — without specifying legal residents — are entitled to the benefits and that the health and human services secretary shall set criteria to determine residency.
33: Sanders’ immigration plan says Medicare for All will "provide comprehensive care to everyone in America, regardless of immigration status."
34: It also calls for employers to follow labor laws when employing undocumented immigrants, which suggests that they would pay the payroll tax.
35: However, some of the other Democrats on the debate stage specifically responded to a New York Times questionnaire with replies that showed the coverage would not be free.
36: Buttigieg , Bennet and Yang said undocumented immigrants would have the option to buy coverage through a public option, the insurance marketplace, or Medicare for All, respectively.
37: Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, one of the top contenders and another advocate for Medicare for All , was not on the debate stage that night.
38: (She went the night before .)
39: Her detailed financial plan for Medicare for All includes a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, which would increase federal revenue for Medicare for All as new people come into the system and pay taxes.
40: When PolitiFact told Gruters what we found — mainly that the debate question did not include the condition that it would be free coverage — he replied: "Illegal Immigrants have little more than what they are carrying with them when they cross the border, so as a result the only logical conclusion is that it would be free."

gpt4: The claim that every Democratic candidate on the stage said they want to give free health care to undocumented immigrants is false.
During the first Democratic presidential debate in Miami in June, candidates were asked by the moderator if their government plan would provide coverage for undocumented immigrants [12].
However, the debate was split into two nights, so not all candidates were present at the same time [14].
Furthermore, it must be clarified that the candidates were not explicitly asked if the coverage they proposed would be free [19].
None of the candidates stated they would provide "free" health care to undocumented immigrants [21].
Thus, the Tampa Bay Times forum, referred to by Gruters, does not provide genuine support for his claim [4][26].

d0471b572f06fb4ee4b183846c3951ee.claim: "  President Barack Obama was ""furious"" that he was caught on camera holding a pro-Muslim book."
d0471b572f06fb4ee4b183846c3951ee.label: false
d0471b572f06fb4ee4b183846c3951ee.passage:
0: A photo of former President Barack Obama shared on Facebook claims that the photographer was "in the right place at the right time" because Obama was apparently furious the picture was snapped.
1: The image shows Obama holding the book " The Post American World ," written by American journalist Fareed Zakaria .
2: While the photo is legitimate –– it was taken by New York Times photographer Doug Mills in 2008 when Obama was campaigning in Montana –– the message in the post about it is not accurate.
3: The text above the photo says : "A picture is worth a thousand words.
4: SOMEONE WAS AT THE RIGHT PLACE AT THE RIGHT TIME WITH A CAMERA.
5: IT WAS REPORTED THAT PRESIDENT OBAMA WAS FURIOUS THAT HE WAS CAUGHT ON CAMERA AND IT WAS PUBLISHED AND TRIED TO BLOCK IT.
6: The name of the book Obama is holding is called: The Post-American World, and it was written by a fellow Muslim.
7: (Fareed Zakaria) "Post" America means: The World "After" America!
8: If each person sends this to a minimum of twenty people on their address list, in three days, all people in the United States of America would have the message.
9: I believe this is the one photo that really should be passed around."
10: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: There is no evidence and no credible news reports that supports the claim that President Obama was "furious" that the photo was taken.
13: The photographer was a known member of the press and wasn’t secretly "in the right place at the right time.".
14: Besides authoring several books, Fareed Zakaria hosts the show "Fareed Zakaria GPS" for CNN Worldwide, and he is a columnist for the Washington Post and a contributing editor for The Atlantic, according to his website .
15: While Zakaria is Muslim-born, he has said in previous interviews that he does not consider himself a "religious guy."
16: The post also make the false claim that Obama is Muslim when it describes Zakaria as a "fellow" Muslim.
17: The characterization of the book is also wrong.
18: "The Post American World" is not a Muslim’s perspective on a future world with a toppled America, but is about "the rise of the rest" with the growth of countries like China and India.
19: In the first chapter, Zakaria writes : "This is a book not about the decline of America but rather about the rise of everyone else.
20: It is about the great transformation taking place around the world, a transformation that, though often discussed, remains poorly understood."
21: A Publishers Weekly review of the book called it "a stimulating, largely optimistic forecast of where the 21st century is heading," saying that Zakaria "predicts that despite its record of recent blunders at home and abroad, America will stay strong, buoyed by a stellar educational system and the influx of young immigrants, who give the U.S. a more youthful demographic than Europe and much of Asia whose workers support an increasing population of unproductive elderly."
22: The New York Times Sunday Book Review said the book is "a relentlessly intelligent book that eschews simple-minded projections from crisis to collapse … Zakaria’s is not another exercise in declinism.

gpt4: The claim that President Barack Obama was "furious" about being photographed holding a pro-Muslim book is false.
Although the photograph in question, taken by New York Times photographer Doug Mills in 2008, is legitimate, the context provided in the post is not accurate[2].
Not only is there no evidence supporting claims that Obama was "furious" about the photograph being taken, there are also no credible news reports verifying this [12].
Additionally, the implication that the photograph was taken surreptitiously is incorrect.
Rather than being covertly "in the right place at the right time," the photographer was a recognized press member [13].
The post also inaccurately pegs Obama as a Muslim when describing the author of the book, Fareed Zakaria, as a "fellow" Muslim [16].

Moreover, Zakaria's book, "The Post American World," does not propagate a Muslim perspective on a future world without America, but discusses "the rise of the rest" with the growth of countries like China and India [18].

659cb75cfd9e69c823e3a182d41f2abf.claim: " On Sept. 5, 1993, ""Vince Foster went to Fort Marcy Park and shot himself 3 times in the back of the head to avoid testifying against Hillary Clinton."""
659cb75cfd9e69c823e3a182d41f2abf.label: false
659cb75cfd9e69c823e3a182d41f2abf.passage:
0: An old allegation suggesting the Clinton family killed yet another associate is making the rounds again as Facebook users share this post from Sept. 5, 2018.
1: "On this date in 1993, Vince Foster went to Fort Marcy Park and shot himself 3 times in the back of the head to avoid testifying against Hillary Clinton," it says.
2: The post, which has been shared more than 79,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Here are the facts.
5: Vince Foster, deputy White House counsel to then-President Bill Clinton, killed himself on July 20, 1993 , at Fort Marcy Park in Virginia.
6: His death was grist for the conspiracy theory mill.
7: Critics of the Clintons speculated that the Clintons had killed Foster.
8: Dan Burton, then a Republican congressman from Indiana, "famously shot a melon in his backyard to ‘prove’ that Foster couldn’t have killed himself," an Esquire story says .
9: An autopsy concluded that he committed suicide, according to the story, but Foster’s death still drew the attention of, among others, Brett Kavanaugh before he was a Supreme Court justice.
10: Back then, Kavanaugh was on independent counsel Ken Starr’s team when it looked into whether Foster was murdered.
11: In early 1995, Kavanaugh offered Starr "the legal rationale for expanding his investigation of the Arkansas financial dealings of President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, to include the Foster death," the Washington Post reported .
12: "Kavanaugh, then 30, argued that unsupported allegations that Foster may have been murdered gave Starr the right to probe the matter more deeply.
13: Foster’s death had already been the focus of two investigations, both concluding that Foster committed suicide."
14: One investigation by then-special counsel Robert Fiske involved four lawyers, five physicians, seven FBI agents, approximately 125 witnesses, and DNA tests, the Washington Post reported in 1994 .
15: "According to Fiske," the paper said, "Foster’s death was a personal collapse, not a White House scandal."
16: He complained to his physician in Little Rock, Ark., about depression and anxiety, and his symptoms worsened when he got to Washington to work in the White House.
17: After he bore some of the political fallout from an incident that became known as "Travelgate," in which seven White House travel office employees were "fired amid hints of financial shenanigans," he became "increasingly obsessed" with the affair and the possibility of a congressional hearing, the Washington Post said.
18: "Though he was confident he and the White House had done nothing wrong," the paper wrote, "he told his friend Webster L. Hubbell that ‘in Washington you are assumed to have done something wrong even if you have not.’" After a series of critical editorials in the Wall Street Journal, he became more distraught, Fiske found.
19: "His anxiety over the congressional hearings deepened," according to the Post.
20: He told his sister he was depressed.
21: He ultimately shot himself once in the mouth with a gun.
22: Kavanaugh eventually affirmed the suicide finding and, in October 1997, Starr issued a report on Foster’s death and concluded that Foster killed himself.
23: But today, conspiracies continue to flourish.
24: In 2016, for example, President Donald Trump called Foster’s death "very fishy."

gpt4: The claim that Vince Foster shot himself three times in the back of the head at Fort Marcy Park to avoid testifying against Hillary Clinton on September 5, 1993 is inaccurate.
According to reports, Vince Foster, the deputy White House counsel to then-President Bill Clinton, committed suicide on July 20, 1993, at Fort Marcy Park in Virginia[5].
His death drew significant attention, including from now-Supreme Court justice, Brett Kavanaugh[9].
Indeed, an autopsy concluded that Foster had committed suicide by shooting himself once in the mouth with a gun[21].
The suicide conclusion was investigated thoroughly by then-special counsel Robert Fiske, which involved four lawyers, five physicians, seven FBI agents, around 125 witnesses, and DNA tests[14].
In October 1997, Kavanaugh affirmed the suicide finding and Starr issued a report concluding that Foster killed himself[22].
Therefore, the claim is false.

fdc8c0bce1da3aaef17e36cb9cf8e29a.claim: In WI, over 79% of Title X patients rely on Planned Parenthood for their basic health care.
fdc8c0bce1da3aaef17e36cb9cf8e29a.label: half-true
fdc8c0bce1da3aaef17e36cb9cf8e29a.passage:
0: It’s hard to have a health care debate without mentioning Planned Parenthood.
1: The organization has been caught in the middle of a years-long partisan battle over federal funding for the nonprofit organization, which is the largest abortion provider in the country.
2: In August 2019, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services issued rules that would bar health clinics from receiving any federal funding if they provide or refer patients for abortions with the exception of cases of rape, incest or a medical emergency.
3: Several 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have already pledged to provide funding for Planned Parenthood if they’re in office.
4: The organization, which has over 600 locations nationwide and 24 in Wisconsin, according to Wisconsin Public Radio , provides reproductive health care to patients, including those who are low-income or underinsured.
5: In response to the Trump administration’s action, U.S. Rep Mark Pocan, D-Madison, sent out this tweet: "In WI, over 79% of Title X patients rely on Planned Parenthood for their basic health care."
6: Is Pocan right?
7: Title X vs. Trump administration Let’s start with some background.
8: Title X is a federal grant program that serves low-income patients or those who don’t have health insurance.
9: It was first enacted in 1970 and signed into law by President Richard Nixon.
10: The program distributes about $260 million a year in family planning grants.
11: The program helps provide patients with cancer screenings, STD testing and annual exams for women, but it does not fund abortion care.
12: Instead of complying with the new rules, Planned Parenthood decided to pull out of the federal program, saying that forcing Title X providers to stop referring abortions would be unfair to patients and limit their access to reproductive health options.
13: According to the Guttmacher Institute , a research organization operating out of Washington D.C. and New York City that studies and advocates for the advancement of sexual and reproductive health and rights, Title X-funded providers serve about 3.8 million contraceptive clients.
14: Of that group, 1.6 million are served by Planned Parenthood centers.
15: The claim When asked for backup, Pocan spokesman Conor McCabe told us the congressman took the 79% figure from a Planned Parenthood graphic.
16: Planned Parenthood told us the Wisconsin statistics came from the Democratic staff of the U.S. Senate’s Health, Education, Labor and Pensions committee.
17: According to that research , there were 19 Title-X funded sites -- not limited to Planned Parenthood -- operating in Wisconsin in 2015.
18: Collectively, the sites provided contraceptive care to nearly 31,000 women across the state.
19: Planned Parenthood health centers served 79 percent of these women.
20: That does not exactly close the case, however.
21: Pocan’s claim said those patients rely on Planned Parenthood "for their basic health care."
22: That brings to mind such things as annual check-ups and flu shots.
23: But Title X doesn’t cover any of that, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
24: The money is strictly for reproductive health care.
25: "Title X funds only cover services that prevent or help to achieve pregnancy," said Mia Heck, director of external affairs at HHS.
26: Among the services covered: birth control, STD screenings, emergency contraception, breast exams, cervical cancer screenings and abortions.
27: One can argue those are considered basic care when it comes to reproductive issues.
28: But Pocan’s tweet used it more broadly, which was misleading.
29: To be sure, Planned Parenthood does provide more general health care.
30: Among the things it offers, according to its website : physicals, anemia testing and screenings for colon cancer, diabetes and cholesterol levels.
31: Certainly some Title X patients may get general care at Planned Parenthood clinics.
32: But that care is not paid for by Title X, as Pocan suggests.

gpt4: Congressman Pocan's claim that over 79% of Title X patients in Wisconsin rely on Planned Parenthood for their basic health care is only partially true.

While Planned Parenthood health centers indeed serve 79 percent of these women, as derived from a Planned Parenthood graphic[19][15], the claim is misleading in terms of what services are covered under Title X funding
According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Title X funds are strictly for reproductive health care and do not cover basic health care [23][24].
Thus, although these patients do depend on Planned Parenthood, it is not Title X that pays for their basic health care [21].

995a59a6853f1371dbce6c482c5712fa.claim: "  Thomas Jefferson said ""the government will one day be corrupt and filled with liars and the people will flock to the one who tells the truth."""
995a59a6853f1371dbce6c482c5712fa.label: false
995a59a6853f1371dbce6c482c5712fa.passage:
0: An alleged quote by Founding Father and former President Thomas Jefferson is circulating on social media.
1: The post in question features a photo of a crowded arena attended by folks in red caps.
2: The words "TRUMP" and "2020" border the top and bottom of the photo.
3: And inside the picture is this quote attributed to Jefferson: "The government will one day be corrupt and filled with liars and the people will flock to the one who tells the truth."
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: This is one of many fictitious statements that have been attributed to Jefferson on the internet over the years.
7: Like others we have fact-checked, there is no evidence he said or wrote it.
8: The quote, or any variation of it, could not be found in a search of the Papers of Thomas Jefferson .
9: A search for it in the Jefferson encyclopedia and collections of his writings and speeches online yielded no results.
10: The Jefferson library at Monticello, his Virginia estate, reported that the quote started being linked to the third president online in about 2015.
11: "This quotation has not been found in the writings of Thomas Jefferson," Monticello research research librarian Anna Berkes wrote on the Monticello website.
12: "It seems to exist mainly on Twitter, but we have been unable to trace its existence before 2015."
13: We reached out to Berkes to check if she has come across any variation of it since.
14: She told us the quote still can’t be located.
15: "All signs point to it being entirely spurious," Berkes wrote in an email.
16: "Usually with a genuine quote, you’ll see it appearing in books by historians or previous compilations of Jefferson’s writings; this one still doesn’t seem to have any paper trail at all."
17: Berkes also wrote a blog post in 2011 to help people know how to spot fake Jefferson quotes.
18: Among her tips: Jefferson almost never used contractions nor did he use the word "you" as an indefinite pronoun.
19: Berkes also warned readers to be wary of quotes that have no citation as to when and where it was said and those that can only be found in non-historical literature.
20: There’s no evidence to support that Jefferson said or wrote this.

gpt4: The claim that Thomas Jefferson said, "the government will one day be corrupt and filled with liars and the people will flock to the one who tells the truth", has been debunked.

Extensive research, including searches in the Papers of Thomas Jefferson and the Jefferson Encyclopedia, as well as collections of his writings and speeches online, has yielded no results corroborating the quote's attribution to Jefferson [8][9].
Moreover, Monticello's research librarian Anna Berkes confirmed that the quotation does not belong to Thomas Jefferson's writings [11].
Despite diligent efforts, the location of the quote still remains elusive[14].
Consequently, it has been concluded that there is no evidence indicating that Jefferson either said or wrote the quote[7][20].

0d2dc8a5b3e85d0695647ce967581138.claim: Illinois lost population in 94 out of the last 95 years, so it’s not like it’s a new thing that we have a slight out-trickle of people leaving the state.
0d2dc8a5b3e85d0695647ce967581138.label: false
0d2dc8a5b3e85d0695647ce967581138.passage:
0: In 2018, the U.S. Census Bureau released figures showing the population of Illinois had declined for a fifth year in a row .
1: The year before, it fell behind Pennsylvania as the nation’s fifth-largest state.
2: The string of recent declines has generated considerable debate, with politicians frequently spinning it to buttress their own policy arguments.
3: This summer, we rated False a claim in which a Republican state lawmaker said Illinois lost middle-class families after the state instituted its last income tax hike.
4: And in years past, Democrats attacked former Gov.
5: Bruce Rauner over the population loss that occurred under his watch.
6: During a sit-down interview at FIA’s annual futures and options expo in Chicago, Democratic Gov.
7: J.B. Pritzker brought up the downward trend while highlighting the work his administration is doing to make higher education more affordable.
8: "People talk about the exodus from Illinois and they’ve blamed it on a lot of things, because we’ve lost population," Pritzker said .
9: "Illinois lost population in 94 out of the last 95 years, so it’s not like it’s a new thing that we have a slight out-trickle of people leaving the state.
10: Nevertheless, I’d like to reverse it.
11: And so, the best way to do that is actually to keep our students here and attract students to our universities."
12: Has Illinois, which is still the nation’s sixth-largest state, lost population almost every year for most of the past century?
13: And what, exactly, does Pritzker mean by "lost population?"
14: Mixed messages The first and most specific part of Pritzker’s claim is contradicted by annual population estimates maintained by the federal government.
15: Illinois’ overall population has grown — not declined — in all but 15 of the past 95 years for which the U.S. Census Bureau has data.
16: In 1924, Illinois’ population was 7.2 million, while in 2018, 12.7 million resided in the state.
17: Figures for 2019 have not yet been released .
18: So if population has gone up for most of the past century, what was Pritzker talking about?
19: We asked his spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh, who told us the governor wasn’t referring to total population but "net domestic migration," which is a subset of overall population that measures the difference between the number of people who move into Illinois from another state versus those who move out of Illinois to other states.
20: If more people leave Illinois than arrive from other states, it’s considered net domestic out-migration, a definition that jibes with the second half of Pritzker’s comment about a "slight out-trickle" of Illinois residents.
21: And a 2016 report authored by some of the state’s most prominent tax policy experts suggest he’s correct that net domestic out-migration isn’t a new phenomenon.
22: Aside from a small increase in 1947, the last time more people moved from other states into Illinois than out of it was 1920, according to the report, which drew on estimates compiled from multiple federal sources by migration expert Lyman Stone.
23: "Illinois has reliably had negative net domestic migration for a century," Stone told us in an email.
24: That also tracks with an analysis of census population estimates conducted by Brookings Institution demographer William Frey in response to our inquiry.
25: He found Illinois has experienced net domestic out-migration annually since 2000, the earliest year for which he had comparable data.
26: While domestic out-migration has driven Illinois’ recent decline, however, Frey cautioned it’s still just one piece of the puzzle when looking at changes in population over time.
27: It’s a metric that does not account for international migration, which Illinois and other large states such as New York and California have relied on for population gains.
28: Nor does it include increases from the number of births that occur in a state.

gpt4: The claim that Illinois lost population in 94 out of the last 95 years has been proven false.
In fact, according to the U.S. Census Bureau's data, Illinois' overall population has grown, not declined, in all but 15 of the past 95 years [15].
This information directly contradicts the initial assertion made by Pritzker [14].

Although it is true that Illinois has had a consistent negative net domestic migration for a century, as pointed out by Stone [23], the state's total population nonetheless experienced an overall increase, going from 7.2 million residents in 1924 to 12.7 million residents in 2018[16].
This data is also backed up by an analysis performed by Brookings Institution demographer William Frey [24].
Hence, the claim of a steady decline in the state's population is baseless and unfounded.

6da0386d894ae0737071ee7435e6efe0.claim: "  Jeb Bush tweeted ""Ok boomer"" at Donald Trump."
6da0386d894ae0737071ee7435e6efe0.label: false
6da0386d894ae0737071ee7435e6efe0.passage:
0: A 25-year-old New Zealand politician recently dismissed a senior lawmaker who interrupted her speech on climate change with two words: "OK boomer."
1: The retort to older people who just don’t get it has gone mainstream, but don’t be fooled into thinking former Florida Gov.
2: Jeb Bush said it to his one-time political rival.
3: An image shared on Facebook on Nov. 4 appears to show Bush tweeting "Ok boomer" in response to Trump’s tweet characterizing the impeachment inquiry as a "Scam and Witch Hunt."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: Yes, Bush is only 66 to Trump’s 73 , but reviewing his Twitter feed on Oct. 9 we found no such tweet.
7: Rather, he responded to a tweet from Michael Morrell, the former acting and deputy director of the CIA.
8: Morrell said: "The Turkish military is about to move into Syria.
9: President Trump allowed this to happen.
10: An ethnic cleansing of our Kurdish allies, a boost to ISIS, and a foreign policy gift to Russia, Iran, & China will be the result.
11: America’s standing in the world will take an immense hit."
12: Bush retweeted Morrell and wrote, "This is a tragedy."
13: He also retweeted New York Times columnist Ross Douthat , an Illinois congressman, and U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham .
14: Searching on Twitchy , which keeps tabs on high-profile people who delete their tweets, we didn’t find evidence that Bush tweeted and then deleted.
15: We also didn’t find any evidence searching for echoes of the tweet more broadly online.
16: Finally, we searched the Nexis news archive for "Jeb Bush" and "Donald Trump" and "Ok boomer" and got no matches.
17: If a lawmaker in New Zealand unknown to many Americans can draw U.S. media attention for saying "OK boomer," we expect Jeb Bush would as well.

gpt4: The claim that Jeb Bush tweeted "Ok boomer" at Donald Trump is false.
An image that was shared on Facebook on Nov. 4 seems to show Bush responding to a Trump tweet with "Ok boomer"[3].
However, this post was flagged as part of Facebook's ongoing efforts to counteract false news and misinformation in its News Feed[4].
Furthermore, a review of Bush's Twitter feed on Oct. 9 revealed no such tweet[6].
Moreover, the website Twitchy, known for monitoring deleted tweets from high-profile personas, bears no record of such a tweet from Bush[14].
No evidence of this alleged tweet could be found through a broader online search[15].

0bc0e5986ff64a2d3ddc609fc9917de5.claim: " Photos from Sept. 11, 2001, show that ""Donald Trump joined America’s heroes and carried victims over his shoulders down the steps of the burning World Trade Center. Obama spent the whole day sitting in the Oval Office with his feet on the desk watching basketball."""
0bc0e5986ff64a2d3ddc609fc9917de5.label: false
0bc0e5986ff64a2d3ddc609fc9917de5.passage:
0: Where were you on 9/11?
1: According to an image shared on Facebook recently, President Donald Trump was helping first responders and former President Barack Obama was watching sports in the White House.
2: "On September 11, 2001, Donald Trump joined America’s heroes and carried victims over his shoulders down the steps of the burning World Trade Center.
3: Obama spent the whole day sitting in the Oval Office with his feet on the desk watching basketball."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: Astute historians will recall that it was former President George W. Bush who was in office in 2001 and was famously reading a children’s book called "The Pet Goat" to a class of first graders when the attacks happened.
7: Obama was serving in the Illinois State Senate in 2001.
8: The image of him that appears in the Facebook post is real, but it’s just been doctored to look like he’s watching a basketball game.
9: There’s no TV in the original photo, image No.
10: 8 in this slideshow, taken by then-White House photographer Pete Souza.
11: Rather, Obama is meeting with his national security adviser, Tom Danilon, Chief of Staff Jack Lew, and Denis McDonough, deputy national-security adviser, on Nov. 14, 2012.
12: Trump, meanwhile, has been edited into this photo taken by Reuters photographer Shannon Stapleton.
13: It shows rescue workers removing Father Mychal Judge from the World Trade Center tower on Sept. 11.
14: Trump was near the Ground Zero site two days after the attacks when he gave a TV interview a few blocks away.
15: As we’ve noted in a previous fact-check , that interview marked the first of several times when he would say, without evidence, that he had sent a lot of men to help in the area.
16: Richard Alles, a New York Department battalion chief on Sept. 11, told us that he had no knowledge of Trump being at the site or sending workers there to help.
17: "I was in a supervisory role with the fire department at the time," said Alles, who said he was on the scene about 20 minutes after the second building collapsed.
18: "I was there for several months — I have no knowledge of his being down there."

gpt4: The claim that Donald Trump helped carry down victims out of the burning World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, and that Obama spent the day in the Oval Office is false.
Richard Alles, a New York Department battalion chief on Sept. 11, stated that he was not aware of Trump being at Ground Zero, or of his sending workers to help there [16].
This is further corroborated by the fact that Trump's proximity to Ground Zero was a TV interview he gave a few blocks away, two days after the attacks [14].
Additionally, the claim about Obama is also untrue, as in 2001, he was serving in the Illinois State Senate[7], and therefore could not have been in the Oval Office as suggested.

bf848b56338351be7a4711a0a68f2e68.claim: JFK Jr was declared the frontrunner for the NY Senate seat in 1999. Days later his plane crashed, making Hillary Clinton the newly elected senator.
bf848b56338351be7a4711a0a68f2e68.label: false
bf848b56338351be7a4711a0a68f2e68.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post revisits well-trodden conspiracy theories about the Clinton family and suggests Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s ambition knows no bounds.
1: "JFK Jr was declared the frontrunner for the NY Senate seat in 1999," the Nov. 5 post says.
2: "Days later his plane crashed, making Hillary Clinton the newly elected senator."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: It’s been shared more than 2,000 times.
6: An identical post from 2017 is nearing 30,000 shares.
7: Here are the facts.
8: On July 16, 1999, John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and his sister-in-law were killed in a plane crash.
9: Kennedy, then the founder and publisher of George magazine, was piloting the single-engine Piper Saratoga when it plunged into the Atlantic Ocean .
10: Then-President Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton and Chelsea Clinton attended the memorial mass .
11: The National Transportation Safety Board determined that the crash probably happened after Kennedy, who was inexperienced at flying his plane alone at night, became disoriented in haze .
12: Kennedy was not a candidate for any public office when he died.
13: But a few days after this death, the New York Daily News ran a story citing two anonymous friends who said they thought Kennedy would have run for office some day.
14: "Earlier this year, in one of the best-kept secrets in state politics, Kennedy considered seeking the seat of retiring Sen. Daniel Moynihan (D-N.Y.) in 2000, the friends confirmed yesterday," the story says.
15: Though a private poll in 1997 found that JFK Jr. was the state’s most popular Democrat by far, according to the story, "the idea became moot once First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton signaled her interest in running, but the two friends said they expected the son of the slain president eventually would have jumped into politics as a candidate."
16: A 1999 Washington Post story says that a "Kennedy insider" claimed leading Democrats had unsuccessfully approached Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to run for Moynihan’s seat.
17: Hillary Clinton was elected to Moynihan’s vacated seat on Nov. 7, 2000.

gpt4: The claim that JFK Jr. was declared the frontrunner for the NY Senate seat just before his death, paving the way for Hillary Clinton's election, is false.

Although JFK Jr. had considered running for the NY Senate seat in 2000 according to some sources, the reality is that he never officially became a candidate for any public office before his untimely death[12][14].
The seat, vacated by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, was subsequently won by Hillary Clinton in an election held on November 7, 2000, long after JFK Jr.'s death [17].
Therefore, any suggestion of a direct causation between JFK Jr's death and Clinton's election is ill-founded.

54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.claim: people shouldn’t make birthday donations on Facebook because the organization can claim the donation as a tax write-off, and only has to deliver 15% of the donation to the charity organization.
54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.label: false
54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.passage:
0: You’ve seen the posts on your timeline –– Facebook friends asking for donations to a charity of their choosing in lieu of birthday wishes or presents.
1: But one post circulating on the social media website warns users against using the Facebook feature to make donations.
2: The post begins with, "Do you know what really happens when you donate your birthday to charity on Facebook?"
3: It goes on to say: "1.
4: Even as a charity donations broker, officially Facebook is allowed to say they donated it themselves as a corporate entity.
5: 2
6: As a corporate entity, Facebook is allowed to declare your donation for a tax write off.
7: 3
8: Facebook gets to brag in the media how much they donated to charity, even though it was your money.
9: 4
10: As a charitable donations broker, by law, they only need to actually deliver 15% of your donation to the charity organization you have chosen.
11: DON’T DONATE TO CHARITY VIA FACEBOOK!"
12: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
13: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
14: This isn’t true.
15: Facebook is a donation platform, and one that people appear to be using a lot.
16: The company in September 2019 announced that since 2015, 45 million people have raised over $2 billion on the platform, with over $1 billion of that total coming from birthday fundraisers.
17: What Facebook is not is a "charity donations broker" (in fact, charity experts told us they’ve never heard that term before).
18: The organization told us it does not declare users’ donations as tax write-offs, nor does it deliver only 15% of a person’s intended donation to the charity specified.
19: Facebook members can access more than 750,000 nonprofit organizations using the social media donations platform.
20: Facebook says it vets organizations by checking their 501(c)(3) status, IRS registration and tax ID numbers.
21: Each nonprofit’s Facebook page also includes a link to its detailed profile on GuideStar , an organization that tracks nonprofits using a database designed to help paint a picture of a nonprofit’s activities and health.
22: Facebook spokesperson Roya Winner told PolitiFact in an email that the post’s claims are "completely false."
23: "Facebook never claims any user’s donations as our own, nor are we a ‘charity donations broker.’ We are a donation platform and payments to charities are processed by our licensed, regulated subsidiaries," Winner said.
24: "A donation to a nonprofit through its Facebook Page or a fundraiser on Facebook may be tax-deductible for the person who made the donation."
25: The Facebook help center has a page explaining whether a particular donation is tax-deductible.
26: It explains that since tax laws vary by country and region, users should consult a tax professional and review laws in their area to determine whether their donation is tax-deductible.
27: The website also says that after a donation is made through the platform, a confirmation is sent to the email listed on that person’s Facebook account.
28: The confirmation shows the person made the donation as a charitable contribution, includes the nonprofit’s EIN number, and states that the donor is not receiving any goods or services in return.
29: But what about the claim that Facebook, by law, only needs to deliver "15% of your donation to the charity organization you have chosen?"
30: That’s also bogus.
31: "100% of what’s raised using donate buttons and fundraisers created on Facebook goes to the benefiting nonprofit," Winner wrote in an email.
32: "Nonprofits either receive funds directly from Facebook, or via Network for Good, a Donor Advised Fund we partner with."
33: These are the two main ways nonprofits can raise funds on Facebook.
34: When a nonprofit enrolls in Facebook Payments, it has to raise at least $100 (per nonprofit, not per fundraiser) before it receives a payout directly to its bank account.
35: Funds will roll over until the payout amount reaches the $100 minimum, and the payment process takes about two weeks, Facebook says .
36: The organization should receive the donation about a month after it is made.
37: For nonprofits not registered with Facebook Payments, donations can be dispersed through fundraising platforms Network for Good (used for the U.S, Canada and Australia) or PayPal Giving Fund (used for other international organizations).
38: Network for Good can take 45-75 days for a donation to be received.
39: For PayPal Giving Fund, it’s between 15-90 days.
40: Only nonprofits that are onboarded through Facebook Payments, or through Network for Good or Paypal Giving Fund, are able to fundraise on Facebook.
41: Though some may worry that such contributions made to charities using the for-profit Facebook platform may not be tax-deductible, Winner told us that concern is unfounded.
42: "That’s an inaccurate representation, the donation goes to the organization, not Facebook," she said.
43: "It is stated as a charitable contribution to the specific nonprofit on the confirmation receipt, along with the organization’s EIN number."
44: Facebook covers all fees for donations made on its website to charitable organizations.
45: In November 2017 , the company announced it would drop the 5% transaction fee on donations to nonprofits on its platform.
46: Facebook once had a 4.3% platform fee for personal fundraisers –– which allows people to host their own fundraiser for a personal cause –– but it eliminated that in May 2018 .
47: Personal fundraisers are now subject to a 2.6% payment processing fee plus $0.30.
48: In some countries, additional taxes will be deducted when the money raised is distributed.
49: The fees broken down by country can be found here.

gpt4: The claim that Facebook keeps a sizable percentage of birthday donations and uses them as a tax write-off is unfounded.
According to Facebook, it is not a "charity donations broker" and does not claim users' donations as its own[17][23].
Its role is to act as a donation platform, facilitating the process of giving, where the payments to charities are handled by their licensed subsidiaries[23].
Facebook has also categorically stated that it sends 100% of what it raises via donate buttons and fundraisers directly to the benefiting non-profits[44].
Following this, the statements about Facebook only delivering 15% of donations to charities and claiming donations as tax write-offs are evidently false[18].

cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.claim: Defendants charged with producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child will be arraigned & set free.
cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.label: half-true
cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.passage:
0: Changes in New York’s bail laws have been hailed by some nonprofit criminal justice organizations as a way to reduce inequities and mass incarceration.
1: The changes will allow people who have been charged with certain crimes to stay out of jail while waiting for their trials without having to come up with money to post bail.
2: But some in law enforcement are critical of the changes, which eliminate money bail for offenses that account for approximately 90 percent of arrests statewide.
3: The union that represents active and retired police officers in New York City made a claim about the new law, which takes effect Jan. 1.
4: In a Twitter post , the New York City Police Benevolent Association said, "Defendants charged with producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child will be arraigned & set free."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com As evidence for its claim, the police union included in its tweet a section of state law regarding child pornography.
6: The union cited section 263.10 of the penal code, which states : "A person is  guilty of promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child when, knowing the character and  content thereof, he produces, directs or promotes any obscene performance which includes sexual conduct by a child less than seventeen years of age.
7: Promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child is a class D felony."
8: We’ve heard many claims about what the new law will do, and we wondered if the police union’s claim is accurate.
9: The law’s details The new law has a list of "qualifying" offenses for which a judge can set bail.
10: These qualifying offenses are serious crimes, and some involve child pornography.
11: Judges are permitted to impose bail under the new law for these offenses: facilitating a sexual performance by a child with a controlled substance or alcohol, use of a child in a sexual performance, or luring a child for the purpose of committing a crime against him or her.
12: On April 1, 2019, when the new law was passed, three people with these qualifying offenses were in jail awaiting trial in New York City, according to a report from the Center for Court Innovation, which advocates for alternatives to incarceration.
13: But not every child pornography charge described in the statute is a qualifying offense.
14: A person charged with the offense cited by the union -- "producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child" -- would have to be released and bail would not be imposed.
15: New York’s pretrial law - the current one and the one that takes effect Jan. 1 - does not allow judges to evaluate whether a person is dangerous to the community when deciding whether that person should be held before trial.
16: Unlike in other states, judges can only consider whether a  defendant is likely to return to court .
17: In cases where a judge has doubts about whether the defendant is likely to return, the judge would have to "release the principal" and select a non-monetary option, such as pretrial supervision or travel restrictions, and choose the least restrictive option "that will reasonably assure the principal’s return to court," according to the law.
18: What experts say We spoke with legal experts, some who specialize in prosecution and others in criminal defense.
19: Many agreed with the police union's tweet.
20: But several pointed to what they call a more realistic legal scenario.
21: Taryn Merkl, a former federal prosecutor who led a human trafficking task force in Brooklyn, said that it is hard for her to imagine a set of facts in which a prosecutor would charge only this crime and not something more serious that would require bail.
22: "This doesn’t strike me as the main charge one would bring," said Merkl, who is senior counsel in the Justice Program & Law Enforcement Leaders at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University Law School.
23: The Brennan Center is in favor of ending mass incarceration .
24: We looked at arrest records from New York City since 2006 to get a sense of how often police charge this specific crime.
25: We found that in at least 135 arrests, approximately 10 per year, this charge was the top charge.
26: Merkl noted that that the charges that prosecutors decide to bring in a complaint or indictment can be different from those charges that a police file during an arrest.
27: In addition, charges other than the "top charge" for these defendants could require detention, even if the top charge does not, according to the Center for Court Innovation.
28: Rebecca Town, a criminal defense attorney at the Legal Aid Bureau of Buffalo, which assists low-income people, said the charge cited by the police union is "almost always" accompanied by a sex offense under Article 130 of the state penal code, which allows a judge to set cash bail.
29: "If the individual accused is directly responsible for creating such material, they will be charged with something that is directly a sex offense that would still trigger money bail," Town said.

gpt4: The claim that defendants charged with creating or promoting obscene material involving minors can be arraigned and freed is partially correct, according to the New York City Police Benevolent Association[4].
These kinds of cases are unlikely to impose custody or bail as its key charge [14].
However, this claim does not consider other possible charges that the defendant may face.

According to Taryn Merkl, a former federal prosecutor and leader of a human trafficking task force in Brooklyn, it's unlikely that the prosecution would limit charges to this crime alone without involving more severe charges, which may necessitate bail [21].
The Center for Court Innovation further adds that other charges for these defendants could result in detention, even if the main charge does not [27].
If the accused individual is directly involved in creating such material, they could be charged with a sex offense that still requires bail [29].

95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.claim: " Texas lawmakers ""left children able to be sterilized and mutilated at any point in their life"" by failing to adopt a law prohibiting minors from undergoing medical or surgical gender transitions."
95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.label: false
95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.passage:
0: During an Oct. 31 press conference, leaders from conservative advocacy organizations in Texas urged Gov.
1: Greg Abbott to call a special legislative session to elect a new House speaker.
2: Earlier that month, embattled House Speaker Dennis Bonnen announced that he would not seek re-election to his seat in the House.
3: The activists also outlined policy proposals that they want lawmakers to address during a special session, proposals they say Republican leaders failed to pursue during the regular session earlier this year.
4: Cindi Castilla, president of the Dallas Eagle Forum, said lawmakers need to take steps to limit what gender transition treatments are available to children, in light of an ongoing legal battle in Dallas over the gender identity of a 7-year-old.
5: "During our last session, our legislators decided to pass a law protecting Texans from e-cigarettes until they reach the age of 21," she said.
6: "They left children able to be sterilized and mutilated at any point in their life.
7: This was a failing, and we need a remedy.
8: "Texas Eagle Forum asked lawmakers to carry a very common-sense bill that would protect young Texans.
9: That bill would have protected (the child), no matter what the verdict was going to be from the courts."
10: Before we dive into this check, it should be noted that medical or surgical treatments used by doctors for transitioning must meet the same safety requirements of other medications or surgeries.
11: To suggest that any child might be mutilated by doctors is inaccurate.
12: "Children in Texas are already robustly protected by the Texas Family Code and medical rules of ethics," said Brian Klosterboer, an attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, in a statement.
13: "No one in Texas may harm a child, including parents and medical professionals."
14: When reached via email, Castilla said that she is unaware of any state laws that "protect children from being given treatments that can lead to sterilization and no law prohibiting surgeries that would seek to make a child appear to be a gender different than the gender they were born."
15: "Thus far, it appears very young children have been protected from this only because of the good sense of the medical community," she said.
16: "As we see this protection waning among a small portion of the medical community we would like to make sure that the most vulnerable Texans are protected."
17: Castilla said the bill she mentioned at the press conference would have "protected children from these procedures," but the group could not find a lawmaker to carry the legislation.
18: Dallas custody case The legal battle in Dallas that Castilla mentioned in her remarks is a custody dispute between a mother and father that centers on the gender identity of their 7-year-old child.
19: The child’s mother says the 7-year-old is a transgender girl and wants to dress as a girl and be identified by female pronouns — a process referred to as a social transition .
20: The child’s father disagrees and insists that the child is a boy.
21: The case has spurred a national debate about children and their gender identities, with some Texas Republicans pledging to pursue legislation to prevent minors in Texas from transitioning by medical means.
22: Gillian Branstetter, spokeswoman for the National Center for Transgender Equality, said an important point to consider in this case is the child’s age.
23: "This child is 7 years old," she said, noting that "no one is talking about" pursuing a medical or surgical transition.
24: "We’re talking about gender affirming parenting and letting the child explore who they are."
25: Looking at the law Under federal law, transition-related medical care is considered the same as any other medically-necessary care and carries the same requirements when it comes to minors, according to Branstetter and attorneys with ACLU of Texas.
26: Generally speaking , Texas law dictates that parents have a "duty" to provide medical and dental care to their children and they have the "right" to consent to that care.
27: But pursuing gender transition treatment is an individualized process for transgender and gender non-binary people and can take many forms, according to multiple resources on gender identity and gender dysphoria.
28: People with gender dysphoria — when a person feels a conflict between the gender they were assigned at birth and the gender with which they identify — choose to act on this in different ways.
29: This can include wearing clothes and using pronouns associated with their gender identity; changing their gender and name on legal documents; pursuing hormone treatment or surgical options available for transitioning.
30: Not every person who has gender dysphoria and is transgender will pursue medical or surgical transition treatment.
31: People can be diagnosed with gender dysphoria at any age, even as children.
32: "While some children express feelings and behaviors relating to gender dysphoria at 4 years old or younger, many may not express feelings and behaviors until puberty or much later," reads an article on the subject from the American Psychiatric Association.
33: "For some children, when they experience puberty, they suddenly find themselves unable to identify with their own body.
34: Medical treatment standards prioritize affirmation When it comes to caring for children who might be exhibiting signs of gender dysphoria, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends the "gender-affirmative care model" that prioritizes validating a child’s gender identity and supporting their exploration and expression of that identity.
35: "There are absolutely no medical interventions or surgical interventions on any prepubertal child," said Colt Keo-Meier, a Texas-based psychologist and author who specializes in gender and sexual health.
36: "That is not happening."
37: The widely accepted "Standards of Care" maintained by the World Professional Association for Transgender Health also emphasize this point.
38: "Before any physical interventions are considered for adolescents, extensive exploration of psychological, family, and social issues should be undertaken," the standards read.
39: "The duration of this exploration may vary considerably depending on the complexity of the situation."
40: Once a child starts puberty, other options emerge.
41: Keo-Meier said the most common treatment — medication to delay the onset of puberty — is fully reversible.
42: "That is literally just hitting pause," he said.
43: The World Professional Association for Transgender Health outline minimum criteria that must be met before a child can receive puberty-suppressing medication, including that the child has demonstrated a "long-lasting and intense pattern of gender nonconformity or gender dysphoria" and that it "emerged or worsened with the onset of puberty."
44: Other, interventions like hormone therapy (partially reversible) or surgery (irreversible) won’t be considered until a patient reaches adolescence.
45: Even then, the Standards of Care stress that certain procedures should not be performed until a patient is old enough to consent on their own (typically 16-18 years old) and others should occur only once a person has received other treatments for a specific time period.

gpt4: The claim that Texas lawmakers have left children able to be sterilized and mutilated at any point in their life by failing to adopt a law prohibiting minors from undergoing medical or surgical gender transitions is false.

The standards of medical treatment for children possibly dealing with gender dysphoria emphasize affirmation of gender identity and its exploration and expression–not medical or surgical interventions at a prepubescent age [34][35].
Colt Keo-Meier, a Texas-based psychologist, confirms that such interventions are not occurring [36].
