The World Professional Association for Transgender Health also stresses this point and outlines extensive prerequisites before a child can receive puberty-suppressing medication, let alone hormone therapy or surgery [37][43].
Both of these latter steps, which are partially reversible and irreversible, respectively, are only considered when a patient reaches adolescence [44].

Additionally, certain procedures should not be pursued until a patient is old enough to provide consent on their own, typically around 16-18 years old and after other treatments have been administered for a set period [45].

Lastly, it's crucial to underline that all medical or surgical treatments used for transitioning must adhere to the same safety standards as other treatments, and a suggestion of mutilation by doctors is inaccurate [10][11].
Therefore, Texas children are already well protected by the Texas Family Code and medical rules of ethics [12].

1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.claim: 449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens… but they were registered voters.
1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.label: false
1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.passage:
0: A viral Facebook post that has peppered social media for at least a year was given fresh life last month when former vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin shared it on her account.
1: "449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens… but they WERE registered voters," reads the text of the Oct. 2 post.
2: "Let that sink in."
3: This post, which has been shared more than 57,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: After searching online and in the Nexis news archive, we couldn’t find this statistic in any news coverage.
6: So we started reaching out to California officials.
7: Sam Mahood, a spokesperson for California Secretary of State Alex Padilla, told us he couldn’t comment on how many Californians declined jury duty on citizenship grounds — that’s not the office’s purview — but he said it’s not true that 449,000 noncitizens were registered to vote.
8: Here’s what else you should know about potential jurors in California.
9: First, people who are summoned for jury duty don’t "turn it down," said Blaine Corren, a public affairs analyst for the Judicial Council of California .
10: Rather, they can be excused from jury duty for various reasons, or a court can disqualify them from serving based on a number of factors including not being 18 or older, having a felony conviction on their record or for not being a citizen of the United States.
11: The council collects statewide data on how many people were excused or disqualified and why — with some caveats.
12: That information comes to the council from individual trial courts but since there’s no requirement that courts provide this data, some courts and categories may be missing in the Jury Data Reports the council produces.
13: The data the state keeps on why someone was excused from jury duty includes financial hardship and physical or mental disabilities, but not citizenship status.
14: The Judicial Council of California does, however, keep track of how many people were disqualified for jury duty because they’re not citizens.
15: We requested the council’s reports through the most recent fiscal year for which a completed report is available, which was July 2017-June 2018.
16: Our analysis shows that, annually, around 1 million people — citizens and noncitizens — are disqualified from jury duty in California.
17: Approximately half aren’t citizens.
18: From July 2008 through June 2017, about 11.3 million people were disqualified.
19: Of those, about 4.7 million were disqualified for not being a U.S. citizen.
20: In 2017-2018, 1,063,784 people overall were disqualified with 425,814 for not being citizens.
21: But it was fiscal year 2016-17 that has a figure that comes closest to the claim in the Facebook post: Among 1,096,478 people who were disqualified for jury duty that year, 449,404 were disqualified for not being U.S. citizens.
22: But that doesn’t mean that those rejected juror candidates were registered to vote.
23: One of the primary sources courts use to summon jurors is the voter registration list, Corren said.
24: The other is the state Department of Motor Vehicles’ list of licensed drivers and identification card holders in the area served by the court.
25: Noncitizens, such as lawful permanent residents, can get driver’s licenses.
26: As of 2015 , undocumented immigrants in California can, too.
27: So it follows that noncitizens — both lawful permanent residents and undocumented immigrants — would be summoned for jury duty as courts tap potential jurors from DMV data.
28: "These two lists are considered inclusive of a representative cross-section of the population, according to the California Code of Civil Procedure," Corren said.
29: But, he added, courts could seek jurors from other sources like telephone directories and utility company lists.
30: In Nevada County, Calif., for example, 97 potential jurors were excused because they weren’t citizens, said Jason Galkin, court executive officer of the Superior Court there.
31: Galkin said the county tapped them from a list it got from the DMV.
32: But searching for their names on the voter registration list, he said, there were no matches.
33: In fiscal year 2017-2018, three Sierra County residents were dismissed from jury duty because they weren’t citizens but none of them were registered voters, said Jean-Anne Cheatham, a court assistant there.
34: Karen Dalton, a spokesperson for the San Diego County Superior Court, told us most courts in California use the DMV’s driver’s license database as its primary source for the jury master list and then augment that with the voter registrar's list.
35: In California, noncitizens can get driver’s licenses so, again, it follows that noncitizens would appear for jury duty in San Diego County, among others.
36: The DMV has a "motor voter" program that automatically registers eligible driver’s license applicants unless they opt out.
37: Sometimes, Corren said, people will inadvertently mark themselves down to register to vote and it’s possible that the lists courts receive from the DMV include these individuals.
38: That information also goes to the California Secretary of State’s office to determine whether to add them to the voter rolls, according to Corren.
39: The office then reviews the lists and cancels requests to register to vote from people who aren’t eligible, he said.
40: Three Republican voters recently sued Secretary of State Padilla over the "motor voter" program, claiming that the state enables voter fraud by failing to investigate voters’ citizenship status, Courthouse News Service reported on Oct. 1.
41: Since the DMV started automatically registering people to vote in April 2018, it acknowledged making 105,000 processing errors out of more than 2.4 million, according to a January Sacramento Bee story , and at least one noncitizen came forward to say he was improperly added to the voter rolls.
42: But that doesn’t mean that 105,000 noncitizens cast ballots.
43: Sam Mahood, with the secretary of state’s office, told us he doesn’t know of any recent convictions for noncitizens registering to vote.
44: It’s also a far cry from the Facebook post’s claim: that 449,000 noncitizens were registered voters who had also been summoned for jury duty and turned it down.

gpt4: The claim that 449,000 Californians declined jury duty on the basis that they were not citizens yet were registered voters is untrue[7].
One of the ways that jurors are summoned is through the voter registration list alongside other methods[23][34].
Nevertheless, non-citizens registering to vote results in rare convictions, which indicates that instances of such occurrence are uncommon[43].
Further, the names of these alleged non-citizen voters could not be found on the voter registration list[32].
Furthermore, the office reviews lists and cancels any registration requests to vote from ineligible individuals, implying comprehensive checks and controls to prevent such incidents[39].

63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.claim: If we make no changes over the next 10 years, Americans will reach into their pockets and pay out about $11 trillion on insurance premiums, copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses.
63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.label: true
63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.passage:
0: Promoting her much-discussed plan to create a single-payer "Medicare for All" health system, Sen. Elizabeth Warren emphasized a striking figure.
1: "If we make no changes over the next 10 years, Americans will reach into their pockets and pay out about $11 trillion on insurance premiums, copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses," the Democratic presidential candidate said in an Instagram video posted Nov. 4.
2: The Democratic health care debate has been full of competing analyses and estimates about what Medicare for All might cost, what it might save and who would bear the brunt of paying for it.
3: But this precise number was new to us.
4: If true, it would be a figure both staggering and significant to the unfolding debate, as Americans try to understand how Warren’s brand of a single-payer health system could affect their pocketbooks.
5: So we decided to dig in.
6: A reasonable estimate We contacted the Warren campaign, which redirected us to a report from the Urban Institute, a Washington think tank, as well as to federal estimates of household out-of-pocket expenses and premium costs over the next decade.
7: The Urban report doesn’t include the $11 trillion figure.
8: But economist Linda Blumberg, who authored the paper , told us the statistic is "perfectly consistent" with the analysis.
9: If anything, she said, the number is a lowball figure.
10: When Blumberg and her team crunched the numbers, they found that, under the existing health care system, Americans can expect to pay $11.7 trillion between out-of-pocket costs – the copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses – and premiums over the next decade.
11: That calculation comes from Urban’s model for projecting what individual households might expect to spend, factoring in inflation, on these types of health costs.
12: "Talking about the amount of money we expect households to be spending over time is a very important part of trying to educate people on what single-payer would do, and what the tradeoffs are for them," said Blumberg, who previously advised the Clinton White House on health policy.
13: On the numbers, "they’re roughly in the right neighborhood," she added.
14: We consulted other analysts, too, and as far as we can tell, no one else has done a similar calculation.
15: Experts told us that Urban’s estimate — and the Warren campaign’s use of it — checks out, based on what we know about American health care spending.
16: Cynthia Cox, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation and expert on the Affordable Care Act, pointed to what a typical American family currently spends on health care: about $5,000 per year, when you look at out-of-pocket costs and premiums combined.
17: Extrapolating from there, she said, Warren’s claim seems reasonable.
18: (Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
19: "Over the course of 10 years, when you add it up — that sounds about right," Cox said.
20: "The reality is, people do spend a lot on health care out of their pockets, and there’s a lot spent on their behalf by employers or taxpayer-funded programs that they never see."
21: Under Warren’s health care plan, Americans would pay nothing directly out-of-pocket — no premiums, copays or deductibles — for health care.
22: So that $11 trillion would disappear from the cost side of the ledger.
23: The figure Warren sited also tracks with national health expenditure projections for out-of-pocket health costs and health premium growth.
24: The bigger picture Still, there are serious questions about the financing such a shift would require.
25: And Warren’s Medicare for All plan has been under intense scrutiny since she unveiled it earlier this month, with many critics suggesting it’s too optimistic in its estimates of how much money a single-payer system would cost.
26: Warren suggests the federal government would need to come up with $20.5 trillion — well below Urban’s estimate of $34 trillion.
27: The difference comes largely from assumptions about how much the government could save, as well as decisions about how much to pay doctors and hospitals.
28: Warren’s financing structure includes cracking down on tax evasion, new taxes on financial institutions and the wealthiest Americans, and maintaining what many employers currently pay into the system.
29: Critics say that could yield its own inefficiencies.
30: For instance, the way employer payments are structured could disproportionately harm small businesses, or lower-wage workers, noted Paul Ginsburg, who directs the USC-Brookings Schaeffer Initiative for Health Policy.
31: He also argued that doctors and hospitals —represented by powerful lobbying organizations in Washington — could successfully battle any effort to pay them less, driving up what the government needs to spend.
32: Still, those disputes are separate from the question of this particular statistic.
33: Here, Warren’s on firm ground.
34: Analysts also said the $11 trillion number gets at a larger point.
35: Americans currently pay a lot out-of-pocket on health care.
36: Certainly, some might see a tax hike under Warren’s proposed reform, or see downward pressure on their salaries.
37: Still, others could experience major pocketbook relief.
38: To be sure, Medicare for All is not the only approach to ameliorating what families pay for health care.
39: Other, more incremental proposals — such as building on the ACA’s coverage expansions or pursuing a "Medicare for all who want it" approach touted by former Vice President Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg, the South Bend, Ind., mayor — would cut into the $11 trillion as well, Cox said.
40: While it wouldn’t eliminate that household cost burden, it would require less in taxes to finance.
41: "There’s a lot of ways to bring down what people spend on health care," Cox said.
42: "Any expansion of the role of public programs is likely to bring down individuals’ costs.
43: It’s just a question of how much taxes have to go up to pay for that."

gpt4: The statement claiming that Americans could potentially pay out about $11 trillion on insurance premiums, copays, deductibles, and uncovered medical expenses in the next decade, if no changes are made, is indeed true[1].
This assertion was redirected to references from the Urban Institute and federal estimates of corresponding expenses and premium costs over the next ten years[6].
The statistic is, according to economist Linda Blumberg, one of the authors of the cited paper, completely in line with her team's analysis[8].

After their calculations, they found that the total amount American households could expect to pay in health costs and premiums over the coming decade, under the existing system and taken inflation into account, was approximately $11.7 trillion[10][11].
Expert sources confirm that the usage of this estimate by the Warren campaign is accurate based on current knowledge about American healthcare spending[15].
Therefore, it can be concluded that the projected figure of $11 trillion in potential health expenses over the next ten years seems to be a reasonable estimate[19].

57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.claim: a Craigslist ad offered to pay actors to be Trump supporters for a rally.
57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.label: false
57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s rallies for reelection around the country are sometimes followed by suspicious posts that say his crowd support is purchased rather than genuine.
1: One version posted Nov. 1 appears to show a Craigslist ad offering to pay people to pose as Trump supporters — "minorities welcome and needed!"
2: The screenshot shows the title of the ad, "Actors needed (Phoenix Convention Center)," with the following description: "Actors/help needed for event tomorrow form 2-11p.m.
3: $15 per hour.
4: Duties include protest activity and holding signs that are Pro Trump.
5: Minorities welcome and needed!
6: Looking to fill about 500 spots.
7: Reply and ask for Allen and mention the CL ad."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: This isn’t the first time a mysterious ad for pro-Trump actors has popped up online.
11: In 2017 , around a rally the president held in Phoenix, a similar advertisement soliciting actors to hold pro-Trump signs and cheer on command was shared on the internet.
12: According to media reports, the 2017 Craigslist ad was deleted.
13: One article by the New York Daily News reported the phone number attached to the ad belonged to a recent 18-year-old high school graduate who became bombarded with profane phone calls, texts and voicemails.
14: The man told KHOU 11 that he wasn’t connected to the president or anyone hiring for the rally.
15: Another ad in October 2018 claimed to solicit paid attendees to a Trump rally in Erie, Pa.
16: But fact-checking website Snopes found that the advertisement was not associated with the president, or any Trump-related organizations, but rather "to a man named Mike Oles, who appeared to have connections to left-leaning activist groups including one called Good Jobs Nation."
17: Good Jobs Nation was apparently planning a demonstration at the same rally.
18: Our search of Craigslist listings for the ad in the Phoenix area turned up no results.
19: A Trump campaign spokesperson told PolitiFact that the president does not need to pay people to attend events and called the ad part of a "recurring hoax."
20: These types of bogus advertisements appear to be intentionally created to make it look like the Trump campaign or those affiliated with the president’s events need to pay actors to show support.

gpt4: The claim that a Craigslist ad was offering payment to people to pose as Trump supporters at a rally is false[1].
Investigations on the alleged Craigslist ad in the Phoenix area provided no evidence of the existence of such an advertisement[18].

A representative for Trump's campaign dismissed the claim, asserting that the president does not necessitate to pay individuals to attend his events and labeling the controversial ad as a repeated hoax[19].

Interestingly, this misconception appears to be part of a series of deceptive advertisements deliberately designed to create the impression that the Trump campaign, or people associated with the president's events, resort to paying actors to demonstrate support[20].
The post that made the false claim was flagged under Facebook's efforts to counteract erroneous news and misinformation on its News Feed[8].

458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.claim: " President Donald Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president ""sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did."""
458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.label: false
458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.passage:
0: Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., suggested that threats by President Donald Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden to withhold aid from Ukraine were "exactly" the same.
1: Speaking on Meet the Press days before the first public hearings on impeachment, Paul said that Americans want fairness.
2: "And I don't think they're going to judge fairness, when they're accusing President Trump of the same thing Joe Biden did, threatening the aid, if some kind of corruption is not investigated.
3: And it seems like everybody, both parties, have been threatening aid, if some kind of investigation either doesn't happen or is ended.
4: And so I think, really, what's going to happen is people are going to say, ‘Oh, they're impeaching President Trump for exactly the same thing that Joe Biden did.’" Paul continued : "He threatened the aid, if they didn't fire someone.
5: And supposedly, the president did, if they didn't investigate someone.
6: So it sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did.
7: And if they weren't going to impeach Joe Biden, they look like, you know, hypocrites, in a way, for going only after President Trump and having not a word to say about what Joe Biden did."
8: U.S. Rep. Jim Himes, D-Conn., disputed Paul’s characterization later on in the show.
9: "Let's be very clear.
10: The president of the United States demanding, extorting a vulnerable country to do his political bidding, to go after his opponent, has nothing to do with Joe Biden executing the foreign policy of the United States," Himes said .
11: We found that Paul created a false equivalency when summarizing the actions of Trump and Biden.
12: The two cases are not the same, or even particularly similar.
13: We told a Paul spokesperson that based on our previous fact-checking , the actions by Trump and Biden are not the same.
14: "The question itself shows the bias of the media on this issue," a spokesperson replied.
15: "The motivations of then-Vice President Biden clearly could have included shielding his family and their oligarch patron from scrutiny, yet this is dismissed because of bias. "
16: What the evidence shows about Biden’s actions Paul’s reference to Biden threatening aid stems from when Biden called for Ukraine to fire prosecutor general Viktor Shokin.
17: Biden assumed a lead role in U.S. diplomacy toward Ukraine after a popular revolution in early 2014 that led to pro-Russia President Viktor Yanukovych fleeing the country.
18: Shokin became top prosecutor in 2015.

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president "sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did" is false.
Our examination found that Paul created a false equivalency when he compared the actions of Trump and Biden[11].
The two cases are not the same, or even particularly similar[12].
This was further underscored when we communicated with a spokesperson for Paul, where we pointed out our prior fact-checking results showing that the actions by Trump and Biden are not the same[13].

2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.claim: "  House Democrats passed impeachment rules that ""do not allow any witness to be called unless the witness is approved by Adam Schiff,"" ""do not allow involvement of the President’s legal counsel"" and ""do not allow any witness to be questioned unless the question is approved by Adam Schiff."""
2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.label: false
2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.passage:
0: It didn’t take long after the Democratic-led House of Representatives formalized the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump for misinformation to start circulating about the rules of the road.
1: One post published Oct. 31 makes three claims about the Democrats’ impeachment resolution: that the rules "do not allow any witness to be called unless the witness is approved by Adam Schiff," "do not allow involvement of the President’s legal counsel," and "do not allow any witness to be questioned unless the question is approved by Adam Schiff."
2: "Welcome to the USSR," the post reads.
3: The post, which has been shared more than 2,300 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: As chair of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., has led the House investigation into a July phone call in which Trump asked the president of Ukraine to investigate the business dealings of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son.
6: A key question is whether Trump held up military and State Department aid in exchange for the Biden probe.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Our research shows that the Facebook post about Schiff’s role is flawed.
8: We reached out to Trump Rules, a conservative Facebook page with nearly 150,000 followers, for the source of its post and did not hear back.
9: Here’s what you need to know from the House impeachment resolution : • Witness requests from ranking minority member Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., must go through Schiff first — but the decision to allow them is not Schiff’s alone.
10: • Trump gets counsel during Judiciary Committee hearings, but not during Intelligence Committee hearings.
11: The Judiciary Committee leads official impeachment proceedings in the House, while the Intelligence Committee leads the investigation.
12: • The Democrats’ resolution does not require questions of witnesses to first be approved by Schiff.
13: Calling witnesses The House resolution says requests from members to call witnesses to provide testimony must be submitted in writing to Schiff.
14: They have three days to do that after a hearing is announced.
15: But the Facebook post overreaches in saying that the rules "do not allow any witness to be called" without his approval.
16: Here’s what the resolution says about the power of members in the minority: "To allow for full evaluation of minority witness requests, the ranking minority member may submit to the chair, in writing, any requests for witness testimony relevant to the investigation described in the first section of this resolution within 72 hours after notice is given for the first hearing designated pursuant to paragraph (1).
17: Any such request shall be accompanied by a detailed written justification of the relevance of the testimony of each requested witness to the investigation described in the first section of this resolution."
18: That means any request from Nunes for additional testimony must go through Schiff.
19: RELATED: PolitiFact's Trump-Ukraine-Biden coverage in one place The impeachment resolution says that if Schiff were to refuse a request for additional witnesses, Republicans can bring the matter to a vote by the entire Intelligence Committee.
20: There are 22 members of the committee, meaning the ultimate decision to call witnesses would not just come down to Schiff.
21: However, in practice, it’s reasonable to assume that the Democratic majority would vote with Schiff.
22: Democrats did not come up with these rules out of thin air.
23: They borrowed from House investigation procedures that Republicans passed in 2015, said Frank Bowman, a law professor at the University of Missouri and an impeachment expert, in an email.
24: The president’s legal counsel The claim that the impeachment resolution does not permit Trump a lawyer is only partially accurate — the two House committees leading the inquiry have different rules.
25: The first is the Intelligence Committee, which has been investigating Trump’s interactions with Ukraine.
26: Under the House resolution, there is no role for the president’s lawyers to cross-examine witnesses, submit new evidence or provide a formal defense during hearings called by that committee.
27: However, the Judiciary Committee, which will assess the Intelligence Committee’s findings, is permitted to carry out its work "as to allow for the participation of the President and his counsel," according to the resolution.
28: And the Judiciary Committee has described a clear role for the president’s counsel in those hearings.
29: "The rules do permit participation by (the president’s) counsel, unless (the president) blocks production of evidence requested by (the) Committee," Bowman said.
30: Witness questioning The House resolution does not say Schiff must approve all questions during impeachment proceedings.
31: RELATED: There’s no evidence Schiff helped write the whistleblower complaint Here’s what the rules say about questioning witnesses: "The chair and ranking minority member of the Permanent Select Committee shall be permitted to question witnesses for equal specified periods of longer than five minutes, as determined by the chair.
32: The time available for each period of questioning under this paragraph shall be equal for the chair and the ranking minority member."
33: Per those rules, Schiff and Nunes will each have the opportunity to question witnesses.
34: The resolution says nothing about Schiff approving Nunes’ questions ahead of time.
35: "The questioning rule seems a complete invention," Bowman said.

gpt4: The claim that House Democrats passed impeachment rules that stipulate the above are largely inaccurate.
Firstly, it is not the case that all witnesses must be approved by Adam Schiff, as the Facebook post suggests [15].
The resolution passed by House Democrats does not specifically require Schiff's approval for each question posed to a witness in the impeachment proceedings [34][12][30].
Secondly, the assertion that the President's legal counsel is not permitted to participate is only partially true.
This is because the two House committees leading the inquiry have different rules [24].

Notably, the Judiciary Committee, which will analyze the findings of the Intelligence Committee's proceedings, is allowed to operate in a manner that allows the participation of the President and his counsel, as specified by the resolution [27].

66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.claim: " A photo of ""Obama’s White House staff"" shows the alleged Ukraine whistleblower."
66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.label: false
66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.passage:
0: Remember that picture of then-President Barack Obama’s White House staff "crying the day after Trump won the election?"
1: That’s what a recent Facebook post asks before claiming to identify one of the men in the photo as "the alleged Ukraine call whistleblower."
2: This post, published on Nov. 5, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The photo is real , though we wouldn’t describe the people in it as crying.
5: AFP photographer Nicholas Kamm took it on Nov. 9, 2016, as U.S. National Security Adviser Susan Rice and White House communications director Jen Psaki, among others, listened to Obama address the nation after Donald Trump’s election.
6: The Facebook post points to the man to the far right of the photo and describes him as the whistleblower who alleged Trump is soliciting foreign interference from Ukraine in the 2020 election.
7: The whistleblower has legal protection from retaliation and U.S. officials have kept that person’s name confidential.
8: Most news organizations have also withheld the name, though, as the Washington Post reports , the name of a CIA officer has appeared widely on social media as posts claim to out him as the whistleblower.
9: But it’s not R. David Edelman, the man in this photo.
10: On Nov. 7, he tweeted another image claiming that he’s the whistleblower.
11: "Here’s a picture of the ‘whistleblower’ see the ‘NERD’ in the picture...his face is circled," it said.
12: "FAKE NEWS," Edelman tweeted, " the ‘NERD’ circled below is the whistleblower.
13: TRUE (just not news): the ‘NERD’ circled below is...this nerd.
14: Me.
15: Left government in 2017.
16: Sorry to disappoint, y’all."
17: "This photo was on the cover of @washingtonpost, people," he added .
18: "Seriously, even conspiracy theories deserve a quick google fact check."
19: Before he left government in January 2017 , Edelman was a special assistant to the president for economic and technology policy, leading policy development and coordination on issues related to the digital economy, according to a White House bio .
20: He also served as senior advisor for internet, innovation and privacy at the Office of Science and Technology Policy, and he was the first director of international cyber policy at the White House National Security Council.
21: He’s included on the 2016 annual report to Congress listing White House office personnel and their pay.
22: But his name doesn’t appear on the June 30, 2017, report .
23: That’s because on March 3, 2017, MIT announced that Edelman was joining its internet policy research initiative.
24: As director of the school’s project on technology, the economy and national security , he leads the initiative’s AI policy research.
25: But the whistleblower complaint that led to the U.S. House impeachment inquiry details recent government work, describing "official duties," "official interagency business" and colleagues — U.S. officials, not academics.

gpt4: The claim that a photo of "Obama’s White House staff" portrays the alleged Ukraine whistleblower is inaccurate.
The photo had been shared on Facebook with the allegation that one of the individuals in the image is the suspected whistleblower involved with the Ukraine scandal[1].
The individual identified in the photo is R. David Edelman[9].
However, this assertion is falsified by the fact that Edelman withdrew from government service in 2017[15].
Consequently, the claim is identified as false.

a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.claim: Photos show the whistleblower with Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton.
a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.label: false
a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.passage:
0: "My, my, my said the liar to the fly," begins a Nov. 10 Facebook post featuring former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi smiling in photographs with a man.
1: "Here’s your whistleblower.
2: Trump 2020."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: That’s because the photo doesn’t show the whistleblower.
6: The man in the photos is Alexander Soros, the son of Democratic fundraiser George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundations .
7: He posted the photo with Pelosi on Instagram on Sept. 2.
8: "Inspiring meeting with speaker @nancypelosi," he wrote.
9: As she says: our #diversity is our strength, our #unity is our power!
10: #bluewave2020" He posted the photo with Clinton back in July 2016.
11: "There can only be one #womancrushwednesday today and that is of course @hillaryclinton, not just for being the first woman to run for president from this nation’s two largest political parties, but I believe the best presidential candidate this nation could have today!," he wrote.
12: The whistleblower who alleged Trump is soliciting foreign interference from Ukraine in the 2020 election has legal protection from retaliation.
13: U.S. officials have kept that person’s name confidential and most news organizations have also withheld the name.
14: This photo’s claim is wrong, and even commenters on this Facebook post have offered corrections.

gpt4: The claim that the photos show the whistleblower with Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton is false.
The man in the photos is indeed not the whistleblower, but Alexander Soros, the son of Democratic fundraiser George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundations[6].
These false assertions are derived from a photo that does not depict the whistleblower [5].

The incorrectness of the photo's claim has been declared not only by proper fact-checking but also by commenters on the specific Facebook post where the photos were initially shared; many individuals have come forward to offer corrections [14].

7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.claim: "  Obama said black people have the ""worst jobs, the worst housing"" and face rampant police brutality, ""but when so-called black committeemen came around election time we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey."""
7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.label: false
7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.passage:
0: A Facebook ad by a PAC supporting President Donald Trump distorts a statement in a book by President Barack Obama about African American voters.
1: The ad by the Committee to Defend the President is entitled "Enough Empty Promises" and targets African American voters.
2: "Democrats promised to help our community," the narrator says.
3: "Promises they never kept."
4: The ad then pivots to Obama: "Here is President Obama: 'Plantation politics.
5: black people in the worst jobs, the worst housing, police brutality rampant.
6: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.'
7: " The narrator then continues: "Enough empty promises.
8: President Trump promised us jobs and he delivered.
9: Democrats don’t care about us."
10: The ad ran Nov. 8 largely in states with a significant African American population including Georgia, Michigan and Louisiana.
11: Trump is trying to chip away at the wide margin by which African Americans vote for Democrats.
12: His ad coincided with his "Black Voices for Trump" visit in Atlanta.
13: (Judd Legum, who writes the newsletter Popular Information, tweeted about the ad the day it first started running.)
14: The ad takes words from a book by Obama where he was talking from the perspective of someone else.
15: It takes those words out of context and gives them a meaning they didn’t have.
16: What Obama wrote in his book We’ve heard a similar ad before from a pro-Trump group.
17: During a congressional election in Georgia in 2017, Great America Alliance ran a radio ad aimed at cutting African American turnout for Democrat Jon Ossoff.
18: We rated that ad Pants on Fire.
19: The voice in that and the current ad sounds like Obama’s, but the words were not his own views.
20: They came from Obama reading from his 1995 book " Dreams From My Father " about his days as a community organizer in Chicago.
21: He recounted his conversation with a barber he called Smitty about Chicago’s first black mayor, Harold Washington.
22: Smitty explains Chicago politics to Obama, who told the barber he was not in Chicago for the election of Washington.
23: Here’s how the scene plays in the book: "Had to be here before Harold to understand what he means to this city," Smitty said.
24: "Before Harold, seemed like we’d always be second-class citizens."
25: "Plantation politics," the man with the newspaper said.
26: "That’s just what it was, too," Smitty said.
27: "A plantation.
28: Black people in the worst jobs.
29: The worst housing.
30: Police brutality rampant.
31: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we'd all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket.
32: Sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.
33: White folks spitting in our faces, and we’d reward ‘em with the vote."
34: In his book, Obama then described the power of African Americans to shape their political destiny when they are unified.
35: Obama wrote: "They had turned out in record numbers on election night, ministers and gang-bangers, young and old.
36: And their faith had been rewarded."
37: In Smitty’s words, "The night Harold won, let me tell you, people just ran the streets,…."
38: he said, recounting how the community was proud of Washington and themselves.
39: "When I woke up the next morning, it seemed like the most beautiful day of my life."
40: The pro-Trump ad uses the passage to create the impression that Obama believed that black voters, ignored and suffering, sold their soul to the Democrats at election time.
41: But the actual book passage is about the good things that come from voting.
42: Chad Banghart, the executive director of the PAC, told us that he thinks it is clear that the ad is Obama reading from his book.
43: However, the ad never states the context of Obama’s words.
44: Banghart also suggested that Smitty the barber was a fictional creation.
45: In the introduction of the book, Obama wrote that for the sake of compression some of the characters are composites .
46: He wrote that other than family or public figures, the names of most characters were changed to protect their privacy.
47: The Chicago Tribune identified the location of the barber shop in 2008 and in this 2015 graphic .
48: The ad also said that "President Trump promised us jobs and he delivered."
49: We found in August that the unemployment rates and poverty rates for African Americans are indeed at or near historical lows, as Trump indicated.
50: However, there were also declines under Obama too.
51: The text on the ad included attacks on four of the Democrats running for president: former Vice President Joe Biden and U.S.
52: Senators Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
53: These attacks related to Biden’s record opposing school busing , Harris’ record as a prosecutor , Warren’s statements identifying herself as Native American , and Sanders’ statements on reparations .

gpt4: The claim suggesting that President Barack Obama made certain remarks about African American voters is false.
The basis of this claim arises from a Facebook ad by a PAC that supports President Donald Trump, which has misconstrued a statement from a book by Obama[0].
The words utilized in this ad were outside of their original context[15].
They were taken from Obama's 1995 book, "Dreams From My Father," in which he discussed his experience as a community organizer in Chicago[20].
In the quoted portion of the book, Obama spoke from the perspective of another individual rather than expressing his own viewpoint[14].
Although the voiceover in the ad might sound like Obama, it is important to underline that the represented views were not his own[19].
Also, the Facebook ad failed to provide the relevant context of Obama’s words[43].
Thus, the claim lacks fairness in representation and is not authentic.

7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.claim: Did you know? Dentists are the only physicians that believe you can get away with leaving dead tissue in the body. One root canal tooth can shut down 63% of your immune system.
7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.label: false
7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.passage:
0: The theory that root canals cause serious illnesses has been debunked for years but seems to have gained new life on the internet after the documentary "Root Cause" was released on streaming platforms in 2019.
1: The film by Australian filmmaker Frazer Bailey is largely based on discredited dental research from the early 1900s and was pulled from Netflix in early 2019 amid backlash from dentistry organizations, academics and professionals.
2: Social media about the film lives on, however, including one viral post on Facebook that says the procedure substantially weakens the body.
3: The post displays an illustration of a row of teeth along with text that says: "Did you know?
4: Dentists are the only physicians that believe you can get away with leaving dead tissue in the body.
5: One root canal tooth can shut down 63% of your immune system."
6: The text outside of the picture advises people to watch "Root Cause" and also makes the startling claim that, of all the women diagnosed with breast cancer, "98% had a root canal on the same side."
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: A root canal repairs damaged or infected teeth.
10: Instead of extracting an infected tooth, endodontists drill into the center of the tooth’s root to clean and fill the canals.
11: The film alleges that infections inside of root canals cause a myriad of serious health problems, including cancer.
12: It instructs viewers to have any teeth treated with root canals removed and replaced with a bridge or implant.
13: The documentary reportedly includes commentary by alternative medicine physicians who have taken controversial stances on health topics including vaccines and Ebola treatments, according to an article by the Philly Voice.
14: The American Dental Association told PolitiFact the film’s claims have been disproven by decades of peer-reviewed, scientific evidence and may cause people unnecessary alarm.
15: The organization said it worked with the American Association of Endodontists and the American Association for Dental Research to contact platforms hosting the film, which included Netflix, Amazon and Vimeo.
16: (The film is no longer available on Amazon Prime video but can still be rented or purchased on Vimeo.)
17: The groups shared the concern that the documentary spreads misinformation, and that hosting such a film "does a disservice to the public because it may cause unwarranted alarm to the point where people might avoid a very necessary dental procedure."
18: The American Dental Association added that approximately 25 million new endodontic treatments, which includes root canals, are performed safely each year.
19: The UCLA School of Dentistry also released a statement regarding the film: "The people in this movie are spreading misinformation and confusion about root canal treatment that is misleading and harmful to the consumer public.
20: Their premise is based on junk science and faulty testing conducted more than 100 years ago that was debunked in the 1950s, continuously since then and is even more discredited today by physicians, dentists and academics.
21: Mainstream medical and dental communities overwhelmingly agree that root canal treatment is safe, effective and eliminates pain."
22: The idea that bacteria trapped inside an endodontically-treated tooth will cause illness stems from research conducted by Dr. Weston Price in the 1920s.
23: Price’s research suggested bacteria trapped in "dentinal tubules" during a root canal could "leak" and cause almost any type of degenerative systemic disease including arthritis and diseases of the kidney, heart, nervous, gastrointestinal, endocrine and other systems, according to a fact sheet on root canal safety by the American Association of Endodontists.
24: The organization reported that Price advocated for extraction instead, resulting "in a frightening era of tooth extraction both for treatment of systemic disease and as a prophylactic measure against future illness."
25: In the time since, multiple reports and reviews published in scientific journals –– such as the Journal of the American Dental Association and the Journal of the American Medical Association –– have criticized Price’s research methods and discredited his findings.

gpt4: The claim that dentists believe that dead tissue can be left in the body and a single root-canal tooth can shut down 63% of your immune system is false.
This assertion was propagated through a film by Australian filmmaker Frazer Bailey.

However, it was heavily criticized and eventually pulled from Netflix in early 2019 due to backlash from dentistry organizations, academics, and professionals, as they condemned it for being premised on outdated and discredited dental research from the early 1900s[1].

This faulty assumption was based on debunked research conducted over a century ago, which has been perpetually discredited ever since by a diverse group of critics: physicians, dentists, and academics[20].

The American Dental Association has also confirmed the falsehood of the film's claims, stating they have been disproven by decades of peer-reviewed scientific evidence, and warned that such unvalidated assertions could incite unnecessary fear[14].

Additionally, numerous articles and reviews published in reputable scientific journals like the Journal of the American Dental Association and the Journal of the American Medical Association have criticized the research behind these claims whilst categorically discrediting its findings[25].

67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.claim: Many of the people in DACA, no longer very young, are far from ‘angels.’ Some are very tough, hardened criminals.
67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.label: false
67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.passage:
0: Hours before the U.S. Supreme Court heard arguments on whether the Trump administration lawfully decided to wind down Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, President Donald Trump claimed that some immigrants in the Obama-era immigration program are criminals.
1: "Many of the people in DACA, no longer very young, are far from ‘angels.’ Some are very tough, hardened criminals," Trump tweeted Nov. 12.
2: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Later, Trump also tweeted : "DACA recipients with arrest records: 53,792!
3: That is a very large proportion of the total."
4: Immigrants with significant criminal backgrounds are not eligible for the program, so we wanted to look into Trump’s claims more deeply.
5: What you need to know The Obama administration started the DACA program in 2012; the most recent numbers show that about 660,880 people (on average in their mid 20s) were protected from deportation under the program.
6: Immigrants are ineligible for the program if they have been convicted of a felony, a significant misdemeanor, or three or more misdemeanor offenses.
7: They also cannot be deemed a threat to national security or public safety.
8: RELATED : Did Obama say he didn't have the right to issue DACA?
9: Most immigration attorneys are "exceedingly cautious" about letting individuals with anything but minor criminal offenses apply for DACA, said Ming Hsu Chen, an associate professor of law at the University of Colorado in Boulder.
10: "This is because they will not only not qualify, but they will put themselves at risk of immigration enforcement, having turned over a substantial amount of personal identity/biometrics information to the government," said Chen, who was a signatory to an amicus brief from immigration law professors urging the Supreme Court to protect DACA.
11: Neither the White House or Trump’s re-election campaign provided on-the-record comment.
12: However, U.S.
13: Citizenship and Immigration Services, or USCIS, which reviews DACA applications, sent PolitiFact data on terminations and the arrest history of applicants.
14: None of this data shows that immigrants with significant offenses are enjoying DACA protection.
15: We found that in a five-year period, officials ended about 2,130 DACA protections.
16: The majority of the terminations were for arrests or convictions unrelated to gang activity; fewer than 70 terminations were related to gang membership or affiliation, and they did not involve convictions or arrests.
17: The government also provided data on approximately 889,000 people who applied for DACA.
18: Of this group, 53,792 (the number Trump tweeted) had an arrest before their application was approved.
19: The top three offenses for those arrests were driving-related (excluding DUI), immigration-related (such as visa overstays), and "theft, larceny, etc."
20: The federal government said an arrest indicates that the individual was arrested or apprehended only, and does not mean the individual was convicted of a crime.
21: They may not have been charged with a crime resulting from the arrest, may have had their charges reduced or dismissed, or may have been acquitted.
22: Immigration experts told PolitiFact they were not aware of data on convictions of current DACA recipients.
23: "There is little to no publicly available empirical data to suggest that DACA recipients are ‘tough, hardened criminals’," said Tom K. Wong, an associate professor and director of the U.S. Immigration Policy Center at the University of California, San Diego.
24: The government’s arrest data should not be taken to imply guilt or a conviction, he said.
25: If DACA recipients have become "hardened criminals," Chen said, they would be ineligible for renewals at two-year intervals.

gpt4: The claim that many people in DACA are tough, hardened criminals is not supported by the evidence.
The guidelines for DACA make it clear that immigrants with significant criminal backgrounds are not eligible for the program[4].
Eligibility restrictions state that immigrants cannot participate if they have been convicted of a felony, a significant misdemeanor, or three or more misdemeanor offenses[6].
Additionally, they cannot be considered for the program if they pose a threat to national security or public safety[7].
Contrary to the claim in question, available data does not show that DACA participants have significant criminal offenses[14].
In fact, most terminations of DACA status were for reasons unrelated to gang activity, with fewer than 70 terminations linked to gang affiliation or membership[16].
Furthermore, as highlighted by immigration expert Chen, DACA recipients with a criminal background would be ineligible for renewal of their status every two years[25].
This firm evidence opposes the assertion that many DACA recipients are hardened criminals.

02cdb7405406296b27ed4d335e295cd9.claim: "  William Taylor and George Kent, the public witnesses in the House impeachment inquiry, are ""Never Trumpers."""
02cdb7405406296b27ed4d335e295cd9.label: false
02cdb7405406296b27ed4d335e295cd9.passage:
0: As the first day of public impeachment hearings began with testimony from William Taylor and George Kent, President Donald Trump attacked the two senior foreign-policy officials at the hearing as implacable foes.
1: "The Impeachment Scam hearings begin today!
2: This is a complete Fake Hearing (trial) to interview Never Trumpers and a Pelosi-Schiff SCAM against the Republican Party and me," Trump said in a blast fundraising email.
3: What caught our eye was the notion that Taylor and Kent were "Never Trumpers."
4: Trump himself had leveled this accusation on Twitter about 90 minutes before the hearing began, tweeting simply, "NEVER TRUMPERS!"
5: He had tweeted that term in reference to the impeachment inquiry several times earlier in November.
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com During the hearing, Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., asked each witness whether they were a Never Trumper.
7: Both said they were not .
8: We’ve found no evidence that either Taylor or Kent qualify under any reasonable definition of "Never Trumpers."
9: (Neither the Trump campaign nor the White House responded to inquiries for this article.)
10: The careers of Kent and Taylor Nothing in Taylor’s or Kent’s biographies shows they have strong political views.
11: They have been in government for decades, serving under presidents of both parties.
12: Taylor is the acting U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, a role known as the chargé d’affaires.
13: A career diplomat and U.S. Army veteran, he has worked in every administration since 1985, including most recently as the ambassador to Ukraine from 2006 to 2009.
14: Kent is a career foreign-service officer who currently oversees State Department policy towards Ukraine, Moldova, Belarus, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan.
15: From 2015 to 2018, Kent served as deputy chief of mission in Kyiv.
16: Previously, he served as the senior anti-corruption coordinator in the State Department’s European Bureau.
17: From 2012 to 2014, he directed the State Department’s Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement.
18: His earlier foreign service postings have included Warsaw; Kyiv; Tashkent, Uzbekistan; and Bangkok.
19: Notably, both Taylor and Kent continue to serve in the Trump administration, and Trump officials named them to their current posts.
20: What is a Never Trumper?
21: The term "Never Trumper" came to prominence during the 2016 election to refer to individuals, especially Republicans, who were unhappy that Trump was the GOP nominee.
22: Liz Mair, one of the early leaders of the Never Trump movement, said she would define Never Trumper as "a Republican who a) voted for Hillary Clinton b) voted third-party c) cast a write-in vote or d) refused to vote in 2016 and has not subsequently reversed course by expressing support for Trump, working for the Trump administration, donating to Trump, endorsing him in 2020, or contemplating voting for him in 2020."
23: Often, the term has been used in reference to historically Republican or nonpartisan foreign policy officials and advisers who refused to join the Trump administration if he were to win the 2016 election.
24: At times, such officials publicly signed their names to letters.
25: One of them , circulated by foreign-policy expert Eliot A. Cohen and others, said that "as committed and loyal Republicans, we are unable to support a party ticket with Mr. Trump at its head.
26: We commit ourselves to working energetically to prevent the election of someone so utterly unfitted to the office."
27: That letter included 122 signatures, none of which belong to Taylor or Kent.
28: A second letter, published in the New York Times , said, "None of us will vote for Donald Trump.
29: From a foreign policy perspective, Donald Trump is not qualified to be President and Commander-in-Chief.
30: Indeed, we are convinced that he would be a dangerous President and would put at risk our country’s national security and well-being."
31: None of the 50 signatories were Taylor or Kent.
32: Tom Nichols, a U.S.
33: Naval War College professor in national security affairs who has become a prominent Never Trump voice, told PolitiFact that he considers it "laughable" to call either Taylor or Kent a Never Trumper.
34: "I did not know of either of them until now, and I have been a regular at meetings of the Never Trump group in D.C. for over two years," Nichols said, speaking in his personal capacity.
35: "This makes no sense to me and seems to be an appellation applied to anyone Trump doesn't like after the fact."
36: Mair agreed.
37: "Kent and Taylor have never been regarded by Never Trumpers as Never Trumpers," she said.
38: She added that, before the Ukraine controversy erupted, she heard other Never Trumpers privately deriding Taylor, Kent, or both as "enablers" of Trump by agreeing to serve in his administration.
39: Geoffrey Kabaservice, director of political studies at the Niskanen Center, a think tank, helped organize some Never Trumper events in Washington.
40: "Certainly I had never heard either mentioned as a Never Trumper," he told PolitiFact.
41: "Trump clearly is trying to define a Never Trumper as a Republican and/or conservative who criticizes any aspect of Trump's presidency, or who cooperates with critics of Trump."
42: What about Taylor’s lawyer?
43: According to news reports , John B. Bellinger III, a lawyer with the firm Arnold & Porter, now represents Taylor.
44: Bellinger does have tangible Never Trumper credentials.
45: Bellinger signed the second letter referenced above, and he also joined a group of conservative legal figures opposed to Trump.
46: "Conservative lawyers are not doing enough to protect constitutional principles that are being undermined by the statements and actions of this president," Bellinger, a State Department and White House lawyer under President George W. Bush, told the New York Times in November 2018.
47: However, just because Bellinger is a Never Trumper doesn’t mean that Taylor himself is a Never Trumper.
48: In any case, Trump made the distinction on Oct. 23 when he tweeted , "Never Trumper Republican John Bellinger, represents Never Trumper Diplomat Bill Taylor (who I don’t know), in testimony before Congress!"
49: We reached out to Bellinger’s firm for this article but did not hear back.

gpt4: The claim that William Taylor and George Kent, the public witnesses in the House impeachment inquiry, are "Never Trumpers" is false.
Both Taylor and Kent have stated themselves that they are not "Never Trumpers"[7].
A Naval War College professor in National Security Affairs, known as a prominent Never Trump voice, describes the idea of labelling either man as such "laughable"[33].
This perspective is further supported by the statement: "Kent and Taylor have never been regarded by Never Trumpers as Never Trumpers"[37].
Moreover, an examination of their careers shows that nothing in Taylor's or Kent's biographies indicates they harbor strong political views[10].
Both have served in government for decades under presidents of both political parties[11].
Lastly, it is notable that both Taylor and Kent continue to serve in the Trump administration and were even appointed to their current posts by Trump officials[19].
Despite extensive research, no evidence has been found that would classify either Taylor or Kent as "Never Trumpers" within any reasonable definition of the term[8].

567f686d38ae8e1f2889f0f9fe2385fb.claim: television host Steve Harvey authored a pro-Trump rant about raccoons and exterminators.
567f686d38ae8e1f2889f0f9fe2385fb.label: false
567f686d38ae8e1f2889f0f9fe2385fb.passage:
0: A viral Facebook rant that likens President Donald Trump to an exterminator and undocumented immigrants to raccoons is being attributed to radio personality and television host Steve Harvey.
1: But the "Family Feud" host did not make this rant.
2: We recently came across one post that’s been shared over 134,000 times, titled "HOW I FEEL ABOUT TRUMP" with a large photo of Harvey.
3: The rant talks about a man finding an infestation of raccoons in his basement.
4: After multiple exterminators say they can’t handle the problem, he decides to bring in "one guy...who guarantees to get rid of them."
5: The message suggests that although the man may have shortcomings, such as being an alcoholic, smelling bad or swearing, it doesn’t matter –– as long as he gets rid of the raccoons.
6: "Here's why we want Trump: Yes, he's a bit of a jerk; Yes, he's an egomaniac; but we don't care!"
7: the analogy continues .
8: "The country is a mess because politicians suck, the Republicans and Democrats can be two-faced and gutless, and illegals are everywhere.. We want it all fixed!"
9: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: It is several years old.
12: The message appears to have originated in March 2016 when it was posted on conservative website "100% FED up!"
13: In the introduction, the website said the letter was submitted by an anonymous 80-year-old American.
14: Best we can tell, the attribution to Harvey started in 2019, when a different man named (you guessed it) Steve Harvey posted it on his Facebook page.
15: His post was shared over 160,000 times.
16: At some point, the TV host’s photo was attached to the rant.
17: The rest is celebrity misattribution history.

gpt4: The claim that television host Steve Harvey authored a pro-Trump rant about raccoons and exterminators is false.
Although the rant was indeed attributed to Harvey, it's been determined that the "Family Feud" presenter did not write it himself[1].
The attribution to Harvey appears to have started in 2019 when another individual named Steve Harvey posted it on his Facebook page [14].
Furthermore, the letter in question was described on the originating website as being submitted by an anonymous 80-year-old American [13].
Consequently, the claim asserting Steve Harvey as the author is patently incorrect.

946ef47a2bdfd2b63c751c35ee67a82c.claim: "  President Trump donated his ""second quarter salary to rebuild military cemeteries"" and that the media ignored it and every other story of him donating his salary as POTUS."
946ef47a2bdfd2b63c751c35ee67a82c.label: false
946ef47a2bdfd2b63c751c35ee67a82c.passage:
0: As a candidate in 2016, billionaire businessman Donald Trump vowed he would not take the annual $400,000 presidential salary.
1: So far, Trump has kept this promise , donating his POTUS paycheck in quarterly increments to various departments and agencies.
2: The National Park Service, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, and the Veterans Administration are among the entities that have benefited from a slice of Trump’s salary.
3: One effort that hasn’t so far, despite a viral Facebook post’s claim , is the rebuilding of military cemeteries.
4: The post from ACT for America shows a photo of the president gripping roses and bending down to greet a child in a military uniform.
5: Chunky text wrapping the photo says: "President Trump donated his second quarter salary to rebuild military cemeteries.
6: Media ignored this story, just like they did for every other salary he’s donated as POTUS."
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.)
9: The president hasn’t donated any portion of his salary to rebuild military cemeteries.
10: The specific second-quarter donations have gone to the Education Department, Small Business Administration, and Surgeon General’s office.
11: Also going against the post: Many media outlets have consistently reported the details of Trump’s salary donations — PolitiFact included.
12: We update Trump’s promise to forgo the salary on the Trump-O-Meter, which tracks his campaign promises.
13: Trump’s presidential salary donations so far 2017 Q1: National Park Service; Q2: Department of Education; Q3: Department of Health and Human Services; Q4: Department of Transportation 2018 Q1: Veteran's Administration (The money went toward "caregiver support in the form of mental health and peer support programs, financial aid, education training, and research," according to Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie.)
14: Q2: Small Business Administration; Q3: National Institutes of Health; Q4: Department of Homeland Security2019 2019 Q1: U.S. Department of Agriculture; Q2: HHS/Office of the Surgeon General The photo of Trump with the child, by the way, is from Memorial Day in 2017 at Arlington National Cemetery.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump donated his second quarter salary to rebuild military cemeteries is false[9].
During his term, Trump has indeed donated his Presidential salary in quarterly increments to various departments and agencies[1].

However, these specific donations for the second quarter did not go towards the reconstruction of military cemeteries, but were instead directed to the Education Department, Small Business Administration, and the Surgeon General’s office[10].

48a4e4c12ddabc820398ad2a65b9cf18.claim: photos show the Trump-Ukraine whistleblower with Chuck Schumer, Elizabeth Warren, Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton.
48a4e4c12ddabc820398ad2a65b9cf18.label: false
48a4e4c12ddabc820398ad2a65b9cf18.passage:
0: Earlier this week we debunked claims that U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton were photographed with the alleged whistleblower.
1: The photos were real, but the man in them isn’t the person that some conservatives have alleged is the man that told federal officials Trump solicited foreign interference from Ukraine in the 2020 election.
2: Rather, the photos show Alexander Soros, the son of Democratic fundraiser George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundation s. Now more social media posts are circulating those pictures with two more images of Democratic lawmakers — U.S. Sens.
3: Elizabeth Warren and Chuck Schumer.
4: "May I have your attention please," reads one such post from Nov. 9 , "THIS IS THE ‘WHISTLEBLOWER.’" This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: And that’s because … they’re posting with Soros, not the internal government whistleblower.
7: But that didn’t stop U.S. Rep. Steve King, R-Iowa, from tweeting something similar.
8: "Adam Schiff said, ‘I do not know the identity of the whistleblower.’ @RepAdam Schiff here are four strong clues," King wrote, sharing the photos of Soros, Warren, Pelosi, Clinton and Schumer.
9: Soros posted the photo with Schumer on Instagram earlier this year with this caption: "Always a pleasure to see @chuckschumer!
10: The #Senate is almost as important as the presidency, and we have to start working now for #2020."
11: He posted the photo with Elizabeth Warren on Instagram in 2016 .
12: "What better way to spend #womencrushwednesday than with the woman who crushes it in Washington as well as anyone else, Senator Elizabeth Warren!"
13: Soros wrote.

gpt4: The claim that photos reveal the Trump-Ukraine whistleblower with Chuck Schumer, Elizabeth Warren, Nancy Pelosi, and Hillary Clinton is false.
While the photos are genuine, they do not depict the whistleblower, as some conservatives have alleged[1].
In fact, the person in the photos is Alexander Soros, the son of Democratic fundraiser George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundations [2].
The figures featured in those photos are indeed Democratic lawmakers, however, they are seen alongside Soros, and not the government whistleblower [6].
So, the photos are circulating online with misleading context.

e8ab764243c893b118d6f8fe415087d4.claim: The Russians are violating all of the rules, treaties, understandings that they committed to that actually kept the peace in Europe for nearly 70 years.
e8ab764243c893b118d6f8fe415087d4.label: half-true
e8ab764243c893b118d6f8fe415087d4.passage:
0: On the first day of the impeachment hearings held in public, Ambassador William Taylor Jr. , the top American diplomat in Ukraine, took a broad swipe at Russia.
1: "The Russians are violating all of the rules, treaties, understandings that they committed to that actually kept the peace in Europe for nearly 70 years," he declared.
2: Experts told PolitiFact that Taylor’s claim is on target.
3: Treaties and agreements have largely kept the peace between Russia, the United States and Europe since World War II ended in 1945.
4: But Russia is now violating many of them.
5: "The use of ‘all’ usually signifies an exaggeration, but this statement is not far off," said Georgetown University government and foreign service professor Matthew Kroenig .
6: "Russia has suspended compliance, violated, or is seriously stretching the limits on almost all of its most important security agreements including: the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, the New START Treaty, the Presidential Nuclear Initiatives, the Budapest Memorandum, the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, the Open Skies Treaty and the UN Charter."
7: Added Max Bergmann , senior fellow at the left-leaning Center for American Progress and an expert on U.S.-Russia policy: "Every agreement?
8: They’re going to be in compliance with some.
9: But even when there is an agreement, and maybe they’re not technically violating it, they push the bounds."
10: More on what Taylor said Taylor, a career diplomat and U.S. Army veteran who has worked in every administration of both parties since 1985, is a key witness in the House’s investigation of President Donald Trump .
11: Trump is accused of pressuring Ukraine to publicly investigate former Vice President Joe Biden , a potential challenger in the 2020 presidential election.
12: U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff , D-Calif., as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, led the Nov. 13 hearing where Taylor testified.
13: At one point, Schiff asked Taylor why it was important for the United States to help protect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
14: Taylor replied that the United States has a national defense policy that identifies Russia and China as adversaries.
15: "The Russians are violating all of the rules, treaties, understandings that they committed to that actually kept the peace in Europe for nearly 70 years," Taylor said, "If we don’t push back on those violations then that will continue.
16: That affects us.
17: That affects the world we live in, that our children and grandchildren will grow up in."
18: Major violations Here are two key Russian violations experts cited to us: 1.
19: Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances for Ukraine The 1994 memorandum committed the United States, Russia and England to, among other things, "respect the independence and sovereignty and existing borders of Ukraine" and to "refrain from the threat or use of force" against that country.
20: By 2014, Russia had "grossly violated the commitments it made in that document," wrote Steven Pifer , a senior fellow at the Arms Control and Non-Proliferation Initiative at the Brookings Institution and a fellow at the Center for International Security and Cooperation at Stanford University.
21: "Basically, the agreement was that the three Soviet republics that had nukes based on their territory would send the weapons to Russia, in return for which Russia, the U.S. and others would guarantee their security," Harley Balzer , a Russia expert and emeritus professor of government and international affairs at Georgetown University, told us.
22: "Annexing Crimea and supporting the separatists in Eastern Ukraine is a clear betrayal.
23: "That is a major concern," Balzer added.
24: "Why would North Korea or anyone else give up nukes if no one will hold the Russians accountable for this reversal?"
25: 2
26: Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty The 1987 treaty, which banned the United States and Russia from fielding land-based missiles with a range between 500 and 5,500 kilometers, ended in August 2019.
27: The U.S. government said Russia’s government violated the treaty with, for example, the 9M729 missile, which developed in the mid 2000s and flew longer than the permissible distance, ForeignPolicy.com reported .
28: "All of the United States’ NATO allies said they agreed with the U.S. judgment: Russia was breaking the rules."
29: The rule-breaking started in about 2014 in direct violation of the treaty, Kroenig told us.
30: The Obama administration accused Russia of cheating at that time, and the Trump administration withdrew from the treaty in 2018.
31: More violations The Crimea annexation and Russia’s armed aggression in 2019 in the Donbass region of Ukraine means "they have certainly violated a lot of their commitments," Pifer told us.
32: He said that includes the 1975 Helsinki Final Act’s provisions on respecting sovereignty; and the provisions of the 1997 Ukraine-Russia Treaty on Friendship, Cooperation and Partnership on territorial integrity and non-use of force against the other.
33: In addition, he said, the UN Charter says that states shall refrain from use of force except in self-defense or if authorized by the UN Security Council.
34: Russia had agreed to get rid of many of its tactical nuclear weapons at the end of the Cold War, under the Presidential Nuclear Initiatives agreement, Kroenig said.
35: "But it kept many more than it promised to and is now building more," he said.
36: In addition, Russian President Vladimir Putin in 2007 suspended implementation of the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty.
37: Bergmann and Kroenig said that among the agreements in which Russia is in compliance is the New START Treaty , an arms-limitation deal signed by the United States and Russia in 2011.
38: But Russia "is building several new strategic systems that threaten the future viability of the treaty," Kroenig said.

gpt4: The assertion that the Russians are violating all the rules, treaties, and understandings that they committed to, which had previously preserved peace in Europe for nearly 70 years, is partially accurate[1][2].
Major violations include the 1994 Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances for Ukraine and the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty [18][19][20][26][27][28].
Russia has also reneged on agreements such as the ones outlined in the Presidential Nuclear Initiatives agreement, the 1975 Helsinki Final Act and the 1997 Ukraine-Russia Treaty [32][34][35].
Additionally, Russia is showing blatant non-compliance with the 2011 New START Treaty as it builds new strategic systems which could potentially compromise the treaty [37][38].
However, it’s essential to note Russia is not breaching all its commitments.
According to experts, Russia is still observing agreements such as the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty[4][36].
Also, their actions in the Crimea annexation and the armed aggression in 2019 in the Donbass region of Ukraine constitute further breaches [31].

8bac6425b0e1af9936b4567c849a4b2e.claim: All signs seem to point to Hillary (Clinton) laying the groundwork to run for president again.
8bac6425b0e1af9936b4567c849a4b2e.label: false
8bac6425b0e1af9936b4567c849a4b2e.passage:
0: With the 2020 general election just under a year away, major political parties on both sides of the aisle are ramping up fundraising.
1: For the Missouri GOP, this has included making some bold claims, such as the one made in an email by Chairwoman of the Missouri Republican Party Kay Hoflander.
2: The October 11 email said, "Have you seen the recent news about Hillary?
3: All signs seem to point to Hillary laying the groundwork to run for president again...GOOD!
4: We welcome her to lose again next November, especially here in Missouri."
5: It’s a tactic to strike fear in the hearts of the Grand Old Party’s potential donors.
6: On its face, a Clinton run seems unlikely.
7: But we were curious.
8: Are there any signs suggesting former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is planning another run for president in 2020?
9: We decided to investigate.
10: Candidate filings We started by looking into the basics — Federal Election Commission statements of candidacy.
11: According to FEC rules, any individual running for federal office must register as a candidate within 15 days of becoming a candidate, which occurs when he or she has raised or spent more than $5,000.
12: Clinton filed her original statement of candidacy for the 2008 election about 21 months before the general election.
13: She filed her original statement of candidacy for the 2016 election nearly 19 months before the general election.
14: If Clinton were to file a statement of candidacy now — joining President Donald Trump and fellow Democrats, all of whom have already declared their candidacy to the FEC — she would be doing so only 12 months before the general election.
15: If Clinton decided on a late-stage run, she would also not be on the primary ballot in Alabama.
16: The deadline to qualify and be on the March 3, 2020, ballot in Alabama was last Friday.
17: While former New York City mayor and businessman Michael Bloomberg made headlines last week by filing paperwork to qualify, Clinton did not take the same step.
18: What has Clinton said about running?
19: At least twice, Clinton made flat out denials: "I’m not running," she told New York television in March.
20: "But I’m going to keep working and speaking and standing up for what I believe."
21: "No, I’m not going to run again," she told BBC Radio 4’s "Woman’s Hour" in October 2017.
22: Jean Evans, the GOP executive director, in an email response specifically cited two articles she said indicate that Clinton’s behavior is "typical of someone who is seriously considering candidacy."
23: The first article from the Washington Post said Clinton is being urged to run, but in the same sentence also said she "signaled that she isn’t planning to run — at least, not at the moment."
24: Evans’ second example was the rumors after Clinton teased at the idea of a 2020 run on Twitter.
25: On Oct. 8, Trump tweeted that Clinton should enter the presidential race, and Clinton responded, "Don’t tempt me."
26: Despite this, former Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta said in January he believes Clinton when she says she isn’t running.
27: He told CNN’s Erin Burnett that the idea of a 2020 Clinton run was "media catnip."
28: One of Clinton’s former advisors, Philippe Reines, said in late October that Clinton had not ruled out a 2020 run entirely.
29: Experts weigh-in Stuart Streichler, a University of Washington affiliate associate professor of law, societies, and justice, said there are a number of problems Clinton would face entering the race so late in the game.
