30: Streichler — who has provided volunteer legal counsel to Sen. Al Gore’s presidential campaign and worked as a Wisconsin poll observer during Barack Obama’s 2008 presidential run — explained that it would be "highly unusual" for someone to enter the race at this point.
31: "A lot of the staff — the talent that you would want to get as staff — are already working for other candidates," Streichler said.
32: Adjunct professor of law at American University Louis Caldera said leading candidates "already have an extensive ground game in Iowa and in the early primary states with millions in the bank," which makes it even less likely that Clinton would try to jump in now.
33: Streichler said money and donors are already committed to other candidates.
34: Streichler and Caldera acknowledged that Clinton would have name recognition on her side if she decided to run.
35: But Streichler said he thinks "there’s almost a zero percent chance" someone new could successfully enter the Democratic field now unless there was a major shift.
36: (Example: In 1968, President Lyndon B. Johnson announced he would not seek re-election after almost losing the New Hampshire primary to Sen. Eugene McCarthy.
37: Johnson’s departure allowed candidates like Sen. Robert F. Kennedy — who entered the race just days after the embarrassing New Hampshire primary — to gain a foothold.)
38: Caldera, who also has an extensive background in public service including serving as President Bill Clinton’s Secretary of the Army and working in the Obama White House, added that someone entering the race late would need a "breakout moment."
39: But he thinks the odds of Clinton jumping into the race are low.
40: "One of the truisms of politics is that the closer you get to the Election Day, the fewer undecided votes there are to convince," Caldera said.
41: Clinton’s Democratic colleagues in the Senate have also warned her against another run for president, and her allies have said they are not taking the talk of her running again in 2020 seriously, according to Politico reporting.
42: Why did the GOP make this claim?
43: The Missouri GOP appears to be using this claim to spur fundraising; the email ends with the sentence, "I am not asking for much, but I am asking for participation to make sure we don't see a President Biden, Warren, Sanders, or Clinton in our future!"
44: It is followed by Kay Hoflander’s sign-off and a button that reads, "Click to give $1 or a [sic] more now!"
45: Caldera said this is not a new tactic.
46: "In politics, party leaders like to fire up the base by trotting out the people who they think they’ll get the strongest response to," Caldera said.
47: He explained that even in local elections, unpopular members of the opposing party are often brought up.
48: Because getting President Trump reelected is the primary job of Republican party leaders, Caldera said it made sense that they would single out Hillary Clinton, who stirs up strong negative reactions among GOP supporters, as a potential threat to Trump’s in 2020.
49: "You know, it’s throwing red meat," Caldera said.
50: "It’s getting people to try to have an immediate negative response and leading them to click on the ‘donate now’ button."
51: He added that as the incumbent president, Trump can run against the Democratic party as a whole or he can target individual opponents.
52: But Caldera explained that Trump would want to avoid elevating any potential Democratic nominees at this stage.
53: "It’s a lot easier to say, ‘Hey, remember that person who almost beat him the last time and that we really don’t like?
54: She might jump in the race if we’re not really formidable in our fundraising and scare her off," Caldera said.

gpt4: Interpreting the available signs, all the evidence opposes the notion that Hillary Clinton is preparing for another presidential run.
Clinton herself has explicitly denied such intentions, both in her claim "No, I'm not going to run again," made in October 2017 to BBC Radio 4’s "Woman’s Hour"[21].
She also made other unambiguous denials[19].
Contary, her former campaign chairman John Podesta revealed his belief in Clinton's statements, expressing no anticipation of her running again[26].
Furthermore, she did not follow the example of Michael Bloomberg, who recently filed the necessary candidacy paperwork[17].

This is noteworthy because, according to FEC rules, any individual intending to run for federal office must do so within 15 days of becoming a candidate, which takes effect once over $5,000 is raised or spent on a campaign[11].
Clinton, unlike the current presidential candidates who have already complied with this obligation, hasn't declared her candidacy to the FEC[14].
Additionally, she would be late in filing for the primary ballot in Alabama[15], revealing an overall lack of preparation for an electoral campaign.
As viewed by an anonymous observer, the chances of Clinton entering the presidential race are considerably low[39].

b913b080021e6e65121d100d0de449b3.claim: Confederate veterans were conferred with many of the same benefits of other United States military veterans by Acts of Congress back in 1929 and 1957.
b913b080021e6e65121d100d0de449b3.label: half-true
b913b080021e6e65121d100d0de449b3.passage:
0: Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller waded into hot salsa on Saturday, when he commented on a Facebook post about a local chapter of the Sons of Confederate Veterans that was told it could not participate in the Stephenville Veterans’ Day parade unless the group removed Confederate flags from its display.
1: The post, shared to an Erath County Facebook group, was shared more than 2,000 times and garnered dozens of comments — including one from the state’s agriculture commissioner.
2: "Who told them to leave?"
3: Miller wrote.
4: "Get a rope."
5: After people expressed outrage at his remark, Miller edited the comment and added: "Good grief people, it’s a joke, an old saying from a Pace Picante commercial.
6: Lighten up."
7: Miller also shared a post about the incident on his Facebook page after the Texas Tribune wrote an article about his comment: "I guess the young leftists at the Texas Tribune have never heard or watched the Pace Salsa commercial.
8: I would also bet that they are not aware that Confederate veterans were conferred with many of the same benefits of other United States military veterans by Acts of Congress back in 1929 and 1957.
9: Sad, that on a day in which we should honor all of our veterans, including those who fought in the Civil War, there are some who, instead, wish to sow discord and discontent."
10: At first glance, Miller’s claim about Confederate veterans is similar to a falsehood that has percolated for years: That the federal government designated Confederate veterans as United States veterans.
11: Instead, Miller’s statement focuses on two pieces of legislation approved by Congress long after the end of the Civil War.
12: One required the federal government to place headstones or markers on the graves of Confederate soldiers.
13: The other allowed veterans and their widows to collect a federal pension.
14: Todd Smith, a spokesman for Miller, pointed to these pieces of legislation and emphasized that Miller did not go so far as to say Confederate veterans were designated as U.S. veterans.
15: "In his post, Commissioner Miller did not state that Confederate veterans had been conferred U.S. veteran status," Smith said.
16: "Instead, he said that ‘Confederate veterans were conferred with many of the same benefits of other United States military veterans by Acts of Congress…’ So, these two laws appear to provide benefits to CSA veterans EXACTLY AS IF they had been a U.S. military service member."
17: Post Civil War: No federal benefits At the close of the Civil War, government assistance for Union veterans and Confederate veterans was handled very differently.
18: In the South, state and county governments were the primary vehicles for offering aid to Confederate veterans and their families, according to Susanah Ural, a professor of history at the University of Southern Mississippi, where she also serves as co-director of the Dale Center for the Study of War and Society.
19: "It became a huge issue, because a lot of families had been promised that if the man left or was injured, we’ll make sure the family is taken care of," Ural said, noting that states had to allocate significant funds to the effort, considering the high number of fatalities and the families left behind.
20: Union soldiers and widows received a pension from the federal government and were able to obtain care from federally-run hospitals and homes.
21: Confederate veterans could not.
22: "The federal government was never paying Confederate pensions at that point," Ural said.
23: "You took up arms against the federal government, so they’re not going to do that."
24: There were also differences when it came to burial.
25: National cemeteries were originally created to honor Union soldiers, according to the National Park Service.
26: Confederate veterans could not be buried in these cemeteries, with some exceptions.
27: Soldiers captured as prisoners of war were buried in designated sections within the cemeteries.
28: In 1929: Headstones approved for Confederate graves In 1906, the federal government authorized the placement of headstones for Confederate soldiers who were buried in national cemeteries — a small percentage of all those who died.
29: It was not until 1929 that Congress authorized Confederate soldiers buried in unmarked graves anywhere to receive — when requested — "appropriate Government headstones or markers at the expense of the United States."
30: In 1958: Federal pensions for veterans, widows By the time Congress authorized federal pensions for Confederate veterans and their widows, the Spanish-American War, World War I and World War II had come to pass.
31: It was 1958 (Miller got the year wrong) and the country was in the throws of the Cold War, prompting a wave of reconciliation internally.
32: "They made a very big deal about the last surviving veterans on both sides," said Barbara Gannon, an associate history professor at the University of Central Florida who specializes in the Civil War and military history.
33: "It was about saying: ‘We’re all real Americans, as opposed to Communists’."
34: Also at this point, the last surviving verified Confederate veteran had died.
35: Pleasant Crump died in 1951 at the age of 104, according to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.
36: Another man purporting to be a Confederate veteran was still alive, but his status is disputed.
37: He died in 1959.
38: News reports from 1958 said there were an estimated 1,500 widows of Confederate soldiers who were still alive and could potentially qualify for the pension.
39: The last surviving Confederate widow was Maudie Hopkins, who died in 2008 at the age of 93, according to the VA.
40: But Hopkins did not receive pension benefits after her husband’s death, according to her obituary in the Seattle Times.
41: The law stated that the Veterans Administration "shall pay to each person who served in the military or naval forces of the Confederate States of America during the Civil War a monthly pension in the same amounts and subject to the same conditions as would have been applicable to such person ... if his service in such forces had been service in the military or naval service of the United States."
42: But there were no surviving veterans to take advantage of this benefit.
43: "It is reasonable to assert that no portion of federal aid ever went to the care of a single Confederate veteran," reads an article published on the website for "The Journal of the Civil War Era" exploring care offered to veterans after the war.
44: Even though there were no surviving veterans who claimed the pension offered by the 1958 legislation, Gannon said the effort was more about the push for reconciliation.
45: "These were gestures, but they were important gestures to southerners," she said.
46: In a March 1958 column by George Dixon , published in The Evening Independent, then-Sen. Russell Long of Louisiana argued the same point: "Wouldn’t you think Uncle Sam could afford to make one generous gesture after a hundred years?"

gpt4: The claim that Confederate veterans were granted many of the same benefits as other United States military veterans by Acts of Congress in 1929 and 1957 stands halfway between truth and falsehood.

In 1929, Congress did pass a law mandating the federal government to place headstones or markers on the graves of Confederate soldiers, thereby providing for the respect and memory of these veterans[12][29].

Similarly, in 1957 (not 1958 as erroneously referred to in some contexts), the Congress enacted a law that the Veterans Administration should pay the same pension to any individual who served in the Confederate army during the Civil War as it would to a person serving in the U.S. military[41][31].
While these laws do seem to extend similar rights and benefits to Confederate veterans, there is a notable asterisk.
When the pension law was passed, there were no surviving Confederate veterans left to benefit from this legislated provision, making the impact of this law more symbolic than substantial[42][43].
It is crucial to highlight here that the federal government was not paying Confederate pensions at any point, further reinforcing the mixed nature of the claim[22].
The claim also closely resembles a falsehood that had been circulating for years, leading some to draw incorrect parallels[10].
Therefore, even though the laws were enacted, their real-world implications were fraught with nuances and complexities.

6f19e21e4b0d4558492a05fa633b8cb3.claim: a zip tie attached a car is a sex trafficking tactic to mark women as a target and abduct them.
6f19e21e4b0d4558492a05fa633b8cb3.label: false
6f19e21e4b0d4558492a05fa633b8cb3.passage:
0: Viral posts on Facebook are warning women to be wary if they find a zip tie attached to their vehicles.
1: The posts – like this one – claim that sex traffickers are leaving zip ties on cars (and sometimes mailboxes and fences) to either mark targets or to distract and kidnap women when they try to remove the ties.
2: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: While human trafficking is a very real threat that impacts millions of people around the world – and it’s possible someone has anecdotal evidence of a sex trafficker leaving zip ties – this is not a widespread tactic to mark or kidnap victims.
5: The hoax appears to have originated in October 2018 after social media posts said the method was being used by traffickers in San Angelo, Texas.
6: Local news outlets reported that the San Angelo Police Department started to receive several phone calls about the rumor after posts on social media went viral.
7: The agency addressed the posts in a news release and noted the department hadn’t received any reports of "human trafficking, kidnappings or attempted kidnappings relating to human trafficking."
8: The release also stated there were no reports of zip ties being used as a means to mark a target of any type of crime.
9: They added that the women who made the original post was not the owner of the vehicle in the photo, and that she simply used the image and copied and pasted the warning to alert other women.
10: When we searched news archives for any reports of zip ties being used by sex traffickers, we found numerous instances in which law enforcement reported such ties had been employed by perpetrators to bind victims.
11: But we did not locate any legitimate mentions of the zip ties being used as a way to target or distract people.
12: Ayan Ahmed is a spokesperson with the Polaris Project , a nonprofit organization that works to combat and prevent modern-day slavery and human trafficking.
13: She provided PolitiFact with a statement from the organization that read that most human traffickers lure victims using psychological means such as tricking, defrauding, manipulating or threatening.
14: Survivors often report being trafficked by people they know.
15: Stranger abduction is less common, the statement said.
16: Polaris encourages people to educate themselves and others about the realities of human trafficking.
17: But the organization’s advocates "strongly caution against spreading stories with potentially misleading information about human trafficking recruitment tactics as they may ultimately cause more harm than good."
18: Polaris recommends anyone who wants to report or seek services related to a case of human trafficking, to contact the National Human Trafficking Hotline at 1-888-373-7888 or email help@humantraffickinghotline.org .
19: It’s important that people remain vigilant and aware of their surroundings, but this post amounts to an unverified, alarmist warning.

gpt4: The claim that a zip tie attached to a car is a sex trafficking tactic intended to mark women as a target and abduct them is false.
Several investigations have been unable to find any established instances of zip ties being used in this manner [11].
This suggests that the original post asserting this claim may have been flagged by Facebook as part of their efforts to combat fake news and misinformation [2].

Furthermore, the local law enforcement agency, in reaction to the post, issued a news release stating that they had received no reports of human trafficking, kidnappings or attempted kidnappings that were connected to this alleged tactic [7].
The release also denied any reports of zip ties being used as a means to mark a target of any type of crime [8].

Moreover, studies have indicated that most human traffickers use psychological means such as trickery, fraud, manipulation, or threats to ensnare their victims, rather than physical signals like a zip tie [13].
Stranger abduction, in fact, is a less common method of recruiting victims of trafficking [15].
Anti-trafficking organizations have warned against spreading potentially misleading information about human trafficking recruitment tactics, as this could cause more harm than good [17].
Incidentally, while human trafficking is indeed a prevalent global threat, there is no widespread usage of zip ties as a means to mark or kidnap victims [4].

293a5274bc34107cc9e213a0cb972d95.claim: "  Democrats ""spent $40,000,000 of YOUR tax dollars trying to impeach Trump."""
293a5274bc34107cc9e213a0cb972d95.label: false
293a5274bc34107cc9e213a0cb972d95.passage:
0: Republicans have criticized the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump’s actions on Ukraine as an overextension of Democrats’ power in Congress.
1: On Facebook, some users take issue with another part of impeachment: the price tag.
2: One post published Nov. 11 by a conservative Facebook page, which has more than 500,000 followers, claims the inquiry has cost American taxpayers tens of millions of dollars.
3: "Democrats spent $40,000,000 of YOUR tax dollars trying to impeach Trump," the post reads.
4: "But not one cent was spent to benefit citizens!"
5: The post, which has been shared more than 4,800 times and copied by a slew of users and pages, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) The House will decide whether to impeach Trump over actions surrounding a July phone call in which he asked the Ukrainian president to investigate Joe Biden’s son’s appointment to an energy board over the next few weeks.
8: But as for the impeachment inquiry’s price tag, there is no evidence that it has cost $40 million.
9: That $40 million figure most likely comes from an incomplete and inaccurate reporting of the cost of the investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller.
10: The impeachment inquiry centers around actions by Trump that occurred after Mueller’s investigation was completed.
11: Posts resurface an old number This isn’t the first time we’ve heard the claim that a public investigation cost $40 million.
12: After Mueller concluded his special counsel investigation on Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal lawyer, claimed during a Fox News interview that it cost "about $40 million."
13: Expenditure filings from May 2017 to 2019 put the cost closer to $32 million.
14: The investigation was paid for through a permanent, indefinite appropriation for independent counsels.
15: RELATED: Here’s what we know about the cost of the Mueller investigation Mueller’s office said indirect expenses — such as personnel from the FBI or other agencies — aren’t really a use of additional tax dollars, since the personnel and resources would have been devoted to other cases if there had been no special counsel investigation.
16: Two notes: First, the cost of the investigation doesn’t account for forfeitures made by people ensnared in the probe.
17: The financial penalties leveled against Paul Manafort, former Trump campaign chairman, stand out among nearly three-dozen indictments stemming from the probe.
18: As part of a plea agreement, Manafort forfeited to the government his real estate property in New York, funds in three bank accounts, and his life insurance policy.
19: Court documents do not specify the estimated value of each asset.
20: (Some news outlets reported that the combined value of the real estate properties could be an estimated $22 million .)
21: Second, none of Mueller’s findings have been — to date — part of the impeachment inquiry.
22: The inquiry has solely focused on Trump’s dealings with Ukraine in the time period after Mueller’s investigation had concluded.
23: No estimate for the inquiry’s cost Tax policy experts told us they aren’t sure how much the impeachment inquiry has cost since Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced it Sept. 24.
24: "I can’t think of anyone who’s tried to calculate this cost," said Matt Gardner, a senior fellow at the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, in an email.
25: We asked the House Intelligence Committee, which is leading the investigation, for an estimate of how much it has spent on the impeachment inquiry.
26: We did not hear back.
27: One potential way to determine the approximate cost of the impeachment inquiry would be to add up the salaries of staffers on the relevant committees.
28: According to LegiStorm , a congressional research website, salary expenditures for staffers on the Intelligence Committee totaled $2.4 million as of June.
29: In 2018, salaries surpassed $5 million.
30: If you factor in staff salaries for the Judiciary Committee, which will weigh in on the Intelligence Committee’s investigation in the House, the total comes to around $5.7 million as of June.
31: But that number still doesn’t tell us a lot about the cost of the inquiry.
32: RELATED: Fact-checking Trump, Ukraine impeachment hearings, day 1 Steve Ellis, vice president of the nonprofit Taxpayers for Common Sense, said there isn’t much congressional spending.
33: "All the members and staff would have been paid regardless.
34: There are costs of transcription of the hearings, but that’s about all I can think of," he said in an email.
35: "For the executive branch there are the costs of having witnesses travel from overseas in the case of Ambassadors (Gordon) Sondland and (William) Taylor (if that is the case).
36: And there are costs for additional attorneys at the White House to work on impeachment."
37: Politico reported that more than a dozen Trump administration officials have hired attorneys that typically earn between $1,000 and $1,500 per hour.
38: But they were paid for by the Republican National Committee, officials themselves or through a legal defense fund — not with taxpayer money.
39: As for the witnesses that will appear in upcoming impeachment hearings, it’s unclear what their travel expenses will be.
40: But there’s no reason to think they’d cost tens of millions of dollars.
41: What past impeachments cost Past impeachments could shed some light on the potential cost.
42: But there’s not a lot to go off of.
43: A 1998 report to Congress estimated that the cost of former special counsel Kenneth Starr’s investigation of former President Bill Clinton had "just shy of $30 million."
44: The investigation, which centered on Clinton’s affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky, resulted in his impeachment in the House.
45: RELATED: Johnson, Nixon, Clinton, Trump: 9 questions about impeachment Later media reports placed the cost somewhere between $47 million and $50 million .
46: Robert Ray, who succeeded Starr as head of the Office of the Independent Counsel, told the Associated Press in 2002 that about $12.5 million was spent on the perjury and obstruction probe of Clinton and his relationship with Lewinsky.
47: But the Starr investigation lasted several years and looked into multiple aspects of the Clinton presidency, such as the Whitewater scandal.
48: And it was independent of Congress, making it more similar to Mueller’s probe of Russian interference in 2016 (which was slightly less expensive, when adjusting for inflation) than the Intelligence Committee’s investigation of Trump’s call with Ukraine.

gpt4: The claim that Democrats spent $40 million of taxpayers' money trying to impeach Trump is false.
To start with, there is no evidence that shows the impeachment inquiry had a price tag of $40 million as the claim suggests[8].
Additionally, tax policy experts have been unable to ascertain the exact cost of the impeachment inquiry since it was announced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi on September 24[23].
The $40 million figure seems to come from an incomplete and inaccurate report regarding the cost of an entirely different investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller[9].
Furthermore, the expenses related to the inquiry were covered by either the Republican National Committee, the officials involved, or from a legal defense fund, and not from taxpayer money[38].

3700c4bb1e8354976207f11b9577d1bd.claim: " While previous clemency boards granted restoration of civil rights to thousands of Floridians,  ""so far this year, under this clemency board, four (felons) have gotten their rights back."""
3700c4bb1e8354976207f11b9577d1bd.label: true
3700c4bb1e8354976207f11b9577d1bd.passage:
0: Florida voters passed Amendment 4 in 2018 with the intention of restoring voting rights to most felons who served their time.
1: But how it will work remains uncertain due to litigation, and a waiting list for felons who want to restore their rights the traditional route continues to swell.
2: State Agriculture Commissioner Nikki Fried said officials don’t have to wait on the legal battle to make the process easier for felons.
3: The four-person state Cabinet could make the changes through the clemency board, she said, referring to the body that already has the power to grant restoration of civil rights.
4: Fried, the only Democrat on the Cabinet, asked her Republican colleagues on the board to adopt new rules for clemency.
5: But that hasn’t happened, she said, and the result has been far fewer rights restored under Gov.
6: Ron DeSantis’ administration than under previous governors Charlie Crist, Jeb Bush and Rick Scott.
7: "Under Governor Crist, over 155,000 Floridians had their rights restored," Fried said.
8: "Under Governor Bush, over 76,000.
9: Even under Governor Scott, more than 3,000 of our fellow citizens earned back their right to participate in society."
10: Fried then pivoted to lower numbers under the current Cabinet.
11: "But so far this year, under this clemency board, four have gotten their rights back," Fried told reporters at a pre-session gathering in Tallahassee.
12: "That is not a typo.
13: Four.
14: Four people."
15: We hadn’t heard that number, so we decided to look into it.
16: Verifying the number since she made the remarks on Oct. 29 required a public record request and weeks of dialogue with state officials.
17: We found that Fried has a point that very few people have gotten their rights restored by the new clemency board in its first year.
18: But there are ways to count restorations that add up to a little more than four.
19: Clemency board approves only a few Fried joins three Republicans on the clemency board: Gov.
20: DeSantis, Attorney General Ashley Moody and Chief Financial Officer Jimmy Patronis.
21: The board reviews cases for eligible applicants at a public meeting about four times a year.
22: The backlog of cases approached 11,000 as of Oct. 1.
23: Amendment 4 was intended to largely get rid of this process for many felons seeking to only regain their right to vote.
24: Amendment 4 restored the voting rights of Floridians with felony convictions after they complete their sentences.
25: It does not apply to those convicted of murder or sexual offenses.
26: The four Floridians Fried referenced were granted restoration of civil rights through the clemency board on Sept. 25, according to a video of the meeting .
27: Each of the four  had their civil rights restored, but none were granted pardons.
28: That means they were not forgiven by the state.
29: That opens up another possibility, state officials told us: Other felons could have had their rights restored through pardons.
30: Florida’s clemency rules state that a full pardon "restores to an applicant all of the rights of citizenship possessed by the person before his or her conviction."
31: In other words, a full pardon also restores civil rights including the right to vote.
32: We submitted a public record request with the Florida Commission on Offender Review seeking records to show how many got pardons and their rights restored at the same time.
33: The agency handles decisions related to clemency and parole.
34: A review of the records showed 20 people have gotten their rights restored through the board so far this year.
35: That includes the four who were granted clemency but did not get a pardon.
36: Because Amendment 4 was supposed to become the main vehicle for felons to regain their voting rights (rather than the clemency board), the clemency board doesn’t appear to have taken up many cases since its passage.
37: Meredith Beatrice, a spokeswoman for DeSantis, said that Amendment 4’s automatic restoration of voting rights has significant implications for the clemency process.
38: The clemency board has prioritized requests for other forms of clemency during its meetings this year.
39: DeSantis also said that Amendment 4 didn’t address other rights such as the right to serve on a jury or hold public office.
40: He said he is considering restoring those rights for non-violent offenders.
41: Litigation has created confusion about which felons can register.
42: "It’s anyone’s best guess how many individuals have registered who have a former felony conviction," University of Florida political scientist Daniel A. Smith said.
43: "The state is not tracking it, nor do I think there is any way for them to track it."

gpt4: The veracity of the claim that so far this year, four felons have had their rights restored by the current clemency board in Florida is true according to Fried's statement during a pre-session gathering in Tallahassee [11].
This statistic was further confirmed by a separate review of records, which indicates that a total of 20 individuals had regained their rights through the board overall this year [34].

It should be noted that Fried, who is the solitary Democratic representative on the cabinet, has approached her Republican counterparts on the board to establish new rules with respect to clemency [4].

Based on this information, it can be inferred that previous clemency boards in Florida presumably granted restoration of civil rights to a larger number of individuals, although direct figures in this regard are not quoted.

3f07314f131266088fea3b991c37cfbe.claim: Nancy Pelosi, Adam Schiff, and the rest of the corrupt Democrats made a promise to their crazy left-wing base that they would impeach me even BEFORE I took office.
3f07314f131266088fea3b991c37cfbe.label: false
3f07314f131266088fea3b991c37cfbe.passage:
0: In a Facebook ad that started running Nov. 14, the day after the first public hearing of the impeachment inquiry, President Donald Trump declared: "Nancy Pelosi, Adam Schiff, and the rest of the corrupt Democrats made a promise to their crazy left-wing base that they would impeach me even BEFORE I took office."
1: Did the two California House members — Speaker Pelosi and impeachment inquiry leader Schiff — and other Democrats pledge to impeach Trump even before his inauguration on Jan. 20, 2017?
2: We found no evidence of it.
3: In fact, Pelosi and Schiff long resisted calls by other Democrats for the current impeachment inquiry.
4: Talk, but no promises There was some early talk about possible impeachment.
5: In April 2016 — before Trump even won the GOP nomination — Politico reported that there was talk of impeaching Trump soon after he took office, were he to be nominated for the presidency and win.
6: Then-U.S. Rep. Alan Grayson , D-Fla., said at the time that if Trump insisted on building a wall at the U.S.-Mexico border despite Congress’s opposition, his actions could lead down a path toward impeachment.
7: In December 2016, five Democratic senators, including 2020 presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, announced they would introduce a bill to require Trump to divest assets that could pose a conflict of interest in his role as president.
8: They said the legislation would symbolically make violations of federal conflict-of-interest rules "a high crime or misdemeanor under the impeachment clause of the U.S.
9: Constitution."
10: But those are only examples of Democrats raising the possibility of impeachment — far short of promising to do it.
11: And Pelosi and Schiff were not involved.
12: Trump’s evidence The same is true of two statements cited to us by the Republican National Committee to back Trump’s claim in the ad.
13: (The ad, by the way, was placed by the Trump Make America Great Again Committee , a joint fundraising committee composed of the Trump campaign and the Republican National Committee.
14: As of Sept. 30, 2019, it had raised more than $96 million during 2019, according to the latest figures from the Federal Election Commission.)
15: 1
16: A Schiff tweet on Dec. 22, 2016, said: "There’s no question the Emoluments Clause applies to POTUS – including Trump.
17: Severe remedies if its violated, including impeachment."
18: The Constitution’s emoluments clause bars officials from receiving payments from foreign entities and is the basis for lawsuits challenging foreign payments to Trump’s Washington hotel.
19: It has rarely been tested in court.
20: At the time, the federal Office of Government Ethics was urging Trump to sell his business holdings as the "only way to resolve these conflicts of interest."
21: Similarly, Schiff was calling on the president-elect to "divest completely," raising impeachment as one possible consequence if Trump didn’t, but not pledging to impeach.
22: 2
23: U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters , another California Democrat, said four days before the inauguration that if there was evidence the Trump campaign colluded with the Russians by using hacked information from Democratic National Committee emails against Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election, it would be an impeachable offense.
24: Waters has repeatedly called for Trump’s impeachment, but those demands didn’t start until the months after Trump took office .
25: The RNC didn’t provide us any information about Pelosi.
26: A Pelosi spokesman denied to us that Pelosi ever promised before Trump took office that she would seek to impeach him.
27: It’s also important to note that Pelosi and Schiff long resisted calls by other Democrats to initiate an impeachment inquiry.
28: Pelosi launched the inquiry, in September 2019, only after evidence emerged Trump allegedly pressured the president of Ukraine to open a corruption investigation of former Vice President Joe Biden , a leading contender for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, and his son.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi, Adam Schiff, and other Democrats vowed to impeach the president even before he took office is false.
There is no evidence supporting this claim [2].
On the contrary, Pelosi and Schiff were not the ringleaders of an early impeachment crusade; indeed, they long resisted calls for impeachment from within their own party[3][27].
Additionally, a spokesperson for Pelosi has categorically denied allegations of such a promise [26].
Hence, the assertion of a premeditated impeachment plan is inaccurately portrayed.[11]

ffe25561dc074807f2f9a4d64d09ea4d.claim: " The Austin Independent School District board voted to mandate ""a pornographic sex education policy that includes instruction on anal sex and how to place a condom on an erect penis."""
ffe25561dc074807f2f9a4d64d09ea4d.label: half-true
ffe25561dc074807f2f9a4d64d09ea4d.passage:
0: Former Fox News Radio host Todd Starnes said that a school district in Texas is requiring "teaching kids how to have anal sex," after the Austin school district board voted to adopt new sex education curriculum for elementary and middle school students.
1: In an Oct. 29  post on his website, Starnes described the new curriculum and relied on information from Texas Values, a conservative organization that opposed the new instruction materials.
2: "In spite of overwhelming opposition from parents and pastors, the district’s trustees voted early Tuesday morning to implement a pornographic sex education policy that includes instruction on anal sex and how to place a condom on an erect penis," he wrote.
3: This is a largely inaccurate description of the new curriculum.
4: The lessons include instructions on condom use, but they do not include detailed information on anal sex or any pornographic materials.
5: Starnes did not return a request for comment.
6: Reviewing the new curriculum The Austin school board approved new sex education curriculum for elementary and middle school students at the end of October.
7: The curriculum includes instruction about sexual orientation, gender identity and sexually transmitted diseases for the first time in the district, starting as early as fifth grade.
8: It also includes lessons about healthy relationships, puberty and reproduction, according to the American-Statesman .
9: Any student in the district can be exempted from participating in some or all of the lessons that fall under the umbrella of "Human Sexuality and Responsibility Curriculum" at the request of a parent or guardian, according to the school district’s policy .
10: The school board voted unanimously to approve the new curriculum, despite resistance from some conservative organizations, including Texas Values.
11: The board heard public feedback on the issue before voting, and roughly 69% of those who spoke disapproved of the changes, according to the American-Statesman .
12: Is new curriculum ‘pornographic’?
13: All of the instructional materials and student handouts for the human sexuality curriculum for third through fifth grades and sixth through eighth grades are available on the school district’s website.
14: Instruction materials for third through fifth grades include anatomical drawings depicting the internal anatomy of both the male and female reproductive systems.
15: Materials for sixth through eighth grade include drawings of internal and external anatomy for both reproductive systems.
16: Pornography is defined by Merriam-Webster as "the depiction of erotic behavior (as in pictures or writing) intended to cause sexual excitement."
17: Medical images and educational materials are generally not considered pornography.
18: Megan Maas, an assistant professor of human development and family studies at Michigan State University, reviewed the new curriculum at the request of PolitiFact Texas and said that it "clearly does not meet the definition of pornography."
19: "It seems comprehensive enough to give students the language they need to enforce the decisions they want to make around sexual behavior," she said in an email.
20: "Even maintaining abstinence requires comprehensive education so that they have the language and skills to refuse some kinds of sexual behavior (e.g.
21: oral sex), but engage in others (e.g.
22: holding hands)."
23: Most importantly: Texas law prohibits the distribution or display of "harmful materials" to minors — including pornography.
24: Does curriculum include instruction on anal sex, condom placement?
25: The bulk of the sex education lessons for both third through fifth graders and sixth through eighth graders focuses on personal identity and safety as well as identifying and maintaining healthy relationships with family, friends and romantic partners.
26: There are also lessons on anatomy, puberty and the reproductive system, as well as abstinence, pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.
27: Austin is considered an "abstinence-plus" district, meaning that lessons encourage abstinence but also discuss other methods of preventing pregnancy and diseases.
28: In addition to lessons on abstinence in the new materials, there are also lessons about other contraceptive methods, but those are limited to sixth through eighth grade instruction.
29: Seventh and eighth grade lessons include information about how to use a male condom , with drawings accompanied by descriptive text.
30: The materials are produced by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
31: Starnes also said that the new lessons include instruction on anal sex.
32: Anal sex is mentioned briefly in the curriculum on a list of commonly recognized types of sexual activity and separately as one of the possible vehicles for sexually transmitted diseases.
33: None of the materials include a detailed description of anal sex or instructions.

gpt4: The claim that the Austin Independent School District mandated a "pornographic sex education policy that includes instruction on anal sex and how to place a condom on an erect penis" is partially true[3].

While the curriculum does briefly mention anal sex as one of the potential ways sexually transmitted diseases can be transmitted[32], the materials do not provide a detailed description or instructions on anal sex [33].

This information contradicts Starnes's post on his website where he relied on information from Texas Values — a conservative organization opposed to the new instruction materials — and stated that the new lessons included such instruction [1][31].

As for teaching how to place a condom on an erect penis, the programs do include an instructional guide for condom use [24], but the seventh and eighth-grade lessons present this with non-explicit drawings accompanied by descriptive text rather than any pornographic materials [29][4].
This comprehensive information is accessible on the school district’s website [13].

Moreover, the curriculum was evaluated by Megan Maas, an assistant professor of human development and family studies at Michigan State University, who clarified that it did not meet the definition of pornography [18].

6482504abd103c11f61e07adecebbfc2.claim: a photo shows a pack of wolves walking in a single line in the snow being led by the sick.
6482504abd103c11f61e07adecebbfc2.label: false
6482504abd103c11f61e07adecebbfc2.passage:
0: An old, miscaptioned photo about wild wolves and their behavior continues to resurface on social media.
1: The image, shared in a Facebook post , shows a pack of wolves trudging single file through the snow.
2: The photo itself is real –– it’s from the BBC’s Frozen Planet series –– but the caption that is attached to it is problematic: "The 3 wolves in the front are either old or sick.
3: They walk in front to lead the way so as to set the pace.
4: The 5 wolves behind them are the strongest.
5: They protect the front in case of an attack.
6: The middle group consists of newborns, pregnant females, and young wolves.
7: They are fully protected from front as well as from back.
8: The 5 wolves, behind the middle group are also among the strongest, they protect the back side.
9: The last and the lone wolf in the back is the leader.
10: He ensures no one is left behind.
11: He keeps the pack tight and cohesive.
12: Also in case of an ambush he remains active to run in any direction to protect his pack."
13: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
14: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
15: This caption is not accurate.
16: The pack is being led by one animal, with the rest following in a single-file line to save energy.
17: The image was taken by Chadden Hunter in 2011 for the BBC series and features a pack of timberwolves hunting bison in Canada’s Wood Buffalo National Park.
18: The original caption reads: "A massive pack of 25 timberwolves hunting bison on the Arctic circle in northern Canada.
19: In mid-winter in Wood Buffalo National Park temperatures hover around -40C.
20: The wolf pack, led by the alpha female, travel single-file through the deep snow to save energy.
21: The size of the pack is a sign of how rich their prey base is during winter when the bison are more restricted by poor feeding and deep snow.
22: The wolf packs in this National Park are the only wolves in the world that specialise in hunting bison ten times their size.
23: They have grown to be the largest and most powerful wolves on earth."
24: However, despite the popular understanding of how wolf packs work, some scientists dispute the term "alpha."
25: In the 1999 paper, "Alpha Status, Dominance, and Division of Labor in Wolf Packs," wolf expert L. David Mech wrote that, in natural wolf packs, the alpha male or female are "merely the parents of the packs."
26: Mech said that after years of observation he saw no dominance contests among wild wolves.
27: "Calling a wolf an alpha is usually no more appropriate than referring to a human parent or a doe deer as an alpha," Mech wrote.
28: "Any parent is dominant to its young offspring, so ‘alpha’ adds no information.
29: Why not refer to an alpha female as the female parent, the breeding female, the matriarch, or simply the mother?
30: Such a designation emphasizes not the animal’s dominant status, which is trivial information, but its role as pack progenitor, which is critical information."
31: The photograph in the post is real and unaltered, but its caption is incorrect.
32: The pack is not being led by the older, sick wolves and the "alpha" or leader wolf is not bringing up the rear.
33: In reality, a strong wolf leads the pack single-file in order to save energy to get through the deep snow.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows a pack of wolves walking in a single line in the snow being led by older, sick wolves is false.
An image depicting this scenario has been shared repeatedly on social media, specifically in a Facebook post[1].
The photo itself, which originates from the BBC’s Frozen Planet series, is real[2].
However, the issue comes with the attached caption, which misrepresents the actual behavior of the wolf pack[0][31].
Contrary to the erroneous caption's claim, the pack is not led by older or sick wolves, and the 'alpha' or leader wolf is not at the back of the line[32].
The pack is actually led by a strong wolf, with the rest of the pack following in a single-file line through the snow[33].
This formation is intended to conserve energy while traversing the deep snow[16].

5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.claim: They never thought ... that I was going to release that call and I really had no choice because Adam Schiff made up a call.
5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.label: false
5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.passage:
0: President Donald Trump argues that his July 25 phone call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky was "perfect," and that Democrats have distorted it to build their case for impeachment.
1: In an interview with conservative show host Dan Bongino, Trump said a false rendition of that call by House Intelligence chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., forced him to release the readout of that call .
2: "They never thought, Dan, that I was going to release that call, and I really had no choice because Adam Schiff made up a call," Trump said Nov. 15 .
3: "He said the president said this, and then he made up a call."
4: The problem with Trump’s statement is that Schiff spoke after the White House released the memo of the phone call, not before.
5: The timeline Sept. 9, 2019: Michael Atkinson, inspector general of the intelligence community, notifies Rep. Adam Schiff, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, that there was a whistleblower complaint of "urgent concern."
6: Sept. 19, 2019: Atkinson briefs the House Intelligence Committee in a closed-door session.
7: Sept. 24, 2019: House Democrats launch a formal impeachment inquiry.
8: Sept. 25, 2019: The White House releases a declassified summary of the July 25 telephone call between Trump and Zelensky.
9: Sept. 26, 2019: Schiff makes opening remarks at a hearing with Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence.
10: Maguire was questioned because he had not forwarded the inspector general’s findings to conference.
11: Trump complained before about Schiff’s words At that Sept. 26 hearing, Schiff offered a dramatized synopsis of Trump’s call with Zelensky.
12: He described rhetorically the nature of Trump’s message to Ukraine.
13: Trump later latched on to Schiff’s words, saying he was lying to the public.
14: "Rep. Adam Schiff illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement, pretended it to be mine," Trump tweeted Sept. 30 .
15: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We can find no other version of Schiff describing the call before the summary emerged.
16: We reached out to the White House and did not hear back.

gpt4: The claim made by former President Donald Trump, asserting that he was compelled to make public the transcript of his call due to a fabricated version by House Intelligence chairman Adam Schiff, has been proven to be false[1].
This statement is incorrect in its order of events as Schiff gave his remarks subsequent to the White House releasing the call's memo[4].
Furthermore, there is no record indicating that Schiff weighed in on the issue prior to the emergence of the call summary[15].

e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.claim: "  Governor Cooper has vetoed ""every single teacher pay raise we've ever passed."""
e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.label: half-true
e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.passage:
0: When it comes to teacher pay, Republicans and Democrats say the other side isn’t doing enough.
1: And, with elections less than a year away, Republicans are slamming Gov.
2: Roy Cooper for using his veto power.
3: NC Rep. David Lewis, a Republican from Harnett County, recently tweeted about Cooper’s history of vetoing proposals passed by the legislature.
4: "Gov.
5: Cooper just vetoed another pay raise that the #NCGA passed, as he has every single teacher pay raise we've ever passed," Lewis tweeted .
6: Lewis went on to say that he’s "tired of Cooper using teachers as political pawns, blocking their raises then trying to convince them he cares."
7: Is it true that Cooper has vetoed every proposed teacher raise the legislature has passed since January 2017, when he took office?
8: Contacted by PolitiFact, Lewis spokesman David Capen said in an email that Cooper has vetoed four opportunities to raise teacher pay.
9: Lewis is suggesting that Cooper is opposed to raises in teacher pay.
10: But, when you look at the reason Cooper vetoed the proposals, you’ll see Cooper hoped to secure better raises for teachers.
11: Cooper vetoed: The 2017 State Budget ( S257 ), saying in his veto message it adopts a tax plan that "will fail to fund promised teacher salary increases in future years."
12: The 2018 State Budget ( S99 ), saying it "falls short of what our teachers and public education need."
13: The 2019 State Budget ( H966 ), saying "we should be investing in public schools, teacher pay and health care instead of more tax breaks for corporations."
14: The Strengthening Educator Pay Act ( S354 ), saying "educators deserve more if our schools are to remain competitive with other states and keep good teachers."
15: Seeking higher raises Cooper vetoed the GOP proposals in hopes of negotiating even higher raises.
16: But the governor and Republican legislative leaders have yet to strike a deal.
17: "Every budget Governor Cooper proposed has contained significantly higher teacher pay raises than the Republican budgets, which deserved vetoes because they shortchanged teachers and prioritized corporate tax cuts," Cooper spokeswoman Megan Thorpe said in an email.
18: For example, she said Cooper’s budget sought to pay first-year teachers $37,500.
19: That’s $2,500 more than the legislative budget proposal, according to the governor’s office.
20: The gap was wider for experienced teachers, Thorpe said.
21: For teachers with 30 years of experience, Cooper proposed $58,000 and the legislature proposed $53,100.
22: Political drama aside, some teachers will get more money in their checks this year.
23: Cooper signed the Teacher Step Act earlier this month, authorizing raises for teachers who had previously qualified for them (by adding another year of work experience.)
24: But Lewis and others don’t consider that signature to be progress in the debate over long-term teacher pay.
25: Step raises The Teacher Step Act authorized raises that had been previously-approved.
26: In other words, the legislation didn’t enact a new raise structure -- which is at the heart of the teacher pay debate.
27: But it did have a real-world effect of funnelling more money into teachers’ pockets.
28: "Step increases are not considered ‘raises’ in the traditional sense, as teachers (and other educators paid on the step schedule) earn them based on years of service," Mark Jewell, president of the N.C. Association of Educators, told PolitiFact in an email.
29: Jewell told the News & Observer in October that lawmakers shouldn’t get any credit for funding step increases that are required under state law.
30: "It’s state law that teachers get their steps based on the step schedule, so in this case all the step bill did was fully fund what was already guaranteed," he told PolitiFact.
31: Still, even though the raises had been previously negotiated, Cooper’s signature was key.
32: Under the State Budget Act, no step increases are actually funded without legislative approval.
33: (see page 22).

gpt4: While it is partially accurate that Governor Cooper has used his veto power in relation to teacher pay raises, the full context paints a more nuanced picture [8].
Specifically, Cooper vetoed four initiatives that proposed to increase teacher pay, but he did so with the intention of securing even better raises for teachers [10][15].
Moreover, his actions have also led to enhanced monetary benefits for educators.
For instance, by signing the Teacher Step Act, he authorized raises for teachers who had earned them by gaining another year of work experience [23].
This move had a tangible effect on teachers' earnings, leading to more money in their pockets [27].

Consequently, the claim that Governor Cooper has vetoed every proposal to increase teacher pay is deemed only half-true because it overlooks the broader context in which these vetoes were made and their intended higher benefit.

984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.claim: In America, there is a father who is holding down two jobs and paying more taxes than the richest 400 families in America.
984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.label: false
984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.passage:
0: One theme U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris sounds in her 2020 presidential campaign is that "justice is on the ballot."
1: The California Democrat did so repeatedly in a Facebook video ad , which leads off with this claim: "In America, there is a father who is holding down two jobs and paying more taxes than the richest 400 families in America."
2: Her statement is based on a study that produced startling headlines , such as one in the Washington Post: "For the first time in history, U.S. billionaires paid a lower tax rate than the working class last year."
3: But Harris misfired by making her claim about taxes paid instead of tax rates.
4: Also, the study, while produced by two prominent economists, makes estimates based on assumptions that are not universally accepted among economists.
5: The study The study, published as a book about a month before Harris’ claim, was done by leading economists Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman of the University of California, Berkeley, whose work PolitiFact has relied on for previous fact-checks.
6: Harris’ campaign told us Harris was referring to rates, even though that isn’t what Harris said.
7: The study said that in 2018, the average effective tax rate paid by the bottom half of American households was 24.2% — a full percentage point higher than the 23% rate paid by the 400 richest families.
8: As the book puts it, "the Trumps, the Zuckerbergs and the Buffetts of this world pay lower tax rates than teachers and secretaries."
9: So, to use Harris’ example, a typical father with two jobs pays a higher tax rate than the richest 400 American families — according to one study by prominent economists.
10: That’s not the same as paying more taxes.
11: Indeed, an individual with $1 million in taxable income would pay roughly $230,000 in all federal and state taxes, Howard Gleckman , a senior fellow at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, told us.
12: Someone with $50,000 in taxable income would pay about $12,000.
13: Criticism of the study Moreover, the study Harris relied on makes estimates for 2018, and its methodology has come in for criticism from some economists.
14: That isn’t to say that the study is wrong or that the critics are right.
15: But the picture isn’t as clear as Harris’ statement suggests.
16: Federal tax data for 2018 were not available, so the Saez-Zucman study had to do extrapolations, Gleckman wrote in a critique of the study.
17: That is "no easy feat," because of fundamental changes made by the 2017 Republican tax cuts; plus, the study excluded certain federal tax credits received by lower- and middle-income people.
18: The upshot, according to Gleckman: Incomes of the very rich are rising faster than for all other income groups, and Trump’s tax law cut the taxes of high earners by more on average than for low- and moderate-income households; "but that doesn’t mean that billionaires paid a lower tax rate than the working class."
19: A similar criticism was made by economists Aparna Mathur of the American Enterprise Institute and Kyle Pomerleau of the Tax Foundation.
20: The Saez-Zucman study, they wrote , "rests on several unconventional methodological assumptions which, in our opinion, biases the outcome towards finding relatively lower tax rates on the wealthy compared to the poor and overstates the decline in top earners’ tax burdens."
21: David Splinter , an economist at Congress’ Joint Committee on Taxation, also found fault with the Saez-Zucman study’s methodology and conclusion that tax rates are nearly equal for people at opposite ends of the income scale.
22: The joint committee, the Tax Policy Center, the U.S. Treasury, the Congressional Budget Office and economists all have found that federal taxes are progressive, he wrote in a critique of the study.
23: The study’s assumptions, Tax Foundation economist Erica York told us, "go against the widely-accepted methods that exist for determining tax burdens, without providing a convincing reason for doing so."
24: Saez referred us to a frequently asked questions web page that explains the study’s rationale and addresses some of the criticism.
25: University of Wisconsin-Madison economist Andrew Reschovsky praised the study, but called Harris’ claim misleading.
26: "In dollar terms, the father holding down two jobs is certainly paying less in taxes than the taxes paid by the richest families," Reschovsky told us.
27: "What Harris should have said, is that the father holding down two jobs is paying a larger share of his income in taxes than the average richest families are paying in taxes relative to their incomes."
28: But, again, that scenario comes from a study that is in some dispute.

gpt4: The claim that in America, a father holding down two jobs pays more taxes than the richest 400 families is not accurate.
An assertion by Reschovsky points out that in dollar terms, fathers working two jobs most likely pay less in taxes compared to the richest families[26].
The phrase used in the claim, 'paying more taxes', could be misleading, creating confusion around the difference between the amount of taxes paid and tax rates[10].
The inaccuracy might stem from misrepresentation where the focus is on taxes paid, rather than tax rates[3].
Thus, the claim doesn't hold up based on the listed reasons.

a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.claim: a photo of a tortured man is U.S. diplomat Chris Stevens, who was killed in the 2012 Benghazi attack.
a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.label: false
a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.passage:
0: On Sept. 11, 2012, terrorists attacked the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, resulting in the deaths of four Americans.
1: Since the attack, internet rumors have claimed that Chris Stevens, the U.S. ambassador killed in the attack, was tortured and raped before his death.
2: PolitiFact fact-checked the claim when it first surfaced and found it to be a combination of fabrication and unsupported speculation.
3: We rated it Pants on Fire.
4: A new viral post goes further, however, using a gruesome photo of a man being tortured as evidence of the false claim that Stevens was tortured and contrasting that photo with an image of Marie Yovanovich, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.
5: In the post , text alongside the photo of the tortured person reads: "This ambassador was tortured, raped, cattle-prodded, and burned for 7 hours with no help from Obama or Hillary.
6: No impeachment inquiry."
7: Below it is a photo of Yovanovitch, who is seated facing a camera during her Nov. 15 testimony in the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump.
8: The text accompanying her picture reads: "This ambassador had her feelings hurt by President Trump.
9: Must impeach now!"
10: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: But this photo depicting violence does not show ambassador Stevens.
13: The image, in fact, appeared on the internet years before Stevens’ death.
14: Facebook screens the troubling torture image from viewers until they click on an "Uncover Photo" icon, warning first that, "This photo may show violent or graphic content."
15: As we previously reported , speculation that Stevens was raped and tortured prior to his death is unsupported.
16: The rumor does not line up with government reviews of the attack and its aftermath, or with contemporaneous media reports and video footage .
17: A website called "The Meme Policeman" reported that it found the photo on the internet as early as 2004 when it appeared in a story by Spanish newspaper Diario de León about Argentinian military torture.
18: We can’t verify that it was shared that early, as the article’s link no longer works, and it doesn’t appear in a search of internet archives.
19: Nevertheless, we did find the image posted on various blogs as early as 2009 .
20: As well, a reverse-image search shows versions of the photo on the internet as early as 2008 –– four years before Stevens’ death.
21: Various blog posts make a myriad of claims about the image’s origin.
22: It has been used to illustrate articles about Spanish war crimes, Argentinian war crimes and CIA torture in Afghanistan.
23: While we weren’t able to pinpoint its exact origin or date, it is clear that this photo existed online several years before Stevens’ death.

gpt4: The claim that a certain photo depicting a tortured man is of U.S. diplomat Chris Stevens, who was killed in the 2012 Benghazi attack, has been found to be false.
The claim was fact-checked by PolitiFact when it first surfaced and it was determined to be a mixture of fabrication and unsupported speculation[2].
Furthermore, the photo in question, which portrays violence, does not feature Ambassador Stevens[12].
Notably, this image had been circulating on the internet several years before the tragic death of Stevens[13][23].
A reverse-image search of the photo pinpointed its presence on the web as early as 2008, a clear four years before the demise of Stevens[20].
It is clear that the image in question existed online several years prior to Stevens' dеаth.

52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.claim: "  Chris Wallace tweeted to Donald Trump, ""You’re a fraud. A charlatan. A thug. A loser. A trust fund baby."""
52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.label: false
52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.passage:
0: President Donald Trump drew quick news coverage when he tweeted criticism of Fox News host Chris Wallace.
1: ".
2: @SteveScalise blew the nasty & obnoxious Chris Wallace (will never be his father, Mike!)
3: away on Chris’s lowest rated (unless I’m on it) morning show," Trump said on Nov. 17.
4: "This kind of dumb and unfair interview would never have happened in the @FoxNews past.
5: Great job Steve!"
6: According to a Nov. 20 Facebook post making the rounds, Chris Wallace sent out a scathing Twitter response: "@realDonaldTrump And you’ll never be your father either, (Fred Trump), a self made Billionaire," the post appears to show Wallace tweeting at Trump.
7: "You’re a fraud.
8: A charlatan.
9: A thug.
10: A loser.
11: A trust fund baby.
12: A punk.
13: A serial adulterer.
14: A pussy grabber.
15: My job is to be a journalist, not a flunky and a propaganda arm for your criminal behavior and corruption.
16: If you want propaganda, go watch Hannity, Ingram, Pirro, and Tucker who do nothing but kiss your ass."
17: The quote is fabricated.
18: Wallace never tweeted that — and he doesn’t appear to have a public, verified Twitter account.
19: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
20: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
21: There are some clues, like how the supposed tweet in the Facebook post is center justified whereas Trump’s real tweet is left justified.
22: Or how the @FoxNewsSunday handle is made to look like it is Chris Wallace’s personal Twitter account, when it’s actually the official account for the Fox show he hosts.
23: On Nov. 17, Fox News Sunday only tweeted clips from the show — including the segment featuring House Minority Whip Steve Scalise , R-La., discussing the impeachment hearings.
24: The account also retweeted country singer Toby Keith, who was promoting an upcoming appearance on the show.
25: The account didn’t reply to anyone that day, nor since.
26: Additionally, we found no personal Twitter account for Wallace.
27: A Fox News host aggressively attacking the president would have garnered the same kind of attention as Trump’s salvo, but we could find none.

gpt4: The claim that Chris Wallace posted a tweet directed at Donald Trump, calling him a "fraud," a "charlatan," a "thug," a "loser," and a "trust fund baby" is false.
Investigations into this claim have revealed that the quote attributed to Wallace is fabricated[17].
Furthermore, Wallace did not send that message as he does not have a public, verified Twitter account where the alleged message could have been posted[18].
Supporting this is the fact that no personal Twitter account has been discovered for Wallace[26].

c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said, ""It is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate."""
c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.label: false
c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.passage:
0: In a 12:15 a.m. tweet on Nov. 19, President Donald Trump bashed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., for an impeachment quote that she never said.
1: In the tweet , in which he tagged Fox News, President Trump wrote: "Nancy Pelosi just stated that ‘it is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate.’ @FoxNews In other words, she thinks I’m going to win and doesn’t want to take a chance on letting the voters decide.
2: Like Al Green, she wants to change our voting system.
3: Wow, she’s CRAZY!"
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com In reality, the statement was a Fox News reporter’s distorted paraphrase of comments Pelosi made in a memo to fellow House Democrats.
5: Within hours of Trump’s tweet, a viral Facebook post shared by the page "President Trump Fans" started to circulate the misattributed quote.
6: The post displays a black-and-white image of Pelosi and attributes the same "it is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate" statement to her.
7: Text below the quote reads: "Ahh!
8: So this is the reason for the fake impeachment inquiry!"
9: It was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: Pelosi never said those words.
12: During an 11 p.m. segment roughly an hour before Trump’s tweet, Fox News chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel said on camera, "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi circulated a memo to Democrats tonight telling them it would be dangerous to let voters decide President Trump’s fate when it comes to the Ukraine investigation."
13: But here’s what Pelosi actually wrote in the memo , which she titled, "Dear Colleague": "The weak response to these hearings has been, ‘Let the election decide.’ That dangerous position only adds to the urgency of our action, because the President is jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
14: Emanuel did not say he was quoting Pelosi directly, but his paraphrase is distorted.
15: Pelosi said waiting for the election is dangerous because she believes the president is "jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
16: She did not say it’s "dangerous to allow voters to decide Trump’s fate."
17: Emanuel, Trump’s tweet, and the Facebook post oversimplify and misconstrue what Pelosi wrote.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi stated "It is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate" is false[11].
The statement was, in fact, a distorted paraphrase by a Fox News reporter of comments Pelosi made in a memo to fellow House Democrats[4].
Pelosi was expressing her concern that waiting for the election is dangerous, as she believes the president is "jeopardating the integrity of the 2020 elections"[15].
This claim, as stated by Emanuel, Trump’s tweets, and on Facebook, grossly misconstrues and oversimplifies what Pelosi actually wrote, twisting her words to serve a different narrative[17].

a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.claim: "  a photo shows CNN chyrons that read, ""Democrats ask, ‘Why even have a Second Amendment?'"" and ""CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro democracy demonstrators."""
a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.label: false
a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.passage:
0: Two images that appeared in a recent Facebook post appear to show stills from a CNN broadcast — but the network says they’re not real.
1: "Breaking news," begins the first chyron below a photo of an assault-style weapon, "CNN Exclusive: Democrats ask, ‘Why even have a Second Amendment?’" "Breaking news," says the chyron on the second image, "CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro democracy demonstrators."
2: This post, published Nov. 20, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Both images have the same boxes in the corner, one showing the Dow and another promoting a "Trump speech in Florida" at 8 p.m. Eastern Time.
5: "Both fake," CNN told us in an email.
6: Searching CNN’s site, we found lots of stories about the gun control debate .
7: One 2017 story features Sean Duffy, the former Republican congressman from Wisconsin, discussing gun control laws.
8: The headline is: "Duffy: Dems want to eradicate 2nd Amendment."
9: But we saw none claiming that Democrats are asking "Why even have a Second Amendment?"
10: Though CNN likewise has coverage of the unrest in Hong Kong, we couldn’t find the story described in the second image, which features a Getty Images photo of riot police firing tear gas at pro-democracy protesters during an August demonstration in Hong Kong.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows CNN chyrons with the headlines "Democrats ask, ‘Why even have a Second Amendment?'" and "CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro democracy demonstrators" is false.
Two images were used to substantiate this claim, supposedly being stills from a CNN broadcast.
However, CNN categorically rejects these images as legitimate, stating that they are both manipulations [0][5].
Further examination of these claims corroborates CNN’s denial.
Despite extensive searching, there were no instances found of Democrats posing the question "Why even have a Second Amendment?"
in any context which would support the claim [9].

Moreover, while CNN has indeed covered the political unrest in Hong Kong, the specific story indicated in the image, supposedly showing riot police firing tear gas at pro-democracy protesters, could not be found within CNN’s reporting [10].

684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.claim: "  ""President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election."""
684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.label: false
684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.passage:
0: The latest ousted U.S. official to feel the wrath of the president’s loyalists is Marie Yovanovitch.
1: In April, she was abruptly removed from her job as ambassador to Ukraine in response to pressure from the president’s personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani.
2: (Giuliani and other former Ukrainian officials stood to lose from her anti-corruption initiatives.)
3: Now, Yovanovitch is a key witness in House Democrats’ impeachment investigation into President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine.
4: The president’s supporters have tried to discredit Yovanovitch — and the entire probe, for that matter.
5: U.S. Rep. Mark Meadows, a Republican from western North Carolina who chaired the conservative Freedom Caucus, recently brushed off Yovanovitch’s removal as routine.
6: In a tweet following Yovanovitch’s testimony before the House Intelligence Committee on Nov. 15, Meadows wrote: "For Washington Democrats and pundits who are incredulous that @realDonaldTrump recalled an ambassador, certain that it must be evidence of a conspiracy… President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election."
7: We wondered whether it was true that Obama fired all of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors.
8: It’s typical for incoming presidents to replace politically-appointed ambassadors There are two breeds of ambassadors: political appointees and career diplomats.
9: Political appointees are usually stationed in countries that are U.S. allies or desirable locations, like the Bahamas .
10: These plum jobs are often awarded to the president’s friends and donors.
11: They step aside when a new president is elected.
12: Peter Feaver, a political scientist at Duke University, said, "It is customary for political ambassadors to rotate out within the first several months of a change in administration precisely because one of their top assets — their closeness to the occupant of the Oval Office — disappears with the departing president."
13: Those are the people who cycled out when Obama took office.
14: That’s standard practice.
15: In his tweet, Meadows linked to a Washington Post article from Dec. 2008 to back up his claim.
16: The article said that the Obama administration told all of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors to vacate their posts by Jan. 20.
17: But we found at least a couple of examples of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors staying in their posts past Inauguration Day, which also is standard practice.
18: One example: Bush appointee Victor Ashe told PolitiFact that the Obama team asked him to continue serving as ambassador to Poland until his successor was confirmed.
19: He ended up staying for nine months into Obama’s first term.
20: "I was flattered," Ashe said.
21: "I thought it was a tribute to my service, that I acted in a nonpartisan way."
22: A Snopes article from 2017 concluded, "We found similar examples of presidents allowing ambassadors appointed by their predecessors to remain at their posts past Inauguration Day for every presidential transition dating back to 1977, when Jimmy Carter succeeded Gerald Ford."
23: So, it’s not accurate to say that Obama "fired every Bush appointed ambassador."
24: Indeed, he wasn’t even the one to ask for their resignations.
25: Ashe told us that the ambassadors received notice from the Bush White House requesting a letter of resignation effective Jan. 20, 2009.
26: In routine fashion, they obliged.
27: Many of Bush’s political appointees left their posts by Inauguration Day, but Ashe and some others were asked to withdraw their resignations and stay on during the transition, Ashe said.
28: But Yovanovitch’s removal wasn’t routine It’s important to note that Yovanovitch’s case is different.
29: She is a career diplomat, not a political appointee, who has served under three presidents.
30: Also, she was ousted more than two years into Trump’s presidency, not during a transition period.
31: Career diplomats hold the majority of ambassadorships.
32: They are foreign service officers who rose through the ranks, often serving for decades before becoming ambassadors.
33: While it’s customary for political appointees to cycle out when a new president takes office, career diplomats usually stay in their posts.
34: In his tweet, Meadows tried to characterize Yovanovitch’s removal as routine — and Democrats’ criticisms about Yovanovitch’s ouster as invalid.
35: But he’s applying the practice of replacing political appointees — and wrongly characterizing what Obama did, to a large extent — to career diplomats.

gpt4: The claim that "President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election" is false.
A number of facts and events contradict this assertion.
Firstly, it's incorrect to state that Obama "fired every Bush appointed ambassador" because many of Bush's political appointees had already left their posts by Inauguration Day.
In fact, some, including Ashe, were asked to withdraw their resignations and continue to serve during the transition period[27][23].
Additionally, Obama himself didn’t ask for their resignations[24].
This claim bears resemblance to the practice of replacing political appointees, which Obama didn't fully adopt.
Instead, it's been wrongly characterized to a large degree and has been applied incorrectly to career diplomats[35].
Furthermore, the context of Yovanovitch's departure is unique and outside the norm, highlighting the inaccuracies of the claim.
Yovanovitch is a career diplomat, not a political appointee, and has served under three presidents[29].
Her removal took place over two years into the Trump presidency, not during a transition period[30][28].

3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.claim: Since President (Donald Trump’s) election, 36,000 jobs have been created in WI.
3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.label: true
