3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.passage:
0: Visiting Wisconsin to tout economic progress and push for an updated North American trade deal, Vice President Mike Pence made the case that Wisconsin is better off than it was before President Donald Trump .
1: During the campaign, Trump said he would be " the greatest jobs president God ever created ."
2: So, it was little surprise Pence built his claim around job numbers.
3: "Since President (Donald Trump’s) election, 36,000 jobs have been created in WI," Pence tweeted while on his way to visit shipbuilder Fincantieri Marinette Marine in northeastern Wisconsin.
4: We’ve tackled several claims on manufacturing jobs in Wisconsin: We rated the Democratic National Committee Mostly False for claiming a decline in manufacturing jobs last year meant Trump broke a campaign pledge to bring such jobs back.
5: And we explained how it is largely accurate to say Wisconsin manufacturing jobs are both up under Trump or to say they’re down in the last year.
6: But Pence’s claim is broader, so we’ll give this another go.
7: Jobs data lines up Pence’s claim largely matches up with the latest jobs data, and actually understates the change a bit.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The number of jobs in Wisconsin rose from 2.94 million in January 2017 — when Trump was sworn in — to 2.98 million in October 2019, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics .
9: That’s a difference of 40,900.
10: Those tallies show non-farm, seasonally adjusted jobs from the agency’s Current Employment Statistics — an estimate based on a monthly survey of a sampling of companies.
11: But the gap is about the same using other breakdowns of the data.
12: For example, Wisconsin’s job count has risen by 44,400 since January 2017 if you look at BLS data for all private-sector jobs (eliminating government positions from the equation).
13: Some caveats But this uptick isn’t exactly a new phenomenon.
14: The number of Wisconsin jobs has risen every year since 2010, when the trend headed up nationally in the wake of the Great Recession.
15: And recent data tells a different story.
16: The monthly jobs data shows a loss of 9,300 jobs from January 2019 to October 2019.
17: Which brings us to the implication in Pence’s claim — that Trump deserves credit for the uptick since 2017.
18: Experts say you can’t give a president full credit or full blame for job gains (or losses) on their watch.
19: "The President can claim some credit for creating an economic environment nationally in which jobs are being created," Abdur Chowdhury, professor emeritus of economics at Marquette University, said in an email.
20: "However … there are many local factors which affect job creation at the state level including, but not limited to, state employment policy,  business environment, national economic trends, tax policy, etc."
21: Dennis Winters, chief economist for the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development, cautioned against giving Trump too much credit in our earlier examination of state manufacturing jobs .
22: He noted Trump took office during an "expanding business cycle" that would inherently lead to more jobs.

gpt4: The claim that 36,000 jobs have been created in Wisconsin since President Donald Trump's election is indeed true, according to recent jobs data [7].

The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics provides evidence for this claim as there was an increase in the number of jobs in Wisconsin from 2.94 million in January 2017—when Trump was sworn in—to 2.98 million in October 2019[8].
It seems that Vice President Mike Pence's tweet claiming the creation of 36,000 jobs in Wisconsin during Trump's administration actually understates the total growth [3].
The actual difference, and therefore the number of jobs created in Wisconsin during this period, is estimated at a higher figure of 40,900 [9].

cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.claim: "  President Donald Trump ""fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified agaisnt (sic) him and corroborated the Whistleblowers (sic) testimony."""
cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.label: false
cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.passage:
0: Before Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman testified to the House Intelligence Committee during a public impeachment hearing Nov. 19, some Facebook users falsely claimed that he had been fired.
1: One post published in a popular anti-Donald Trump group on Nov. 10 includes a screenshot of a tweet.
2: It claims President Donald Trump fired Vindman, who is responsible for Ukraine policy on the National Security Council, for participating in the impeachment inquiry.
3: "Trumputin fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified agaisnt (sic) him and corroborated the Whistleblowers (sic) testimony that Trump indeed did attempt to extort Ukraine," the photo’s caption reads.
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared hundreds of times and reposted by several different users and pages.
7: The source of the Facebook post is a Nov. 10 tweet from Scott Dworkin, co-founder of the Democratic Coalition, a super PAC founded in 2016 to oppose Trump.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Dworkin wrote that the president had fired Vindman from the NSC after he gave closed-door testimony about Trump’s July phone call with the president of Ukraine.
9: The call, which Vindman listened to, is at the center of the impeachment investigation about whether Trump solicited Ukraine’s help to investigate political rival Joe Biden.
10: Dworkin’s tweet was based on a story from Talking Points Memo about comments that National Security Agency Adviser Robert O’Brien made during a Nov. 10 interview with Margaret Brennan on CBS News’ "Face the Nation."
11: Here’s what they said on the show: Margaret Brennan: "Lt. Col. Vindman, who has testified under oath, is serving on the National Security Council currently.
12: Will he continue to work for you despite testifying against the president?"
13: Robert O’Brien: "Well look, one of the things that I've talked about is that we're streamlining the National Security Council.
14: It got bloated to like 236 people, up from 100 in the Bush administration, under President Obama.
15: We're streamlining the National Security Council.
16: There are people that are detailed from different departments and agencies.
17: My understanding is that Col. Vindman is detailed from the Department of Defense.
18: So everyone who's detailed at the NSC, people are going to start going back to their own departments and we'll bring in new folks."
19: When pressed on whether Vindman was being taken off the NSC out of retaliation for his testimony, O’Brien denied it.
20: O’Brien: "I never retaliated against anyone.
21: So it's —" Brennan: "But his time is coming to an end?"
22: O’Brien: "There will be a point for everybody who's detailed there —" Brennan: "Okay."
23: O’Brien: — "that their time, that their detail will come to an end.
24: They'll go back to their agency."
25: RELATED: Who is Alexander Vindman?
26: What to watch for in Tuesday impeachment testimony Those comments spurred reporting that Vindman was being removed from the NSC.
27: But Vindman’s lawyer clarified to CBS , on Veterans Day, that he had not been fired.
28: "LTC Vindman is still detailed to the National Security Council.
29: His detail ends July 2020," the lawyer said in the statement.
30: "We are not aware of any change in his status.
31: Obviously any retaliatory action against LTC Vindman on a day when we honor our military heroes would be reprehensible."
32: The White House also told the Washington Examiner that Vindman had not been removed from the NSC.
33: Dworkin’s tweet has been clarified, but the Facebook post has not.
34: It is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified against him and corroborated the Whistleblower's testimony is false.
Vindman's lawyer clarified to CBS on Veterans Day that the Lt. Colonel had not been fired [27].
Furthermore, the White House confirmed to the Washington Examiner that Vindman had not been removed from the National Security Council (NSC)[32].
He remains actively detailed to the NSC, debunking any claims of his dismissal [28].

6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.claim: " When it comes to how many of the 35 different federal welfare benefits each state can offer, ""the average in the country is about 12 to 14. Why are we giving every one?"""
6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.label: false
6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.passage:
0: Assemblymember David DiPietro is a leading proponent of the push to divide New York state into three parts and create an autonomous government in each one.
1: The idea to split New York because of competing interests in the upstate and downstate regions is an old one .
2: One of DiPietro’s reasons for wanting to carve up the state caught our attention.
3: It has to do with welfare benefits.
4: The Republican from East Aurora said that an autonomous upstate region could be less generous with welfare benefits.
5: Talking to reporters outside a Divide New York caucus meeting in Lackawanna, DiPietro said that while the average state offers 12 to 14 welfare benefits, New York offers about 35 different benefits, every one that the federal government allows.
6: "Do we need to give every single welfare benefit that the federal government has in their control, when the average is that there are 35 different types of benefits?"
7: DiPietro said, according to WBFO .
8: "The average in the country is about 12 to 14.
9: Why are we giving every one?
10: We're one of the only states that does that."
11: New York has a reputation for providing a safety net that is more generous than other states, but is it as generous as DiPietro claims?
12: Asking the experts We approached DiPietro to learn his source of this claim.
13: Over a week and a half, we called his office twice, emailed him four times and tried to reach him on his cellphone.
14: He did not return our messages.
15: Since we don’t know where his information comes from, we reached out to experts to find out if they had heard this claim before.
16: Experts across ideological lines agree New York has a generous safety net, but no one we spoke with could trace the source of DiPietro’s claim.
17: The Fiscal Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank, referred us to a U.S. Department of Health and Human Services list of 41 federal programs that use poverty guidelines to determine whether a person is eligible or not.
18: But a review of that list did not offer any support for DiPietro's claim.
19: Some programs such as the Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid can be more generous in different states, but New York does not offer more programs relative to other states.
20: Of the 41 federal programs: Twenty-seven are available in every state, such as Medicaid, Head Start, and Community Services Block Grant.
21: For two programs, which benefit older Americans, it wasn't clear whether they are offered in every state, but their umbrella program, Senior Corps , is available in all states.
22: Nine of the programs are not provided through state governments.
23: They are either delivered by federal agencies directly to individuals, or they are delivered by federal agencies to other organizations, such as schools or Indian reservations.
24: One program is available exclusively in Hawaii, and another is available exclusively in Washington, D.C. One program, promoting nutrition for older adults through farmers' markets, is available in 44 states, including New York.
25: There are different ways to define and count "welfare" programs.
26: A 2013 report from the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank, counted 126 separate federal anti-poverty programs, either means-tested assistance or those with an explicit purpose in fighting poverty.
27: In 2012 congressional testimony , the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, said it counted 79 federal means-tested welfare programs.
28: Regardless of how think tanks count the programs, there’s no doubt New York is generous compared with other states.
29: In Cato’s analysis, New York ranked seventh among states for the total value of welfare benefits.
30: It also found that New York ranks third most-generous in the value of Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, the primary cash benefit for the poor.
31: But TANF, which is distributed through block grant to all states, has not changed since 1996 .
32: States have flexibility in how they use the funds and can use it for programs other than cash assistance, such as child welfare or preschool.
33: The annual funding level of $16.5 billion was set in 1996 and has not changed.
34: Inflation has reduced the program's real value by 40 percent since then, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank.
35: Angela Rachidi , a research fellow in poverty studies at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank that favors free enterprise, said DiPietro’s claim is possibly true.
36: But she’s not sure where he got his numbers from.
37: It is true the federal government authorizes programs and gives states flexibility in how to deliver them, said Rachidi, who worked in human resources administration in New York City’s Department of Social Services.
38: "The general perception is true that New York is a very generous state," she said.
39: Medicaid choices Some experts suggested DiPietro might be talking about Medicaid.
40: Without a response from DiPietro, we can’t be sure.
41: Medicaid, the health care program for people who have low incomes or disabilities, is designed differently in every state.
42: There are 15 mandatory benefits , including inpatient and outpatient hospital services, as well as optional benefits that vary by state, such as hospice, eyeglasses and podiatry services.
43: States can decide how generous each benefit will be, like whether to require a co-pay or set a limit on services.
44: The Kaiser Family Foundation , a nonpartisan organization that analyzes health policy, surveyed all 50 states in 2018 about the Medicaid benefits they offer.
45: The foundation asked about 47 different benefits, 14 of which are mandatory.
46: Of the remaining 33 benefits, New York offers all of them.
47: New York also offers services that were not part of KFF's survey, such as fertility services and lactation services .
48: To see how New York compared with other states, we looked at the 33 optional benefits included in the survey.
49: We found that, on average, the 44 states that participated in the survey offered 26 optional benefits.
50: Alabama and Virginia had the fewest, with 15 optional benefits.
51: New Jersey and Minnesota offered 32.
52: New York did not respond to the KFF survey, but we researched Medicaid benefit information from the state Department of Health and the state's official Medicaid plan .
53: New York’s Medicaid spending has always been high, if not the highest, among other states.
54: In 2015, per capita spending on Medicaid was highest in New York, and 76 percent above the national average, according to an analysis from the Empire Center, a conservative think tank.

gpt4: DiPietro's claim that New York state offers all 35 federal welfare benefits, against an average of 12 to 14 in other states, is false.
DiPietro made this statement in an interview outside a Divide New York caucus meeting[5].
However, an in-depth look into his assertion revealed inconsistencies.
While New York is known for its generous safety net, no expert consulted could confirm the exactness of DiPietro's claim[16].
A review of an analysis that included 33 optional benefits did not support his assertion[18][48].

It's known that programs such as Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid vary in terms of generosity within states, it was discovered that New York does not offer more programs compared to other states[19].
Thus, DiPietro's notion that New York provides all 35 federal benefits while most states offer around 12 to 14 is misleading.
In fact, the 44 states that participated in the survey offered an average of 26 optional benefits[49].
While New York did not participate in the survey, data sourced from the state Department of Health revealed no evidence supporting DiPietro's claim[52].
His claim, therefore, is not consistent with the available facts.

04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.claim: The president had to confess in writing, in court to illegally diverting charitable contributions that were supposed to go to veterans.
04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.label: false
04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.passage:
0: The Democratic presidential debate in Atlanta kicked off with a discussion of the ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump.
1: Pete Buttigieg claimed that Trump’s conduct was impeachable, but also that Trump has already done something that would have gotten any other president out of the White House — and it has nothing to do with Ukraine.
2: "Under normal circumstances a president would leave office after something that was revealed recently that barely got any attention at all," Buttigieg said, "which was the president had to confess in writing, in court, to illegally diverting charitable contributions that were supposed to go to veterans."
3: Is Buttigieg right that Trump admitted in writing to illegally diverting donations for veterans?
4: No.
5: Buttigieg mischaracterized what Trump agreed to in a lawsuit settlement.
6: What Trump agreed to in writing was that his 2016 political campaign, instead of his charitable foundation, coordinated a fundraising event for veterans and directed the distribution of funds.
7: A judge said that Trump breached his fiduciary duties to the foundation by allowing the campaign to take over the fundraiser, furthering his political campaign.
8: The funds were given to veterans.
9: Buttigieg’s campaign sent PolitiFact links to several articles about the settlement which pointed out that Trump’s campaign took control over the fundraiser and other admissions of wrongdoing.
10: Lawsuit and settlement The New York Attorney General Office in June 2018 sued the Donald J. Trump Foundation, Trump (who founded the foundation and served as its president), and his three eldest children (who served on the board of directors).
11: The lawsuit charged that the foundation persistently violated state and federal laws and that Trump repeatedly used his foundation's money for his own personal, business, and political interests.
12: The foundation in December 2018 agreed to dissolve.
13: Earlier this month, on Nov. 7, New York Attorney General Letitia James announced she’d reached a settlement in the lawsuit and that the New York Supreme Court ordered Trump to pay $2 million in damages "for improperly using charitable assets to intervene in the 2016 presidential primaries and further his own political interests."
14: The settlement outlined several matters Trump agreed to.
15: But the part that is most pertinent to this claim relates to early 2016, when Trump said that in lieu of attending a Republican primary debate he would hold a fundraiser for veterans in Iowa.
16: Trump in the settlement agreed that his political campaign planned, organized, and paid for the fundraiser, with the administrative assistance of the foundation.
17: Further, he agreed that the campaign "directed the timing, amounts, and recipients of the foundation’s grants to charitable organizations supporting military veterans."
18: The event raised about $5.6 million in donations intended for veterans’ groups — about $2.8 million of that went to Trump’s foundation and the rest was donated directly to veterans’ groups.
19: Trump even presented foundation checks to veterans’ groups during his campaign events.
20: However, we find nothing in the settlement terms that suggests Trump admitted to illegally diverting those funds away from veterans, as Buttigieg claimed.
21: Trump "breached his fiduciary duty" to the foundation by allowing his campaign to "orchestrate" the Iowa fundraiser and by "using the fundraiser and distribution of the funds to further" his political campaign, New York Supreme Court Justice Saliann Scarpulla said Nov. 7.
22: "I find that the $2,823,000 raised at the fundraiser was used for Mr. Trump’s political campaign and disbursed by Mr. Trump’s campaign staff, rather than by the foundation" in violation of state laws, Scarpulla wrote.
23: However, she added, "the funds did ultimately reach their intended destinations, i.e., charitable organizations supporting veterans."

gpt4: The claim that President Trump had to confess in writing to illegally diverting charitable contributions intended for veterans is false.
It is based on misunderstandings or misrepresentations of the terms of a lawsuit settlement.

The term that Trump admitted in the settlement was that his 2016 political campaign, not his charitable foundation, coordinated a fundraising event for veterans and determined how the funds raised would be distributed [6].
Buttigieg appears to have mischaracterized this settlement, leading to the incorrect claim that Trump admitted to illegal activities [5].
Despite any potential mismanagement, it is important to note that the funds did ultimately find their way to the intended veterans' charities [23].
The settlement did not contain any admission by Trump that he had illegally diverted funds away from veterans [20].

bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.claim: Today in America — a new study came out — 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94% of them have paid off their student loan debt; 5% of African Americans have paid it off.
bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.label: false
bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.passage:
0: In the Nov. 20 Democratic presidential debate , Sen. Elizabeth Warren called for student loan debt forgiveness after citing a startling racial disparity statistic.
1: "Today in America — a new study came out — 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94% of them have paid off their student loan debt; 5% of African Americans have paid it off," Warren, D-Mass., said .
2: There are racial disparities when it comes to student debt.
3: But Warren misstated these two figures.
4: Student debt at record high Warren has proposed that, for anyone making under $100,000, the federal government would pay off up to $50,000 of their debt.
5: The government would also help people making up to $250,000, although on a sliding scale.
6: Student loan debt totals nearly $1.5 trillion, according to an August 2019 report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
7: That’s as high as it’s ever been and up about 200% from 2006, we’ve found .
8: It is a result of increases in both the number of borrowers and the loan balances they carry.
9: As for race, 17.7% of borrowers who live in black-majority ZIP codes default on their student loans — nearly double the rate (9%) of borrowers from white-majority areas, according to a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released a week before the debate.
10: But Warren’s claim alludes to a September 2019 report from Brandeis University in Massachusetts.
11: Study Warren cites The major finding of the Brandeis study is this: "Twenty years after starting college, the median debt of white borrowing students has been reduced by 94% — with almost half holding no student debt — whereas black borrowers at the median still owe 95% of their cumulative borrowing total."
12: The problem here is that Warren talked about borrowers , whereas the statistic she tried to cite from the study talked about the amounts borrowed.
13: 1
14: Warren claimed that the study said that 20 years out, 94% of white borrowers had paid off their student loans.
15: But what the study’s measure of student debt actually found is that, 20 years after starting college, the median debt of white borrowers had been reduced by 94%.
16: 2
17: Warren claimed the study said that only 5% of African American borrowers had paid off their student debt.
18: But the study found that the median debt of black borrowers had decreased by only 5%.
19: We wondered about data for the borrowers.
20: Three student debt experts who were not part of the study pointed out another racial disparity finding of the study: 48% of white borrowers had paid off their student loans, compared with 26% of black borrowers.
21: A Warren campaign spokesman acknowledged that Warren misquoted the study, saying the study is "another alarming reminder of why we need to cancel student loan debt and close the racial wealth gap."
22: One of the study’s authors told us that Warren gets right the broader policy point that there are racial disparities in student debt that should be addressed.
23: "In the important discourse concerning student debt and when race is added, Sen. Warren is right on the mark," said Tom Shapiro , director of Brandeis’ Institute on Assets and Social Policy.
24: But, as we’ve laid out, the way she stated it in the debate was wrong.

gpt4: The claim that in America, 94% of white student loan borrowers and 5% of African American student loan borrowers have paid off their loans 20 years out, is verifiably false.
This claim was made by Warren who misstated the findings of the study during the debate[3][24].

Warren erroneously claimed that, according to the study, 94% of white borrowers pay off their student loans 20 years out[14], however, the study specifically found that the median debt of white borrowers had been reduced by 94% after 20 years[15].

Furthermore, her assertion that only 5% of African American borrowers had paid off their student debt is also incorrect[17], as the study actually showed only a 5% decrease in the median debt of black borrowers[18].
A spokesperson from Warren's campaign acknowledged that Warren had misrepresented the study's findings[21].

f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said ""Americans are the stupidest people on earth."""
f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.label: false
f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.passage:
0: Did the leader of the people’s house really say that Americans are the "stupidest people" on the planet?
1: No.
2: But that hasn’t stopped stories like this one from claiming House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was caught saying that  "while speaking to an aide" at a fundraiser in Illinois.
3: The story from the website Conservative Bless says Pelosi was caught in a hot mic moment after finishing a speech full of lavish promises.
4: It falsely says she told an aide the following: "I can’t believe they cheered.
5: Were they serious?
6: They were, weren’t they?
7: Un-frickin-believable.
8: Trump proved how dense republican voters are and I guess I just left no doubt that Democrats are the same.
9: Americans are the stupidest people on earth."
10: The article, shared nearly a thousand times on Facebook, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: The problem is the entire story was contrived by satire website Busta Troll in late October 2019.
13: RELATED STORY: If you're fooled by fake news, this man probably wrote it While the article and quote originated on a website that describes its content as satire and contains a disclaimer, it was picked up by Conservative Bless and other sites and shared without any such disclaimer.
14: This is not a real news report.

gpt4: The claim that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that "Americans are the stupidest people on earth" is false.
This misinformation was propagated by an article claiming that Pelosi was overheard making the statement to an aide at a fundraiser in Illinois[2].
However, in reality, the story was entirely concocted by the satire website Busta Troll in late October 2019[12].

c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.claim: Today I opened a major Apple Manufacturing plant in Texas that will bring high paying jobs back to America.
c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.label: false
c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.passage:
0: After a brief visit to Austin on Wednesday, President Donald Trump shared a tweet taking credit for opening an Apple Inc. manufacturing plant in the city.
1: Trump toured a facility that manufactures Apple computers during his stop in Austin with Apple CEO Tim Cook, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and his daughter and adviser Ivanka Trump.
2: "Today I opened a major Apple Manufacturing plant in Texas that will bring high paying jobs back to America," Trump said in a tweet after departing the city.
3: "Today Nancy Pelosi closed Congress because she doesn’t care about American Workers!"
4: In reality, the plant he toured has been manufacturing Apple’s Mac Pro computers for nearly six years.
5: The tech giant considered shifting operations to China earlier this year but decided to stay put after receiving federal tariff exemptions.
6: Also: Pelosi did not close Congress on Wednesday.
7: The House approved a bill outlining U.S. support for activists in Hong Kong; and House lawmakers continued their impeachment hearings .
8: The White House and Apple did not return requests for comment.
9: Apple in Austin Apple has had a presence in Austin since 1992, and recent investments have turned the Texas capital into the company’s largest hub outside of its headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. As Trump toured the production plant on Wednesday, Apple started construction on its $1 billion corporate campus in Austin, the latest expansion in the city.
10: The campus will house a number of company operations, including engineering, research and development, operations, finance, sales and customer support, according to the Austin American-Statesman.
11: It is expected to open in 2022 and have 5,000 employees.
12: During his trip to Austin, Trump did not visit the new location nor will it be a manufacturing plant.
13: Mac Pro in Austin Apple has produced its Mac Pro desktop computers in Austin since 2013 at the Flextronics Americas factory in Northwest Austin.
14: The computer has always been designed and engineered in California, and its components are produced in different states and other countries.
15: Final assembly of the product happens in Austin, according to the company.
16: In June, the Wall Street Journal reported that Apple would move the manufacturing of its new Mac Pro models from Austin to China, citing capacity challenges at the Austin plant.
17: Another concern for the tech company was the Trump administration’s proposed tariffs on Chinese goods, which were expected to affect imports of certain materials needed for the Mac Pro.
18: The company asked the Trump administration in July to exclude from the tariffs components needed for its "completely redesigned" Mac Pro, according to Bloomberg .
19: Days later, Trump shut down the request in a tweet : "Apple will not be given Tariff waiver, or relief, for Mac Pro parts that are made in China.
20: Make them in the USA, no Tariffs!"
21: But in September, the U.S. trade representative agreed to grant the exemption, and Apple announced that it would continue to use the Austin facility for Mac Pro assembly.
22: The facility has about 500 workers and has been the company's only major device assemblage operation in the United States, according to Bloomberg .
23: Most of Apple's products are produced and assembled in China.

gpt4: The Claim that a new major Apple Manufacturing plant was opened in Texas is not accurate.
In fact, the facility visited by the Trump administration has been in operation for almost six years, and has been manufacturing Apple’s Mac Pro computers during that period [4].
Apple's Mac Pro desktop computers have been produced at the Flextronics Americas factory in Northwest Austin, Texas since 2013 [13].
Furthermore, during the visit to this existing facility with Apple CEO Tim Cook and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, there was no announcement regarding the opening of a new plant [1].

This visit was timely as the U.S. trade representative recently agreed to grant Apple an exemption that will allow the company to continue using the Austin facility for the assembly of Mac Pro computers [21].

2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.claim: Maxine Waters, Nancy Pelosi and Bernie Sanders have passed six bills in a combined 67 years.
2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.label: false
2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.passage:
0: A viral post on Facebook tried to rewrite three Democratic lawmakers’ congressional records.
1: The post , which was published Nov. 17 by the popular conservative page Trump Rules, includes photos of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., and Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt.
2: Text written over the images claims the trio has not been very productive during their government careers.
3: "67 combined years.
4: 6 bills passed," the post reads.
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: It has been shared thousands of times by several different users and pages.
8: Like past social media posts , this one is inaccurate.
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Let’s look at the first claim — that Sanders, Pelosi and Waters have served a combined 67 years in Congress.
10: Sanders was first elected to Congress in 1991 and has served as both a representative and senator.
11: Pelosi was elected in 1987 and has served as both a representative and speaker of the House.
12: Waters has served as a representative since 1991.
13: When combined, the three lawmakers have served 88 years in Congress — actually more than the Facebook post claims.
14: On the second claim, the Facebook post also falls flat.
15: According to GovTrack , a website that keeps tabs on congressional legislation, the lawmakers mentioned in the post have passed more than six bills.
16: For this fact-check, we first used the most stringent definition of the word "passed" — legislation that is "enacted," or signed by the president — to assess the validity of the post.
17: Then we looked at how many sponsored bills had passed at least one chamber of Congress.
18: Here is each lawmaker’s legislative record as of Nov. 17: Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt.
19: Passed : 2 Enacted : 3 Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.
20: Passed : 9 Enacted : 7 Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif.
21: Passed : 23 Enacted : 3 That puts the lawmakers’ combined enacted bills at 13 — not six, as the Facebook post claimed.
22: However, experts have told us that counting enacted bills is not the only nor the best way to measure lawmaker productivity.
23: "Very few bills are ever enacted — most legislators sponsor only a handful that are signed into law," reads a notice on the GovTrack site.
24: "But there are other legislative activities that we don’t track that are also important, including offering amendments, committee work and oversight of the other branches, and constituent services."
25: Additionally, Pelosi has served as House speaker for seven years, nonconsecutively.
26: That role is more focused on setting the party’s agenda than actually introducing bills, according to GovTrack.
27: The Facebook post is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that Maxine Waters, Nancy Pelosi, and Bernie Sanders have passed six bills in a combined 67 years in Congress is incorrect.
According to GovTrack, a website that tracks congressional legislation, these lawmakers have indeed passed more than six bills[15].
Additionally, when we combine the total years that these three lawmakers have served, it totals 88 years, which is actually more than the 67 years claimed in the original statement[13].
It is also important to note that the process of bill enactment involves many legislative stages and complexities, and as a result, very few bills are ever enacted.
Most legislators sponsor only a handful of bills that are signed into law[23].

5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.claim: "  his campaign hasn’t accepted corporate PAC money and isn’t funded by ""special interests."""
5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.label: half-true
5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.passage:
0: A Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate in North Carolina wants to send a clear message: he won’t be a tool for big businesses.
1: Cal Cunningham, who’s campaigning to be the Democratic nominee against Republican Sen. Thom Tillis, says he won’t take money from corporate political action committees.
2: "That means this campaign is funded by people like you -- not the special interests," he tweeted on July 31.
3: Is it true that Cunningham has received no donations from special interests?
4: PolitiFact has investigated similar claims by former Senate candidate Beto O’Rourke , Congressman Conor Lamb and, in North Carolina more recently, congressional candidate Kathy Manning .
5: While it’s true that Cunningham hasn’t received money from corporate PACs, he has received money from business executives and PACs that receive money from corporations.
6: Corporate PACs The Center for Responsive Politics tracks donations of all types, including political action committees (PACs.)
7: PACs are generally put into three categories: business, labor and ideological.
8: The CRP’s campaign tracker backs up Cunningham’s claim that hasn’t accepted money from business PACs .
9: That’s not necessarily a significant sacrifice for Cunningham, according to Brendan Quinn, CRP’s outreach and social media manager.
10: "Corporate PACs don’t usually give that much to challengers," Quinn said.
11: When those PACs do donate to Democrats, he said they typically give to those in safe districts.
12: "Not much would go to a Democrat trying to swing a Senate seat in a purple state," he said.
13: Cunningham has received $10,000 from labor PACs, $22,590 from ideological PACs, and even more from PACs tied to Democrats in the U.S. Senate.
14: And that’s where Cunningham’s claim comes into question.
15: He’s received money from PACs that get some of their money from corporations.
16: Other PACs Cunningham has received thousands from PACs tied to individual senators, according to campaign finance disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission.
17: For example, Cunningham received $10,000 from Forward Together PAC , which is affiliated with Democratic US Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia.
18: According to CRP, Forward Together has received money from employees of Amazon, Microsoft, and other big corporations.
19: Cunningham also received $10,000 from Motor City PAC , affiliated with Democratic US Sen. Gary Peters of Michigan.
20: Motor City recently received $5,000 donations from American Express, Charter Communications, Comcast, Delta Air Lines, FedEx, General Motors, Goldman Sachs and other large corporations.
21: So, even if Cunningham has shunned corporate PACs, may have received money that originated with a corporation.
22: Some experts consider that degree of separation that some experts consider significant.
23: Andrew Mayersohn, a committees researcher for the CRP, told PolitiFact last year that candidates who receive money from a Senate PAC money are more likely to feel indebted to the Senator than the company who donated to the senator’s PAC.
24: In some cases, though, there’s no separation between Cunningham and corporate leaders.
25: Cunningham has received thousands of dollars from corporate executives.
26: CEO money He received big individual donations from the CEO of a financial consulting group , the founder of a pharmaceutical company , and the president of Blue Shield California , among others.
27: End Citizens United, a group that aims to reduce the influence of money in politics, sees a distinction between receiving money from corporate CEOs and from corporate PACs.
28: The PAC exists to benefit a company, while the motivation of an individual CEO is often unclear.
29: "Individuals can give to candidates for any reason," said Patrick Burwinkle, spokesman for End Citizens United.
30: "That candidate could align with (the CEOs) values," from reproductive rights to foreign policy and other issues.
31: "And that's why - unlike Senator Tillis - Cal has taken and followed a pledge against taking corporate PAC money while also releasing a comprehensive anti-corruption plan that would reform Washington's broken political system," said Rachel Petri, spokeswoman for Cunningham.
32: Some, however, don’t see much of a difference in who the money is coming from.
33: Corporate PACs are funded by the corporations’ employees, not the organization itself.
34: "Every dime that goes into a pac is an individual dime, it’s just pooled resources," Cleta Mitchell, a conservative campaign-finance and election-law attorney told The Atlantic last year .
35: Michael Williams, founder of the public policy and communications consulting firm The Williams Group, explained his skepticism to Fortune Magazine earlier this year.
36: "What’s the difference?
37: If you won’t take a particular bank’s money, but you’ll take the bank executive’s money?"
38: Williams told Fortune.
39: "Are you really materially changing anything?"

gpt4: While it's factual that Democratic nominee Cal Cunningham stated that he won't accept money from corporate political action committees (PACs) for his campaign against Republican Senator Thom Tillis[1], and that he suggested his campaign is instead funded by individual donations[2], some discrepancies have been observed.
The Center for Responsive Politics’ campaign finance tracker supports Cunningham's assertion that he hasn't accepted money directly from business PACs[8].
This is true, Cunningham received funds from labor PACs, ideological PACs and PACs associated with Democratic U.S Senate members[13].
However, it's also evident that his campaign has received funds from business executives[5] and some of the PACs that funded his campaign are known to receive funds from corporations[15][21].
Notable individual donations came from corporate executives, such as the CEO of a financial consulting group, the founder of a pharmaceutical company, and the president of Blue Shield California[26].

Therefore, it's half-true to say that Cunningham’s campaign hasn’t accepted corporate PAC money and isn’t funded by "special interests," as there appears to be some financial ties to corporations and special interests, albeit indirectly.

3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.claim: An image shows Rep. Elise Stefanik flipping off the camera at the impeachment proceedings
3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.label: false
3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.passage:
0: Did Republican congresswoman Elise Stefanik really flip off a camera during one of the impeachment hearings?
1: That’s what a viral photo circulating on Facebook appears to show.
2: No, Stefanik did not flip the bird during or after at the hearing.
3: The image has been manipulated.
4: The image looks as if Stefanik, who represents New York’s 21st district, is using the hand gesture while her colleagues stand in the background.
5: The Facebook post’s caption reads: "US Representative Elise Stafanik and an ‘always trumper’ gives bird finger to the Democrats at the trump impeachment hearing.
6: Classy!"
7: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: We consulted with FotoForensics, a visual analysis tool, which showed evidence that the image was altered to include the gesture.
10: What’s more, the viral photo shows a raised finger with dark red fingernail polish on it.
11: Photos taken by the Associated Press during the Nov. 15 hearing at which this altered picture was supposedly taken show Stefanik was not wearing such a color on her nails.
12: The manipulated version of the photo gained traction online after it was posted in a now-deleted tweet on Nov. 16.
13: When it was pointed out that the photo was fake, the Twitter user, Brian J. O’Malley, deleted the tweet, acknowledged the mistake and apologized to Stefanik.
14: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Stefanik did draw attention during the impeachment hearings, especially during the Nov. 15 testimony of former ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch.
15: Stefanik accused House Intelligence Committee chairman Adam Schiff of trying to undermine Republicans when he interrupted her line of questioning.
16: Stefanik may have voiced her displeasure at the hearing, but there is no evidence she used this vulgar hand gesture.

gpt4: The claim that an image displays Rep. Elise Stefanik flipping off the camera at the impeachment proceedings is false.
First and foremost, the image in question has been manipulated.
This was confirmed after consultation with FotoForensics, a visual analysis tool, which showed evidence of alteration in the photo to include the obscene gesture [3][9].
Furthermore, independent verification of the supposed event contradicted the claim, as Stefanik did not flip the bird during or after the hearing [2].

Photos taken by the Associated Press during the Nov. 15 hearing at which this altered image was purportedly taken actually show Stefanik not wearing the color on her nails as depicted in the manipulated image [11].
When this falsification was pointed out, the Twitter user who made the initial claim, Brian J. O’Malley, deleted the tweet, acknowledged his mistake and issued an apology to Stefanik[13].

530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.claim: The Ukrainian government just indicted the Burisma gas company & named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund.
530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.label: false
530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.passage:
0: Around the time U.S.
1: Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland made some unflattering allegations about President Donald Trump and other administration officials during an impeachment hearing, new claims about Hunter Biden and the Ukrainian energy company Burisma started to spread on social media.
2: "BREAKING NEWS," began one such post on Facebook .
3: "The Ukrainian government just indicted the Burisma gas company & named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund.
4: Your move, Dems."
5: Another post appears to show Clint Eastwood — though it’s not really him — tweeting about the "breaking" and "developing" news.
6: "#Ukraine just indicted Taras Burdeinyi, the chief executive officer of #Burisma," this post said.
7: "Including naming #HunterBiden as the recipient of millions of dollars from slush fund.
8: The tide is turning folks."
9: Both posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: The Facebook account called "Educating Liberals" that shared the first post also wrote: "Before the Facebook ‘fact-checkers’ try to call this fake news & take away my reach again….
12: here’s a source."
13: The account linked to a story published on Interfax-Ukraine, a news agency that’s part of the Russian outlet Interfax .
14: The story’s headline says, "MPs demand Zelensky, Trump investigate suspicion of U.S.-Ukraine corruption involving $7.4 bln."
15: However, the story doesn’t describe an indictment.
16: Rather, it says Ukrainian members of parliament held a press conference at Interfax-Ukraine to demand Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelensky and Trump investigate what they called suspected money laundering involving Burisma founder Minister Mykola Zlochevsky and former President Viktor Yanukovych.
17: According to the story, one of the members of parliament, Andriy Derkach, said that the money transferred to "representatives of the Burisma Group, including Hunter Biden," amounted to $16.5 million.
18: Burisma is central to the U.S. House impeachment inquiry.
19: Trump is accused of holding up U.S. aid to Ukraine on the condition that Zelensky announce an investigation into Burisma and Hunter Biden, son of former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020.
20: Hunter Biden was on Burisma’s board of directors until this year.
21: His involvement has led to scrutiny from Republicans and inspired conspiracy theories .
22: But as NBC News reported , there was no announcement of an indictment Wednesday, as the Facebook posts claim.
23: And according to the Daily Beast , Ukraine’s chief prosecutor, Ruslan Ryaboshapka, said there is no investigation into the Bidens by his office.
24: Here’s what did happen: In October, Ryaboshapka, announced his office would conduct a wide-ranging review of all previous cases involving Burisma, according to NBC.
25: And on Nov. 20, Reuters reported that Ryaboshapka said the country would widen its investigation into Burisma founder Zlochevsky to include suspicion of embezzling state funds.
26: Reuters reported that the prosecutor’s announcement followed the press conference that Interfax-Ukraine wrote about, in which members of parliament called for an investigation into Burisma-related money laundering.
27: There, a document from the general prosecutor’s office was leaked, Reuters said, showing that another prosecutor suspected Zlochevsky, the Burisma founder, of using his official position to embezzle $33 million from the country’s central bank.
28: According to NBC News, the finance blog ZeroHedge appears to have misconstrued the Interfax-Ukraine story and within an hour of publishing its own dispatch, the claim of an indictment had spread on Twitter by tens of thousands of users.
29: Nina Jankowicz, a former adviser to Ukraine’s foreign ministry and a disinformation researcher at the Wilson Center, told NBC the claims appear to be a misinterpretation of a press conference related to allegations "about corruption with Burisma’s head, which have been well known for a long time."
30: She speculated that the lawmakers who held the press conference were angling for Trump’s attention and trying to "curry favor" with his administration.
31: Anders Aslund, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council who researches kleptocracy in Russia, told NBC that the lawmakers pushing new allegations at the press conference — Oleksandr Dubinsky and Andriy Derkach — are "professional disinformers."
32: "This is generally known in Ukraine," he said, "this is not outstanding news.
33: Anybody who’s anybody knows about these two.
34: They are not credible."

gpt4: The claim stating that 'the Ukrainian government just indicted the Burisma gas company & named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund' is demonstrably false.
Contrary to the claim, there was no announcement of this supposed indictment by the Ukrainian government [22].
Furthermore, Ukraine's chief prosecutor, Ruslan Ryaboshapka, clearly stated that there is no investigation into the Bidens currently being conducted by his office [23].
While there was mention of the two parties in question, specifically Hunter Biden and the Burisma gas company, the referenced content does not report an indictment at all [15][3].
Thus, upon examination of provided purported evidence, the claim's inaccuracies are evident.

a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.claim: "  Nike pays factory workers, 80% of whom are women, ""20 cents an hour"" and has them work ""70 to 80 hours a week."""
a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.label: half-true
a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.passage:
0: In September 2018 , Nike announced an endorsement deal with former NFL quarterback and activist Colin Kaepernick.
1: Since then, claims about the company’s labor practices have flooded the internet, attracting thousands of shares on Facebook and Twitter.
2: Many of these viral posts feature a photo of Nike factory workers accompanied by a claim that the company exploits workers with long hours and abysmally low wages.
3: (Most posts are screenshots of a September 2018 tweet by conservative commentator Ryan Fournier.)
4: The posts say: "Just so I'm clear: These factory workers (which are 80% female) are making NIKE's for 20 cents an hour and working 70 to 80 hours a week, so NIKE can profit enough to pay Colin Kaepernick millions to speak out against oppression and injustice?"
5: The Associated Press photo accompanying the post is legitimate, though quite old.
6: It shows Vietnamese workers putting finishing touches on Nike shoes at a factory in Ho Chi Minh City in February 2005.
7: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: It is true that, at one time, Nike paid factory workers close to 20 cents per hour and that many worked over 10 hours a day, six days a week.
10: While most of these numbers are now outdated, experts tell us that overseas factory workers for Nike (and most other major garment industry bands) continue to work long hours for low wages.
11: Let’s take a look.
12: Investigations into Nike’s Vietnamese factories in the 1990s In October 1996, CBS’ 48 Hours news program aired an investigative report on the conditions of Nike factories in Vietnam.
13: The segment revealed that factory workers, mostly women, worked "six days a week for only $40 a month," which translated to about 20 cents an hour.
14: An investigation by Dara O’Rourke , a researcher with the Transnational Resource and Action Center, followed in 1997 and reported several labor law violations at the Vietnamese Tae Kwang Vina plant, a factory that employed over 9,000 workers who produced 400,000 pairs of shoes a month for Nike.
15: According to the investigation, the plant’s night-shift employees worked an average of 10.5 hours a day, six days per week at a monthly salary of $40.
16: A 2003 World Bank report said Nike violated Vietnamese environmental and labor laws by exposing 10,000 workers at the Tae Kwang Vina plant to toxic solvents and forcing them to work above legal overtime limits.
17: The report noted that the investigations, along with public outcry evoked by activists in Vietnam and the United States, prompted Nike to make improvements: "Consequently, Nike took proactive measures and allowed independent auditing of the sweatshops.
18: In 1999, Nike implemented its own ‘Code of Conduct’ in Vietnamese factories.
19: During recent years, there has been a visible improvement in VT’s practices, such as safer work conditions and workers’ awareness of their rights and entitlements."
20: What about now?
21: PolitiFact reached out to the Clean Clothes Campaign , an alliance of labor unions that focuses on improving working conditions in the garment and sportswear industries.
22: The organization told us that the numbers for the pay and hours, aren’t precise but  the sentiment with regard to fair pay and treatment is correct: Factory workers for Nike –– and other major sportswear brands such as Adidas and Under Armour –– do not earn "anywhere near a living wage."
23: They confirmed that the claim of 80% of factory workers being women lines up with industry estimates, which have been as high as 85%.
24: Clean Clothes also pointed us to a June 2019 report that surveyed top brands about their progress in implementing a living wage for workers and said most brands –– Nike included –– provided no evidence that their workers anywhere in the world were being paid a living wage.
25: Research from 2014 shows that, in most of the Southeast Asian countries that Nike sources from, wages reach around 25% of a living wage.
26: Paul Roeland, a campaign coordinator with the Clean Clothes Campaign, told PolitiFact that, when it comes to working hours, most workers have a contract to work 48 hours a week but regularly continue working beyond that, often up to 60 hours a week.
27: He said the hours fluctuate and are often longer during peak production times.
28: "The factual numbers are shocking enough: it would come down to between 65-90 cents (USD) per hour (depending on the country), and regular 60-hour work weeks," Roeland told PolitiFact by email.
29: That said, he bristled at the overall message in this viral post: "At Clean Clothes Campaign, our aim is in supporting garment workers worldwide, as it has been over the past 30 years," Roeland said.
30: "However, we strongly believe that criticizing Nike's labour practices with the sole aim of disparaging the anti-racist activism of others, as some right-wing U.S. political figures are doing, is highly disingenuous.
31: Garment workers deserve so much better than to be used as a handy argument in a social media meme."
32: PolitiFact reached out to Nike for a response but did not hear back in time for publication.
33: Nike’s code of conduct for supplier facilities reads, "the regular work week shall not exceed 48 hours" and suppliers should "allow workers at least 24 consecutive hours of rest in every seven-day period.
34: All overtime work shall be consensual.
35: Suppliers shall not request overtime on a regular basis and shall compensate all overtime work at a premium rate.
36: Other than in extraordinary circumstances, the sum of regular and overtime hours in a week shall not exceed 60 hours."
37: It’s important to note that Nike isn’t alone.
38: While wages and hours for factory workers vary from country to country, many major companies use the same factories and all pay the same low wages for their workers.
39: Experts tell us that while it depends on the country and the volume of production, violation of legal overtime standards is common in the garment industry.

gpt4: While it is accurate that Nike has previously paid factory workers close to 20 cents per hour and many worked over 10 hours a day, six days a week, these figures are outdated and do not represent the current scenario[9][10].

Nike's code of conduct currently stipulates that the regular work week for suppliers should not exceed 48 hours, and suppliers are to allow workers at least 24 consecutive hours of rest in every seven-day period[33].
In extraordinary circumstances, the sum of regular and overtime hours in a week can go up to 60 hours but should not exceed that [36].
However, Paul Roeland from the Clean Clothes Campaign claims that despite the contract on paper, in reality, workers often work up to 60 hours a week [26].
Furthermore, an investigation revealed that the plant’s night-shift employees worked an average of 10.5 hours a day, six days per week at a monthly salary of $40 [15].

In terms of wages, a June 2019 report surveying top brands about their progress in implementing a living wage for workers pointed out that most brands, including Nike, provided no evidence of paying their workers a living wage [24].
Overall, while the wages and hours worked by factory employees do remain low, the claim that workers are paid 20 cents an hour and work 70 to 80 hours a week is only half-true.

e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.claim: "  a study projected that a pension buyout program he expanded would save ""billions and billions, potentially $25 billion."""
e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.label: half-true
e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.passage:
0: During a recent sit-down interview at a local business forum, Democratic Gov.
1: J.B. Pritzker dismissed the possibility of changing the Illinois constitution to make it possible to reduce public retiree benefits.
2: Echoing growing calls from certain groups to ask voters next year to eliminate the clause that protects those benefits, the moderator at the event hosted by the Economic Club of Chicago asked Pritzker why he won’t promote such a plan as part of his broader push to shore up the state’s finances.
3: In response, he argued there are other ways to help fill the state’s massive pension hole.
4: One of his examples caught our attention: "In the spring, we expanded a program to buy out — a voluntary program — to buy out retirees when they’re retiring at 60% of what their pensions would be," Pritzker said .
5: "People are choosing to take the money up front.
6: It’s saving the state money.
7: In fact, a study was done of what the savings would be and it’s billions and billions, potentially $25 billion of savings.
8: And by the way, people are choosing it — almost 20% of people who are retiring are choosing that buyout."
9: Illinois’ unfunded liability — the gap between its pension assets and the benefits it has committed to pay future retirees — is nearly $137 billion , largely due to decades of underfunding by public officials .
10: And $25 billion sounds like it could go a long way toward addressing that shortfall.
11: But Pritzker left a lot of questions unanswered.
12: He didn’t provide a timeframe for those savings, nor was it clear from his remarks which program he was describing or what study determined it could save the state billions.
13: So we decided to find out.
14: Unpacking Pritzker’s claim In response to our inquiry, Pritzker spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh said the governor was referencing two programs that allow some participants in the state’s three largest retirement systems to forego certain benefits in exchange for an upfront payment.
15: Both buyout programs were created as part of the 2018 state budget and were extended in the budget Pritzker signed this year to June 30, 2024 from their original sunset date in mid-2021.
16: But each program is more limited than what the governor described.
17: One program allows people who formerly worked for the state — including its public schools and universities — long enough to qualify for a state pension and who have not yet begun to draw from it to trade all rights to a future retirement benefit in exchange for a lump sum equal to 60% of the total lifetime pension they would have received.
18: Despite being a total buyout worth the same percentage Pritzker referenced, this program applies to a much smaller subset of state retirement system members than his comment suggests.
19: The other program permits retiring members who were hired before 2011 to trade the 3% compounded automatic annual increase to which they are entitled under the state’s two-tiered pension structure for an annual increase of 1.5% on the original value of their pension, which would not be compounded.
20: In exchange, they receive a lump sum equal to 70% of the difference between the value of the higher and lower annual increases.
21: In short, it is not a total pension buyout.
22: So far, participation and cost savings associated with both programs has been limited.
23: Out of 3,600 qualified inactive members of the State Employees’ Retirement System (SERS), which covers state employees who do not work in public education or for the judicial and legislative branches, 22 have elected to take a total buyout since it became an option for those members in 2018, according to a spokesman.
24: At the Teachers Retirement System of Illinois (TRS), 297 out of 14,598 eligible members have decided to participate, a spokesman for that system told us.
25: The participation rate was higher for the accelerated annual increase program.
26: Since last December, 719 out of 2,889 retiring Tier 1 SERS members have elected to take it, for a participation rate of nearly 25%, according to SERS.
27: At TRS, which covers employees at public schools outside Chicago, 596 — or 16% — of the system’s 3,715 eligible retiring members opted for it this year.
28: For context, however, there are roughly 61,000 retired SERS members and 64,000 current employees.
29: TRS, the state’s largest system, has about 112,000 retirees currently drawing benefits and 163,000 current employees.
30: "The statement makes it sound like a large portion of people are taking these options and it’s important to realize that it’s a limited pool who’s even eligible for these buyout programs," said Amanda Kass, associate director of the Government Finance Research Center at the University of Illinois-Chicago and an expert on state and local pensions.
31: We did not receive a response from the third major state pension fund, the State Universities Retirement System, by publication time.
32: As for Pritzker’s contention that the buyouts would save the state billions, his spokeswoman said the governor was presented with an independent analysis that came to that conclusion.
33: However, she declined to provide the study itself or offer any further details about where it came from and what it was based on.
34: "The governor was referencing a proprietary study conducted by and for an outside organization that he was presented," Abudayyeh wrote in an email.
35: "It determined that pension buyouts, depending on the structure of the options, have the potential to save billions, including as much as roughly $25 billion.
36: The administration has not yet determined its estimate, nor did the governor say that this was the administration’s estimate for how much money buyouts are currently saving or will save."
37: Without access to the study, we cannot confirm Pritzker’s comments square with its findings.
38: This July, however, a budget watchdog group published an analysis finding the programs had "generated relatively minor savings" in the last fiscal year.
39: While the programs were expected to save the state more than $400 million that year, they generated just $13 million in savings for the state’s general fund, the Civic Federation found.
40: As the group’s analysis notes, the original state estimate overstated the potential savings because it was based on an actuarial review of a different buyout proposal that extended through 2045.
41: "It seems like these programs are going to save the state some money, but it’s likely to be much less than people may have thought," said Kass, the state pension expert.

gpt4: Governor Pritzker claimed that a pension buyout program he expanded could potentially save billions, or potential $25 billion, as projected by an independent study according to his spokeswoman [32].
However, it was not clarified in the governor's remarks which program was involved, the specific study or a timeline for these savings [12].
Critics point out that while these programs could potentially save the state money, it may be considerably less than the projected figures [41].
This is backed up by the Civic Federation's discovery that the programs, expected to save more than $400 million in a year, only generated $13 million in state general fund savings [39].
Further, the original state estimate was criticized for over stating potential savings as it was based on an actuarial review of a different, long-term buyout proposal [40].
The governor's administration has not yet determined its own saving estimates nor confirmed if the current or future savings align with the governor’s claims [36].
The validity of the governor's claim remains uncertain due to unavailable access to the study for confirmation[37].
As a result, despite the analysis endorsing potential savings, the governor's claim is rated only half-true.

40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.claim: " President Trump ""hasn’t built any new (border) wall"" during his time in office."
40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.label: half-true
40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently claimed President Donald Trump isn’t serious about building his promised Southern border wall and that his comments on the topic "are really an applause line at a rally."
1: "The President hasn’t built any new wall in the whole term of office," Pelosi added, speaking on "Face the Nation" this week.
2: Trump’s intentions are difficult to judge, but we can examine his progress, or lack thereof, on the border project.
3: Was Pelosi right that no "new wall" has been built?
4: Our research We started by reviewing last week’s White House briefing by acting U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Mark Morgan.
5: Asked by a reporter about the project, Morgan confirmed that all 78 miles of what he described as "new" border wall built so far are replacements for existing barriers.
6: The work includes building steel bollard fencing, which consists of vertical steel posts with a small amount of space between them.
7: It is not, however, the solid concrete wall that Trump promised during his campaign and said Mexico would pay for.
8: "The Trump Administration has not completed any new miles of border wall.
9: Replacement wall is not new wall," Pelosi’s spokesman Drew Hammill told us in an email.
10: Hammill added that the House Appropriations Committee hasn’t funded any new border wall, at least not of the type Trump had promised.
11: That is supported by The W ashington Post’s September analysis of the project’s funding.
12: "Trump asked Congress in 2018 for $25 billion to cover the cost, but Congress refused.
13: Lawmakers appropriated $1.57 billion, restricted to "fencing," such as "currently deployed steel bollard designs," the Post reported.
14: As PolitiFact National reported back in January, "Congress has not appropriated money for a wall.
15: Fencing is being built or has been completed at the southwest border.
16: But not a wall."
17: President Donald Trump reviews border wall prototypes, Tuesday, March 13, 2018, in San Diego.
18: Evan Vucci / AP Photo First truly new section Pelosi’s statement ignores one key new stretch: Construction started in late October on the first new section where no structures stood previously, just south of Donna, Texas, according to a recent New York Times article .
19: This eight-mile stretch will take months to complete.
20: So far, it includes two twin see-through panels of 18-foot-tall steel beams, according to the Times .
21: A matter of semantics Theresa Cardinal Brown, director of immigration and cross-border policy at the Bipartisan Policy Center, said much of the debate over Trump’s progress and whether he’s built any "new wall" comes down to semantics.
22: "It depends on your definition of 'new,' Cardinal Brown wrote in an email.
23: "If 'new' is defined as newly-built, even if it is replacing other barriers in the same location, then you can accurately say new wall has been built.
24: If 'new' is defined as built in new locations along the border where previous barriers did not exist, then it would be correct to say that there hasn’t been any new wall built.
25: It is that semantic difference that the government and Democrats are exploiting in their rhetoric."
26: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Our rating House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently claimed President Trump "hasn’t built any new wall" during his time in office.
27: That’s supported, in part, by the Trump administration’s Customs and Border Protection acting commissioner.
28: He confirmed at a press briefing last week that all 78 miles of what he described as "new" border wall built so far are replacements for existing barriers.
29: These replacement barriers, however, aren’t the solid, concrete wall candidate Trump talked about.
30: They are see-through bollard fencing.
31: Pelosi’s statement does leave out one piece of key information.
32: Construction is now underway on the first original stretch of border barriers during Trump’s presidency, an eight-mile section of fencing in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas.
33: Pelosi’s statement is accurate but needs clarification or additional information.
34: We rate it Mostly True.
35: MOSTLY TRUE – The statement is accurate but needs clarification or additional information.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump "hasn't built any new (border) wall" during his term in office is partly true.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's statement that no new wall has been constructed during Trump's presidency was confirmed by an official who stated all 78 miles of what was touted as "new" border wall are actually replacements for existing barriers[1][5][28].
It should be noted, however, that construction has begun on the first original stretch of border barriers under Trump's term: an eight-mile section in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas[32].
Also, it's important to clarify that these replacement barriers aren’t exactly the solid, concrete wall that Trump talked about during his campaign [29].
This context provides a nuanced understanding of the claim, hence its categorization as half-true.

93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.claim: I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries -- the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry.
93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.label: true
93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Ron Kind, in office since 1996, has been on the front lines of history.
1: In 1998, the Wisconsin Democrat had to vote on an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton, a Democrat.
2: This time around, Kind faced a vote on the impeachment investigation into President Donald Trump, a Republican.
3: Partisan politics in Washington has changed dramatically in the two decades between the votes, with today’s open warfare fueled by a divide among the public that plays out every day on TV and social media.
4: Kind represents a district covering the western part of the state that Trump won by 4 percentage points in 2016 over Democrat Hillary Clinton.
5: Party lines aside, Kind says he has a one-of-a-kind distinction in Congress.
6: "I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries, the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry," Kind said on WISN-TV’s "UpFront" program.
7: Is that true?
8: Clinton’s impeachment It’s been more than 20 years since Clinton became the second president to be impeached.
9: The first was Andrew Johnson in 1868.
10: After a nearly five-year investigation led by independent prosecutor Ken Starr, Clinton was ultimately impeached by the Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.
11: But the effort did not muster enough votes from the Senate to remove Clinton from office.
12: In all, 31 Democrats voted in favor of a Republican resolution to launch a formal impeachment inquiry of Clinton.
13: Kind -- who was starting his second term in Congress at the time -- was one of them.
14: Ultimately, four articles of impeachment were brought against Clinton, including two perjury charges, one charge of abuse of power and one of obstruction of justice.
15: Kind voted against all of the articles of impeachment, and the House eventually voted to impeach on obstruction of justice and a single perjury charge.
16: The perjury charge passed the House with a 228-206 vote, while the charge for obstruction of justice passed with a 221-212 vote.
17: The Senate followed with a 50-50 split on the accusation that Clinton obstructed justice, but dismissed the charge of perjury 55-45.
18: Let’s fast forward to today.
19: The case against Trump In October 2019, House Democrats voted 232-196 -- a vote that fell largely on party lines -- to pursue an impeachment inquiry into Trump.
20: The investigation revolves around accusations that Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine unless the country agreed to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a chief Trump rival in the 2020 presidential race.
21: Kind has been less vocal on Trump and the impeachment process than his Democratic counterparts Gwen Moore of Milwaukee and Mark Pocan of Madison.
22: Kind has been open about his support for investigating Trump, but told Wisconsin Public Radio in an interview that aired Oct. 17, 2019 that impeachment and removal from office should be a "last resort."
23: At the time, Kind called the allegations "extremely serious" but said he wanted to gather all the facts before deciding whether impeachment was the proper path forward.
24: He also referred to the actions involved in the allegation as unlawful, unpatriotic and unconstitutional.
25: In all, 55 current members of the House -- 40 Democrats, 15 Republicans -- were also in office during the time the House voted to start an impeachment inquiry into Clinton.
26: Our research shows Kind, indeed, was the only one to vote for both.

gpt4: The claim made by the Wisconsin Democrat that he was the only member of Congress to vote for both the Clinton and Trump impeachment inquiries does hold up under scrutiny.
In 1998, when he was just beginning his second term, the Wisconsin Democrat indeed voted on an impeachment inquiry into Democratic President Bill Clinton [1][13].
More recently, in October 2019, House Democrats, including the Wisconsin Democrat, voted largely along party lines to pursue an impeachment inquiry into President Trump [19].
This evidence is further corroborated by research verifying that he was the only Congress member to vote for both impeachment inquiries [26].
This was also confirmed by the Wisconsin Democrat himself in WISN-TV’s "UpFront" program [6].

6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.claim: President Obama used government funds to pay for his personal vacations for the next 20 years and Trump sent him a bill.
6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.label: false
6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.passage:
0: Did President Donald Trump send former President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama a bill to "repay the government" for vacations they took that weren’t "official state business"?
1: The account is just as false now as it was when it first appeared in 2017.
2: The bogus story recently resurfaced in an Oct. 29 Facebook post that has been shared over 21,000 times.
3: A portion of the lengthy post reads: "... TRUMP JUST ENDED OBAMA’S VACATION SCAM!
4: Before Obama left office, he arranged with the State Department for a series of ‘official visits’ to foreign countries spanning the next 20 years.
5: Using discretionary funds from the Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations, Obama was planning to weasel what would have been another $2.1 billion in free vacations for him and up to 24 members of his family plus staff and even a dog sitter until the year 2036" The post continues, saying that Trump canceled the Obamas’ plans, recalled Secret Service agents and sent the Obamas a $214 million bill for vacations they took that weren’t "official state business."
6: It claims the Obamas spent 692 days on vacation.
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: No, President Obama didn’t take $2.1 billion from the "Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations" — an office that does not exist — to pay for family vacations for the next 20 years, and President Trump didn’t end the "vacation scam" and bill the Obamas to repay a portion of the money.
10: None of this is true.
11: The entire story was fabricated and originated from satirical website, "The Resistance: The Last Line of Defense," which is a part of a network of satire and parody sites.
12: We were able to track down the article, which was posted in February 2017, using the internet archive tool Wayback Machine.
13: The website includes a disclaimer that reads: "All articles should be considered satirical and any and all quotes attributed to actual people complete and total baloney.
14: Pictures that represent actual people should be considered altered and not in any way real."
15: According to CBS News White House reporter Mark Knoller, who keeps records of presidential travel, President Obama took 29 vacation trips over his eight years in the White House.
16: The trips spanned all or part of 235 days (not 692).
17: He also made 39 visits to Camp David, totaling around 93 days.
18: Even though the original story was published with a disclaimer, versions of the account were copied and pasted in social media posts with no such explanation and circulated as real news.
