gpt4: The claim that President Obama used government funds to finance his personal vacations for the next two decades and President Trump billed him for it, is categorically false[1].
Despite recurring appearances, this assertion traces back to "The Resistance," a satirical website known for manufacturing spurious stories, nullifying its authenticity[11].
The narrative alludes to a non-existent "Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations," which President Obama allegedly pilfered $2.1 billion from, further discrediting this rumor.
In fact, it's worth noting that President Obama did not even plan any extravagant vacation schedule as suggested[9].

CBS News' White House correspondent Mark Knoller, who meticulously chronicles presidential travel, reports that over his entire term of 8 years, President Obama availed 29 vacation trips, amounting to a total of 235 days, and not the exaggerated number of 692 days as per the false account[15][16].

b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.claim: Missouri, in general, has more crime, percentage-wise, than the rest of the country. So, we are seeing overall crime throughout the country is going down but not here in Missouri.
b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.label: half-true
b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.passage:
0: Last month, Gov.
1: Mike Parson began a task force to " help combat violent crime in the St. Louis region ."
2: In September, Democrats filed 16 gun-related bills during a special session.
3: So you can bet that crime will be a big topic in the General Assembly session in January.
4: Jean Evans, the executive director of the Missouri Republican Party, spoke up about crime on a recent Missouri Times interview panel .
5: The panel focused on St. Louis crime, but Evans began talking about the state as a whole.
6: "Missouri, in general, has more crime, percentage-wise, than the rest of the country.
7: So, we are seeing overall crime throughout the country is going down but not here in Missouri," Evans said.
8: We wanted to know whether Missouri’s crime rate is higher than the national average, and if the rate is going up while the rest of the country’s crime is going down.
9: We spoke with Evans to see where she got this information.
10: "Missouri’s murder rate is higher than the national average," she said.
11: "There are numerous resources for crime statistics, from the FBI to Wikipedia.
12: I’ve seen reports in both the Post-Dispatch and KC Star on this topic.
13: I wasn’t quoting a specific article."
14: We looked.
15: The articles Evans might have been citing look into metropolitan crime, not Missouri in general.
16: And the Wikipedia page "Crime in Missouri" contained statistics from 2011.
17: So we decided to dig some more.
18: Looking at the data The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting Program is the main source for most statistics about crime.
19: The two most prominent categories are violent crime and property crime.
20: Violent crime is defined as murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, rape, robbery and aggravated assault.
21: Property crime includes burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft and arson.
22: In 2018, the United States violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 380.6 compared to 502.1 for Missouri.
23: Both fell last year from 20l7 to 2018 after three years of increases.
24: Missouri’s violent crime last year decreased by 5.2% while the United States saw a 3% decrease.
25: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com In the larger picture, Missouri’s violent crime rate has increased in the last five years.
26: In 2013, the state’s violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 433.7, and in 2018 that number was up to 502.1.
27: In 2013, the United States violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 379.1, and in 2018 was 380.6.
28: "I always say you want to look at crime trends, you have to look at a span that's more than just year to year, you have to look kind of at a five-year trend," said Aida Hass-Wisecup, a criminology professor at Missouri State University.
29: In property crime, the nation saw a steady decrease in the past five years.
30: Missouri’s property crime rate has had some fluctuations, like from 2016 to 2017 there was a 1.5% increase.
31: But overall,  the property crime rate for five years decreased in Missouri.
32: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Evans’ response includes murder rates, so we looked into that too.
33: In Missouri, murder rates have increased since 2013.
34: The United States saw a large spike from 2014 to 2016 in murder rates, but they’ve decreased since then.
35: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com Other cautions on the data Hass-Wisecup noted that analyzing crime by metropolitan statistical areas, because looking at the overall state can leave "a very distorted perception."
36: "You kind of have to take crime data with caution," Hass-Wisecup said.
37: "Sometimes, arrest does not mean more crime, it means more crime is being detected, because of law enforcement becoming more vigilant."
38: In fact, on the FBI’s 2018 Crime in the United States page , it says, "It is important for users of UCR data, including federal data, to avoid drawing such simplistic conclusions as one area is safer than another or one agency is more or less efficient than another based solely on crime counts."

gpt4: The claim that Missouri, on a percentage basis, has more crime than the rest of the country, and while overall crime decreases nationwide this isn't the case for Missouri, is partly true.
It is certainly accurate to say that in general, Missouri has higher crime rates compared to the rest of the United States.
For example, in 2018, the violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 502.1 for Missouri, while the United States average was only 380.6[22].
Moreover, murder rates in Missouri have been trending upward since 2013, contrary to the overall trend of decreased murder rates across the United States, particularly between 2014 and 2016[33][34].
However, other statistics indicate that this claim is not entirely correct.
Though Missouri's crime rate over the past five years shows an increase[25], it is also true that in the past year, Missouri's violent crime decreased by 5.2%[24].
Nationally, the decrease was slightly lower at 3%[24].
These trends suggest that, at least in terms of recent decreases in violent crime, Missouri fits the national profile.

45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.claim: " China today is ""burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we’re burning in the United States."""
45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.label: true
45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.passage:
0: When former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced that he would spend $500 million on a Beyond Carbon initiative, West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice joined energy industry representatives at a press conference to denounce the effort.
2: The project Justice criticized aspires to retire all coal use by 2030 while securing an economic future for fossil fuel-producing communities.
3: In an op-ed announcing the effort, Bloomberg — who has since entered the Democratic presidential primary race — touted an existing partnership between Bloomberg Philanthropies and the Sierra Club that has "shut down 289 coal-fired power plants since 2011."
4: The new initiative would build on this effort and also "work to stop the construction of new gas plants," Bloomberg wrote.
5: "By the time they are built, they will be out of date because renewable energy will be cheaper."
6: Justice, a Republican whose state is a leading producer of coal and other carbon-based energy, said the effort could be "catastrophic" to West Virginia.
7: (Justice himself also inherited a coal mining business and continues to own several mines.)
8: At one point in the press conference , Justice was asked about the environmental impacts of fossil fuels.
9: He responded by questioning the value of the United States cutting back if China is using carbon-based fuels on full blast.
10: "How does it make sense that in China, they’re burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we’re burning in the United States?"
11: Justice asked.
12: Is his comparison accurate?
13: Justice’s ratio is not far from the reported data, though it’s worth noting that the reason for the discrepancy has a lot to do with the fact that China has a much larger population.
14: (His office did not respond to inquiries for this article.)
15: A look at the numbers There’s little doubt that, as a whole, coal consumption by China is several times larger than it is in the United States.
16: According to the 2019 BP Statistical Review of World Energy , China’s coal consumption was 1.91 billion tons of oil equivalent in 2018.
17: In the same year, the United States consumed 317 million tons.
18: That means China consumed about six times as much coal as the United States did.
19: Another data source, the Global Energy Statistical Yearbook 2019 published by Enerdata, an energy intelligence and consulting firm, found a nearly identical difference — China was about six times larger than the U.S. in consumption of coal and lignite (a low-efficiency type of coal).
20: Justice didn’t mention it, but another country, India, also consumes more coal than the United States does — 452 million tons of oil equivalent, according to the BP review.
21: What about population?
22: We’ll note that the difference in coal consumption between China and the United States is partially explained by the two countries’ difference in population — China has about 4.3 times higher in population than the United States.
23: However, adjusting for population is less significant in this case than it often is, given Justice’s point.
24: Justice is arguing that greenhouse gases do not stay within national borders; they spread everywhere in the atmosphere.
25: So any decreases in carbon emissions made in the United States will be a relatively small factor compared to China in the global context — regardless of which country has a bigger population.
26: Indeed, according to the BP data, China accounted for just over half of the world’s coal consumption in 2018.
27: In addition, the same data shows that China’s coal consumption increased by 1.8% between 2007 and 2017, whereas U.S. coal consumption declined by 4.9%.
28: Unlike the United States, which has a lot of economically competitive natural gas under development, China doesn’t, said Anna Mikulska, a nonresident fellow in energy studies at the Center for Energy Studies at Rice University's Baker Institute for Public Policy.
29: "China has to go against the economic calculus to retire at least some of the coal if it wants to lower emission levels," she said.
30: "This is why we see China still consuming so much."
31: Mikulska added that the current trade friction with China "does not help, as China turns more to domestic or regional resources due to energy security concerns.
32: One of them is coal."
33: That said, the Paris-based International Energy Agency, has projected that China’s coal consumption will indeed decline over the next two decades.
34: "This new direction will have consequences that are no less significant for China and the world than its earlier period of energy-intensive development."

gpt4: According to credible sources, China's coal consumption significantly surpasses that of the United States.
The 2019 BP Statistical Review of World Energy indicated that China's coal consumption amounted to 1.91 billion tons of oil equivalent in 2018[16].
From this data, it can be inferred that China consumed about six times as much coal as the United States[18].

This statistic is supported by another resource, the Global Energy Statistical Yearbook 2019, published by Enerdata which also found that the discrepancy in coal and lignite (a low-efficiency type of coal) consumption between China and the U.S was approximately six times[19].

The ratio stated by Justice is not far removed from these findings, although the difference in coal consumption between the two countries can be in part attributed to China's significantly larger population[13].
Therefore, the claim that China is "burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we’re burning in the United States" is largely true.

c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.claim: "  photo shows ""the Golden Gate Bridge opening to the public for the first time back in 1937, and yes, it almost collapsed."""
c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.label: false
c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.passage:
0: So many people packed San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge when it first opened in 1937 that it nearly collapsed, claims a popular Facebook post, falsely.
1: "The Golden Gate Bridge opening to the public for the first time back in 1937, and yes, it almost collapsed," said caption for a Nov. 29 post that’s been shared about 5,000 times.
2: The attached black and white photo shows a massive crowd of people filling the bridge.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: What’s true: the photo does show thousands of people crammed on the Golden Gate Bridge.
6: What’s not true: The photo isn’t of the 1937 opening.
7: It was taken in 1987 and shows masses of people walking the bridge to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the 8,981-foot long suspension bridge.
8: Here is a San Francisco Chronicle slideshow of pictures from the 1987 event (it includes the one in the Facebook post), and here’s another slideshow from the 1937 opening, with significantly fewer people walking the bridge.
9: There is no evidence that the bridge "almost collapsed" at its 1937 opening.
10: So what about in 1987 when this photo was actually taken?
11: Did it almost collapse then?
12: Some people on the bridge that day thought it might.
13: "Ten years ago, while trapped shoulder to shoulder in the mob, unable to move for more than two hours, I remember discussing with my wife the real possibility that we were about to participate in one of the 20th century's landmark disasters.
14: A bridge collapse would have put to shame all those petty Third World bus and ferry tragedies you read about in the newspaper," Winston Montgomery, a painting and plastering contractor in San Francisco wrote in 1997 .
15: High winds swayed the bridge and an arch on the bridge deck flattened with the weight of the crowd.
16: But engineers told the Mercury News that a collapse wasn’t likely because the bridge was over-engineered to withstand all that weight.
17: No deaths were reported in connection to the 1987 event.

gpt4: The claim that a photo showcases the Golden Gate Bridge opening in 1937 and nearly collapsing is false.
Firstly, evidence indicates that the picture in question was captured in 1987 during the celebration of the bridge's 50th anniversary, not its initial opening in 1937[7].
In addition to this, no verifiable evidence has been found to suggest that the bridge ever came close to collapsing during its inaugural event in 1937[9].

Furthermore, engineers have argued against the plausibility of such an incident, emphasizing that the bridge was over-engineered to carry significantly more weight than it was subjected to, making a collapse highly unlikely [16].

d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.claim: The President wants to cut 3 MILLION people from SNAP, including children, seniors and veterans.
d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.label: true
d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.passage:
0: Over Thanksgiving week, a North Carolina Democrat drew attention to a Trump Administration proposal that would cut the number of people who receive public funding for food.
1: U.S. Rep. Alma Adams, a Democrat representing the Charlotte area, tweeted on Nov. 26 about the administration’s proposal for cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, known as SNAP.
2: "The President wants to cut 3 MILLION people from #SNAP, including children, seniors and veterans," Adams tweeted .
3: "This is unacceptable.
4: SNAP is the first line of defense against hunger and I stand with @TheBlackCaucus to protect America’s most vulnerable: our children.
5: #1MillionKids."
6: Is it true that the Trump administration is proposing to cut 3 million people from the SNAP program?
7: Does that proposal include children, seniors and veterans?"
8: There are multiple proposed changes to the SNAP program, The SNAP program provides "nutritional assistance" to people who are low-income or disabled.
9: Adams referred to proposed changes to "categorical eligibility."
10: And, as it turns out, the Adams’ claim is mostly on-point.
11: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com 3 million The proposed change to "categorical eligibility" rules would affect 3.1 million people currently receiving those benefits, according to the USDA’s own estimates .
12: SNAP currently allows states to grant categorical eligibility to people who are already on other social programs.
13: The USDA believes some those people wouldn’t qualify otherwise.
14: "As a result, some households can qualify when they would not under regular programs rules," the department wrote in a fact sheet.
15: The Trump administration sees this change as closing a loophole allowing some to abuse a program that’s intended to be a "temporary safety net," NPR reported.
16: Who’s affected?
17: We reached out to the USDA’s Food and Nutrition Service department for insight on how many SNAP participants might be affected by the proposed change.
18: An estimated 673,000 households with seniors and 597,000 households with children are projected to lose benefits, the USDA’s communications office told us in an email.
19: As for military veterans, the number is a little less clear.
20: We reached out to the USDA and other groups that track SNAP beneficiaries, but struggled to find a specific number of veterans that might be affected.
21: Veterans not tracked "USDA does not have data to determine the specific impacts of the rule on households with veterans, as veteran status does not impact eligibility and therefore is not captured in the caseload data used to analyze the rule," the USDA told us.
22: But it’s possible veterans would be affected.
23: About 40 million people participate in the SNAP program.
24: About 1.4 million veterans live in participating SNAP households, according to a 2018 study by the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.
25: The center analyzed data provided by the U.S. Census Bureau and estimated SNAP is currently assisting 55,000 veterans in North Carolina.
26: Rebecca Vallas, a senior fellow at the left-leaning Center for American Progress, believes it’s "more than fair to conclude" veterans would be affected.
27: She believes Adams is on "strong footing."

gpt4: U.S. Representative Alma Adams made a claim on Twitter about the administration's proposed cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which were intended to affect around 3 million individuals, including children, seniors, and veterans[1][2].
The proposed changes involve a modification to "categorical eligibility" rules, which would impact exactly 3.1 million of the current beneficiaries, as estimated by the USDA[11].
The USDA's communications office further explained that the benefits cut would likely hit an estimated 673,000 households with seniors and 597,000 households with children[18].

The exact number of military veterans to be affected by this change isn't completely clear but it's notable that about 1.4 million veterans benefit from the SNAP program and an analysis by a 2018 study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimated that the program is helping about 55,000 veterans alone in North Carolina[19][24][25].
Hence, the claim can be viewed as true given these assessments.

69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.claim: the cartels are so bad in a Mexican border state that the U.S. government issued a ‘Do Not Travel’ warning -- the same warning it issued for Syria.
69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.label: true
69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.passage:
0: A North Carolina Congressman appears to support President Trump’s move to designate Mexican drug cartels as terrorist groups.
1: U.S. Rep. Mark Walker, a Greensboro Republican, tweeted a thank you to President Trump on Nov. 27.
2: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com "Thank you @realDonaldTrump.
3: These cartels endanger Americans and threaten our country’s national security.
4: The problem is so bad that @StateDept issued a "Do Not Travel" advisory to a Mexican state that has a 230m border with the US–the same designation as Syria," Walker tweeted .
5: Walker, who has 26,000 Twitter followers, tweeted his comments in reaction to a story about the U.S. designating drug cartels as terrorist groups.
6: But Walker’s claim — about a Mexican state having the same travel warning as Syria — isn’t addressed by the New York Times story he tweeted.
7: So we wondered whether the claim by Walker was true.
8: And, from our research, he’s on-point.
9: We analyzed Walker’s claim in three parts: Did the U.S. government issue a "Do Not Travel" advisory for a Mexican state?
10: Did the U.S. government issue the same travel advisory for Syria?
11: And how long is that Mexican state’s border with the U.S.?
12: Travel advisories The State Department labels the safety levels in foreign countries using a four-step scale: 1- Exercise normal precautions.
13: 2- Exercise increased caution.
14: 3- Reconsider travel.
15: 4- Do not travel.
16: The State Department considers Mexico as a whole to be a Level 2 country, meaning travelers should "exercise increased caution."
17: The department also assigns advisory levels to individual states.
18: Five states are at the "do not travel" level: Colima, Guerrero, Michoacan, Sinaloa, and Tamaulipas.
19: A ‘lawless’ border state Only one Level 4 state, Tamaulipas, shares a border with the United States.
20: And it is known for being dangerous.
21: The Associated Press has described the Tamaulipas as a " lawless border state ."
22: The state department website says this about the area: "Violent crime, such as murder, armed robbery, carjacking, kidnapping, extortion, and sexual assault, is common.
23: Gang activity, including gun battles and blockades, is widespread.
24: Armed criminal groups target public and private passenger buses as well as private automobiles traveling through Tamaulipas, often taking passengers hostage and demanding ransom payments."
25: As it turns out, Tamaulipas has the same travel advisory as Syria .
26: Length of the border Walker’s tweet about the length of the border — 230m — might give readers pause.
27: The letter "m" is an abbreviation for a meter of length.
28: A meter is about 39 inches.
29: So, at first glance, one might think Walker was referring to a border slightly longer than two football fields.
30: But, given the U.S. isn’t on the metric system, it’s more likely that Walker was referring to miles.
31: And indeed that was the case, according to spokesman Jack Minor.
32: (Quick fact: the correct abbreviation for a mile is "mi," according to Dictionary.com .)
33: Asked for the source of Walker’s information, Minor emailed a link to a 2012 McClatchy DC story, " Along Mexico border, drug taint on politicians lingers ."
34: The second paragraph describes Tamaulipas as "a muggy Gulf Coast state that shares a 230-mile border with Texas and is a major conduit for licit and illicit trade."
35: And that length estimate checks out.
36: A page found on the Mexican government website describes the Tamaulipas-U.S. border as being 370 kilometers, which is equal to 230 miles.

gpt4: The statement that the U.S. government issued the same 'Do Not Travel' warning for a Mexican border state, due to the severity of cartel activity, as it did for Syria is indeed correct.
The 'lawless' border state of Tamaulipas, described as a humid Gulf Coast state, shares a 230-mile border with Texas and is a crucial channel for both legal and illegal trade[34][19].
Its severe travel advisory corresponds to the one issued for Syria[25].
This state's notorious status led U.S. Rep. Mark Walker to react by thanking President Trump, via a tweet, for designating drug cartels as terrorist groups[1][5].
Doubts regarding the border's stated length of 230m as mentioned in Walker's tweet have been verified and found accurate[26][35].

ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.claim: "  people can send Christmas cards to ""a recovering American soldier"" at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C."
ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.label: false
ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.passage:
0: Sending a card to "a recovering American soldier" at Walter Reed Army Medical Center sounds like a nice gesture of holiday cheer.
1: But it won’t work out, despite the advice of social media.
2: An old rumor that urges people to send Christmas cards to recovering soldiers is back in online circulation despite being debunked several years ago.
3: Multiple viral Facebook posts being shared about a non-existent holiday card program read: "When filling out your Christmas cards this year, take ONE CARD and SEND it to this address: A Recovering American Soldier, c/o Walter Reed Army Medical Center, 6900 Georgia Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20307-5001.
4: If we pass this on and everyone sends one card, think of how many cards these soldiers could get to bring up their spirits!
5: Feel free to repost.
6: This is a wonderful thing to do!!!"
7: These posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: This is not accurate.
10: The U.S.
11: Postal Service will not deliver any letters, postcards or packages addressed to "Any Service Member" or "Any Soldier, Sailor, etc."
12: Military hospitals also do not accept mail to unnamed service members.
13: What’s more, the address on the Facebook post is the center’s former location.
14: Walter Reed Army Medical Center was merged with the National Naval Medical Center in 2011 to form the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md.
15: An archived USPS FAQ page on supporting troops said programs that allowed people to send mail to service members unknown to them were discontinued following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks: "If this mail is deposited into a collection box it will be returned to sender.
16: Items without return addresses are opened in our Mail Recovery Center Network to determine the sender’s address.
17: If it is impossible to determine the sender’s address, we donate care items to local charities."
18: In a 2007 news release, Walter Reed Army Medical Center officials cited Department of Defense security policies in the post 9-11 world, saying "military medical centers cannot receive mail addressed to ‘any soldier’ or ‘a recovering patient.’ These cards are returned to the post office."
19: The medical center advised people to send holiday cards to service members through the American Red Cross "Holiday Mail for Heroes" program — but that’s changed now, too.
20: Now called "Holidays for Heroes," the American Red Cross effort is handled at the local level and includes other holiday activities that are not solely about mail.
21: The organization’s website says the change "allows local Red Cross offices to identify and engage in a variety of activities that thank and recognize members of the military and veterans living in our communities.
22: There is no longer a national Holiday Mail for Heroes P.O.
23: Box to which cards are sent.
24: Please contact your local Red Cross office for details."

gpt4: The claim that people can send Christmas cards to "a recovering American soldier" at Walter Reed Army Medical Center is false.
Sending mail to "Any Service Member" or "Any Soldier, Sailor, etc." is not permitted by the Postal Service[11].
This is in alignment with the regulations of military hospitals, including Walter Reed Army Medical Center, which also do not accept mail addressed to unnamed service members[12].

Walter Reed officials have previously clarified that due to Department of Defense security policies in the post 9-11 world, they cannot receive mail addressed to "any soldier" or "a recovering patient"[18].
Adding to the inaccuracy, the address circulated on social media is outdated and is the center's previous location[13].
Despite the suggestions from social media, this effort to support unnamed recovering soldiers via Christmas cards will not be successful[1].

8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.claim: "  former Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko ""actively worked for Secretary Clinton."""
8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.label: false
8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.passage:
0: As the House impeachment hearings move forward, Sen. John Kennedy, R-La., argued that Ukraine tried to undermine Donald Trump in the 2016 election, so Trump had good reason to be wary of Ukraine and delay nearly $400 million in military aid.
1: There’s no question that some Ukraine officials publicly objected to comments then-candidate Trump made about Russia annexing Crimea, about 10,000 square miles of what had been Ukrainian territory.
2: Trump cast the Russian land grab essentially as a done deal.
3: But Kennedy said the Ukrainian response went beyond a few officials.
4: He said the Ukrainian anti-Trump effort came from the very top.
5: "Russia was very aggressive, and they're much more sophisticated," Kennedy told NBC’s "Meet the Press" host Chuck Todd Dec. 1 .
6: "But the fact that Russia was so aggressive does not exclude the fact that (former) President Poroshenko actively worked for Secretary Clinton."
7: Todd pushed back, noting the only person pushing that theory is Russian President Vladimir Putin.
8: "Wait a minute, Senator Kennedy, you now have the president of Ukraine saying he actively worked for the Democratic nominee for president," Todd said.
9: "I mean, now come on."
10: Kennedy invited Todd to read news reports, especially articles from The Economist magazine.
11: "Do you believe The Economist magazine is a reputable journal?"
12: Kennedy said.
13: "It's been around, I think, since 1843."
14: Kennedy’s office sent us a list of eight articles to support Kennedy’s claim.
15: None of them back him up.
16: Given Kennedy’s focus on the work of The Economist, it’s noteworthy that little in The Economist’s coverage matches Kennedy’s words.
17: An Oct. 12 article about the U.S.-Ukraine relationship and corruption in Ukraine said, "President (Poroshenko), who had favoured Hillary Clinton in the American elections of 2016, was keen to patch things up with Mr.
18: Trump."
19: The rest of the article does the Republicans no favors, laying out the political work of Trump’s former campaign manager Paul Manafort in Ukraine, and corruption under the previous president.
20: "We are a bit puzzled by Sen. Kennedy citing us to the effect that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 elections," the Economist’s U.S. editor John Prideaux told us.
21: Prideaux said Poroshenko and others trusted Clinton to be tougher on Russia than Trump.
22: In the campaign, Trump often talked about building closer ties to Russia, and warned at rallies that undoing Russia’s hold on Crimea could trigger World War III.
23: "Mr. Poroshenko did not make his feelings secret in Ukraine," Prideaux said.
24: "But nor did he direct any government agencies to meddle in the 2016 presidential election, which is what Mr. Putin did."
25: More of Kennedy’s sources Kennedy mentioned The Economist three times in his interview, but he also listed other news organizations.
26: "It's been well documented in the Financial Times, in Politico, in The Economist, in the Washington Examiner, even on CBS, that the prime minister of Ukraine, the interior minister, the Ukrainian ambassador to the United States, the head of the Ukrainian Anti-Corruption League, all meddled in the election on social media and otherwise," he said.
27: None of those stories put Poroshenko at the heart of a plan to interfere in the U.S. election.
28: They do paint a picture of leaders fearful of Russia and of Trump’s comments that took a more conciliatory stance on Russian aggression.
29: The Financial Times focused on Ukrainian lawmaker Serhiy Leshchenko, who revealed over $12 million in secret payments to Manafort from Ukraine’s pro-Russia party.
30: The Mueller special counsel investigation did not cite those records, but Manafort is now in prison for hiding his foreign income.
31: Leshchenko told the Financial Times that in addition to exposing corruption, it was important to show that Trump was a "pro-Russian candidate who can break the geopolitical balance in the world.’" But Financial Times editor Edward Luce said there was no overlap between Kennedy’s sweeping claims and the newspaper’s coverage.
32: "I’ve been racking my brain, as have my colleagues, as to which Financial Times reporting Senator Kennedy’s referring to," Luce said Dec. 2 on MSNBC .
33: In January 2017, Politico covered some of the same ground, but focused more on the work of a Democratic political contractor who tried to dig up dirt on Trump and his advisers.
34: Republicans frequently mention that article.
35: We vetted it and found that the GOP has used its findings selectively.
36: RELATED: The Politico story at the center of a Ukraine conspiracy The article specifically said there was little evidence of a top-down effort in Ukraine.
37: The Washington Examiner published many opinion and analysis pieces that put Ukrainians’ actions in a dark light, but its straight reporting pieces tracked with the accounts in other publications.

gpt4: The claim that former Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko "actively worked for Secretary Clinton" has been found to be false.

Several Ukraine officials disapproved of then-candidate Trump's comments regarding the annexation of Crimea, an area of approximately 10,000 square miles previously belonging to Ukraine, which Russia claimed [1].
Therefore, the Ukrainian officials' objections were in response to Trump's statements about a sensitive national issue, rather than explicit support for Secretary Clinton.

Furthermore, the assertion is not substantiated by comments made to NBC’s "Meet the Press" host Chuck Todd by Kennedy on December 1, which points to Russia's sophisticated aggression, not any specific activity from Ukraine related to the U.S. presidential election [5].

68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.claim: Speaker Pelosi's drug pricing plan would siphon $1 trillion or more from biopharmaceutical innovators over the next 10 years. CBO's preliminary estimate found this bill ‘would result in lower spending on research and development and thus reduce the introduction of new drugs.’
68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.label: false
68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s flagship proposal to curb prescription drug prices, the "Lower Drug Costs Now Act" ― H.R.
1: 3 ― could come up for a vote in the chamber this month.
2: The measure would allow Medicare to negotiate prices for a limited number of drugs, cap what seniors pay out-of-pocket at $2,000 and force companies that have raised prices beyond inflation since 2016 to either reverse the price or rebate the amount of the increase to the federal government.
3: And drug manufacturers are in full attack mode.
4: Take a recent Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America advertising message embedded in the popular, inside-the-Beltway "Politico Playbook PM" newsletter.
5: "Speaker Pelosi's drug pricing plan would siphon $1 trillion or more from biopharmaceutical innovators over the next 10 years," read the ad.
6: "CBO's preliminary estimate found this bill ‘would result in lower spending on research and development and thus reduce the introduction of new drugs.’" The trade group’s statement represents a core drug-industry argument, deployed whenever lawmakers propose reining in drug prices: Efforts to limit what drug companies can charge means they won’t have the means or incentive to develop lifesaving medications.
7: The argument also appears in ads like this one ― from America’s Biopharmaceutical Companies ― that highlight patients who say they depend on new medications to keep chronic conditions at bay.
8: But many experts contest the link between drug prices and pharmaceutical R&D.
9: So PhRMA’s citation of the Congressional Budget Office ― an influential nonpartisan government agency ― caught our attention.
10: We decided to look deeper.
11: What the CBO says A PhRMA spokeswoman pointed us to a preliminary CBO analysis of H.R.
12: 3
13: Published Oct. 11, the letter doesn’t analyze the Pelosi bill but attempts to explain in broad strokes what kind of economic impact it might have.
14: The "$1 trillion" over 10 years statistic is the CBO’s upper estimate (the range begins at $500 billion) of what the industry might lose in revenue if this bill were enacted.
15: But the agency leaves wiggle room, noting that this is a "preliminary" figure and that the agency hasn’t finished analyzing the full bill yet.
16: Once it does, the $1 trillion could change.
17: "They’re trying to provide some sense of the relative impact on drug development, but I don’t think we have enough data to provide this," said Stacie Dusetzina, an associate professor of health policy at Vanderbilt University.
18: "It’s not a fact.
19: It’s a preliminary estimate that is on very shaky ground."
20: That leads to the next issue: If pharmaceutical revenues dip, would fewer innovative drugs become available?
21: Technically, kind of.
22: But there’s a lot of important context that PhRMA’s assertion overlooks.
23: The CBO estimates that, over the next decade, between eight and 15 fewer drugs would come to market.
24: But the big picture matters: Every year, the Food and Drug Administration approves 30 new drugs, on average.
25: That’s 300 new drugs over 10 years.
26: So if you assume 15 fewer drugs out of 300 projected approvals, that’s a loss of 5%.
27: Certainly that is, as PhRMA argued, a reduction.
28: But none of the experts we spoke with saw it as a blow to innovation.
29: "The lower prices envisioned by [Pelosi’s] bill would barely slow new drug discovery at all," argued Dr. Peter Bach, who directs the Drug Pricing Lab at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, in an op-ed for Bloomberg .
30: It’s not clear from the CBO analysis what kind of clinical value these forgone drugs would have ― whether they would represent meaningful breakthroughs or marginal improvements to medications that already exist.
31: We asked PhRMA.
32: The organization’s position is that the lost revenue could discourage drugmakers from researching new treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s , lung cancer and sickle cell disease .
33: But the group didn’t offer much evidence explaining how or why this would happen, or acknowledging that it would involve stepping away from potentially lucrative markets.
34: And experts dispute the idea ― Dusetzina called the industry line "a scare tactic."
35: In fact, she said, "there is a good reason to believe that the drugs you would lose are those that have the smallest benefit and highest price tag."
36: This gets at another point: A substantial portion of drug research and development isn’t actually done by drugmakers.
37: The riskiest portions often are conducted in government-funded labs, noted Dr. Aaron Kesselheim, a professor at Harvard Medical School who studies pharmaceutical policy.
38: Drug companies get involved much later, making it even less certain that a loss in pharmaceutical revenue would meaningfully discourage breakthrough drug innovation.
39: And any loss of new drugs would likely be at least somewhat offset by Americans’ increased ability to afford newly cheaper drugs.
40: As the CBO report put it: "The overall effect on the health of families in the United States that would stem from increased use of prescription drugs but decreased availability of new drugs is unclear."
41: So, in short: Nonpartisan analysis suggests that H.R.
42: 3 could result in fewer drugs coming to market.
43: But it’s a very preliminary estimate, and even then, it suggests only a small dip.
44: The value of the drugs that don’t emerge is unclear, too.
45: All this context matters a lot.
46: "Hundreds of billions in savings to taxpayers, businesses and patients would mean a real but very small decline in the rate at which new treatments are discovered," Bach wrote.
47: Other arguments PhRMA also pointed us to a Dec. 3 report put out by the White House Council of Economic Advisers .
48: It found a much higher impact ― arguing that H.R.3 would result in "as many as 100 fewer drugs" entering the American market in the next 10 years.
49: This White House report comes after President Donald Trump has repeatedly said he wants to work with Congress to lower drug prices.
50: The CEA number rests on a series of assumptions.
51: First, it estimates that a new drug costs $2 billion to develop.
52: It also assumes that drug companies typically spend at least a fifth of their revenue on research and development.
53: Therefore, if companies’ revenue goes down by $1 trillion, then the math comes out to losing 100 drugs.
54: But experts called this analysis suspect at best.
55: For one thing, Bach told us, the $2 billion figure isn’t substantiated.
56: For another, the CEA assumes that "every penny of company R&D spending goes to inventing new drugs."
57: That, he added, is "utter nonsense."
58: Multiple experts noted that the CEA assumes pharmaceutical companies would cut their R&D to perfectly match the proportion of revenue they currently spend.
59: There’s no reason to assume that’s true.
60: Drug companies also spend a good deal on marketing, administration and dividends to shareholders.
61: Dusetzina also noted that the analysis doesn’t consider the increased revenue drug companies might experience from more people being able to afford drugs and therefore buy them.
62: And it assumes the drugs that never make it to the marketplace would be of high value ― without evidence to support that.
63: "This is not a serious analysis of the question of trade-offs of this policy and innovation.
64: This is fearmongering," Dusetzina said.

gpt4: The claim that Speaker Pelosi's drug pricing plan would drain over $1 trillion from biopharmaceutical innovators over the next decade and result in reduced introduction of new drugs is false[14][15][16][23][26][27][28][35][36][37][39][43][44][45][54][55][56][57][58][61][62][64].

The Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) initial calculations, which estimated a potential loss in revenue ranging from $500 billion to $1 trillion over 10 years, were described as preliminary and presently unfinished, indicating that these figures could change[14][15][16].
Should the bill become law, the CBO projects that between eight and 15 fewer drugs might enter the market in the next decade, indicating a potential 5% drop in the 300 anticipated approvals[23][26].
While this is technically a reduction, no experts saw it as a significant deterrent to innovation[27][28].
Furthermore, some argue that the drugs likely to be lost under the bill are those with minimal benefit and a high price tag[35].
Most importantly, the effects of reduced drug launches could be offset by the increased affordability of these potentially cheaper drugs for Americans[39][43].
Speculation that this plan might severely consequent in less research and development is unfounded according to experts[54][55][56][57][58].

Finally, some also assert that assuming all pharmaceutical company R&D spending is used to create new drugs and that all drugs that never reach the market would be of high value is fallacious[55][56][57][62].
Further, potential increased revenues from enhanced drug affordability were not considered[61].

3a242b6243f14744e0c0d005ef78effc.claim: "  House Intelligence Chair Adam Schiff ""made up the conversation. He lied. If he didn't do that in the halls of Congress, he'd be thrown in jail. He did it in the halls of Congress, he's given immunity."""
3a242b6243f14744e0c0d005ef78effc.label: false
3a242b6243f14744e0c0d005ef78effc.passage:
0: At a NATO summit in London, President Donald Trump took aim at one of his adversaries back across the pond: House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., a key figure in the inquiry into impeaching the president.
1: Trump has repeatedly referred back to the time when Schiff paraphrased Trump’s phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky — an event at the heart of the impeachment inquiry.
2: Trump has portrayed Schiff’s words as a fabrication that twisted what he said, but Schiff prefaced his remarks by saying they were not verbatim but were rather "the essence of what the president communicates" and "in sum and character, what the president was trying to communicate."
3: In a press conference at the NATO summit, Trump once again attacked Schiff over his remarks, suggesting that Schiff could be arrested for what he said.
4: "This guy (Schiff) is sick," Trump said.
5: "He made up the conversation.
6: He lied.
7: If he didn't do that in the halls of Congress, he'd be thrown in jail.
8: He did it in the halls of Congress, he's given immunity.
9: This is a sick person.
10: He's a liar."
11: We found it hard to believe that, outside of the walls of Congress, someone who fabricated and lied would be "thrown in jail."
12: Experts said there is something to what Trump is saying that deserves explanation, but ultimately he’s still wrong that Schiff could be subject to prosecution, even if he wasn’t in Congress.
13: (The White House did not respond to an inquiry.)
14: The Speech or Debate Clause Trump has a point that members of Congress have special speech protections that members of the general public do not.
15: The Constitution’s " Speech or Debate Clause " says that "for any Speech or Debate in either House, (Senators and Representatives) shall not be questioned in any other Place."
16: It aligns with the Constitution’s determination that the House, and not another branch of government, should have the power to sanction its own members for abuses.
17: "The Speech or Debate Clause protects legislators from all criminal prosecutions or civil lawsuits for legislative conduct, broadly understood as anything within the sphere of legitimate legislative activity and necessary to the deliberative process," said Howard M. Wasserman, a law professor at Florida International University.
18: "This includes the sort of legislative oversight and investigation in which Schiff is engaged when discussing that phone call."
19: There are limits.
20: In the 1979 Supreme Court decision Hutchinson vs. Proxmire , the justices ruled that Sen. William Proxmire was not immune from civil or criminal challenge made in a press release or constituent newsletter.
21: "But the clear implication is that the same statements, had they been made on the Senate floor or in a committee hearing, would have been immune," Wasserman said.
22: Can fabrication or libel be punished criminally?
23: The vast majority of libel or slander cases are civil rather than criminal, said Leonard Niehoff, a University of Michigan law professor.
24: This means the speaker’s money could be at risk if they lose a libel or slander case, but they would not be imprisoned.
25: However, criminal libel laws of one kind or another do exist on the books in almost half the states.
26: According to the American Civil Liberties Union and the Committee to Protect Journalists , two dozen states have criminal libel laws.
27: The Supreme Court ruled in the 1964 case Garrison vs. Louisiana that the standard for criminal conviction is the same as in the landmark case from the same year, New York Times vs. Sullivan , that addresses civil libel cases.
28: "The prosecution must prove falsity and actual malice, beyond a reasonable doubt," Wasserman said.
29: Some of today’s 24 state laws wouldn’t be relevant to the Schiff example.
30: The laws in Illinois and Texas only cover slanders against financial institutions, while the one in Massachusetts concerns hate speech based on race or other classifications.
31: Three others specifically exclude imprisonment as a possible sentence.
32: (The states that do set maximum prison sentences top out at one year, possibly including fines.)
33: In addition, the Committee to Protect Journalists cites court cases in seven of these states that would seem to make these laws unconstitutional today, meaning that their existence on the books is archaic.
34: Even the states that have criminal libel laws rarely use them.
35: "As a general proposition, prosecutors have vastly better things to do with their time that pursue charges of criminal libel," Niehoff said.
36: In addition, such laws "would likely be deemed unconstitutional under the First Amendment if they were applied," said Roy S. Gutterman, director of the Tully Center for Free Speech at Syracuse University’s S.I.
37: Newhouse School of Public Communications.
38: Importantly for Schiff’s case, there’s no criminal libel statute for the District of Columbia, or an equivalent federal statute.
39: Nor is there one in Schiff’s home state of California.
40: "So even if Schiff's summaries of the conversations were knowingly false and he were not immune, I am not sure what law he could be prosecuted under," Wasserman said.

gpt4: The claim that House Intelligence Chair Adam Schiff could be prosecuted and jailed for his summary of President Trump's communications is false.

While Trump contended that Schiff fabricated his words, Schiff, on his part, had clarified that his remarks were essentially the crux of the president's communications, and not a verbatim recounting [2].
The claim also fails factually on legal grounds.
There is no criminal libel statute in the District of Columbia where Congress is located, nor is there a federal equivalent [38].

Legal experts, including Florida International University law professor Howard M. Wasserman, have underscored the dubiousness of successful prosecution even if Schiff's summary were knowingly false and he was not under immunity.
They cited the lack of an obvious prosecutable law [40].

Moreover, Schiff, as a member of Congress, is protected by the Speech or Debate Clause, a provision that shields legislators from criminal prosecution or civil lawsuits for legislative conduct encompassing all activities within the sphere of legitimate legislative activity [14][17].
Therefore, even if Schiff were to lose a hypothetical libel or slander case, it would put at risk his financial wealth, but not result in imprisonment [24].
While experts acknowledge that Trump raises considerations worthy of clarification [12], the overall claim is misleading and incorrect.

f41192be9b9024d1930772b7a83cce34.claim: " On red-flag laws says, ""What (Democrats) wanted to do was say, ‘I think you might do something, so I’m going to take away your gun and make you prove you wouldn’t do it."""
f41192be9b9024d1930772b7a83cce34.label: half-true
f41192be9b9024d1930772b7a83cce34.passage:
0: Wisconsin state Assembly Speaker Robin Vos, R-Rochester, has a new take on how red-flag gun laws work.
1: Generally speaking, the laws allow judges to temporarily take guns away from people who are deemed to be a danger to themselves or others.
2: Republicans and Democrats in the state Legislature have been widely divided on a bill that would create such a law in Wisconsin.
3: Gov.
4: Tony Evers, a Democrat, called the Legislature into special session to consider a red-flag law proposal and a separate measure expanding background checks to cover all gun sales, but the GOP quickly adjourned the session without taking action on either.
5: In a Nov. 10, 2019 appearance on WISN-TV’s UpFront , Vos told host Adrienne Pedersen: "What (Democrats) wanted to do was say, ‘I think you might do something so I’m going to take away your gun and make you prove you wouldn’t do it.’ " In other words, the claim is the proposed law would allow a gun to be taken away, and then put the burden of proof on the gun owner to show they are not a threat in order to get the gun back.
6: But that’s counter to one of the basic foundations of the U.S. legal system.
7: It would be akin to saying someone charged with a crime has to prove their innocence -- not that a prosecutor has to convince a judge or jury of the defendant’s guilt.
8: Is Vos right?
9: Let’s dig in.
10: Defense misses the mark Asked for backup, Vos spokeswoman Kit Beyer pointed to the language of the proposed bill that says once an injunction is issued, a judge can vacate it "if the respondent demonstrates, by clear and convincing evidence, that the respondent is no longer substantially likely to injure the respondent or another person if the respondent possesses a firearm."
11: The language is accurate, but Vos is misapplying it.
12: He argues this standard applies to the process from the beginning, when the language actually refers to a step later in the process, when a gun owner can ask the judge to reconsider the original decision.
13: Joseph Blocher, a law professor at Duke University, said the burden of proof is always with the petitioner when it comes to seeking red-flag seizures.
14: "What that burden is -- ‘clear and convincing’ or ‘preponderance of the evidence’ -- varies state by state and depending on whether it’s a temporary ex parte order or a final order," Blocher told PolitiFact Wisconsin.
15: "But in all cases, a judge has to be persuaded of the risk."
16: Indeed, the proposal from Evers would allow guns to be seized if a judge finds "reasonable grounds that the respondent is substantially likely" to harm themselves or others.
17: How would it work?
18: The process varies a bit state-to-state, but always begins with a petition to a court that argues an individual is a danger to himself (or herself) or others.
19: Such a petition typically comes from law enforcement officials, but may also come from family members or friends.
20: Under Evers’ proposal, a judge or court commissioner would hear the request and then decide whether to issue a preliminary order without first having to notify or hear from the gun owner.
21: A temporary order is then put in place for up to 14 days.
22: So, there would be a short period where a gun could be taken before an owner has a say, but with the burden placed on the other party.
23: A judge would then schedule a second hearing to make a final determination.
24: The gun owner would have a chance to be present for this hearing.
25: This is where whomever filed the original petition would make their case.
26: The burden would be on them to convince the judge the gun owner was a danger.
27: The final order would be valid for up to one year, though requests could be made to extend it.
28: Additionally, the gun owner could ask the court for an early end to the order This is the step the language Vos cited actually refers to.
29: It is then -- when a gun owner is seeking an early end to an order -- that the burden of proof would fall on the gun owner.
30: Laws are relatively new The first red-flag law was put in place in Connecticut in 1990, but it wasn’t until 2005 that the second law was approved in Indiana.
31: Following the February 2018 mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., many other states passed similar laws.
32: Now, at least 17 states and Washington D.C. have a red-flag law in place.
33: Each state allows law enforcement to seek the removal of guns, while 12 states also allow family or household members to do so.
34: A handful of states also allow petitions from medical professionals, colleagues or school officials, according to Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence , a research and gun control advocacy organization.
35: There are already several spots in Wisconsin law that relate to when guns can be taken.
36: Under current law, a person is prohibited from having guns or must surrender their firearms if they’re "subject to a domestic abuse injunction, a child abuse injunction, or, in certain cases, a harassment or an individuals-at-risk injunction."
37: If the person surrenders a firearm because of one of those convictions, the firearm can’t be returned to them until a court determines that the injunction has been vacated or has expired, according to a November 2019 analysis by the Legislative Reference Bureau .
38: The law also says people must surrender their firearms as a result of certain proceedings, such as mental health commitments and restraining orders.

gpt4: The claim that Democrats would make gun owners prove they wouldn't commit a harmful act under red-flag laws is only half-true because it somewhat distorts the lawful process involved.
Generally, the laws grant judges the authority to temporarily confiscate guns from individuals deemed a danger to themselves or others [1].

In fact, initially, the burden of proof rests with the petitioner seeking the red-flag order [13], as reinforced by a proposal from Evers, which stipulates that guns can only be confiscated if a judge determines that there is a substantial likelihood that the respondent will inflict harm on themselves or others [16].
However, there can be a brief period during which a gun could be seized prior to the owner being able to present a defence, yet the onus remains on the petitioner [22].
When a gun owner petitions for an early termination of the order, the burden of proof then shifts onto them to demonstrate they're not a danger [29].
So, while it's true that gun owners might have to prove they're not a threat in certain circumstances, the scenario is not valid for the entire legal process, as claimed.

c7ec2f012ca1be9e0995d30f9028fef6.claim: In West Virginia, we have 20,000 jobs in which we don’t have skilled workers.
c7ec2f012ca1be9e0995d30f9028fef6.label: half-true
c7ec2f012ca1be9e0995d30f9028fef6.passage:
0: Is West Virginia falling significantly behind in the job skills required for today’s economy?
1: West Virginia University President E. Gordon Gee said so in an address to students at Musselman High School in Berkeley County.
2: "In West Virginia, we have 20,000 jobs in which we don’t have skilled workers," Gee told students at the high school .
3: Gee’s office told PolitiFact West Virginia that they could not point to the original source of the statistic.
4: However, we were able to reverse-engineer data that falls short of Gee’s number.
5: This gets a bit complicated, so bear with us.
6: Here’s the overall concept.
7: First, we’ll estimate the total number of job openings in West Virginia that require skilled workers.
8: Then we’ll look into how hard these jobs are to fill, based on the educational shortcomings of West Virginia’s workforce.
9: How many job openings in West Virginia require advanced skills?
10: On the job openings side, Brian Lego, a research assistant professor at WVU’s College of Business and Economics, suggested we look at data produced on an experimental basis by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the federal government’s chief agency for employment statistics.
11: This data in question is a spinoff of the longstanding Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey , which produces monthly estimates of job openings, hires, and employee departures on a national basis.
12: For several years, the bureau has also produced an experimental study of this data on a state-by-state basis, which is what Lego was referring to.
13: We looked at the most recent data for West Virginia, which covers the first six months of 2019.
14: We found that in each of those six months, West Virginia had 38,000 job openings.
15: (BLS acknowledges that this is an estimate, though the agency says it isn’t sure what the margin of error is.)
16: This 38,000 figure represents all job openings in West Virginia -- not necessarily those requiring advanced skills.
17: However, we found a way to estimate the percentage requiring advanced skills, using data in a report published by Georgetown University’s Center on Education and the Workforce .
18: The report is from 2010, but it offered projections for the share of jobs in every state by 2018 that would require various levels of educational attainment, so it should offer a rough guide.
19: For West Virginia, the report said, 9% of jobs would be open to high school dropouts, 38% would require a high school degree, 12% would require some college but not a college degree, 15% would require an associate’s degree, 17% would require a bachelor’s degree, and 8% would require a master’s degree or higher.
20: All told, the Georgetown data sees 25% of jobs requiring a bachelor’s degree or higher.
21: And 25% of 38,000 job openings in West Virginia works out to 9,500 job openings in any given month that require a bachelor’s degree.
22: How big are the educational shortcomings in West Virginia’s workforce?
23: This 9,500 figure refers to the number of high-skill job openings in West Virginia -- the demand side.
24: What about the supply side -- the share of West Virginia workers who have the necessary skills to fill those jobs?
25: We found a way to estimate that number, too.
26: Statistics from the U.S. Education Department show that in 2016, about 21% of West Virginians age 25 and up had a bachelor’s degree.
27: Meanwhile, in October 2019, West Virginia had 38,052 unemployed workers .
28: If one assumes that this group of unemployed workers is a representative cross-section of the state’s educational attainment patterns, this would mean there are just under 8,000 unemployed West Virginians who could fill a job requiring a bachelor’s degree.
29: But in reality, better-educated workers tend to be more likely to be employed, meaning the actual number of unemployed workers with a bachelor’s degree is probably well below 8,000.
30: Tara Sinclair, a George Washington University economist, told PolitiFact West Virginia that a reasonable guess is probably 4,000.
31: So of the 9,500 West Virginia job openings requiring a bachelor’s degree, qualified workers who are currently unemployed could potentially fill a 4,000 of those.
32: That leaves 4,500 bachelor’s-level jobs unfilled.
33: And that’s quite a bit smaller than Gee’s 20,000 figure.
34: Some caveats We should emphasize that our estimates involve a lot of moving parts, each with a source of statistical error.
35: We also focused on bachelor’s-level jobs.
36: If we were to instead define "skilled" positions as requiring at least some college experience, the supply of skilled jobs could go as high as 53%, according to the Georgetown University data.
37: That works out to 21,400 jobs requiring advanced skills, rather than 9,500.
38: Using this broader number could make Gee’s figures closer to accurate.
39: Finally, we should note that in the Georgetown comparison, West Virginia ranks 51st in the nation -- dead last among the 50 states and the District of Columbia -- in the percentage of jobs requiring advanced skills.
40: So West Virginia may require advanced skills to fill many of its jobs, but the pressure to fill these advanced-skill jobs is weaker in West Virginia than it is in every other state.
41: "Gee's argument could have been better supported by focusing on the deficit of college educated workers in West Virginia compared to the rest of the U.S. -- 21% versus 31%," Sinclair said.
42: "That seems to be a really big problem.
43: That might actually be the driver of West Virginia’s ranking in terms of jobs requiring college degrees: Employers go where the workers are."

gpt4: Gordon Gee, the president of West Virginia University, made the claim that in West Virginia, there are 20,000 jobs for which there aren't skilled workers[2].
However, a reverse-engineered data contradicts this number[4].
Collecting empirical data over six months indicated that the state of West Virginia had roughly 38,000 job openings[14].
Academic qualifications requirement for these jobs varied, with 25% or 9,500 of those needing a bachelor’s degree[21], in hopes of obtaining a larger pool of talents with higher education levels.

However, considering the previous report from 2010 which predicted job shares by 2018[18], and the unemployment rate in October 2019 which counted 38,052 unemployed workers[27], it raises uncertainties over Gee's claim.
Considering that better-educated workers are often more likely to be employed[29], it suggests that the actual number of unemployed degree-holders is probably significantly less than 8,000.
Hence, of the 9,500 job openings that require a bachelor's degree, only 4,000 could potentially be filled by currently unemployed qualified workers [31].
This smaller figure[33], thus put to question Gee's 20,000 jobs assertion.
Therefore, while there is a labor skill gap in West Virginia, the extent of this issue appears less severe than indicated by Gee's initial approximation.

a89a7562e7ca1249cc7f75c9657c53f2.claim: "  for every ""share"" that a photograph of a sick boy gets, Facebook will donate one dollar."
a89a7562e7ca1249cc7f75c9657c53f2.label: false
a89a7562e7ca1249cc7f75c9657c53f2.passage:
0: Have you ever come across a heartbreaking photo on social media with a caption that claims every share or comment will raise money for a cause?
1: One of these viral posts that pulls on the heartstrings of Facebook users displays a photo of a little boy wearing a breathing mask.
2: It suggests that he has "severe cancer" and every share will generate money for his care.
3: The post, which has gotten over 141,000 shares, reads: "This boy has severe cancer.
4: Facebook will donate 1 dollar for every share!
5: Type AMEN and SHARE!"
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: That’s because it isn’t true.
9: Facebook does not make donations based on the number of shares or comments a particular post or photo may receive.
10: The post is an example of a long-running scam that is employed to generate user interaction by falsely claiming that shares or comments will help pay for a sick child’s care.
11: While it may seem harmless at first, research indicates the tactic exploits children for another entity’s personal gain, makes people believe they are helping and inadvertently bumps up the page’s visibility, in turn allowing scammers to gain followers and cook up more hoaxes.
12: In 2015, the Better Business Bureau released a statement about such scams, calling them "like-farming," and warned that some use the scheme to collect and sell information about users who interact with the posts.
13: "Once the page creators have piled up hundreds of likes and shares, they may strip the page and promote something else, such as products that they will receive commissions for selling," the organization said in the statement.
14: "They may also sell the page and information that was collected from the ‘likes’ with a more direct threat of gaining access in an attempt to gather credit card numbers that may be stored for certain Facebook apps, passwords or other personal information."
15: The Better Business Bureau encourages people to refrain from interacting with these posts and  report them to Facebook instead.

gpt4: The claim that Facebook will donate one dollar for every 'share' a photograph of a sick boy receives is false.
The assertion was flagged as part of Facebook’s initiative to combat fake news and misinformation on its News Feed[6].
To clarify, Facebook's donation policy is not influenced by the number of shares or comments a specific post or image may amass[9].

The claim also seems to be a typical example of an enduring scam designed to stimulate user engagement by deceitfully asserting that shares or comments will financially aid a sick child's healthcare[10].

These types of scams, identified as 'like-farming' by the Better Business Bureau in their 2015 statement, can ultimately be used to accumulate and peddle user information to those who engage with such posts[12].

According to the statement, some even sell the gathered data along with the 'liked' page, providing a more direct threat towards obtaining access to accumulate credit card numbers saved for Facebook apps, passwords and other personal data[14].

e66f6ad36cd11d1ffd60f4454c8b17dc.claim: West Virginia is sixth overall in the average number of at-risk youth.
e66f6ad36cd11d1ffd60f4454c8b17dc.label: true
e66f6ad36cd11d1ffd60f4454c8b17dc.passage:
0: Woody Thrasher, a Republican who is challenging West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice in the 2020 GOP primary, took to Twitter to call out the state’s level of at-risk youth on his opponent’s watch.
2: "‘West Virginia is sixth overall in the average number of at-risk youth.’ Let’s turn this around and grow our workforce by supporting post-secondary training programs.
3: #TimeToGetToWorkWV #wvpol ," Thrasher tweeted.
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Here, we won’t address whether or how much post-secondary training programs can help at-risk youth.
5: Instead, we’ll focus on the credibility of his statement that "West Virginia is sixth overall in the average number of at-risk youth."
6: There are certainly warning signs about West Virginia’s youth, many of them traceable to the opioid crisis.
7: We have rated as True the statement that West Virginia "has the highest overdose rate per capita of any state in our nation."
8: The drug epidemic is "the driving force in (the) child welfare crisis," the West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources said in a statement in February 2018.
9: The department said that the opioid crisis has made it difficult to help get children back on their feet and is making them more prone to mental-health issues.
10: But how does West Virginia compare nationally?
11: In his tweet, Thrasher linked to a July 18 editorial in the Exponent-Telegram newspaper of Clarksburg.
12: The editorial includes the exact sentence Thrasher quoted, and it says the source is the most recent edition of an annual survey by the website WalletHub.
13: Thrasher’s campaign also confirmed to PolitiFact West Virginia that the WalletHub survey was the source.
14: As Thrasher indicated, the WalletHub report does show West Virginia ranking sixth in at-risk youth, behind Louisiana, the District of Columbia, Mississippi, Arkansas, and Nevada.
15: The website determined the overall rankings by weighting 15 different metrics.
16: They include the population aged 18 to 24 years who are not attending school, not working and have no degree beyond a high school diploma; the labor force participation rate, the poverty rate, and the homelessness rate for the population aged 16 to 24 years; the rate of teen pregnancy; the percentage of those under age 21 who are detained in residential facilities in the criminal justice system; and the percentage of youth who are overweight, who use drugs, who have alcohol problems, or who have clinical depression.
17: We reached out to several of the academic advisers to the WalletHub study.
18: The only one to answer us was Rigaud Joseph, an assistant professor of social work at California State University San Bernardino.
19: However, Joseph said that he "did not have any statistical input in the study.
20: WalletHub decided on the criteria for the rankings."
21: So we turned to independent experts, who said that WalletHub’s study was credible.
22: "The WalletHub methodology seems fine and it generates a credible ranking of states," said Gary Natriello, a professor of educational research, sociology, and education at Teachers College, Columbia University.
23: "Other rankings would be possible if different combinations of indicators were used, but West Virginia would likely be among the states with the most at-risk youth, as Thrasher’s statement suggests."

gpt4: The claim that West Virginia is sixth overall in the average number of at-risk youth is true as per the evidence available.
As cited by Thrasher, who quoted directly from an editorial, the source of this claim is WalletHub's most recent annual survey[12].

This ranking is substantiated by the WalletHub report, which indeed places West Virginia in the sixth position of states with the highest number of at-risk youth, behind Louisiana, the District of Columbia, Mississippi, Arkansas, and Nevada[14].
The reliability of the data from WalletHub was attested independently.

Notably, Gary Natriello, a professor of educational research, sociology, and education at Teachers College, Columbia University, commented on the website's methodology, stating that it was sound and produced credible rankings[22].
This assessment of credibility was also supported by other independent experts who reviewed WalletHub’s study[21].

a7d5fd421f14d1306596ef9d7ff02586.claim: “Pete Buttigieg claims Bible says babies can be aborted ‘up to their first breath.’”
a7d5fd421f14d1306596ef9d7ff02586.label: false
a7d5fd421f14d1306596ef9d7ff02586.passage:
0: We’ve previously debunked claims that New York laws make it "perfectly legal to murder" a baby a minute before it would be born.
1: A Sept. 6 post on LifeNews.com strikes a similar note with a story bearing this headline about a Democratic presidential candidate: "Pete Buttigieg claims Bible says babies can be aborted up to their first breath."
2: This story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The LifeNews.com story, which originated on The Daily Caller under a different headline, cites a Sept. 6 interview Buttigieg did on "The Breakfast Club," a syndicated radio show out of New York.
5: The story links to a video of the interview, starting about 35 minutes into the 48-minute conversation.
6: Buttigieg, former mayor of South Bend, Ind., talks about how the current Republican Party conflicts with Christian values like helping those in need, and how there will be "a reckoning" over it.
7: Then he says: "Right now they hold everyone one in line with this one kinda piece of doctrine about abortion, right, which is obviously a tough issue for a lot of people to think through morally.
8: Then again, there’s a lot of parts of the Bible that talk about how life begins with breath, and so even that is something that we can interpret differently."
9: The host interjects and says, "I’m pro-choice."
10: Buttigieg replies, "Me too.
11: But I think no matter where you think about the kind of cosmic question of how life begins, most Americans can get on the board with the idea, of I might draw the line here, you might draw the line there, but the most important thing is the person who should be drawing the line is the woman making the decision."

gpt4: The claim that Pete Buttigieg stated the Bible allows for babies to be aborted up until their first breath is not entirely accurate.
What he actually stated was that there are parts in the Bible which postulate that life begins with breath, and this interpretation may vary among individuals[8].
He further proposed that the decision-making power about when life begins should ultimately lie with the woman involved [11].
Therefore, the assertion that he asserted the Bible advocates abortion up until the first breath is misleading and false.

74e77afea6ec8023cdd7bd53a3e1a6c3.claim: "  U.S. Rep. Sean Casten has held numerous ""invite-only"" town halls."
74e77afea6ec8023cdd7bd53a3e1a6c3.label: false
74e77afea6ec8023cdd7bd53a3e1a6c3.passage:
0: Before Republican Jeanne Ives can challenge freshman Democrat Rep. Sean Casten for his 6th District Congressional seat, she has to win her party’s primary in March.
1: But that hasn’t stopped Ives from focusing her attacks squarely on Casten, who flipped the once ruby-red west suburban district blue in 2018.
2: Ives, a former state lawmaker from Wheaton, Ill., made a name for herself the same year by nearly defeating then-incumbent Republican Gov.
3: Bruce Rauner in the GOP primary.
4: Several months ago, when Rauner’s former lieutenant governor was also vying for the chance to oust Casten, Ives claimed her conservative opponent had not denounced a controversial bill that expanded public funding for abortions.
5: We rated that False .
6: Now, Ives is making a baseless claim about her Democratic foe.
7: "His numerous (invite-only) town halls don't make up for a failure to take action to save jobs & protect independent biz," Ives wrote in a tweet about Casten.
8: The press release attached to that tweet repeated that claim, and included a link to another one she published in October, which explained what she meant.
9: "Rep. Sean Casten announced a series of town halls that are invite only.
10: Tickets required," that release stated.
11: But it linked to a public eventbrite page advertising a series of town halls Casten held on Oct. 5 to which anyone could book a ticket for free by providing a name and email.
12: So we reached out to Ives’ campaign to find out whether the congressional hopeful had any evidence showing only those who received some kind of invitation to Casten’s town halls were allowed to attend.
13: Neither she nor her staff responded to our repeated calls and emails.
14: We also contacted Casten’s team to learn more about how people can participate in the congressman’s town halls.
15: Spokeswoman Chloe Hunt said they use the online sign-up as a way to track attendance.
16: "It’s all first come, first served, it’s all posted online," she said.
17: "There’s no additional vetting.
18: It’s literally just if you sign up."
19: Even those who don’t sign up can still attend if there is enough space, Hunt added.
20: Getting a ticket simply reserves their spot at the events, which are advertised online ahead of time.
21: Casten posted on Facebook and tweeted about the series of town halls Ives focused on several days before the events took place, inviting readers to RSVP at the same eventbrite link.
22: His office also sent out an email the day before to his subscriber list.
23: All told, Casten has held 20 town halls this year, according to Hunt.
24: They are live-streamed on Facebook so those who can’t make it can follow along virtually.
25: What’s more, it’s clear participants with views different from Casten’s were able to attend his October events.
26: A report from Politico on Casten’s town hall marathon describes several heated exchanges between the congressman and constituents.
27: In one, he was taken to task for labeling Trump’s immigration policies "racist."
28: In another he was pressed to "push back" against progressive House Democrats, including New York’s Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Minnesota’s Ilhan Omar, whom the speaker referred to as "crazies."

gpt4: The claim that U.S. Rep. Sean Casten has held numerous "invite-only" town halls is false.
Despite assertions that these town halls were exclusive [7], they were, in fact, open to the public.
Details about the town halls were posted online, with a simple first come, first served policy in place [16].
Access to these events was publicized through a link to an Eventbrite page where anyone could book a free ticket by providing a name and email [11].
Furthermore, Casten promoted these town halls on his social media platforms, encouraging followers to RSVP using the same Eventbrite link [21].
Even if individuals did not sign up in advance, they could still attend the town halls if there was enough space [19].
The only requirement was that attendees had tickets [10].
This shows that the town halls were not "invite-only", debunking the initial claim.

a899b9ae472bac323f68253b02027172.claim: In Bakersfield, where there’s a lot of oil drilling going on, there’s more solar jobs now in Bakersfield and around that area than there are oil jobs.
