a899b9ae472bac323f68253b02027172.label: false
a899b9ae472bac323f68253b02027172.passage:
0: Former California Gov.
1: Arnold Schwarzenegger likes to boast about his home state’s move to clean energy sources such as wind and solar.
2: But on Sunday’s Meet the Press on NBC, the GOP politician and climate activist may have gone too far.
3: Schwarzenegger was on the show promoting World War Zero, a coalition of scientists, politicians and celebrities hoping to bring greater urgency to climate change, ahead of the 2019 United Nations Climate Change Conference.
4: He said California’s embrace of renewables is evident even in Bakersfield, a city of 380,000 better known for oil derricks and country music than solar arrays and wind turbines.
5: "I just want to tell you that, for instance, in California, in Bakersfield, where there’s a lot of oil drilling going on, there’s more solar jobs now in Bakersfield and around that area than there are oil jobs," Schwarzenegger claimed.
6: "People are leaving the oil fields and going to work in solar and clean energy and stuff like that."
7: More solar jobs than oil jobs in the Bakersfield area?
8: We drilled down on a fact check.
9: Our research Our reporting, along with a fact check by Bakersfield NBC TV affiliate KGET, calls Schwarzenegger’s specific claim into question.
10: But it also shows renewable energy jobs are growing in the region.
11: Asked about the claim solar jobs have overtaken oil positions, Kern County spokesperson Megan Person told the station "we know that not to be true."
12: She said the county is home to approximately 2,500 solar jobs, most of which are temporary and tied to construction and installation.
13: By comparison, it has about 14,000 jobs directly connected to the oil and gas industry, most of which Person said are permanent oil jobs.
14: She said the figures come from private service JobsEQ.
15: It’s the same amount listed in a 2017 Oil and Gas in California report by the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation.
16: Bakersfield is the largest city in Kern County, located south of Fresno and north of Los Angeles.
17: The region, like much of the state, has seen a jump in renewables, but not to a level matching traditional energy jobs.
18: "Kern County is seeing a rise in solar installations, and I don’t mean just residential.
19: I mean giant commercial projects," Person said, citing a new solar field that will generate 850 solar construction jobs.
20: "It could be confusion related to that," she continued.
21: "I don’t know where [Schwarzenegger’s] numbers came from.
22: We can’t substantiate them."
23: 'It was a mistake' The former governor’s spokesperson, Daniel Ketchell, told PolitiFact California that Schwarzenegger "meant to say new jobs.
24: What he said was not meant to mislead.
25: It was a mistake."
26: Ketchell clarified that he intended to say the San Joaquin Valley has gained more new clean energy jobs than oil jobs.
27: There’s some evidence for that, but it’s a far different claim than what the governor said on TV.
28: The Valley includes a much bigger area, running from Stockton to Bakersfield, and clean energy goes beyond just solar.
29: "Yes, it’s on the rise," Carol Zabin , director of the Green Economy Program at the UC Berkeley Labor Center, said of solar and other clean energy sources.
30: "The big solar farms are located in various parts of the state.
31: But there’s a concentration in the San Joaquin Valley."
32: Zabin said the Center does not have figures comparing solar and oil jobs in the Bakersfield area.
33: But in a 2017 study , it reported that California’s clean energy initiatives "created 88,000 total jobs, including 31,000 direct jobs" in the San Joaquin Valley from 2002 to 2015.
34: She added that automation has led to a decrease in some oil and gas jobs in the Valley, though she noted demand for fossil fuels continues to be strong.

gpt4: The claim that there are more solar jobs than oil jobs in Bakersfield, originally made by Arnold Schwarzenegger, has been found to be untrue[5].
This assertion was directly disputed by Kern County spokesperson Megan Person, who stated that reports suggesting that solar jobs have overtaken oil positions were inaccurate[11].

In fact, Kern County has about 14,000 jobs directly related to the oil and gas industry, most of which are permanent oil positions, providing further evidence that oil jobs still outnumber solar jobs in the region[13].

cb4ff849e21f0d3227d4068c7d3e4989.claim: "  Donald Trump tweeted, ""Danny DeVito supports baby murder."""
cb4ff849e21f0d3227d4068c7d3e4989.label: false
cb4ff849e21f0d3227d4068c7d3e4989.passage:
0: On the campaign trail, President Donald Trump pledged to defund Planned Parenthood because, he said, "of the abortion factor."
1: A Nov. 25 Facebook post appears to show him attacking actor Danny DeVito, who is pictured with actor Mark Ruffalo wearing T-shirts that say "I stand with Planned Parenthood."
2: Above the image is what appears to be a Donald Trump tweet saying: "Danny DeVito supports baby murder."
3: In response, it appears Mark Rufaflo replied: "What about me asshole?"
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: That’s because on Nov. 17, conservative Carmine Sabia actually tweeted "Danny DeVito supports baby murder" above the photo of DeVito and Ruffalo.
7: Searching for "Danny DeVito supports baby murder" online, we couldn’t find any instances of Trump tweeting or saying that.
8: We didn’t unearth it searching Trump’s Twitter account, either.
9: And such an online skirmish would certainly draw media attention, but looking in the Nexis news archives for stories about "Danny DeVito" and "Donald Trump" and "baby murder," we found none.

gpt4: The claim that Donald Trump once tweeted "Danny DeVito supports baby murder" is false.
Extensive online searches for this specific phrase yielded no results, implying that no such statement was made by Trump on this platform [7].

Additionally, despite the fact that such a provocative statement would inevitably attract significant media attention, there are no records in the Nexis news archives linking "Danny DeVito", "Donald Trump", and "baby murder" together[9].
Even a direct search within Trump’s Twitter account did not reveal any such tweet [8].
Therefore, the evidence available clearly contradicts the claim, making it baseless and false.

e946162b7bdef008ac4738b7da3c8444.claim: "  Elizabeth Warren tweeted, ""Looks like I’m the last woman of color left in this race."""
e946162b7bdef008ac4738b7da3c8444.label: false
e946162b7bdef008ac4738b7da3c8444.passage:
0: After Sen. Kamala Harris dropped out of the presidential race on Dec. 3, Sen. Cory Booker and former Housing Secretary Julián Castro pointed out that the California lawmaker was the only nonwhite candidate to qualify for the next presidential debate.
1: Online, people started criticizing the Democratic National Committee using hashtags like #DemsSoWhite and #DebateSoWhite.
2: Enter this Facebook post , that appears to show a tweet from presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.
3: "Looks like I’m the last woman of color left in this race," the tweet says, seemingly nodding to her earlier and controversial claims of Native American ancestry .
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: That’s because it’s not real, and while some Facebook users realized that right away, others weren’t so sure.
7: "Get off your high horse built of lies," one woman wrote.
8: Warren has two verified Twitter accounts.
9: One is her official Senate account, @SenWarren , and one is her official campaign account, @ewarren .
10: The Dec. 3 tweet that appeared on the Facebook post has Elizabeth Warren’s name and the same photo as her campaign Twitter account, but the handle is @EWarenn.
11: If you go to that Twitter account , the name reads: "Elizabeth Warren (fake)."
12: The bio says: "Bernie-lite candidate, I have a plan for that!
13: (Parody)."
14: The tweet that appears in the Facebook post is also here , and people have retweeted it about 3,700 times.
15: Back in December 2018, Warren said in a speech to a group of largely black students: "I’m not a person of color.
16: And I haven’t lived your life or experienced anything like the subtle prejudice, or more overt harm, that you may have experienced just because of the color of your skin."

gpt4: The claim that Senator Elizabeth Warren, a former presidential candidate, tweeted "Looks like I'm the last woman of color left in this race" is false.
The origin of this false statement can be traced back to a Facebook post showing a supposed tweet from Warren [2].

The featured tweet, dated December 3, appeared to be from Warren due to the use of her name and campaign photo; however, the handle shown in the post was @EWarenn, not Warren's verified Twitter handle [10].
This is an indication that the original tweet is a parody [13].
Despite the clarity of the irregularities, some Facebook users still fell for the misinformation [6].

ab0dbc5a18f680badf21470dd8887d37.claim: former Democratic Sen. Harry Reid has an outlaw horse thief ancestor and Reid’s office offered a spin-job biography about the man.
ab0dbc5a18f680badf21470dd8887d37.label: false
ab0dbc5a18f680badf21470dd8887d37.passage:
0: A wild tale about a horse thief ancestor of former Democratic Sen. Harry Reid continues to spread online despite being debunked for several years The online story has been circulating since at least 2000 , targeting not only Reid but several political figures.
1: Other versions have featured the surnames of President Donald Trump, former President George W. Bush, Hillary Clinton and Al Gore, among others.
2: A Reid version was posted to Facebook in 2013 and is being re-shared recently.
3: The post claims a genealogy researcher named Judy Wallman was working on her family tree when she found that the former senator from Nevada has a great-great uncle, Remus Reid, who was "hanged for horse stealing and train robbery in Montana in 1889," and whom Wallman also shared as an ancestor.
4: The post displays a black-and-white photograph that is supposedly Remus Reid standing on a platform as a noose is tightened around his neck.
5: It isn’t him.
6: The image actually depicts outlaw Tom "Black Jack" Ketchum, who was hanged in New Mexico in 1901 for attempted train robbery, among other crimes.
7: All versions of this claim end with the politician’s office — in this case, Harry Reid’s office — issuing a statement to Wallman that attempts to spin the life-story of the supposedly criminal "great-great uncle" into something more legitimate, calling the ancestor a "famous cowboy," who "passed away during an important civic function held in his honor when the platform upon which he was standing collapsed."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: With good reason: The entire account is fabricated.
11: Harry Reid is simply one of many political figures to be implicated in this bogus ancestry spin job.

gpt4: The claim that former Democratic Sen. Harry Reid has an outlaw horse thief ancestor and Reid's office provided a misleading biography about the man is inaccurate.

The man in the circulated image, often misrepresented as Reid's ancestor, is actually outlaw Tom "Black Jack" Ketchum, a figure known for his involvement in a variety of crimes, including attempted train robbery, who was executed in New Mexico in 1901[6].
The assertion is part of a series of false narratives that have been circulated concerning various political figures.

Earlier versions of this falsehood have involved using the surnames of several political personalities, ranging from President Donald Trump and former President George W. Bush to Hillary Clinton and Al Gore, among others[1].
Therefore, it is not Reid's ancestor depicted in the image nor is there any verified information to substantiate the supposed connection[5].

131944e8d7923934901e00d17284c401.claim: "  the Clinton Foundation ""gave ONLY $5 million to charities, spent $85 million for their salaries & travels and KEPT the rest = $87 million"" in 2014."
131944e8d7923934901e00d17284c401.label: false
131944e8d7923934901e00d17284c401.passage:
0: It’s not 2016 anymore.
1: But on Facebook, misinformation is still targeting Hillary Clinton and her family’s charitable foundation.
2: One post published in the form of an image on Nov. 18 claims most of the money the foundation brings in doesn’t actually go to charity.
3: "They took in $177 million in so-called ‘donations,’ gave ONLY $5 million to charities, spent $85 million for their salaries & travels and KEPT the rest = $87 million," the post reads.
4: The image, which has been shared thousands of times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A popular Facebook image claims the Clinton Foundation only gave $5 million to charity in 2014.
7: We rate it False.
8: (Screenshot from Facebook) This isn’t the first time we’ve seen a claim about the Clinton Foundation’s charitable giving.
9: In 2015, we fact-checked a similar statement from conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh.
10: "Eighty-five percent of every dollar donated to the Clinton Foundation ended up either with the Clintons or with their staff to pay for travel, salaries, and benefits," he said during his show.
11: "Fifteen cents of every dollar actually went to some charitable beneficiary."
12: We rated that claim Mostly False .
13: In 2016, we rated a similar claim False from Reince Priebus.
14: This case is similarly inaccurate.
15: How the Clinton Foundation works The Facebook post’s claim is built on the assumption that the primary charitable contributions made by the Clinton Foundation are grants.
16: But that’s not the case.
17: Instead of giving all of its money away, the philanthropy keeps its money in-house and hires people to carry out its own humanitarian programs.
18: That means the Clinton Foundation’s finances get complicated.
19: "Although it has ‘foundation’ in its name, the Clinton Foundation is actually a public charity," wrote Brian Mittendorf, a professor of accounting at Ohio State University’s Fisher College of Business, in the Chronicle of Philanthropy in 2015.
20: "In practical terms, this means both that it relies heavily on donations from the public and that it achieves its mission primarily by using those donations to conduct direct charitable activities, as opposed to providing grants from an endowment."
21: What kinds of projects does the foundation work on?
22: The Clinton Development Initiative has helped farmers in Malawi grow and sell more crops and assisted coffee farmers in Haiti .
23: The Clinton Giustra Enterprise Partnership has helped to provide job training for people in Cartagena, Colombia.
24: "While measuring charitable endeavors by the amount of grants awarded may be appropriate for many private foundations, it is not for an organization that acts as a direct service provider like the Clinton Foundation," Mittendorf wrote.
25: Where the foundation’s money goes The Facebook post took the Clinton Foundation’s tax filings out of context to paint an inaccurate picture of how it spends its money.
26: We looked at both the Clinton Foundation’s 990 tax form and audited financials from 2014.
27: Mittendorf said the latter is a more complete measure of the organization’s finances, as it includes all entities related to the foundation, such as the Clinton Health Access Initiative.
28: Upon first inspection, the numbers in the 990 form look like they affirm the Facebook post.
29: But there’s more to these figures than meets the eye.
30: RELATED: No, Russia did not donate $145 million to the Clinton Foundation First, $177 million is the total revenue for the Clinton Foundation — which includes money from program services and investments, not just donations, as the Facebook post claims.
31: And the group’s 2014 audited financial report puts the group and its related affiliates’ revenue closer to $242 million.
32: Second, the post inflated the importance of the $5 million the Clinton Foundation spent on grants.
33: Since most of the foundation’s work is done in-house, all of its charitable expenses aren’t classified as grants on tax forms.
34: Charity Navigator, a nonprofit organization that evaluates charities, reported that 86.6% of the Clinton Foundation’s expenses go toward program expenses.
35: The foundation’s audited financials show that it spent $217 million on programs in 2014.
36: And 10.7% of the Clinton Foundation’s money goes toward administrative expenses, according to Charity Navigator.
37: That proportion actually distinguishes the foundation from most other organizations.
38: Third, the Clinton Foundation did not spend $85 million "for their salaries and travel," as the Facebook post claims.
39: The foundation’s audited financials show that it spent about $20 million on travel and $95 million on salaries and benefits in 2014.
40: But not all the money allocated for salaries and travel in 2014 went to the group’s employees — the bulk of it went to program services.
41: About $13 million fell under the "management/general" category.
42: The Clintons themselves did not receive compensation from the foundation in 2014, according to the foundation’s 990 form.

gpt4: The claim that the Clinton Foundation spent only $5 million on charities and $85 million on salaries and travels while retaining $87 million in 2014 has been proven false.
The contention appears to be based on the misguided presumption that the Foundation's main form of philanthropy is through grants[15], which is not actually the case[16][20].

It's essential to understand that unlike many private foundations, the Clinton Foundation functions primarily as a direct service provider, hence the amount awarded in grants is not the sole indicator of its charitable endeavours[24].
Examining the foundation’s audited financials and 990 tax form from 2014[26], it is evident the Foundation did not allocate $85 million towards salaries and travel.
Instead, approximately $20 million was expended on travel and $95 million on salaries and benefits[39].
Notably, the Clintons themselves were not compensated in 2014[42].
Additionally, the significance of the $5 million spent on grants by the Foundation was ironically inflated[32].
Lastly, it's important to highlight, as reported by Charity Navigator, that 86.6% of the Clinton Foundation's expenses were directed towards program expenses[34].

226750b98fc6a51c3f77c095408288f5.claim: Ilhan Omar just hosted a flag burning party.
226750b98fc6a51c3f77c095408288f5.label: false
226750b98fc6a51c3f77c095408288f5.passage:
0: A satirical story claiming U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar hosted a flag burning party is being reshared on Facebook without labeling to let readers know it’s not actually real.
1: "Ilhan Omar just hosted a flag burning party," reads the headline of the Dec. 8 post on a website called Dayz Report Daily News that describes itself as providing "latest news."
2: It was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The story originated on Bustatroll.com , where it was tagged with labels like "conservative fan fiction" and "satire for Islamaphobes."
5: "Saturday night at Ilhan’s!"
6: reads a description of the invitation in the fake news story about the Minnesota Democrat.
7: "Bring your flags and throw them into the bonfire!
8: Burgers, shawarma, and tea for all!"

gpt4: The claim that U.S. Representative Ilhan Omar hosted a flag burning party is false.
This rumor originated from a satirical piece on a site called Bustatroll.com, which categorizes such stories under labels such as "conservative fan fiction" and "satire for Islamaphobes"[4].
However, the story has been dispersed widely on Facebook without any of these categorizations, misleading readers into considering it as real news[0].

d60a52137ddb86ba506e367f62498bfd.claim: the NAACP endorsed Donald Trump in the 2020 election.
d60a52137ddb86ba506e367f62498bfd.label: false
d60a52137ddb86ba506e367f62498bfd.passage:
0: Two stories posted on Facebook Dec. 7 claim that the NAACP has endorsed President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential race.
1: But the articles were lifted from a satirical news website and republished without the caveat that this isn’t real news.
2: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Daily World News, where the story originated , describes itself as "satire for Flat Earthers, Trumpsters and Y’all Qaeda."
5: It’s also tagged "conservative fan fiction" and "satire."
6: But on this Wordpress site called "Today Breaking News," the Daily World News story is stripped of that context.
7: Same goes for this site called "Daily News Updates."
8: The NAACP hasn’t yet endorsed a 2020 candidate, but on Dec. 5 it published this story on its website: "NAACP applauds call for articles of impeachment against Donald Trump."

gpt4: The claim that the NAACP endorsed Donald Trump in the 2020 election is false.
The miscommunication originates from an article on Daily World News, which is actually a satirical news website known for creating news content "for Flat Earthers, Trumpsters and Y'all Qaeda"[4].
The error was further disseminated when this content was lifted and republished without the clear indication that it is not real news[1].
This happened despite the fact that, as of December 5, the NAACP hadn't endorsed any candidate for the 2020 election[8].

2f0aad89405e0e696cb6f4c0f93073e5.claim: "  Adam Schiff is ""under investigation for Ukrainian Burisma oil connections."""
2f0aad89405e0e696cb6f4c0f93073e5.label: false
2f0aad89405e0e696cb6f4c0f93073e5.passage:
0: One America News, a pro-Trump cable news upstart, posted a story with a powerful headline.
1: "Adam Schiff Under Investigation for Ukrainian Burisma Oil Connections," it said Nov. 30 .
2: It would be a twist if Schiff himself were under investigation for his ties to Burisma.
3: But One America News’ report is rife with factual errors and misleading innuendo.
4: Schiff, D-Calif, spearheaded the House Intelligence Committee investigation into President Donald Trump’s July 25 phone call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which Trump asked Zelensky to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden.
5: When his father was vice president, Hunter Biden took a lucrative post on the board of the Ukrainian energy company Burisma.
6: One America makes a claim that Schiff has received campaign donations from companies tied to Burisma.
7: "New evidence appears to show that Schiff has received donations from two U.S. corporations tied to the $7.4 billion corruption scandal involving Ukrainian gas giant Burisma," One America News reported .
8: "A report from Gateway Pundit shows Schiff has received numerous donations from both Blackrock and Franklin Templeton Investments.
9: Both of which are now part of a criminal investigation for laundering money through Burisma."
10: One America News seems to have confused donations with investment earnings.
11: Campaign finance records show neither of the two investment companies mentioned — Blackrock and Franklin Templeton — made any campaign donations to Schiff.
12: On his 2017 financial disclosure form , Schiff showed dividends, capital gains and interest earned on seven funds managed by the Blackrock and Franklin Templeton firms, out of a total of 38 investments.
13: So, there’s a "connection," but not the sort that the One America News report described.
14: Note that by 2017, Schiff had sold his Blackrock holdings.
15: As for Franklin Templeton, the firm offers a wide variety of funds, and more Republicans (22) held Franklin Templeton funds than did Democrats (18).
16: The claim about an underlying "criminal investigation for laundering money" comes from an article on the Ukrainian news website Interfax Ukraine.
17: At a news conference, two members of parliament called for an investigation into the alleged diversion of $7.4 billion by deposed former president Viktor Yanukovych.
18: They said, according to "investigative journalists," Ukraine’s prosecutor general has "suspicions" of money laundering.
19: The Ukrainian lawmakers mentioned Burisma and the two fund management firms, but offered no clear connection between Burisma and the other two companies.
20: The pair cited no official materials from the Prosecutor General’s office.
21: They said nothing about Schiff.
22: Many conservative websites have been carrying this story, and, from what we see, the connection to Schiff stems solely from his holdings managed by the two fund management firms.

gpt4: The claim that Adam Schiff is "under investigation for Ukrainian Burisma oil connections" is false.
While there has been a report by One America News suggesting a connection, the report was found to be full of factual errors and misleading innuendo [3].
Additionally, the perceived "connection" does not reflect the manner in which One America News describes it [13].

Moreover, campaign finance records revealed that neither BlackRock nor Franklin Templeton made any campaign donations to Schiff, contradicting any allegations about financial contributions impacting Schiff's involved with these Ukrainian matters [11].
Lastly, it is important to note that none of the mentioned companies has expressed any comments about Schiff [21].

aeb0837ba5d33f89e52c8dbdb868b14c.claim: a photo shows Adam Schiff and Jeffrey Epstein.
aeb0837ba5d33f89e52c8dbdb868b14c.label: false
aeb0837ba5d33f89e52c8dbdb868b14c.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff has drawn conservative fire for his role in the impeachment hearings, and a recent Facebook post attempts to tie the California Democrat to the late Jeffrey Epstein, the financier accused of sexually assaulting underage girls .
1: In a photo published on Facebook on Nov. 24, Schiff appears to be sitting cozily on a couch with Epstein.
2: "Apparently they were buddies," the poster wrote.
3: "Which one is (was) the most sleazy?"
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: That’s because the image is doctored — and this isn’t the first to feature Epstein edited into a photo.
7: Earlier this year we debunked a post that claimed to show Epstein smirking while President Donald Trump inappropriately touched a young girl.
8: The original image in this most recent Facebook post shows Schiff sitting with his father, not Epstein.
9: He tweeted the picture on Nov. 22, 2018, saying: "Eve and I are spending a wonderful Thanksgiving with my 90 year old Dad, Ed, and cousins Karen and Julia.
10: Alexa is away for her studies and Eli is our photographer!
11: Wishing you and your family a Happy Thanksgiving!"
12: The image that appears on Facebook also appears manipulated to make it look like a sex toy is resting on a table by the couch.
13: It isn’t in the original image.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows Adam Schiff and Jeffrey Epstein is false.
The original image that emerges in the recent Facebook post actually shows Adam Schiff with his father, not Epstein[8].
On top of this, the post was flagged as part of Facebook's measures to eliminate false news and misinformation on its News Feed[4].
Further establishment of its unreliability comes from the fact that the image turns out to be a doctored one, a practice previously identified involving Epstein being edited into photos[6].

b216a595c62406069541d4d92e562299.claim: Will Smith and his son Jaden Smith died in a car crash.
b216a595c62406069541d4d92e562299.label: false
b216a595c62406069541d4d92e562299.passage:
0: A fake death story about actor Will Smith and his rapper son Jaden Smith is circulating on Facebook.
1: The post surfaced in early December 2019 and displays a photograph of a mangled vehicle, a photo of the father and son with "RIP" above their names, and claims the two died in a crash "after truck and their car collide.
2: [sic]" See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com This is a hoax.
3: Will Smith and his son were not killed, injured or involved in a car crash.
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: Clicking on the post leads social media users to a junk website that features a fake video using the CNN logo that allegedly announces the "breaking news."
7: The webpage says the video has been viewed more than 1.6 million times.
8: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com This is an attempt to bait people into sharing a celebrity hoax on their Facebook pages and to click on the video as a way to redirect them to other websites where they are subjected to pop-up ads.
9: It’s strongly advised not to try and play the video or click on any of the ads.

gpt4: The claim that Will Smith and his son, Jaden Smith, died in a car crash is false.
A fabricated death story was circulated on Facebook involving the two celebrities but it was established that they were not killed, injured, or involved in a car crash[0][3].

This erroneous news was an attempt to draw users into sharing a celebrity hoax on their Facebook pages and enticing them to click on a video that redirected them to other websites filled with pop-up advertisements [8].
Furthermore, if one clicked on the deception, it would navigate the user to a junk website featuring a phony video, falsely using the CNN logo, purporting to announce the "breaking news"[6].

af9364c977f77e4401abf3d95e2c3801.claim: We have the lowest corporate tax rate since 1968.
af9364c977f77e4401abf3d95e2c3801.label: true
af9364c977f77e4401abf3d95e2c3801.passage:
0: In Gov.
1: Andrew Cuomo’s 10th State of the State address last week, he claimed that under his administration, "We have the lowest corporate tax rate since 1968."
2: New York’s business climate has for years been the subject of criticism from business groups and conservative lawmakers, so we wondered about this claim.
3: We approached Cuomo’s office, where spokesman Jason Conwall provided us with historical tax data.
4: The Department of Taxation and Finance maintains this data, and a table titled "History of Corporate Tax Rates in New York State, 1917-2009," shows that between 1968 and 1970, the corporate tax rate, also known as the corporation franchise tax, was 7 percent.
5: The rate did not fall below 7 percent in later years, and in the final year, 2009, the rate was 7.1 percent.
6: Since 2009, the rate changed once, when it was lowered to 6.5 percent, Conwall said.
7: The 6.5 percent rate took effect on Jan. 1, 2016 .
8: Historically, New York has had separate rates for banks and insurance companies.
9: The bank tax was merged into the corporate tax system in 2015.
10: We reached out to observers of the state’s tax policies for context and to check for any conflicting data.
11: The Tax Foundation, a national organization, studies federal and state tax policy and advocated for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act supported by President Trump and congressional Republicans.
12: The Tax Foundation confirmed Cuomo’s claim.
13: "New York saw remarkable improvement in both its corporate rate - bringing it down to 6.5 percent - and structure - cutting four corporate bases down to three - through tax reform in 2014," said policy analyst Janelle Cammenga.
14: The Tax Foundation advocates for simpler tax codes, and Cammenga noted that New York’s complex individual income tax code affects so-called pass-through businesses, such as partnerships, sole-proprietorships, and limited liability companies.
15: E.J.
16: McMahon, founder and research director at the conservative Empire Center, also confirmed Cuomo’s claim.
17: McMahon added that in the 12-county region in downstate New York served by the Metropolitan Transit Authority, a surcharge brings the tax rate to 8.34 percent there.
18: But even with the surcharge, it’s still the lowest rate since 1970, McMahon said.
19: At the left-leaning Fiscal Policy Institute, executive director Ron Deutsch confirmed Cuomo’s claim.
20: Dave Friedfel, director of state studies at the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan research and advocacy organization in Albany and New York City, said that readers should be aware that companies in New York pay more than just the corporate franchise tax.
21: In addition to the MTA surcharge, set by the state , New York City imposes a 8.85 percent corporate franchise tax.
22: "Overall, it’s good that New York State’s corporate franchise tax rates are lower than they were and are competitive nationwide , but it’s just a small part of the taxes paid by businesses in New York," Friedfel said.

gpt4: In his 10th State of the State address, Governor Andrew Cuomo stated that under his administration, New York has the lowest corporate tax rate since 1968, which is, based on the historical data, to be true[1].
The Department of Taxation and Finance, which records this data, shows that the corporate tax rate, also known as the corporation franchise tax, was 7 percent between 1968 and 1970[4].
From the available data, the rate only changed once post-2009, when it was reduced to 6.5 percent[6], a rate which took effect from January 1, 2016, and remains unchanged[7].

Cuomo's claim has been verified as accurate by various sources, including the Tax Foundation[12], the conservative Empire Center led by founder and research director McMahon[16], and the left-leaning Fiscal Policy Institute led by executive director Ron Deutsch[19].

51f07ffd318edcddfa2f7fb6103c14da.claim: Jeff Foxworthy wrote a list of examples explaining how ""you might live in a nation that was founded by geniuses but is run by idiots."""
51f07ffd318edcddfa2f7fb6103c14da.label: false
51f07ffd318edcddfa2f7fb6103c14da.passage:
0: "If you can get arrested for hunting or fishing without a license, but not for entering and remaining in the country illegally — you might live in a country that was founded by geniuses but is run by idiots."
1: That’s one of many examples in a list posted to Facebook on Nov. 19 and falsely attributed to comedian Jeff Foxworthy.
2: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Foxworthy is famous for his "You might be a redneck if…" jokes , but searching online we couldn’t find any credible evidence that he penned this list that touches on abortion, Muslims and federal debt.
5: Rather, we found users on web forums crediting someone named Fritz Edmunds with the list.
6: Snopes, which fact-checked this claim back in 2013, also noted that "the original compiler of this appears to be Fritz Edmunds, who posted it to his ‘Politically True’ blog back in Feb. 3, 2013 (albeit with a disclaimer noting that ‘some of the ideas were from an email that did not contain a copyright’)."
7: The link to that post is now dead but the url includes the words "channeling Jeff Foxworthy."

gpt4: The claim that Jeff Foxworthy composed a list of examples explaining how "you might live in a nation that was founded by geniuses but is run by idiots" is false[1].

While Foxworthy is well-known for his "You might be a redneck if…" jokes, no credible evidence was found to suggest that he wrote this particular list that discusses topics such as abortion, Muslims, and federal debt[4].
In investigating this claim on various web platforms, users are more frequently seen accrediting a person named Fritz Edmunds for the list[5].

This was also corroborated by Snopes, a well-respected fact-checking website, which highlighted that Fritz Edmunds seems to be the original compiler of this list, originally sharing it on his 'Politically True' blog back in February 3, 2013[6].

23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.claim: "  President Donald Trump is ""waging a trade war against WI farmers -- forcing > 1600 dairy farms to close."""
23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.label: half-true
23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.passage:
0: It’s a tough time to be the Dairy State.
1: The family farms that long formed the backbone of the state’s milk production are increasingly being forced out of business.
2: And the U.S. agriculture secretary came to town and cast doubt on the future viability of any small dairy farms.
3: U.S. Rep. Mark Pocan , D-Madison, says Wisconsinites should lay the blame at the feet of President Donald Trump.
4: In a Dec. 2, 2019, tweet , Pocan said Trump is "waging a trade war against WI farmers — forcing more than 1600 dairy farms to close."
5: Trade tensions are certainly having an impact, but is it reasonable to blame them — and Trump — for that many closures?
6: Dairy was in trouble long before Trump Pocan’s is roughly correct on the number of closures.
7: Wisconsin had 9,288 dairy farms on Feb. 1, 2017 — about two weeks after Trump was sworn in.
8: By Dec. 1, 2019, that number dropped to 7,337, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture .
9: That’s a loss of 1,951 farms, even more than Pocan referenced.
10: But Wisconsin dairy farms closing is hardly a new trend.
11: The number of milking operations here has plummeted by more than half in the last 15 years, from 15,000 at the end of 2004 to about 7,300 as of December 2019.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com That trend has indeed worsened under Trump, however.
13: In the 34 months since Trump’s election Wisconsin has lost an average of 57 dairy farms per month.
14: In the 34 months before that, the monthly average was 33 farms.
15: Many factors conspire against farmers Pocan blamed the closures not only on Trump, but specifically on the president’s trade wars.
16: Defending the claim, Pocan spokesman Usamah Andrabi pointed to a category of Chinese dairy exports that dropped from mid-2018 to mid-2019 amid retaliatory tariffs.
17: "That being said, I think we can reasonably attribute the majority of these farm closures to the effects of China’s tariffs/Trump’s trade war," Andrabi said.
18: That’s simply not accurate.
19: Pocan’s claim — and his spokesman’s defense — oversimplify an industry facing a complex set of economic pressures.
20: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Low milk prices, historic levels of oversupply and changing consumer demand were dealing devastating blows to dairy farmers long before Trump picked a fight with China.
21: The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel summarized the demand struggles this way as part of its Dairyland in Distress project, an exhaustive examination of the state’s trademark industry.
22: Sales of milk as a beverage have fallen steadily since the 1970s, with fewer parents encouraging their children to drink milk than ever before.
23: Soy milk and almond milk — which dairy farmers point out aren't real milk — and scores of sports drinks have flooded the beverage market.
24: And although consumption of cheese, yogurt and butter have all increased, they've not always kept pace with runaway production.
25: Today, for instance, U.S. commercial and government cheese stockpiles are at about 1 billion pounds — the highest level in a century.
26: At the same time, foreign markets for American dairy products have shrunk in response to tariffs that President Donald Trump placed on foreign steel and aluminum.
27: Cheese shipments to China have fallen almost 65 percent, according to industry figures, and exports to Mexico are down more than 10 percent.
28: So tariffs are a factor in limiting demand, but far from the only one.
29: And supply is a major problem as well.
30: Advances in genetics and feed science mean the average cow today produces about four times more milk than it would have in the 1950s.
31: This leads to a market saturation that both generates waste — some farmers are forced to dump milk down the drain for lack of a buyer — and contributes to reduced prices.
32: Milk prices have nudged up in recent months but before that went through a yearslong downturn that often left prices below the break-even point for farms.
33: "There were four years of the depressed milk prices before the trade war started," Laurie Fischer, CEO of the American Dairy Coalition, told PolitiFact Wisconsin.
34: "If you go back and you look, we've always had attrition going on."

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump's trade war is forcing Wisconsin dairy farms to close is oversimplified, making it only half-true.

While tariffs imposed by Trump have indeed contributed to the decline of foreign markets for American dairy products, resulting in a significant decrease in cheese shipments to China and a 10% decrease in exports to Mexico[26][27], this is not the sole factor for the closure of more than 1600 dairy farms in Wisconsin[4].
The industry has been battling economic pressures, including low milk prices, historic levels of oversupply, and changing consumer demands[19][20].
The four years of depressed milk prices preceding the trade war's inception was particularly devastating[33].
Furthermore, the rate of farm closure had increased to an average of 57 per month since Trump’s election, up from 33 farms per month prior to his presidency[13][14].
Therefore, though the trade war has added challenges for the dairy industry, it is part of a larger set of issues that have led to the closure of these farms.

8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.claim: The Inspector General’s report now makes clear that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions.
8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.label: false
8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.passage:
0: Attorney General William Barr blasted the FBI over its 2016 decision to open the Russia investigation later led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller , rejecting an inspector general’s conclusion that the FBI’s probe was justified from the get-go.
1: "The Inspector General’s report now makes clear that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions that, in my view, were insufficient to justify the steps taken," Barr said in a statement .
2: The report by Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz did find "significant inaccuracies and omissions" left out of the FBI’s applications for court-ordered surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page.
3: But it said the agency’s decision to open an investigation into the campaign’s ties with Russia was warranted and not motivated by politics.
4: Barr’s reading put him at odds with FBI Director Christopher Wray, who pledged to make changes to the FBI’s surveillance process and accepted the report’s determinations in full.
5: Barr doubled down in interviews with NBC News and the Wall Street Journal , calling the basis for the investigation "flimsy" and claiming the FBI spied on the Trump campaign.
6: He said John Durham, the U.S. attorney he picked to lead a separate probe on the same topic, would have the final word on the matter.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We decided to look at some key conclusions from the IG report, which was based on more than 1 million documents and interviews with over 100 witnesses, in light of Barr’s remarks.
8: (A Justice Department spokesperson referred us to the report and Barr’s interviews.)
9: We found that Barr’s claim that the report shows the FBI launched its probe on "the thinnest of suspicions" does not square with one of the report’s key findings.
10: The FBI had "authorized purpose" When the FBI opened its investigation — known as "Crossfire Hurricane" — into possible coordination between members of President Donald Trump’s campaign and Russia, it had both an "authorized purpose" and an "articulable factual basis," the IG report found .
11: The investigation was launched on July 31, 2016, three days after the FBI heard from a "friendly foreign government" that Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos had signaled that Russia had dirt on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for the Trump campaign.
12: The IG report said this information alone was enough to trigger the Russia probe, because it gave the FBI reason to believe a crime or threat to U.S. national security was in the works.
13: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The report also discounted the role of a dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele, saying it "played no role" in the FBI’s decision.
14: (Trump has falsely claimed the dossier started the investigation.)
15: Rosa Brooks, professor of law and policy at Georgetown University, told us that Barr’s assessment that the suspicions were thin "appears willfully inaccurate."
16: "The report concluded precisely the opposite," she said.
17: "The IG report makes it clear that the decision to launch the investigation was justified."
18: Jennifer Daskal, professor of law at American University, agreed.
19: "Barr’s statement is at best a misleading statement, if not a deliberate distortion, of what the report actually found," she said.
20: The investigation was not politically motivated The IG report also dismissed the notion that the investigation was politically motivated.
21: For years, Trump has ripped into former FBI officials Peter Strzok and Lisa Page for anti-Trump texts that he saw as proof that career government officials were out to get him.
22: But the report concluded that Page and Strzok were not the decision makers Trump made them out to be.
23: According to the report , Lisa Page "did not play a role in the decision" to open the investigation or the related individual cases tied to Papadopoulos, Carter Page and fellow Trump campaign advisers Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn.
24: Strzok was "directly involved," but "he was not the sole, or even the highest-level, decision maker as to any of those matters," the report found.
25: The final say on whether to launch the investigation belonged to Bill Priestap, assistant director of the FBI’s counterintelligence division, who complied with DOJ and FBI policies and made the decision with widespread support from FBI officials.
26: "We did not find documentary or testimonial evidence that political bias or improper motivation influenced his decision," the IG report said .
27: The FBI’s applications to surveil Carter Page left out information Where Barr has a point is on the issue of intrusiveness.
28: To determine which campaign officials had Russian connections, the FBI used various methods listed among its "least intrusive" measures, such as open-source searches, the report said .
29: That led the agency to open four individual cases against Page, Papadopoulos, Manafort and Flynn.
30: The FBI then used confidential human sources — a "permitted" but more intrusive technique — to "interact and consensually record conversations" with Papadopoulous and Page.
31: The IG report found no evidence that this technique was politically motivated or done in bad faith.
32: Eventually, the FBI secured and repeatedly renewed a court-ordered FISA warrant to electronically surveil Page.
33: The IG report said this technique is considered "highly intrusive" and said the FBI did not seek similar warrants to monitor Papadopoulous, Manafort or Flynn.
34: Notably, there were problems with the requests to surveil Page, which relied in large part on information from Steele.
35: The report counted seven "significant inaccuracies and omissions" in the original application and 10 "additional significant errors" in the three renewal requests, including one resulting from alleged document tampering by a low-level FBI lawyer.
36: The IG report said these errors made the FISA applications appear more convincing.
37: The report was silent on whether the court would have approved them with more accurate information.
38: Still, surveillance under FISA is legal, and the report said the FBI did not "infiltrate" or otherwise spy on the Trump campaign.
39: Plus, the errors made in relation to the FISA application process had no bearing on the start of the Russia investigation.
40: "The report separately found some problems with respect to specific, and later in time, applications for FISA surveillance of Carter Page," Daskal told us.
41: But those problems "do not change the fact that the initial overarching decision to investigate was justified."

gpt4: The claim that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions has been proven false by the Inspector General's report.
The report found that the FBI's decision to open an investigation into the campaign’s ties with Russia was warranted and not motivated by politics[3].
The investigation, known as "Crossfire Hurricane", was launched with "an authorized purpose" and an "articulable factual basis"[10].
Despite some errors made in relation to the FISA application process, these had no bearing on the start of the Russia investigation[39].
Additionally, this information alone was enough to trigger the Russia probe as it gave the FBI reason to believe a crime or threat to U.S. national security was impending [12].
These conclusions were drawn from an extensive study of more than 1 million documents and interviews with over 100 witnesses[7].
However, the report indeed deemed the surveillance technique used as "highly intrusive" and noted that the FBI did not seek similar warrants to monitor Papadopoulous, Manafort, or Flynn [33].
The report ultimately makes it clear that the decision to launch the investigation was justified[17][41].
Accusations suggesting otherwise can be seen as misleading or distortive of the report's findings[19][20].

a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.claim: " The U.S. spends ""57 cents on the dollar on defense."""
a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.label: false
a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.passage:
0: The Progressive, a 110-year-old national magazine based in Madison, Wis., calls itself "a voice for peace, social justice, and the common good!"
1: It published an article Dec. 1 about Rep. Ilhan Omar saying the Democratic Minnesota congresswoman "wants to redefine U.S. foreign policy as we know it."
2: Omar elaborated on her philosophy by addressing military spending.
3: "We can fight to have our Green New Deal.
4: We can certainly get Medicare for All.
5: We can cancel out student debt.
6: We can certainly pass our Housing for All bill.
7: We can get a universal school meals program up and running," she said.
8: "But in order to do all of those things, we have to stop policing the world, right?
9: We have to not have over 800 military bases around the world.
10: We have to not spend 57 cents on the dollar on defense."
11: Omar’s major claim is wrong.
12: Defense spending accounts for only 15% of the federal budget.
13: 57% was wrong before In 2015, we rated as False a claim that 57% of federal spending goes to the military and just 1% goes to food and agriculture, including food stamps.
14: Rather than being dominated by the military, the budget was actually dominated by spending on Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, we found.
15: At the time, military spending, including spending on homeland security, accounted for 54% of discretionary spending — that is, not-mandatory spending.
16: But it accounted for only 16% of federal spending overall.
17: "This is a common mistake," Robert Bixby , executive director of the centrist Concord Coalition, which works for fiscal responsibility, said about Omar’s claim.
18: In fact, a spokesman for the congresswoman said Omar was referring to discretionary funding.
19: He cited a Washington Post article that says defense would be 57% of discretionary spending in the 2020 federal budget request unveiled by President Donald Trump in March 2019.
20: Defense percentage steady The percentage of the total federal budget spent on defense has been in the same range for years.
21: 2007: 19% , FactCheck.org found 2011: About 25% , according to the Washington Post Fact Checker 2017: 15% according to the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities Currently, about 17% of the federal budget goes toward defense, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office — a figure confirmed to us by Marc Goldwein of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
22: The Peter G. Peterson Foundation puts the figure there, too, at 15% .
23: As for the dollars, the 2018 federal budget contained, according to a June 2019 report by the Congressional Budget Office: • $1.3 trillion went to discretionary spending, including $600 billion for defense.
24: That would be about 46% .
25: • Total outlays were $4.1 trillion, with defense getting $623 billion.
26: That’s 15% .
27: The 15% figure also holds true for 2019, as well.

gpt4: The claim that the U.S. spends "57 cents on the dollar on defense" is false.
It is incorrect to state that we have to spend 57 cents on every dollar on defense [10].
In reality, defense spending accounts for only 15% of the federal budget, not 57% [12].
To clarify, 15% equates to 15 cents on the dollar, not the alleged 57 cents [26].
Moreover, the percentage of the total federal budget spent on defense has remained at the same range for years; it has not dramatically increased to 57% [20].

e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.claim: "  a photo of a woman wearing a costume holding the sign ""vagina lady"" is Stanford law professor Pamela Karlan."
e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.label: false
e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.passage:
0: Viral posts circulating on social media claim that a photo of a woman in a vagina costume holding the sign "vagina lady" is Stanford law professor Pamela Karlan, who recently provided testimony in the impeachment proceedings of President Donald Trump.
1: But there is no evidence that the woman is Karlan.
2: One Dec. 6 post , which has been shared over 2,400 times, displays the photo along with the caption: "This was the Democrats Constitutional Expert witness Stanford Professor Karlan."
3: (There have also been some posts that show another photo of a woman in a pink "pussyhat" who has also been misidentified as Karlan.)
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: A reverse-image search led us to a Flickr page that posted the photograph in May 2007 as part of an album for the annual "Bay to Breakers" race held in San Francisco.
7: The caption does not name the person in the photo, but reads, "One of two ladies in vagina costumes."
8: We reached out to race officials about whether Karlan’s name appeared on that year’s roster, but were told their registration data doesn’t go back that far.
9: We searched news coverage of the event and found no mention of Karlan.
10: Karlan herself responded to PolitiFact in an email, and said she didn’t attend the race and the photograph is not of her.

gpt4: The claim that a photograph of a woman wearing a costume and holding a sign that reads "vagina lady" is Stanford law professor Pamela Karlan is proven to be false.
There is no evidence to suggest that the woman depicted in the image is indeed Karlan [1].
The image was found via a reverse-image search to have been posted on a Flickr page in May 2007, as part of an album for the annual "Bay to Breakers" race held in San Francisco [6].
Furthermore, Karlan has explicitly stated in an email correspondence with PolitiFact that she did not attend this event and the picture in question is not of her [10].

6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.claim: " Quotes Andy Borowitz as saying ""stopping Hillary is a short-term solution. The long-term solution — and it will be more difficult — is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."""
6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.label: false
6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.passage:
0: Andy Borowitz is a writer and comedian who authors the popular satirical column " The Borowitz Report " for the New Yorker.
1: (Here are some of his latest columns .)
2: But we recently came across a statement falsely attributed to Borowitz on social media that disparages Hillary Clinton and people who voted for her.
3: To be fair, he said most of it, but with one rather significant difference: He was talking about then-presidential candidate Donald Trump, not Clinton.
4: The post that we found had been shared on Facebook more than 3,000 times and featured a photograph of Borowitz alongside text that reads: "Stopping Hillary is a short-term solution.
5: The long-term solution –– and it will be more difficult –– is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: While that particular post was deleted while we were fact-checking it, we found the image several other places .
9: The quote in the image is doctored to make it look like Borowitz is being critical of Clinton.
10: We found that he posted the statement on his verified Facebook page on Nov. 4, 2016, four days before the presidential election.
11: The only words altered in the Facebook post’s version are the two references to "Hillary," in which Borowitz actually wrote "Trump."
12: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The statement has been altered.

gpt4: The claim suggesting Andy Borowitz criticized Hillary Clinton and her voters is false.
The quote in question circulating on social media has been falsely attributed to Borowitz and manipulated to defame Clinton and her supporters[2].
The image quote has been doctored with Borowitz's actual comments being manipulated to include two references to "Hillary" where he originally referred to "Trump" [9][11].
On scrutiny of the information divulged on PolitiFact.com, it is clear that the statement has been altered which further discredits the claim[12].

bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.claim: "  Fox News ""posts a fake picture to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan….forgets to take out the Universal Studios sign in the background."""
bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.label: false
bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.passage:
0: On Thanksgiving Day, President Donald Trump made an unannounced visit to Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan.
1: Fox News reported on the trip .
2: But a Dec. 3 Facebook post alleges the network aired a staged photo while covering the news.
3: "Fox propaganda posts a fake picture to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan ….
4: forgets to take out the Universal Studios sign in the background," reads the text over a photo of soldiers smiling and cheering.
5: A yellow arrow is drawn on the image to point out a sign in the upper left corner that’s cropped.
6: The letters "versal," "national" and "tudios" are visible."
7: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: That’s because the photo appears doctored.
10: The words on the sign look more like NBCUniversal International Studios than Universal Studios , but neither studio name appears in the original version of the photo used in the Facebook post.
11: AFP photographer Olivier Douliery took the photo on Nov. 28 .
12: The caption says: "U.S.
13: Soldiers react with cheers and applause as US President Donald Trump arrives in Bagram Air Field during a surprise Thanksgiving day visit."
14: Fox News told FactCheck.org that it never aired the image, but other news outlets ran it, including the Times of Israel , Axios and the Daily Mail .
15: None of those images show the sign that appears in the Facebook post.

gpt4: The claim that Fox News posted a fake picture of soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan with a Universal Studios sign in the background is false.
It was confirmed by Fox News to FactCheck.org that it never aired such an image [14].
This image surfaced in other outlets like The Times of Israel, Axios, and the Daily Mail [14].
However, none of these featured images showed the sign that appears in the initial Facebook post [15].

Furthermore, the text on the sign that allegedly appears in the photograph appears to resemble NBCUniversal International Studios as opposed to Universal Studios, but a closer look revealed that neither studio name can be found in the original version of the photo used in the Facebook post [10].

10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.claim: "  a proposed change to Illinois’ gambling law would result in ""lower taxes paid to the state and higher taxes paid"" to Chicago from a city casino so that the total amount would be the same, but the city would get to ""keep more of it."""
10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.label: half-true
10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.passage:
0: During her visit to Springfield last month, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot pressed state lawmakers to lower tax rates on a future city casino after a consultant found the tax burden would be so heavy it could seriously jeopardize the casino’s ability to turn a profit.
1: But in an interview conducted in mid-November shortly after the legislature’s fall veto session, a Republican state lawmaker claimed Chicago’s proposal would actually raise the city’s take of casino tax revenue while leaving the state with less cash for projects that could benefit communities across Illinois.
2: "They wanted lower taxes paid to the state and higher taxes paid to the city," state Sen. Dave Syverson of Rockford told WCIA’s Mark Maxwell in a sit-down at the capitol, which aired Dec. 8.
3: "The amount of taxes would be the same, but Chicago wanted to keep more of it."
4: "As quick example," Syverson continued, "in all the other casinos in the state, the local community keeps 5% of the revenue and then the state gets an average of about 35%.
5: Under this scenario, Chicago — instead of 5% — Chicago would be keeping about 22% or 23% of the revenue and the state would get half the amount of what every other casino in the state was paying."
6: There’s a lot of moving pieces in Syverson’s claim, but the text of the bill he was referencing makes clear Chicago would have to cut its share as well — a point the senator conceded when we spoke with him.
7: What the bill says The plan Syverson referenced was introduced on the final day of veto session as an amendment to the gambling law that passed in the spring.
8: It didn’t gain enough traction for a floor vote this fall, but lawmakers could take it up again when they return to Springfield next month.
9: Lightfoot continues to push hard for a change to the original gambling bill, pointing to a state-mandated consultant’s report from August that called the tax structure on a Chicago casino "onerous."
10: The consultant report warned that after accounting for operating expenses the effective tax rate on the Chicago casino would be 72%, leaving a profit margin of only 1% or 2%, or even exceeding casino revenue entirely.
11: To address this, Democratic state Rep. Bob Rita of Blue Island introduced a city-backed plan to lower both state and city tax rates for Chicago’s casino, which is likely to become the state’s highest grossing.
12: The gambling bill that passed the General Assembly in the spring and was later signed into law by Democratic Gov.
13: J.B. Pritzker calls for a 33.3% tax on the casino’s gross receipts dedicated to the city’s pension obligations.
14: Rita’s legislation would have eliminated the city’s flat tax and replaced it with rates ranging from 10.5% to 34.7%.
15: "It would be a cut to the city, because you’re eliminating that 33% [flat rate]," Rita told us in a phone interview.
16: Meanwhile, the state’s original graduated rates of 15% to 50% on the casino would have been lowered to a range of 12% to 40%, according to the bill.
17: The varying rates would be applied at different levels based on how much money the casino brings in under the plan.
18: A similar series of graduated rates for both Chicago and the state would apply to revenue from table games.
19: When we ran the bill’s specifics by Syverson, he agreed the legislative language would cut rather than raise Chicago’s take.
20: "If, in fact, we use the strict definition of the bill and Chicago was only going to get the tax rates that you gave me … then I would concede that Chicago would get a little bit less money," he said.
21: "Now, having said that, anyone with any common sense would say, why would Chicago introduce a bill that says, ‘We want less money’?"
22: Rita’s rejoinder: Without a lower tax structure that encourages companies to build and run a Chicago casino, there won’t be a casino for the city or the state to tax.
23: Still, Syverson remains concerned about the plan.
24: He said his job as a state senator is to ensure Illinois doesn’t lose out on needed funding from a Chicago casino and noted Lightfoot and the Chicago City Council have other tools to further tax the casino without getting an OK from the legislature.

gpt4: A Republican state lawmaker from Illinois asserted after a legislature session that Chicago’s proposal of modifying their gambling laws would increase the city's share of casino tax revenue, leaving the state with a reduced share that could be utilized for projects benefiting various communities across the state [1].

On the other hand, Democratic state Representative Bob Rita introduced a new plan backed by the city to diminish both state and city tax rates for Chicago's casino, which is projected to be the most lucrative in the state [11].
However, Rita suggested that it would decrease the savings for the city, considering the elimination of the 33% flat rate tax [15].
Additionally, according to the proposed bill, the state's initial tax schedule with a gradual increase from 15% to 50% would have been reduced to a range between 12% and 40% [16].

This legislative language agreed by Syverson implies a cut in the city's earning rather than an increase [19], making the claim that the proposed change would result in lower state taxes and higher city taxes only half-true.

8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.claim: "  a new annual report shows that ""West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year, reversing years of decline and outpacing national growth by 58 percent."""
8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.label: true
8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.passage:
0: West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice took to Facebook in October to tout gains in his state’s tourism industry.
2: "When I took office, I made tourism a top priority because I knew it had all the potential in the world," Justice wrote in his post .
3: "Today I am proud to announce that West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year, reversing years of decline and outpacing national growth by 58%!
4: Way to go West Virginia Tourism!"
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post linked to a press release that provided additional detail and cited a study conducted by  Dean Runyan Associates, an economic consulting firm that has examined the state’s tourism industry annually since 2000.
6: A year ago, we fact-checked how well Justice described the previous year’s statistics and rated it Mostly True , because Justice glossed over some of the report’s negative findings.
7: How about this year?
8: Let’s take a look, point by point.
9: (Justice’s office did not respond to inquiries for this article.)
10: "West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year... " This is accurate.
11: The report found that overall spending on tourism in West Virginia grew from $4.14 billion in 2016 to $4.28 billion in 2017 to $4.55 billion in 2018.
12: That’s an increase in the most recent year of 6.5%, easily exceeding the rate of inflation.
13: Spending also grew for the second straight year if you set aside gambling revenue.
14: It rose from $3.48 billion in 2016 to to $3.63 billion in 2017 to $3.91 billion in 2018.
15: That’s an increase in the most recent year of 7.5%.
16: This also exceeded the rate of inflation.
17: "... reversing years of decline …" This is accurate, too.
18: According to the data in the report, the rise over the past two years came after four consecutive annual declines, as this chart shows: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com "… outpacing national growth by 58%."
19: The report also provides data for the national tourism market that’s comparable to the West Virginia numbers.
20: According to the report, spending was $980 billion in 2018, a 4.1% increase over 2017.
21: (These figures are not adjusted for inflation, but neither is the West Virginia figure, so the national and state figures can be compared equitably.)
22: Justice’s 58% figure appears to come from comparing the most recent one-year increase in West Virginia (6.5%) with the most recent one-year increase nationally (4.1%).
23: The West Virginia percentage increase is 58.5% bigger than the national increase.

gpt4: The claim that West Virginia's tourism industry has experienced growth for two consecutive years, reversing previous years of decline and surpassing national growth by 58 percent is, in fact, true.
The Governor of West Virginia made tourism a top priority upon taking office, understanding its potential for the state [2].
Reports confirm a steady rise in spending on tourism in the state over the past two years, increasing from $4.14 billion in 2016 to $4.28 billion in 2017 and further to $4.55 billion in 2018[11].
This growth rate, at 6.5% in the most recent year, easily outpaced inflation [12].
The surge in tourism growth comes after a period of four consecutive annual declines, effectively reversing this negative trend [17][18].
When compared with national tourism market data, this growth in West Virginia indeed outpaced the national growth rate, which saw an increase of only 4.1% in 2018[19][20].
The stated figure of 58% appears to have been derived from a comparison of the most recent one-year increases in West Virginia and nationally.
Accordingly, West Virginia's percentage increase was observed to be 58.5% larger than the national increase [22][23].

d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.claim: " Delaware has the ""eighth-largest black population in the country"""
d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.label: false
d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.passage:
0: Former Vice President Joe Biden exaggerated the size of the black population in Delaware in an interview in which he spoke about why he thinks he has more black support than Mayor Pete Buttigieg.
1: "I come out of an environment where I have the eighth-largest black population in the country, in my state, and that's where I got my political education," he told Axios .
2: Biden was referring to a comparison of the black population in states and Washington, D.C. by percentage, but he didn’t mention the word "percentage" in that interview.
3: In terms of raw numbers, Delaware — a state with a population of just under 1 million — has a small black population that does not rank among the top states.
4: RELATED: U.S. minorities surpassed 25% of electorate when Obama ran in 2008, and it's going up What Census data shows for Delaware’s black population The U.S. Census sent us 2018 data showing the percent of the African American population in each state.
5: Delaware was in seventh place — about 22.5% of the population is black.
6: The top states in order were Mississippi, Louisiana, Georgia, Maryland, Alabama, South Carolina, Delaware and North Carolina.
7: If we include the District of Columbia, then Delaware would be in eighth place.
8: But if we look at raw numbers, Delaware does not rank among the top states for the size of the black population.
9: Delaware has about 220,000 black residents , placing it around the bottom one-third of states.
10: By population, the top five states would be Texas, Georgia, Florida, New York and California.
11: William Frey , a demographer at the Brookings Institution who is known for his research on race, said it is appropriate to look at the percent of the black population for the state.
12: However, Frey said, Biden’s comment would be more compelling if applied to a state with a large black percentage and sheer numbers such as Georgia.
13: A Census spokesman told us that both metrics — the percentage and raw numbers — are useful data, but it provides a more complete picture to look at both of them.
14: In Biden’s case, he was using the statistic to make his case that he has a history of representing black voters and cares about issues of importance to them.
15: But it’s important to understand how small the Delaware population is.
16: "There are more black people in one county in Florida than in Delaware," said Keneshia Grant, a Howard University political scientist who does research on black voters.
17: "It looks like the ten cities with the largest black populations all have larger black populations than the entire state of Delaware."
18: The percentage of black residents in Delaware is significant in terms of showing that Biden had to take into account the concerns of black voters when he was a senator there, University of Delaware political scientist David Redlawsk said.
19: "This is best expressed in terms of a percentage, which provides the relative importance to his own elections," he said.
20: We found that in some interviews Biden states that he is talking about a percentage while in other instances he omits that crucial explanation.
21: (Biden has been making similar statements at least since 2006 .)

gpt4: The claim that Delaware has the "eighth-largest black population in the country" is false.
This misrepresentation may have emerged from a statement by Joe Biden in an interview with Axios where he used these exact words.
Nevertheless, he was referring to a comparison of black population by percentage across states and Washington, D.C. instead of raw numbers [2][1].

To clarify, in terms of the actual number of black residents, Delaware, with a population of almost 1 million, is considerably smaller, with about 220,000 black residents, making it rank around the bottom one-third among all states [3][9].
The top five states with the highest number of black residents in the country, by population, are Texas, Georgia, Florida, New York and California [10].

d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.claim: "  Koalas are ""functionally extinct"" as bushfires in Australia continue to destroy their habitat."
d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.label: false
d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.passage:
0: As catastrophic bushfires spread across parts of Australia, misinformation about one of the region’s most beloved animals, the koala, spreads, too.
1: Areas of Australia started to burn in September 2019, marking an early start to the region’s fire season and scorching more than 5 million acres in News South Wales and parts of Queensland.
2: When the fires became international news, online stories – like this one – went viral with shocking headlines that claim koalas are now "functionally extinct" as a result of the blaze.
3: It is true that several hundred koalas have died in the bushfires ( some estimates put the death toll in the thousands) and large swaths of the marsupial’s habitat have been destroyed.
4: However, the claim that koalas are "functionally extinct" is inaccurate.
5: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: It appears that the idea that koalas are "functionally extinct" started when the Australian Koala Foundation , a local conservation nonprofit that advocates for koala protection and preservation, released a statement in May 2019 calling on Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison to enact the Koala Protection Act, which was written in 2016.
8: "The Australian Koala Foundation (AKF) believes Koalas may be functionally extinct in the entire landscape of Australia," the statement says.
9: "The AKF thinks there are no more than 80,000 Koalas in Australia."
10: Since the fires, the organization released another statement in October 2019 standing by its use of the term.
11: Noah Greenwald, endangered species director at the US-based Center for Biological Diversity , told PolitiFact there are two different definitions of "functionally extinct."
12: One is that a species still occurs in the wild but can’t effectively reproduce, so is all but extinct.
13: The other, is that a species is so reduced that it can no longer play its role in the ecosystem.
14: Neither definition, he says, applies to the koala.
15: The koala population is indeed declining, but AKF’s estimate is much lower than other assessments.
16: The International Union for Conservation (IUCN), the global authority on the conservation status of all species, approximates that 300,000 mature adult koalas remain in the wild, and lists the species as vulnerable , a step above endangered and two above critically endangered.
17: But IUCN last assessed the koala population in 2014, and the species may very well be worse off due to food degradation, deforestation, hunting, drought and fires over the last several years.
18: That said, another group of scholars studied the koala population in 2016 and found comparable numbers.
19: Nevertheless, several wildlife experts reject the notion that koalas are currently "functionally extinct."
20: "By either definition, it's hard to see koalas as functionally extinct," Greenwald said.
21: "The last estimate for their numbers is roughly 300,000, and in some places they are very much playing their ecological role of munching on eucalyptus leaves."
22: Wildlife conservation experts also told National Geographic that it’s difficult to measure koala populations, even at the best of times, because the animal has a wide range across eastern Australia, are human-shy and live very high up in trees.
23: Christine Adams-Hosking, a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Queensland in Australia, told PolitiFact that koalas "are certainly not functionally extinct" in Australia.
24: And though they have been affected by habitat loss as a result of the fires, she said, it’s too early to know the impact.
25: "We will never know exact numbers because we don’t know how many koalas exactly there were there in the first place," she said.
26: "Time will tell.
27: Over the next few years, the burnt areas will need to be monitored to see how many koalas recolonize the burnt areas and whether they can successfully build up their population numbers again."
28: PolitiFact also reached out to the World Wide Fund for Nature-Australia about the claim.
29: The organization’s senior manager for land clearing and restoration, Stuart Blanch, told us that while the bushfires are a setback for koala conservation, WWF-Australia does not agree that the species is functionally extinct.
30: The organization estimates that from July to November, the fires scorched more than 8% of the known koala forest in New South Wales and that, even before the fires, koala populations disappeared from large areas of eastern and southern Australia.
