31: "While koalas will survive this bushfire crisis, the longer-term picture in New South Wales and Queensland is not good unless excessive tree clearing is halted," Blanch said.
32: "WWF-Australia has published a report projecting ‘that koalas will become extinct in the wild in eastern Australia by as early as 2050 – and highly likely by 2100 – if deforestation and other threats continue.’ " The organization said that koalas require remaining eucalypt forests to be preserved, cleared forest areas to be regenerated, and isolated patches of habitat to be connected by newly planted wildlife corridors.

gpt4: The claim that koalas are "functionally extinct" due to the bushfires destroying their habitat in Australia is false[4].
Noah Greenwald, the endangered species director at the U.S.-based Center for Biological Diversity, asserted that the term "functionally extinct" has two interpretations[11].

It may denote a species' occurrence in the wild without effective reproduction making it virtually extinct[12] or that the species' population has reduced to such an extent that it cannot maintain its ecological role[13].
Greenwald also stated that neither definition is applicable to the current state of the koala population[14].

Further corroborating this, the International Union for Conservation (IUCN) estimates that approximately 300,000 mature adult koalas exist in the wild, categorizing the species as vulnerable, which is better than being endangered, and significantly better off than being critically endangered[16].

Many wildlife experts, including Christine Adams-Hosking, a research fellow at the University of Queensland, and Stuart Blanch, senior manager for land clearing and restoration at WWF-Australia, concurred that the term "functionally extinct" does not accurately reflect the current status of the koala species[19][23][29].

2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.claim: Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators.
2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.label: false
2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.passage:
0: West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice, facing a competitive Republican primary in 2020, recently introduced an ad touting his accomplishments in office, including a focus on K-12 education.
2: The ad, released in a Dec. 4 tweet , features several West Virginians reading off a series of scripted accomplishments from Justice’s tenure.
3: One of the accomplishments, voiced by a teacher, is that "Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators."
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com This struck us as odd, since governors of all parties regularly tout their support for teachers — a group that’s popular with voters and, in many states, a politically powerful constituency.
5: Teacher salaries have been an especially sensitive issue in West Virginia.
6: Between 2005 and 2017, West Virginia teacher salaries never rose higher than 44th in the nation.
7: That history set the stage for a 2018 teacher strike in West Virginia, which was the state’s first major K-12 walkout in almost three decades.
8: Justice eventually signed a 5% pay bump, which is more than the legislature had offered prior to the strike.
9: So is Justice really the first West Virginia governor ever to push for teacher pay raises?
10: His office did not respond to inquiries for this article, but we found that each of Justice’s five immediate predecessors either proposed or enacted teacher pay raises.
11: Gov.
12: Earl Ray Tomblin, Democrat, 2011-2017 In his first state of the state address in 2011, Tomblin proposed a one-time, across-the-board $800 increase for teachers.
13: "Frankly, it should be more and we need to strive for a day when our teachers are paid at a rate equivalent to the most important role they play," he said in the speech, according to the Associated Press .
14: In 2014, despite offering few increases in his relatively austere budget proposal, Tomblin did include a 2% pay raise for teachers.
15: The bill he eventually signed contained a $1,000 raise for teachers for the 2014-2015 school year.
16: Gov.
17: Joe Manchin, Democrat, 2005-2010 As governor, Manchin — now a U.S.
18: Senator — periodically sparred with teachers’ unions over the size of his salary increase proposals.
19: But both Manchin’s Senate office and West Virginia teachers’ unions agree that he proposed a teacher salary increase and signed it into law .
20: During his tenure, Manchin raised teacher salaries by 3.5%, according to a joint statement released by the West Virginia Education Association, the American Federation of Teachers-West Virginia, and the West Virginia School Service Personnel Association when the groups endorsed Manchin’s Senate reelection bid in 2018.
21: Manchin’s Senate office cited the same 3.5% increase when we inquired.
22: The legislation Manchin signed also improved teachers’ annual salary increments and allowed educators to move from a 401(k)-style defined contribution plans to a defined-benefit system.
23: Gov.
24: Bob Wise, Democrat, 2001-2005 In his 2001 state of the state address, Wise proposed raising teacher salaries by $1,000, plus $2,500 in incentives.
25: "Teachers are the heart of the educational system.
26: We must honor the work of our teachers," he said .
27: After leaving the governor’s office, Wise became CEO of the Alliance for Excellent Education, an education advocacy group.
28: Gov.
29: Cecil Underwood, Republican, 1997-2001 In his 1998 state of the state address, Underwood proposed giving teachers a $750 pay raise.
30: He signed a three-year pay raise into law later that year.
31: Gov.
32: Gaston Caperton, Democrat, 1989-1997 Caperton was governor during a divisive, 11-day West Virginia teacher strike in 1990, but he ended up presiding over a significant pay increase for the state’s teachers.
33: The strike was settled when all parties agreed on a $5,000 pay increase phased in over three years.
34: Last year, PolitiFact reported that most significant recent improvement in West Virginia teacher pay compared to other states came between 1990 and 2000, a period during which Caperton and Underwood were in office.
35: Like Wise, Caperton headed an education group — the College Board — after serving as governor.

gpt4: The claim that Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators is false.
Research shows that several of Justice’s predecessors also pursued pay increases for teachers in West Virginia.
Notably, Democrat Gaston Caperton, who was in office from 1989 to 1997, presided over a significant pay rise for teachers after an 11-day strike[32][33].

Former governor Earl Ray Tomblin proposed a one-time $800 raise for teachers in his first state-of-the-state address in 2011, and later on in 2014, he included a 2% pay raise in his proposal, which culminated in a $1,000 pay raise for teachers in the 2014-2015 academic year[12][14][15].
Similarly, Former Governor Joe Manchin, in office from 2005-2010, proposed a teacher salary increase enacted into law as well, which resulted in a raise by 3.5% during his tenure[17][19][20].
Former Democrat Governor Bob Wise proposed raising teacher salaries by $1,000, plus $2,500 in incentives during his tenure from 2001-2005[24].
Republican governor Cecil Underwood also proposed a $750 raise for teachers in his 1998 state-of-the-state address[29][30].
Thus, it is clear that the claim is not accurate.

63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.claim: "  justices of the peace in Texas are being asked to choose: ""give up your career or violate your religious beliefs"" and perform same-sex marriages."
63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.label: false
63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.passage:
0: During an interview on a Fort Worth radio program with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, host Chris Salcedo pressed his guest about the case of a Waco justice of the peace who was sanctioned by a state commission earlier this month for only officiating opposite sex, but not same-sex, marriages.
1: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct issued Justice of the Peace Dianne Hensley a public warning over her refusal to perform same-sex ceremonies; the commission could take further action if she refuses to stop the practice.
2: Paxton, a Republican, reiterated the stance of his office, one that has not changed since just after the 2015 Supreme Court decision legalizing gay marriage.
3: He said people are entitled to religious exemptions when it would violate their faith to carry out the duties of their job.
4: On the show, Salcedo characterized the case as such: "I shouldn’t have to give up my career — make a choice, either give up your career or violate your religious beliefs," Salcedo said.
5: "The government shouldn’t put me in that position."
6: Saledo’s description of Hensely’s situation is inaccurate.
7: No one is asking Hensley to violate her religious beliefs to keep her career: officiating marriages is an optional activity.
8: A state commission’s opinion on the matter suggested she could officiate all or no marriages, but not selectively choose one type.
9: Protection of religious beliefs Justices of the peace handle low-level civil and criminal cases, including traffic and other Class C misdemeanor cases and civil cases involving up to $10,000.
10: They can also officiate marriages, but this is considered "extra-judicial," an optional activity that earns them thousands per year in personal income.
11: So while there may be some financial incentive to do it, it is by no means required.
12: In fact, some justices of the peace in Texas have chosen not to officiate any marriages in order to avoid the religious dilemma, including in McLennan County, where Hensley hails.
13: The commission decided to investigate Hensley based at least in part on a Waco Herald-Tribune article in which she was quoted about her decision to decline same-sex marriages and how she believed she was entitled to a religious accommodation.
14: It found that she had refused to perform same-sex marriages since 2016, instead only performing opposite-sex marriages and referring same-sex couples to other officiating JPs and clergy.
15: The state commission that sanctioned Hensley said her actions cast "doubt on her capacity to act impartially to persons appearing before her as a judge due to the person’s sexual orientation."
16: Now, Hensley can appeal the sanction, start performing same-sex marriages or stop performing marriages altogether.
17: Hensley has argued that she is entitled to a "religious exemption," but there is no law or legal precedent in Texas establishing such an exemption for a justice of the peace in this context.
18: This question varies by state, depending on whether the state’s Supreme Court has taken up a case and established a precedent.
19: In separate interviews, Douglas Laycock and John Dzienkowski, law professors at the University of Texas, said they weren’t aware of any such cases in Texas.
20: Two legal opinions on the subject that have been issued by state agencies — a 2015 opinion from the attorney general’s office and the Judicial Commission sanction — are nonbinding.
21: In a 2015 opinion filed after the U.S. Supreme Court case on same-sex marriage, Paxton supported people’s right to assert a religious exemption under the First Amendment, though he noted that fines and litigation were possible.
22: The recent Judicial Commission opinion punished Henlsey for giving off the appearance of bias, seeming to indicate an exemption would not be possible.
23: But Laycock said neither document is legally binding.
24: "The basic answer is we don’t know yet," Laycock said.
25: "This may well wind up in the courts."
26: Some states, such as North Carolina, have passed laws on this subject, but Texas has not.
27: The North Carolina law allows some officials, similar to a justice of the peace, to decline to administer any marriages if they have a "sincerely held religious objection" to same-sex marriage, but they may not be selective and only marry opposite-sex couples.
28: Other positions have different requirements People in other government positions, like county clerks who issue marriage licenses, have less flexibility, as issuing marriage licenses can be part of their job description.
29: Perhaps most famously, Kim Davis , a clerk in Kentucky, refused to issue a license to a same-sex couple and, in a high-profile case, she was sued.
30: When she refused to comply with the judge’s order compelling her to follow the law, she was jailed for six days for being in contempt of court.
31: Davis was later released after agreeing not to interfere with other clerks in the office issuing licenses.
32: Some county clerks in Texas are allowing those officials who object to same-sex marriage to find another clerk within the office to issue a license in their place.
33: But if everyone else in the office also refuses, the office as a whole can’t deny a couple the right to marry in defiance of the law, Laycock said.
34: That may explain why no religious exemption case has risen to the Supreme Court level in Texas, Laycock said.
35: As long as the couple receives their license or has their marriage officiated, the damages they can claim in court are limited to emotional distress.
36: That someone in Hensley’s position should not be forced to choose between their job and religious belief, as Salcedo commented, is "not a settled rule of law yet; it’s an opinion about what the law ought to be," Laycock said.

gpt4: The claim that justices of the peace in Texas are being asked to choose between their career or violating their religious beliefs in order to perform same-sex marriages is false.
The state's laws for officiating marriages are not specifically tied to the individual religious beliefs of a Justice of the Peace (JP)[17].
JPs in Texas have the choice to officiate all marriages, or to opt out of performing such ceremonies completely.
This optional activity can potentially provide them with substantial personal income [10].
Some JPs in Texas, including in McLennan County, have chosen this latter approach, opting not to officiate any marriages to navigate around any personal religious conflicts [12].

Moreover, Justice of the Peace Dianne Hensley was publicly warned by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for refusing to perform same-sex marriages, while still performing opposite-sex ceremonies, a violation of the non-discriminatory practices expected of a JP [1][14].
Thus, the option to refrain from officiating any marriages entirely safeguards against any potential conflict between a JP's career and their personal beliefs.

ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.claim: Male birth control testing stopped after men’s testicles start exploding in India.
ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.label: false
ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.passage:
0: A viral story shared on Facebook about male birth control testing — claiming that it caused men’s testicles to explode — originated on a satirical website.
1: But some online posts don’t make that clear.
2: They were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: "Male birth control testing stopped after men’s testicles start exploding in India," reads the headline.
5: Readers of the story are directed to " faceofmalawi.com " below the headline, and "n pas" is cited as a source at the end of the article.
6: That refers to "npas," which are the letters at the top of the website ihlayanews.com, where the story appeared on Dec. 3 .
7: Below "npas" are the words "nuusparodie waarvan jy hou."
8: As AFP Fact Check notes , that’s Afrikaans for "news parody you like."
9: But the post flagged by Facebook includes no such disclaimer.

gpt4: The claim that male birth control testing in India was halted due to men's testicles exploding is false.
The origin of this story is a satirical website that used humor and exaggeration to present the news [0].
The fact that the story went viral on Facebook does not confirm its truthfulness.
Moreover, the term "news parody you like," found in the original story, is a clear indication of its satirical nature as confirmed by AFP Fact Check [8].
Therefore, it's important to scrutinize the sources of such sensational claims and not to take them at face value.

9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.claim: a photo shows Pamela Karlan reacting to Hillary Clinton’s presidential defeat.
9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.label: false
9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.passage:
0: In the wake of Pamela Karlan’s impeachment hearing testimony, some social media users have seemingly attempted to discredit the Stanford law professor by connecting her to images of other women online.
1: We’ve already debunked a viral post that claims a photo of a woman in a costume holding the sign "vagina lady" is Karlan.
2: Other fact-checkers have found another post misidentifying a woman wearing a pink crocheted hat during the 2017 Women’s March on Washington as Karlan.
3: Now a Dec. 5 Facebook post claims to show a photo of "Pamela Karlan when Hillary lost."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The woman the post identifies as Karlan appears upset and is wearing an Uncle Sam-style hat and Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign logo.
7: But the person in the image is actually Janna DeVylder , who was photographed at an election party in Australia that year.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The Des Moines Register reported in January 2017 that DeVylder grew up in Iowa and was living and working in Sydney when Clinton lost to Trump.
9: She had voted absentee for Clinton.
10: The picture of her watching election results quickly became a meme, and she was derided online as the "poster child for the mentally insane Hillary snowflakes."

gpt4: The claim alleging that a specific photo shows Pamela Karlan reacting to Hillary Clinton's presidential defeat is not accurate.
The photo in question was shared in a Facebook post dated Dec. 5, purporting to feature Pamela Karlan in the aftermath of Hillary Clinton's loss[3].
However, upon further investigation, it was uncovered that the person depicted in the image is in fact Janna DeVylder.
The photo was actually taken at an election party held in Australia that year[7].
Therefore, the claim is false.

d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.claim: Yesterday Virginia announced the end of youth hunting!
d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.label: false
d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.passage:
0: As Democrats won control of the Virginia legislature in November, an image started to spread online showing a child in hunting hear holding a dead deer.
1: One such post published on Facebook Nov. 8 says: "Yesterday Virginia announced the end of youth hunting!
2: The governor said that no kid under 18 will be allowed to shoot a gun.
3: This is the end of a 400 year tradition of kids helping put food on their family’s (sic) table.
4: It’s a sad day in the Commonwealth!"
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: We reached out to the governor’s office about the claim but didn’t hear back.
8: However, the state’s Department of Game and Inland Fisheries wrote in a Nov. 8 Facebook post that it "wanted to clear up some rumors that have been circling about youth hunting in Virginia."
9: "There are no changes to currently scheduled youth hunting days," the post says.
10: "All current laws and regulations pertaining to hunting in Virginia are in effect as shown on the DGIF website and the current Hunting & Trapping in Virginia Digest.
11: Any changes to hunting laws would require action either by the Virginia General Assembly or the Board of Game and Inland Fisheries, and currently no such changes are proposed."
12: In November, Virginia Gov.
13: Ralph Northam, a Democrat, announced that in the upcoming legislative session he would push for gun control measures like "getting rid of bump stocks" and reintroducing red flag laws designed to remove firearms from people deemed by a judge to be a danger to themselves or others.
14: After a mass shooting in Virginia Beach in May, Northam introduced eight policy proposals and called a special session to address gun control, but no action was taken before it was adjourned by Republicans, CNN reported.
15: The proposals included "legislation enhancing the punishment for allowing access to loaded, unsecured firearm by a child from a Class 3 Misdemeanor to a Class 6 felony," according to July a press release , and raising "the age of the child from 14 to 18."
16: Outdoors writer Ken Perrotte wrote a Nov. 27 column in the Free Lance-Star, a newspaper in Fredericksburg, Va., warning that "proposed legislation would be trouble for Virginia hunters."
17: One bill for the upcoming 2020 session, writes Perrotte, "would make it a felony to leave loaded, unsecured firearms where anyone under the age 18 could access them.
18: This bill also contains a bombshell provision that makes it a crime for anyone under age 18 to use a firearm without adult supervision.
19: Presumably, this includes hunting scenarios."
20: The proposed legislation says it would be unlawful for anyone "to recklessly leave a loaded, unsecured firearm in such a manner as to endanger the life or limb of any person under the age of 18."
21: But a spokeswoman for the governor’s office told the Associated Press that "a responsible hunter — regardless of age — would not be affected by this bill."
22: The bill also says it would be unlawful for anyone younger than 21 to "knowingly and intentionally possess or transport a handgun or assault firearm anywhere in the Commonwealth."
23: However, that wouldn’t apply to "any person actually engaged in lawful hunting or going to and from a hunting or preserve," according the proposed legislation.
24: We further didn’t find evidence that the state "announced the end of youth hunting," as the Facebook post says, or that the governor "said that no kid under 18 will be allowed to shoot a gun."

gpt4: The recent claim that Virginia announced an end to youth hunting is false.

The claim was responded to by the state’s Department of Game and Inland Fisheries in a Facebook post that contradicted the claim, stating it wanted to "clear up some rumors that have been circling about youth hunting in Virginia"[8].
The post further clarified, "There are no changes to currently scheduled youth hunting days"[9].

The enactment of any modifications to hunting laws would necessitate measures by the Virginia General Assembly or the Board of Game and Inland Fisheries, with no current propositions of changes to these laws[11].
Furthermore, a spokeswoman for the governor’s office communicated to the Associated Press that an accountable hunter, of any age, would not be affected by this bill.
The bill would not apply to individuals engaged in lawful hunting or traveling to and from a hunting or preserve[21][23].

Moreover, there was no evidence found to affirm that the state "announced the end of youth hunting," as the Facebook post implies, or that the governor "said that no kid under 18 will be allowed to shoot a gun"[24].

7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.claim: "  the Potomac River ""has gotten dirtier and dirtier and dirtier and dirtier. I go down there and that litter is left almost exclusively by immigrants."""
7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.label: false
7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.passage:
0: Fox News host Tucker Carlson ripped into immigrants in the nation’s capital, accusing them without evidence of contaminating the Potomac River.
1: In an interview with the Atlantic, Carlson said he’s been fishing in the river, which stretches from West Virginia into the Chesapeake Bay, for almost 35 years.
2: "It has gotten dirtier and dirtier and dirtier and dirtier," he said.
3: "I go down there, and that litter is left almost exclusively by immigrants."
4: Asked how he knew immigrants were to blame, Carlson added: "Because I’m there.
5: I watch it."
6: We found that Carlson’s claim is at odds with data collected by activists devoted to keeping the Potomac clean, who told us that the river has actually gotten cleaner over time.
7: Plus, there’s no evidence that immigrants are especially to blame for any trash floating around the river’s waters.
8: (Fox News did not respond to requests for comment.)
9: Cleaner and cleaner, not dirtier and dirtier The Potomac River has long been considered too polluted for swimming, particularly in and around Washington, D.C., where Carlson lives .
10: Its waters were so bad that in 1965, former President Lyndon Johnson declared the river a "national disgrace."
11: But a 2018 report from the Potomac Conservancy, a nonprofit clean-water advocate in the region, found that the Potomac’s overall health has improved dramatically in the last 10 years.
12: Hedrick Belin, president of the group, blasted Carlson for his "groundless accusation" in a statement to PolitiFact, calling the Fox News host’s comments "factually incorrect" and "racist."
13: "For the first time in generations, we are within reach of fully enjoying a healthy, thriving Potomac River," Belin said, noting that river pollutants are in decline as fish are returning.
14: Other experts agreed.
15: "This is a river that's getting cleaner and cleaner, not 'dirtier and dirtier,'" said Philip Musegaas, vice president of programs and litigation for the Potomac Riverkeeper Network.
16: The nonprofit called Carlson’s claim "dead wrong" in a Facebook post.
17: Musegaas said plans to upgrade the sewer systems in Washington and Alexandria, Va., should eliminate the "last sources of untreated sewage pollution" in the nearby metropolitan area.
18: Curtis Dalpra, communications manager for the Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin , said different environmental issues affect different parts of the river, which is more than 380 miles long.
19: But generally speaking, the river is cleaner than it was 30 years ago.
20: Still, Carlson was talking specifically about litter, so we also reached out to the Alice Ferguson Foundation, which organizes annual trash cleanups along the riverside and keeps tabs on the total amount of trash and recyclables its volunteers haul out of the Potomac’s shores each year.
21: According to the foundation’s data , less litter was collected in 2019 than in 2007, even as the number of volunteers increased.
22: Specifically, the number of trash-and-recyclable-filled bags per volunteer dropped from an average of 2.14 bags in 2007 to 1.20 in 2019.
23: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com At Fletchers’ Cove — a spot that, according to the Washington Post , is roughly a 10-minute drive from Carlson’s house — the average number of bags-per-volunteer went from roughly 2.11 in 2007 to about 1.32 in 2019.
24: Litter isn’t the main problem Local experts also cast doubt on Carlson’s claim that immigrant litter was at fault.
25: For starters, litter is not the top pollutant soiling the Potomac River’s waters.
26: Belin said nutrients and sediment that flow off the land are the main causes for concern.
27: When they hit the water, they harm wildlife, degrade habitats and taint the water, making it less clean and safe.
28: Litter is still an issue.
29: But foreign-born people — who make up roughly 14% of the population in Washington, D.C., according to the Census Bureau — are not uniquely prone to littering.
30: "Littering is definitely a problem, but it is a problem that knows no color or ethnicity," Musegaas said.
31: "Tourists litter, residents litter, and people fishing and boating on the river litter."
32: Not only that, but most of the trash that ends up in the Potomac River is not deposited directly, experts said.
33: Often, trash left in the street or outside in barrels gets swept by rain into the sewer or the river.
34: Of course, that trash has to come from someone, Dalpra noted.
35: At some point, it was thrown on the ground or stuffed in the trash.
36: And in a dense city like Washington, there’s likely more litter to go around than elsewhere.
37: But that litter "is really a problem that spans society," Dalpra said.
38: While we won’t discount the possibility that Carlson has spotted immigrants tossing trash in the Potomac, there’s no evidence that the litter "is left almost exclusively by immigrants."

gpt4: The claim that the Potomac River has consistently gotten dirtier and that the commonplace litter is predominantly left by immigrants is false.
Contrarily, data collected by activists determined to maintain the cleanliness of the Potomac River highlights an improvement in the river's overall cleanliness over time[6].
Evidence to support the claim that the blame for any litter found in the river can be attributed mainly to immigrants is absent[7].

Observations made by Carlson, hinting at immigrants being the primary source of litter in the Potomac, lack the necessary evidence to validate the allegation that a majority of the trash "is left almost exclusively by immigrants"[38].
Inline with this, the Potomac Conservancy's 2018 report also indicates the river's health has dramatically improved over the past decade[11].
Belin of the Conservancy added that the decrease in pollutants and the return of fish in the river signals a healthy, thriving river on the horizon[13].
Furthermore, comparisons between the river’s current state and that of 30 years back reveal an improvement in cleanliness[19].
Data from the conservancy shows that the litter collected in 2019 was less than the amount collected in 2007, despite an increase in volunteers[21].
This is demonstrated by the decrease in trash-and-recyclable-filled bags per volunteer from an average of 2.14 in 2007 to 1.20 in 2019[22].
Local experts have also questioned the blaming of immigrant litter[24].
Musegaas, a local expert, also drew attention to the issue of littering, labeling it as a ubiquitous problem irrespective of color or ethnicity [30].

0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.claim: George P. Bush to place statue of (Mexican general) Santa Anna at the Alamo.
0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.label: false
0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.passage:
0: In a lengthy Facebook post , a group called Save the Alamo warned that Texas Land Commissioner George P. Bush wants to erect a statue of the Mexican general who led his nation’s forces during the Battle of the Alamo in 1836 on the grounds of the historic mission in San Antonio.
1: Save the Alamo was created by Rick Range, a former candidate for land commissioner who challenged Bush during the 2018 Republican primary.
2: In the post, Range described a Dec. 4 meeting of the San Antonio Historic Design and Review Commission, at which he said new information about Bush’s plans for the site came to light.
3: "However, during that hearing, it was revealed that not only do George P. Bush and the GLO intend on moving the Cenotaph outside the boundaries of the Alamo; they also intend to erect a statue of the dictator Santa Anna and a memorial honoring the Mexican Army!"
4: Range wrote.
5: "I am not making this up.
6: We know that parts of the Bush plan were going to be horrendous, but it now looks like it will be worse than we ever dreamed."
7: It’s true that the General Land Office, which Bush heads, has proposed moving the cenotaph monument, which honors those Texans who died at the Alamo, to a different location as part of the agency’s planned $450 million project to restore the Alamo.
8: But there are no plans to build a monument to Santa Anna and the Mexican Army at the Alamo.
9: Bush shared a series of tweets on Thursday rebutting the allegations in the post and suggesting that the claim has racist roots.
10: Here are his tweets, presented together: "One must ask themselves, why am I being accused of honoring the murderous dictator Santa Anna?"
11: Bush wrote. "
12: Is it because my mother (now a naturalized citizen) is from Mexico?
13: I was born in Houston, my wife is from San Angelo, and my boys were born-you guessed it- here in Texas.
14: "As a United States Navy Veteran, who deployed to Afghanistan, I know exactly what it means to be loyal to the American flag, this country and this great state.
15: The idea that I would EVER place a statue of Santa Anna at the Alamo is patently false.
16: Enough is enough.
17: This is an outright lie, and is quite frankly, flat out racist."
18: There is no mention of constructing a statue or monument of Santa Anna in the official synopsis of the Alamo Master Plan , the restoration project.
19: The only time Santa Anna is mentioned in the synopsis is during an overview of the different political factions present during the Battle of the Alamo.
20: San Antonio Council Member Roberto Treviño, who serves on the Alamo Master Plan Management Committee, told the Rivard Report that the statement is "baseless, and downright ridiculous."
21: "Among the information and rumors being spread about the plan for the Alamo, this might be one of the most obscene," he said.
22: "We are honoring our history; we are honoring the truth; we are honoring freedom.
23: Erecting a statue of Santa Anna does none of these things."
24: Molly Quick, director of government relations for the General Land Office, gave state lawmakers a progress report on implementation of the restoration project in a Dec. 17 email.
25: There is no mention of Santa Anna or the Mexican Army in her materials.
26: Commission meeting video not altered During the public meeting of the San Antonio Historic Design and Review Commission on Dec. 4, designers behind the restoration project sought the commission’s approval to start implementing the first phase of the plan, which includes landscaping and street improvements — as well as the repair and relocation of the cenotaph to its new location.
27: Range, who was not present at the meeting, said he was told by others in attendance that one of the speakers presenting the project said there were plans to "honor Santa Anna" at the redesigned site.
28: "One of the consultants on the design teams made the statement that they were going to honor both sides, including Santa Anna and the Mexican army," Range told PolitiFact Texas.
29: "If you’re going to honor somebody, that is a statue or a memorial or a monument.
30: I don’t know how else you would honor somebody."
31: But multiple viewings of the archived video of the hearing reveal that none of the people presenting the project said anything about honoring Santa Anna or constructing a sculpture for him or the Mexican army.
32: The only mention of Santa Anna came at the end of the presentation, when John Kasman, vice president of PGAV Destinations, spoke about future phases of the project and some details still under consideration.
33: "There are multiple stories that occurred upon that south edge that deserve to be told," he said, briefly mentioning the position of Santa Anna’s troops as one of those stories.
34: Range said this was not the remark from the meeting that concerned him — in fact, he said he thought a plaque showcasing the movement of the Mexican troops during the 1836 battle would be a "good idea" for the site.
35: Even though the video does not show any individual discussing a plan to "honor" Santa Anna, Range said he was certain the remark was made at the hearing.
36: "What they did was one of their typical ploys — they went through that video and redacted out that segment that caused the hubbub," Range said.
37: "They didn’t want people seeing it."
38: David McElroy, the studio manager of TVSA, the public access channel that airs government meetings in San Antonio, said that footage of the Dec. 4 meeting was not edited.
39: The city uses a vendor that indexes and uploads footage from public meetings to the city’s website.
40: If technical difficulties arise, the city may need to step in and upload its own version of the footage.
41: Either way, McElroy said the city "won’t ever edit a meeting for content," including during the Dec. 4 commission meeting.
42: "Is this the full record of this meeting?
43: Absolutely," McElroy said.

gpt4: The claim that George P. Bush intends to place a statue of Mexican general Santa Anna at the Alamo is false.
This assertion has been vehemently denied with the statement "The idea that I would EVER place a statue of Santa Anna at the Alamo is patently false"[15].
Corroborating this, it has been explicitly stated that there are currently no plans to construct a monument to Santa Anna and the Mexican Army at this historical site [8].

Furthermore, multiple reviews of the available footage from a relevant government meeting held on Dec. 4 confirm that there was no discussion or proposal about honoring Santa Anna or constructing a sculpture for him or the Mexican army [31].
David McElroy, manager of the public access channel that airs these meetings, additionally notes that no content was edited out of this meeting [38][41].
The official Alamo Master Plan, which overviews the restoration project for the landmark, also makes no mention of a sculpture or monument dedicated to Santa Anna [18].
Similarly, no reference to Santa Anna or the Mexican Army is found in any associated materials [25].
Therefore, the claim is clearly unsupported and false.

0fc76a64c67926a9b4382ad49553cacf.claim: "  immigrants wanted by ICE have victimized ""tens of thousands of children"" in North Carolina."
0fc76a64c67926a9b4382ad49553cacf.label: false
0fc76a64c67926a9b4382ad49553cacf.passage:
0: North Carolina politicians are divided over what should be done with undocumented immigrants after they’re arrested.
1: After the 2018 election, a new wave of Democratic sheriffs vowed to halt their jails’ practice of holding undocumented immigrants on behalf of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, known as ICE.
2: The sheriffs’ position: if a judge or magistrate grants a person’s release, he or she should be released -- regardless of immigration status.
3: In response, some Republicans said the sheriffs were endangering public safety, and the GOP-controlled North Carolina legislature passed a bill that would require sheriffs to comply with ICE requests.
4: But Democratic Gov.
5: Roy Cooper vetoed it.
6: Lt. Gov.
7: Dan Forest, who’s running for governor against Cooper, recently spoke at a press conference about the impact of the Democrats’ decisions.
8: Speaking about immigrants wanted by ICE, Forest encouraged the media to use certain terms.
9: "Please think carefully about the words that you use.
10: Many of you are going to be struggling to try not to use words like illegal and alien and words like criminal and rapist and murder and child sex offender," he said.
11: "But if we have tens of thousands of children in our state -- tens of thousands of children in our state that have been victims of these violent criminals already, you have a lifetime, tens of thousands of lifetimes of victims in our state that are going to grow up with that on their mind."
12: His speech can be viewed in a YouTube video , and his claim was first flagged by the liberal American Independent website.
13: Forest’s claim stuck out to us because it’s not specific to a number or timeframe, but loaded with a hefty accusation.
14: So we wondered: have undocumented immigrants victimized "tens of thousands" of children in North Carolina?
15: To answer this question, we knew we’d need a credible source that tracks: violent crimes committed by immigrants in the U.S. illegally, the age of the victims of those crimes, and a state-level breakdown of those statistics.
16: Contacted by PolitiFact, Forest’s campaign cited news stories about crimes committed by undocumented immigrants.
17: But none of the stories verify Forest’s claim that "tens of thousands" of children have been victimized by undocumented immigrants.
18: One big reason Forest’s claim can’t be verified: There is no federal government database or study tracking how many people have been victimized by undocumented immigrants or the age of the victims.
19: Forest’s campaign says they meant the word "victim" in a general sense as much as a legal one.
20: We’ll get to his argument later.
21: But first, let’s look at the legal meaning of what Forest said, and whether there’s data to back it up.
22: "The thing is, it’s very easy to identify individual cases and want to extrapolate up.
23: But that is a major, major fallacy in statistics," said Charis E. Kubrin, professor of criminology, law and society at the University of California Irvine.
24: She called Forest’s claim "very vague and problematic."
25: A familiar claim Generally speaking, Forest’s claim is similar to others made by Republicans.
26: President Trump, for instance, frequently expresses concern about crimes committed by immigrants who are in America illegally.
27: But the lack of data makes it difficult to get a clean look at claims like the one Forest made.
28: ICE doesn’t track crimes committed by immigrants in the United States illegally, nor does it track the age of victims of those crimes, Lindsay Williams, spokeswoman for the agency, told us in an email.
29: North Carolina-specific data isn’t available, either.
30: Neither the NC Attorney General’s Office, the State Bureau of Investigation, nor the Department of Public Safety tracks the statistic Forest mentioned, according to spokespeople for those agencies.
31: Texas is the only state that tracks the immigration status of those convicted on the state level, said Alex Nowrasteh, director of immigration studies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank.
32: Wrong to assume Forest spokesman Andrew Dunn emailed us a list of news stories to back up the Lt. Governor’s statement.
33: One was a story by WBTV that details 1,020 criminal charges and 407 convictions for immigrants sought by ICE in 2019 but released from NC jails before ICE could obtain custody.
34: But many of those charges were for driving offenses, larceny and other nonviolent crimes.
35: And it’s unclear whether the charged immigrants were convicted, or if their victims were children.
36: "Two of those examples identify children as the victim," Nowrasteh said.
37: To back up his claim, Forest would "need 10,000 times as many examples."
38: Dunn also suggested the word "victim" refers to an emotional toll on children who aren’t directly involved in a crime.
39: He noted that, in Charlotte, "hundreds of families were evacuated from their homes and countless thousands impacted during a 9-hour SWAT standoff with an illegal immigrant accused of kidnapping, strangulation and assault on a female."
40: Still, those numbers and anecdotes don’t back up Forest’s original claim.

gpt4: The claim that immigrants wanted by ICE have victimized "tens of thousands of children" in North Carolina is not accurate.
It emanated from a notable individual, Forest, and yet lacked specificity, especially around timeframes and the exact number of victims [13].

When probed by PolitiFact for justification, Forest's campaign referenced different standalone instances of crimes by undocumented immigrants, with only two of these instances having children as victims [16][36].
However, these isolated cases don't substantiate the original claim that posited tens of thousands of child victims [40].
Forest's claim is also not validated by any official documentation or tracking by relevant authorities.
For instance, the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) does not gather data on crimes committed by immigrants in the U.S. illegally or the age of their victims [28].
Similarly, the NC Attorney General’s Office, the State Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Public Safety do not track these kinds of statistics [30].
Furthermore, a vast number of the charges that immigrants face are related to nonviolent crimes such as driving offenses and larceny [34].
Therefore, the claim is unsupported and false.

2abe0997e35bc4996e68482ba8d244d6.claim: "  voter roll purge would mean ""more than 200,000 registered Wisconsin voters will be prohibited from voting."""
2abe0997e35bc4996e68482ba8d244d6.label: false
2abe0997e35bc4996e68482ba8d244d6.passage:
0: Up to 234,000 Wisconsin residents are at risk of being removed from the voter rolls, a political lightning-rod that has drawn national attention given the state’s critical role in the 2020 presidential election.
1: Wisconsin election officials believe those people may have moved, so they sent letters inquiring about their status in October.
2: A series of ensuing lawsuits and court actions have sought to more quickly remove these people from the voting rolls -- or delay that from happening.
3: The controversy caught the attention of U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi , a Democrat.
4: A Twitter account described as Pelosi’s "political account" retweeted a statement from Wisconsin Democratic Party Chair Ben Wikler and then offered its own take on the situation.
5: "It’s beyond alarming that more than 200,000 registered Wisconsin voters will be prohibited from voting," the tweet said.
6: The tweet does not appear to have been sent by Pelosi herself, since it was not signed with her initials, a style referenced in the account description .
7: There’s clearly room for disagreement over how to handle the 234,000 voters.
8: But Pelosi’s claim is a significant exaggeration of what’s at stake.
9: Here’s why.
10: The background The controversy began in October 2019 when the Wisconsin Elections Commission sent letters to 234,000 voters it believed may have moved because of information it received from the post office, Division of Motor Vehicles or other government entities.
11: That’s 7% of the 3.3 million registered voters in the state.
12: The letters asked recipients to re-register at their new address if they had moved or to confirm they were still at their same address if they hadn't.
13: Related: Here's what Wisconsin voters should do to ensure they're registered properly All of this is a big deal in Wisconsin, a state President Donald Trump won by less than 23,000 votes in 2016, a key factor in his victory.
14: Officials have refused to release the names of those who received the letters, but a Milwaukee Journal Sentinel analysis of the mailings showed 55% went to municipalities won by Democrat Hillary Clinton in 2016.
15: A higher percentage of voters received the mailings in traditional Democratic strongholds, such as Milwaukee, Madison and many college towns.
16: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com State officials want to put off forcing people off the rolls until 2021, not wanting to affect the 2020 election since they aren’t certain all of those people actually moved.
17: Indeed, as of Dec. 5, 2019, the Elections Commission said 2,300 recipients had responded to the letter to report they still lived at the same address.
18: By that point, 16,500 recipients had also registered to vote at new addresses, and 60,000 letters had been returned as undeliverable.
19: But a lawsuit brought in November by three voters with the help of the conservative Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty argued election officials were required to remove voters from the rolls 30 days after sending the letters if they hadn't heard from them.
20: On Dec. 13, 2019, an Ozaukee County judge ruled those people should be removed immediately.

gpt4: The claim that more than 200,000 registered Wisconsin voters will be prohibited from voting due to a voter roll purge is false.

The controversy started in October 2019 when the Wisconsin Elections Commission sent out letters to 234,000 voters whom it believed may have moved, based on information from the post office, Division of Motor Vehicles or other government entities [10].

These letters inquired about the voters' status, specifically asking them to either re-register at their new address if they had moved or confirm they were still at the same address if they hadn't [12][1].
By that point, 16,500 voters had registered at new addresses, and 60,000 letters were returned as undeliverable [18].

Although a lawsuit was filed which argued that election officials were required to remove voters from the rolls 30 days after sending the letters if they hadn't heard from them [19], state officials intended to delay forcing people off the rolls until 2021 to avoid affecting the 2020 election, due to uncertainty about whether all these people had indeed moved [16].
This decision was affirmed by an Ozaukee County judge ruling that those individuals should be removed immediately [20].
Despite the legal developments, the removal of such voters from the roll would not prohibit them from voting, contrary to the claim made.

fc818756b16b6b4b785d96793dd5c9f1.claim: An old image shows a drug store with a marijuana leaf sign.
fc818756b16b6b4b785d96793dd5c9f1.label: false
fc818756b16b6b4b785d96793dd5c9f1.passage:
0: A viral social media post shows an old, black-and-white photograph of a drug store with a marijuana leaf painted above its entrance.
1: Text above the photo reads: "They say history repeats itself."
2: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The photo isn’t legitimate.
5: A reverse-image search led us to a February 2009 post on the website Deviant Art , where the image was shared under the description tags of mash-ups, pop culture and memes.
6: Multiple comments on the page congratulate the poster on the photo manipulation, and one commenter asks for a link to the original photograph, to which the poster replies that they can’t find it anymore.
7: The manipulated image also appears on meme websites , including a page of altered mashup images .
8: However, the notion that marijuana was used for medicinal purposes in the 1800s isn’t wrong.
9: According to PBS , the U.S.-marijuana relationship dates back to the Colonial Era, and it wasn’t until the 1930s that the government started to criminalize the drug: "American production of hemp was encouraged by the government in the 17th century for the production of rope, sails, and clothing.
10: (Marijuana is the mixture of dried, shredded flowers and leaves that comes from the hemp plant.)
11: Domestic production flourished until after the Civil War, when imports and other domestic materials replaced hemp for many purposes.
12: In the late 19th century, marijuana became a popular ingredient in many medicinal products and was sold openly in public pharmacies."
13: Nevertheless, this photo does not appear to be authentic.

gpt4: The claim that an old image shows a drug store with a marijuana leaf sign is false.
This has been proven by a viral social media post which displayed a black-and-white photograph of the store with alleged marijuana signage [0].
However, a deeper investigation has revealed that this photo lacks legitimacy [4].

In fact, a reverse-image search traced the source of the image to a February 2009 post on the website Deviant Art, where the image was shared under the tags of mash-ups, pop culture, and memes, thus indicating that the image was manipulated and not an authentic historical photograph [5].

This was further substantiated by multiple comments congratulating the poster on the photo manipulation and human requests for a link to the original photo, which the poster admitted they could not locate [6].

aa4cfa76a7df32cd14b2ed8a603f946c.claim: "  President Trump’s mother said, ""Yes, he’s an idiot with zero common sense, and no social skills, but he is my son. I just hope he never goes into politics. He’d be a disaster."""
aa4cfa76a7df32cd14b2ed8a603f946c.label: false
aa4cfa76a7df32cd14b2ed8a603f946c.passage:
0: Viral social media posts are spreading a questionable quote attributed to President Donald Trump’s mother.
1: The posts – like this one – show a black-and-white photograph of President Trump and his mother, Mary Anne Trump.
2: The quote attributed to her reads: "Yes, he’s an idiot with zero common sense, and no social skills, but he IS my son.
3: I just hope he never goes into politics.
4: He’d be a disaster."
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: This does not appear to be a legitimate quote from President Trump’s mother.
8: The post gives no details or citations as to when or where the statement was made, and a search of news archives turns up no trace of it.
9: The quote cannot be found in any interviews or books and only appears to exist in the form of memes and social media posts.
10: Other fact-checking websites have also been unable to locate the statement outside of social media.
11: Mary Anne Trump passed away in 2000 , and if she had said such an inflammatory statement about her son, it would have likely come up in the news cycle during his 2016 presidential campaign.
12: There is no credible evidence to suggest this quote is real.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump's mother allegedly referred to him as an 'idiot with zero common sense' and hoped he wouldn't go into politics is false.
The statement appears to exist solely in the form of memes and social media posts, but the quote cannot be traced back to any verifiable interviews or publications[9].
Furthermore, the post lacks any specific details or evidence such as the time or place when the comment was supposedly made, and an exhaustive search of news archives yields no trace of it[8].
This claim has also been vetted by other fact-checking websites, all of which have been unable to find any authentic source or credible evidence to support it outside of social media[10][12].

c4b8568739243d6112af65b5d5aa5e3f.claim: I (found) the Republican votes for the Recovery Act, Obamacare, help us from falling into a Great Depression.
c4b8568739243d6112af65b5d5aa5e3f.label: false
c4b8568739243d6112af65b5d5aa5e3f.passage:
0: Former Vice President Joe Biden said the next president has to unite the country, and having a solid plan for big problems isn’t enough.
1: "We need someone with proven ability to bring people together and do the hard work of getting legislation passed," Biden said at a Dec. 13 rally in San Antonio, Texas .
2: "I have done that before — finding the Republican votes for the Recovery Act, Obamacare, helping us from falling into a Great Depression."
3: Given Biden’s emphasis on uniting the country, a reasonable interpretation is that he was talking about bringing together Democrats and Republicans.
4: Biden’s staff told us he was talking broadly about his track record of passing key legislation, not necessarily to have won support from Republicans.
5: To the extent this was about bipartisanship, the two bills he picked don’t prove his point.
6: When the Democrats took the White House and both houses of Congress in 2009, they inherited a nation on a steep slide into the Great Recession.
7: Their first major act was to pass a bill to kickstart the economy, the $787 billion American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.
8: The bill passed 60 to 38 , the number needed to avoid a filibuster, with just three Republican senators voting in favor: Maine’s Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins, and Arlen Specter from Pennsylvania.
9: Not a single Republican in the House backed the bill.
10: Biden pushed for passage; so did President Barack Obama and the rest of the Democratic leadership.
11: Republicans said a stimulus was needed.
12: They also said the Democratic package cost twice what was needed.
13: "This is one of the most expensive pieces of legislation Congress has ever approved," said then-Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell on Feb. 13, 2009 .
14: "This isn't Monopoly money.
15: It is real.
16: It adds up.
17: It has to be paid back by our children and their children."
18: As for the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act , otherwise known as Obamacare, the sweeping health care reform bill passed in 2010 with zero Republican votes in both the Senate and the House .
19: The bill needed to pass in the Senate with a 60-vote veto-proof majority, which it got.
20: Biden lobbied fellow Democrats to back the measure, but again, so did other Democratic leaders.

gpt4: The claim that the speaker found the Republican votes for the Recovery Act, Obamacare, and helped prevent a Great Depression is false.
Evidence suggests that the Recovery Act bill passed 60 to 38, just enough to avoid a filibuster, with only three Republican senators voting in favor [8].
There were no Republican votes in the House to support the bill [9].
Regarding the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, it passed in 2010 with no Republican votes in the Senate or the House [18].
Thus, the claim that Republican votes were found for these significant bills is not accurate.

0539d453edb3a3682247b3f10631f806.claim: " California firefighters decided ""to speak out"" against President Trump because his tweet about the state’s wildfires ""contained so much misinformation."""
0539d453edb3a3682247b3f10631f806.label: true
0539d453edb3a3682247b3f10631f806.passage:
0: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden attacked President Trump in a new digital campaign ad , which claims California firefighters "spoke out" against the president over his controversial tweet during the state’s deadly November 2018 wildfires.
1: Trump’s tweet, which was his first public comment on the fires, blamed the state’s poor "forest management" for the infernos and threatened to withhold federal funding.
2: Biden’s ad includes images of California burning and the head of the state’s largest firefighters union calling Trump’s statement "idiotic."
3: "Firefighters say the tweet contained so much misinformation, they had to speak out," the ad claims.
4: Is Biden’s ad right?
5: Did California firefighters, beyond the union president, really criticize Trump during the wildfires?
6: We set out on a fact check.
7: The Camp Fire rages through Paradise, Calif., on Thursday, Nov. 8, 2018.
8: Noah Berger / AP Photo Background on the fires The ad references Northern California’s Camp Fire and Southern California’s Woolsey Fire, both of which broke out in November 2018.
9: The Camp Fire killed 86 people in Butte County and destroyed nearly 19,000 structures, including 14,000 homes, making it the state’s most deadly and destructive wildfire in history.
10: The Woolsey Fire killed three people and destroyed more than 1,600 structures.
11: Here’s Trump’s tweet from Nov. 10, 2018: Shortly after, PolitiFact California fact-checked Trump’s claim that forest management is the sole reason for the fires.
12: We rated it False.
13: Forestry and climate experts told us stronger winds, higher temperatures and drier conditions driven by climate change are also making California’s fires worse.
14: They said forest management is one factor, but not necessarily the driving force.
15: In another tweet two days later, Trump thanked California’s firefighters and first responders.
16: He also approved California's request for a major disaster declaration, freeing up federal aid for fire response and recovery.
17: Criticism from firefighters The most vocal fire leader to criticize Trump was Brian Rice, president of the California Professional Firefighters.
18: Rice is shown in the Biden ad saying "That statement was idiodic," referring to Trump’s tweet.
19: The comments were lifted from an interview Rice did with a San Francisco TV news station.
20: In the full interview, he added: "It was ill timed.
21: And it’s ignorant.
22: It’s a statement of an ignorant man.
23: … I love my country.
24: I am proud to be an American.
25: But I am disgusted with my president."
26: In an interview this week, Rice called Biden's ad "fair and accurate."
27: A union spokesperson said Rice "clearly spoke out," citing a formal statement he issued at the time.
28: "The statement pretty clearly indicates that Mr. Rice believes Mr. Trump’s tweet was misinformed," he said.
29: Rice said his chapter fully supports the decision of its national union to endorse Biden’s 2020 presidential bid.
30: The International Association of Fire Fighters announced its support for Biden in April.
31: Biden is in a virtual tie with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren among likely voters in California’s Democratic primary, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls .
32: A spokesperson for Biden’s campaign attributed all of the ad’s statements, including the claim that firefighters spoke out against the president, to news coverage.
33: The claim in question, that "Firefighters say the tweet contained so much misinformation, they had to speak out," comes directly from a TV reporter narrating a news story .
34: We found Rice wasn’t the only fire leader to criticize Trump’s words.
35: The Biden ad includes a brief clip of Los Angeles Fire Chief Daryl Osby, pulled from a separate TV interview .
36: In it, he says the state is "in extreme climate change right now."
37: That by itself isn’t a biting critique.
38: But Osby goes on to say in his full interview: "I personally find that statement unsatisfactory … It’s very hurtful for all first responders that are putting their lives on the line to protect lives and property."
39: Tom O’Connor, president of the San Francisco Fire Local 798, also criticized Trump’s tweet, telling a TV station after asked about the tweet that, "Now is not the time for politics.
40: It’s a time for leadership.
41: It’s not the ‘red and blue states of America.’ It’s the United States of America."
42: Finally, Scott Austin, president of the Pasadena Firefighters Association said in a tweet : "Mr. President, with all due respect, you are wrong.
43: The fires in So.
44: Cal are urban interface fires and have NOTHING to do with forest management.
45: Come to SoCal and learn the facts & help the victims.
46: Scott Austin, Pres IAFF 809."
47: The Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment.

gpt4: The claim that California firefighters chose to voice their objections against President Trump due to the inaccuracies in his tweet about the state's wildfires is confirmed as true.
The most vocal firefighter leader to critique Trump was Brian Rice, president of the California Professional Firefighters [17], who is shown in a Biden ad labeling Trump's statement as "idiotic"[18].
This Biden ad also contains images of California on fire [2] and includes a brief clip of Los Angeles Fire Chief Daryl Osby from a separate TV interview [35].

Additionally, other fire officials such as Tom O’Connor, the president of the San Francisco Fire Local 798, spoke against Trump's tweet, highlighting the inappropriate timing of the politics involved [39].

Scott Austin, the president of the Pasadena Firefighters Association, expressed via a tweet that the wildfires in California are urban interface fires and do not pertain to forest management [42][44].
As the ad claims, firefighters stated that the tweet contained so many errors, they felt the need to voice their objections [3].
Other fire leaders were also found to have criticized Trump's statements [34].

35e6e0db42e76e39b615358962629c19.claim: "  minimum markup law goes beyond gas, tobacco and alcohol to make ""many doorbuster deals and holiday shopping specials technically against the law."""
35e6e0db42e76e39b615358962629c19.label: false
35e6e0db42e76e39b615358962629c19.passage:
0: There’s nothing Wisconsinites love more than a good deal — it’s baked into all those not-so-subtle price drops we sneak into responses to compliments.
1: "Nice sweater!"
2: "Thanks, I got it for 43 cents at Kohl’s since it was clearance and then I had 30% off coupon and I had Kohl’s cash and…."
3: But one state lawmaker says there’s a problem with some of those deals, especially when it comes to Black Friday-style doorbusters – they’re illegal.
4: In a Dec. 13, 2019, email to constituents , state Sen. Dale Kooyenga condemned what he called the "Wisconsin Grinch" -- the state’s minimum markup law.
5: The law — most commonly known for setting baseline prices for gas, alcohol and tobacco products — actually prohibits far more than that, he said.
6: "The minimum markup law also forbids retailers from selling most other products below cost," said the Brookfield Republican.
7: "That makes many doorbuster deals and holiday shopping specials technically against the law.
8: It’s essentially a state-mandated profit margin."
9: Could doorbusters really be illegal?
10: Let’s dig into the law books.
11: The history The minimum markup law — technically called the Unfair Sales Act — dates back to the Great Depression.
12: It seeks to ensure fair competition among businesses by taking aim at "loss leaders" -- items priced below cost to draw in customers for other purchases, or to drive a competitor out of business.
13: Several other states have similar laws .
14: Wisconsin’s nonpartisan Legislative Fiscal Bureau described the law’s origin this way in a 2019 informational paper : The Unfair Sales Act took effect in the 1930s with the intent of preventing predatory pricing by large firms.
15: It was thought that large firms could reduce prices below cost to levels smaller firms could not match.
16: Larger firms would incur short-term losses but drive smaller firms out of business.
17: It was thought the remaining large firms would use near-monopoly power to charge exorbitant prices after smaller firms were mostly forced from the market.
18: The law itself describes selling below cost as "a form of deceptive advertising and an unfair method of competition in commerce."
19: These pricing limitations have remained on the books despite efforts from both parties to limit them.
20: Republican lawmakers proposed repealing the law, or parts of it, in 2015 and 2017, to no avail.
21: The repeal was opposed by numerous agriculture and business and tourism interests, and favored by just one registered entity — Walmart, according to the Wisconsin Democracy Campaign .
22: And in 2019, Democratic Gov.
23: Tony Evers hit a wall with a budget proposal to repeal the minimum markup for gasoline.
24: The Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection enforces the law, along with local district attorneys.
25: Violators can face forfeitures of up to $500 for first-time offenders and $2,500 for repeated violations, but there is no active monitoring of pricing since the agency only investigates based on complaints.
26: For example, someone filed a complaint in 2015 when Meijer, new to the area, was selling bulk instant coffee for $4.98, the Milwaukee Business Journal reported.
27: But no one has been fined for such a violation in at least a decade, said Ti Gauger, spokesman for the department.
28: So what exactly is banned?
29: Limits on retailers The law is best known for its effect on prices for gas, alcohol and tobacco products.
30: Each of these must be marked up 3% above cost by the wholesaler and 6% by the retailer, the statute says.
31: But the law also says all other products cannot be sold below the seller’s cost under a section titled "illegality of loss leaders."
32: It says sales under cost "with the intent or effect of inducing the purchase of other merchandise or of unfairly diverting trade from a competitor, impairs and prevents fair competition, injures public welfare and is unfair competition.
33: … Such sales are prohibited."
34: As proof of Kooyenga’s claim, spokesman Chris Rochester pointed to the statutory wording above and a 2017 memo from the Legislative Fiscal Bureau that summarized the law as generally prohibiting sales below cost.
35: That said, the statute does offer a number of exceptions where sales below cost are allowed, including sales for charity, under court order or as part of a government contract.
36: These are the other five exceptions spelled out in the law: 1.
37: "Bona fide" clearance sales 2.
38: Prices set to match a competitor’s documented price 3.
39: Perishable merchandise 4.
40: Damaged or discontinued merchandise 5.
41: Pre-closing liquidations sales Statutes can be open to some interpretation, but we’ll assume the "clearance sales" referenced are where retailers are clearing out excess stock, or making way for new stock.
42: And doorbusters won’t always involve matching a competitor’s documented price.
43: The other three wouldn’t apply to doorbusters.
44: That leaves a swath of low-priced specials that would appear to violate the law if below cost.
45: But that’s a key if.
46: It’s often assumed that doorbuster deals like those on Black Friday are sold below cost, as referenced in reports published by CNBC , the Washington Post and others.
47: But Jerry O’Brien , an expert on retail industry trends at the University of Wisconsin, said the actual invoice cost is "incredibly difficult" to pin down.
48: That’s because agreements between vendors and retailers often depend on many factors outside of actual production cost.
49: They can factor in whether one side is providing advertising, whether the vendor provides in-store services, such as keeping the item stocked, and how returns are handled.
50: For example, the vendor could lower the price by a set percentage if the retailer agrees to simply discard returns instead of sending them back to the vendor.
51: "I’m really not sure anyone in the state is openly breaking the law.
52: I’d say the law has a lot of room for wiggle," said O’Brien, executive director of the Kohl’s Center for Retailing Excellence.
53: "When you’ve got these giant vendors selling to these giant retailers, they’re negotiating some amazing invoices that would probably stand up (to the law’s requirements)."
54: Kooyenga’s office did not respond to a request for evidence of specific retailers that have sold below cost in Wisconsin.

gpt4: The claim that "Minimum markup law goes beyond gas, tobacco and alcohol to make many doorbuster deals and holiday shopping specials technically against the law" is false.
This claim was first made in an email to constituents by state Sen. Dale Kooyenga, who referred to the state’s minimum markup law as the "Wisconsin Grinch"[4].
He identified the minimum markup law as prohibiting retailers from selling most products below cost [6].

However, the statutory wording shared by Chris Rochester, a spokesperson for Kooyenga, and the summary of the law in a 2017 memo from the Legislative Fiscal Bureau do indicate that there is a general prohibition on sales below cost, providing substantiation to the claim [34].
But what changes the veracity of the claim are the exceptions in which sales below cost are allowed, which include sales for charity, under court order, or as part of a government contract [35].
This flexibility in the law allows for deals and holiday shopping specials, despite the pricing restrictions that remain on the books [19].

7db80ec361462c9eaa34545806167817.claim: In November 2019, Speaker Pelosi said it would be ‘dangerous’ to leave it to voters to determine whether President Trump stays in office.
7db80ec361462c9eaa34545806167817.label: false
7db80ec361462c9eaa34545806167817.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Doug Collins, R-Ga., misquoted House Speaker Nancy Pelosi as he argued unsuccessfully against the impeachment of President Donald Trump.
1: "In November 2019, Speaker Pelosi said it would be ‘dangerous’ to leave it to voters to determine whether President Trump stays in office," said Collins, ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee, Dec. 18 on the House floor.
2: Collins’ claim is False.
3: This is a mischaracterization of what Pelosi told Democratic members a month before the House passed two articles of impeachment.
4: (The near-party-line vote set up a trial in the Republican-controlled Senate early next year.)
5: Collins is referencing a Nov. 18 open letter to Democrats in which Pelosi justified impeachment.
6: Here’s what she said, in context: "The facts are uncontested: that the President abused his power for his own personal, political benefit, at the expense of our national security interests.
7: "The weak response to these hearings has been, ‘Let the election decide.’ That dangerous position only adds to the urgency of our action, because the President is jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
8: A Fox News reporter distilled her message this way in his report: "Pelosi circulated a memo to Democrats tonight telling them it would be dangerous to let voters decide President Trump’s fate."
9: Trump referenced that quote in a tweet an hour after chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel said it on Fox News.
10: From there, the claim was repurposed into several popular Facebook posts, which we previously rated False.
11: Emanuel did not say he was quoting Pelosi directly, but his paraphrase is distorted.
12: And so is Collins’.
13: Pelosi said waiting for the election is dangerous because she believes the president is "jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
14: She did not say it’s dangerous to leave it to voters to determine whether Trump stays in office, as Collins said she did.
15: We reached out to Collins’ press office for comment, but we haven’t heard back.
16: The statement is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that Speaker Pelosi declared it would be 'dangerous' to allow voters to decide whether President Trump stays in office is false.
Indeed, during a speech in November 2019, Pelosi did use the word "dangerous" but her meaning has been misunderstood and taken out of context[14].
What Pelosi actually said was: "The weak response to these hearings has been, ‘Let the election decide.’
That dangerous position only adds to the urgency of our action, because the President is jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections"[7].
Instead of expressing fear of voters' decision, Pelosi was pointing out the risk of allowing potentially manipulative actions to influence an election.
Her statement was therefore not directly about the danger of voters deciding, as Collins - the ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee - has claimed[1].

545d481e425e3d72c7e62f9a8db0ad62.claim: When Jesus was falsely accused of treason, Pontius Pilate gave Jesus the opportunity to face his accusers. During that sham trial, Pontius Pilate afforded more rights to Jesus than the Democrats have afforded this president in this process.
545d481e425e3d72c7e62f9a8db0ad62.label: false
545d481e425e3d72c7e62f9a8db0ad62.passage:
0: During the House debate on the articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump , Rep. Barry Loudermilk closed his remarks with a statement that drew its own headlines.
1: "Before you take this historic vote today, one week before Christmas, I want you to keep this in mind," the Georgia Republican said Dec. 18.
2: "When Jesus was falsely accused of treason, Pontius Pilate gave Jesus the opportunity to face his accusers.
3: During that sham trial, Pontius Pilate afforded more rights to Jesus than the Democrats have afforded this president in this process."
4: The comparison didn’t stand up well among experts in religion and law.
5: Loudermilk’s evidence We asked Loudermilk’s press secretary, Brandon Cockerham, for information to back Loudermilk’s statement, but didn’t get a reply.
6: The Catholic News Agency reported that Cockerham defended the statement in an email to the news service, saying: "Congressman Loudermilk was simply making a comparison about the process; that Pontius Pilate allowed Jesus (to) face his accusers, but the Democrats refused to allow the president or Republicans to even know who the accuser was, much less the right to question him or her."
7: Cockerham was alluding to the whistleblower , whose complaint about Trump’s dealings with Ukraine triggered the impeachment proceedings.
8: That person’s identity has remained confidential.
9: But Loudermilk didn’t single out the whistleblower; rather, he alluded to multiple accusers.
10: Jesus’ case Several passages from the New Testament of the Bible tell how Jesus appeared before Pontius Pilate , a Roman governor, before being crucified.
11: During Passover, Pilate freed any prisoner the people asked for.
12: Jesus was accused of blasphemy and treason for stating he was the King of the Jews.
13: From Matthew Chapter 27 , on the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops’ website: Now Jesus stood before the governor, and he questioned him, "Are you the king of the Jews?"
14: Jesus said, "You say so."
15: And when he was accused by the chief priests and elders, he made no answer.
16: Then Pilate said to him, "Do you not hear how many things they are testifying against you?"
17: But he did not answer him one word, so that the governor was greatly amazed.
18: Jesus received no due process before Pilate, according to Robert Tuttle , professor of law and religion at George Washington University.
19: "He just questions Jesus and says he finds no fault, then asks the crowd what they want done."
20: The passages from the biblical books of Matthew (chapter 27), Mark ( chapter 15 ) and Luke ( chapter 23 ) "pretty much agree on the story," said Douglas Laycock , a professor of law and religious studies at the University of Virginia.
21: "No one says that Jesus was offered a lawyer, or a chance to bring one, or a chance to call his own witnesses.
22: No one said he could testify in writing if he didn't want to answer orally," Laycock told us.
23: "They say the priests and scribes made accusations; no one says that any witnesses were called to support those accusations.
24: Pilate thought Jesus was innocent, but the mob demanded his execution and Pilate finally acquiesced."
25: Trump’s case The House’s impeachment proceedings were akin to an investigation by the police, a prosecutor or a grand jury — and due process rights are not granted.
26: Trump’s trial will be in the Senate.
27: Trump was not denied a fair hearing, said Michael Gerhardt , author of "Impeachment: What Everyone Needs to Know" and a University of North Carolina professor of law who testified before Congress in support of impeaching Trump.
28: "He was invited but declined, and still had his bully pulpit."
29: Allan Lichtman , author of " The Case for Impeachment " (from April 2017) and a history professor at American University, said Trump’s supporters in the House and their attorneys could have cross-examined witnesses, Trump declined an invitation to present a defense before the Judiciary Committee, and he blocked witnesses from appearing.
30: "The only comparison between these two proceedings is that they both pretty much refused to defend themselves in the actual tribunal," Laycock said.

gpt4: The claim that Pontius Pilate afforded more rights to Jesus than the Democrats have to Trump in the impeachment process is false.
The comparison has been refuted by experts in religion and law[4].
Robert Tuttle, a professor of law and religion at George Washington University, points out that Jesus received no due process before Pilate[18].
Although Pilate believed Jesus was innocent, he ultimately succumbed to public pressure and permitted the execution[24].

In contrast, Allan Lichtman, author and history professor at American University, highlights that during the House’s impeachment proceedings — akin to an investigation by law enforcement or a prosecutor — Trump’s supporters and their attorneys were given the opportunity to question witnesses.
However, Trump declined the invitation to present a defense before the Judiciary Committee and blocked witnesses from appearing[29].
