In this context, the impeachment proceedings do not grant due process rights, similar to a police investigation or a grand jury[25].
The lack of such rights in the impeachment process is in stark contrast to the supposed rights Jesus was afforded.

0125ad6bdbdebb865949ea7357d32657.claim: "  President Donald Trump ""has not given this Congress a single email, phone record or document."""
0125ad6bdbdebb865949ea7357d32657.label: half-true
0125ad6bdbdebb865949ea7357d32657.passage:
0: On a day that ended with President Donald Trump becoming the third U.S. president to be impeached, House Democrats hammered Trump for refusing to comply with their investigation, saying his stonewalling proved he has something to hide.
1: "(This) was an attempt by Donald J. Trump to aim Ukrainian corruption straight at the heart of the presidential election of 2020," said Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut, a Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee.
2: "The president knows this, which is why he has not given this Congress a single email, phone record or document."
3: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The White House did release summaries of Trump’s April 21 and July 25 phone calls with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
4: But when we examined whether the administration transmitted any other records to Congress, we found that it defied the House’s multiple requests and subpoenas for documents.
5: In a statement to PolitiFact, a White House official said the call readouts are "what matters."
6: "The White House raised well-recognized presidential privileges in response to these document requests," the official said.
7: "House Democrats chose not to address those privileges, clinging instead to an artificial impeachment deadline on their sham proceeding."
8: The White House pledged not to cooperate In early October , the House Intelligence, Oversight and Foreign Affairs committees subpoenaed the White House for Ukraine-related documents that Democrats had requested but not received.
9: In response, White House Counsel Pat Cipollone sent a letter to Congress saying the executive branch would not be participating in the investigation.
10: At the White House’s direction, several top administration officials also defied subpoenas seeking testimony or documents.
11: The night before European Union Ambassador Gordon Sondland was expected to testify, for example, his attorneys received a last-minute call from the State Department informing them that the Trump administration would not allow his testimony.
12: Sondland eventually testified against the White House’s orders and in response to a subpoena , but his recollections in both his private and public testimony were limited because the White House refused to turn over documents and call records.
13: Nine administration officials defied similar subpoenas from the House.
14: "The executive branch cannot be expected to, and will not participate in, this exercise of partisan political theater," White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said in a statement .
15: House Democrats elected not to take the issue up in court.
16: Instead, they packaged Trump’s efforts to block cooperation into an article of impeachment alleging obstruction of Congress.
17: The obstruction of Congress article, which the House approved by a 229-198 margin, charges Trump with "directing" the White House and various executive branch agencies "to defy lawful subpoenas and withhold the production of documents."
18: What documents did Congress get?
19: According to the House Intelligence and Judiciary Committees’ reports, "not a single document" was produced by the White House, the vice president’s office, the Office of Management and Budget, the State Department, the Defense Department or the Energy Department.
20: In total, those agencies received "71 specific, individualized requests or demands for records," the committees’ reports said.
21: The House did obtain some documents, such as text messages that former special envoy to Ukraine Kurt Volker exchanged with Sondland and other U.S. and Ukrainian diplomats, that were in witnesses’ "personal possession," according to the Judiciary Committee’s report .
22: But multiple witnesses testified to the existence of other key White House documents that Congress never received.
23: These materials included: • Talking points prepared ahead of Trump’s July 25 call with Zelensky by Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, director for European affairs at the National Security Council.
24: • Notes taken during Trump’s call with Zelensky by Vindman and by Tim Morrison , the former top Russia expert on the NSC.
25: • A memo prepared by Vindman that former National Security Adviser John Bolton was expected to present to Trump conveying "the consensus views from the entire deputies small group" that "the security assistance be released."
26: • Call records between Trump and Sondland.
27: • Notes from NSC legal advisor John Eisenberg detailing his discussions with Vindman about a July 10 meeting with a top Ukrainian official , during which Sondland suggested that investigations could help secure a White House meeting for Zelensky.
28: • The readout of Trump’s Sept. 25 meeting with Zelensky in New York.
29: The House Intelligence Committee’s Republican minority report does not dispute that Trump’s White House withheld these and other documents.
30: But it notes that Trump made readouts of his April 21 and July 25 phone calls with Zelensky publicly available, calling them "directly relevant."
31: Himes spokesman Patrick Malone said the readouts were released in response to public pressure rather than congressional subpoenas.
32: The White House published the July 25 call summary on Sept. 25, days after news of the whistleblower complaint broke and one day after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi launched the House impeachment inquiry.
33: "They weren’t released to Congress in response to our requests," Malone said.
34: "They were released to the public."

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump "has not given this Congress a single email, phone record or document" is partially true.
The White House did release summaries of Trump's phone conversations with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on April 21 and July 25[3], and these were indeed made public[34].
The July 25 call summary was published by the White House on Sept. 25[32].
However, in terms of other forms of documentation, the Trump administration did not comply with the House's multiple requests and subpoenas for additional documents[4].
In reaction to these requests, White House Counsel Pat Cipollone sent a letter to Congress stating that the executive branch would not be participating in the investigation[9].

Indeed, according to reports from the House Intelligence and Judiciary Committees, no documents were submitted by the White House itself, the Vice President's office, or several other government departments[19].
Therefore, while it's not accurate to say that the Trump administration gave no information at all, it is true that they did not provide any emails, phone records, or other documents.

638072687c4d09f7c7de435c82683982.claim: Last year, ""for the first time in 51 years, the cost of prescription drugs actually went down."""
638072687c4d09f7c7de435c82683982.label: false
638072687c4d09f7c7de435c82683982.passage:
0: At the 2020 State of the Union , President Donald Trump zeroed in on prescription drug prices, arguing that his administration is "taking on the big pharmaceutical companies."
1: Among the evidence for that claim: a talking point the administration has been using since last April.
2: "I was pleased to announce last year that, for the first time in 51 years, the cost of prescription drugs actually went down," Trump said.
3: We’ve examined this claim twice before, rating it Mostly False .
4: But prescription drug prices are a major voter concern.
5: So we wanted to take another look, in case things had changed.
6: Experts told us the data remains essentially unchanged.
7: Drug prices are still not going down.
8: The old talking point Last spring, Trump’s team pulled this claim from two sources: A 2018 report from the president’s Council of Economic Advisers and data comparing the January 2019 Consumer Price Index for drugs to the January 2018 one.
9: The CPI data suggested a decline in drug prices.
10: But when we spoke to experts, they quickly debunked this position.
11: For one thing, CPI data is imperfect — it shows list prices, rather than what consumers pay at the pharmacy counter.
12: For another, it only covers drugs sold through retail, which accounts for about three-quarters of all prescriptions.
13: That misses high-priced specialty drugs which are only sold through mail.
14: Plus, other metrics showed that drug prices had in fact gone up, although by very little.
15: Last April, for instance, the same CPI data indicated an increase — between April 2018 and April 2019, drug prices had increased by 0.3%.
16: Data from the Kaiser Family Foundation also suggested an increase in total spending on drug prices that year, even if growth had slowed.
17: What’s changed?
18: Today, prices aren’t going up as fast as they were before, said Stacie Dusetzina, an associate professor at Vanderbilt University, who studies drug pricing.
19: But they’re still going up.
20: "That probably doesn’t provide the average person with much relief," she said.
21: Meanwhile, there’s the question of individual list price increases.
22: (List prices are defined as what’s charged before rebates — a number few people pay, but that dictates negotiations.)
23: The CPI data paints with a broad brush, drug pricing analysts said, obscuring just how many drugs have seen and continue to see their prices go up.
24: In 2019, 4,311 prescription drugs experienced a price hike, with the average increase hovering around 21%, according to data compiled by Rx Savings Solutions, a consulting group.
25: Meanwhile, 619 drugs had price dips.
26: And already in 2020, 2,519 drugs have increased prices.
27: The average hike so far this year is 6.9%.
28: Meanwhile, 70 drugs have had their prices go down.
29: Typically, branded drugs increase their prices early in the year, and generics do so later, said Michael Rea, the CEO of Rx Savings Solutions.
30: When generics post their price increases, the 2020 average price hike will likely go up.
31: "As a broad brush stroke, the story remains the same.
32: Drug prices are going up, not down," Rea said.

gpt4: The claim that "for the first time in 51 years, the cost of prescription drugs actually went down" last year is false[3].
When this claim was previously examined, it was rated as Mostly False[3].
Although it was stated by President Trump[2], experts have essentially disagreed with his assertion[6][10].
In fact, different metrics showed that drug prices had marginally increased rather than decreased[14].
For example, data from the Consumer Price Index (CPI) showed a 0.3% increase in drug prices between April 2018 and April 2019[15].
Additionally, the Kaiser Family Foundation recorded an increase, albeit slowed, in total spending on drugs during that year[16].
Furthermore, there were 4,311 prescription drugs in 2019 that saw an average price hike of around 21%[24], and there have already been price increases for 2,519 drugs in 2020[26].
Therefore, contrary to the claim, drug prices are still on the rise[19].

fe84f719061bd6cd842e2e5e169cbed1.label: true
fe84f719061bd6cd842e2e5e169cbed1.passage:
0: In the Democratic debate in Los Angeles, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders pushed back against the idea that President Donald Trump can point to a strong economy as he runs for re-election.
1: "Trump goes around saying the economy is doing great," Sanders said Dec. 19.
2: "You know what real inflation accounted-for wages went up last year?
3: 1.1%.
4: That ain't great."
5: According to the latest U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics numbers, Sanders is correct.
6: The agency reported that real average hourly earnings were 1.1% higher in November compared with 2018.
7: When people talk about real earnings, they mean how much workers make after taking the cost of living into account.
8: When costs rise, it eats away at the increase people see in their paychecks.
9: There are other ways to track wage trends.
10: For real median weekly wages for all full-time workers, the rise was 1.3% over the course of the year, again using government data.
11: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com After the Great Recession, real wages began to grow again in 2014.
12: The highest jump was 2.2% in 2015.
13: There’s no way to quantify whether a 1.1% increase "ain’t great," as Sanders said.
14: Broadly, the rise is consistent with the long-running economic growth the country has seen.
15: It is not the biggest increase workers have seen in recent years.
16: But looking back to 1980, the average yearly change is .3%.
17: In that light, 1.1% is better than average.
18: The trends, however, will vary depending on the sort of workers (all workers, or just production and nonsupervisory ones) and the time period.
19: In general, for the production and nonsupervisory group, real weekly earnings have been rising since the late 1990s, with significant dips during recessions.
20: There is an encouraging sign for lower wage workers.
21: In 2018, wages rose fastest for those at the bottom end of the pay scale.
22: With wages, there are many possible ways to slice the data, and no single measure captures the full story.

gpt4: The claim that "real wages" increased by 1.1% last year is indeed accurate, as per the latest data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics [5].
This percentage signifies the growth of real average hourly earnings in November as compared to the same period in the previous year [6].
To better understand this figure, it's important to highlight that 'real earnings' refers to the total earnings of workers after considering the cost of living [7].
Therefore, this rise shows an increase in earnings even after adjusting for inflation or living expenses.

62668dae334cc3c1cf3a3cf1fc5d0474.claim: "  Pete Buttigieg ran statewide in Indiana and ""lost by 20 points."""
62668dae334cc3c1cf3a3cf1fc5d0474.label: true
62668dae334cc3c1cf3a3cf1fc5d0474.passage:
0: One of the testier back-and-forths at the Democratic presidential debate in Los Angeles centered around electability, focusing on two candidates from the Midwest who say they can best connect with voters who backed President Donald Trump in 2016.
1: Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., went after South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, saying "Winning matters.
2: I think a track record of getting things done matters."
3: Buttigieg responded, "If you want to talk about the capacity to win, try putting together a coalition to bring you back to office with 80% of the vote as a gay dude in Mike Pence’s Indiana," to prolonged applause.
4: But Klobuchar had her own applause-line ready: "If you had won in Indiana, that would be one thing.
5: You tried and you lost by 20 points."
6: People following the 2020 Democratic presidential primary probably know a little bit of Buttigieg’s background as mayor and his successful re-election.
7: But they probably haven’t heard the election story Klobuchar is referencing.
8: Before Buttigieg was first elected mayor in 2011, he ran for Indiana state treasurer in 2010.
9: He lost the general election to Republican Richard Mourdock by nearly 25 percentage points , according to voting records kept by the Indiana Secretary of State.
10: Buttigieg received 37.54% of the 1.68 million votes cast.
11: Mourdock, a tea party Republican, received 62.46% of the vote.
12: Mourdock went on to run for the U.S. Senate in 2012, defeating incumbent Richard Lugar in the Republican primary before losing in the general election to Democrat Joe Donnelly.
13: Mourdock, you might remember, said during that Senate campaign that when a woman is impregnated during a rape "it’s something God intended."
14: As for Buttigieg and the 2010 treasurer’s race, it’s important to note that: 1.
15: Mourdock was the incumbent in the race; 2.
16: No Democrat in Indiana won statewide in 2010; and 3.
17: No Democrat has been elected state treasurer in Indiana since 1979.
18: Comments Buttigieg made during that race have come up in the current campaign.
19: Buttigieg attended a meet-up of tea party activists at a South Bend church.
20: Video of Buttigieg speaking includes the following lines.
21: "There are some, especially in my party, who think that the tea party is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Republican Party," Buttigieg said .
22: "But there are many others who believe that the tea party is motivated by real concerns about the direction of our government, and the responsiveness of our government to citizens, and above all the frustration with business as usual.
23: That is what motivated me to run.
24: And so while we may come from often very different perspectives, I believe we might find that we have a lot in common on that front."
25: The Buttigieg campaign for president has said his 2010 comments make clear he comes from " a very different perspective ."
26: Further reading : Roll Call’s take on Buttigieg’s 2010 election .

gpt4: The claim that Pete Buttigieg ran a statewide campaign in Indiana and lost by 20 points is indeed true.
Before Buttigieg's tenure as mayor of South Bend, he campaigned for the position of Indiana state treasurer in 2010[8].

Unfortunately, the outcome of the election wasn't in his favor, as he was defeated by Republican Richard Mourdock by nearly a margin of 25 percentage points, as per voting records maintained by the Indiana Secretary of State[9].

Despite the past loss, Buttigieg later highlighted his achievement of winning office back with an overwhelming majority in a conservative state while defending his winning capability responding to the remarks of Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn[1][3].

a77c8a40ba31ccbdc4859f4130c09cb0.claim: If you're a black woman, you're 320% more likely to die from complications in childbirth.
a77c8a40ba31ccbdc4859f4130c09cb0.label: true
a77c8a40ba31ccbdc4859f4130c09cb0.passage:
0: In an exchange about racial inequality at December’s Democratic presidential primary debate, businessman Andrew Yang  highlighted jaw-droppingly different health outcomes between black and white women, and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders picked up that thread.
1: "If you're a black woman, you're 320% more likely to die from complications in childbirth," Yang said in a discussion about racial disparities between black and white Americans.
2: Sanders returned moments later, arguing, "Black women die three times at higher rates than white women."
3: Those figures, which are roughly equivalent, would speak to glaring inequities in the health care system.
4: So we decided to dig in.
5: We reached out to both the Yang and Sanders campaigns for comment.
6: The Yang campaign referred us to data from a May 2019 report on maternal mortality disparities from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
7: The context, and the data Based on the context of the debate, we also interpreted Sanders as discussing maternal mortality gaps between black and white women — an issue that public health researchers say is a major concern, and one that’s garnered sizable attention on Capitol Hill.
8: The best data comes from the CDC report Yang’s team cited.
9: The May report outlines maternal mortality disparities, using data from 2011 to 2015 and select data from 2013 to 2017.
10: Per the CDC, 700 women in the United States were reported to die from pregnancy-related complications each year.
11: Non-Hispanic black women were 3.3 times as likely as non-Hispanic white women to die from complications in childbirth — data that roughly tracks with both Yang and Sanders’ stat.
12: So, while their phrasing may have been inelegant, the point is correct.
13: What’s at stake Experts say most of these deaths are preventable.
14: One issue: Hospitals that predominantly serve black women are often worse-performing than those that serve mostly white women — and that, researchers say , contributes to the gap.
15: Another issue comes from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
16: It released a comprehensive guide in May on preventing maternal mortality, which provided data showing that cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of pregnancy-related death, and it disproportionately affects women of color.
17: "Most of these deaths are preventable, but we are missing opportunities to identify risk factors prior to pregnancy and there are often delays in recognizing symptoms during pregnancy and postpartum, particularly for black women," said ACOG former president Dr. Lisa Hollier in a press release about the guide.
18: Black women’s risk of dying from cardiovascular disease while pregnant is 3.4 times higher than that of white women.
19: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists said this disparity is in part due to racial bias and overt racism in the medical system, with black women’s cardiovascular disease risk not being addressed before they become pregnant.
20: Dr. Neel Shah, an assistant professor of obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive biology at Harvard Medical School, said that both candidates reported the CDC statistics accurately.
21: He also reiterated that this disparity persists irrespective of education or income and stems from medical providers’ implicit bias.
22: "When black women express concerning symptoms, particularly pain, the health system is slower to respond," Shah wrote via email.
23: "The reasons are surprising but also apparent to nearly everyone who works in health care.
24: Clinicians are trained to profile people by race — nearly every exam question in medical school tells you the race of the patient and reinforces race-based associations."

gpt4: The claim that black women are 320% more likely to die from complications in childbirth has been validated as true.
Andrew Yang asserted this during a discussion about racial disparities, indicating that the increased risk pertains to black women[1].
His statement was based on the data provided in a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) from May 2019[6][8].
According to this report, non-Hispanic black women were indeed 3.3 times more likely to suffer fatal childbirth complications compared to non-Hispanic white women[11].
This statistic concurs with both Yang and Sander's assertions.

Dr. Neel Shah, an assistant professor at Harvard Medical School specializing in obstetrics, gynecology, and reproductive biology, further confirmed the accuracy of the candidates reporting of the CDC data[20].

5142df058cf86ffb3c945388ab6a4bdd.claim: They banned face masks in Hong Kong. Why? Because they have AI technology that now is using facial recognition to identify protesters if they so much as do anything on the street, so they can follow up with them and detain them later.
5142df058cf86ffb3c945388ab6a4bdd.label: half-true
5142df058cf86ffb3c945388ab6a4bdd.passage:
0: Entrepreneur Andrew Yang slammed the reaction to ongoing protests in Hong Kong, accusing the government of using new technologies to punish pro-democracy activists for speaking out.
1: "They banned face masks in Hong Kong," Yang said during the presidential debate in Los Angeles.
2: "Why?
3: Because they have AI technology that now is using facial recognition to identify protesters if they so much as do anything on the street, so they can follow up with them and detain them later."
4: We wondered if Yang’s description of Hong Kong’s artificial intelligence capabilities was accurate, so we decided to dig into the matter.
5: We found that the ban on face masks has been stalled in the courts, and the facial recognition technology has not necessarily been used in the way Yang suggested.
6: The face-mask ban is currently lifted, pending appeal Hong Kong is a part of China but governs itself independently.
7: That "one country, two systems" setup has been in place since the United Kingdom returned the former colony to China in 1997.
8: In June, pro-democracy protesters took to the streets to rebel against a Chinese bill that would have allowed for extradition from Hong Kong to China for certain serious crimes.
9: Even after the bill was withdrawn , the unrest has continued, with protesters pushing for larger demands and Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam’s resignation.
10: In October, Lam invoked emergency powers to ban protesters from wearing face masks, making the act punishable by fines and jail time.
11: A court in Hong Kong ruled the ban unconstitutional the next month before allowing it to be temporarily reinstated days later.
12: Then, in December, the South China Morning Post reported that a court lifted the ban again, pending an appeal that is set to take place in January.
13: So currently, there’s no ban in place, but the final decision has not been made.

gpt4: The claim that face masks were banned in Hong Kong in order to use AI facial recognition technology for identifying and detaining protestors is partly accurate.
It is true that face masks were banned in Hong Kong, as stated by Andrew Yang during a presidential debate [1].
This ban was indeed invoked by Lam under emergency powers in October, to prevent protesters from wearing face masks, potentially leading to fines or imprisonment [10].
However, by December, a court lifted the ban, though an appeal was scheduled for the following month [12].

As for the assertion that the ban was specifically to facilitate the use of facial recognition technology to identify and subsequently detain protestors, it's worth noting that while there are claims of such technology being used, it hasn't been categorically established how it has been utilized in relation to the protests [5].
So, while some aspects are factually correct, the claim isn't fully substantiated and is therefore regarded as half-true.

ec074dc7e8e07ee7d642fc232c631fcf.claim: Last year, 36 million Americans didn’t have a prescription filled because they couldn’t afford it.
ec074dc7e8e07ee7d642fc232c631fcf.label: true
ec074dc7e8e07ee7d642fc232c631fcf.passage:
0: During a heated exchange over health reform during the December Democratic presidential primary debate Thursday, Sen. Elizabeth Warren turned to the topic of high prescription drug prices.
1: "Last year, 36 million Americans didn’t have a prescription filled because they couldn’t afford it," the Massachusetts senator said.
2: Drug prices are a persistent hot-button issue, and one of the health issues voters say they most want Washington to take on.
3: So we decided to take a closer look.
4: We contacted the Warren campaign, which directed us to a February survey from the Commonwealth Fund, a foundation headquartered in New York.
5: The data The Commonwealth data supports Warren’s point; in fact, it’s a slightly larger number than she said on the debate stage.
6: In 2018, the researchers estimate, 37 million non-elderly adults went without filling a prescription because they could not afford it.
7: That’s almost 1 in 5 of the U.S. population.
8: Having coverage, the researchers note, doesn’t guarantee you’ll afford medication.
9: The survey makes a point of noting the 87 million non-elderly adults are uninsured, experienced a gap in coverage or "underinsured" — which means they had coverage the entire year, but still faced out-of-pocket costs (excluding premiums) that imposed a substantial financial burden.
10: That’s another point Warren — and other candidates — repeated during the debate’s health care portion.
11: "Those are people with health insurance, as well," Warren added.
12: "People who can't do the copays, people without can't do the deductibles."
13: The Commonwealth paper suggests much of this "underinsurance" issue comes from deterioration of health plans Americans get through work, which is the way most non-elderly Americans get coverage.
14: Commonwealth isn’t the only organization to look at this question of prescription drug affordability.
15: A November poll from West Health and Gallup surveyed more than 1,000 adults, asking them if, in the past 12 months, they had not had enough money to afford a doctor-recommended medication.
16: About 23% of respondents reported such an issue — a figure Gallup extrapolated to suggest 58 million Americans experiencing what it called "medication insecurity."
17: Meanwhile, a February poll from the Kaiser Family Foundation found that of adults taking prescription drugs, about one in four reported some difficulty in affording that medication.
18: (KHN is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
19: The findings drive home a crucial point: broadly, Warren’s number matches what the data shows.
20: If anything, it could be even worse than she suggested.

gpt4: The claim that last year, 36 million Americans didn’t have a prescription filled because they couldn’t afford it is indeed accurate.
It has been stated as such by the Massachusetts senator [1].
This statement is supported by data from The Commonwealth, which corroborates the senator's claim and actually estimates a slight increase in the numbers [5].
The researchers estimate that in 2018, 37 million non-elderly adults were unable to afford their prescription and therefore did not have it filled [6].

d08472adac5571d514673d67d8fc9d02.claim: "  the New York Times reported that Hillary Clinton and George Soros ""paid (a) woman to accuse Trump of sexual attack."""
d08472adac5571d514673d67d8fc9d02.label: false
d08472adac5571d514673d67d8fc9d02.passage:
0: A conservative website is misrepresenting a New York Times story to spin a conspiracy about George Soros and Hillary Clinton.
1: The Red Pilled News, whose name borrows from a term that’s popular among fascists online, published a story Nov. 29 that claims the liberal financier and the former Democratic presidential candidate paid women to fabricate sexual assault allegations against President Donald Trump.
2: "The names of two of were (sic) uncovered by the NY Times and both are attached to the evilness.
3: Guess who?
4: George Soros and Hillary Clinton," the story reads.
5: The article, which has been shared more than 87,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from the Red Pilled News) We took a look at the New York Times story cited by the Red Pilled News.
8: It doesn’t prove what the website says it does.
9: The article, which was published in December 2017, reported how some political operatives have raised money to support accusers bringing sexual harassment charges against Trump and members of Congress.
10: The story noted how the influx of partisan money could muddy the waters of the #MeToo movement.
11: For allegations made specifically about Trump, the story focuses on two lawyers (and Democratic donors): Gloria Allred and her daughter Lisa Bloom.
12: Both women raised money from "influential Democrats" to support women accusing Trump of sexual misconduct, according to the Times.
13: Bloom asked one pro-Clinton super PAC for money to help her vet a claim against the president after he received the Republican nomination.
14: But Bloom told the Times she did not communicate directly with Clinton or her campaign.
15: And the story doesn’t mention Soros.
16: RELATED: Exaggerated post connects Clintons, Russia, uranium deal The other article that Red Pilled News cited was published by the Hill in December 2017.
17: It also reported on Bloom’s efforts but found no connection to Clinton or Soros.
18: Red Pilled News’ domain was created in late September, according to WhoIs data.
19: Many of its articles contain grammatical mistakes, and the site includes a share button for VKontakte, a Russian social media site that’s been a hotbed for disinformation.
20: Soros and Clinton were popular targets of Russian disinformation in 2016.
21: We could not confirm who or what is behind the Red Pilled News site.
22: But an analysis from Hoaxy, a tool that detects automated Twitter accounts, shows that a sizeable number of bot-like accounts have amplified the site’s content.
23: The Red Pilled News article is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that the New York Times reported that Hillary Clinton and George Soros paid a woman to accuse Trump of sexual assault is false.
When examining the relevant New York Times story cited by the Red Pilled News[7], it was observed that the contents of the story do not confirm the website's claims[8].
Furthermore, the person concerned, Bloom, had expressed in her interview with the publication that she had not been in direct communication with Clinton or her campaign[14].
George Soros is not even mentioned in the New York Times story[15].
An additional review of Bloom's actions revealed no discernible link to either Clinton or Soros[17].
It's imperative to assess sources critically to ensure accurate interpretation and mitigate the spread of misinformation.

5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.claim: 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year.
5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.label: false
5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.passage:
0: In a tweet promoting legislation that he says will improve children’s access to cancer treatments worldwide, U.S. Rep. Michael McCaul shared a startling statistic about the likelihood of surviving cancer for children born in developing nations.
1: "A child’s chance of surviving cancer should not be determined by where they are born," said McCaul, a Republican from Austin.
2: "But sadly, this is the case.
3: 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year.
4: That is why I introduced the #GlobalHopeAct so children have access to life saving treatments."
5: A reader flagged McCaul’s statement about children dying of cancer and asked us to fact-check the statistic — which is inaccurate.
6: We found that his claim is a misquote of a finding by the World Health Organization that just 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured.
7: McCaul’s spokeswoman Rachel Walker pointed to the World Health Organization’s fact-sheet on childhood cancer as the source for the congressman’s statement.
8: "In high-income countries more than 80% of children with cancer are cured, but in many low- and middle-income countries only about 20% are cured," reads the fact-sheet, published in September of 2018.
9: If 20% of children with cancer are cured, it is safe to assume that 80% are not, which would explain the figure McCaul cited in his claim.
10: But he applied the number to an entirely different pool of people — every child born in developing countries — and created a new, inaccurate statistic.
11: The World Health Organization finding measured survival rates for children diagnosed with cancer in different countries.
12: It did not measure what percentage of all children born in different countries die from cancer each year.
13: When reached via email, Walker acknowledged that "a few words were left out in the tweet," but the larger claim McCaul made still stands: "Too many kids die from curable cancers and we are working to change that with our bill."
14: She also pointed to the video accompanying his tweet and noted that McCaul communicated the statistic differently.
15: "The mortality rate for children diagnosed with cancer in developing nations is a staggering 80%, matching the survival rate here in the United States," McCaul said in the video.
16: We decided to pursue a fact-check of the language in McCaul’s tweet, since it was flagged by a reader and is more readily accessible than the language he used in the video.
17: Plus, it is still visible online and has not been corrected.

gpt4: The claim that 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year is false.
A reader flagged this statement by McCaul which prompted us to fact-check it and we found it to be inaccurate[5].
Our investigation revealed that this claim is a misquotation of a finding by the World Health Organization[6].

The original data from the World Health Organization measured survival rates for children diagnosed with cancer in different countries, reporting that only 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured[11].
However, McCaul misapplied this statistic, incorrectly attributing it to every child born in developing countries, thus creating a distorted and incorrect statistic[10].
The WHO research did not estimate what percentage of all children born in different countries die from cancer each year, hence McCaul's claim is patently false[12].

636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.claim: a photo shows a white man smiling while holding a black man with a bloody face.
636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.label: false
636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.passage:
0: A popular Facebook post says people should stop talking about former NFL player Michael Vick and dogfighting and instead reflect on a picture that seemingly shows violence against a black man by a smiling white man.
1: "I am a big animal lover, but stop bringing up Michael Vick when this is in your history!!!
2: The man did his time and constantly gives back.
3: But you want us to forget about this," said text above a photo that shows a black man with a bloody face being grabbed up by a white man who appears to be looking at the photographer and either smiling or grimacing.
4: Another white man in a U.S. Army sweatshirt is also in the photo, standing next to the black man and looking at the camera.
5: Vick served time in prison after pleading guilty to charges related to a dogfighting ring run in a property he owned.
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: The caption in the Facebook post implies that the white men in the photo attacked the bloodied black man and that one smiled about it.
9: That’s not an accurate account.
10: The Associated Press photo is from June 21, 1943.
11: News organizations that have used the photo say the image shows two young white men helping a black man to his feet after he was badly beaten in street fighting during race riots in Detroit .
12: The captions don’t explain why one of the men appears to be smiling, or if he’s actually grimacing.
13: The photo posted to Facebook is also cropped and doesn’t show that the man in the U.S. Army sweatshirt in one hand has a rag, seemingly with blood from the black man.
14: The cropping also doesn’t fully show that the black man is hardly able to stand on his own.
15: Time magazine in 2014 published a slideshow of photos from the 1943 race riots.
16: One of the photos features the three men but in a different setting, walking huddled; in this shot, the man that appeared to be smiling in the other photo has a worried look.
17: The caption says that the white men are helping the black man to safety, and that black people reported many instances of aid from white people during the rioting.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows a white man smiling while holding a black man with a bloody face is not truthful.
Close examination reveals that the Associated Press photo in question is actually from June 21, 1943[10].
In the image, two young white men are seen helping a black man to his feet after he was badly hurt during street fighting amid race riots in Detroit, as reported by news outlets [11].
There is also another picture taken from a different setting where the three men are walking huddled and the man who was seen as smiling in the initial photo actually appears worried [16].
Therefore, the initial assertion does not provide an accurate account of what the photos depict [9].

5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.claim: "  the California congressional district he represents ""has a higher GDP than Russia."""
5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.label: false
5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.passage:
0: Just how insignificant is Russia in the global economy?
1: Quite insignificant, argued Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif., in a Dec. 20 interview with MSNBC’s Hallie Jackson.
2: Khanna was discussing President Donald Trump and his warm relations with Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.
3: Khanna told Jackson that he was mystified why Trump would pick Putin as a global partner.
4: "Here is what is so shocking," Khanna said .
5: "Russia is not even a top-10 economy any more.
6: I mean, my district in Silicon Valley has a higher GDP than Russia."
7: (GDP refers to gross domestic product, or the sum of all economic activity in a given jurisdiction.)
8: Does a single California congressional district with 777,468 residents really outpace an entire nation of 144 million people ?
9: No, and Khanna acknowledged that after PolitiFact contacted him.
10: "I misspoke," Khanna said in an email.
11: "What I meant to say is that two companies in my district — Apple and Google — have a higher market capitalization, $2 trillion, than Russia’s economy, and that California has a higher GDP."
12: Let’s look at the numbers.
13: Russia’s GDP in 2018, according to the World Bank , was $1.66 trillion.
14: That ranks 11th in the world, behind the United States, China, Japan, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, India, Italy, Brazil, and Canada.
15: As for Khanna’s congressional district, California’s 17th, we were able to find a calculation by the Brookings Institution’s Metropolitan Policy Program.
16: Earlier this year, the think tank calculated GDP for every congressional district in 2018 and published summary numbers in the Wall Street Journal .
17: The article doesn’t include individual figures for every district, but Brookings researchers provided a figure for Khanna’s district: $103.9 billion.
18: So Russia’s GDP is about 16 times bigger than the GDP for Khanna’s district.
19: The entire state of California, meanwhile, had a GDP just shy of $3 trillion in 2018, so California as a whole does outpace Russia in GDP.
20: What about Khanna’s point about market capitalization?
21: Market capitalization is the total market value of all outstanding shares in a company.
22: It’s a different measurement than GDP, which measures all economic activity within a locale.
23: So the two aren’t directly comparable, but they can give a rough sense of scale.
24: Apple’s market capitalization was $1.25 trillion on Dec. 20.
25: Google’s was $932.3 billion.
26: So the total for the two companies is $2.2 trillion.

gpt4: The claim that the California congressional district represented by Ro Khanna has a higher GDP than Russia is inaccurate.
In 2018, Russia's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) was $1.66 trillion, according to the World Bank[13].
It was pointed out that Russia’s GDP was approximately 16 times greater than the GDP for Khanna’s district[18].

While the entire state of California did have a near $3 trillion GDP in 2018, which meant it marginally outpaced Russia's GDP, it is misleading to attribute this to an individual district within the state[19].
Khanna acknowledged the error in his remark, stating "I misspoke" in an email[10].
Hence, the claim is false.

b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.claim: “As the State Department warned Mizzou in July 2019, and as I have repeatedly stated, (the Confucius Institute) presented security risks for students & university as a whole.”
b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.label: false
b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., applauded the University of Missouri following its announcement that the university’s Confucius Institute will shut down in August.
1: "Pleased Mizzou is shutting down the#China Communist Party funded ‘Confucius Institute.’ As the State Department warned Mizzou in July 2019, and as I have repeatedly stated, this program presented security risks for students & university as a whole," Hawley tweeted Jan. 15.
2: Hawley has criticized the Confucius Institute and raised questions about the program in the past, including when he sent a letter to MU Chancellor Alexander Cartwright on July 24 urging him to "reconsider the costs and risks that come with allowing a Confucius Institute to remain on (Mizzou’s) campus, and with entering any other agreements with the Chinese government."
3: That wasn’t the first time a politician urged a university to shut down its Confucius Institute program citing threats to security; Texas A&M closed its program after two U.S. representatives wrote a letter recommending the action to four Texas universities.
4: We decided to look into whether the State Department really warned Mizzou in July about security risks arising from a Confucius Institute program.
5: We found a letter, but struggled to find a warning.
6: The controversy Mizzou’s Confucius Institute is one of about 500 established worldwide by Hanban, a subsidiary of the Chinese Ministry of Education.
7: Hanban’s website describes Confucius Institutes as nonprofit, public institutions that "aim to promote Chinese language and culture in foreign countries."
8: Hawley criticized Hanban in his letter to Cartwright, saying that it is governed by leaders of 12 Chinese ministries, including those that handle media and propaganda.
9: He also said universities that partner with Hanban sign contracts that prohibit "tarnishing the reputation" of Hanban, and they send teachers and textbooks designed to promote a positive image of China.
10: In the United States and across the globe, universities have been shutting down their programs amid concerns and investigations.
11: BBC News reported in September 2019 that a "flurry" of universities worldwide had closed their programs in the preceding weeks.
12: Mizzou announced on Jan. 14 that its contract with the Confucius Institute will be terminated, effective in August, according to a news release from the university .
13: The main reason: a change in State Department guidelines that now requires a certified Mandarin teacher to accompany classrooms with Confucius Institute staff members.
14: The Confucius Institute instructors were classified as interns on exchange visas, not teachers.
15: The university said it would cost too much to make the changes in categories.
16: DOWNLOAD THE LETTER The release says the State Department notified Mizzou in a July letter.
17: Hawley’s press secretary confirmed with us this is the same letter he was referring to in his tweet.
18: So, did the State Department warn Mizzou that the Confucius Institute presented security risks?
19: MU spokesperson Christian Basi provided us the July 15 letter from the Department of State’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs.
20: It was signed by Henry C. Scott, director of the Office of Private Sector Exchange Program Administration.
21: There’s no direct warning given by the State Department here.
22: The letter was meant to notify Mizzou of violations in its Confucius Institute program that were found by the department and address how to fix them.
23: The letter states the exchange program administration attempts to help sponsors of a Confucius Institute program correct errors when the office notices them.
24: It addressed specific areas of concern.
25: The first area of concern was Confucius Institute student interns teaching in K-12 classrooms without a supervisor who speaks Mandarin.
26: The language barrier "creates a vulnerability, as efficacy of the co-teacher’s supervision is severely limited," the letter states.
27: If that is a warning about security, it’s pretty opaque.
28: The other areas of concern listed were failures to comply with required form signatures and worker’s compensation policies, improperly listing Confucius Institute student interns’ primary site of activity and misusing a "Research Scholar" role defined by the department.
29: There is no specific mention of potential risks to students or Mizzou in the letter.

gpt4: The claim that the State Department warned Mizzou in July 2019 about security risks from the Confucius Institute program is false.
Our investigation indicates that the State Department's letter to Mizzou did not specifically mention or direct any potential risks to the students or the university[29].
Instead, the letter was intended to notify Mizzou of violations found by the Department within its Confucius Institute program [22].
The letter contained instructions on how to address these violations, yet it did not issue a direct warning about any security risks arising from the Confucius Institute program [21][4].

c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.claim: "  Bill Gates will provide ""money-500K, car, phone, visa"" or other gifts if you email him."
c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.label: false
c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.passage:
0: Bill Gates is a generous man.
1: Through his Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation , he gave away $4.78 billion in 2017 and $138 million in 2018, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy .
2: But the founder of Microsoft won’t just send you $500,000 just for reaching out to him on social media, as a post now circulating on Facebook says.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The post purports to come from "Bill Gate Foundation" (yes, the post misspelled his name) and features a photograph of Gates helping provide health care to a family that appears to be from Africa, a longtime mission of Gates’ (real) foundation.
6: The post repeats the misspelling in the text: "MY NAME IS BILL GATE, I AM THE RICHEST MAN IN THE WORLD "Tell me one thing you need from me, and i will do it for you "1.
7: M0NEY - 5OOK "2.
8: CAR "3.
9: PHONE "4.
10: VISA "5.
11: SCHOLARSHIP TO STUDY ABROAD "6.
12: PROMOTE YOUR BUSINESS "7.
13: OTHERS SIGNIFY "Use the (SEND MESSAGE) button below and send me a message today, and I will surprise you.. "Start now!"
14: One tipoff that the post is fake is that it does not come from the genuine Gates Foundation Facebook page , which has a blue-checkmark verification.
15: Social media experts will remind users to always be skeptical with posts claiming to be from celebrities but lack a verified status.
16: We also checked with a representative of the real foundation, and they confirmed to us via email that the post did not come from them.
17: The foundation has struggled with scammers trading on their name for years.
18: The post does not come from Bill Gates’ foundation, so don’t expect any gifts to follow.

gpt4: The claim circulating on Facebook that Bill Gates will provide "$500K, car, phone, visa" or other gifts if you email him is false[2].
One significant indication that the post is fraudulent is that it does not originate from the official Gates Foundation Facebook page, which is marked with a blue-checkmark verification[14].
Additionally, we confirmed the falsehood of the claim with a representative of the actual foundation, who verified via email that the post did not originate from their organisation[16].

869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.claim: "  Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam is planning to cut off the electricity ""so Virginia residents cannot reveal what is happening once gun confiscation begins to take place."""
869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.label: false
869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.passage:
0: Ahead of a potential vote on an assault weapons ban in Virginia, some Facebook users are posting misinformation about the legislation.
1: The source of the false information is a white supremacist with a rap sheet and a history of spreading conspiracy theories.
2: One post published Dec. 16 includes a screenshot of a tweet from user @cindyseestruth, which appears to be an automated account.
3: The tweet claimed Virginia Gov.
4: Ralph Northam, a Democrat, is planning drastic measures to take away guns.
5: "WARNING… VIRGINIA GOV RALPH NORTHAM SET TO.. Cut off electric… telephones… faxes… cellular phones & cellular data, Internet, so #Virginia residents cannot reveal what is happening once gun confiscation begins to take place," the tweet reads.
6: The Facebook post, which has been shared nearly 10,000 times, was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) There’s no evidence for this disconnected conspiracy.
9: While a variety of gun control legislation has been introduced in Virginia, one bill is particularly relevant to the Facebook post and tweet: Virginia Senate Bill 16 .
10: The measure, which was introduced in late November, would ban the possession, transport and sale of assault weapons.
11: The bill includes six definitions for "assault weapons," which include anything from a semi-automatic rifle to a shotgun with a revolving cylinder.
12: Democrats will take control of both the Senate and the House of Delegates in January, which helps the chances for passage.
13: But there’s no evidence that Northam would cut off the state’s electricity to enforce the legislation or suppress news about enforcement.
14: SB 16, which would make the possession of an assault weapon a felony, does not spell out how it would deal with firearms that Virginians already own.
15: Northam has said he would call on law enforcement to enforce the bill, and he’s pushed back on resolutions that deem certain cities "Second Amendment sanctuaries."
16: "We're not going to take people's guns away," he told reporters Dec. 11.
17: RELATED: All statements involving Guns In its tweet, which got more than 2,000 retweets, @cindyseestruth linked to a story published Dec. 13 by the Hal Turner Radio Show.
18: Other Twitter bots have also amplified the article, according to Hoaxy, a tool that tracks automated accounts.
19: Hal Turner is a white supremacist who uses internet and radio broadcasts to float conspiracy theories and hate speech.
20: In 2010, he was sentenced to 33 months in prison for threatening three federal judges over their decision to uphold handgun bans in Chicago.
21: The story contains the tweet’s claim about shutting down cellular infrastructure almost verbatim.
22: In an email, Alena Yarmosky, Northam’s press secretary, said that it is "absolutely false."
23: "People who spread lies like this should be ashamed of themselves," she said.
24: We reached out to Turner for more evidence to support his site’s claim, but we haven’t heard back.
25: The Facebook posts are inaccurate and make a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that Virginia Governor Ralph Northam is planning to cut off electricity to prevent residents from revealing activities surrounding gun confiscation is not accurate.
The governor clearly stated that there are no plans to confiscate guns from the citizens[16].

Furthermore, there is no evidence suggesting that Northam would resort to such extreme measures as severing the state's power supply in a bid to enforce legislation or suppress news about enforcement[13].
This misinformation has been directly rebutted by Northam's press secretary, Alena Yarmosky, who affirmed via email that the allegation was absolutely false[22].

81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.claim: I am very proud that I am the only candidate in the Democratic primary to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets.
81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.label: false
81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.passage:
0: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders isn’t a big fan of President Donald Trump’s latest defense spending bill.
1: Tuesday morning, the U.S. Senate voted 86-8 in favor of the $738 billion National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2020, sending it to the president for his signature.
2: The day before senators passed the legislation, Sanders published an op-ed in the Washington Post panning the proposal, writing he opposes the bill as he as "all previous Trump military budgets."
3: Hours after the Tuesday vote, the Vermont senator and Democratic candidate for president doubled down, posting a video to his campaign’s social media accounts, in which Sanders explained how cutting defense spending could pay for his proposed social programs.
4: Sanders begins his video with a claim about his voting record on Trump’s defense spending proposals.
5: "I am very proud that I am the only candidate in the Democratic primary to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets," Sanders says in the campaign video .
6: But Sanders, like many other candidates who also serve in the Senate, missed this week’s vote.
7: So how can he claim to have voted against it?
8: And is he actually the only anti-Trump presidential candidate in the Democratic field who has voted against all of the president’s defense budgets?
9: Starting with the voting record Sanders’ presidential campaign declined to comment on the statement, referring questions to Sanders’ Senate office.
10: Keane Bhatt, Sanders’ Senate spokesperson, pointed to the Vermont independent’s votes against the defense budget bill for fiscal years 2019, 2018, and 2017.
11: Bhatt deferred back to the campaign on the first part of Sanders’ claim that he is the only candidate in the Democratic primary to vote against all of Trump’s military spending bills.
12: The campaign did not respond with evidence to support this part of the statement.
13: Sanders has voted against the last three national defense authorization bills but he was not present in the Senate for Tuesday’s vote on the bill he has publicly opposed.
14: Sanders’ Senate office also said his vote against the defense spending bill fiscal year 2017 was evidence he has voted against all of Trump’s military budget bills.
15: However, the Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2017 was signed by former President Barack Obama on Dec. 23, 2016, and not by Trump.
16: A survey of Sanders’ record on Trump’s defense spending bills has him voting against the first two but missing the vote earlier this week .
17: The Vermont independent also missed the chance to vote on this year’s military spending bill in June when the Senate moved it to the House of Representatives.
18: Democratic candidates against military budgets Sanders also claims he is the only candidate in the Democratic primary who has voted against all of the president’s defense budgets.
19: Sens.
20: Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., Cory Booker, D-N.J., and Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., all missed this week’s vote on the military spending bill.
21: Warren voted against last year’s defense budget, but supported Trump’s first national defense authorization proposal.
22: Booker and Klobuchar have supported both of Trump’s previous military budget bills.
23: However, there is one other candidate in the crowded Democratic field who has cast votes in opposition of all three of the president’s defense authorization bills.
24: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, D-Hawaii — who is polling between 1% and 3% nationally and has remained in the race as others have started dropping out — was one of 48 House members to vote against the current $738 billion spending proposal.
25: Gabbard has also cast no votes on the legislation in 2018 and 2017 — Trump’s two other military budgets.
26: The House member from Hawaii also voted against President Obama’s last defense spending budget in 2016 .

gpt4: The claim that the speaker is the only candidate in the Democratic primary to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets is false.
According to records, Sanders voted against the last three defense authorization bills but was absent for a recent vote on a bill which he had publicly opposed [13].
A survey of Sanders’ voting record demonstrates that he voted against the first two of Trump’s defense spending bills, but missed a vote this week[16].
However, it should be noted that the Defense Authorization Act for the fiscal year 2017 was signed into law by former President Barack Obama, not President Trump [15].
Furthermore, there is another Democratic candidate, Gabbard, who also voted against all three of Trump's defense budgets for 2018 and 2017 [23][25].

4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.claim: "  his opponent for NC Insurance Commissioner is a ""perennial candidate"" over 30 years."
4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.label: true
4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.passage:
0: One of North Carolina’s more obscure political races will feature familiar opponents.
1: Wayne Goodwin, the chairman of the North Carolina Democratic Party, plans to challenge Insurance Commissioner Mike Causey.
2: They faced off in 2016.
3: On Twitter this weekend, Goodwin cast himself as the more serious and experienced candidate, having held the office from 2009 to 2017.
4: Causey was the first Republican to be elected to the office this century, when he won election in 2016.
5: In a tweet , Goodwin referred to Causey as a "30 (year) perennial candidate for (the) same office."
6: It takes a lot of money and energy to run one campaign, much less multiple campaigns over the course of three decades.
7: That level of commitment is uncommon.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com So we wondered: how many times has Causey run for insurance commissioner over the last 30 years?
9: There have been seven elections for Insurance Commissioner since 1990.
10: Causey, who has a background in the insurance industry, ran in many of them -- but not all of them.
11: Race history Here’s a look back each race for Insurance Commissioner over the last 30 years, and whether Causey participated.
12: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Note: Goodwin should’ve known a little about the Republican in the 2008 election , since he won the seat by beating a different candidate -- John Odom.
13: If Causey follows through with his plan to run for re-election in 2020 (he already filed to run ), he’ll have run in six of the last eight elections, or 75 percent of them.
14: Other campaigns Goodwin specifically noted Causey’s history of running for the "same" office.
15: This could be interpreted to mean Causey has only ever run for one office.
16: That’s not the case.
17: In 2014, Causey ran for Congress in the 6th Congressional District.
18: But he didn’t make the November ballot, having placed seventh in the Republican primary that May.
19: He also ran for state Senate in 2002, the race in District 28 to Democrat Katie Dorsett.
20: Goodwin has some other races on his record, too.
21: In 2004, he lost a bid to unseat Republican Cherie Berry as Labor Commissioner.
22: Two years before that, he won an NC House race.
23: And in 1996, Goodwin was elected to the NC House after running unopposed.
24: Another meaning Finally, let’s look at the term "perennial candidate."
25: The word can be a bit squishy, as an Ohio newspaper columnist once pointed out .
26: Goodwin told us he used the term only to communicate that Causey has run frequently, and in that sense he’s right.
27: He also pointed out that, if had intended to say Causey ran in every election since 1990, he would’ve used the word " quadrennial " -- meaning someone who runs every four years.
28: However, used in the context of politics, the term "perennial candidate" often refers to candidates who don’t have much of a shot at winning.
29: Major media outlets have used the term not only to describe someone who runs frequently -- but someone who almost always loses, and runs despite having questionable qualifications and/or low odds of winning.
30: NPR in 2011 used the term to describe frequent presidential candidates U.S. Rep. Ron Paul, Ralph Nader, and Alan Keyes.
31: The Associated Press has used the term to describe a Reform Party gubernatorial candidate in Mississippi who once promised to establish a series of snow-cone stands to fund state services.
32: The AP used the term again in 2019 to describe a "cult-like figure" and conspiracy theorist who ran one of his several presidential campaigns from prison.
33: Causey’s different from most candidates because he’s won elected office, represented a major political party in the five elections he didn’t win, and has a background in the insurance industry.

gpt4: The claim that Wayne Goodwin's opponent for NC Insurance Commissioner is a "perennial candidate" over 30 years is true.
This assertion was made by Wayne Goodwin, the chairman of the North Carolina Democratic Party, who plans to contest against Insurance Commissioner Mike Causey[1].
Goodwin had referred to Causey as a "30 (year) perennial candidate for (the) same office" in his tweet[5], emphasizing Causey's long-running candidacy status.
Looking at Causey’s political history, he indeed stands out from most candidates due to his representation in multiple elections.
Causey has won an elected office, represented a major political party in five elections that he did not win, and has a background in the insurance industry[33].
He has also filed for re-election in 2020, which adds up to his participation in six out of the last eight elections, or 75% of them[13].
Beyond the insurance office, Causey had run for Congress in the 6th Congressional District in 2014[17] but did not make it to the November ballot[18].
He also partook in the state Senate race in 2002[19].
When Goodwin terms Causey as a "perennial candidate," he intends to depict Causey’s frequent run in elections[26].
However, notwithstanding Goodwin's usage, the term "perennial candidate" in political context often refers to candidates who do not have a substantial shot at victory[28].

ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.claim: " The United States is the only nation ""that grants legal permanent residency to more than a million people per year."""
ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.label: true
ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.passage:
0: There is no doubt the United States is a magnet for immigrants, but with a crackdown on both illegal and legal immigration under President Donald Trump, how does it compare with other countries when it comes to providing residency?
1: According to U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, the U.S. continues to outpace other nations when it comes to granting permanent residency to people entering the country.
2: "There is not another nation on Earth, other than the United States of America, that grants legal permanent residency to more than a million people per year," Johnson tweeted Nov. 13, 2019.
3: The tweet featured a clip of Johnson speaking at a Senate hearing that day discussing migration rates over the past year.
4: Is Johnson right?
5: The language Johnson uses the term "legal permanent residency," which the Department of Homeland Security defines as non-citizens lawfully authorized to permanently live in the U.S.
6: They can also be referred to as "green card" holders.
7: Legal permanent residents, or LPRs, are allowed to work without special restrictions, own property, receive financial aid for higher education and join the military.
8: Though they have the majority of the same rights as a U.S. citizen, green card holders can’t vote in any federal elections and typically are barred from voting in state and local elections as well.
9: When traveling out of the country, authorities may also scrutinize green card holders more than citizens, especially if they intend to be out of the country for a significant length of time.
10: Steven Camarota, director of research for the Center for Immigration Studies, which advocates for lower immigration rates, said the "legal permanent residency" pathway to citizenship is not used in most other countries outside the United States.
11: "LPRs, if they live in the U.S. for 5 years, 3 years if (they’re) spouses of citizens, can get U.S. citizenship -- assuming they do not commit a serious crime," Camarota told PolitiFact Wisconsin in an email.
12: "Other countries admit foreigners for long-term temporary work or study or they even grant them asylum, etc.
13: "But, in most cases, they do not offer them a clear path to citizenship.
14: In that sense, the U.S. is different."
15: Limiting entry We asked Johnson’s office for backup on this claim, but they did not respond.
16: According to the Brookings Institution , a left-leaning think tank, hardline rhetoric and policies under Trump may be having an impact on the declining rate of immigrants into the U.S.
17: In 2018, the foreign-born population in the U.S. rose by 203,000, the lowest level since the first year of the Great Recession in 2007.
18: Over the past decade, the annual increase has ranged between 400,000 and 1 million.
19: The total number of foreign-born people residing in the U.S. in 2018 was 45 million.
20: Of that number, roughly 22.6 million were naturalized citizens and 22.1 were noncitizens -- with half that number estimated to be residing illegally, according to Brookings.
21: According to Department of Homeland Security data from 2017, the most recent year available, the number of people who were given legal permanent residence in the U.S. was still over 1.1 million.
22: How does that compare with other nations?
23: Global comparison Camarota said Canada, Australia and New Zealand are the closest to the U.S. when it comes to granting legal permanent residencies that could lead to eventual citizenship.
24: The Canadian government set out a three-year plan that aims to provide residency to 1 million new immigrants between 2018 and 2020.
25: In 2018, Canada exceeded its goal of accepting 310,000 permanent residents by about 10,000.
26: The target for 2019 was set at about 313,000, while 2020 is set at 340,000.
27: Earlier this year, Australia limited its migration cap to accepting only 160,000 permanent new residents a year over the next four years, with its government emphasizing border protection.
28: New Zealand accepted 142,900 migrants in 2018, which their government considered a high number.
29: Through May 2019, roughly 144,900 migrants arrived in the country this year.
30: Regardless, those numbers all fall short of the U.S. What about European countries that have dealt with an influx of refugees from war-torn Syria?
31: A record 1.3 million migrants applied for asylum across the 28 member states of the European Union, plus Norway and Switzerland in 2015.
32: Though asylum is often temporary, these numbers do show an increase in the number of people being taken in across Europe.
33: Even at the height of admitting asylum seekers, though, no country topped 1 million.
34: In 2015, Germany admitted around 890,000 refugees, according to the English-language German news site, the Local.
35: Robert Warren, a senior visiting fellow at the Center for Migration Studies, said despite immigration upticks from other nations, the U.S. is still in the lead.
36: "No other country admits nearly as many immigrants as the United States over long periods," Warren said.

gpt4: The claim that the United States is the only nation that grants legal permanent residency to more than a million people per year is true.
According to the Department of Homeland Security data from 2017, over 1.1 million people gained legal permanent residence in the U.S [21].

In comparison, in the year 2015, Germany accepted approximately 890,000 refugees [34] while Canada had a plan to grant residency to 1 million new immigrants over the span of three years from 2018 to 2020[24].
Additionally, earlier this year, Australia had put a capping to accept only 160,000 permanent new residents annually for the next four years [27].
New Zealand considered 142,900 migrants that they took in 2018 as a large intake [28].
As stated by Warren, over a considerable time span, no other country grants residency to as many immigrants as does the United States[36].

c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.claim: Cory Booker’s son charged with assault after attack on Santa.
c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.label: false
c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.passage:
0: Satire often morphs into fake news on click-bait sites.
1: That what lies behind a post aimed at embarrassing Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., on AJUAnews.com.
2: (The page is one giant link to another page that tries to dupe the unwary into downloading software they don’t need.)
3: The Dec. 25 headline said, "Cory Booker’s son charged with assault after attack on Santa."
4: The article itself decried, "the Democrats’ War on Christmas," and described how Booker’s son "Elroy Booker flew into a rage this Christmas Eve."
5: "When Elroy came across a sidewalk Santa Claus, collecting alms for charity, his seething anger was unleashed with a relentless assault on the kindly old elf," the article said.
6: "Those who witnessed the attack were horrified at its ferocity."
7: This story was copied from a site that openly states that it posts satire .
8: Booker has no son , much less one named Elroy.
9: The article quotes local police officer Satya Martin.
10: There is no such person in Hope, N.J., a quiet township with under 2,000 residents.
11: Martin gets around, or at least her name does.
12: AJUA had her as the spokeswoman for a non-existent group of Democrats who filed to switch parties to protest the impeachment of President Donald Trump –– another piece of fake news.

gpt4: The claim that Cory Booker's son was charged with assault after an attack on Santa is false.
The primary reason is that Cory Booker does not have a son, negating the possibility of such an incident involving a son named Elroy [8].
Furthermore, the story originated from a website that evidently proclaims that it publishes satirical content, indicating that the information should not be taken as factual [7].
Thus, the claim is baseless and untrue.

4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said, if impeachment ""doesn’t go through, I’ll resign."""
4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.label: false
4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.passage:
0: The website Breaking News offered Christmas Day news aimed to cheer anyone opposed to impeachment.
1: According to Breaking News, on Dec. 25 House Speaker "Nancy Pelosi gave a startling and wholly unexpected statement today during an interview with Belgian magazine ‘Le Mensonge’."
2: Asked what she would do if impeachment failed to get the votes needed to pass, Pelosi said, "I won’t wait around.
3: If it doesn’t go through, I’ll resign."
4: "Hallelujah," the article said.
5: Except, of course, Pelosi never said that.
6: The Belgian magazine "Le Mensonge" doesn’t exist.
7: The word itself means a lie in French .
8: A search of the Nexis news database brought up nothing to back up the site’s claim.
9: This is another example of a material moving from a so-called satire site to a website with no satire disclaimer.
10: The original bunk was dated Dec. 9.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi stated she would resign if impeachment doesn't go through is not true[5].
There is no evidence to substantiate the assertion, as a comprehensive search of the Nexis news database did not return any relevant results[8].
In addition to this, it is claimed that the source of this information was the non-existent Belgian magazine "Le Mensonge"[6].
Therefore, based on these findings, the statement is completely false.

4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.claim: Florida school drops Common Core – soars to number one
4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.label: false
4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.passage:
0: A viral but false story on Facebook invokes the controversial Common Core program endorsed by former President Barack Obama.
1: "Florida school drops Common Core — soars to number one," said the headline in Neon Nettle in June 2018.
2: The same headline has circulated at least since 2017 and gained traction at the end of 2019.
3: Neon Nettle is a London-based website which states that "we believe the mainstream media has become less valid as it continues to push engineered narratives through an ever-increasingly censored internet."
4: The Facebook post was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The story says that a charter school, Mason Classical Academy in Naples, rejected the Common Core State Standards Initiative because it "deliberately dumbs down children,  creating unnecessary and complicated techniques for working out relatively simple problems."
7: Snopes fact-checked the same claim about the school in March 2018 and rated it False.
8: Snopes and news reports show that the charter school never adopted Common Core in the first place, so it makes no sense to claim that getting rid of it was the driving force behind high test scores.
9: State rankings show that the school has consistently been an A-rated school.
10: A St. Augustine Record editorial in February 2019 quoted the school principal, David Hull, disputing the claim that the school vaulted after dropping Common Core.
11: "The general theme of the original article argues that MCA is a charter school that has abandoned Common Core, and doing so catapulted the school to number one status.
12: The pursuit of truth requires humility, so I therefore must admit, although the argument is on the right track, the author misses much of the bigger picture," Hull said.
13: The school’s website makes it clear that it does not adhere to Common Core: "Students in Kindergarten through 8th grade follow the Core Knowledge Sequence (not to be confused with Common Core)."
14: Common Core refers to a set of national education standards adopted by the majority of states, including Florida, during the Obama administration.
15: From the beginning, Common Core faced fierce opposition from some opponents including in Florida.
16: We have fact-checked multiple falsehoods about Common Core including that  the standards aim "to instill federally determined attitudes and mindsets in students including political and religious beliefs ."
17: Florida Gov.
18: Ron DeSantis called for getting rid of Common Core.
19: The state’s education commissioner, Richard Corcoran, is expected to present new state curriculum standards to the Legislature in 2020.

gpt4: The claim that a Florida school improved its position to number one after dropping the Common Core curriculum is factually incorrect.
Investigations from fact-checking organization Snopes and several news reports affirm that the said charter school in question never implemented the Common Core curriculum in the first place.
Therefore, it is invalid to argue that the schooling institution catapulted to the top after discontinuing a program it never adopted [8].
Furthermore, this claim was directly refuted by the school's principal, David Hull, in an editorial published in the St. Augustine Record in February 2019[10].

8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.claim: that four Democrats — Sheila Jackson Lee, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez — made specific, suspect remarks about such topics as the Constitution, abortion and guns.
8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.label: false
8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.passage:
0: Fabricated or misreported quotes by Democratic politicians continue to circulate on social media.
1: A simple black-and-white text post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: The post includes the following purported remarks by politicians: By Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee: "Homicide is the leading cause of murder."
4: By former Vice President Joe Biden: "No ordinary American cares about Constitutional rights."
5: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass.
6: : "Having an abortion is no different than having one’s tonsils removed."
7: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y.: "Owning guns is not a right.
8: If it were a right, it would be in the Constitution."
9: Let’s scrutinize these quotes one by one.
