10: Jackson Lee The quote attributed to Jackson Lee appears to come from a now-defunct blog called the Habanero of Texas.
11: That post, or excerpts of it, was widely shared by other conservatives and pro-gun advocates on social media and in forums.
12: According to one blog that quoted the original Habanero of Texas post, Jackson Lee "held an informal press conference today announcing that her administration, through great efforts and much expense, had completed a decade-old study that focused on the cause of murders in the United States.
13: She was reported as saying that the results were predominantly leaning towards ‘homicide’ as being the primary cause for the murders."
14: The original post appears to have been an attempt at satire, since the direct "quote" attributed by the blog to Jackson Lee is nearly unintelligible: "Datas (sic) uncover (sic) today give us a clearer portrait of a couple of possible cause (sic) for murder, but let’s be clear.. Changes in the atmospheres (sic) and combustibles (sic) also play a roles (sic) in how peoples (sic) are behave (sic).
15: By continuing homicide (sic) and climate changes (sic) we are ascend (sic) ourselves to vulnables (sic), and we cannot deny that, Nor shall we, Nor shall I, Nor shall we all, So say we all (sic).
16: End homicide and end climate change, and we end murder.
17: THIS, we know."
18: The apparent satire may have been inspired by remarks posted by the Blaze, a conservative website, that Jackson made in 2013 .
19: She said in part, "Homicide is the leading cause of death — second-leading cause of death — for young people ages 15 to 24.
20: In my community, African Americans, it is the leading cause of death for those 10 to 24."
21: Biden The statement is not authentic and has circulated the internet for years .
22: We have rated it False .
23: This quote spiraled out of a comment Biden made during a weapons control forum in 2013, but it has been altered and taken out of context.
24: A YouTube video posted in 2015 and titled "Biden: no ordinary American cares about his constitutional rights" has more than 33,000 views.
25: The YouTube video tracks back to a February 2013 address Biden gave during a forum held at Western Connecticut State University, about two months after the Sandy Hook elementary school shooting.
26: At no point during the video does Biden say the words cited in the social media posts.
27: In the clip, he talks about the "roadblocks" that are put up by those who oppose gun control: "They say all you’re going to do is deny law-abiding citizens their rights under the Second Amendment.
28: Not true.
29: They say guns like the AR-15 are needed for self-protection and recreation.
30: They are not.
31: There are plenty of ways you can protect yourself and recreate without an AR-15.
32: They say it isn’t about guns.
33: They’re wrong; it is about guns.
34: Let me say at the outset to all the press: No law abiding citizen in the United States of America has any fear that their Constitutional rights will be infringed in any way.
35: None, zero.
36: Look, common sense facts are these assault weapons are unnecessary and dangerous weapons that put our law enforcement personnel at risk…" Warren Warren did make a comparison between abortion and tonsil removal procedures, but the quote shared in the post is heavily edited and is not something Warren said or wrote.
37: We have rated it Mostly False .
38: In a Jan. 21, 2018, opinion column in Time magazine, she wrote: "On the 45th anniversary of Roe vs. Wade , I think about what has changed since abortions became legal.
39: Our health care system has pretty much dealt with the safety issue: thanks to Roe vs. Wade, abortion is now safer than getting your tonsils out.
40: A lot of women are alive today because of Roe."
41: She made similar statements in a Senate floor speech and an opinion column published in Marie Claire magazine in July 2018.
42: In the piece, Warren links to a Time magazine article , which reported in 2014 that women who get abortions are less likely to have complications than people who have their wisdom teeth removed, citing a study published in the peer-reviewed Obstetrics & Gynecology medical journal.
43: Ocasio-Cortez We didn’t find any credible sources corroborating her purported comment.
44: We rated the claim that she said it Pants on Fire .
45: Ocasio-Cortez’s campaign website said of gun control policy, "Cities and states with strong gun laws have managed to cut gun violence significantly without running afoul of the Second Amendment.
46: Alexandria believes that supporting common-sense gun legislation is necessary for any politician who claims to care about the lives of constituents."
47: Her campaign platform also said she thinks that "it’s clear that the founding fathers did not have assault weapons in mind when they wrote" the Second Amendment, and that she advocates for banning such guns.
48: Among other gun control measures, she thinks domestic abusers and stalkers should have to surrender their firearms, and she wants to require universal and improved background checks before someone can buy a gun.
49: "Keep the severely mentally ill and people with a history of domestic abuse from purchasing guns," Ocasio-Cortez said about a year ago while answering questions on Reddit.
50: "I am a believer in the Second Amendment but this is where I draw the line."
51: All told, each of the four quotes is either made up or seriously mangled.

gpt4: The claim that four Democrats – Sheila Jackson Lee, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez – made specific, questionable remarks about topics including the Constitution, abortion, and guns has been proven to be false.
The original post attributing a quote to Jackson Lee seems to have been an attempt at satire and the content is close to being incomprehensible[14].
Similarly, the statement attributed to Joe Biden is not authentic and has been spreading across the internet for several years[21].
For Elizabeth Warren, she did draw a comparison between abortion and tonsil removal procedures, but the quote shared on the post is heavily edited and isn't a direct quote from Warren[36].
Furthermore, there are no credible sources that corroborate a comment purportedly made by Ocasio-Cortez on this matter[43].

ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.claim: China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution.
ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.label: false
ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.passage:
0: An image on Facebook overstates the amount of pollution produced by China.
1: "China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution!," states a Facebook post .
2: We saw the post on Lexit , a movement to convince Latinos to embrace conservatism.
3: The same image has been posted by other conservative groups on Facebook, too.
4: #LEXIT is a grassroots effort to help Latinos exit the liberal left and embrace conservatism.
5: The Facebook post was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: The Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR) shows that while China is the leading producer of CO2 emissions, it’s far below 90%.
8: EDGAR, a joint project of the European Commissionand the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency, has compiled the percent of emissions by each country for many years.
9: For 2018 , it found that China was responsible for about 30% of the total emissions, putting China at the top.
10: The United States produced about 14% of the emissions, the European Union produced about 9%, and India 7%.
11: The vast majority of countries produced less than 1%.
12: If we examine the same countries by per capita emissions , then China’s production share drops to about 8%.
13: RELATED FACT-CHECK: Does China burn seven to eight times as much coal as the U.S.?
14: The Facebook post shows Greta Thunberg , the Swedish teenager and climate change activist, stating "why are we not going to China?"
15: It then shows billionaire George Soros saying "shut up and stick to the script!"
16: We found no evidence that either made those statements.
17: Thunberg and Soros have been used in multiple false posts.
18: We debunked this one that said Thunberg posed with Soros and ISIS .
19: AFP Fact-Check rated the same claim about China and found it false.
20: We found no evidence that China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions.

gpt4: The claim that China produces 90% of the world's carbon emissions pollution is false.
A Facebook post erroneously stated that China is responsible for 90% of the global carbon emissions, however, there is no evidence to support this assertion [1][20].
On the contrary, the Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR) demonstrates that China, despite being the leading producer of CO2 emissions, is far below the 90% mark [7].
In fact, data for 2018 reveals that China accounted for roughly 30% of total global emissions, which, although significant, is a far cry from the quoted 90% [9].

d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.claim: " An email from Hillary Clinton to Donna Brazile Oct.17th, 2016 stated: ""If that f-----’ bastard wins, we’re all going to hang from nooses! You better fix this s---!"""
d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.label: false
d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.passage:
0: More than three years after Hillary Clinton lost to Donald Trump, a viral claim continues to circulate alleging she wrote a crude, angry email to Democratic leader Donna Brazile.
1: The post says that Clinton wrote an email to Donna Brazile Oct.17, 2016, that stated: "If that f-----’ bastard wins, we’re all going to hang from nooses – You better fix this s---!"
2: The Facebook post was published Dec. 28 in a pro-Donald Trump group .
3: It was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: We found no evidence that Clinton wrote such an email to Brazile, who was the head of the Democratic National Committee in the fall 2016.
6: Factcheck.org and Snopes debunked similar statements in 2019.
7: Evidence-less memes showing Clinton going on a profanity-laced tirade started to circulate after Clinton and Trump were separately interviewed by NBC’s Matt Lauer for a commander-in-chief forum in September 2016.
8: News reports showed that liberals and Clinton supporters felt Lauer wasn’t tough enough on Trump.
9: Victurus Libertas , a conspiracy site, posted an article in September 2016 after the forum saying that Clinton threw a "Hitler-like rage down" and tantrum after the forum.
10: The article linked to Politico’s report headlined "Liberals lash out at Lauer, NBC" and then Victurus wrote: "Hillary’s meltdown included throwing a water glass at a staffer- narrowly missing her head, and demanding Matt Lauer be fired!
11: She was overheard threatening executives at NBC saying "If I lose, we all go down and that Fascist F--- will have us swinging from nooses!
12: What the fuck is wrong with you idiots?"
13: Politico didn’t directly quote Clinton at all.
14: Victurus Libertas also wrote, without evidence, that Clinton singled out Brazile during her rant.
15: Our search of news articles did not reveal any evidence that Clinton sent a profanity-laced tirade to Brazile after the forum.
16: We searched WikiLeaks’ Hillary Clinton email archive and found nothing about nooses.
17: The post makes a ridiculous claim about Clinton’s emails that isn’t supported by any proof.

gpt4: The claim that Hillary Clinton sent a profanity-laced email to Donna Brazile on October 17th, 2016 is false.
Several investigations, including a search through WikiLeaks' Hillary Clinton email archive, found no evidence of the alleged email [16].
Additional searches of news articles also provided no evidence of the alleged tirade by Clinton [15].
There was no evidence found that Clinton had written such an email to Brazile, who was the head of the Democratic National Committee in the fall of 2016 [5].
Furthermore, this claim was debunked by Factcheck.org and Snopes in 2019, who found it to be baseless [6].

3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.claim: CBC Cuts Donald Trump's 'Home Alone 2' Cameo Out of Broadcast.
3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.label: half-true
3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.passage:
0: Conservatives slammed Canada’s leading public broadcaster this holiday season for cutting President Donald Trump’s cameo out of its broadcast of "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York."
1: But what many writers and social media users chalked up to anti-Trump bias was actually the result of a standard edit made five years ago, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said .
2: Some headlines generating buzz on social media omitted this context.
3: "CBC cuts Donald Trump’s ‘Home Alone 2’ cameo out of broadcast," said a Dec. 25 headline from PJ Media , a conservative opinion and commentary outlet.
4: This story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: According to the PJ Media article, the CBC’s claim that Trump’s roughly seven-second appearance was edited out to allow for commercial time "fails to pass the smell test."
7: "Trump's presidential bid appears to be the beginning of the folks at the CBC being triggered by Trump so badly that they actually had to edit him out of their broadcast," the article said.
8: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation acknowledged scrapping Trump’s cameo from its 2019 broadcast, but there’s no evidence that the cut was made for political reasons.
9: "The CBC admitted that Trump was cut out of the scene," said Paula Bolyard, PJ Media’s managing editor, in an email to PolitiFact.
10: "(Writer) Matt Margolis speculated that perhaps there was more to it than that, but left open the possibility that the CBC is telling the truth."
11: The CBC said time was the issue Trump’s appearance in the original version of the 1992 movie is brief, lasting roughly seven seconds.
12: The scene shows protagonist Kevin McCallister, played by actor Macaulay Culkin, asking Trump for directions to the lobby of a New York City hotel.
13: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com CBC spokesman Chuck Thompson said the scene was one of several deleted when the broadcaster acquired the rights to the film in 2014.
14: He said the edits were made to make way for commercials, as is standard operating procedure when movies move from the big screen to the small screen.
15: "As is often the case with feature films adapted for television, Home Alone 2 was edited for time," Thompson said .
16: "The scene with Donald Trump was one of several that were cut from the movie as none of them were integral to the plot."
17: CNN reporter Daniel Dale noted that viewers on social media have been complaining about the broadcaster’s omission of Trump’s scene and other scenes not involving Trump for years.
18: Trump — who also weighed in on the controversy on Twitter — announced his bid for the presidency in June 2015 and was elected to office in November 2016.

gpt4: The claim that CBC cut Donald Trump's 'Home Alone 2' cameo out of its broadcast is half-true.

While it is accurate that the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation excluded Trump's cameo from their 2019 broadcast of the film, it would be misleading to suggest that this action was strictly motivated by anti-Trump sentiment [8].
The edit was actually part of a broader set of cuts made when the broadcaster gained the rights to the movie in 2014, five years before the film was aired on CBC [13].
These changes were not unique to Trump's scene, as a number of others were also removed that were deemed unnecessary to the story's progression [16].

CBC spokesperson Chuck Thompson stated that these alterations were carried out to accommodate commercials, reflecting standard practices when films transition from cinema to television viewing[14][1].

5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.claim: "  Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam said, ‘You will give up your guns, if you don’t I’ll have the National Guard cut your power, your phone lines, and your internet. Then, if you still refuse to comply I’ll have you killed.’"""
5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.label: false
5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.passage:
0: A Virginia state bill that would institute a ban on assault weapons if passed in January has led to an uptick in misinformation targeting Virginia’s leading Democrats on Facebook.
1: One meme , which was shared thousands of times on Facebook, falsely attributes a threatening quote to Virginia Gov.
2: Ralph Northam, a Democrat.
3: The quote is made up.
4: "You will give up your guns, if you don’t I’ll have the National Guard cut your power, your phone lines, and your internet.
5: Then, if you still refuse to comply I’ll have you killed," the meme, posted Dec. 19 , said above an image of Northam.
6: This post — the latest in a series of hoaxes targeting Northam over his support for a proposed assault weapons ban in Virginia — was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Like another set of false posts about Northam, this one seems to trace back to a Dec. 13 blog post from Hal Turner, a white supremacist with a history of spreading conspiracy theories who was sentenced to 33 months in prison in 2010.
9: But we found no proof that Northam ever made such a statement.
10: Northam’s press secretary, Alena Yarmosky, told us in an email that the quote is "absolutely false."
11: "People who spread lies like this should be ashamed of themselves," she said.
12: Democrats in Virginia are poised to take control of both the Senate and the House of Delegates in January, opening the door for the potential passage of proposed gun regulations such as Virginia Senate Bill 16 , which would ban the possession, transport and sale of assault weapons.
13: The bill would expand the definition of "assault weapon" in the state and make possession of any such weapon a felony.
14: But there’s no evidence that Northam would order the National Guard to cut off power, phone lines and internet or otherwise punish those who disobey any ban that takes effect.
15: The ban does not spell out how it would deal with firearms that Virginians already own, and Northam told reporters on Dec. 11 that the state is "not going to take people’s guns away."
16: Northam has said he would call on law enforcement to enforce the bill, and he has also pushed back on resolutions that would make certain cities "Second Amendment sanctuaries."

gpt4: The claim attributing a menacing quote to Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam is false.
A meme disseminating the quote was widely shared on Facebook but the quote was found to be concocted[1][3].
There is no evidence that Northam ever made such a statement in any public forum or media platform[9].
Furthermore, Alena Yarmosky, Northam's press secretary, confirmed via email that the quote is absolutely false[10].
The claim also falsely suggests that Northam would order the National Guard to cut off power, phone lines, and the internet, or to execute individuals disobeying a certain ban.
No proof was found to support this notion[14].

c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.claim: a quote defending President Donald Trump can be attributed to Clint Eastwood.
c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.label: false
c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.passage:
0: A viral Facebook post wrongly attributed a 500-word defense of President Donald Trump to actor Clint Eastwood.
1: But it wasn’t the Hollywood icon who wrote the words in question.
2: It was New Hampshire state Rep. Fred Doucette, the chair of Trump’s campaign in that state.
3: The Dec. 28 Facebook post , which was shared more than 1,600 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The post lifted almost word-for-word from Doucette, who published his defense of Trump on Sept. 30 as a letter to the Eagle-Tribune, a local news outlet covering parts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire.
6: Eastwood was never mentioned in Doucette’s piece.
7: "I love it when people call President Donald Trump stupid," Doucette wrote.
8: "You mean the multi-billionaire who kicked every Democrat’s butt, buried 16 career Republican politicians, and continues to make fools out of once reputable news organizations?"
9: The confusion linking Eastwood to the letter likely came after the Massachusetts Republican Party reposted Doucette’s writing to its Facebook page in November .
10: That post included a meme that showed a photo of Eastwood and quoted him as saying, "If Congress really gave a rat’s ass about the American people, they would resign."
11: For what it’s worth, we checked Google and Nexis and could not verify that Eastwood ever made that statement about Congress, either.
12: In 2013, he did criticize Washington, saying, "It’s almost like they don’t give a damn."
13: He also spoke at the Republican National Convention in 2012.

gpt4: The claim that a statement defending President Donald Trump can be attributed to Clint Eastwood is false.
A viral Facebook post is responsible for this misinformation, erroneously accrediting a 500-word defense of Trump to the actor[0].
The real author of this quote is actually Fred Doucette, the chair of Trump's campaign in New Hampshire and state representative[2].
The post nearly replicated Doucette's words, which he initially published on September 30 as a letter to the local news outlet, the Eagle-Tribune[5].
Clint Eastwood was not mentioned at any point in Doucette's original piece[6], further confirming the Hollywood icon was not the author of the text in question[1].

76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.claim: "Congress rejects $336 (per) month increase in"" Social Security and disability benefits ""but approves $8,872 (per) month increase for themselves."
76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.label: false
76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.passage:
0: A Facebook post gives the impression that Congress is sticking it to ordinary folks when it comes to Social Security and disability benefits, while handsomely taking care of itself.
1: "Congress rejects $336 month increase in SS/SSDI but approves $8,872 month increase for themselves," the post says.
2: "Vote them out!!!"
3: The claim is a head turner, partly because Social Security is so big.
4: The $1 trillion-a-year program helps more than 63 million retirees, the disabled and their families.
5: But it’s wrong on both counts.
6: FactCheck.org checked the same claim in June, saying it was made in a viral post on Facebook, and found it false.
7: Our friends pointed out that: 1.
8: Annual cost-of-living adjustments for beneficiaries of Social Security and Supplemental Security Income benefits are determined not by Congress but by the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, which is calculated by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
9: We found that the cost-of-living increase for 2020, which was announced nearly two months before the post we’re checking, is 1.6% .
10: For a worker retiring at full retirement age, the maximum Social Security benefit in 2020 is $3,011 per month, up $150 from 2019.
11: 2
12: At the time of the FactCheck.org check, Congress had not decided whether to allow an automatic increase in pay for its members of 2.6% for 2020.
13: That would have meant an additional $4,500 annually — not "$8,872 monthly."
14: A deal for the $4,500 pay raise fell apart after a group of freshmen Democrats facing tough re-election campaigns asked their leader not to move forward, the New York Times reported .
15: That means the annual salary for members of the House and Senate remains at $174,000 .
16: (Leaders earn more.)
17: As we’ve reported, under federal law, congressional pay raises are fixed to the Employment Cost Index, which measures changes in wages.
18: The raises are automatic each year unless Congress votes it down — which it has done every year since 2009.

gpt4: The claim stating that "Congress rejects $336 (per) month increase in Social Security and disability benefits but approves $8,872 (per) month increase for themselves" is false.

To clarify, the annual cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and Supplemental Security Income beneficiaries are not decided by Congress, rather, they are determined by the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, a figure calculated by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics[8].
In 2020, the maximum Social Security benefit for a worker retiring at full retirement age was $3,011 per month, an increase of $150 from 2019[10].
Meanwhile, during the same period, Congress had not made a decision to allow an automatic pay increase of 2.6% for its members[12].
Contrary to the claim, such an increase would have meant an additional $4,500 annually, not "$8,872 monthly"[13].
Furthermore, the annual salary for members of both the House and the Senate was maintained at $174,000[15].
It's worth noting that the raises happen automatically each year unless Congress votes it down — which it has done every year since 2009[18].
The claim, therefore, is incorrect on both counts[5].

52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.claim: It’s nothing I do, but the probation office here in the Eastern District of Missouri is the best in the country. They have about a 7.5% recidivism rate, compared to national averages of 70 or 80%
52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.label: half-true
52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.passage:
0: Jeff Jensen, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Missouri, believes his district’s probation office has the lowest recidivism rate in the country.
1: In a Nov. 20 interview with St. Louis Public Radio , Jensen expressed frustration over St. Louis’ crime rate.
2: His one positive note, however, was about the recidivism rate for the Eastern District of Missouri probation office, which includes St. Louis and Cape Girardeau, Missouri.
3: "It’s nothing I do, but the probation office here in the Eastern District of Missouri is the best in the country," he said.
4: "They have about a 7.5% recidivism rate, compared to national averages of 70 or 80%."
5: We’ve had a similar check in Wisconsin , but we haven’t delved into Missouri’s Eastern District.
6: Does it really outperform the rest of the country?
7: Here’s what we found.
8: Jensen is making an apples-to-oranges comparison between district and national numbers.
9: It’s impossible to check whether the Eastern District is the best in the nation because the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics doesn’t study recidivism at state and county levels.
10: An apples-to-oranges comparison The numbers are difficult to compare.
11: Scott Anders, chief U.S. probation officer for the Eastern District, responded to PolitiFact’s request for the source of Jensen’s statistics.
12: The district’s numbers match Jensen’s claim.
13: In 2019, 7.5% of people under supervision — prisoners on parole, supervised release or probation — were rearrested, Anders said.
14: Additionally, the rearrest rate from 2012 to 2016 averaged 7.76%, according to the Eastern District’s rearrest reports.
15: It’s not as easy as Jensen made it seem to compare those rates to national averages.
16: In a report that studied recidivism rates of state prisoners from 2005 to 2014, the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics broke up the rates into one-year, three-year, six-year and nine-year periods.
17: Here’s what the study found: 44% of state prisoners were arrested within one year after release, 68% were arrested within three years, 79% within six years and 83% within nine years.
18: So, while the statistics match Jensen’s ballpark estimate of a 70 or 80% national recidivism rate, he is making an apples-to-oranges comparison when weighing them against the Eastern District’s rate.
19: Best in the country?
20: The first part of Jensen’s claim — that the Eastern District is the best in the country — is more difficult to check.
21: Bureau of Justice Statistics spokesperson Tannyr Watkins wrote in an email that the bureau has not studied recidivism rates for individual states or counties.
22: There’s no other governmental group that tracks the rates by district across the country.

gpt4: While it is correct that the probation office in the Eastern District of Missouri exhibits a significantly lower recidivism rate in comparison to national averages[4], the veracity of the claim stating it is the best in the country remains unsubstantiated.
The 7.5% recidivism rate asserted refers specifically to people under supervision such as prisoners on parole, supervised release or probation who were rearrested in 2019[13].
This trend is also seen in the average rearrest rate from 2012 to 2016, reported as 7.76%[14].

However, no information or comparative data on performance of other probation offices across the country has been provided to firmly confirm or deny that the probation office in the Eastern District of Missouri is indeed the best[3].
Consequently, the veracity of the claim is deemed half-true, on account of this lack of comprehensive, countrywide comparative data.

29e542006ba432a0caf10947b672c7d0.claim: You have literally 140 people dying every day of opioid-related overdoses.
29e542006ba432a0caf10947b672c7d0.label: true
29e542006ba432a0caf10947b672c7d0.passage:
0: As cases of opioid use disorder continue to wreak havoc across the U.S., many states have taken steps to address the issue.
1: Missouri is one of more than 30 states that brought a lawsuit against opioid manufacturers, alleging the companies misrepresented the dangerous and addictive nature of the drugs.
2: Speaking at a roundtable discussion about the opioid epidemic Nov. 25, Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt, who inherited Missouri’s lawsuit when he took office, said, "You have literally 140 people dying every day of opioid-related overdoses.
3: That’s like a passenger plane going down every day of every week of every month of every year of every decade."
4: Stating that 140 deaths per day are caused by opioid-related overdoses emphasizes the high stakes of the opioid crisis, so we wanted to see if Schmitt’s number was correct.
5: Here’s what we found: He’s off by about 10.
6: Preliminary data for last year shows fewer deaths.
7: The numbers When asked about where Schmitt found the statistic, Chris Nuelle, the attorney general’s press secretary, said that opioid-related research can fluctuate, so it can be hard to get exact numbers.
8: He also noted that Schmitt has often attributed 130 deaths per day to opioids, though Nuelle believes the 140 number is still accurate.
9: Nuelle pointed to a National Institute on Drug Abuse article that attributed more than 130 deaths per day and provided the link to a U.S. News & World Report story that analyzed opioid data, but did not indicate the number of deaths due to opioid overdoses each day at all.
10: The most reliable and most recent data available on drug and opioid overdose deaths in the U.S. comes from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
11: The CDC’s most recent data was released in 2018 and analyzes 2017 drug and opioid overdose deaths.
12: In 2017, there were 70,237 drug overdose deaths in the United States.
13: Of those deaths, 47,600 — or 67.8% of all drug overdose deaths — involved some type of opioids whether natural, synthetic or semisynthetic.
14: When you break these statistics down into deaths per day, there were approximately 192 drug overdose deaths each day on average in 2017.
15: Of those 192 deaths, about 130 each day involved an opioid.
16: This statistic does not match up exactly with Schmitt’s claim that there are 140 opioid-related deaths daily in the U.S. Jasmine Reed, a public affairs specialist at the CDC, said in an email that the 130 daily deaths from opioid overdoses is an average calculated by dividing the total number of opioid overdoses in the year by the number of days in a year.
17: She said this means the number is not an absolute figure, but that it is more accurate to say there are 130 opioid overdose deaths in the U.S. each day than it is to say there are 140.
18: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The CDC estimates that between 1999 and 2017, more than 702,000 people have died from a drug overdose, and about 399,000 of those deaths were due to opioid overdoses.
19: Overall, the number of opioid overdose deaths each day and drug overdose deaths each day have both been steadily increasing within that time period.
20: If the number of opioid overdose deaths continued growing steadily, as it has in past years, the number of deaths each day in 2019 might, in fact, be 140 or even exceed 140.
21: However, this is not yet known because the final counts of overdose deaths for 2018 and 2019 have not been released.
22: The CDC has released provisional data for 2018 that indicates the number of drug overdose deaths dropped from 70,237 in 2017 to 68,110 in 2018.
23: The CDC warns that this number is likely "underreported due to incomplete data," but the overall drop suggests that opioid-related overdoses also decreased in 2018.
24: This could mean the number of opioid overdose deaths is actually less than 130 per day.
25: Reasons for overdoses Aaron Williams, senior director for training and technical assistance for substance abuse at the National Council For Behavioral Health, explained there are a number of reasons why opioid overdose deaths constitute such a large portion of drug overdose deaths.
26: "Over the last decade and a half, there has been a significant increase in the prescription of and use of opioid-based medications for pain, in particular," Williams said.
27: He said many people developed substance use problems due to this uptick, which increased overdose deaths because high doses of opioids can cause respiratory depression that leads to death.
28: Williams also said in recent years illegal opioids have become easier to get, with heroin getting "cheaper and purer" as one example.
29: He said potent synthetic opioids (tramadol, fentanyl, etc.)
30: have moved into the pipeline as well.

gpt4: Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt, in a roundtable discussion about opioid epidemic, noted that approximately 140 people are dying every day due to opioid-related overdoses[2].
The latest and most reliable data on drug and opioid overdose deaths in the U.S. originates from the CDC[10].
From a total of 192 deaths, roughly 130 every day included an opioid[15].
This figure doesn't exactly align with Schmitt's claim of 140 daily opioid-related deaths.

As explained by a CDC public affairs specialist, Jasmine Reed, the statistic of 130 daily deaths is an average arrived at by dividing the total number of opioid overdoses annually by the days in a year[16].
There's potential that Schmitt's claim could be valid if the growth trend in opioid overdose deaths remained constant.
If this was the case, the daily death toll in 2019 could stand at 140 or even higher[20].
However, the exact figures for 2018 and 2019 haven't been made public as of now[21].
Consequently, it's also possible that the number of opioid deaths could be less than the calculated average of 130 per day[24].

17f5ad85c8e0cdb5fedd25dd083a19e4.claim: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar vowed ""to remove senior’s ‘entitlements,’ Social Security/Medicare."""
17f5ad85c8e0cdb5fedd25dd083a19e4.label: false
17f5ad85c8e0cdb5fedd25dd083a19e4.passage:
0: A spam website is reposting alleged satire as genuine news content in an attempt to spread misinformation about Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., and Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn.
1: In one post published Dec. 23, AJUAnews.com claimed the Democratic representatives said they want to get rid of government benefits for seniors.
2: Several links on the website try to get readers to download anti-virus software they don’t need.
3: "They intend to screw over our greatest generation by removing from them everything that we have earned over the years," the article reads.
4: "The two held a joint press conference yesterday to announce their intention to remove from senior citizens what they termed ‘entitlements’, such as Social Security and Medicare."
5: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: It has been shared more than 18,000 times.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from AJUAnews.com) The article is fake — its source is a website that publishes satire.
9: And we’ve previously debunked similarly false stories from AJUAnews, which was created in early December, according to WhoIs data.
10: The article about Ocasio-Cortez and Omar was originally published by Daily World Update, a website that purports to publish political satire.
11: The site is run by Christopher Blair, a liberal who tries to trick conservatives into sharing made-up stories on social media.
12: The original story has several labels warning that it’s satire.
13: But AJUAnews’ version includes only one small, hard-to-read disclaimer, and several Facebook users and pages have shared the story with the assumption that it’s true.
14: There was no press conference for cutting entitlements.
15: In fact, both congresswomen have spoken in favor of Medicare for All, which would change the private insurance system to a government-run approach that would cover most Americans.
16: Ocasio-Cortez has also advocated for the Social Security 2100 Act, which aims to raise the program’s benefits — including those provided by Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance.
17: The article is inaccurate and makes a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar vowed to "remove senior’s ‘entitlements,’ Social Security/Medicare" is false.
This unfounded claim is being circulated by a spam website that is reposting alleged satire as genuine news in an attempt to spread misinformation about the two congresswomen[0].
The source of this claim is a website known for publishing satire, rather than credible news updates, evident from a screenshot captured on PolitiFact[8].
It's also essential to mention that there was no press conference held, where such serious entitlement cuts were discussed[14].

On the contrary, Representatives Ocasio-Cortez and Omar have both publicly expressed their support for Medicare for All, a plan which proposes transforming the private insurance industry into a government-run system that would provide coverage to the majority of Americans[15].
The circulation of this false assertion is, therefore, at odds with their stated policy positions.

a2d8be4c1673aad5280178ab72c76290.claim: Lee Majors died and left $6 million to Donald Trump.
a2d8be4c1673aad5280178ab72c76290.label: false
a2d8be4c1673aad5280178ab72c76290.passage:
0: As millions of Americans celebrated Christmas, some Facebook users were sharing a made-up story about Lee Majors.
1: The Dec. 25 article , which was published by AJUAnews.com, claims Majors died from complications during a Penuma surgical procedure.
2: (Penuma is a kind of penile implant .)
3: It also claims the actor, who has starred in movies like "The Six Million Dollar Man" and "Scrooged," left $6 million for President Donald Trump’s re-election campaign in his will.
4: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared more than 6,000 times.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from AJUAnews.com) AJUAnews is a hoax news site that has a track record of republishing false, satirical stories without their original context.
8: It also tries to redirect readers to links for anti-virus software they don’t need.
9: The original source of the article about Majors is a website called Conservative Tears.
10: It’s run by Christopher Blair, a liberal who tries to trick conservatives into sharing made-up stories on social media.
11: A lot of AJUAnews’ content appears to come from Blair’s network of sites.
12: The story on Conservative Tears has several satire labels — including a "Death Hoax" tag — while AJUAnews’ version does not.
13: Facebook users and pages have also shared the latter with the assumption that it’s real.
14: Majors has been cast in an upcoming movie called "Narco Sub," which is in pre-production for release in 2020.
15: No news outlets have reported that he’s dead.
16: The article is inaccurate and makes a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that actor Lee Majors died and left $6 million to Donald Trump is false.
Various pieces of evidence support this assertion.
Firstly, Majors has been cast in an upcoming movie called "Narco Sub," which is currently in pre-production for release in 2020, indicating that he is very much alive[14].
In addition, no reputable news outlets have officially reported his death[15].
The originating story of his death appeared on AJUAnews, a hoax news site known for republishing false, satirical stories without their original context[7].
In comparison, the version of the story on Conservative Tears, a known satirical site, has several spoof labels, including a "Death Hoax" tag, suggesting it was never meant to be taken literally[12].

fb817932b3092a3cb4c257606c866915.label: false
fb817932b3092a3cb4c257606c866915.passage:
0: A viral story prematurely declared actress Carol Burnett dead and falsely described her as a supporter of President Donald Trump.
1: Oh, it misspelled her name in the headline, too.
2: "Carol Burnette dead at 89 — a huge Trump supporter lost," said a headline on AJUAnews.com .
3: A small box in the corner of the image says it is satire, but it’s possible to miss that small warning when scrolling on Facebook.
4: AJUAnews is a hoax news site that has a track record of republishing false, satirical stories without their original context.
5: It also tries to redirect readers to links for anti-virus software.
6: The Facebook post was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: The article appears to have been copied from another website with a similar satire label, Conservative Tears , which is part of Christopher Blair’s network of satirical sites .
9: There are several cues that the story is false.
10: One sign is the misspelled surname.
11: The story also says she was born in 1934 and was 89 in December, which is mathematically impossible.
12: We found no evidence that Burnett was a "huge Trump supporter."
13: Burnett told Larry King in February 2016 that she doesn’t endorse candidates.
14: When he asked her, "if I say ‘Donald Trump’ do you comment?"
15: she laughed in response and said "that’s my comment."
16: She told Conan O’Brien in 2018 that political comedy wasn’t her thing.
17: "It never occurred to me to be political, I really wasn’t thinking about it — it just wasn’t my bag," she said, speaking about the Carol Burnett show.
18: So what is Burnett actually up to?
19: USA Today interviewed her in late December and reported that she will appear in the reboot of "Mad About You" and has an upcoming Netflix film, "Sorta Like a Rock Star."
20: A story said that Carol Burnett is dead and was a Trump supporter, but we found no evidence to back up either statement.
21: Burnett lives.

gpt4: The claim that Carol Burnett is dead is false[21].
A story stating this went viral but it was traced back to the AJUAnews site, which is known to republish false and satirical stories without their original context [4].
This particular story not only falsely declared Carol Burnett dead, but also inaccurately painted her as a supporter of President Donald Trump [0].
Currently, instead of propagating claims about her political leanings or death, one should ask: what is Burnett actually up to now [18]?

870d21ac1ed82b572f512d56c83f8c04.claim: Iran will be shooting at our soldiers with bullets, etc., purchased with the $150 billion Obama gave them.
870d21ac1ed82b572f512d56c83f8c04.label: false
870d21ac1ed82b572f512d56c83f8c04.passage:
0: Angered by deadly U.S. airstrikes that targeted an Iran-backed militia, dozens of Iraqi Shiite militiamen and their supporters broke into the U.S. Embassy compound in Baghdad on Dec. 31.
1: The next day, a Facebook post referencing former President Barack Obama made this claim: "Iran will be shooting at our soldiers with bullets, etc., purchased with the $150 billion Obama gave them."
2: The post misrepresents the Iran nuclear deal from 2015.
3: The agreement was promoted by Obama.
4: But it included China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom and the European Union — not just the United States and Iran.
5: The deal resulted in Iran getting access to some of its own funds — assets that had been frozen — it wasn’t cash given to Iran by the United States.
6: And $150 billion is a high-end estimate and the one with the least evidence to support it.
7: The high-end estimate from the U.S. Treasury Department in 2015 was $56 billion, and outside analysts believed the number could be lower.
8: Per the deal , the United States and other countries lifted the sanctions and the funds were unfrozen after nuclear inspectors verified in January 2016 that Iran was doing enough to curb its nuclear program.
9: (On Jan. 5, in the aftermath of the airstrikes, Iran said it no longer will comply with limits on uranium enrichment provided under the deal.)
10: It’s worth noting that it was not clear what became of the unfrozen funds.
11: In January 2016 , then-Secretary of State John Kerry said he expected that some of the money ultimately would end up with organizations involved in terrorism.

gpt4: The claim that Iran will be using bullets purchased with $150 billion given to them by former President Obama is false.
Firstly, it misrepresents the 2015 Iran nuclear deal where the funds Iran received were actually unfrozen assets belonging to them, not cash provided by the United States[2][5].
Furthermore, the count of $150 billion is an overstated estimate, and the claim has weak factual support[6].
In 2015, the highest estimate given by the U.S. Treasury Department was $56 billion, and some external analysts even believed it to be a lower amount[7].
Also, the Iran nuclear deal was a multilateral agreement involving not only the U.S. and Iran, but also China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the European Union[4].

44701d7f1144f60929701fbaeefe8415.claim: President Trump didn't say he'd go after a cultural site.
44701d7f1144f60929701fbaeefe8415.label: false
44701d7f1144f60929701fbaeefe8415.passage:
0: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo falsely claimed on Fox News that President Donald Trump did not threaten to target Iranian cultural sites.
1: Pompeo’s claim came when host Maria Bartiromo asked about a tweet in which Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., said Trump was advocating for a war crime.
2: "President Trump didn't say he'd go after a cultural site," Pompeo said.
3: "Read what he said very closely."
4: We read what Trump said closely.
5: In a series of tweets , the president issued a warning to Iran, saying the United States has "targeted 52 Iranian sites" it could strike if Iran were to attack.
6: Trump’s twitter thread came after the United States killed Iranian military commander Qasem Soleimani in an airstrike aimed at an airport in Baghdad, Iraq.
7: "Iran is talking very boldly about targeting certain USA assets as revenge for our ridding the world of their terrorist leader," Trump said .
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com "Let this serve as a WARNING that if Iran strikes any Americans, or American assets, we have targeted 52 Iranian sites (representing the 52 American hostages taken by Iran many years ago), some at a very high level & important to Iran & the Iranian culture, and those targets, and Iran itself, WILL BE HIT VERY FAST AND VERY HARD," he continued .
9: Iran has 22 cultural sites on the UNESCO World Heritage List .
10: Some pundits and politicians, such as Ocasio-Cortez, argued that strikes against them could be considered war crimes under international law.
11: The Geneva Conventions prohibit "acts of hostility directed against the historic monuments, works of art or places of worship which constitute the cultural or spiritual heritage of peoples."
12: And in March 2017, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution condemning "the unlawful destruction of cultural heritage."
13: Hours after Pompeo made his claim on Bartiromo’s show, Trump restated his willingness to go after Iran’s cultural sites while speaking to reporters.
14: "They’re allowed to kill our people," he said, according to the Associated Press .
15: "They’re allowed to torture and maim our people.
16: They’re allowed to use roadside bombs and blow up our people.
17: And we’re not allowed to touch their cultural sites?
18: It doesn’t work that way."
19: The State Department did not respond to our requests for comment by deadline.

gpt4: The claim that President Trump didn't say he'd go after a cultural site is false.

Contrary to the statement made by Pompeo [2], President Trump, through a series of tweets, issued a warning to Iran that the United States had identified 52 Iranian sites that it could strike if Iran were to attack [5].
Furthermore, Trump specifically indicated that some of these chosen targets were "important to Iran & the Iranian culture"[8].
Hours after Pompeo's claim, Trump reiterated his readiness to target Iran’s cultural sites when addressing journalists [13].

e9ac1d1fbf8c26666c7afa69332e993a.claim: an image shows a satellite view of fires in Australia.
e9ac1d1fbf8c26666c7afa69332e993a.label: false
e9ac1d1fbf8c26666c7afa69332e993a.passage:
0: As wildfires continue to burn millions of acres of land in Australia, some social media users are misusing a digital visualization to draw attention to the disaster.
1: One image published on Facebook Jan. 5 claims to show a satellite view of Australia provided by a NASA satellite.
2: "Pray for us please," the user wrote alongside the image, which shows bright orange spots where fires are purportedly burning across the continent.
3: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Similar versions have been shared thousands of times on both Facebook and Instagram, where some celebrities and public figures have reposted it.
6: The photo isn’t a satellite image of Australia — it’s a digital visualization of fire data.
7: Anthony Hearsey, a Brisbane-based photographer and graphic designer, created the visualization and published it on Instagram Jan. 5.
8: He said in the caption that he created the visualization using nearly eight months of data from NASA’s Fire Information for Resource Management System (FIRMS), which "distributes near-real-time active fire data."
9: "These are all the areas which have been affected by bushfires," Hearsey said in his photo caption.
10: "Scale is a little exaggerated due to the render’s glow.
11: Also note that not all the areas are still burning."
12: That’s different than an actual satellite image of Australia, which does not show glow from the fires at a continental view.
13: (It is possible to see smoke from the fires on some closer satellite images.)
14: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com (NASA) A map from FIRMS that shows the locations of active fires in Australia also helps place Hearsey’s digital visualization in context.
15: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from FIRMS) The Facebook posts that portray the visualization as a NASA satellite image are wrong.

gpt4: The claim that an image published on Facebook Jan.5 shows a satellite view of Australia's fires is false[1].
In reality, the picture does not portray an actual satellite image; rather, it is a digital visualization of fire data[6].
Brisbane-based photographer and graphic designer Anthony Hearsey created the visualization and shared it on his Instagram account on the same date[7].

06b3afa146800484bf727f9d33e4e9f2.claim: he did not tell former President Barack Obama ""don’t go"" after Osama bin Laden"
06b3afa146800484bf727f9d33e4e9f2.label: false
06b3afa146800484bf727f9d33e4e9f2.passage:
0: Former Vice President Joe Biden has continued to recast what advice he gave President Barack Obama about whether to raid the compound that was the suspected hideaway for Osama bin Laden.
1: Biden’s latest statement occurred during a brief exchange with Fox News reporter Peter Doocy in Iowa on Jan. 3, following President Donald Trump’s order to kill Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani.
2: Doocy: "As commander in chief, if you were ever handed a piece of intelligence that said you can stop an imminent attack on Americans but you have to use an airstrike to take out a terror leader, would you pull the trigger?"
3: Biden: "Well, we did.
4: Guy’s name was Osama bin Laden."
5: Doocy: "Didn’t you tell President Obama not to go after bin Laden?"
6: Biden: "No, I didn’t.
7: I didn’t."
8: It is a challenge to fact-check what Biden told Obama in advance of the May 2011 raid to kill bin Laden, because their conversations were largely private.
9: However, Biden has made conflicting statements about what he told Obama.
10: In 2012, Biden said he told Obama "don’t go" and called for him to take additional steps to confirm bin Laden was at the compound.
11: But in 2015, Biden said he told Obama "go."
12: In 2012 Biden said he told Obama not to launch raid on compound In January 2012 at a Democratic congressional retreat, Biden recounted how Obama asked senior officials whether they should go ahead with the raid.
13: Everyone in the room "hedged their bet" except CIA Director Leon Panetta, who said "go."
14: "Mr. President, my suggestion is, don't go," Biden recounted.
15: "‘We have to do two more things to see if he's there."
16: (He did not explain what the two additional things were at the time.)
17: (When a reporter asked White House spokesman Jay Carney in 2012 about Biden’s comments stating he was against the raid, Carney said: "I know that he is speaking accurately.")
18: In May 2012 on NBC’s Meet the Press , Biden said he told Obama "follow your instincts."
19: "I wanted him to take one more day to do one more test to see if he was there," Biden said.
20: Obama’s statement during a debate in 2012 supported the idea that Biden was critical about the raid proposal.
21: Obama said that "even some in my own party, including my current vice president," critiqued the proposed raid.
22: Biden later said he told Obama to go ahead with the raid By 2013, Biden started to recast his account of what he told Obama.
23: In January 2013, the New York Times magazine wrote that Biden had advised against the 2011 raid on the house in Pakistan that was suspected to be bin Laden’s hideaway.
24: But the quote by Biden was more vague: "I remember walking up to his office and saying, ‘Look, follow your instincts, follow your instincts.’" In 2015, Biden said he did tell Obama privately to go after bin Laden.
25: On Oct. 20, 2015, at an event honoring former Vice President Walter Mondale, Biden said when Obama asked everyone in the room whether he should go forward, only two were definitive: Panetta said "go" and Secretary of Defense Robert Gates said "don’t go."
26: Biden recounted that he suggested a third option, though he said it was one "that I didn’t really think we should do."
27: Biden said he proposed to take one more pass with an unmanned aerial vehicle to confirm that it was bin Laden at the compound.
28: Then Biden said he told Obama in a private conversation, "I thought he should go but to follow his own instincts."
29: That led to multiple news reports showing that Biden had revised his account from 2012 when he said he told Obama "don’t go."
30: Days later, CBS journalist Norah O’Donnell asked Biden to clear up the confusion about whether he told Obama to conduct the raid.
31: "Everything I said was completely accurate.
32: I just never until last Tuesday night told the whole story," he said, referring to the Mondale event.
33: Biden said he first told Obama to do another check, and then he told Obama to follow his own instincts: "I said, ‘You should do that, and there would be still time to have the raid, but that’s what I would do."
34: Biden continued: "Immediately, we got up, as we always do, and I walked out with the president.
35: We walked up to the Oval.
36: I said, ‘Mr.
37: President, follow your instincts.
38: I know you should do it, but follow your instincts.’ " Biden’s 2020 campaign pushed back against criticism that his statements have been inconsistent.
39: The campaign said in a statement that at the outset, Biden advised that the United States should first obtain additional confirmation that bin Laden was at the compound.
40: Biden, the campaign said, never proposed stopping the operation.
41: Obama-era officials said Biden expressed skepticism Biden’s claim that he told Obama to "go" conflicted with other accounts from Obama-era officials in their books.
42: (A Trump campaign spokesman, Zach Parkinson, tweeted many of these passages.)
43: Obama’s Secretary of State Hillary Clinton wrote in " Hard Choices" that Biden "remained skeptical."
44: Panetta wrote in " Worthy Fights " that Biden "argued that we still did not have enough confidence that bin Laden was in the compound, and he came out firmly in favor of waiting for more information."
45: Defense Secretary Robert Gates wrote in " Duty: Memoirs of a Secretary at War " that he and Biden were the "two primary skeptics."
46: "Biden’s primary concern was the political consequences of failure," Gates wrote.

gpt4: The claim that Joe Biden did not tell former President Barack Obama "don't go" in relation to Osama bin Laden is false.

According to statements made by Biden himself, in 2012, he was clear that he advised President Obama against the raid, saying "don’t go" and urging for additional measures to ensure bin Laden was indeed at the targeted compound [10][14].
While it is true that Biden changed his narrative by 2015[11], stating that he did indeed tell Obama "go", it is important to note that this revision occurred years after his initial statements.
By 2013, Biden began to recast his account of his advice to Obama, with latter statements contradicting his 2012 version [22].
This revision led to multiple news outlets noting that Biden had altered his account from 2012 when he initially said he advised Obama against the raid on bin Laden's compound[29].

e8ad8acb2ba9b9a5fe11d6234264ed5e.claim: a photo shows Barack Obama looking through binoculars the wrong way.
e8ad8acb2ba9b9a5fe11d6234264ed5e.label: false
e8ad8acb2ba9b9a5fe11d6234264ed5e.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post appears to show former President Barack Obama peering through the wrong end of a pair of binoculars while a general watches.
1: "The look on the 4 stars face as obama looks through the wrong end of the upside down binoculars…" the Dec. 2 post says.
2: "People actually voted for this clown… No face ever screamed "You gotta be sh tting me louder than this… #obama."
3: But the image has been manipulated, and this post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: You can see the original here .
6: Associated Press photographer Pablo Martinez Monsivais took it on March 25, 2012, as Obama looked through the correct end of the binoculars to see North Korea from the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea.
7: Getty Images has other photos from that day from other angles.
8: Obama isn’t holding his binoculars incorrectly in any of them.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows Barack Obama looking through binoculars the wrong way is false.

The Associated Press photographer Pablo Martinez Monsivais captured the original photo on March 25, 2012, where Obama is clearly seen using the binoculars correctly to view North Korea from the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea[6].

The photograph was later manipulated, which led to the spread of the erroneous claim, but this post was flagged as part of efforts by Facebook to combat the dissemination of misinformation and false news on its News Feed[3].
It is imperative to note that none of the original pictures showed Obama holding his binoculars incorrectly[8].

bd6e202f5dd71188930b60a6e8a76651.claim: the Democratic leadership and presidential candidates ""are mourning the loss of (Qassem) Soleimani"""
bd6e202f5dd71188930b60a6e8a76651.label: false
bd6e202f5dd71188930b60a6e8a76651.passage:
0: Nikki Haley, President Donald Trump’s former ambassador to the United Nations, baselessly accused leading Democrats of mourning the death of Iran’s Qassem Soleimani.
1: In an interview with Sean Hannity on Fox News Jan. 6, Haley praised Trump’s actions to take out Soleimani with a drone strike of his vehicle near the airport outside Baghdad.
2: While the world knows that he was "evil," Haley said, she accused top Democrats of grieving his loss.
3: "You don’t see anyone standing up for Iran," Haley said.
4: "You are not hearing any of the Gulf members, you are not hearing China, you are not hearing Russia.
5: The only ones that are mourning the loss of Soleimani are our Democrat leadership and our Democrat presidential candidates."
6: Haley proceeded to tweet out her statement .
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com But Haley is wrong in counting top Democrats among the mourners of Soleimani.
8: RELATED FACT-CHECK: Haley wrongly says Congress had no input on Iran nuclear deal Leading Democrats running for president The five Democrats who have qualified so far for the Jan. 14 debate in Iowa — Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Amy Klobuchar — all expressed concern about the potential for Trump’s strike on Soleimani to escalate tensions and prompt a rush for war.
9: However, four of the five prefaced their comments by saying that Soleimani was a dangerous man with blood on his hands.
10: None had anything close to praise for him or sympathy for his death.
11: Here are some of the statements by these Democrats: Biden : In a written statement , the former vice president said that "no American will mourn Qassem Soleimani’s passing."
12: He added that Soleimani deserved to be brought to justice and "supported terror and sowed chaos."
13: Biden said Trump owes Americans an explanation of his strategy and how he plans to keep troops safe.
14: "I hope the administration has thought through the second- and third-order consequences of the paths they have chosen," Biden wrote.
15: Later, on Jan. 3 , Biden made a similar statement, criticizing Soleimani as the "architect of the slaughter of countless lives in the region" and stating that "no American mourns his passing."
16: He said Americans don’t want another war in the Middle East and that Trump shouldn’t take us to war without congressional approval .
17: Warren : The Massachusetts senator’s message evolved in the days after the airstrike.
18: But nothing she wrote could be considered an expression of "mourning."
19: In her initial tweet , she explicitly called Soleimani "a murderer, responsible for the deaths of thousands, including hundreds of Americans."
20: She went on to call Trump’s action "reckless" and something that "escalates the situation with Iran and increases the likelihood of more deaths and new Middle East conflict."
21: In a second tweet , she didn’t repeat the preface criticizing Soleimani, nor did she in comments to CNN’s Jake Tapper.
22: Instead, she focused on criticizing Trump for his handling of policy toward Iran.
23: In these later statements, Warren said nothing positive about Soleimani.
24: Buttigieg : In a statement , the former South Bend, Ind., mayor said that Soleimani was a threat who "masterminded threats and attacks on Americans and our allies, leading to hundreds of deaths."
25: In addition, in Iowa, Buttigieg said Soleimani has "blood on his hands" and that "taking out a bad guy is not a good idea unless you are ready for what comes next."
26: Buttigieg called for a deliberative approach that includes working with Congress and U.S. allies and said we must prepare for the potential of escalation.
27: Buttigieg tweeted that Trump owes American troops a strategy and should give Americans answers.
28: Klobuchar : In her statement after the airstrike, the Minnesota senator criticized the "timing, manner, and potential consequences of the administration’s actions."
29: But she prefaced this by saying that "Qassem Soleimani was responsible for directing Iran’s destabilizing actions in Iraq, Syria, and throughout the Middle East, including attacks against U.S.
30: forces."
31: Sanders : The Vermont senator’s written statement had nothing positive to say about Soleimani, focusing instead on how the "assassination" by Trump was a "dangerous escalation" that "brings us closer to another disastrous war in the Middle East that could cost countless lives and trillions more dollars."
32: He said much the same in a streamed campaign event he tweeted out , briefly mentioning Soleimani but neither explicitly criticizing or praising him.
33: In an interview with CNN , Sanders called him a "bad news guy" but focused more on his opposition to going to war with Iran.
34: Several other Democratic presidential candidates also made a point of criticizing Soleimani.
35: Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., said on MSNBC that "Soleimani has American blood on his hands."
36: Sen. Michael Bennet, D-Colo., said in a statement that Soleimani "has the blood of Americans and our allies on his hands" and "there is no mourning his death."
37: Businessman Tom Steyer tweeted that Soleimani was "a terrorist responsible for killing Americans."
38: And former New York City mayor Michael Bloomberg tweeted that Soleimani "was a murderer with the blood of Americans on his hands."
39: The Democratic leadership Top congressional Democrats echoed the critiques offered by the presidential candidates.
40: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., had harsh words for Soleimani while criticizing the Trump administration’s actions, calling the general a "notorious terrorist" and saying that "no one should shed a tear over his death."
41: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., did not dwell on Soleimani in either of two statements released after the operation.
42: She said in her first statement that the airstrike was "provocative and disproportionate" and in a later statement that it raised "urgent questions about the timing, manner and justification" for the operation.
43: Neither of her statements made any effort to mourn Soleimani.
44: Other leading Democrats on foreign policy issues, including Sen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn ., and Rep. Eliot L. Engel, D-N.Y. , also criticized Soleimani.
45: A response from Haley’s spokesman included such a broad interpretation of the word "mourning" to render its definition meaningless, saying Democrats are "effectively" mourning Soleimani by questioning whether the United States is better off after his killing.

gpt4: The claim suggesting that the Democratic leadership and presidential candidates are mourning the loss of Qassem Soleimani is false.
Despite the controversial nature of Soleimani's death, there is no credible evidence to back up the contention that prominent Democrats have expressed mourning for the Iranian general.
In fact, this claim has been refuted by a fact-check performed by PolitiFact which states, "But Haley is wrong in counting top Democrats among the mourners of Soleimani"[7].
This directly contradicts the initial claim by clearly establishing that top Democrats were not included in the group mourning Soleimani's demise.

571212a15217b95e00e475f41d50be15.claim: Trump volunteered his airline to bring troops home during Operation Desert Storm.
571212a15217b95e00e475f41d50be15.label: false
571212a15217b95e00e475f41d50be15.passage:
0: A viral Facebook post depicts President Donald Trump as a generous airline owner who donated his planes to transport American soldiers home from Saudi Arabia in 1991.
1: But the details don’t square with what happened.
2: The post features a letter purportedly written by a man named Ron Knouse.
3: He describes how he and other soldiers had to wait four days for buses to the airport because there was a shortage of planes at the end of Operation Desert Storm.
4: "Finally, the buses came and took the young man to the airport.
5: The planes waiting were from Tower Air.
6: The owner of Tower Air had volunteered his planes and staff to bring soldiers home for the cost of fuel only.
7: Happily, the young veteran got home just in time for Easter weekend in 1991 and spent that time emotionally healing with friends and family surrounding him… "The Airline owner – Donald J Trump.
8: "This needs to go viral.
9: He’s done so many good things you never hear about."
10: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: Donald Trump did operate an airline at one time.
13: But the details of the letter are inaccurate.
14: Trump did not own Tower Air, and we found no evidence he assisted in the transport of military personnel from Saudi Arabia.
15: Beyond that, Trump’s airline — Trump Shuttle — was being controlled by a consortium of banks, not Trump, when the United States military chartered flights from the airline for personnel transport.
16: That was for flights within the United States, not from Saudi Arabia.
17: The end of Trump Shuttle A different story about a Trump plane transporting 200 marines from North Carolina to Florida after Operation Desert Storm in 1991 emerged when conservative talk radio host Sean Hannity aired a now-deleted segment about it in May 2016, during Trump’s presidential campaign.
18: In that version, about 200 Marines took two trips on a Trump-owned plane from North Carolina to Florida after a logistics error left them stranded.
19: While Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign allegedly confirmed the story, details show that he was not personally involved in transporting any American troops.
20: Trump ran the airline for a short time.
21: In May 1989, he purchased Eastern Airlines for $365 million, renaming it Trump Shuttle.
22: The airline operated short flights in the northeastern United States using a fleet of Boeing 727 airliners.
23: A 2016 fact-check by the Washington Post reported that while some Trump Shuttle planes did transport military personnel around the country in the early 1990s, it was the U.S. military that chartered those flights, not Trump personally.
24: Retired Lt. Gen. Vernon Kondra, who was in charge of all military airlift operations at the time, told the newspaper his notes indicated several references to a 1990-91 contract for Trump Shuttle to carry personnel across the country.
25: He said it would have made little sense if Trump personally arranged the flights and said he was "certainly not aware" of him being involved.
26: Trump wasn’t in a position to donate plane rides, anyway.
27: NYC Aviation reported that he had defaulted on his loan in September 1990, and control of the airline went back to the banks until it was sold to US Air.
28: US Air agreed in late 1991 to operate the airline with an option to buy it outright after five years.
29: By April 1992 , Trump Shuttle had ceased to exist when it was merged into a new corporation, Shuttle, Inc., which began operating as the USAir Shuttle.
30: Tower Air Trump’s name does not appear anywhere in the nearly 20-year history of Tower Air, which is mentioned as being owned by Trump in the Facebook post.
31: The airline contracted with the Department of Defense to transport soldiers on charter flights in the early 1990s and was founded by Zev Melamid, Mordechi Gill, Morris Nachtomi and Sam Fondlier in 1982, according to Airline History records .
32: When Tower Air filed for bankruptcy in May 2000, Nachtomi was listed as its CEO.
33: To summarize our findings, Trump Shuttle planes were contracted by the U.S. military to transport personnel around the country while the airline was in the process of being sold; it was not under Trump’s control at the time.
34: Trump was not affiliated with Tower Air, which contracted with the Department of Defense in the 1990s to transport soldiers stationed overseas.

gpt4: The claim that Donald Trump volunteered his airline to bring troops home during Operation Desert Storm is untrue.
Trump did operate an airline at one point, namely Trump Shuttle [12].

However, it is important to note that Trump had defaulted on his loan in September 1990 and control of his airline had reverted back to a consortium of banks by the time the United States military chartered flights from the airline for personnel transport [15][27].
Moreover, Trump was not affiliated with Tower Air, the airline contracted by the Department of Defense in the 1990s to transport soldiers stationed overseas[34].
It is also documented that Trump nor his airline had any role in the transport of military personnel from Saudi Arabia[14].
Furthermore, despite claims to the contrary on social media, neither Trump's name nor his airline appear anywhere in the nearly 20-year history of Tower Air [30].

2491ef9c9f326941b35decae3dd68392.claim: Qassem Soleimani ""assisted in the clandestine travel to Afghanistan of 10 of the 12 terrorists who carried out the September 11 terrorist attacks in the United States."""
2491ef9c9f326941b35decae3dd68392.label: false
2491ef9c9f326941b35decae3dd68392.passage:
0: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com In a series of tweets justifying the U.S. killing of Qassem Soleimani, Vice President Mike Pence said that among the Iranian military leader’s "worst atrocities" was helping 9/11 terrorists.
1: Soleimani "assisted in the clandestine travel to Afghanistan of 10 of the 12 terrorists who carried out the September 11 terrorist attacks in the United States," Pence tweeted Jan. 3.
2: The U.S. Defense Department on Jan. 2 announced it had killed Soleimani, who commanded the Quds Force in Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.
3: The Trump administration said the killing was a defensive action and that Soleimani was developing plans to attack American diplomats and troops in Iraq and the region.
4: PolitiFact decided to take a closer look at Pence’s claim that Soleimani assisted the men who carried out the terrorist attacks on 9/11.
5: There’s no evidence to support his statement, and his press secretary did not provide information that directly tied Soleimani to the travel of the 9/11 terrorists.
6: Iran and terrorists’ travel to Afghanistan The 9/11 terrorist attacks were carried out by 19 men who hijacked four commercial airplanes, deliberately crashing two planes against the World Trade Center towers, flying another plane into the Pentagon, and the fourth crashing into a field in Pennsylvania.
7: The attacks killed nearly 3,000 people and were orchestrated by the al-Qaida terrorist group based in Afghanistan.
8: The attackers traveled to Afghanistan for training.
9: The 19 hijackers included 15 from Saudi Arabia, two from the United Arab Emirates, one from Lebanon, and one from Egypt.
10: The 9/11 Commission Report , published in 2004, provided a comprehensive account of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the events and circumstances leading to the attacks, and recommendations to prevent other attacks.
11: Soleimani is not named anywhere in the report.
12: A section of the report said Iranian officials had been willing to facilitate the travel of al-Qaida members through Iran, on their way to and from Afghanistan, telling Iranian border inspectors not to stamp the passports of those travelers.
13: (Iran and Afghanistan share a border.)
14: The report said that Saudi "muscle" operatives traveled into or out of Iran between October 2000 and February 2001.
15: "Muscle" operatives were hijackers who would storm cockpits and control passengers.
16: But the report also said it found no evidence that Iran was aware of the planning for what later became the 9/11 attack.
17: "At the time of their travel through Iran, the al-Qaida operatives themselves were probably not aware of the specific details of their future operation," the report said.
18: So while the report mentions Iranian officials’ willingness to facilitate the travel of al-Qaida members, it doesn’t implicate Soleimani.
19: Philip Zelikow, executive director of the 9/11 Commission Report, told PolitiFact that the report did not directly tie Soleimani to assisting the travel of the terrorists and that he was not aware of any other information that would tie Soleimani to their travel.
20: Two other experts shared the view of a lacking Soleimani connection: James Gelvin, a professor of modern Middle East history at UCLA, and Hooshang Amirahmadi, a distinguished service professor at Rutgers University with expertise in United States-Iran relations.
21: What is Pence’s defense?
22: Pence spokeswoman Katie Waldman pointed out the Trump administration’s April 2019 stated intention to designate the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization.
23: The administration in a fact-sheet said the U.S. Treasury Department in 2016 sanctioned three senior al-Qaida operatives in Iran, and that Iran had knowingly permitted those operatives, including several of the 9/11 hijackers, to transit Iran on their way to Afghanistan.
24: But that fact-sheet does not mention Soleimani.
25: Pence’s tweet said Soleimani assisted "10 of the 12 terrorists," and Twitter users pointed out that there were 19 terrorists on 9/11.
26: Waldman tweeted , "For those asking: 12 of the 19 transited through Afghanistan.
27: 10 of those 12 were assisted by Soleimani."
28: Her tweet did not provide any additional information or links to evidence to support Pence’s claim.

gpt4: The claim that Qassem Soleimani assisted in the clandestine travel to Afghanistan of 10 of the 12 terrorists responsible for the September 11 terrorist attacks in the United States has been determined false.

The reasoning behind this verdict is that there is no existing evidence that corroborates this assertion, and attempts to secure information that could directly connect Soleimani's involvement with the travel of the aforementioned terrorists from his press secretary were not successful[5].
Furthermore, Soleimani's name is noticeably absent from the 9/11 Commission Report[11].
And while the same report does note the willingness of Iranian officials to facilitate the travels of al-Qaida members, it does not specifically implicate Soleimani[18].
This lack of direct tech was confirmed by Philip Zelikow, the executive director of the 9/11 Commission Report.

Zelikow, when speaking to PolitiFact, clarified that the report did not directly associate Soleimani with assisting the travel of the terrorists and that he was unaware of any additional information linking Soleimani to their journeys[19].
Even a fact-sheet related to the matter did not mention Soleimani as involved in any way[24].

a74ea124fc03521b4e5b4c37a1f55cc0.claim: a photo shows Barack Obama smiling and shaking hands with Hassan Rouhani.
a74ea124fc03521b4e5b4c37a1f55cc0.label: false
a74ea124fc03521b4e5b4c37a1f55cc0.passage:
