0: A lengthy meme that regularly makes the rounds on Facebook attacks Democrats on Social Security.
1: We’re focusing here on two of the claims in the question-and-answer formatted post , which has been shared more than 450,000 times.
2: The Democratic Party "took Social Security from the independent ‘Trust Fund’ and put it into the general fund so that Congress could spend it," the post claims, and "eliminated the income tax deduction for Social Security (FICA) withholding."
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: It’s wrong on both counts.
6: The Social Security challenge Social Security was signed into law by Democratic President Franklin Roosevelt in 1935 to, according to the law’s preamble , "provide for the general welfare by establishing a system of Federal old-age benefits, and by enabling the several States to make more adequate provision for aged persons, blind persons, dependent and crippled children, maternal and child welfare, public health, and the administration of their unemployment compensation laws."
7: Now a $1 trillion-a-year program , it helps more than 63 million retirees and the disabled, plus their families, pay the bills.
8: The federal government faces a major challenge: Social Security’s $2.9 trillion in its combined trust funds, or reserves, will run out by about 2035.
9: The program will continue to pay benefits, but without additional taxpayer dollars, it could only afford to pay between 70% and 80% of the benefits people expect.
10: Social Security is often the object of inaccurate statements that stir fear or anger.
11: We previously rated as False a claim on Facebook that Congress rejected a $336-per-month increase in Social Security and disability benefits but approved an $8,872-per-month pay increase for itself.
12: As for the post we’re checking now, the Social Security Administration includes both parts of the claim in a "Debunking Some Internet Myths" section of its website.
13: No trust fund to general fund The first part alleges the Democratic Party "took Social Security from the independent ‘Trust Fund’ and put it into the general fund so that Congress could spend it."
14: The Social Security Administration says: "There has never been any change in the way the Social Security program is financed or the way that Social Security payroll taxes are used by the federal government.
15: … From its inception, the Trust Fund has always worked the same way.
16: The Social Security Trust Fund has never been ‘put into the general fund of the government.’ "Most likely this question comes from a confusion between the financing of the Social Security program and the way the Social Security Trust Fund is treated in federal budget accounting.
17: Starting in 1969, the transactions to the Trust Fund were included in what is known as the ‘unified budget.’ This means that every function of the federal government is included in a single budget.
18: ...This budget treatment of the Social Security Trust Fund continued until 1990 when the Trust Funds were again taken ‘off-budget.’ This means only that they are shown as a separate account in the federal budget.
19: But whether the Trust Funds are ‘on-budget’ or ‘off-budget’ is primarily a question of accounting practices — it has no effect on the actual operations of the Trust Fund itself."
20: While the Social Security trust fund balances weren't affected by the accounting change, "what economists and other policy analysts were concerned with is whether combining Social Security's surpluses with the on-budget's deficits encouraged policymakers to run larger deficits in the non-Social Security part of the budget," said American Enterprise Institute scholar Andrew Biggs, a former deputy commissioner with the Social Security Administration.
21: "For example, let's imagine that the public demanded that budget deficits be no more than, say, $100 billion per year.
22: If they exceeded that amount, voters would consider Congress to be fiscally irresponsible and punish them at the next election.
23: But if Social Security were running a $100 billion surplus, then Congress could run a $200 billion deficit in the rest of the budget while still reporting only a $100 billion unified budget deficit," Biggs told us.
24: "Most research has concluded that this is pretty much what happened: surpluses in Social Security encouraged Congress to run larger deficits in the rest of the budget, either by taxing less or spending more."
25: No tax deduction The second part of the claim is that the Democratic Party  "eliminated the income tax deduction for Social Security (FICA) withholding."
26: This too is inaccurate.
27: "There was never any provision of law making the Social Security taxes paid by employees deductible for income tax purposes.
28: In fact, the 1935 law expressly forbid this idea," the Social Security administration says.

gpt4: The claim that the Democratic Party "took Social Security from the independent ‘Trust Fund’ and put it into the general fund so that Congress could spend it" and "eliminated the income tax deduction for Social Security (FICA) withholding" is false.
The Social Security Administration itself has addressed these misconceptions in a section of its website titled "Debunking Some Internet Myths"[12].
In fact, the Social Security Trust Fund has never been moved to the general fund of the government [16].
The confusion in these claims likely arises from misunderstandings about the financing of the Social Security program and its accounting within the federal budget [16].
However, the distinction between whether the Trust Funds are considered 'on-budget' or 'off-budget' doesn't impact the actual operation of the Trust Fund [19].
The claim that the income tax deduction for Social Security withholding was eliminated is also not true[26].
The Social Security Administration confirms that the original 1935 law expressly forbade this action [28].

bbeddfca550988ff6bddfc246c2e4436.claim: the Chinese Communist Party ""will finally admit that the real source of the coronavirus is from ‘a lab in Wuhan’ linked to its covert biological weapon programs."""
bbeddfca550988ff6bddfc246c2e4436.label: false
bbeddfca550988ff6bddfc246c2e4436.passage:
0: A website with ties to Steve Bannon and a Chinese billionaire is claiming to have a scoop on the source of the coronavirus.
1: In an article published Jan. 25, G News wrote that Chinese Communist Party officials would soon "admit that the real source of the coronavirus is from ‘a lab in Wuhan (China)’ linked to its covert biological weapon programs."
2: "A reliable source told Miles Guo today that the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will admit to the public of an ‘accidental’ leak of lab-created virus from a P4 lab in Wuhan to put blames on ‘human errors,’" the article reads.
3: "But the official announcement is still being finalized."
4: The article was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared thousands of times.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from G News) The coronavirus, which originated in the central China city of Wuhan, has infected more than 2,700 people worldwide, according to a Jan. 27 World Health Organization report.
8: China has restricted travel within the country amid a rising death toll.
9: While we can’t know who G News has or hasn’t spoken to, we could find no evidence to support the website’s story.
10: Miles Guo, also known as Guo Wengui, is a Chinese billionaire and political activist .
11: He fled China in 2014 in anticipation of corruption charges from the Communist Party.
12: Since then, Wengui, who is a member of President Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, has become known for his outspoken criticism of Chinese efforts to weed out corruption.
13: G News is the media arm of Guo Media, a company linked to Wengui.
14: Axios reported in October that the company paid Bannon, Trump’s former chief strategist and former executive chairman of Breitbart News, at least $1 million for "strategic consulting services."
15: Both Bannon and Wengui have their own sections on G News.
16: We could find no other media reports that corroborate G News’ story about the source of the coronavirus.
17: There is a lab near Wuhan that deals with dangerous pathogens — and some have linked it to China’s biological warfare program.
18: The country denies having such a program, but the U.S. State Department has raised concerns about China’s potential noncompliance with the Biological Weapons Convention, which bans the production of such weapons.
19: Officials are still working to determine the source of the coronavirus outbreak.
20: In its most recent situation summary , the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that both it and Chinese authorities had isolated the genome of the 2019 coronavirus.
21: Their findings suggest "a likely single, recent emergence from a virus related to bat coronaviruses and the SARS coronavirus."
22: The disease appears to have originated at a seafood and animal market in Wuhan, and it spread from there to several Asian countries, Australia, France, Canada and the United States.
23: Researchers believe the current outbreak pattern suggests the coronavirus may have spread from animal to human at first, and now from human to human.
24: G News’ story is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will officially admit the source of the coronavirus is a lab in Wuhan, related to covert biological weapon programs is unsupported and likely false.

While an article published by G News on Jan. 25 posits that the CCP will attribute the virus to an accidental leak from a Wuhan P4 lab due to human errors [1][2], none of this information could be corroborated.
There is no available evidence supporting the article's account on the source of the virus, and other media reports have not substantiated G News' story [9][16].
Furthermore, officials are still in the process of determining the origin of the coronavirus outbreak [19].
Presently, researchers suggest that the coronavirus initially spread from animals to humans, and afterwards from human to human, aligning with the standard pattern for viral outbreaks [23].

a72b99191f902b11c8972e4a7ae3b518.claim: Obama’s lawyers officially admit birth certificate is fake.
a72b99191f902b11c8972e4a7ae3b518.label: false
a72b99191f902b11c8972e4a7ae3b518.passage:
0: A 2012 story about former President Barack Obama’s birth certificate is, somehow, getting new traction as Facebook users share it.
1: But we reluctantly welcome it to our archive of mistruths about the 44th president’s citizenship.
2: The story, posted on Occupycorporatism.com, has this headline: "Obama’s lawyers officially admit birth certificate is fake."
3: It goes on to say that "lawyers for the Obama Administration announced that Barack Obama’s long form birth certificate was a forgery" and "Alexandra M. Hill, representative defense attorney for Obama, made comments that brought the Tea Party members to question the legitimacy of Obama’s birth certificate."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: This inaccurate story seems to stem from coverage of a 2012 lawsuit filed by two New Jersey residents challenging Obama’s eligibility to appear on the state’s presidential primary ballot.
7: Plaintiff’s attorney Mario Apuzzo got to the heart of the complaint during an April 2012 court hearing:.
8: ""What evidence does New Jersey have that this person who is running for president is who he is?"
9: Apuzzo said, according to an April 10, 2012, story in the Home News Tribune, a daily paper serving Middlesex County.
10: .

gpt4: The claim that Barack Obama's lawyers officially admitted that his birth certificate is fake is false[1].

This misinformation appears to have originated from the misinterpretation of a 2012 lawsuit, filed by two New Jersey residents who challenged Obama's eligibility to appear on the state's presidential primary ballot[6].

The lawsuit suggested that the Obama Administration's legal representatives announced the forgery of Barack Obama's long-form birth certificate, a statement that prompted members of the Tea Party to question the legitimacy of Obama’s birth certificate [3].
However, these representations of the lawsuit proceedings are false, thus the claim is labeled as a falsehood in our archive of untruths regarding the 44th President’s citizenship [1].

b79ae5ea542449e6e75a39b405c6b98c.claim: Video shows Gianna Bryant in the hospital after helicopter crash.
b79ae5ea542449e6e75a39b405c6b98c.label: false
b79ae5ea542449e6e75a39b405c6b98c.passage:
0: A video claims to show Gianna Bryant being ushered through a hospital, surrounded by medical staff.
1: But that didn’t happen.
2: Bryant died with her father Kobe Bryant in a helicopter crash on Jan. 26.
3: The next day, a video titled, "Kobe Bryant Daughter Gianna Bryant Final Hours" was uploaded to YouTube.
4: The video shows a young girl laying motionless on a hospital bed.
5: She is slowly moved down a hallway lined with doctors and nurses in the first part of the video, and in the second she is surrounded by hospital staff and mourners.
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Together, they’ve been shared thousands of times.
9: As of Jan. 28, the video has 485,771 views on YouTube and 112,600 likes on the original TikTok it appeared in.
10: While this video does feature a young woman who was killed in an accident, that woman is 28-year-old Ariana Cervantes.
11: The original video was titled "Ariana’s Honor Walk" and was uploaded to YouTube on Sept. 4, 2019.
12: The Pacific Attorney Group reported that Cervantes was one of two people killed by a traffic collision on Aug. 28, 2019, in Downey, Calif. She died two days later in the hospital.
13: The video description says that Cervantes was an organ donor who received an honor walk, a ritual described by the New York Times as a way to show respect to dying patients planning to donate their organs.
14: The full version of this video was uploaded more than four months before Gianna Bryant’s death.

gpt4: The claim that a video shows Gianna Bryant in the hospital after a helicopter crash is false.
Gianna Bryant, the daughter of Kobe Bryant, tragically died alongside her father in a helicopter crash on January 26th [2].
The day after, a video surfaced on YouTube titled, "Kobe Bryant Daughter Gianna Bryant Final Hours"[3].
However, this video does not actually feature Gianna Bryant.
The young woman in the video is actually 28-year-old Ariana Cervantes, not Gianna Bryant[10].
Furthermore, the original video, named "Ariana’s Honor Walk", was uploaded to YouTube on September 4, 2019, long before the helicopter crash even occurred [11][14].

fa0d4324a6b40ff0b67e2fe7615125fe.claim: FDA finally admits dental fillings are toxic.
fa0d4324a6b40ff0b67e2fe7615125fe.label: false
fa0d4324a6b40ff0b67e2fe7615125fe.passage:
0: Facebook users have been sharing a story that warns the U.S. Food and Drug Administration "finally admits dental fillings are toxic."
1: This post, which was published on Principia Scientific on Dec. 12, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: The story says that, as part of a lawsuit settlement with consumer groups, the FDA was forced to publicly admit that "all ‘silver’ dental fillings are poisoned with mercury."
4: It’s referring to dental amalgam, a filling material dentists use to fill cavities.
5: According to the FDA , its primary component is elemental mercury.
6: Amalgam fillings are also known as "silver fillings" because of their silver-like appearance.
7: The agency says such fillings have been used in hundreds of millions of patients around the world for over a century, and are beneficial because they’re strong and less likely to break than those made of other materials.
8: But there are also risks.
9: Amalgam releases low levels of mercury vapor that can be inhaled and absorbed by the lungs.
10: High levels of mercury vapor exposure can harm the brain and kidneys.
11: The FDA says it reviewed scientific evidence to determine whether low levels of mercury vapor from dental amalgam fillings were cause for concern.
12: Based on the evidence, according to the agency, the FDA considers them safe for adults and children 6 and older.
13: But fetuses and young children may be more sensitive to the "neurotoxic effects of mercury vapor," according to the FDA.
14: It says there is "very limited to no" clinical data on the long-term health outcomes for pregnant women, their fetuses and young children, and advises concerned patients to talk to their dentists.
15: The agency also discourages patients from removing their dental amalgams if they’re in good condition and there’s no tooth decay under the filling because, in part, it could expose that person to additional mercury vapor released during the removal process.
16: Though the Principia Scientific story was published in 2018, it uses an FDA statement from 2008 to show that the agency "was finally forced to admit" amalgam fillings are toxic.
17: It was then, Reuters reported in June 2008 , that the FDA settled a lawsuit with several consumer advocacy groups, including Consumers for Dental Choice and Moms Against Mercury.
18: The group sought to ban mercury fillings from the U.S. market.
19: As part of the settlement, according to Reuters, the FDA agreed to alert consumers about the potential risks on its website and to issue a more specific rule about fillings that contain mercury.
20: In a notice on its website — and this is what the Principia Scientific story quotes — the FDA said that amalgams contain mercury, which may have neurotoxic effects on the nervous systems of developing children and fetuses.
21: "Pregnant women and persons who may have a health condition that makes them more sensitive to mercury exposure, including individuals with existing high levels of mercury microburden, should not avoid seeking dental care, but should discuss options with their health practitioner," the FDA said.
22: At the time, a lawyer for Consumers for Dental Choice described the FDA’s statement as a major shift.
23: "Gone, gone, gone are all of the FDA’s claims that no science exists that amalgam is unsafe," he said.
24: The Associated Press, reporting on the settlement , said that "silver dental fillings contain mercury, and the government for the first time is warning that they may pose a safety concern for pregnant women and young children."
25: It described it as a victory for "anti-mercury activists."
26: But the report also notes that the warning isn’t aimed at everybody — just two groups of people who are already urged to limit mercury from seafood because too much can harm a developing brain.

gpt4: The claim that the FDA has admitted dental fillings are toxic is false.

The FDA has indeed acknowledged that dental amalgams, which are a type of filling, contain mercury, and that this may have neurotoxic effects on the nervous systems of developing children and fetuses [20].

However, it emphasizes that pregnant women and those with health conditions that make them more sensitive to mercury exposure should not avoid dental care, but should discuss options with their health practitioner [21].
As part of a settlement, the FDA did agree to alert consumers about potential risks and issue a more specific rule about fillings that contain mercury [19].
Yet, it clearly states that it considers such fillings safe for adults and children 6 and older based on existing evidence [12].
Therefore, to claim that the FDA has declared dental fillings as toxic is a distortion of the agency's stance.

68e134b759a589f544e34dc963d03906.claim: More than 80% of Republicans think we ought to at least be doing universal background checks.
68e134b759a589f544e34dc963d03906.label: half-true
68e134b759a589f544e34dc963d03906.passage:
0: Pete Buttigieg is running in the Democratic primary for president, but he said a lot of "future former Republicans" are coming to hear his ideas.
1: "I am proposing things that most Americans even in conservative states think we ought to do," including gun control, Buttigieg said Jan. 26 at a Fox News town hall in Des Moines.
2: "More than 80% of Republicans think we ought to at least be doing universal background checks," the former South Bend, Ind., mayor said.
3: We’ve fact-checked multiple claims about support for expanding background checks among the general public and NRA members .
4: So what about support for universal background checks among Republicans?
5: Many Democrats running for president have called for universal background checks , which would extend such checks to private sales, including at gun shows.
6: The House in 2019 passed a bill to ban the private transfer of firearms without a background check, but it hasn’t been heard in the Senate.
7: RELATED: Do gun background checks work?
8: What the research shows Polls about background checks show majority GOP support Buttigieg’s campaign pointed to two polls that backed up his point.
9: Both followed the back-to-back mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton in August 2019.
10: While one could argue that such timing could affect the public’s willingness to support stricter measures on guns, we found support was also above 80% before those mass shootings.
11: A Politico/Morning Consult poll in August 2019 found that 90% of Republicans said they would back background checks for all gun sales.
12: A Washington Post-ABC News poll in September 2019 found that 83% of Republicans support requiring background checks for all potential buyers.
13: We looked at other polls in recent years and found that between 82% and 95% of Republicans stated support for background checks for all buyers.
14: NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist Poll in July 2019 found that 84% of Republicans said it was a good idea to require background checks at gun shows and private sales.
15: Gallup found in 2017 that 95% of Republicans supported background checks for all buyers after the Las Vegas shooting.
16: ( Gallup didn’t include the statistic specifically for Republicans in their original press release because there wasn’t a significant difference between parties, but a spokeswoman gave us the information.)
17: Quinnipiac polls between 2013 and 2019 showed that between 86% and 92% of Republicans supported background checks for all buyers.
18: Pew Research Center found in a September 2019 poll that 82% of Republicans favor making private gun sales and sales at gun shows subject to background checks.
19: Polls can differ from responses to specific legislation or ballot questions The National Rifle Association has pointed to the results of background check referendums in Maine and Nevada in 2016 that showed lower support for background checks than the national polls suggest.
20: In Maine , 52% rejected a background check measure.
21: In Nevada , a background check question just barely passed with about 50.5% of the vote.
22: Leading up to the election, polls showed higher support for the measures.
23: The gist of the NRA’s argument is that when people are asked a generic question by a pollster, that leads to a different result than when they actually face a question on a ballot that could affect their own rights.
24: Pew Research Center found in 2013 that support for expanded background checks isn’t necessarily the same as support for specific legislation.
25: Pew’s poll found 81% of Republicans supported expanded background checks, but when asked if they supported a U.S. Senate bill that included such legislation, Republican support dropped to 57%.
26: That still suggests strong support, though by a smaller margin.
27: Some respondents expressed concerns that the bill included restrictions beyond background checks or would lead to a "slippery slope."
28: "People may support background checks in general, but become more skeptical when gun rights groups highlight specific complications or unintended consequences that could arise when these laws are implemented," said Kristin Goss, professor of public policy and political science at Duke University.
29: Also, it’s possible that some respondents who say they want background checks for all sales may not realize that it is not current federal law -- a point backed up by a 2013 poll done for the Democratic National Committee.
30: Of the 50% of people who said they preferred enforcement over new laws, 48% said they thought federal law prohibits gun purchases privately or at a gun show without a background check.
31: Another 10% disclosed that they didn’t know the rules.
32: "Most people don’t have a very good grasp of what our gun laws are," Goss said.
33: "To be fair to Americans, gun laws are complicated and vary greatly state by state."

gpt4: While polling indicates that a significant majority of Republicans, around 81%, are in favor of expanding background checks as measured in a Pew's poll[25], this figure doesn't necessarily confirm that over 80% of Republicans support universal background checks.
The figures can change depending on the context of the question as noted by the NRA[23].
When Republicans were confronted with a specific U.S Senate bill which included expanded background checks, the level of support dropped to 57%[25].

So, although a clear majority of Republicans support increased background checks, there's evidence to suggest the figure drops when potential impacts on personal rights are made explicit[23], thus making the claim only partially accurate.

834e34b800c8b47aa043b06d62ca631b.claim: An MSNBC reporter was fired for using a racial slur while covering the Kobe Bryant helicopter crash.
834e34b800c8b47aa043b06d62ca631b.label: false
834e34b800c8b47aa043b06d62ca631b.passage:
0: MSNBC anchor Alison Morris came under fire this week after allegations that she used a racial slur on air while covering the tragic Kobe Bryant helicopter crash .
1: During her report on Jan. 26, Morris flubbed the word "Lakers," leading some people to believe she stuttered the N-word.
2: A Change.org petition calling for Morris’ resignation has received more than 145,000 signatures as of Jan. 29.
3: And now a blog post has gone viral on Facebook with a false headline that claims Morris was fired over the incident: "MSNBC Reporter allegedly fired over racial slur while reporting on TV￼."
4: The headline has been viewed by more than 13.8 million people on Facebook as of Jan. 29.
5: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: This isn’t accurate –– Morris has not been fired.
8: She apologized on Twitter, saying the flub was an accident and not a racial slur.
9: You can listen to the video yourself below.
10: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The blog post , published on a Wordpress page called "Peterson Breaking News of Trenton," displays a photograph of Morris –– and while the headline claims she was fired –– the story doesn’t mention it.
11: The article only talks about the viral flub and Morris’ subsequent apology on Twitter: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com We found no credible report claiming Morris has been fired.
12: MSNBC has not released a statement about the incident or a change in Morris’ employment.
13: The cable channel did not respond to a request for comment.

gpt4: The assertion that an MSNBC reporter was terminated for using a racial slur while covering the Kobe Bryant helicopter crash is false.
Confirmation of this came when a blog post misrepresenting the incident garnered significant traffic on Facebook[3].
However, no official statement has been released by MSNBC concerning the incident or any alteration in Morris' employment status[12].
Furthermore, the facts verify that Morris has not been dismissed from his role at MSNBC[7].

2bc427132b3b9dbaa43736e7e2cb2603.claim: When asked if he’s defended former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch, ""I've defended every single person on this team."""
2bc427132b3b9dbaa43736e7e2cb2603.label: false
2bc427132b3b9dbaa43736e7e2cb2603.passage:
0: An interview between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and NPR’s Mary Louise Kelly ended shortly after she asked him about Ukraine and his treatment of Marie Yovanovitch after her removal as U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.
1: "Do you owe Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch an apology?"
2: Kelly asked him.
3: Pompeo said he had "defended every State Department official."
4: "Sir, respectfully, where have you defended Marie Yovanovitch?"
5: Kelly asked.
6: "I've defended every single person on this team," Pompeo said Jan. 24.
7: "I've done what's right for every single person on this team."
8: Kelly asked him to point to remarks where he’d defended Yovanovitch.
9: Pompeo did not do that.
10: Yovanovitch was the point person for American anti-corruption policy in Ukraine and later became the target of smears by Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.
11: Trump also disparaged her foreign service history.
12: We rated Trump’s inaccurate claims about her as Pants on Fire .
13: RELATED : Who is Marie Yovanovitch, the former ambassador to Ukraine removed by Trump?
14: We wanted to know if Pompeo had defended Yovanovitch.
15: So we reviewed more than 120 State Department transcripts of interviews Pompeo had with online news agencies, TV, radio, and newspaper reporters since May 2019, the month that Yovanovitch was recalled from her post in Ukraine.
16: We found no record of Pompeo publicly defending Yovanovitch.
17: When asked, he broadly spoke about defending all State Department employees without defending anyone in particular.
18: We found no indication of Pompeo defending her to the press at conferences or while traveling to events.
19: The Twitter accounts for Pompeo, the State Department, and the department’s press secretary also don’t show a defense of Yovanovitch.
20: The State Department did not respond to our queries asking for evidence for Pompeo’s claim.
21: Here are some typical interviews where Pompeo was directly asked about Yovanovitch and his lack of a public defense for the former ambassador.
22: Oct. 20 interview with George Stephanopoulos of ABC’s This Week In an extensive back-and-forth , ABC’s George Stephanopoulos asked Pompeo whether he was aware of Giuliani’s push to get rid of Yovanovitch.
23: Pompeo said "she's a foreign service officer in good standing," that ambassadors serve at the pleasure of the president, and it’s in everyone’s best interest for ambassadors to leave their post if the president has lost confidence in them.
24: "I'm not going to get into personnel matters inside the State Department.
25: I’ve not done it and I’m not going to do it for you here this morning," Pompeo said.
26: Stephanopoulos said many foreign service professionals believe Pompeo had a duty to speak up for her and protect her in that position.
27: "George, in good time all of the facts surrounding each of these incidents will become clear.
28: But it's not appropriate for me to comment on all of the things that happen inside of personnel decisions," Pompeo said.
29: "None of our foreign service officers would welcome the Secretary of State talking about why someone stayed, why someone was removed, why someone was transferred.
30: It wouldn’t be appropriate."
31: Oct. 11 interviews with Tennessee media Nancy Amons of WSMV in Nashville told Pompeo that career diplomats had publicly expressed frustration over what they saw as Pompeo’s failure to stand up for government employees.
32: "Did you do enough to defend the ambassador, privately and publicly, against the smear campaign that was being waged against her, and will you speak to that now?"
33: Amons asked. "
34: Well, ma’am, you have some of your facts wrong, so you should be careful about things you assert as facts before you state them," Pompeo said .
35: He went on to say he was proud of the work done by the State Department. "
36: I’ve supported every mission that the State Department’s been engaged in and will continue to do that," Pompeo replied.
37: Jason Lamb of WTVF in Nashville also interviewed Pompeo that day.
38: Lamb told Pompeo that Democrats in a letter had accused him of remaining silent regarding Yovanovitch.
39: "The letter says it’s incumbent on you not to further the president’s damaging and unfounded attacks, but to send a simple message to everyone who works at the Department of State: you have their backs," Lamb said.
40: "What is your message to everyone at the Department of State?"
41: "I have their backs," Pompeo said, without saying anything specific about Yovanovitch.
42: Nov. 18 press briefing On Nov. 18 at a State Department press briefing , Pompeo was asked why he had not made statements of support for employees testifying in the impeachment inquiry.
43: "I’m not going to get into the issues surrounding the Democrat impeachment inquiry.
44: I’m just not going to do it today," Pompeo said, according to a State Department transcript.
45: A reporter asked again: "But no defense of your employees?"
46: "I always defend State Department employees," Pompeo said.
47: "It’s the greatest diplomatic corps in the history of the world.
48: Very proud of the team."
49: New York Times article on John Bolton’s book The New York Times on Jan. 26 reported about an unpublished manuscript for a forthcoming book by former National Security Adviser John Bolton.
50: The New York Times said Bolton in his book wrote that Pompeo acknowledged privately to him that there was no basis to Giuliani’s claims that Yovanovitch was corrupt and that he believed Giuliani may have been acting on behalf of other clients.
51: PolitiFact is unable to verify whether that private conversation took place and we’ve seen no public confirmation from Pompeo about Bolton’s manuscript.

gpt4: The claim that Pompeo defended Marie Yovanovitch, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, is false.
The exploration for evidence to substantiate this claim yielded the fact that no verifiable record exists in which Pompeo stood up publicly for Yovanovitch[14][16].
Moreover, a review of Pompeo's, the State Department's, and the department’s press secretary's Twitter accounts also did not furnish any statements in defense of Yovanovitch[19].

478ea72116ff299a7cdc08e31f9825a6.claim: The president of the United States already has the legal authority to reduce the price of many commonly used prescription drugs.
478ea72116ff299a7cdc08e31f9825a6.label: true
478ea72116ff299a7cdc08e31f9825a6.passage:
0: On the presidential primary campaign trail in Iowa, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., brought out a favorite talking point: ways the president can bring down drug prices without waiting for Congress.
1: It’s not the first time Warren and other candidates have referenced this alleged power.
2: In this case, she pointed to insulin, EpiPens and HIV/AIDS drugs as possible targets.
3: We asked the Warren campaign for the basis of her claim and they directed us to her "Medicare for All" transition plan.
4: It identifies two legal mechanisms ― "compulsory licensing" as outlined in 28 U.S. Code Section 1498 and the so-called march-in rights provision of the 1980 Bayh-Dole Act.
5: We spoke to legal and pharmaceutical policy experts about whether those mechanisms could be used to bring down drug prices, as Warren described.
6: The answer?
7: Yes.
8: But it’s complicated and controversial.
9: The legal mechanisms Of the two legal levers, Section 1498 is perhaps more straightforward.
10: The law says the government can intervene to take over patents without a company’s permission, if the price is too high.
11: The government can then create competition to bring down prices by importing those products from abroad, or manufacturing them.
12: The original manufacturer can sue for damages but cannot stop Washington from breaking the patent.
13: "What they would do is announce they are taking other bids from other companies to supply the product" to government programs such as Medicare, said Aaron Kesselheim, a professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School who researches drug pricing laws and has written extensively about Section 1498.
14: The provision has been used before ― in the 1960s to procure cheap generic drugs ― and was invoked as recently as 2001, as a threat to get a better price on Ciprofloxacin, a high-powered antibiotic used to treat anthrax.
15: It also was used in 2014 in non-pharmaceutical contexts, such as by the Defense Department to acquire lead-free bullets.
16: Invoking this part of the U.S. code wouldn’t necessarily apply to all drugs, said Jacob Sherkow, a professor at New York Law School.
17: But products such as the ones Warren mentioned ― insulin and EpiPens, for instance, which are patented in the United States and abroad, and cost far less in other countries ― would qualify.
18: And that could send a message to other drug manufacturers.
19: "If you’re a particularly aggressive president, you can find some low-hanging fruit, and use 1498 to show other pharmaceutical companies you’re damn serious," Sherkow said.
20: There are other caveats.
21: Sherkow noted that licensing a competing drug is only part of the equation; competition often brings down drug prices, but not always.
22: In addition, not all drugs have equivalent patents here and abroad, which complicates importation.
23: But many of the technical obstacles are surmountable, argued Amy Kapczynski, a professor at Yale Law School.
24: The march-in rights authority a little trickier.
25: Bayh-Dole, the law that created march-in rights, suggests the government can "march in" when a drug isn’t available amid concerns over public health, such as an epidemic.
26: It applies only to pharmaceuticals for which the government holds all the patents because it funded the research that led to their development.
27: An example could be Truvada for PrEP, the HIV prevention pill, Kesselheim said.
28: Unlike Section 1498, march-in rights have  never been used to negotiate a lower price ― despite multiple petitions to the National Institutes of Health, the federal agency that would approve and oversee the process.
29: The question is whether high prices can constitute both a barrier and a public health concern having rendered  a drug unavailable.
30: Sherkow, for one, expressed skepticism.
31: NIH has historically opted against making this determination.
32: For one, its directors have typically argued that cost isn’t within their area of expertise.
33: And, for another, they have suggested that "marching in" would discourage pharmaceutical companies from using government-funded research ― ultimately leading to fewer breakthrough drugs being developed.
34: "That is a matter of culture, and I think a president could alter that perspective," Kesselheim said.
35: Doing so, though, would require political capital.
36: Even though Congress isn’t required to vote on the matter, the president would have to, for instance, appoint officials willing to change the NIH perspective ― and those leaders do require Senate confirmation.
37: "You’d probably have to defend it in court," Kesselheim added.
38: Finally, these mechanisms would also draw sharp pushback from the pharmaceutical industry.
39: Given the fervor over the drug pricing debate, neither Section 1498 nor march-in rights should be used ubiquitously, Kesselheim said.
40: "It is a complicated enough and politically charged enough procedure, that it’s something that should be reserved as a safety net for real public health emergencies," he said.
41: "I think Sen. Warren is identifying some of those cases."
42: They’re all talking about it Warren’s proposals are part of a larger pattern ― Democratic presidential candidates including Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg ― have talked about ways to bring down drug prices without congressional action.
43: Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar also referenced such action during the January presidential primary debate.
44: "I have a plan of 137 things I found that a president can do herself in the first 100 days without Congress that are legal.
45: And one of those things is that you can start bringing in less expensive drugs from other parties," she said.
46: According to Klobuchar’s campaign, she was referring to a list she published on Medium in June 2019 in which she wrote that she would use "existing Food and Drug Administration authority to grant a waiver that allows people to import safe prescription drugs for personal use from countries like Canada to decrease drug costs for seniors and all Americans."
47: Sherkow said this is indeed another example.
48: Section 804 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act authorizes the HHS secretary to order the importation of specific drugs if it would impose no additional risk to the public’s health and safety and would result in a significant cost reduction.
49: But this example also highlights the complexities involved and why it is not necessarily fast or easy.
50: He pointed out that the president would have to nominate a candidate for secretary, get that person confirmed, then have the secretary make this order in respect to specific drugs, certify that the drugs are safe and would result in cost reduction ― then have the importation take place.
51: "Kudos to anyone for trying that in the first 100 days," Sherkow said.

gpt4: The claim that the president of the United States already has the legal authority to reduce the price of many commonly used prescription drugs is upheld by two existing legal provisions.

The first is "compulsory licensing," as defined by 28 U.S. Code Section 1498, which posits that the government can intervene to take over patents without a company’s permission if the price is deemed prohibitive[10][4].

It has had historical usage since not only has it previously been leveraged in the 1960s to procure inexpensive generic drugs, but it was also impliedly threatened as recently as 2001 to haggle a better price on Ciprofloxacin, a powerful antibiotic used to treat anthrax[14].

The second provision is the "march-in rights" stipulated in the 1980 Bayh-Dole Act, supported by the fact that it allows the government to "march in" when a drug isn’t available, especially during a public health crisis, such as an epidemic[25].
However, it's worth mentioning that it is solely applicable to medications for which the government holds all the patents, as it had sponsored the research that led to their creation[26].

Despite this, even widely-patented pharmaceuticals such as insulin and EpiPens, that also cost significantly less in other countries, can qualify [17].It is important to note that march-in rights have never been used to negotiate a lower price, despite multiple petitions to the National Institutes of Health, the federal agency tasked with approving and supervising the process[28].

1ef8e957d91abe6514ca926a9ed723ab.claim: Vice President Biden threatened a foreign country and forced them to fire a prosecutor who was investigating a company,"" that paid his son Hunter."
1ef8e957d91abe6514ca926a9ed723ab.label: false
1ef8e957d91abe6514ca926a9ed723ab.passage:
0: "Sen. Rick Scott, R-Fla., isn’t running for anything in 2020, yet he’s paying for a television ad in Iowa that calls the impeachment case against President Donald Trump a "charade" while targeting Democratic presidential candidate and former Vice President Joe Biden.
1: The ad contains the same misleading allegations about Biden that have been supplied by Trump’s most ardent defenders.
2: "The real story here is the corruption Joe Biden got away with," says Scott, looking into a camera .
3: "Vice President Biden threatened a foreign country and forced them to fire a prosecutor who was investigating a company paying his son $83,000 a month.
4: Biden got away with it, and his son got paid."
5: The facts: Biden did pressure Ukraine to fire its top prosecutor, but there is no evidence it was in connection with his son’s role as a board member with the Ukranian gas company Burisma.
6: Biden’s position wanting the prosecutor removed was the same as official U.S. foreign policy, and mimicked the positions by governments and anti-corruption organizations throughout Europe.
7: The prosecutor Scott portrays as a corruption fighter was, in fact, believed to be ineffective and failing to pursue corruption cases.
8: We asked the Scott for Florida campaign for any new evidence but did not get a response.
9: News reports say the first-term senator and former governor has future presidential aspirations.
10: RELATED: Rand Paul’s false equivalence about Trump, Biden on Ukraine RELATED: Ask PolitiFact: Does a video show Joe Biden confessing to bribery?
11: No Biden was one of many who wanted prosecutor ousted Biden assumed a lead role in U.S. diplomacy toward Ukraine after a popular revolution in early 2014 that led to pro-Russia President Viktor Yanukovych fleeing the country.
12: Viktor Shokin became top prosecutor in 2015.

gpt4: The claim that Vice President Biden threatened a foreign country to fire a prosecutor investigating a company that paid his son, Hunter, is false.

It is crucial to understand that Biden’s insistence on the prosecutor's removal mirrored the official United States foreign policy and was in line with the stance of several governments and anti-corruption organizations throughout Europe[6].
Furthermore, the prosecuted person, portrayed as a fighter against corruption by some sources, was widely considered ineffective and was criticized for not pursuing corruption cases[7].

a1ace59092c3357b28987bc559cfa89e.claim: some of the names that may be purged from voter roll are people who have died.
a1ace59092c3357b28987bc559cfa89e.label: half-true
a1ace59092c3357b28987bc559cfa89e.passage:
0: The debate over whether to purge more than 200,000 names from the Wisconsin voter roll continues to bounce around the Wisconsin court system.
1: An Ozaukee County judge has repeatedly ordered the names be removed by the Wisconsin Elections Commission, but the latest order was stayed by an appeals court .
2: With the matter in limbo, two members of the divided Elections Commission took to the airwaves to make their cases.
3: The six-member board is evenly split between Republican and Democratic appointees, leading to a series of deadlocked votes on the next steps.
4: Asked if there was any middle ground, Republican appointee Bob Spindell said the voter roll needs to be updated.
5: "These are people that are probably alive, but they’ve moved, I’m sure some have died," Spindell said in the Jan. 19, 2020, appearance on WISN-TV’s ‘ UpFront’ program.
6: "This could be a very close (2020 presidential) election, and we don’t have any room for having huge numbers of people on the voting rolls that should not be there."
7: So, in framing his argument, Spindell is saying the fact dead people may be among the 230,000 is a primary reason to move ahead with the full purge.
8: Democratic appointee Ann Jacobs, appearing with Spindell, objected immediately, saying the list had already been culled for people who had died.
9: Let’s sort this out.
10: The background This controversy dates to October 2019, when the Elections Commission sent mailers to 230,000 people saying it believed they may have moved, asking them to update their voter registration or confirm if they lived at the same address.
11: The commission planned to remove people from the roll in 2021 if the resident took no action.
12: But three voters — represented by Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty — filed a lawsuit arguing the state had to remove the names from the roll faster.
13: Ozaukee County Judge Paul Malloy agreed and ordered the names be stricken from the voter roll.
14: When the commission twice deadlocked on whether to immediately remove the names — all Republicans for, all Democrats against — Malloy found the Democratic members in contempt and fined them each $250 per day until names are removed.
15: An appeals court then stayed both the fines and the order to remove the names.
16: To be sure, anyone removed from the roll would still be able to vote by re-registering ahead of the election or even at the polls on Election Day.
17: Doing so would require providing proof of residence, however, which critics say creates an unfair burden and would lead to people being unable to vote if they couldn’t provide the documents in time.
18: Does the list include dead people?
19: The Elections Commission maintains a statewide voter registration system, which municipal clerks use to manage their local voter rolls.
20: Clerks enter new voter registrations and are responsible for activating and deactivating local voters.
21: Here’s how it works for people who have died: The county coroner issues a death certificate, which is then sent to the state Department of Health Services.
22: Once a month, DHS sends a file to the state Elections Commission with a list of people who have died, and the commission then alerts municipal clerks to verify the deaths and deactivate the voters, said Reid Magney, spokesman for the Elections Commission.
23: (These updates are made more frequently as elections get close.)
24: Clerks can also on their own deactivate voters who have died based on information from family members, obituaries or other reliable sources.
25: Municipal clerks also update voters lists for a variety of other reasons, including when someone has registered to vote in another state, been convicted of a felony, been declared incompetent by a court or moved, Magney said.
26: In October, the commission used various data sources to flag 232,000 people they believed may have moved, which would require them to re-register at their new address before voting again.
27: The names came from a database already culled through the normal process for people known to have died, registered elsewhere, etc.
28: But several months have passed since then.
29: As of the week Spindell made his claim, 21,802 people who received the mailers in October had been deactivated by their municipal clerk, Magney said.
30: That included 934 deactivated due to death.
31: Which people are we talking about?
32: Spindell’s reference on "UpFront" didn’t clarify if he was referring to the original mailing list or the current list with some names removed.
33: In an interview with PolitiFact Wisconsin, he said he was referring to dead people who had since been removed through the process Magney described.
34: But his phrasing was in the present tense, saying "these are people."
35: And he raised the issue of dead voters during a discussion of what to do with the people who remain at risk of having their names removed from the voter roll — in other words those who are still on the list.
36: Anyone known to have died wouldn’t be on the list anymore, since the normal process is set up to address that situation and it has continued during the legal battle.
37: The only dead people on the list are those who have died since the latest regular update, and their names would be removed through the processes already in place.

gpt4: The claim that some of the names that may be purged from the voter roll are people who have passed away is partially accurate.
The process of removing names of deceased individuals from the voter roll involves a systematic procedure[21].
Once a month, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) sends a file to state Elections Commission containing details of individuals who have died.
The commission then informs municipal clerks to verify the deaths and deactivate the voters[22].
Clerks also have the latitude to independently deactivate voters who have passed away, based on information from family members, obituaries, or other dependable sources[24].
Names on the list that may be purged also include those who have died since the latest regular update.
After verification, these names are eventually removed using existing procedures[37].
Thus, while a fraction of the names to be purged are people who have died; other names could be removed due to other reasons, making the claim only partially true.

a2e4c0697fff524de19219bd870c0afb.claim: a ""Clorox bottle claimed it could kill (the 2019 coronavirus)... before it was developed."""
a2e4c0697fff524de19219bd870c0afb.label: false
a2e4c0697fff524de19219bd870c0afb.passage:
0: Some social media users are publishing photos of Clorox bottles to claim that the coronavirus was created before the outbreak in China.
1: In a Jan. 28 Facebook post , one user published a photo of what appears to be a Clorox bottle listing the viruses the cleaning agent kills when used on surfaces.
2: "Human Coronavirus" is circled in red.
3: "So it turns out that that ‘brand new’ ‘never before seen’ ‘insanely contageous’ (sic) ‘crazy deadly’ ‘better buy your casket right now’ virus that has ‘randomly broke out’ in China... yeah turns out my Clorox bottle claimed it could kill it... before it was developed - I mean discovered," the post reads.
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has more than 2,000 shares.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) We’ve seen plenty of hoaxes that falsely conflate the 2019 coronavirus with other strains of the illness.
8: And this post is no different.
9: There are seven kinds of coronaviruses that can infect humans.
10: They were first identified in the mid-1960s, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and some of the viruses are quite common.
11: The latest coronavirus, categorized as the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), is the strain that is spreading from Wuhan, China.
12: More than 6,000 people have been infected worldwide, according to the World Health Organization’s Jan. 29 situation report .
13: There is no evidence that it was "developed" prior to the outbreak.
14: So while some Clorox labels mention "human coronavirus," that is because it has been proven effective against past strains of coronavirus, which is to say it can be used on surfaces to stem the spread of the virus (it should never be ingested!).
15: In a blog post published Jan. 24, Clorox said that several of its products are effective at killing coronaviruses "similar to" the 2019 strain.
16: "The products listed below have demonstrated effectiveness against viruses similar to 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) on hard, nonporous surfaces," the post reads.
17: "Therefore, per the EPA Emerging Pathogen Policy, these products can be used against 2019-nCoV when used as directed."
18: Usually, per Environmental Protection Agency regulations, companies aren’t allowed to make claims about the efficacy of disinfectants against pathogens unless regulators have reviewed them.
19: But the coronavirus outbreak has triggered emergency guidance from the EPA.
20: RELATED: Fact-checking hoaxes and conspiracies about the coronavirus That guidance sets forth two criteria.
21: First, a manufacturer’s disinfectant must be registered with the EPA for use on "hard, porous or non-porous surfaces."
22: Second, the disinfectant’s label must make previously approved claims about its efficacy against one of three "viral pathogen groupings."
23: Clorox said three of its products meet those criteria, including disinfecting wipes, disinfecting bleach and "Clean-Up Cleaner + Bleach."
24: In related news: Clorox shares rose several percentage points following the outbreak of the coronavirus.
25: The company has historically performed well on the stock market during epidemics.

gpt4: The claim that a Clorox bottle stated it could eliminate the 2019 coronavirus before it was developed is false.
To begin with, there exist seven known strains of coronaviruses that are capable of infecting humans, a fact established since the mid-1960s[9][10].

Furthermore, while Clorox, in a January 24 blog post, indeed stated that several of its products could kill coronaviruses similar to the 2019 strain, the company never specifically claimed that they could destroy the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), the variant which started spreading in Wuhan, China[15][11].
The appearance of "human coronavirus" on some Clorox labels stems from the proven effectiveness of the products against previous strains of the virus when used on surfaces[14].
This does not directly translate into an ability to combat the 2019 coronavirus.

b6f5d0b8201786f2277379237d8954b7.claim: drinking a bleach solution will prevent you from getting the coronavirus.
b6f5d0b8201786f2277379237d8954b7.label: false
b6f5d0b8201786f2277379237d8954b7.passage:
0: Social media users are spreading a dangerous conspiracy theory that says drinking a bleach concoction will prevent contracting the 2019 coronavirus strain at the center of a current outbreak.
1: Don’t fall for it.
2: We came across the claim in a Jan. 28 tweet by Twitter user "Chief Police 2" that urged their followers to buy "20-20-20 spray" to ward off the virus.
3: The spray is also known as MMS, or Miracle Mineral Solution , a bleaching agent that’s been touted by anti-vaxxers and QAnon theorists as a "miracle cure" that can treat everything from autism to cancer.
4: RELATED: QAnon and Donald Trump rallies: What's that about?
5: The same account tweeted about MMS in relation to the coronavirus multiple times , saying that  drinking the solution will instantly "kill the deadly virus."
6: The tweets also share a now-deleted YouTube video that told people to buy and drink the mixture.
7: ( YouTube banned videos promoting MMS in 2019 .)
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The tweet was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: This type of "cure" is dangerous and should not be taken seriously.
11: It is also one of the latest hoaxes that have spread online about the coronavirus, which originated in Wuhan, China, and, as of Jan. 30 , has killed about 170 people and infected more than 7,700 worldwide.
12: While some Clorox cleaning agents have been found to be effective against prior coronavirus strains when used on surfaces to stem the spread of the virus, the products should never be ingested.
13: There is no scientific evidence that drinking bleach, MMS, or other sodium chlorite products will help cure or prevent disease.
14: The Food and Drug Administration has released multiple warnings about the "dangerous and potentially life threatening side effects" of the solution and urge people not to drink it.
15: "The FDA recently received new reports of people experiencing severe vomiting, severe diarrhea, life-threatening low blood pressure caused by dehydration and acute liver failure after drinking these products," the organization said in an August 2019 news release .
16: "The FDA is not aware of any scientific evidence supporting the safety or effectiveness of MMS products, despite claims that the solution is an antimicrobial, antiviral and antibacterial.
17: The FDA encourages consumers to talk to a health care professional about treating medical conditions or diseases."

gpt4: The claim that drinking a bleach solution can prevent the coronavirus is verifiably false.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has explicitly stated that the agency is unaware of any scientific evidence supporting the safety or effectiveness of such solutions, including products marketed as MMS [16].
There is, in fact, no scientific evidence validating the idea that drinking bleach or other sodium chlorite-based products will aid in curing or preventing disease [13].
The FDA has even issued multiple warnings about the "dangerous and potentially life-threatening side effects" of these kind of solutions, urging people to refrain from consuming them [14].

The agency has also reported receiving new cases of individuals suffering severe reactions like vomiting, diarrhea, dangerously low blood pressure due to dehydration, and acute liver failure post-drinking such products [15].

59d8a1fe2b05e6ed62fce3c7d561287e.label: true
59d8a1fe2b05e6ed62fce3c7d561287e.passage:
0: In a tweet proclaiming "so goes Texas, so goes the world," state Rep. James White said that 10% of children in the United States are Texans.
1: Texas is the second most populous state in the nation and PolitiFact has checked a number of claims about its residents in the past.
2: Most recently, we rated False a claim that a third of Texas has seen a "20-25% population loss in the last 5 years."
3: But what about White’s claim that 10% of all children in the United States live in Texas?
4: White’s tweet used many abbreviations and symbols, but can be paraphrased as such: Texas youths are 20% of our state population, but 100% of our state’s future.
5: Texas holds the destiny of our nation.
6: Ten percent of U.S. children are Texans.
7: So goes Texas, so goes the world.
8: He included a link to a video showing a public interview he did with Raise Your Hand Texas, a non-profit education advocacy organization, about educational development of teachers in his district.
9: Looking at the data When we asked White, a Republican from Hillister, for the source of his claim, he pointed us to a 2016 report from the Center for Public Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank, titled "State of Texas Children."
10: The report said: "More than 7 million children live in Texas today, representing nearly 1 in 10 children living in the U.S." PolitiFact Texas checked a similar statement in 2017: "One in 10 babies born in this country is born in Texas."
11: We rated that claim True , based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention about annual births.
12: But White’s claim is a bit different, as it focuses on total population, not annual births.
13: For this check, we turned to two sets of data from the Census Bureau measuring population by age and location.
14: There are about 73.4 million people in the United States under the age of 18, according to 2018 population estimates.
15: There are about 7.4 million in Texas — about 10% of the total population of people under 18 in the United States.
16: Texas makes up the second largest share of people under 18 in the U.S., after California, which is home to about 12% of the population under 18 years old.
17: Within Texas, the population under 18 made up about 26% of the state’s population in 2018.
18: In California, minors made up 23% of the state’s population in 2018.

gpt4: The assertion that "10% of U.S. children are Texans" is an authentic one.

White, a Republican member from Hillister, when prompted for the source of his pronouncement, directed us towards a 2016 report from the Center for Public Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank voluminously titled "State of Texas Children"[9].
In our pursuit of verification, we referred to two distinct datasets provided by the Census Bureau, which records population by age and geographical locality[13].

These census statistics reveal that Texas is home to approximately 7.4 million individuals under the age of 18, a figure that indeed constitutes about 10% of the United States' total population in this age category[15].

7b2e0f245e656c9fc0dcc6fca63f6c7c.claim: “Over the past year, Illinois has reduced its unemployment rate more than all of the top 20 most populated states in the nation — and more than our Midwestern peers.”
7b2e0f245e656c9fc0dcc6fca63f6c7c.label: true
7b2e0f245e656c9fc0dcc6fca63f6c7c.passage:
0: Democratic Gov.
1: J.B. Pritzker frequently praises Illinois’ economic progress, unlike his predecessor, who often complained the state was falling behind.
2: So it was no surprise when Pritzker devoted part of his 2020 State of the State address to highlighting Illinois’ recent employment gains.
3: "We’re wresting the public conversation in Illinois back from people concerned with one thing and one thing only: predicting total disaster, spending hundreds of millions of dollars promoting it, and then doing everything in their power to make it happen," Pritzker said .
4: "I’m here to tell the carnival barkers, the doomsayers, the paid professional critics the state of our state is growing stronger each day."
5: To back that up, Pritzker pointed to Illinois’ record-low unemployment rate and the job growth it saw last year across the state .
6: He also made a broader comparison that caught our attention.
7: "Over the past year, Illinois has reduced its unemployment rate more than all of the top 20 most populated states in the nation — and more than our Midwestern peers," Pritzker said.
8: We hadn’t heard Illinois had bested all those states in reducing joblessness last year, so we decided to check it out.
9: Pritzker spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh told us the governor was relying on seasonally adjusted data from December 2018 compared with the same data from December 2019, which are the latest available figures from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
10: A BLS economist confirmed it’s appropriate to compare the current December unemployment rate using seasonally adjusted data to that of the same month a year ago, noting that "over the year" is commonly used to reference that timeframe.
11: BLS data show Pritzker is correct that Illinois saw a greater drop in its over-the-year unemployment rate than any of the other states he referenced.
12: It saw its rate fall from 4.3% in December 2018 to 3.7% a year later, amounting to a 0.6% reduction.
13: But it’s worth noting those states saw very similar changes in their unemployment rates.
14: Georgia, the state that saw the second-largest reduction, dropped its rate by 0.5%.
15: In fact, the reductions seen by the top 10 states on the list were all clustered within less than 0.5% of one another.
16: Economic experts we spoke with also cautioned that unemployment rate declines don’t say much about a state’s overall stability.
17: "If they really go way up, that’s clearly a problem," said Michael Hicks, an economist at Ball State University in Indiana.
18: "But the unemployment rate could be fairly low and we could still have significant problems.
19: For example, there could be a retreat of men and women from the labor force."
20: Hicks also said it takes time for meaningful shifts in the labor force to emerge.
21: "Saying that you’ve done better than other states is kind of taking out all the context about those states," said Richard Auxier, a research associate at the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center, which maintains a database on state economic indicators .
22: "Some states have high unemployment, some states have low unemployment and they’re just consistently high or consistently low."
23: Even though Illinois tops the list for reductions over the past year, it still has a higher unemployment rate than 12 of the states Pritzker cited in his comparison.
24: For instance, Iowa saw an increase in its unemployment rate last year.
25: But at 2.7%, it still has the second-lowest unemployment rate on the list.
26: And although Texas’ rate fell by just 0.2%, it started out at 3.7% last December — the rate Illinois has just now achieved.
27: "This is one of the types of statistics that is true but ultimately not that illuminating," Auxier said.

gpt4: The statement claiming that in the past year, Illinois has reduced its unemployment rate more than all of the top 20 most populated states in the nation, as well as its Midwestern peers, is accurate.

This statement was made by Governor Pritzker and is based on seasonally adjusted data from December 2018 compared with the same data from December 2019, as the latest available figures from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics show [9].

The BLS data confirms that Illinois experienced a larger drop in its over-the-year unemployment rate, falling from 4.3% in December 2018 to 3.7% a year later, a reduction of 0.6%, than any of the other states Pritzker mentioned[12][11].
Hence, Pritzker's assertion is backed by factual data[7].

df552d754ef87032b152d640944bab37.claim: ""Earnings for the bottom 10% are rising faster than earnings for the top 10%.”"
df552d754ef87032b152d640944bab37.label: half-true
df552d754ef87032b152d640944bab37.passage:
0: One of President Donald Trump’s central promises was to produce a rising economy that lifts all boats.
1: At a rally in Wildwood, N.J., he touted record low unemployment rates, especially for African Americans and Hispanics.
2: His policies of tax cuts and rolling back regulations, he said, had been particularly good for those making the least.
3: "This is a blue-collar boom," Trump said Jan. 28 .
4: "Earnings for the bottom 10% are rising faster than earnings for the top 10%."
5: The Bureau of Labor Statistics has the numbers behind Trump’s statement.
6: There’s data for each quarter and each year.
7: The quarterly numbers back Trump up, but the yearly numbers are more reliable — they capture seasonal employment and have a lower standard error.
8: Looking at the changes from year to year, earnings for the lowest 10% grew faster in only one year, 2018.
9: Here’s how that looks: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com So Trump is right for only one out of the three years of his presidency.
10: We also looked at the change between 2016, the year before Trump took office, and 2019.
11: Viewed that way, the numbers support Trump’s statement.
12: Between 2016 and 2019, the low-wage earners saw a 14.6% rise, compared with 13.5% for the top earners.
13: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Problems with the weekly earnings data This data has limitations.
14: The earnings data misses income from a second part-time job that many low-wage earners rely on.
15: But more significant are the dollars it misses on the high end.
16: It doesn’t count the self-employed at all –– about 10% of the workforce –– which in the higher income group includes lawyers, engineers, financial advisers and other lucrative professions.
17: "The earnings growth in that group could be very high, because that’s where we’ve seen some of the highest income growth over the past 30 years," said Erica Groshen, the former head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
18: Plus, this survey doesn’t count earnings over $150,000.
19: Someone making $250,000 would be entered as earning $149,999.
20: That makes the high-end number in the data artificially low.
21: This measure is not well suited to the comparison at the extremes that Trump made.
22: Did tax cuts and cutting regulations make the difference?
23: Trump pushed for the tax cuts and signed spending bills that spurred growth (and rising deficits ) so he can take some credit for a steady economy.The growth has led employers to boost wages to attract and keep workers.
24: But Trump has not supported raising the minimum wage, and that’s also a plausible driving factor.
25: The federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour hasn’t changed since 2009, but 29 states have increased it on their own, including very large states such as New York and California.
26: "The minimum wage absolutely could be at play," said economist Elise Gould with the Economic Policy Institute, a group focused on gains for low and middle income workers.
27: "In states that raised the minimum wage, lower income wages rose faster than in those that didn’t."
28: Between 2010 and 2018, in states that raised the minimum wage faster than inflation, the bottom 10% of workers saw their wages go up nearly 10% .
29: For states that didn’t act, wages rose too, but by less than 6%.
30: So tax and regulation cuts are only part of the story.
31: Deficit spending and hikes in the minimum wage also played a role.

gpt4: At a rally in Wildwood, N.J., President Trump proudly spoke about the record low unemployment rates, particularly among African Americans and Hispanics [1].
Between 2016 and 2019, data shows that low-wage earners experienced an increase in their earnings by 14.6%, compared to the increase of 13.5% for high earners [12].
When discussing changes from year to year, it was observed that the earnings of the lowest 10% grew at a faster rate only in 2018[8].

Yet, this analysis may not fully capture the reality, as some significant dollar amounts on the higher end might be excluded[15], thus potentially making the high-end figure in the data artificially low [20].
These factors lead to the conclusion that this measure may not be the most suitable for the comparison at the extremes made by Trump [21].

Further credibility to the claim may emanate from factors such as the lack of Trump's support for raising the minimum wage, an action that could plausibly drive faster growth in earnings for the lower 10% [24].
As economist Elise Gould from the Economic Policy Institute articulates, "The minimum wage absolutely could be at play"[26].
Other contributing factors are likely to be deficit spending and increases in the minimum wage [31].
Therefore, the claim that "earnings for the bottom 10% are rising faster than earnings for the top 10%" is assessed as being half-true.

5b1161f4d7dc151f2b40a7adf6ae4ad5.claim: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” Novel coronavirus outbreak
5b1161f4d7dc151f2b40a7adf6ae4ad5.label: false
5b1161f4d7dc151f2b40a7adf6ae4ad5.passage:
0: A small stuffed toy is fanning the flames of another coronavirus conspiracy theory .
1: A Jan. 27 Facebook post about an adorable plushie drew attention to an October 2019 gathering called Event 201 .
2: It was designed to help plan for a global pandemic by bringing together business, government, and public health leaders.
3: "Nobody has been able to explain why they gave out stuffed souvenir Coronavirus toys at #Event201 yet," the post reads .
4: "Almost like this is big fun — for them.
5: Or maybe it’s to commemorate the virus that’ll make them a fortune on vaccines & other treatments we will be forced to buy — Thoughts?"
6: Underneath the post are three photos: a screen grab of Jan. 27 tweet from the Daily Mail showing images of the coronavirus under a microscope and two images showing small, stuffed toys shaped like orange suns with red rays and black eyes.
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: We noticed that there have also been many tweets speculating about Event 201’s pandemic simulation.
10: So is it true that this plushie was distributed in commemoration of the coronavirus outbreak?
11: Did the organizers of Event 201 have insider knowledge about this global health scare?
12: No.
13: Here’s what we know.
14: The toy at the center of the controversy is supposed to be a microbe.
15: Two months before the outbreak of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) was detected in Wuhan, China, the Event 201 scenario — which was organized by John Hopkins Center for Health Security World Economic Forum and Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation —"simulated a novel zoonotic coronavirus transmitted from bats to pigs to people that eventually becomes efficiently transmissible from person to person, leading to a severe pandemic," according to the Event 201 website .
16: The fictionalized scenario, which was planned in part because there have been two worldwide outbreaks of coronaviruses in the last 20 years, also included 65 million related deaths in 18 months from the pretend coronavirus.
17: Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security on Oct. 16, 2019, tweeted a picture of the stuffed microbe as part of its Event 201 registration drive: "Have you registered for the #Event201 virtual pandemic exercise yet?"
18: the tweet read.
19: "See the story of #Event201 play out in real-time and answer tough questions that could arise in a severe pandemic.
20: Register today and be entered to win one of our Event201 giant microbes!"
21: Have you registered for the #Event201 virtual pandemic exercise yet?
22: See the story of #Event201 play out in real-time and answer tough questions that could arise in a severe pandemic.
23: Register today and be entered to win one of our Event201 giant microbes!
24: https://t.co/phz7Qc0LQL pic.twitter.com/fJZdjH1fVi — Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security (@JHSPH_CHS) October 16, 2019 On Jan. 24, 2020, the John Hopkins Center for Health Security released a statement clarifying that they had not been predicting the current coronavirus outbreak: "To be clear, the Center for Health Security and partners did not make a prediction during our tabletop exercise.
25: For the scenario, we modeled a fictional coronavirus pandemic, but we explicitly stated that it was not a prediction."
26: A World Economic Forum article stated that the Event 201 simulation of a pandemic was meant to "bring together public and private leaders to inform multi-stakeholder cooperation for pandemic preparedness and response."
27: The article argues there needs to be pandemic simulations like these to prepare for the average of 200 epidemics that take place annually.
28: Johns Hopkins has hosted other simulations in recent years, including Dark Winter in 2001, Atlantic Storm in 2005, and Clade X in 2018.

gpt4: The claim that Event 201 gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys to commemorate the Novel coronavirus outbreak is false.
Event 201, hosted by the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, the World Economic Forum, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, was a pandemic simulation conducted in October 2019[15].
It aimed to bring together business, government, and public health leaders to plan for a global pandemic[2].
A fictional coronavirus pandemic was modeled for this scenario, but the organisers explicitly stated that it was not a prediction[25].

While a stuffed microbe toy was indeed tweeted by the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security as a part of the event's registration drive[17], it was not distributed as a memento of the Novel coronavirus outbreak, as that event had not yet occurred.

3aff046e38f52d0d92ae4f99fcbad5ca.claim: Kobe Bryant’s wife “recorded her suicide after depression attack this morning.”
3aff046e38f52d0d92ae4f99fcbad5ca.label: false
3aff046e38f52d0d92ae4f99fcbad5ca.passage:
0: We’ve debunked a lot of hoaxes about NBA star Kobe Bryant since he and one of his daughters were killed in a helicopter crash on Jan. 26.
1: Now a gruesome blog post being shared online falsely claims that Bryant’s wife, Vanessa Bryant, ended her life.
2: "BREAKING NEWS," reads what looks like a BBC News headline, "Vanessa Bryant recorded her suicide after depression attack this morning."
3: The words "ACTUAL footage" appear above a video embedded in the blog post.
4: The video still shows a picture of Vanessa Bryant and says "R.I.P.
5: Vanessa Bryant 1982-2020."
6: The BBC News logo is in the corner.
7: But searching the BBC’s website, we found no coverage of Vanessa Bryant’s supposed suicide.
8: Other news organizations likewise didn’t report on her death.
9: This blog post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: If you click on the video, a clip of Fox News anchor Neil Cavuto begins.
12: He says he has some "very sad news."
13: Then the video stops and this message appears: "Warning: This video may show graphic content (18+).
