14: Share to continue watching."
15: Clicking on video opens a window to share the blog post on Facebook.
16: And many people have followed through, spreading this hoax.
17: More astute news consumers, however, have followed credible news stories about Koby Bryant’s death.
18: And more than 10 million liked this photo that Vanessa Bryant posted of her family on Instagram last week when she thanked the "millions of people who’ve shown support and love during this horrific time."
19: "I’m not sure what our lives hold beyond today, and it’s impossible to imagine life without them," she said.
20: "But we wake up each day, trying to keep pushing because Kobe, and our baby girl, Gigi, are shining on us to light the way."

gpt4: The claim that Kobe Bryant's wife, Vanessa Bryant, recorded her suicide after a depression attack is false.
This falsehood can be traced back to a sensationalized blog post that has been circulated online [1].
However, the credibility of this claim is highly dubious as no prominent news outlets have reported on the supposed suicide [8].
A lack of coverage likewise can be seen on the BBC's website, further challenging the validity of the claim [7].
The lack of credible journalism supporting this claim makes it clear that it is a baseless rumor.

132cc0e006a0453ef7923e886bfe053d.claim: Say Nancy Pelosi’s net worth is $196,299,990.
132cc0e006a0453ef7923e886bfe053d.label: false
132cc0e006a0453ef7923e886bfe053d.passage:
0: How rich is House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.?
1: A post making the rounds on social media offers a number that’s way off.
2: The post, which features a picture of Pelosi gesturing, says: "Annual salary: $193,400.
3: Time in office: 28 years = $5,415,200.
4: Net worth: $196,299,990.
5: ‘Something is wrong with this picture’ -- Nancy Pelosi."
6: The meme’s point is that Pelosi is a modestly paid public servant who has nonetheless collected almost a fifth of a billion dollars in net worth, presumably by corrupt means.
7: That interpretation, and the facts underlying it, are badly flawed.
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: Breaking down the numbers First, we’ll note that Pelosi’s current salary is higher than the meme says.
11: As House speaker, Pelosi earns $223,500 a year, which is more than a rank-and-file member.
12: But Pelosi hasn’t been earning that the whole time.
13: When she first entered Congress in 1987, the full-year salary for a rank-and-file member was $89,500.
14: It has risen in fits and starts since then.
15: The meme’s bigger mistake, however, concerns her net worth.
16: Pelosi’s husband, Paul Pelosi, has been a prominent businessman in real estate and venture capital for decades.
17: So Pelosi hasn’t built a fortune from her government salary; most of it stems from her husband’s investments.
18: Pelosi’s 2018 financial disclosure form shows the value of the assets she and her husband held at the time of the filing.
19: Much of it appears to be from her husband’s business investments — a mix of real estate, partnerships, and blue-chip stock holdings, including Apple, Facebook, Visa, and Walt Disney Co.
20: The disclosure forms that all members of Congress must file lists their assets and liabilities, such as mortgages.
21: Both categories are listed in broad ranges — a minimum and a maximum for each asset and liability in their portfolio — and they include the holdings of both the members of Congress as well as their spouses, if any.
22: The maximum amount of the range for Pelosi was about $257 million in assets and $97 million in liabilities, which produces a maximum net worth of nearly $160 million.
23: If you use the minimum in the reported range instead, the numbers are $54 million in assets and $20 million in liabilities, for a net worth of about $34 million.
24: Either figure falls short of the $196 million in the meme.
25: Averaging the maximum and minimum values as a back-of-the-envelope estimate of the couple’s net worth produces a figure of $97 million, almost exactly half of the amount claimed in the meme.
26: The $196,299,990 figure in the meme dates back in conservative media to at least 2011 , and it may have been an accurate reflection of Pelosi’s assets back then, without liabilities subtracted.
27: In February 2018, the congressional newspaper Roll Call published its most recent comparison of wealth disclosures by all members of Congress.
28: Pelosi ranked as the 30th highest in wealth among both House members and senators, and 24th among House members alone.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi's net worth is $196,299,990 is false.
The assumption made by the meme is that Pelosi has amassed nearly a fifth of a billion dollars from her modestly paid public office, implying corrupt practices.
However, this claim is unfounded[6].
Most of the Pelosi family's wealth actually comes from her husband's investments[17].
If we were to estimate Pelosi's net worth by averaging the family's known maximum and minimum values, we would arrive at a figure of approximately $97 million.
This is almost exactly half the claim presented in the meme[25].
Furthermore, either figure falls significantly short of the alleged $196 million suggested in the meme[24].
Hence, the claim is unverifiable and misleading.

adeffe996731db3b12a361ea201e14e8.claim: “Cory Booker and all these people couldn't get any of the things that (Michael) Bloomberg's getting now"" with respect to DNC debate rules."
adeffe996731db3b12a361ea201e14e8.label: half-true
adeffe996731db3b12a361ea201e14e8.passage:
0: Fox News host Sean Hannity invited President Donald Trump to bash the Democrats running for president during an interview before the Super Bowl on Feb. 2.
1: "This is called our lightning round," Hannity said .
2: "I’m just going to throw out a name, whatever comes to your mind."
3: When Hannity asked about former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg , Trump said the Democratic National Committee, which recently announced changes to its debate qualification requirements , was bending over backward to benefit him.
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com "Cory Booker and all these people couldn’t get any of the things that Bloomberg’s getting now," he said .
5: "I think it’s very unfair for the Democrats."
6: The DNC did make significant changes to its qualification criteria, raising the polling threshold while scrapping the individual donor requirement that candidates previously had to meet.
7: The DNC’s recent shift does open the door for Bloomberg, who is self-funding his campaign and not taking donations, to participate in a debate for the first time.
8: But Trump’s claim glosses over important details.
9: The new rules are different from what Booker asked for, and they don’t guarantee that Bloomberg will earn a spot on stage.
10: Debate qualification requirements have gradually changed For the DNC’s first two debates, candidates qualified by meeting one of two requirements: Polling at 1% in three national or early-state polls approved by the DNC, or getting donations from 65,000 unique donors, with at least 200 donors per state in 20 different states.
11: Over time, the requirements became more difficult to satisfy.
12: At the September debate in Houston, the thresholds for polling and donors increased, and candidates were required to meet both benchmarks , not one or the other.
13: By the time of the January debate in Des Moines, Iowa — the seventh on the DNC’s schedule — the polling threshold had risen to 5% in four national polls or 7% in two early-state polls, and the donor threshold bumped up to 225,000 donors, with 1,000 per state in 20 different states.
14: Then came the February debates, the first contests scheduled to take place after voters and caucus-goers started making their picks for a nominee.
15: For the Feb. 7 debate in New Hampshire, the DNC announced that while candidates could still qualify by meeting both the polling and donor thresholds set for the January debate, they could also qualify by earning one delegate to the national convention in the Iowa caucuses.
16: (Bloomberg hasn’t campaigned in Iowa .)
17: For the Feb. 19 debate in Las Vegas, the DNC has eliminated the donor requirement entirely.
18: Candidates can either qualify by polling at 10% in four national polls or 12% in two early-state polls, or by getting one delegate in either the Iowa caucuses or the New Hampshire primary.
19: (Bloomberg’s name won’t appear on the New Hampshire ballot.)
20: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Adrienne Watson, a spokeswoman for the DNC, told Politico that the early primary results will give a greater window into a candidate’s support than the donor tally.
21: "The donor threshold was appropriate for the opening stages of the race, when candidates were building their organizations, and there were no metrics available outside of polling to distinguish those making progress from those who weren’t," she said, according to Politico .
22: The DNC’s recent change makes room for Bloomberg Bloomberg’s refusal to take donations precluded him from participating in the DNC’s first seven debates, and because he is skipping the early states, he is unlikely to win the delegates in Iowa or New Hampshire that could put him in the ring for the Feb. 7 debate.
23: But since candidates can qualify for the Feb. 19 debate simply by hitting the 10% polling mark, Bloomberg, who had called for the DNC to get rid of the donor requirement, now has a shot.
24: That doesn’t mean he’ll make the stage.
25: Currently, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders have met the 10% polling threshold, according to Politico , which tracks public polling and has identified just one poll that has Bloomberg at 10%.
26: Watson told us Trump’s suggestion that the change was meant to help Bloomberg was "false."
27: "With the primary underway, we are assessing a candidate’s support through a significantly higher polling threshold and through actual election results," she said.
28: "We were always planning to do this, we signaled it many times, it is not designed to benefit any one candidate, and every candidate has an equal opportunity to qualify."
29: DNC Chairman Tom Perez did signal in November and December that he was considering doing away with the donor threshold for the early 2020 debates, according to reports.
30: Still, other Democratic candidates have denounced the change, saying the DNC is catering to the billionaire.
31: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com A Sanders adviser said the change was evidence of a "rigged system."
32: Warren tweeted that the DNC was letting Bloomberg "play by different rules."
33: Entrepreneur Andrew Yang said the change was "clearly tailor made to deliver (Bloomberg) to the debate stage."
34: Booker, Yang asked for different changes In December, Booker led a push to lower qualification standards so that he, Julian Castro and others would stand a better chance of making the January and February debates.
35: The New Jersey senator sent a letter , signed by several candidates, requesting that the DNC go back to requiring candidates to meet the polling threshold or the donor threshold, but not both.
36: The DNC rejected Booker’s petition.
37: "Our qualification criteria is extremely low and reflects where we are in the race," the committee said in a statement, per Politico .
38: "Once voting starts in February, our criteria will reflect those contests, which is more than appropriate."
39: Similarly, Yang asked the DNC to commission more polls so candidates would have a higher likelihood of meeting the polling requirement.
40: Both of these changes would have made the path to the debates easier.
41: While the DNC has now scrapped the donor requirement and given candidates the option of qualifying through delegates or the polls, it has also doubled the polling threshold, a change that could potentially cut the number of candidates who qualify for the Nevada debate.
42: For what it’s worth, the donor threshold was not usually the requirement keeping candidates from the debates.
43: Bloomberg is the only candidate who failed to qualify for a debate specifically because of the donor requirement, according to Politico .
44: But it wasn’t nothing.
45: Booker campaign staffers, for example, have described having to divert resources in order to satisfy the committee’s donor thresholds.

gpt4: The claim that "Cory Booker and all these people couldn't get any of the things that (Michael) Bloomberg's getting now" with respect to DNC debate rules is partially true.
In December, Cory Booker led a campaign to lower qualification standards to increase his chances, and those of others like Julian Castro, of participating in January and February debates [34].

The New Jersey Senator sent a letter, signed by various candidates, urging the DNC to return to the old rules where candidates were required to meet the polling or the donor threshold - not both [35].
However, the DNC counteracted this by raising the polling threshold while eliminating the individual donor criterion that candidates previously had to fulfill [6].
Bloomberg, who is self-financing his campaign and does not take donations, could participate for the first time due to this change [7].
However, this new setup differs from what Booker requested and does not assure Bloomberg a place on stage [9].
The only aspect that specifically benefits Bloomberg is the withdrawal of the donor requirement - his failure to qualify for a debate resulted from this requirement alone, according to Politico [43].

The claim that the DNC is bending backwards for Bloomberg, as stated by Trump during an interview with Hannity, pertains to the committee's recent alteration in the debate qualification requirements [3].
The DNC however rejected Booker's petition [36].
It's important to clarify that while the changes in the rules could benefit Bloomberg, they were not the exact changes Booker asked for, hence making the original claim partially true.[4]

e1f13ea6d731f1ce6c17856ad83cc003.claim: “All of the aid has not arrived” to Ukraine.
e1f13ea6d731f1ce6c17856ad83cc003.label: true
e1f13ea6d731f1ce6c17856ad83cc003.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s hold on $400 million in aid for Ukraine is at the heart of the Senate impeachment trial.
1: One of the Democratic House managers said Ukraine is still waiting on what the United States promised to send.
2: "The aid, although it did arrive, it took the work of some senators in this room who had to pass additional laws to make sure that the Ukrainians did not lose out on $35 million additional dollars," said Rep. Val Demings, D-Fla., Jan. 29.
3: "Contrary to the president’s tweet that all of the aid arrived and that it arrived ahead of schedule, that is not true.
4: All of the aid has not arrived."
5: As Demings said, Trump was wrong to say the aid was delivered ahead of time (see this report from FactCheck.org. )
6: But we wanted to know whether Ukraine was still waiting on some amount of American support, even now.
7: Aid, interrupted Demings has a point that not every dollar intended for Ukraine has been delivered.
8: The money was supposed to come in two pots: $250 million managed by the Pentagon for military aid and $141 million managed by the State Department.
9: Trump’s hold on the aid last summer sent it off the usual path.
10: The question about what federal dollars have not yet arrived relates to defense money.
11: Here’s a refresher on the relevant events from 2019: June 18: The Defense Department announced plans to provide $250 million to Ukraine.
12: July: Trump ordered the Defense Department money, and $141 million in State Department aid, to be frozen ahead of his July 25, 2019, call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
13: Emails show that Pentagon and OMB staff were scrambling to freeze the aid July 24-25, and paperwork to freeze the aid was in the works before the phone call.
14: The New York Times reported that Trump first asked about freezing the aid in June.
15: Aug. 12: A whistleblower filed a complaint about Trump’s phone call and related actions.
16: Sept. 11: Under pressure, the White House released nearly $400 million of frozen U.S. aid to Ukraine.
17: The White House’s reversal didn’t leave time to disburse all of the money before the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30.
18: On Sept. 27, 2019, Trump signed a continuing appropriations bill to extend the $250 million in Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative funds for another year.
19: Most of the aid was obligated, the term the federal government uses to refer to money that the government has promised to spend.
20: But a small portion wasn’t.
21: Mark Sandy, an official in the Office of Management Budget, said in his House deposition that roughly $35 million had not been obligated.
22: Without the September extension, those funds would have expired, he said.
23: Some of those funds were intended for lethal equipment and radars, according to a Nov. 18 letter from four Democratic senators .
24: About 93% of the $250 million designated for Ukraine by Congress has been obligated, said Pentagon spokeswoman Lt. Col. Carla Gleason.
25: That means about $17 million has not yet been obligated.
26: Officials at the Office of Management and Budget have argued that it’s common for agencies to not fully spend their money by the end of the fiscal year, including for Ukraine aid .
27: But the Government Accountability Office concluded that the office violated the federal Impoundment Control Act by withholding security assistance to Ukraine.
28: "It’s atypical that $35 million out of $250 million wouldn’t be spent by the end of the fiscal year, especially when (the Defense Department) certified that Ukraine was meeting the anti-corruption and transparency conditions outlined by Congress," said Seamus P. Daniels, a defense budget expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

gpt4: The claim that "All of the aid has not arrived" to Ukraine is true.
This is substantiated by statements from officials and financial assessments that indicate a significant portion of the allocated aid has not yet been obligated towards Ukrainian relief.
Mark Sandy, an official from the Office of Management Budget, disclosed during his House deposition that roughly $35 million of the funds earmarked for Ukraine remain unassigned [21].
Additionally, an approximate amount of $17 million is still yet to be obligated, reaffirming the consistency of these findings [25].
As such, it's evident that not all the intended aid has been delivered to Ukraine, essentially validating the point made by Aid, interrupted Demings [7].

ece173d22c37953eaf13224a05605f9a.claim: ""EIGHT Iowa counties have more adults registered to vote than voting-aged adults living there.”"
ece173d22c37953eaf13224a05605f9a.label: false
ece173d22c37953eaf13224a05605f9a.passage:
0: One day before the Iowa caucuses, a conservative activist started making claims on Twitter about alleged voter fraud.
1: "It’s been revealed that EIGHT Iowa counties have more adults registered to vote than voting-aged adults living there," tweeted Charlie Kirk, founder of Turning Point USA, Feb. 2.
2: "Don’t let voter fraud steal the 2020 election."
3: The tweet was flagged by VineSight , an organization that uses artificial intelligence to surface potential misinformation, and also appears on Facebook .
4: The allegations from Kirk and another conservative organization aim to stir up concerns about voter fraud with a questionable methodology that leads to unsubstantiated conclusions.
5: On Caucus Day, Iowa election officials issued public statements denouncing their numbers and the narrative.
6: The current data released by Iowa election officials don’t support Kirk’s tweet.
7: Iowa disputes report Kirk’s viral tweet makes the same claim as a Feb. 3 report published by Judicial Watch, a conservative legal group.
8: The Judicial Watch report says "eight Iowa counties have more voter registrations than their eligible voting-age population."
9: Two of them, Johnson and Scott counties, are the locations of Davenport and Iowa City, respectively.
10: The report was based on its analysis of data from the U.S. Election Assistance Commission and the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.
11: "Dirty voting rolls can mean dirty elections and Iowa needs to undertake a serious effort to address its voting rolls," said Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton in the news release.
12: RELATED: We fact-checked the Democrats' closing push in Iowa before the caucuses Iowa officials refuted the report.
13: A Feb. 3 news release from Iowa Secretary of State Paul Pate said his office’s data "shows this information to be false."
14: "It’s unfortunate this organization continues to put out inaccurate data regarding voter registration, and it’s especially disconcerting they chose the day of the Iowa Caucus to do this," Pate said in the statement.
15: "My office has told the organization, and others who have made similar claims, that their data regarding Iowa is deeply flawed and their false claims erode voter confidence in elections."
16: We reached out to Kirk and Judicial Watch for comment, but neither has responded with one.
17: It appears they were using old voter registration numbers.. An ‘apples-to-oranges measure’ We took a look at the most recent voter registration and population data from Iowa’s government and the Census Bureau.
18: The numbers don’t support what Kirk said, and experts say comparing them is flawed.
19: Among the counties identified by Judicial Watch, none have more active registered voters than adults.
20: For example, Scott County — the largest county included in the Judicial Watch story — has an estimated population of 131,961 people ages 18 and older, according to 2018 data from the Census’s American Community Survey.
21: According to the Iowa secretary of state, there are 127,737 total voter registrations, 115,393 of which are active.
22: Judicial Watch’s story looked at "total registrations," which includes inactive voters.
23: In Iowa, inactive voters are those that have not responded to notices from the state asking them to verify their registration and residence.
24: Only one county, Lyon, has more total registered voters than adults: 8,490 to 8,430.
25: But that data is from 2018.
26: The Iowa secretary of state’s office says 8,117 of voters in Lyon County are active.
27: Either way, experts say comparing voter rolls and Census estimates isn’t an accurate measurement of registration rates.
28: "That’s an apples-to-oranges measure.
29: They measure different things, at different times, with different types of levels of certainty," said Justin Levitt, a Loyola Law School professor, in an email.
30: "And so it’s really bad science to claim that a disconnect between those two numbers means that there’s fraud."
31: Even if there were more registered voters than voting-age adults in some Iowa counties, experts told us it would not amount to voter fraud.
32: "For there to be voter fraud in connection to bloated voter rolls, you’d have to see people going to the polling places and see them voting in places of people who have moved or died," said Richard Hasen, a law professor at the University of California at Irvine.
33: "Not only would that be a difficult thing to do … you’d have to do this on a wide enough scale to sway an election without being able to verify how the people you’ve paid to do this have voted."
34: Voter fraud remains rare in American elections.
35: A database maintained by the conservative Heritage Foundation has documented 17 confirmed instances of voter fraud in Iowa dating back to 2011.

gpt4: The claim by Charlie Kirk, founder of Turning Point USA, that "Eight Iowa counties have more adults registered to vote than voting-aged adults living there," has been found to be false[1].

This claim has been refuted not only by the Iowa Secretary of State Paul Pate in a news release, stating that the data reveals the information to be incorrect [13], but also by various experts, highlighting how the numbers do not sustain Kirk's claim and how the comparison between them is flawed [18].
Additionally, election officials from Iowa issued public statements on Caucus Day denouncing their figures and the narrative stemming from them [5].
It's crucial to understand that in Iowa, inactive voters are individuals who haven't responded to state-issued notices asking them to confirm their registration and resident status [23].
Furthermore, experts emphasize that comparing voter rolls and Census estimates is not an accurate way of determining registration rates [27].
In a more specific contradiction to Kirk's claim, none of the counties identified by Judicial Watch have more active registered voters than adults [19].

40a051cc8499b2f12af5c4d7c695fbb5.claim: “Over the past two years, climate and weather disaster damage has cost the U.S. over $400 billion.”
40a051cc8499b2f12af5c4d7c695fbb5.label: half-true
40a051cc8499b2f12af5c4d7c695fbb5.passage:
0: When it comes to weather and climate change, there has been lots of talk about causes and consequences.
1: In some areas of Wisconsin this winter, rapidly melting snow has overtaken roads and caused sewage to overflow , while flooding and its effects continue to be a concern.
2: The National Weather Service in Green Bay indicated most rivers in northeastern Wisconsin have more than a 50% chance of flooding to some extent .
3: Whether it be the toll on infrastructure or disrupting business operations, weather and climate change carries a monetary cost.
4: On Dec. 10, 2019, the U.S. Senate Democrats’ Climate Committee sent out a tweet arguing Wisconsin roads and bridges are at risk of collapse from severe storms and flooding.
5: That same day, U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin, D-Wis., tweeted this about the national cost: "Over the past two years, climate and weather disaster damage has cost the U.S. over $400 billion and our economy will lose over $500 billion annually from lost labor, crop failure and damages related to extreme weather if we don’t #ActOnClimate now."
6: Is Baldwin right about $400 billion-plus in damages?
7: The source When asked for backup for the claim, Baldwin’s staff pointed to The Fourth National Climate Assessment , a 1,526-page document that examines the effects, risks and course of climate change in the United States.
8: The Fourth National Climate Assessment is a cooperative effort between experts from academia and government agencies , such as the U.S. Department of Energy, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the U.S. Department of the Interior.
9: On page 66, the report indicates NOAA estimates the United States incurred $400 billion in damages from weather and climate disasters from 2015 through April 6, 2018.
10: But that figure is for different years and a longer time period (three-plus years) than Baldwin claimed.
11: NOAA climatologist Adam Smith from the Center for Weather and Climate at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information in Asheville, N.C., noted the numbers in the report are also a bit dated.
12: He pointed us to newer figures.
13: Baldwin’s reference was to the "past two years."
14: She made the statement in December 2019, so examining the two-year span immediately before that, her numbers are dramatically off.
15: NOAA estimates the U.S. experienced $137.8 billion of economic damage from 2018 and 2019 when adjusted for the consumer price index, and $135.6 billion unadjusted.
16: However, looking at the two most recent full years before Baldwin’s claim — 2017 and 2018 — Baldwin’s figures line up.
17: NOAA estimates the inflation-adjusted damage in those calendar years was $411.7 billion.
18: The NOAA calculation includes damage to buildings and public infrastructure, among other costs .
19: The agency tracks damage from drought, flooding, freeze, severe storms, tropical cyclones, wildfires and winter storms.
20: Smith said in an email NOAA uses data from agencies such as the National Weather Service, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and the National Interagency Fire Center.
21: There are some types of data they do not include due to inconsistencies.
22: "For example, our disaster cost estimates are actually somewhat conservative, as we don’t account for losses/damages to natural capital assets, mental and physical healthcare-related costs post-disaster, or incorporate all downstream economic impacts," Smith wrote.
23: We checked with several experts from academia who agreed that the NOAA numbers are probably the best available for the United States.
24: The agency’s data shows that the number of disasters that topped $1 billion in damages has increased each decade since the 1980s.
25: There were 119 weather and climate disasters that topped that threshold during the 2010s, up from 59 in the 2000s, even after adjusting for inflation.
26: Over the past three years (2017 through 2019), there was an average of nearly 15 disasters that topped $1 billion in damages.

gpt4: The claim that the U.S. has incurred over $400 billion in damages from weather and climate disasters over the past two years is half-true.
This statement was made by Baldwin in December 2019, referencing the past two years [13][14].
However, the specific two-year period chosen affects the accuracy of her statement.
Baldwin's staff identified her source as The Fourth National Climate Assessment, a comprehensive document studying climate change in the United States [7].
Page 66 of this report shows that the NOAA estimates that the United States incurred $400 billion in damages from these disasters between 2015 and early 2018[9].

But, when examining the two-year span immediately before her statement, from 2018 to 2019, NOAA estimates indicate the figure is lower at $137.8 billion when adjusted for inflation, or $135.6 billion unadjusted [15].
However, if the span used is from 2017 to 2018, the estimate is $411.7 billion, matching Baldwin's claim [16][17].
Therefore, the accuracy of the claim strongly depends on the specific two-year period being referred to.

b4f1c86883adc2a20c54a724dff5512a.claim: Democrats ""blocked the Iowa poll"" and ""blocked the Iowa caucus."""
b4f1c86883adc2a20c54a724dff5512a.label: false
b4f1c86883adc2a20c54a724dff5512a.passage:
0: Just after the clock struck midnight — and there were still no official results from the Democratic caucuses in Iowa — a group supporting Bernie Sanders for the Democratic presidential nomination accused the Democratic Party of a conspiracy.
1: Organizers for Bernie 2020, which has 15,000 followers on Twitter, made the two-fold attack in this tweet , with a widely used and misspelled hashtag: "They blocked the Iowa poll.
2: They blocked the Iowa caucus.
3: We are winning so hard the Democrats are shutting down the damn entire primary process.
4: #PresidentSanders #IowaCaucas " They blocked the Iowa poll.
5: They blocked the Iowa caucus.
6: We are winning so hard the Democrats are shutting down the damn entire primary process.
7: #PresidentSanders #IowaCaucas pic.twitter.com/fWZItLIBMe — Organizers for Bernie 2020 (@OFB2020) February 4, 2020 Problems surfaced in Iowa both with a widely anticipated pre-caucus poll and reporting the results of the Democratic caucuses.
8: But no evidence has surfaced to suggest the problems were the result of Democrats "blocking" efforts to poll or caucus — and certainly not within the first few chaos-filled hours after the caucusing ended.
9: Possible polling error Results of the final CNN/Des Moines Register/Mediacom poll were scheduled to be released Feb. 2, two days before the caucuses.
10: The New York Times reported that the decision not to release the results was made after the campaign for Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg said that an Iowa supporter received a poll phone call from an operator working for the Register’s polling operation, but that the name of the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., was not listed on the menu of options.
11: One operator had apparently enlarged the font size on their computer screen, perhaps cutting off Buttigieg’s name from the list of options, according to two people interviewed by the Times.
12: Other news media, including Politico , also reported that Buttigieg’s campaign had raised the issue and that the font change apparently was the problem.
13: The Register’s executive editor, Carol Hunter, explained the decision in a Feb. 1 article , saying "it appears (Buttigieg’s) name was omitted in at least one interview in which the respondent was asked to name their preferred candidate," and that the omission "could have compromised the results of the poll."
14: Cause of caucus count problems unclear The second part of the statement undoubtedly refers to the unprecedented delay in the reporting of the results of Democratic caucuses.
15: By midday the following day (Feb. 4), the Iowa Democratic Party was saying it expected to release some results by 5 p.m. that day.
16: At that point, news organizations were reporting that the delays were caused by technical problems — both with an app and with a telephone system that had been set up as a backup for the electronic reporting of caucus tallies.
17: People who called experienced long delays or couldn’t get through at all.
18: No evidence had surfaced that the delay was due to Democrats "blocking" the poll or caucus.
19: We messaged Organizers for Bernie 2020, but didn’t get a reply.
20: A Sanders campaign spokeswoman told us the group has no relationship with the campaign.
21: She had no comment on the claim we’re checking.

gpt4: The claim that Democrats "blocked the Iowa poll" and "blocked the Iowa caucus" is false.
Despite thorough investigations, no evidence has surfaced indicating that the delay or problems in Iowa were a result of Democrats obstructing efforts to poll or caucus [8][18].
Furthermore, these allegations were not substantiated within the chaotic period immediately after the caucusing process ended [8].
Even a Sanders campaign spokeswoman openly affirmed that the group had no connection with their campaign, eliminating the possibility of an internal act from within the party [20].

d3be842e5367ad2b04269f10db84987d.claim: “There are more guns in this country than there are citizens.”
d3be842e5367ad2b04269f10db84987d.label: half-true
d3be842e5367ad2b04269f10db84987d.passage:
0: Culpeper Sheriff Scott Jenkins recently told state senators that reinstating Virginia’s one-handgun-a-month purchase limit would not reduce crime.
1: He was speaking before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Jan. 13, a few minutes before the panel approved the limit.
2: Slightly different versions of the legislation have since passed the Senate and the House , largely on party-line votes with Democrats in favor and Republicans opposed.
3: Gov.
4: Ralph Northam, a Democrat, backs the measure.
5: Jenkins spoke against the bill and made an interesting statistical claim.
6: "Simply put, there are more guns in this country than there are citizens," he said.
7: "All you’re going to do is continue to drive up the cost for the criminal to purchase the illegal guns.
8: Evil will still be committed."
9: Are there more guns than people in the United States?
10: The estimates Hard figures on the number of guns in the U.S. are elusive.
11: In the past few years, headlines in the Washington Post and on Vox have declared there are more guns than people in the country.
12: Both noted a surge of gun sales following the 2008 election of President Barack Obama .
13: But the headlines suggest the figures are certain when they’re not, given that there is no record keeping that would produce an actual count of guns in the United States.
14: As the Pew Research Center has observed , "Gun ownership is one of the hardest things for researchers to pin down."
15: At the same time, there have been studies to produce estimates on the number of civilian guns in the nation.
16: Both the Post and Vox noted an estimate on the high end - 310 million guns - that was cited in a 2012 report by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service.
17: The study said the estimate was based on U.S. Department of Justice data and was the "total number of firearms available to civilians" as of 2009.
18: That 310 million count is higher than the U.S. population in 2009 of about 307 million and the citizenship estimate of 285 million , estimated by the U.S. Census Bureau.
19: But one gun-statistics expert, Philip Cook at Duke University, told the Post that the actual figure then was probably closer to 245 million guns, not 310 million, to take into account circumstances such as guns that break down or are lost or destroyed.
20: Cook and two other experts -- Tom Smith at the University of Chicago and Daniel Webster at the Johns Hopkins at the Center for Gun Policy and Research -- have told PolitiFact the best, most recent estimate is in a study published in October 2017 by researchers from the Harvard Injury Control Research Center.
21: A total of 3,949 adults, representative of the U.S. population, were surveyed online.
22: The lead author of the study, Deborah Azrael , says respondents were asked if they owned guns and how many, and told not to count BB guns, replicas or other firearms that were not functioning.
23: The estimate: 265 million civilian guns in the United States, as of when the survey was taken, in January 2015.
24: The number of U.S. citizens at that time, according to the Census Bureau, was about 299 million .
25: Other highlights of the Harvard study: Of the estimated 265 million total civilian guns, 113 million were handguns.
26: The typical gun owner (the median, in the survey) owned two guns.
27: 39% of the estimated 265 million guns were owned by 8% of the gun owners -- that 8% of all owners owned 10 or more guns.
28: Prior fact checks PolitiFact has previously rated two claims that there are more guns than people in the U.S. That’s similar - but not identical - to Jenkins’ claim that there are more guns than citizens.
29: One of the claims was made in 2013 by Democrat Eleanor Holmes Norton , the non-voting delegate in the U.S. House of Representatives representing the District of Columbia; the other in 2018 by Kevin Nicholson, an unsuccessful Republican candidate for Congress in Wisconsin.
30: PolitiFact National, noting the lack of firm gun numbers, rated each statement Half True.

gpt4: The claim that there are more guns in the United States than there are citizens is considered to be half-true[6].
A report from the Harvard Injury Control Research Center states that the most recent estimate of guns outnumbers the U.S. population in 2009, with approximately 310 million guns counted[20][18].

This figure is higher than both the total U.S. population at the time, which stood at about 307 million, and the estimated count of 285 million American citizens, according to the U.S. Census Bureau[18][24].
However, these statistics should be approached with caution, as there's an absence of record-keeping that would yield an accurate count of guns in the U.S[13].
This makes the numbers subject to speculation and prevents a definitive conclusion on the claim.

cad2dbd366f4738f9a50f156df967b56.claim: “The president has exploded the debt by more than $3 trillion — all to give billion-dollar tax cuts to the wealthiest few.”
cad2dbd366f4738f9a50f156df967b56.label: half-true
cad2dbd366f4738f9a50f156df967b56.passage:
0: Rep. Veronica Escobar, D-Texas, took aim at the tax law that President Donald Trump signed into law in 2017, saying it has ballooned the debt.
1: "The president has exploded the debt by more than $3 trillion — all to give billion-dollar tax cuts to the wealthiest few," said Escobar, the lawmaker tapped to respond to President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address in Spanish .
2: (The Spanish version of the statement was, "El presidente ha disparado la deuda por más de 3 billones de dólares, todo por recortarle miles de millones de dólares de impuestos a los más ricos.")
3: Escobar is in the ballpark on the amount, but she’s exclusively blaming Trump when in fact her own party contributed to the passage of other laws that also increased the debt significantly.
4: She also overstates that the impact of the tax cuts by singling out only "the wealthiest few."
5: (Escobar’s office did not respond to an inquiry.)
6: "The president has exploded the debt by more than $3 trillion …" There are two ways of measuring the federal debt , and both get you to around $3 trillion.
7: The debt held by the public rose by about $2.8 trillion between Trump’s inauguration in 2017 and the day before his State of the Union address.
8: A broader measurement, gross federal debt, includes public debt plus the debt owed by one part of the government to another.
9: That rose by a bit over $3.3 trillion over the same time period.
10: While Trump’s tax bill, which passed only with Republican votes, was one of the main reasons for the increase in debt, it wasn’t the only one.
11: The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a fiscally conservative group, last year estimated that two other bills — the major federal spending bills that passed in February 2018 and August 2019 — jointly increased the debt by about as much as the tax bill did through 2019.
12: Other bills added a smaller amount.
13: The spending bill approved in 2018 passed with the support of most Senate Democrats and a bit over one-third of the House Democratic caucus.
14: The spending bill approved in 2019 passed with the support of most Senate Democrats and the overwhelming majority of House Democrats.
15: Escobar’s statement does not acknowledge this broad Democratic support for bills that played a significant role in increasing the debt.
16: "...all to give billion-dollar tax cuts to the wealthiest few."
17: The tax cut does provide tax breaks for the wealthiest few, and lots of other people, too.
18: The cuts are projected to total $1.8 trillion over the next decade, according to the Tax Foundation , a think tank with a pro-business leaning.
19: In 2018, about 80% of taxpayers had a tax cut due to the new law, according to the Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center , an independent group that models the effects of tax legislation.
20: The savings skew toward high-income earners.
21: The center said 21% of the total tax savings went to the highest-earning 1% of taxpayers in 2018, more than the total for the bottom 60%.
22: By 2025, that gap is projected to increase, with 25% of the tax savings going to the top 1%.
23: The increases are larger for higher-income earners on a percentage basis as well — not just in raw dollars.
24: In 2025, the top 1% are expected to see after-tax income grow by 2.9%, compared to 1.4% or less for the bottom 80% of income earners.

gpt4: The statement that the president has increased the federal debt by over $3 trillion is accurate, using both recognized forms of measuring the federal debt[6].
However, attributing this rise in debt solely to tax cuts aimed at the wealthiest individuals is a simplification.
Indeed, Trump's tax bill, passed solely with Republican votes, contributed to this increase, but other factors were in play[10].
Two extensive federal spending bills, passed in February 2018 and August 2019, were also significant contributors to the hike in federal debt.
These bills expanded the debt almost on par with the tax reform through 2019[11].
Despite the claim's implication, these spending bills saw broad bipartisan support, with the majority of Senate Democrats and significant portions of House Democrats voting in favor[13][14].
This widespread Democratic backing for debt-increasing bills is not acknowledged in the claim[15].
When it comes to the distribution of the tax cuts, the wealthiest individuals did benefit, along with many others[17].
In 2018, the top 1% of income earners received 21% of the total tax savings, a figure projected to rise to 25% in 2025[21][22].
The highest-income earners are expected to see their after-tax income grow by 2.9% in 2025, compared to 1.4% or less for the bottom 80% of earners[24].

4e78d5bafeea4c81a62b958bd26cf8b6.claim: “Traditionally, the Speaker says: ‘Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States.’ (Tonight) Speaker Pelosi said, ‘Members of Congress, the President of the United States.’ """
4e78d5bafeea4c81a62b958bd26cf8b6.label: true
4e78d5bafeea4c81a62b958bd26cf8b6.passage:
0: Following President Donald Trump’s 2020 State of the Union Address, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., ripped up a copy of Trump’s speech in full view of the cameras.
1: But earlier, she made a less dramatic deviation from protocol.
2: CNN host Jake Tapper noted the shift in his post-speech analysis, as well as in a tweet that attracted more than 36,000 likes.
3: Tapper wrote, "Traditionally, the Speaker says: ‘Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States.’ (Tonight) Speaker Pelosi said, ‘Members of Congress, the President of the United States.’ " Tapper is right, we found.
4: We looked back at all of the speaker-president interactions in State of the Union addresses going back to 2007, which was Pelosi’s first as speaker.
5: (The 2009 and 2017 addresses are technically not considered State of the Union addresses, but we counted them too.)
6: Between the 2007 and 2018 addresses, every speaker has said something very close to the following: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
7: Here’s the rundown, with links to the video.
8: 2007 : Pelosi to President George W. Bush: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
9: 2008 : Pelosi to Bush: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
10: 2009 : Pelosi to President Barack Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
11: 2010 : Pelosi to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
12: 2011 : House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, to Obama: "I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting the president of the United States."
13: 2012 : Boehner to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
14: 2013 : Boehner to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
15: 2014 : Boehner to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
16: 2015 : Boehner to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
17: 2016 : Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., to Obama: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
18: 2017 : Ryan to Trump: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
19: 2018 : Ryan to Trump: "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States."
20: The Pelosi-Trump interactions The pattern changed abruptly in 2019, with Trump as president and Pelosi as speaker.
21: In 2019, Pelosi didn’t say anything before Trump started speaking.
22: It’s unclear whether there was a miscommunication, but Pelosi insisted to reporters later that "there was no snub.
23: It went quickly, I guess."
24: In 2020, Pelosi did say part of the phrase — but as Tapper noted, it was just a part.
25: She said: "Members of Congress, the president of the United States."
26: Pelosi’s office did not respond to an inquiry for this article.

gpt4: The claim that Speaker Pelosi deviated from the traditional phrase used during the State of the Union addresses is true.
According to Tapper, the phrase traditionally spoken by the Speaker is "Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States"[3].
This was confirmed by looking back at all of the speaker-president interactions in State of the Union addresses dating back to 2007, which was Pelosi’s first tenure as speaker[4].
However, there was a notable shift in the pattern of Pelosi-Trump interactions in 2019 and 2020 when Trump was president[20].
In 2020, Speaker Pelosi did slightly alter the phrase, only saying "Members of Congress, the President of the United States"[24].
These findings reveal that the claim is indeed accurate.

3efdb8af4ee582feecee44484e3fe151.claim: “Over 130 legislators in this chamber have endorsed legislation that would bankrupt our nation by providing free taxpayer-funded health care to millions of illegal aliens, forcing taxpayers to subsidize free care for anyone in the world who unlawfully crosses our borders."""
3efdb8af4ee582feecee44484e3fe151.label: half-true
3efdb8af4ee582feecee44484e3fe151.passage:
0: In his 2020 State of the Union address, President Donald Trump attempted to tie a Democratic proposal for health care reform to one of his signature issues: immigration.
1: "Over 130 legislators in this chamber have endorsed legislation that would bankrupt our nation by providing free taxpayer-funded healthcare to millions of illegal aliens, forcing taxpayers to subsidize free care for anyone in the world who unlawfully crosses our borders," Trump said Feb. 4.
2: That appears to be a reference to the "Medicare for All" bills put forth in the Senate and House by Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) that would establish a universal, government-funded health care system.
3: They’re the flagship Medicare for All proposals  and have shaped a large portion of the 2020 campaign discourse on health care.
4: We reached out to the White House to confirm that Trump was referring to these plans, but didn’t hear back.
5: That said, Trump has made similar remarks before about Medicare for All.
6: And he is on target with his co-sponsor estimate for these bills.
7: The Sanders measure has 14 Senate co-sponsors and the Jayapal legislation has 118 in the House.
8: His remarks were dramatic, though, in highlighting the proposal’s alleged consequences for undocumented immigrants.
9: And health policy experts told us Trump missed the mark.
10: The immigration question Trump is correct in his understanding that these proposals were intended to provide coverage regardless of immigration status.
11: But evidence does not support his argument that Medicare for All would "bankrupt" the country by extending health insurance coverage to everyone, and to immigrants in the country illegally in particular.
12: One point: While the single-payer system outlined in the pending legislative proposals would increase public spending — and by a significant amount — its backers say that total health care spending likely wouldn’t change that much.
13: That’s because, as the plan is envisioned, while government spending would go up, private health expenditures would disappear.
14: "Medicare for All would dramatically shift how we pay for health care, but not necessarily how much we spend in total," said Larry Levitt, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation.
15: "It’s hard to make the case that it would bankrupt the country."
16: (Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
17: Furthermore, to suggest that providing them with insurance would bankrupt the country is misleading.
18: Those immigrants make up a small size of the population — about 11 million, compared to the total national population of approximately 372 million.
19: "A very, very small percentage of the total cost is associated with that 11 million people," said Linda Blumberg, an analyst at the Urban Institute, a Washington think tank.
20: "We’re talking about a strawman."
21: In fact, she noted, many existing programs on the state, county and local level already provide health benefits to undocumented immigrants.
22: Those programs haven’t led to bankruptcy.
23: Part of a broader theme Trump’s claim on health care for undocumented immigrants was part of a larger broadside on Democratic health proposals.
24: He also argued Democrats would "impose a socialist takeover of our health care system" and "raid the Medicare benefits our seniors depend on."
25: Those statements are also misleading.
26: For one thing, Levitt noted, Medicare for All would not socialize the medical care system, even if it would replace private insurance with all public programs.
27: Under the current proposals, hospitals and doctors would still stand as private entities.
28: "It would in no way mean a socialist takeover of the health care system," Levitt said.
29: "When Americans think of health care, I suspect they think of the people who actually deliver that care."
30: The idea of "raiding" Medicare is also tricky, as we noted last October .
31: While the single-payer plan would replace conventional Medicare with a new government program, that program (according to the Sanders and Jayapal bills) would have more generous benefits than Medicare currently offers.
32: If anything, then, benefits wouldn’t be raided; they would be bolstered.
33: The result, analysts said: a series of arguments that distracts from the actual debate at hand.
34: "It is worthwhile having a serious debate over the inherent tradeoffs of the reform being discussed," Blumberg said.
35: "But this is the same kind of throwaway line and inflammatory language to thwart serious conversation.

gpt4: While it is true that over 130 legislators endorsed the "Medicare for All" bills introduced by Sen. Bernie Sanders and Rep. Pramila Jayapal, this legislation's intent is to establish a universal, government-funded healthcare system and not exclusively targeted at illegal immigrants [2].
The claim that this legislation would bankrupt the nation, as stated by President Trump, does not find support in evidence [1].

Experts argue that although government spending would increase if this legislation is passed, private health expenditures would vanish, thus indicating a significant shift in how healthcare is bought and paid for, not necessarily the total amount spent [13][14].
It is also potentially misleading to argue that providing healthcare to illegal immigrants alone would bankrupt the nation.

These immigrants make up only a small part of the population, approximately 11 million out of 372 million, hence their healthcare costs would constitute a very tiny percentage of the total expenses [17][18][19].

Therefore, the claim is half-true: while it is accurate that many legislators endorsed the legislation, the implications concerning national bankruptcy and its burden on taxpayers are not entirely supported by facts.

8efd4c8fa08261b703ff445d9b572abb.claim: Donald Trump tweeted, “I have it on good authority that the real reason for the delayed results from the #IowaCaucus is they are trying to hide the fact that the winner was @VerminSupreme. This is one time I hope the DNC is actually successful, as Vermin is the only candidate that is smart (and crazy) enough to possibly beat me!”
8efd4c8fa08261b703ff445d9b572abb.label: false
8efd4c8fa08261b703ff445d9b572abb.passage:
0: The results of the Iowa Democratic presidential caucus were delayed because, according to the state’s Democratic Party, an app it was using to tabulate results had a "coding issue."
1: A Feb. 4 Facebook post appears to show a tweet from President Donald Trump offering another explanation.
2: "I have it on good authority that the real reason for the delayed results from the #IowaCaucus is they are trying to hide the fact that the winner was @VerminSupreme," the tweet says.
3: "This is one time I hope the DNC is actually successful, as Vermin is the only candidate that is smart (and crazy) enough to possibly beat me!"
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: "I never thought the day would come when I’d 100% agree with President Trump on something," one account commented on the post.
7: "I stand corrected!"
8: The screenshot of the tweet shows it was published at 10:59 a.m. on Feb. 4.
9: Trump tweeted several times on Feb. 4, including about the Iowa Democratic caucuses.
10: But we didn’t see a tweet about Vermin Supreme , a performance artist and perennial Libertarian presidential candidate who wears a boot on his head.
11: And because it’s widely reported when the president deletes tweets — such as this one , where he wrongly referred to the Kansas City Chiefs’ home state as Kansas — we’d expect similar coverage about a scrubbed Vermin Supreme tweet.
12: Of course, there’s none.

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump made a tweet implying that the Democratic National Committee was trying to hide the fact that Vermin Supreme, a perennial Libertarian presidential candidate, had won the Iowa Caucus, has proved to be false.
This purported tweet was actually part of a Feb. 4 Facebook post [1].
However, there's no evidence that such a tweet from Trump exists as no record of this tweet was found about Vermin Supreme [10].
In fact, no such tweets exist at all [12].
The claim, therefore, lacks any credible or verifiable evidence supporting it and was likely a misinterpretation or deliberate fabrication.

ec060b3aae1183c5e1731e3cba034e85.claim: “In sanctuary cities, local officials order police to release dangerous criminal aliens to prey upon the public instead of handing them over to ICE to be safely removed.”
ec060b3aae1183c5e1731e3cba034e85.label: false
ec060b3aae1183c5e1731e3cba034e85.passage:
0: During the 2020 State of the Union address, President Donald Trump slammed "sanctuary cities" for their limited cooperation with Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
1: "In sanctuary cities, local officials order police to release dangerous criminal aliens to prey upon the public instead of handing them over to ICE to be safely removed," he said.
2: Trump cited an incident in which an undocumented immigrant released from custody allegedly assaulted and killed a 92-year-old woman in New York City.
3: Trump also spotlighted the brother of a man killed in a crime spree by an undocumented immigrant released in California.
4: "The United States of America should be a sanctuary for law-abiding Americans, not criminal aliens," he said, calling on Congress to pass a bill to let victims sue sanctuary cities.
5: There’s no federal definition for a sanctuary city, and the details vary from place to place.
6: But broadly speaking, the term refers to any jurisdiction that refuses to continue holding people in local jails beyond their jail or prison sentence solely because ICE has asked the jurisdiction to do so.
7: (ICE’s request is formally known as a detainer.)
8: The individual cases Trump addressed were documented in media reports, and the White House has published a list of other criminal noncitizens shielded from ICE officials.
9: But Trump’s claim that local officials "order police to release dangerous criminal aliens" makes setting criminals free sounds like standard operating procedure.
10: As we detailed while fact-checking a similar claim in 2018 , that’s not the case.
11: Even sanctuary cities typically turn over to ICE many of the felons Trump warns about.
12: The White House and Trump campaign did not respond to requests for comment.
13: It’s unclear how frequently this happens ICE news releases report numerous instances of ignored detainer requests that result in undocumented immigrants being set free and later arrested by ICE.
14: According to ICE’s report for the 2019 fiscal year, 86% of the roughly 143,000 noncitizens arrested by ICE had criminal convictions or pending charges.
15: It’s unclear how many were arrested after being released in sanctuary cities.
16: The report says ICE issued 165,487 detainers to law enforcement officials, and that "a number of aliens who have been released under these circumstances have gone on to commit additional crimes."
17: Some insight came during an October Senate hearing , when ICE official Timothy Robbins said the agency brought roughly 1,300 noncitizens into custody over the span of a "few weeks," including "large numbers" of people who had been released in sanctuary cities.
18: Robbins said three of those 1,300 people had prior convictions for manslaughter or murder, 100 had convictions for sexual assault or related crimes, 70 had convictions for drug-related crimes, and 320 had convictions for driving under the influence.
19: "Almost 200 of the aliens arrested during the most recent operation could have been taken into custody at local jails if the detainer had been honored," Robbins said.
20: Robbins did not say whether any of the 200 people ICE targeted with detainers went on to commit further crimes or, in Trump’s words, "prey" on Americans.
21: Violent felons and others can usually be detained Sanctuary policies across the country treat dangerous criminals differently, but experts told us many have specific ways of dealing with them.
22: "A number of the sanctuary policies have carve-outs for individuals with certain types of felony offenses, and some non-felony offenses," Annie Lai, clinical professor of law at the University of California Irvine, told us .
23: "You want to see if the policy allows for detention for ICE, notification to ICE, transfer to ICE or transfer only with a warrant.
24: Each of these mean different things."
25: California’s sanctuary law , for example, gives law enforcement officials leeway to hold someone for ICE if they’ve committed one of a number of crimes.
26: The list includes gang-related offenses, assault, battery, sexual abuse and exploitation, rape, crimes endangering children, burglary, robbery, theft, fraud, forgery, any crime resulting in death, some domestic violence offenses, and drug and weapon-related offenses.
27: In New York City , people convicted of one or more of 177 types of felonies within the last five years can be handed over to ICE authorities, but only if those authorities secure a warrant first.
28: Michelle Mittelstadt, director of communications at the Migration Policy Institute, told us she’s "unaware of a jurisdiction that releases ‘dangerous criminal aliens’ as a matter of policy."
29: "Where jurisdictions have set limits on their cooperation with ICE typically revolve around the issue of whether the agency is seeking transfer of a noncitizen who has been booked or charged versus an offender who is completing a criminal sentence, as well as whether ICE needs to seek a court order for the request to detain a noncitizen," she added.
30: Trump’s examples Mittelstadt explained that when noncitizens are released in sanctuary cities, "the criminal justice process has taken place or is taking place as it would in the case of anyone else."
31: "When state and local prisons release noncitizens without transfer to ICE, the person has completed their criminal sentence, has been released without charge, or has been charged and released on bond pending further action in the criminal justice system," she said.
32: The New York City murder suspect Trump mentioned had originally been arrested for attacking his father with a broken coffee cup and arraigned on charges of assault and criminal possession of a weapon before he was released pending trial, according to reports .
33: He had not yet been convicted on those charges by the time of the alleged murder.
34: Meanwhile, the California man who went on a crime spree in 2018 had previously been convicted of armed robbery.
35: But the charge was 15 years old, meaning local police couldn’t use it to justify holding him for ICE, according to the Washington Post .
36: He had been deported twice before, in 2004 and 2014, and was arrested in 2018 after a caller reported erratic behavior.
37: He tested positive for use of a controlled substance, but because that offense only carried a misdemeanor charge, he was released after 10 hours in custody.
38: Mike Boudreaux, the county sheriff on the case, blamed California’s sanctuary law for keeping his officers from coordinating with ICE authorities.
39: "That tool has been removed from our hands," he said, according to the Washington Post .
40: "And because of that, our county was shot up by a violent criminal."

gpt4: The claim that local officials in sanctuary cities systematically release dangerous criminal aliens, allowing them to pose a threat to public safety rather than handing them over to ICE, is factually inaccurate.

This assertion posits that there is a purposeful choice to jeopardize public safety in favor of protecting undocumented immigrants from deportation, with local authorities instructing police to set these so-called dangerous criminals free [1].
However, even in sanctuary cities, most felons that pose a real threat, as characterized in the claim, are typically handed over to ICE [11].
Furthermore, evidence does not support that any jurisdiction follows a policy of releasing "dangerous criminal aliens"[28].
This discrepancy may be fueled by the fact that there's no federal definition of what constitutes a sanctuary city, and policies can greatly differ from one place to another[5].
When a similar claim was made in 2018, it was also debunked, reinforcing that this is a misunderstanding or misrepresentation [10].

1643f3e44c9bcb8fd85e679188e9526a.claim: the coronavirus isn’t new because “Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses that it kills.”
1643f3e44c9bcb8fd85e679188e9526a.label: false
1643f3e44c9bcb8fd85e679188e9526a.passage:
0: Many social media users are sharing posts that suggest health officials are lying when they claim ignorance about the recent coronavirus outbreak, such as this one from Jan. 31 .
1: "Don’t fall for the B.S.
2: they claim the Coronavirus is new… But regular over the counter Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses that it kills!"
3: the post says.
4: It shows one image of someone holding a Lysol disinfectant spray can, and another of what looks like the back of the can, where the words "Human Coronavirus" appear.
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: We’ve already debunked several hoaxes and conspiracies about the coronavirus, including one that’s similar to the claim in this Facebook post: that Clorox bottles prove the coronavirus was developed before the recent outbreak in China.
8: Here’s what you should know.
9: There are seven kinds of coronaviruses that can infect humans.
10: They were first identified in the mid-1960s and some of the viruses are common, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention .
11: The strain of coronavirus spreading from Wuhan, China, is categorized as the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
12: According to the World Health Organization , a novel coronavirus  is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans.
13: The 2019 strain was first reported from Wuhan on Dec. 31.
14: As of Feb. 4, more than 20,000 cases have been confirmed globally .
15: Deaths total 426, with only one occurring outside of China.
16: Some cleaning product labels mention "human coronavirus" because those surface products have been proven effective against past strains of coronavirus.
17: On its website, Lysol has a section dedicated to the coronavirus .
18: It says that specific Lysol products, including its disinfectant spray, "have demonstrated effectiveness against viruses similar to 2019 Novel coronavirus (2019-n-CoV) on hard, non-porous surfaces."
19: (Again, this is only when used to clean surfaces; such products should never be ingested!)
20: This Facebook post falsely assumes that because the label for Lysol disinfectant spray includes mention of its effectiveness against "coronavirus," media descriptions of a current outbreak as being caused by a new virus are "B.S."
21: But that assumption is wrong.
22: The Lysol spray has demonstrated effectiveness against past strains of coronavirus.
23: The current outbreak spreading from Wuhan, China, is caused by a previously unidentified strain known as the 2019 Novel coronavirus.
24: Cleaning products that list coronavirus on their labels are not referring to this strain.
25: We rate this Facebook post False.

gpt4: The popular claim that the coronavirus isn’t new because “Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses that it kills” is false.
There are in fact seven different kinds of coronaviruses that can infect humans[9], but not all of them are the same.
A novel coronavirus, as defined by the World Health Organization, is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans[12].
The exact strain which caused the recent outbreak spreading from Wuhan, China, is the 2019 Novel coronavirus, a previously unidentified strain[23].
Therefore, while certain cleaning products might list 'coronavirus' on their labels, they specifically do not refer to the novel strain that sparked the current pandemic[24].

42dba2241ed1ef7e6c707aaa61e3aff2.claim: “I have also overseen historic funding increases for high-quality child care, enabling 17 states to help more children, many of which have reduced or eliminated their waitlists altogether.”
42dba2241ed1ef7e6c707aaa61e3aff2.label: half-true
42dba2241ed1ef7e6c707aaa61e3aff2.passage:
0: President Donald Trump told Congress during his State of the Union address that under his watch the federal government has achieved record spending on child care.
1: "I have also overseen historic funding increases for high-quality child care, enabling 17 states to help more children, many of which have reduced or eliminated their waitlists altogether," he said Feb. 4.
2: We asked the White House to provide evidence but did not get a response.
3: Trump was likely referring to the Child Care and Development Block Grant, which he touted in a December 2019 list of his accomplishments .
4: Trump is correct that he oversaw a historic funding increase.
5: But we don't have complete information on how many children have been removed from wait lists.
6: Experts said Congress gets the credit for passing the increase.
7: Historic funding increase for 2018 The block grant program that started in 1990 is the largest source of federal funding for child care.
8: The federal government sends money to states to subsidize child care for low-income families.
9: Parents who generally are working or in school pay a small copay .
10: About 1.3 million children received this subsidy in 2018.
11: Congress included a $2.37 billion increase for the block grants in the fiscal year 2018 omnibus spending bill.
12: It was the largest one-year increase in federal funding for child care in history, according to the Center for Law and Social Policy , an advocacy organization for low-income people.
13: The low-income day care program has enjoyed bipartisan support, even before the Trump years, said Stephanie Schmit, an analyst at the center.
14: In his address to Congress, Trump said he had "overseen" the historic increase.
15: But his 2018 budget proposal called for a $95 million decrease in the program compared with actual spending in 2017 .
16: Ultimately Congress approved an increase anyway.
17: Funding remained relatively flat for fiscal year 2019.
18: But in the 2020 appropriations bill, Congress boosted the program by about $550 million .
19: It’s tricky to determine the precise impact the additional funding had on waiting lists, because the money can be spent over a number of years.
20: But we found two reports that support the idea.
21: A National Women’s Law Center report found that eight states were using or were planning to use the extra money to serve families on the waiting list.
22: (Those eight states were Arkansas, Florida, Indiana, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Texas.)
23: A Government Accountability Office analysis on how states used the money after 2018 found that nearly one-third of surveyed states (16) reported plans to use the new funds to pay for spots for children on wait lists.
24: Child care advocates say the funding increases are good news, though vast needs remain: Of the children eligible in 2015, only 15% received subsidies, according to a 2019 analysis by the federal government .
25: That percentage is unlikely to change substantially even after the funding increases, said Karen Schulman, an expert at the National Women’s Law Center.
26: There are likely more eligible families that need care than actually applied, said W. Steven Barnett, senior co-director of the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University.
27: ‘Waiting lists are the currently eligible people who bothered to sign up to wait, not all of the people eligible and unserved," he said.

gpt4: President Trump's claim that he has "overseen historic funding increases for high-quality child care, enabling 17 states to help more children, many of which have reduced or eliminated their waitlists altogether" is partially correct [1].
Trump likely referred to the Child Care and Development Block Grant, which experienced a significant funding boost during his tenure [3].
His statement contains elements of truth, as this was the most substantial single-year increase in federal funding toward child care in history [12].
This funding rise resulted from a $2.37 billion increment included in the fiscal year 2018 omnibus spending bill passed by Congress [6][11].
However, it's worth mentioning that his initial 2018 budget proposal suggested a $95 million reduction for the same program [15].
Ultimately, Congress approved a funding increase regardless of this initial proposal [16].

Furthermore, a National Women's Law Center report and a Government Accountability Office analysis found that eight and sixteen states respectively, planned to utilize the added funds to assist families on waiting lists [21][23].
Even though Trump's claim of oversight is technically correct [14], the responsibility for this historic increase lies primarily with Congress [4].

4d5c6849807b31d6cab3f7ba8be2e26c.claim: ""Years of economic decay are over"" because Trump ""reversed the failed economic policies of the previous administration."""
4d5c6849807b31d6cab3f7ba8be2e26c.label: false
4d5c6849807b31d6cab3f7ba8be2e26c.passage:
0: One of the biggest themes of President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address — and one of the biggest themes of his reelection campaign — is that he inherited a weak economy from President Barack Obama and turned it into a strong economy by implementing his own policies.
1: "The years of economic decay are over," he told the joint session of Congress on Feb. 4, 2020.
2: "The days of our country being used, taken advantage of, and even scorned by other nations are long behind us.
3: Gone, too, are the broken promises, jobless recoveries, tired platitudes and constant excuses for the depletion of American wealth, power and prestige."
4: Trump added, "If we hadn’t reversed the failed economic policies of the previous administration, the world would not now be witnessing this great economic success."
5: When we reached out to the Trump campaign, they offered several statistics showing Trump has notched greater gains than Obama did, such as manufacturing job creation, the unemployment rate, and economic growth.
6: We found those statistics, and other specific facts Trump cited during the State of the Union , were accurate, or largely so.
7: However, unlike Obama, who inherited the Great Recession, Trump inherited an economy that was already getting back on its feet.
8: Overall, we found a continuation of the favorable trend lines Trump inherited from Obama.
9: We looked at 15 common economic statistics, from unemployment rates to growth in gross domestic product to poverty, foreclosures, and bank failures.
10: They cover the period of the Great Recession until today.
11: Where possible, we’ve highlighted periods under a Republican president in red and periods under a Democratic president in blue.
12: The bottom line: For virtually each of these measurements, we found that the trend lines continued almost seamlessly from the second half of Obama’s presidency into the first three years of Trump’s tenure.
13: Trump’s claim that he turned around a failing economy is wrong.
14: "I do not think economic gains have been any faster or better under Trump than gains we would have forecast based on the steady improvements we saw in the economy and job market in President Obama’s second term," said Gary Burtless, an economist with the Brookings Institution.
15: Also, no president has total control over the factors affecting the economy.
16: Broader trends beyond their powers — from international economic conditions to technological changes — shape the course of the economy as well.
17: "All our decisions together produce the economy," said Aaron Sojourner, a University of Minnesota economist.
18: "It doesn't change when the resident of the White House does."
19: Employment statistics For unemployment rates and for median weeks of unemployment, the declines under Obama were at least as fast — if not faster — than they have been under Trump.
20: That holds for several of the racial and ethnic groups Trump often cites in speeches, as well as for women.
21: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Meanwhile, since the recovery gained speed, the pattern of monthly job gains has been quite similar under both Obama and Trump.
22: That’s also broadly true for manufacturing job gains, a metric that Trump has been especially focused on.
23: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com The percentage of Americans either working or looking for work took longer to recover than other statistics, and it still hasn’t returned to pre-recession levels.
24: This statistic did fall for most of Obama’s tenure, but it started to rise in his final year and has continued to rise under Trump.
25: Wages Inflation-adjusted wages fell for much of Obama’s first term, but they began rising again during his second term.
26: Their path under Trump has been along much the same trajectory.
27: Gross domestic product As a candidate, Trump promised 4% economic growth.
28: But he’s never hit that mark in any quarter (Obama did so in four quarters) and he has hit 3% in four quarters, the same number that Obama did during an equivalent period, his final three years in office.
29: See Figure 4 on PolitiFact.com Poverty and food stamps The poverty rate and food stamp use has declined under Trump.
30: Those declines began during Obama’s final years in office.
31: Credit and banking The big declines in foreclosures, bankruptcies and bank failures occurred under Obama, with marginal advances under Trump.
32: The stock market Trump often touts how the stock market has risen on his watch, and it has, to record levels.
33: But a look at the Standard & Poor’s 500, a broad measure of stock market value, shows that the markets have risen at roughly the same rate under both presidents.
