34: Consumer confidence Trump may have his strongest argument on the most intangible of these statistics: consumer confidence.
35: Regular measurements by Gallup and the University of Michigan show a "breakpoint right after the election" in Trump’s favor, said Jed Kolko, the chief economist for Indeed.com.
36: In Gallup’s measure, for instance, the statistic broke into positive territory with Trump’s election and has stayed there, after being in negative territory for virtually all of Obama’s tenure.
37: "Multiple economic confidence measures took an immediate and sustained jump after the election, even though it's hard to find similar shifts among the key measures of actual economic performance," Kolko said.
38: But another widely tracked statistic, the Conference Board’s Consumer Confidence Index, shows a continuing rise during Obama’s full tenure that presaged the later heights Trump reached.

gpt4: The claim that years of economic decay are over due to Trump reversing the failed economic policies of the previous administration is found to be false.

A close examination of the Standard & Poor’s 500, a broad measure of stock market value, indicates the markets have risen at a similar rate under both Trump and Obama, suggesting a continuity in economic trends across both administrations [33].
Economists observe that Trump inherited an economy that was already on the road to recovery after the Great Recession, as opposed to Obama [7].
Moreover, this trend of economic improvement under Trump was a continuation of the favorable circumstances he inherited from Obama [8].
Consequently, the claim that Trump turned around a failing economy is incorrect[13].

According to Gary Burtless, an economist with the Brookings Institution, the economic gains under Trump have not been significantly faster or better than what could have been predicted based on the steady improvements noticed during Obama's second term [14].

Limitations of Presidential control should also be considered, with broader trends such as international economic conditions and technological changes being equally influential on the course of the economy [16].
Additionally, inflation-adjusted wages fell during much of Obama’s first term, but rose throughout his second term, and followed a similar trajectory under Trump [25][26].
In fact, trends regarding job gains and economic growth have been quite similar under both administrations [21][28].
In and of itself, the economy does not dramatically change when the resident of the White House does [18].

ea14e3f27d980b9785159a10f0f2b86c.claim: U.S. Rep. Sean Casten “demanded the impeachment of the Republican President before the Mueller report was even released.”
ea14e3f27d980b9785159a10f0f2b86c.label: false
ea14e3f27d980b9785159a10f0f2b86c.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s legal team and his supporters argue Democrats in Congress fueled by partisan politics began making a case for impeaching Trump the day he took office.
1: Illinois Republican congressional candidate Jeanne Ives last week took a similar jab at Democratic U.S. Rep. Sean Casten of Downers Grove, who holds the 6th District west suburban seat she wants.
2: A press release from her campaign states Casten "demanded the impeachment of the Republican President before the Mueller report was even released."
3: That’s a reference to Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s account of his investigation into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election, including possible ties between Trump’s campaign and Russian officials.
4: A redacted version of Mueller’s report released on April 18 affirmed the Trump campaign thought it would benefit from Russia’s election interference.
5: But the report did not establish coordination between the Trump campaign and Russia.
6: It also detailed the president’s efforts to curtail the nearly two-year probe.
7: Casten was critical of Trump during this time but the freshman congressman did not announce his support for launching an impeachment inquiry until two months after Mueller’s report was made public.
8: And, even then, he did not say he would vote yes on articles of impeachment drawn up by the House until December .
9: "I didn’t run for Congress to impeach the President," Casten said in a June 20 press release that noted he had read the report and was alarmed by its findings.
10: "But I also ran for office because I felt the people of my District deserved transparency from their elected representative.
11: That’s why, after much thought and careful deliberation, I support opening an impeachment inquiry into the President of the United States."
12: So we contacted Ives’ campaign to find out what she was referencing.
13: Instead of providing evidence showing Casten had gone public with his support for impeachment prior to the release of Mueller’s report, spokeswoman Kathleen Murphy highlighted a different point on the timeline.
14: "He didn't wait for Mueller's congressional testimony," Murphy wrote in an email.
15: "Casten was only interested in getting whatever thinly veiled contrivance he could get to support a position he’s had from the day Trump was elected: removing Trump from office.
16: As soon as the Mueller report was released, he ran screaming into the public square to declare it what he wished upon a star it would be rather than what it actually was."
17: Murphy also claimed Casten voiced support for impeachment before he was even elected, pointing to a 2018 Sun-Times candidate questionnaire in which he stated that "strong and plentiful evidence" of Russian election interference could not be ignored.
18: "It is imperative that the Mueller investigation into this matter be allowed to continue to its conclusion without obstruction from the White House or interference by Congress," Casten continued, a passage Murphy highlighted.
19: However, Casten made no call for impeachment in his Sun-Times response.
20: And at several points during his 2018 campaign when he was asked where he came down on the issue, he stopped short of advocating for the House to take that course.
21: Casten later called for an inquiry when such a move was beginning to gain traction among House Democrats .
22: As a freshman Democrat who flipped a district held by Republicans for nearly five decades , he was one of the first vulnerable members of his party to take that stance.
23: The House introduced two articles of impeachment against Trump on Dec. 10, 2019 .
24: Those articles say Trump wanted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to announce investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden and a debunked conspiracy related to the 2016 election.
25: They also say Trump withheld security aid and a White House meeting to pressure Zelensky, then obstructed Congress to cover it up.
26: On Dec. 12, Casten announced in a tweet he would vote in favor of impeachment.

gpt4: The claim that U.S. Representative Sean Casten demanded the impeachment of the Republican president before the Mueller report was released is deemed false.

While there was indeed a press release from his campaign stating otherwise[2], evidence shows that Casten was cautious about expressing vociferous support for impeachment prior to the release of the Mueller report.
In fact, during his 2018 campaign, when asked about his stance on impeachment, he refrained from advocating for the House of Representatives to pursue this course of action[20].
His response to the Sun-Times also did not include any call for impeachment[19].

Even though he was critical of the Republican president, it was not until two months after the public release of Mueller’s report that Casten formally announced his support for initiating an impeachment inquiry[7].
This discrepancy reveals that the campaign’s press release was inaccurate.

06bc0821da8ae256dbc4592d714ff198.claim: ""Nancy Pelosi may have just committed a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2071, Section 2071 (a) when she ripped up President Trump’s State of the Union address. This violation is punishable by up to three years in prison.”"
06bc0821da8ae256dbc4592d714ff198.label: false
06bc0821da8ae256dbc4592d714ff198.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., drew the ire of Republicans when she tore up a copy of President Donald Trump’s 2020 State of the Union address.
1: One conservative pundit said she deserved more than just the ridicule of her GOP colleagues.
2: "Nancy Pelosi may have just committed a violation of 18 U.S.C.
3: § 2071, Section 2071 (a) when she ripped up President Trump’s State of the Union address," Turning Point USA founder Charlie Kirk wrote in a Feb. 4 tweet .
4: "This violation is punishable by up to three years in prison."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Kirk’s claim made the rounds on Twitter, with former congressional candidate Carl Higbie , North Carolina Rep. Dan Bishop and Donald Trump Jr. all repeating or retweeting versions of it.
6: But when we asked a number of legal experts about what Kirk said, we found that their answer was unanimous: Kirk’s claim is wrong.
7: "I take it that this is a printout of the Trump speech, in which case it is absurd to suggest that Pelosi can be prosecuted for doing with it whatever she pleases," said Heidi Kitrosser, a law professor at the University of Minnesota.
8: Why Pelosi didn’t violate the law See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com In a statement to PolitiFact, a spokesperson for Kirk cited the federal law Kirk mentioned and a Justice Department webpage summarizing it.
9: "Anything that comes out of the office of the president is a government document under the Presidential Records Act of 1978," the statement said.
10: The statute in question deals with the "concealment, removal, or mutilation generally" of records and reports.
11: It sets a penalty for anyone who "conceals, removes, mutilates, obliterates, or destroys" any government record "filed or deposited with any clerk or officer of any court of the United States, or in any public office, or with any judicial or public officer of the United States."
12: The statute also says that any person with "custody" of a government record cannot "willfully and unlawfully" conceal, remove, mutilate, obliterate, falsify or destroy it.
13: "The point of the statute is to prevent people from destroying records in official repositories like the National Archives or in courts," said Georgetown Law professor Victoria Nourse.
14: Pelosi is in the clear, experts said, because her copy of Trump’s speech wasn’t a government record.
15: The State of the Union text was never "filed or deposited" with her, nor did she have "custody" of it in the legal sense.
16: Video of the event shows that Trump handed her and Vice President Mike Pence copies before he began speaking, and Pelosi can be seen following along throughout.
17: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com President Donald Trump hands copies of his State of the Union address to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Vice President Mike Pence before delivering it to Congress on Feb. 4, 2020, in Washington.
18: (AP/Semansky) "Her copy of the State of the Union address is not a government record or government property at all," said Douglas Cox, professor of law at the City University of New York School of Law and an expert in the laws governing the preservation of government records.
19: "It is personal property."
20: Under House rules , members of Congress are encouraged to preserve records or donate them to a research institution for historical study, Cox said.
21: Unlike congressional committees , members are not legally required to hold onto their office’s files.
22: "They can keep them private, they can destroy them, or they can rip them up," he said.
23: This is in contrast to presidential records, which have been considered government property since the Presidential Records Act of 1978 and are supposed to be stored with the National Archives for safekeeping.
24: "The State of the Union is a presidential record, which must go to the National Archives under the Presidential Records Act," Nourse said "(Pelosi) did not mutilate the record that is filed with the Archives."
25: The purpose of the records law "is to prevent someone from depriving the government from the use of its documents," so Pelosi’s move "doesn’t fit within the statute," added Kathleen Clark, professor of law at Washington University in St. Louis.
26: There are probably countless copies of Trump’s address, such as the version the White House posted online.
27: Pelosi’s action doesn’t preclude future generations from accessing one.
28: "If the statute were not read this way, then any copy of the State of the Union held by anyone could never be destroyed," Nourse said.
29: For what it’s worth, Trump has a habit of ripping up papers when he’s done with them.
30: According to Politico , staff members have had to tape Trump’s shredded files together in order to send them to the Archives and avoid crossing the Presidential Records Act.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi may have committed a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2071, Section 2071 (a) when she ripped up President Trump’s State of the Union address, and this is potentially punishable by up to three years in prison is false.
Several legal experts assure the situation doesn't involve any violations.
Heidi Kitrosser, a law professor at the University of Minnesota, argues that Pelosi could do whatever she pleased with a printout of the Trump speech [7].
Georgetown Law professor Victoria Nourse reinforces this by stating that the statute aims to prevent people from destroying records in official repositories [13].

Furthering this, Pelosi's copy of Trump’s speech wasn’t a government record [14] and that the text was never "filed or deposited" with her, hence, she did not have "custody" of it in the legal sense [15].
Douglas Cox, a law professor at City University of New York, emphasizes that her copy of the address is not a government record or property at all [18].

Kathleen Clark, professor of law at Washington University in St. Louis, reasoned that the records law "is to prevent someone from depriving the government from the use of its documents," therefore Pelosi’s move "doesn’t fit within the statute," [25].

Finally, Nourse points out that "the State of the Union is a presidential record, which must go to the National Archives under the Presidential Records Act," thus Pelosi did not mutilate the record that is filed with the Archives.[24].

79af3592e7377aa46dd9e10cc1147ec7.claim: John F. Kennedy “smoked cannabis in the White House, while president, because he suffered from severe back pain and Addison's disease."""
79af3592e7377aa46dd9e10cc1147ec7.label: false
79af3592e7377aa46dd9e10cc1147ec7.passage:
0: Richard Nixon signed a law designating marijuana — along with ecstasy, heroin and LSD — a drug that has "no currently accepted medical use in the United States, a lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision and a high potential for abuse."
1: Nearly 50 years later, Tommy Chong promoted his drug of choice by invoking one of Nixon’s political rivals and predecessor as president, John F. Kennedy.
2: Chong, an actor and part of the former Cheech and Chong comedy team, made his plug for pot with a Jan. 30 post on Instagram that has more than 70,000 likes.
3: The post features a black-and-white image of Kennedy in a shirt and tie.
4: Kennedy appears to be exhaling smoke while holding perhaps a cigar of some sort.
5: Text below the image claims: "JFK SMOKED CANNABIS IN THE WHITE HOUSE, WHILE PRESIDENT, BECAUSE HE SUFFERED FROM SEVERE BACK PAIN & ADDISON'S DISEASE."
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Kennedy suffered from a number of serious ailments, including chronic back pain and Addison’s disease (which causes extreme fatigue and other symptoms).
9: He was known for trying to keep them secret.
10: He served less than three years as president before being assassinated in Dallas in 1963.
11: There’s no proof he smoked marijuana to treat his ailments.
12: We asked historians and consulted the history books.
13: A 1998 book on Mary Meyer, one of Kennedy’s mistresses, recounted a 1976 National Enquirer story that said Meyer and Kennedy smoked marijuana once at the White House.
14: The information in the article was attributed to the late Jim Pruitt, who by then was a former Washington Post editor, who said Meyer told him about the encounter.
15: The Washington Post reported on the Enquirer article at the time.
16: According to the Post, Pruitt confirmed his account about the marijuana smoking, said he had given the marijuana to Meyer, and he said the Enquirer had paid him for the story.
17: But none of that goes to the idea that Kennedy regularly used marijuana at the White House in order to fight his ailments.
18: Stacey Flores Chandler, a reference archivist at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library, told us the foundation has Kennedy’s medical records from the 1950s and ‘60s as well as records of several of Kennedy's physicians.
19: "I haven't found any evidence in either the records here or in secondary sources that the president used cannabis as a treatment for any of his medical conditions," she told us.
20: Chandler also noted that historian Robert Dallek, who had access to Kennedy’s medical records, wrote about amphetamines, steroids, painkillers and other medications prescribed for Kennedy’s back and Addison’s, but made no mention of marijuana.
21: We messaged Chong’s website but didn’t get a reply.

gpt4: The claim that John F. Kennedy smoked cannabis in the White House for his severe back pain and Addison's disease is false.
Kennedy did indeed suffer from numerous health problems including chronic back pain and Addison’s disease[8].
However, there is no substantial evidence to suggest that he used cannabis as a treatment for these ailments.

In fact, a statement provided explicitly says, "I haven't found any evidence in either the records here or in secondary sources that the president used cannabis as a treatment for any of his medical conditions"[19].

Furthermore, historian Robert Dallek, who had comprehensive access to Kennedy’s medical records, has confirmed that, while Kennedy was prescribed a number of treatments including amphetamines, steroids and painkillers for his back pain and Addison’s disease, there was no reference of cannabis[20].
Lastly, assertions confirming that Kennedy smoked marijuana to alleviate his ailments lacks any concrete proof[11].

29fbefcc222c0066f6e2d917b5de9f16.claim: National polls have “never predicted who will be president from our party. Carter was in the single digits a few months before caucuses. Bill Clinton was. Obama — 20 points behind in the national polls roughly.”
29fbefcc222c0066f6e2d917b5de9f16.label: true
29fbefcc222c0066f6e2d917b5de9f16.passage:
0: A few days before Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., announced the end of his White House bid, he encouraged Iowans with whom he was campaigning to disregard polling numbers when choosing a candidate in their state’s first-in-the-nation presidential nominating precinct caucuses.
1: Booker urged his Iowa audiences to caucus Feb. 3 for candidates who inspire them.
2: "Do not make this decision based on what the polls say," Booker said at a Jan. 9 event in North Liberty, Iowa.
3: "They've never predicted who will be president from our party.
4: Carter was in the single digits a few months before caucuses.
5: Bill Clinton was.
6: Obama — 20 points behind in the national polls roughly.
7: And they all went on to be our president."
8: We found Booker’s statement to be true, because, from 1972 to 2016, fewer than half of  nonincumbent candidates who won the Democratic presidential nomination led national polls taken between November and January leading up to Iowa’s caucuses.
9: Moreover, Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama lagged behind in national polls in the months leading up to Iowa’s caucuses.
10: We reached out to the Booker campaign for comment on Booker’s statement and where he got his information from but received no response.
11: Booker suspended his campaign on Jan. 13.
12: To research the numbers, we started with 1972 because that year marked the beginning of the  Democratic Party’s modern nominating process.
13: Democratic Party members are surveyed locally and nationally to take stock of the amount of support for a presidential candidate at a snapshot of time.
14: Polling data are a determining factor in who gets to grace the party’s debate stage, which gives presidential hopefuls a platform to pitch their ideas in front of a national audience and garner support from potential campaign donors and likely voters.
15: ‘They’ve never predicted who will be president from our party’ FiveThirtyEight compiled polling data from competitive primary elections starting in 1972 , comparing the eventual nominee’s performance in the polls in the first and last halves of the calendar year to other Democratic contenders.
16: From 1972 to 2016, it showed, only three out of 10 non-incumbent Democratic nominees were ahead in national polls up to three months before Iowa’s caucuses.
17: In the last half of 1983, former Vice President Walter Mondale polled nationally at an average of 40.1 percent, leading throughout a six-month period.
18: An early top-polling Democratic nominee didn’t show up again until 2000 , when Al Gore became the Democratic nominee after polling at an average 54.8 percent.
19: Hillary Clinton had the highest pre-caucus polling numbers leading up to the 2016 caucuses, an average of 60.7 percent in the second half of 2015.
20: But while each won the party’s nomination none won the presidency.
21: University of Iowa political-science Professor Fred Boehmke wrote in an email to The Daily Iowan that too many unknowns exist to use polling numbers as a reliable predictor of nominees.
22: "So the short answer is that there is a lot of truth in what Booker says — polls won’t tell us with great confidence who the nominee will be at convention time," Boehmke said, referring to the national nominating convention.
23: "It’s not even that the polls might be wrong or poorly done.
24: It’s that lots of people haven’t made up their minds, we don’t know who will turn out for the upcoming caucuses and primaries, we don’t know who will drop out and when and where their supporters will go, and we don’t know the major campaign-relevant political events that will shape the primary."
25: David Redlawsk, a political science professor at the University of Delaware who has researched and written about Iowa’s caucuses, said current national polls are about the nomination, not the presidency.
26: "I know he's talked about people (who) became president, but you've got to get the nomination first," Redlawsk said.
27: "This isn't about, you know, head to head for November.
28: It's the nomination.
29: Because I think that's what that focus has to be."
30: In early January 1976, a national Gallup poll put Carter at 4 percent, with Hubert Humphrey in the lead at 29 percent.
31: Gallup put Bill Clinton at 17 percent, 4 percentage points behind then-California Governor Jerry Brown, in early January 1992.
32: According to December 2007 national polling data from Gallup , Obama’s poll numbers were much lower than Hillary Clinton’s before the Iowa caucuses.
33: The polls put Obama at 27 percent, with Hillary Clinton in the lead with 45 percent.

gpt4: The claim that national polls have never predicted who will be president from the Democratic party, and that candidates such as Carter, Clinton and Obama all lagged behind in national polls a few months before the caucuses, is indeed true[8][9][16].

In fact, from 1972 to 2016, fewer than half of non-incumbent candidates who won the Democratic presidential nomination led national polls taken between November and January leading up to Iowa’s caucuses[8][16].
For instance, December 2007 national polling data from Gallup placed Obama at 27 percent, significantly lower than Hillary Clinton’s 45 percent[32][33].
Similarly, in early January 1976, a national Gallup poll put Carter at 4 percent, far behind Hubert Humphrey's 29 percent[30].
Bill Clinton was also not leading; Gallup placed him at 17 percent, 4 percentage points behind then-California Governor Jerry Brown, in early January 1992[31].
Thus, as Booker suggested in his Jan. 9 event in North Liberty, Iowa, decisions about a candidate's prospects should not be made based solely on what the polls say[2].

fc50f0081c228affa3e35434decc5062.claim: a photo shows Patrick Mahomes wearing a shirt that says, “The Great State of Kansas.”
fc50f0081c228affa3e35434decc5062.label: false
fc50f0081c228affa3e35434decc5062.passage:
0: After the Kansas City Chiefs won the Super Bowl on Feb. 2, the commander-in-chief fired off a tweet that he would perhaps soon regret.
1: "Congratulations to the Kansas City Chiefs on a great game and a fantastic comeback,under immense pressure," President Donald Trump wrote.
2: "You represented the Great State of Kansas and, in fact, the entire USA, so very well.
3: Our Country is PROUD OF YOU!"
4: But the Chiefs are based in and play in Kansas City, Mo., and Trump quickly deleted the message .
5: When he tweeted again, he got their residence right.
6: "Congratulations to the Kansas City Chiefs on a great game and a fantastic comeback under immense pressure.
7: We are proud of you and the Great State of Missouri."
8: An image being shared online appears to show Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes poking fun at the president.
9: Posted on Facebook on Feb. 5 , the photo shows what looks like Mahomes wearing a shirt with the shape of the state of Missouri and the words "The Great State of Kansas."
10: This post, which has been shared more than 15,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: That’s because the image has been doctored.
13: Mahomes’ marketing agent posted the original on Feb. 3.
14: In that version, Mahomes’ shirt says "Showtime."
15: No states are pictured.
16: "Let the victory tour begin," tweeted his agent, Jacquelyn Dahl.
17: "First stop: Disney World."
18: In another photo Dahl posted, Mahomes is posing with Chewbacca.

gpt4: The claim stating that a photo shows Patrick Mahomes wearing a shirt that reads, "The Great State of Kansas" has been proven to be false.
The image in question has been manipulated and does not depict the original text on Mahomes' shirt [12].
Originally, Mahomes' shirt bore the writing "Showtime" [14].

This misinformation gained significant attention, having been shared over 15,000 times, and was flagged by Facebook in their ongoing effort to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [10].

bc57c68a9f488f359720e1c58e60f452.claim: Maxine Waters said: “I say, we knock off Trump and then, go after Pence. We have the power.”
bc57c68a9f488f359720e1c58e60f452.label: true
bc57c68a9f488f359720e1c58e60f452.passage:
0: A viral post on Facebook claims that U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters made a violence-inciting remark about President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence.
1: The image shows an image of the California Democrat standing at a podium.
2: It attributes this quote to her, saying she said it Sept. 17, 2018: "I say, we knock off Trump and then, go after Pence.
3: We have the power."
4: Below the quote, the post says: "Yes, she actually said this and then blames President Trump for inciting violence.
5: "Worth repinning!
6: Why isn’t she in jail??"
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: Waters was one of the earliest elected officials supporting impeachment of Trump, calling for it just a few months after he took office in January 2017.
10: While she didn’t make this exact comment, it appears she did say something similar, but it was in the context of impeachment, not violence.
11: Waters called for Trump’s impeachment during a September 2018 event of the National Newspaper Publishers Association, which represents African American-owned community newspapers.
12: "All I want for him and about him is to be impeached and get him out of the White House," she said, according to a Sept. 17, 2018 article by Fox News .
13: It continues to say that Waters said she would "go after" Pence if Trump were to be removed from office.
14: The article — like other websites that reported on the speech — embedded a YouTube video of her comments in the report.
15: But that video is no longer available online.
16: We searched Google and the Nexis news archives and found that the most extensive reporting about Waters’ address came from conservative websites.
17: The American Mirror, a conservative blog by Kyle Olson, reported that after Waters said, "All I want for him and about him is to be impeached and get him out of the White House!
18: "she dismissed criticism that an ousted Trump would make Pence president.
19: Then, according to the website: "Knock off the first one, and then go after the second one," she said.
20: "We have the power.
21: We have the numbers, but we’ve got to understand our power and we’ve got to use our power."
22: We reached out to the National Newspaper Publishers Association to see if we could get more information about exactly what Waters said, but the organization did not respond to our request for information.
23: Waters has made similar statements, before and since.
24: Each of them were also in the context of impeachment: Aug. 4, 2017: Interviewed on "The View" TV show, Waters had this exchange with co-host Joy Behar.
25: Behar: "Do you think Pence will be better than Trump if he were impeached?"
26: Waters: "No.
27: And when we finish with Trump we have to go and get Putin.
28: He’s next."
29: Behar: "Putin or Pence?"
30: Waters: "Uh, Pence."
31: Oct. 20, 2017: Speaking at an event for homeless LGBTQ people in honor of a man named Ali Forney: "Wow, what a moving evening this is.
32: I'm sitting here listening, watching, absorbing, thinking about Ali even though I never met him.
33: And with this kind of inspiration, I will go and take out Trump tonight."
34: (CNN published the quote based on a video that has since been removed from YouTube.)
35: In an interview four days later, Waters rejected the idea that she was vowing harm to Trump: "That's absolutely ridiculous ... that a 79-year-old grandmother who is a congresswoman and who has been in Congress and politics all these years doing any harm.
36: The only harm I might be doing to the president is I want him impeached."
37: Sept. 8, 2018: Speaking at a Democratic club event: Referring to the "highest office of the land," Waters said (starting at the 13:45 mark in the video): "I wake up in the middle of the night and all I can think about is I am going to get him."
38: About a minute later, Waters told the group that "leadership" had asked her not to say the word "impeachment" anymore.
39: "And when they say that, I say ‘impeachment, impeachment, impeachment, impeachment,’" she said to laughter.
40: Waters also said she was told that if Trump were impeached, Pence would be worse.
41: "And I said, look, one at a time.
42: You knock one down and then we’ll be ready for Pence.
43: We’ll get him, too.
44: Waters’ office did not respond to our requests for information.

gpt4: The claim that U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters made a violent suggestion about President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence, originating from a viral Facebook post, is somewhat misrepresented[0].
In context, Waters did make remarks regarding Trump and Pence, however, her comments were in relation to impeachment rather than an incitement to violence[10].
Waters made this call for Trump’s impeachment during a 2018 function of the National Newspaper Publishers Association[11].
She was quoted as saying, "All I want for him and about him is to be impeached and get him out of the White House"[12].
Also, the statement about going after Pence was mentioned in the context of him assuming office after a hypothetical impeachment of Trump[13].
Contrary to the claim of promoting violence, four days after the interview, Waters dismissed any suggestion that she was advocating for harm to befall Trump[35].
Therefore, the claim, although including some truth, is mostly a misinterpretation of Waters's actual comments.
Her statement about having the power was part of a broader comment encouraging collective action: "We have the numbers, but we’ve got to understand our power and we’ve got to use our power"[21].

86649eada9569ab20bfa686d2e922d9d.claim: “Very close to 160 million people are now working in the United States. Nobody's ever even come close to that number.”
86649eada9569ab20bfa686d2e922d9d.label: half-true
86649eada9569ab20bfa686d2e922d9d.passage:
0: President Donald Trump loves to brag about the economy.
1: Trump frequently points to economic success to make his case for re-election.
2: He did so in his State of the Union address — just as he did in his Jan. 14, 2020 visit to Milwaukee.
3: "Very close to 160 million people are now working in the United States," Trump told a crowd of supporters in Milwaukee.
4: "Nobody's ever even come close to that number."
5: The Bureau of Labor Statistics tracks a range of data including jobs, unemployment and the number of people working.
6: Trump’s statement focused on one such tool to measure the economy — but it’s one that doesn’t consider changes to the population over time.
7: How does the president’s claim rate?
8: Breaking down employment numbers Trump claimed nearly 160 million people are working in the United States.
9: When asked to back up the claim, Trump’s campaign pointed to data from the BLS’ Current Population Survey, also known as the household survey.
10: The survey, best known for producing the national unemployment rate, samples households every month to provide a snapshot of the labor force at that time.
11: The campaign specifically cited the seasonally adjusted version of the survey, which controls for changes in the market throughout the year based on seasonal events and does not show annual averages.
12: According to that measure , roughly 158.8 million people were working in December.
13: By comparison, the unadjusted data show 158.5 million people working in December, with a 2019 average of 157.5 million.
14: "Just to note, this is different from the number of jobs added (nonfarm payroll)," Trump aide Zach Parkinson said in an email.
15: "The BLS breaks down that difference here , but the short story is the employment level counts people with jobs, while nonfarm payroll counts jobs.
16: Someone with two jobs would be counted once in the employment level, but twice in nonfarm jobs, so employment level is the better measure for seeing how many people are working."
17: The household survey also includes categories of workers not counted in other BLS measures, such as those who are self-employed and work in agriculture.
18: The Trump campaign is largely correct about the difference between the household survey and the Bureau’s other tool, known as the Current Employment Statistics survey, or payroll survey.
19: Both occur monthly, but the payroll survey samples businesses to determine how many jobs are on their payroll.
20: Because this survey counts jobs, not people, someone who works at two different places will be counted twice, said Nicholas Jolly , an associate professor of economics at Marquette University.
21: That survey tallied nearly 152.4 million jobs in December 2019 when seasonally adjusted.
22: Context is key When Trump said nearly 160 million people are working in the United States, he added "nobody's ever even come close to that number."
23: The implication here is that employment is better than it’s ever been.
24: But the number Trump cites to support that claim isn’t the only — or the best — way to analyze it.
25: The U.S. population and size of the labor force have grown over time, with both at their own peak.
26: "If you look at the number of employed individuals, it is higher than it has ever been," Jolly said.
27: "That makes sense because the civilian labor force is higher than it’s ever been."
28: According to the BLS , the population of people 16 and over who are not in the Armed Forces or residing in an institution — such as a prison or nursing home — averaged 259.1 million in 2019.
29: Compare that to  101.8 million in 1947 and 189.1 million in 1990.
30: Indeed, that number has steadily increased over time.
31: The same can be said for the size of the civilian labor force, which covers people who are either working or actively seeking employment.
32: The average size of the labor force in 2019, unadjusted, was 163.5 million.
33: In 1947, it was 59.3 million.
34: When assessing the workforce, economists say it’s important to account for the overall population.
35: The BLS has a tool for that: the employment-population ratio.
36: This shows what percentage of the civilian noninstitutional population is employed.
37: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com This is where the numbers start to deviate from the trend Trump referenced.
38: According to unadjusted BLS numbers , 60.8% of the population on average was working in 2019.
39: That percentage has increased gradually since 2010, as the country began to bounce back from the recession.
40: However, BLS data show that peak employment occurred from 1998 to 2000, when the employment-population ratio sat at around 64%.
41: The numbers today are trending back that direction, Jolly said, but are not currently at historic highs.

gpt4: President Trump's statement that nearly 160 million people are working in the United States and that such a number is unprecedented is partially correct.
His claim largely aligns with December's employment figures that approximately 158.8 million people were employed in the U.S[12].
However, some denote that this is not necessarily the most effective method to evaluate the situation [24].
Context is paramount, and when Trump refers to the near 160 million employed, he implies that this is an unprecedented figure [22].
However, it's more reflective to look at the percentage of the population that is employed.
According to the unadjusted Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data, in 2019, around 60.8% of the population was employed [38].
Although current numbers are approximating those figures, they have not yet surpassed historical highs [41].
So, when it comes to the aspect of the claim referring to historic highs, this is less accurate.
Thus, the president's statement is only partially true.

daa20b87f13941328d7f7602807caf4d.claim: “We have an America where … hard-working families have flat wages.”
daa20b87f13941328d7f7602807caf4d.label: false
daa20b87f13941328d7f7602807caf4d.passage:
0: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., is concerned about the state of worker pay in the United States.
1: "Instead of building a new factory, or instead of training new workers, or starting a new product line," Warren said, many companies use their influence in Washington to rewrite laws in ways that benefit their profit line.
2: "The next thing you know, we have an America where the (gross domestic product) keeps going up, where corporate profits keep going up, where the stock market keeps going up, and where hard-working families have flat wages and rising expenses for health care, for housing, for child care, for trying to send a kid off to school," she said during a CNN town hall in New Hampshire .
3: The part that caught our ear was what Warren said about "flat wages."
4: Over the past six years, that’s not correct.
5: Wages have been rising , with a few minor and subsequently reversed dips, since the second quarter of 2014.
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com During that period, which included about three years each under Democratic President Barack Obama and Republican President Donald Trump, wages rose by 9.7% above the rate of inflation.
7: Warren’s campaign told PolitiFact that over the longer term, wages have been growing rather slowly, especially for those in the bottom half of the income spectrum.
8: On that claim, the campaign has a point.
9: For Americans in the lower part of the spectrum, income has generally outpaced inflation by only a slight margin since 1974, according to data collected by the left-of-center Economic Policy Institute shows inflation-adjusted data for wages going back to 1973.
10: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com However, it’s worth noting that wage statistics do not include other types of income, including payments from programs like Social Security, food stamps, or refunds from the earned-income tax credit.
11: So working Americans’ actual income flows may be higher than is indicated by their wages alone.
12: "What Sen. Warren says with respect to real wages is frequently said by political leaders, but it is incorrect," said Gary Burtless, a Brookings Institution economist.
13: "Real median earnings have been rising for more than a half decade, even if it may not feel that way to some wage earners whose wages have flatlined or even trended down over that period."

gpt4: The claim that American hard-working families have flat wages is not accurate.
Over the past six years, this claim does not hold true[4].
In fact, wages have been rising without significant setbacks since the second quarter of 2014 [5].

There was a substantial increase during the span of three years under both the administrations of Democratic President Barack Obama and Republican President Donald Trump, where wages rose by 9.7% above the rate of inflation [6].
Moreover, it's believed that the actual income of working Americans could potentially be higher than what's indicated by their salaries alone[11].

98ab4759c8dea464ab6915ab524f3e46.claim: Patrick Mahomes said, “I believe George Zimmerman is innocent.”
98ab4759c8dea464ab6915ab524f3e46.label: false
98ab4759c8dea464ab6915ab524f3e46.passage:
0: Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes led his team on Feb. 2 to its first Super Bowl victory in 50 years.
1: But before the big game, Twitter users called out the NFL star for an old tweet about George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who was acquitted of criminal charges on July 13, 2013, in the fatal shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin.
2: The Miami Herald reported that Mahomes was 17 when he responded to a high school classmate’s tweet that day about Zimmerman’s trial.
3: The classmate’s tweet said: "This case was an absolutely horrible tragedy, however there was no criminal activity that occurred."
4: Mahomes replied: "No one knows what actually happens which is why he is not guilty but a crime could have occurred."
5: Twitter users shared that tweet and another screenshot of a tweet from 2011 , in which Mahomes responded to another account and said: "stop resisting or assaulting a cop #realcops."
6: As the Herald documents, Twitter users started using the tweets, which have since been deleted, as evidence that Mahomes supports Zimmerman.
7: But a Jan. 14 blog post on MTONews.com goes further with this headline: "NFL Star Patrick Mahomes: ‘I believe George Zimmerman is INNOCENT’!!"
8: It goes on to say that Mahomes believes Zimmerman is not guilty and that he supports the trial’s verdict.
9: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: Searching social media and news archives, we couldn’t find evidence that Mahomes ever said, "I believe George Zimmerman is innocent."
12: Because the blog’s headline puts that phrase in quotes, it could lead readers to think that Mahomes made that direct comment.
13: But even if the statement is meant to be an interpretation of what Mahomes tweeted back in 2013, his tweets are ambivalent enough that they do not make it clear how the quarterback felt.
14: Other tweets from Mahomes’ exchange with his high school classmate show him saying "there was no reason for Zimmerman to follow him and Trayvon just defended himself and Zimmerman had a (gun) so he shot him" and "I still don’t understand what the point of him following him with a (gun) was."
15: Another tweet he published that day suggests he was disappointed by the verdict and critical of Zimmerman.
16: "Knew this was going to happen," he tweeted, "at least you know Zimmerman will never be able to go in public again."

gpt4: The claim asserting that Patrick Mahomes declared, "I believe George Zimmerman is innocent" is false.
A comprehensive search through social media and news archives failed to provide any evidence to support this statement[11].
If the claim is inferred from tweets made by Mahomes in 2013, the content of the tweets were ambiguous enough to leave his stance on the issue unclear[13].
Further examination of his Twitter exchange with a high school classmate indicated he had questions about the incident, doubting Zimmerman's decision to follow Trayvon Martin with a firearm[14].
Another tweet from the same day insinuates Mahomes may have been disappointed with the court verdict and critical of Zimmerman [15].

3d78d7c58c187406d5d1f8eace5186cd.claim: it shows a “DNC Group” teaching “ILLEGAL VOTING in Arizona.”
3d78d7c58c187406d5d1f8eace5186cd.label: false
3d78d7c58c187406d5d1f8eace5186cd.passage:
0: With Democratic primary elections starting, a secretly recorded video is spreading misinformation about voter fraud.
1: The video, uploaded to YouTube on Jan. 22, is titled "LEAKED: DNC Group teaches ILLEGAL VOTING in Arizona."
2: It shows two men pretending to be undocumented immigrants as they approach a Democratic activist at a Women’s March rally in Phoenix, Ariz., on Jan. 19.
3: The video caption reads: "After asking the organization's co-founder, Richard Gooding, about how to vote as non-citizens, asking if they ‘support illegals,’ the staffer told our undercover journalists how they could sneak around voter laws and vote as non-citizens in federal elections!"
4: The video was flagged by VineSight , a company that uses artificial intelligence to flag misinformation on social media.
5: We also found the video on Twitter and Facebook .
6: The "undercover journalists" in the video, Joe Basrawi and Josh Aminov , are college students and conservative activists for Turning Point USA, a group that supports limited government and free markets.
7: The YouTube video is similar to clips from Project Veritas, an investigative outlet run by conservative activist James O’Keefe.
8: Project Veritas has a history of using undercover reporting , hidden cameras and selectively edited videos.
9: With that in mind, we wanted to take a closer look at what was said during the video.
10: We found that Gooding’s comments were misconstrued to play into a common conspiracy theory about voter fraud.
11: What Gooding said The shaky video lasts nearly four minutes.
12: It shows a booth at an outdoor event.
13: No one’s face is visible.
14: Over the course of the recording, Basrawi and Aminov repeatedly question Gooding about how they can vote illegally.
15: At four points, Gooding tells them that they must be citizens to vote.
16: Here’s everything that Gooding, co-founder of the liberal grassroots organization AZ Blue 2020, said in response: Aminov: "I like Democrat but I come here illegally.
17: Can I register?"
18: Gooding: "No, you can’t."
19: … Gooding: (to Basrawi) "Are you registered to vote?"
20: Basrawi: "No."
21: Gooding: "How old are you?"
22: Basrawi: "21."
23: Gooding: "Are you a U.S.
24: citizen?"
25: Basrawi: "Not yet."
26: Gooding: "OK. Are you going to get your naturalization?"
27: Basrawi: "Maybe.
28: I don’t know."
29: Gooding: "Well, when you do, if you do that, they actually have people there that will register you to vote, but you have to be a U.S. citizen and over 18."
30: Basrawi: "Oh."
31: … Basrawi: "I’m from the Middle East.
32: I came here to study."
33: Gooding: "Where at?
34: Where are you at school?"
35: Basrawi: "Over at ASU.
36: I want to vote to get Trump out of office."
37: Gooding: "You have to get your citizenship to vote."
38: Basrawi: "I have to get my citizenship.
39: There’s no way for me to vote?"
40: Then the camera shuts off and is replaced by some distorted audio that claims to be the same interaction.
41: In it, Gooding tells Basrawi and Aminov that, for them to vote, they’d have to "tell me you’re a citizen when you’re not."
42: Gooding: "You can go to the Secretary of State’s office, and ask them for a federal form because they don’t verify your citizenship."
43: Basrawi: "And I can register to vote?"
44: Gooding: "Yes, but you’re going to have to check the box that says you’re a citizen.
45: I mean you would, and it’s illegal, but …" When Basrawi and Aminov press him on the comment, asking if it’s a "big deal" or if they would get deported, Gooding says: "I have no idea."
46: Aminov: "I want to support party."
47: Gooding: "Yeah, I know.
48: Really the best thing to do is to become a citizen."
49: When the two men continue to press Gooding on the voter registration form, he clarifies.
50: Aminov: "Tuesday we can come, we register to vote and we don’t need citizen."
51: Gooding: "Well, there’s a federal form, and they don’t check your citizenship.
52: So you illegally registered to vote."
53: Then the video shuts off again.
54: AZ Blue 2020 The video is misleading on several fronts.
55: First, AZ Blue 2020, the group that Gooding belongs to, is not part of the Democratic National Committee.
56: A public Facebook group for AZ Blue 2020 describes itself as "an independent organization of energized volunteers who want to make a difference.
57: Our goal is to elect Democrats at every level to create a Democratic governance in Arizona by 2020."
58: RELATED FACT-CHECK: Did 3 million undocumented immigrants vote in the 2016 election?
59: The organization’s mission is to "empower and prepare the grassroots members of the Democratic Party, the Precinct committeepersons."
60: Gooding told PolitiFact that AZ Blue 2020 does not have a connection to the DNC, which oversees the national efforts of the Democratic Party.
61: "We are a AZ State PAC and an Indivisible group," he said, referring to a progressive movement that launched after Trump’s election.
62: In a phone call, Basrawi conceded that AZ Blue 2020 is not a DNC group but stood by the video’s assertion that Gooding was teaching "illegal voting."
63: Non-citizen voting in Arizona During the YouTube video, Gooding repeatedly told Aminov and Basrawi that, if they want to vote in the federal election, they should become citizens.
64: He said it’s illegal to register as a citizen if you’re not.
65: What Gooding was describing in the video about a federal form is an Arizona quirk: the state accepts voter registration forms from people who don’t provide proof of citizenship, such as a valid driver’s license, birth certificate, passport or naturalization documents.
66: But they can only vote in federal elections, they have to attest to their citizenship when they register, and they must bring a valid photo ID to their polling place.
67: "A person is not required to submit proof of citizenship with the voter registration form, but failure to do so means the person will only be eligible to vote in federal elections (known as being a ‘federal only’ voter)," the Arizona secretary of state’s website reads .
68: "A ‘federal only’ voter will become eligible to vote a ‘full ballot’ in all federal, state, county and local elections if he or she later provides valid proof of citizenship to the appropriate County Recorder’s office."
69: If federal-only voters lie about their citizenship on Arizona’s voter registration form , they are subject to prosecution, said C. Murphy Hebert, director of communications for the Arizona secretary of state.
70: The federal voter registration form also asks about applicants’ citizenship status.
71: Respondents must check either yes or no, under penalty of perjury.
72: RELATED: Report about potential Iowa voter fraud is false "We never use the federal form and have never registered a voter using the federal voter registration form, because we could be registering non-citizens," Gooding told PolitiFact in an email.
73: "My error was sharing that information with those with an ulterior motive."
74: Undocumented immigrants sometimes end up registered to vote after getting a driver’s license or state ID card.
75: The Arizona Republic has reported on efforts by state elections departments to verify voters’ citizenship.
76: Officials in Maricopa County, where Phoenix is located, told the newspaper that "instances of non-citizens or undocumented immigrants attempting to register, let alone casting ballots, are extremely rare."
77: According to a database maintained by the conservative Heritage Foundation, there have been 20 confirmed instances of voter fraud in Arizona dating back to 2009.

gpt4: The claim that a "DNC Group" was teaching "ILLEGAL VOTING in Arizona" is false[10].

The video, identified as the primary source of this claim, shows "undercover journalists" Joe Basrawi and Josh Aminov, who are college students and conservative activists for Turning Point USA, pretending to be undocumented immigrants approaching a Democratic activist at a Women’s March rally in Phoenix[2][6].
The activist, a member of AZ Blue 2020, was questioned about how they could vote illegally, to which he repeatedly reiterated that one must be a citizen to vote[14][15].
Neither the activist nor AZ Blue 2020, however, have a direct connection to the Democratic National Committee, both facts supported by statements from the activist himself and Basrawi[55][60][62].

Furthermore, it was noted that illegal voting in Arizona, or attempts by non-citizens or undocumented immigrants to register to vote, is extremely rare, with just 20 confirmed instances of voter fraud in Arizona dating back to 2009[76][77].
Thus, any assertion that the activist was promoting "illegal voting" is not supported by the evidence.

f4bc79b0f94a5a31515637894b02fc95.claim: the USMCA is the “biggest trade deal ever made.”
f4bc79b0f94a5a31515637894b02fc95.label: false
f4bc79b0f94a5a31515637894b02fc95.passage:
0: President Donald Trump touted the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, as the "biggest trade deal ever made" shortly after signing it into law.
1: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com His tweet built on past claims that the USMCA is the "largest," "most significant," "modern" and "balanced" trade agreement.
2: The revised agreement mostly updates NAFTA, which has been in place since 1994 and was previously the largest U.S. trade deal ever signed.
3: The USMCA adds significant changes for the auto industry and implements new policies on intellectual property protection, the Canadian dairy market, and labor and environmental standards.
4: Trump overreaches by calling it the "biggest trade deal ever made."
5: For one, it’s not a trade agreement from scratch; it’s building off of NAFTA.
6: And two, this neglects larger trade pacts across the world.
7: In 2018, the European Union signed a trade agreement with Japan, covering a quarter of the global economy and 600 million people.
8: Although the Trans-Pacific Partnership never came into force, it included the same three USMCA partners –– the United States, Canada and Mexico –– as well as nine other Pacific Rim countries and would have represented nations with 40% of global gross domestic product.
9: Trump withdrew the United States from the pact his first week in office.
10: Then there is the mammoth 1994 Uruguay Round trade talks, which included the United States and 122 other countries, kicking off the World Trade Organization.
11: The initial membership of the WTO "accounted for more than 90% of international trade in goods and services," found the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.
12: The WTO now has more than 160 members, including China.
13: Trump’s campaign pointed us to evidence that shows how substantial the USMCA is for the United States alone.
14: The latest International Trade Administration data shows that total U.S. trade with Canada and Mexico (under NAFTA) is the largest of any U.S. free trade partners.
15: As a percentage of total trade, Canada and Mexico account for about 30% of U.S. goods exports and imports, according to a 2019 Census Bureau report on top trading partners.

gpt4: The claim that the USMCA is the "biggest trade deal ever made" is false.
While the USMCA does revise and update NAFTA, a significant U.S. trade deal that was enacted in 1994, it is not the largest in history[2].
This perspective fails to acknowledge other substantial global trade pacts[6].
For instance, in 2018, the European Union signed a formidable trade agreement with Japan.
This agreement covers a quarter of the global economy and affects 600 million people, marking a significant milestone in global trade history[7].

21d39bb31aec7318d685040dbe6a09db.claim: a video proves Pelosi “was planning” to rip up President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address “from the start.”
21d39bb31aec7318d685040dbe6a09db.label: false
21d39bb31aec7318d685040dbe6a09db.passage:
0: One of the most viral moments of President Donald Trump’s 2020 State of the Union address was when House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., publicly tore up a copy of his speech.
1: Republicans called her actions after the speech disrespectful, Democrats celebrated her ripping Trump on national TV.
2: Others engaged in a playground-like "he started it!"
3: pointing out Trump did not shake her hand at the outset of the speech.
4: Now a conservative journalist says her tear was premeditated before Trump started his address.
5: "Here's Pelosi testing to see if she could rip the speech before the speech even started," tweeted Brandon Morse , a senior editor at RedState, on Feb. 5.
6: "She was planning to do it from the start."
7: (He credited a Reddit user for the video .)
8: Two hours later, Morse tweeted a follow-up : "I need to make a correction.
9: Pelosi actually divided the papers into piles and tested them before ripping them.
10: This exact moment caught here occurred not before Trump's speech began, but 50 minutes into it."
11: (His article about the video got a correction , too.)
12: Morse’s initial tweet drew about 40,000 likes or retweets while his "correction" tweet drew less than 2,000 likes or retweets by noon the next day.
13: So we wanted to set the record straight about his initial message.
14: We attempted to reach Morse but did not hear back.
15: RELATED: Charlie Kirk wrongly suggests Pelosi broke law by ripping Trump State of the Union speech RELATED: Fact-checking Donald Trump's 2020 State of the Union address Timing the tear The video clip that Morse tweeted shows Pelosi turning over the pages of Trump’s speech, but part of her actions are underneath a table and not fully in view.
16: Based on the video alone, we can’t say what she was doing.
17: Pelosi has indicated her decision came later on in the address.
18: "He didn’t want to shake hands, That meant nothing to me, that had nothing to do with my tearing up —  that came much later," she said at the weekly press conference Feb. 6.
19: Pelosi said she started reading ahead.
20: "I just went right through that thing so I knew what was coming.
21: When I saw the compilation of falsehoods, when I heard the first quarter or third then I started to think there has to be something that clearly indicates to the American people that this is not the truth and he has shredded the truth in his speech, he is shredding the Constitution in his conduct, I shredded his ‘state of his mind’ address."
22: That’s consistent with what was reported as telling Democrats in a closed-door meeting the day after the State of the Union.
23: Those news reports are based on anonymous Democratic aides or people who attended the meeting.
24: The Hill quoted Pelosi as calling herself a "speed reader" who could not let what she saw as a "pack of lies" stand.
25: "So, somewhere along the way, realizing what was coming, I started to stack my papers in a way that were tear-able," the Hill quoted her as saying.
26: ABC News and Reuters had similar accounts, and Pelosi spokesman Drew Hammill  said the quotes are accurate.
27: Morse’s article mentions The Hill report and then argues that "she clearly planned to rip the speech before she even knew what was in it."
28: The New York Post showed photos that appeared to show tiny tears on the edges of Pelosi’s paper copy.
29: The Post showed an 18-second clip of Pelosi and said she "pre-ripped."
30: But this moment was about 46 minutes into his speech when Trump was talking about Rush Limbaugh, not at the start.
31: Here’s our take after watching Trump’s speech on C-SPAN : The camera was focused on Trump and sometimes the audience, so it doesn’t show Pelosi during every second of his roughly 80-minute speech.
32: Pelosi was seated and her hands aren’t always fully visible.
33: Pelosi sometimes flipped through the papers, appearing to read parts of it.
34: Based on the video of Pelosi, we can't say when she had a thought to rip up his speech.

gpt4: The claim that a video proves Pelosi planned to rip up President Donald Trump's State of the Union address from the start is false.

While a tweet from conservative journalist Brandon Morse suggested that Pelosi was testing to see if she could rip the speech before it started [5], it is imperative to note that the exact moment caught was not at the beginning of Trump's speech, but instead about 50 minutes into it [10].
Similarly to this, Pelosi reportedly began planning to tear up the speech during the discourse but was not plotting to do so from the outset[25].

According to Pelosi herself, the decision to rip the speech was a response to a compilation of falsehoods and the shredding of the constitution by the President that she noticed while the speech was well-underway [21].
Furthermore, Pelosi mentioned during a February 6 weekly press conference that then-President Trump's refusal to shake her hand had no role to play in her decision to tear up his speech [18].
She also clarified that this decision came much later during the speech [17].
In fact, one notable moment where Pelosi appeared to prepare for tearing up the speech occurred around 46 minutes into the address when Trump was discussing Rush Limbaugh [30].
Therefore, the claim that Pelosi had premeditated the tear from the start is incoherent and inconsistent with the evidence [4].

5eeefeedeaac812ef1c2e4dbd8bdd8ab.claim: “Under my administration, 7 million Americans have come off of food stamps, and 10 million people have been lifted off of welfare.”
5eeefeedeaac812ef1c2e4dbd8bdd8ab.label: half-true
5eeefeedeaac812ef1c2e4dbd8bdd8ab.passage:
0: In his third State of the Union address, President Trump claimed that since he took office: "7 million Americans have come off of food stamps and 10 million have been lifted off of welfare."
1: There is some data to back him up when it comes to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, also known as SNAP, but our analysis found that the data is flawed.
2: In addition, we could not substantiate his claim that 10 million people have been lifted from welfare.
3: SNAP figures are trending downward, but data is incomplete There are around 7 million fewer Americans participating in SNAP, sometimes called food stamps, than when Trump entered the White House, according to figures from the Department of Agriculture.
4: The program provides "nutritional assistance" to people with low incomes or disabilities.
5: That’s what the data shows, but there are some issues.
6: The real number is likely a bit lower due to two things: A data reporting problem in North Carolina and a reporting discrepancy from the 2018-19 government shutdown.
7: SNAP participation numbers by state show there are no North Carolina recipients being accounted for from October 2017 through all of 2019, dragging down the national average of recipients.
8: (In 2018, the News and Observer reported that North Carolina's food stamp numbers were too good to be true.)
9: During the winter 2019 government shutdown, the federal government asked states to issue double the amount of SNAP benefits in January so enrollees would not miss their  February benefits if the shutdown continued.
10: (It lasted from Dec. 22, 2018, to Jan. 25, 2019.)
11: Because of this, numbers for January 2019 are consistent with the number of people receiving food stamps in prior months.
12: But February 2019’s numbers show a huge drop, which also drags down the average.
13: With all this being accounted for, the number of reductions may be closer to 6 million.
14: Also, SNAP participation was falling since before Trump took office, a trend that experts say is likely due to a growing economy.
15: Participation in the program usually follows along with the official poverty rate, which has been falling since 2010 .
16: Meanwhile, the administration finalized a rule in late 2019 that tightens guidelines on who can receive benefits and for how long.
17: The changes are expected to move more "able-bodied" adults into the workforce, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue said in a news release .
18: The rule was projected to end benefits for about 700,000 people.
19: RELATED: Fact-checking Donald Trump's 2020 State of the Union address Unclear where Trump derives his ‘welfare’ numbers Trump’s claim that 10 million people were lifted "off of welfare" doesn’t add up.
20: We didn’t hear back from the White House when we asked about this claim.
21: One key problem is that "welfare" is an imprecise term.
22: Besides SNAP, we reviewed the federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program and its Separate State Maintenance of Effort.
23: Under TANF, the federal government provides a block grant to states, which use the funds to operate their own assistance programs.
24: When Trump took office in January 2017, there were about 3.68 million recipients of these programs combined.
25: In June 2019, that number dropped by about 825,000 to 2.85 million.
26: The Center for Law and Social Policy , an advocacy organization for low-income people, told us it’s hard to determine how Trump arrived at the 10 million number.
27: Elizabeth Lower-Basch, director of the organization’s income and work supports team, said it couldn’t be the TANF caseloads, as those numbers are much too low.
28: "It’s possible the administration could get to 10 million by combining reductions in TANF with reductions in the use of Medicaid, the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP, or food stamps), but we haven’t seen any published data that show this figure," Lower-Basch wrote in an email.
29: Most people think of "welfare" as a program for people who are not working, Lower-Basch said.
30: In that respect, Medicaid, CHIP and SNAP don’t necessarily fit into that category as the vast majority of people who are getting these types of benefits are children , seniors, or working adults .

gpt4: While President Trump's assertion that "7 million Americans have come off of food stamps, and 10 million people have been lifted off of welfare" is partly supported by data[1], it also contains some inaccuracies and imprecisions[21].

First, data from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), colloquially known as food stamps, shows a downward trend; around 7 million fewer Americans are participating in SNAP since Trumpassumed presidency[3].
However, this data has flaws and inconsistencies[1].

SNAP participation has been falling even before Trump's inauguration, likely due to a growing economy[14], and the participation rate usually aligns with the official poverty rate, which has been decreasing since 2010[15].
Certain states' figures, such as North Carolina, were not accounted for from October 2017 to 2019, which ostensibly drags down the national average of recipients[7].
Additionally, a significant drop in SNAP’s numbers was recorded in February 2019, resulting in a lower average[12].
Considering these factors, the real reduction in SNAP participants could possibly be around 6 million, rather than the 7 million asserted by Trump[13][6].

As for the claim of lifting 10 million people off welfare, the term "welfare" is ambiguous; this analysis considered federal programs alike SNAP and the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program.
The total number of recipients for these programs declined by around 825,000 between January 2017 and June 2019, a figure considerably lower than the 10 million stated by Trump[24][25][22].

Advocates at the Center for Law and Social Policy suggest reaching the cited number might involve counting reductions in other programs like Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program, but there is no published data that corroborates this[28][26].

886aba09483e9ebc675ae83644331d31.claim: “Chinese people eat human baby soup to improve health.”
886aba09483e9ebc675ae83644331d31.label: false
886aba09483e9ebc675ae83644331d31.passage:
0: With the world focused on a coronavirus outbreak that appears to have started in Wuhan, China, some social media posts are now spreading falsehoods about Chinese culture.
1: One viral post being shared on Facebook builds on xenophobic stereotypes: "Chinese people eat human baby soup to improve health" reads the headline.
2: The Jan. 30 post, which had been viewed on Facebook more than 46 million times as of Feb. 10, features images of a man seated at a table preparing to eat what appear to be parts of a baby.
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: These pictures are from a 20-year-old controversial work of performance art.
6: The post links to an undated article on b4blaze.in, an India-based website that says its "aim is to promote creative thoughts, Ideas online which are yet to be discovered and deserves recognition."
7: The article carries essentially the same headline as the post as well as more gruesome images that include a hand grasping what appears to be an infant by its arms and legs.
8: The article attributes the claim to "an email report received by The Seoul Times," and describes a town "in the southern province of Canton (Guangdong)" where "Chinese folks there are enjoying baby herbal soup to increase overall health and stamina and the power of sexual performance in particular" at a price tag of $4,000 U.S.
9: This article also appears on the website of The Seoul Times, an English-language newspaper, under the heading "Letters to the Editor."
10: But there is no evidence to back this claim.
11: The photos with the post are from Chinese performance artist Zhu Yu.
12: He staged a performance called "Eating People" at a Shanghai arts festival in 2000.
13: The photos showed Zhu Yu appearing to eat a stillborn or aborted child.
14: AFP Fact Check on Feb. 6 debunked another Facebook post that uses a photo from the exhibit.
15: It also reported that images from the exhibit have been used in hoax reports about cannibalism in China.
16: What’s more, experts we spoke to described such cannibalism rumors as ridiculous and misguided.
17: "This sounds like complete bull----.
18: And if it is true, I’ve certainly never heard of it," William Schutt wrote to us in an email.
19: He is a professor of biology at Long Island University, research associate at the American Museum of Natural History and author of the 2017 book, "Cannibalism: A Perfectly Natural History."
20: He Bian, a China historian at Princeton University, was more direct: "It’s misinformation at the most malign level," she said.
21: "Medical traditions in both Europe and China had records of consuming human body parts, ranging from hair, urine, to semi-magical use of human remains.
22: It seems to me (the post) is a malicious manipulation of this fact to make a sweeping racist statement in the present tense, which is categorically false."
23: Fabio Lanza, a professor of modern Chinese history at the University of Arizona, agreed.
24: "Blood libel has a long and sordid history in China, one that does not seem to ever end," he said.

gpt4: The claim that Chinese people eat human baby soup to improve health is false[10].
It appears to stem from misconstrued interpretations of images from a Jan. 30 Facebook post, which has been viewed more than 46 million times[2].
The images in the post show Chinese performance artist Zhu Yu seemingly preparing to consume parts of a baby[11].

These pictures indeed create shock, but they are actually from a 20-year-old controversial piece of performance art titled "Eating People," which was performed at a Shanghai arts festival in 2000[5][12].
The experts we consulted deemed such cannibalism rumors as ridiculous and completely misguided[16].

a4304e1145377990adb9bc12460d4935.claim: Joe Biden’s campaign told an Iowa library where Jill Biden was holding an event “to remove the American flag as they did not want to say the pledge of allegiance.”
a4304e1145377990adb9bc12460d4935.label: false
a4304e1145377990adb9bc12460d4935.passage:
0: On Jan. 24, before the Iowa Democratic presidential caucuses, Jill Biden, the wife of former Vice President Joe Biden, held a meet-and-greet at a library in Corning, Iowa.
1: Soon after, allegations about the Bidens’ patriotism appeared on social media.
2: Folks began sharing a screenshot of a Facebook post that claims the Biden campaign clashed with library staff over an American flag.
3: "This happened in my hometown this week in Iowa.
4: It makes me so sad," reads the screenshot, which we found being shared on Feb. 2.
5: "Joe Biden’s wife stopped in town at the library this week.
6: The library staff was told to remove the American flag as they did not want to say the pledge of allegiance.
7: The librarian refused so the campaign people went out and took it down themselves!
8: Now explain to me why someone representing her husband running for President of the United States would do this?"
9: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: We reached out to the person who wrote the original post — the one that people are sharing the screenshot of — but we didn’t hear back.
12: And it appears the original post recounting the flag flap has been removed from public view.
13: We also reached out to Joe Biden.
14: In a statement, his campaign told us that before Jill Biden went to the Corning Public Library , a campaign staff member arrived and saw that the American flag in the conference room reserved for the meet-and-greet "was not properly dressed."
15: In this case, according to the campaign, it wasn’t draped correctly .
16: "Out of respect for the flag — because it could not be dressed properly in time for the event — the staff member asked the library if they were comfortable moving it to another room.
17: The library staff member then moved the flag out of the room.
18: In no way did this have anything to do with the pledge of allegiance and in no way did a directive come from Dr. (Jill) Biden.
19: This is pure misinformation swirling around Facebook.
20: The Bidens are a military family.
21: Any insinuation they would somehow disrespect the flag — or our veterans — is shameful and categorically false."
22: We called the library, which referred us to Corning Mayor Janice Mercer Leonard.
23: Leonard told us that she had heard several different accounts of what happened at the library, though she was not there to witness it herself.
24: Leonard said one of the librarians told her that Jill Biden’s staff arrived at the library before the event and wanted to remove the flag from the conference room, where it was hanging on a stand in the corner.
25: "I heard two different stories," Leonard said.
26: "One was the advance staff asked to remove it and one story was they weren’t asked and just went ahead and set up the room the way they wanted to set up the room."
27: The flag was relocated to the hallway, she said.
28: "What possible reason could there be to remove the flag?"
29: she asked.
30: She heard two explanations from people she said attended the meet-and-greet but who did not see the room being set up.
31: One person told Leonard that "they didn’t want to say the pledge of allegiance," she said, and another told her that there was a smudge on the flag.
32: In a letter to the editor , Leonard pointedly questioned why the Biden campaign removed the flag.
33: "Did you think you were going to have such a large turnout that you needed that two foot space in the corner where the flag was located?"
34: she wrote.
35: "Was this just a stop to check off little Adams County so you could say you visited all 99 counties?"
36: Snopes, which also looked into this claim , spoke with Fred Shearer, president of the library board in Corning.
37: Shearer said the campaign rented the room and arranged it themselves, moving the flag "probably 5 feet into a hallway next to the room," according to Snopes.

gpt4: The claim stating that Joe Biden's campaign directed an Iowa library to remove the American flag since they did not want to say the pledge of allegiance is false.
The incident appears to have begun after a screenshot of a Facebook post making this claim was circulated[2].
However, upon investigation, we learnt that a staff member of Biden's campaign did indeed interact with the library staff about the American flag.

Before Jill Biden's meet-and-greet at the Corning Public Library, a campaign staff member noticed that the American flag in the room reserved for the event was not properly dressed or draped correctly [14][15].
Out of respect and because the flag could not be properly arranged in time, they asked the library staff if they were comfortable moving it to a different room [16].
The library staff agreed and moved the flag [17].
This action did not have any connection with the pledge of allegiance and there was no directive from Jill Biden about this[18].
The library board president, Fred Shearer, also corroborated this version of events [36].

cd0aa7881b18be55923e2ad3b7da445c.claim: a video shows a fox allowing itself “to feed koala babies in Australia.”
cd0aa7881b18be55923e2ad3b7da445c.label: false
cd0aa7881b18be55923e2ad3b7da445c.passage:
0: "This is motherhood," reads the description of a recent YouTube video claiming to show a fox feeding baby koalas in Australia.
1: But people commenting on the clip, posted by an account called "Lets Make it Viral LMIV," weren’t buying it.
2: "ROFL," one person wrote.
3: "Those are fox pups, and, no koala is going to get milk like that."
4: "Reported for being fake," someone else said.
5: The video, which has been viewed thousands of times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: That’s because they’re foxes, not koalas.
8: Wildlife photographer Luc Durocher posted the video on Facebook in December 2014.
9: He posted it again on Jan. 28 , after Snopes reported that it contacted him about the miscaptioned video on YouTube.
10: This time, he was more specific in his description of the video.
11: "The young are thirsty," he wrote in French.
12: "Red foxes."
13: He places the video in a park in Montreal, Canada.
14: In another video of red foxes suckling that Durocher posted on YouTube in 2014, you can more clearly see their faces — and there’s no confusing them for koalas.
