gpt4: The claim that a video shows a fox feeding koala babies in Australia is false.
The widely shared video, posted by an account called "Lets Make it Viral LMIV," drew skepticism from people who viewed it, as they were not convinced by what they saw [1].
Critics argue that the animals shown in the video are not koalas; instead, they're foxes [7].
Further evidence dispelling the claim comes from another video that the same individual posted in 2014.
In this older content, viewers can clearly see the face of red foxes, which are unmistakably different from those of koalas [14].
Adding to the inconsistency, the video was recorded in a park located in Montreal, Canada, rather than Australia, countering the original claim [13].

8cb94213e60ae007ee35838e3f700bd0.claim: ""I thought it was a terrible thing when (Nancy Pelosi) ripped up the speech. First of all, it's an official document. You're not allowed. It's illegal what she did. She broke the law."""
8cb94213e60ae007ee35838e3f700bd0.label: false
8cb94213e60ae007ee35838e3f700bd0.passage:
0: President Donald Trump repeated a false claim about House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., telling reporters on the White House lawn that Pelosi "broke the law" when she ripped up her copy of his State of the Union address.
1: "I thought it was a terrible thing when she ripped up the speech," Trump said.
2: "First of all, it's an official document.
3: You're not allowed.
4: It's illegal what she did.
5: She broke the law."
6: "It’s so disrespectful to our country," he added.
7: "And actually, very illegal, what she did."
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We fact-checked a similar claim when Turning Point USA founder Charlie Kirk first floated it on Twitter .
9: Legal experts told us Pelosi was in the clear.
10: The papers she tore up were not the official record of Trump’s speech, nor were they the only copy in existence.
11: "I take it that this is a printout of the Trump speech, in which case it is absurd to suggest that Pelosi can be prosecuted for doing with it whatever she pleases," said Heidi Kitrosser, professor of law at University of Minnesota.
12: Since our fact-check of Kirk, Snopes and other news outlets have also concluded that Pelosi did not violate the law.
13: So has Jonathan Turley , the George Washington University law professor who testified against impeaching Trump in the House Judiciary Committee.
14: Even Fox News host Laura Ingraham, whose on-air commentary is typically pro-Trump, knocked the idea in an interview with Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., who filed an ethics complaint against Pelosi.
15: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The federal statute in question sets a penalty for anyone who "conceals, removes, mutilates, obliterates, or destroys" any government record "filed or deposited with any clerk or officer of any court of the United States, or in any public office, or with any judicial or public officer of the United States."
16: The statute also says that any person with "custody" of a government record cannot "willfully and unlawfully" conceal, remove, mutilate, obliterate, falsify or destroy it.
17: "The point of the statute is to prevent people from destroying records in official repositories like the National Archives or in courts," said Georgetown Law professor Victoria Nourse.
18: Experts told us Pelosi’s move was not illegal because her copy of Trump’s speech wasn’t the official government record that would need to be preserved.
19: The State of the Union text was never "filed or deposited" with her, nor did she have "custody" of it in the legal sense.
20: Trump handed her and Vice President Mike Pence copies before he began speaking.
21: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com President Donald Trump hands copies of his State of the Union address to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Vice President Mike Pence before delivering it to Congress on Feb. 4, 2020, in Washington.
22: (AP) "Her copy of the State of the Union address is not a government record or government property at all," Douglas Cox, professor of law at the City University of New York School of Law and an expert in the laws on the preservation of government records, told us.
23: "It is personal property."
24: Under House rules , members of Congress are encouraged to preserve their records or donate them to a research institution for historical study, Cox said.
25: Unlike congressional committees , members are not legally required to hold onto their office’s files.
26: "They can keep them private, they can destroy them, or they can rip them up," he said.
27: RELATED: No evidence Pelosi planned to tear Trump’s State of the Union speech at start This is in contrast to presidential records, which have been considered government property since the Presidential Records Act of 1978 and are supposed to be stored with the National Archives for safekeeping.
28: "The State of the Union is a presidential record, which must go to the National Archives under the Presidential Records Act," Nourse said "(Pelosi) did not mutilate the record that is filed with the Archives."
29: There are probably countless copies of Trump’s address, such as the version the White House posted online.
30: Pelosi’s action did not preclude future generations from accessing one.
31: "If the statute were not read this way, then any copy of the State of the Union held by anyone could never be destroyed," Nourse said.
32: The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi broke the law by tearing up papers containing Trump's speech is false.
The assertion was dismissed by legal experts who clarified that Pelosi had not engaged in any illegal activity [9].
They explained that the papers she destroyed were not the official record of Trump's speech nor were they the only copy in existence [10][29].
Additionally, Pelosi's copy wasn't a government-issued document that required preservation, thus her actions fell within legal boundaries [18].
Renowned law professor Douglas Cox from the City University of New York explained that Pelosi's copy of the State of the Union address did not qualify as a government record or property [22].

Reiterating this, it was clarified that the State of the Union is a Presidential record, and must be forwarded to the National Archives under the Presidential Records Act, a responsibility Pelosi did not violate [28].

3fcdfc398602066dea3a66baf7bcc449.claim: San Antonio has “the lowest per capita income of any major Texas city.”
3fcdfc398602066dea3a66baf7bcc449.label: half-true
3fcdfc398602066dea3a66baf7bcc449.passage:
0: During a meeting with the San Antonio City Council, former mayor Henry Cisneros made a pitch for a new transportation plan that emphasizes roads over public mass transit.
1: Cisneros, who served as secretary of Housing and Urban Development under President Bill Clinton, highlighted the need for more money to go toward transportation and explained how this kind of investment could transform the city.
2: "We are a poor city," Cisneros said of San Antonio.
3: "We have the lowest per capita income of any major Texas city."
4: We ran the numbers, and the latest figures show that San Antonio has a lower per capita income than some, but not all, of the state’s most populous cities.
5: Cisneros did not return a request for comment seeking clarification on his definition of a major Texas city.
6: To be clear: there is no universal definition of a major city, so we looked at Texas cities with a population estimate of at least 500,000 in 2018.
7: Census figures show rankings To check this claim, we looked at yearly estimates of per capita income from the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.
8: Per capita income is "the mean income computed for every man, woman, and child in a particular group," according to the Census Bureau.
9: In this case, those groups are Texas cities.
10: The per capita income is calculated by "dividing the aggregate income of a particular group by the total population in that group."
11: The final figure is rounded to the nearest whole dollar.
12: In 2018, the per capita income in Texas was $30,641.
13: In the United States, it was $33,831.
14: Looking at individual Texas cities reveals a wide range of values, from $65,743 in The Woodlands, a master planned community north of Houston, to $15,369 in Pharr, a city on the Texas-Mexico border east of McAllen.
15: In San Antonio, per capita income in 2018 was $24,684.
16: San Antonio is the second most populous city in the state (1.5 million), preceded by Houston (2.3 million) and followed in order by Dallas (1.3 million), Austin (964,254), Fort Worth (895,008) and El Paso (840,758), according to 2018 population figures.
17: Here’s the per capita income in 2018 in these cities, presented from highest to lowest: Austin: $42,923 Houston: $31,162 Fort Worth: $29,010 Dallas: $27,729 San Antonio: $24,684 El Paso: $22,777 An analysis of the rankings of these cities each year from 2010 through 2018 shows that San Antonio is low on the list, followed by El Paso.
18: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Another way to assess income in a community is to look at median household income or median family income.
19: Median household income includes the income of the householder and anyone else living in the home over 15 years old.
20: This figure is different than median family income, according to the Census Bureau: "Because many households consist of only one person, average household income is usually less than average family income."
21: Median family income looks at incomes of "all members 15 years old and over related to the householder."
22: In 2018, the median household income in San Antonio was $49,024, lower than all of the six most populous Texas cities besides El Paso ($45,031).
23: San Antonio’s median family income was $60,689 in 2018, a higher figure than Dallas ($58,835), Houston ($56,693) and El Paso ($50,245).
24: Poverty in San Antonio Cisneros made this claim after stating that San Antonio is "a poor city," so we also looked at poverty data available from the Census Bureau for the 10 most populous cities in the state.
25: In 2018 in San Antonio, about 19% of its population was living below the poverty line — more than any of the other cities with populations over 500,000.
26: Take at look at each city and the percent of its population below the poverty line, ordered from highest to lowest: San Antonio: 19% Houston: 18.2% El Paso: 18.1% Dallas: 15.7% Fort Worth: 13.5% Austin: 12.5% Another factor worth mentioning here is cost of living.
27: San Antonio may be among the cities with the lowest per capita income, but the cost of living is also on the lower end.
28: The Economic Policy Institute‘s Family Budget Map shows an estimated cost of living for a two-parent, two-child family in counties across the state.

gpt4: The claim stating that San Antonio has "the lowest per capita income of any major Texas city" is only half-true.

With a population of 1.5 million, San Antonio is the second most populous city in Texas according to the 2018 population figures, coming after Houston and Dallas but before Austin, Fort Worth, and El Paso[16].
If we rank the cities based on their per capita income, then San Antonio doesn't fare as poorly as the claim suggests.
As of 2018, the per capita income in San Antonio was reported to be $24,684[15].
While it is true that San Antonio has a lower per capita income than some of the state's most populous cities, it isn't the lowest[4].
This indicates that although San Antonio experiences economic challenges, it doesn't necessarily have the lowest per capita income among major cities in Texas as the initial statement implies[3].

d27c67b80d67d2074cf52c7bcf6141ae.claim: William Barr tweeted, “BREAKING NEWS Senator Mitt Romney is the only Republican Senator who voted to remove President Trump from office… IN A COMPLETELY UNRELATED STORY Senator Mitt Romney is also the only Republican Senator who has a son who sits on the board of a Ukrainian Energy Company.”
d27c67b80d67d2074cf52c7bcf6141ae.label: false
d27c67b80d67d2074cf52c7bcf6141ae.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Mitt Romney was the only Republcan to vote to convict President Donald Trump of abuse of power.
1: Attorney General William Barr appeared to acknowledge that on Twitter on Feb. 5, at least if you saw this Facebook post .
2: The Feb. 6 post features a screenshot of tweet from "A.G. William Barr," whose Twitter handle is @AGWilliamBarr.
3: "BREAKING NEWS," the Feb. 5 tweet says, "Senator Mitt Romney is the only Republican Senator who voted to remove President Trump from office… IN A COMPLETELY UNRELATED STORY Senator Mitt Romney is also the only Republican Senator who has a son who sits on the board of a Ukrainian Energy Company."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The tweet is real , but the account doesn’t belong to Barr.
7: What’s not clear from the Facebook post is that @AGWilliamBarr is a parody account .
8: "The Official PARODY Account of the Attorney General with the USA," the Twitter bio says.
9: "Followed by Corn Pop, Blocked by Pierre Delecto & RT’d by Right Wing Conspiracy Theorists."
10: As for whether Romney has a son on the board of a "Ukrainian Energy Company," we’ve already fact-checked that .
11: There’s no evidence any of his sons have served on the board of any energy company with ties to Ukraine.

gpt4: The claim that William Barr tweeted about Senator Mitt Romney voting to remove President Trump from office and his son sitting on a Ukrainian energy company's board is false.

The tweet referenced in the claim was actually made by a parody account under the handle @AGWilliamBarr, not the official account of the Attorney General, according to a February 6th post featuring a screenshot of the tweet[2][8].
The report confirms that the tweet exists, but the account does not, in fact, belong to Barr[6], and furthermore, it is important to note that this Twitter account is flagged as a parody account[7].

dedfd06ec00b86a90417aec111fce87f.claim: Mitt Romney’s father “U.S. Senator George Romney, was a liberal Republican who had ties to Saul Alinsky, yes, the same dude who wrote the book, Rules For Radicals and dedicated to Satan.”
dedfd06ec00b86a90417aec111fce87f.label: false
dedfd06ec00b86a90417aec111fce87f.passage:
0: After U.S. Sen. Mitt Romney cast the lone Republican vote in favor of impeaching President Donald Trump, viral news about the Utah politician flooded Facebook.
1: One post zeroed in on his dad: "You see, his father, U.S.
2: Senator George Romney, was a liberal Republican who had ties to Saul Alinsky, yes, the same dude who wrote the book, Rules For Radicals and dedicated to Satan," states the Feb. 6 post.
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The post wrongly called George Romney a U.S. senator — he was governor of Michigan between 1963 and 1969.
6: (The author of the post later changed the wording to call George Romney a politician.)
7: Gov.
8: Romney was known as a moderate who was sometimes at odds with his Republican Party.
9: In 1969, he was appointed by President Richard Nixon as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
10: A spokeswoman for Sen. Mitt Romney declined to comment.
11: George Romney met with Alinsky in the 1960s We found that Gov.
12: Romney did meet with Alinksy, a famous liberal community organizer, in 1967 .
13: That’s not much of a tie.
14: Nor is there much to the claim that Alinsky dedicated a book to Satan.
15: Alinsky only mentioned Lucifer in one paragraph of his book.
16: Alinsky was a Chicago community organizer who wrote the 1971 book " Rules for Radicals: A Practical Primer for Realistic Radicals ."
17: The book offers advice to activists seeking to influence public policy, covering topics such as class differences and tactics such as disrupting meetings and winning media attention.
18: Alinksy didn’t dedicate his book to Satan.
19: The word "dedication" isn’t included in the intro — though he does have a "personal acknowledgments" section where Alinsky listed his wife and editors.
20: However, Alinsky did indeed include an opening blurb on Lucifer, attributed to Alinsky himself.
21: The epigraph is one of three; the other two quote Rabbi Hillel and philosopher Thomas Paine.
22: "Lest we forget at least an over-the-shoulder acknowledgment to the very first radical: from all our legends, mythology, and history (and who is to know where mythology leaves off and history begins — or which is which), the first radical known to man who rebelled against the establishment and did it so effectively that he at least won his own kingdom — Lucifer.
23: — SAUL ALINSKY" His point seems to be acknowledging Lucifer in a figurative sense, rather than advocacy for satanism.
24: The rest of the book includes no real discussion of Lucifer or Satan, though it does talk about the way people demonize political opponents so that others see their opponents as "devils."
25: As we noted, Mitt Romney’s father George Romney did meet with Alinsky.
26: BuzzFeed reported that after the 1967 riots in Detroit, Romney met with Alinksy to discuss the grievances of the urban poor.
27: The Library of Congress preserved photos of Alinsky meeting with black community organizers as well as meeting with Romney .
28: T. George Harris's 1968 book Romney’s Way quoted Romney saying to his "reluctant white friends": "I think you ought to listen to Alinsky.
29: It seems to me that we are always talking to the same people.
30: Maybe the time has come to hear new voices," he said.

gpt4: The claim that George Romney, the father of Mitt Romney, who is inaccurately referred to as a U.S. Senator, had ties to Saul Alinsky, is false.
George Romney was not a U.S. Senator, but rather he served as the governor of Michigan between 1963 and 1969[5].
While it's true that George Romney did meet with Saul Alinsky in 1967, such a meeting does not constitute a solid or significant tie between the two[12][13].
Furthermore, the part of the claim purporting that Alinsky dedicated his book, "Rules For Radicals", to Satan is also incorrect.
Although Alinsky refers to Lucifer in his book, this appears to be a figurative acknowledgment rather than an actual dedication to Satan or an endorsement of Satanism[18][23].

01630cce10f88c316eef89303fd05ee7.claim: with his guilty impeachment vote, Senator Mitt Romney “could be removed from office.”
01630cce10f88c316eef89303fd05ee7.label: false
01630cce10f88c316eef89303fd05ee7.passage:
0: Utah Sen. Mitt Romney cast the only Republican vote to convict president Donald Trump in the impeachment trial – marking the first time in U.S. history a senator voted to convict a president of the same party.
1: Trump was acquitted on both charges, but that didn’t stop Romney’s vote from making him a top target of misinformation online.
2: One viral blog post circulating on Facebook claims that Romney could be removed from office over his vote.
3: Its headline reads: "#RecallMitt Movement: With His ‘Guilty’ Vote, Mitt Romney Could Be Removed From Office."
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The headline makes it appear as if his vote alone could have him removed.
7: That’s not true.
8: The body of the post goes into specifics about a state measure introduced in Utah that would allow voters to recall their senators.
9: It’s a proposal and not official law.
10: "As Mitt Romney grandstands in the U.S Senate’s doomed Trump impeachment trial in an effort to demonstrate his own moral superiority, the Utah legislature is mulling a measure that would allow the state’s citizens to recall their senators.
11: The measure could hypothetically be used to recall Romney from office."
12: The bill, HB217 was introduced on Jan. 29 by Rep. Tim Quinn and would create a system where Utah voters could set up a "recall election to remove senators."
13: Quinn maintains that the bill’s timing is coincidence and has nothing to do with Romney.
14: He told Utah public radio station KPCW that the bill stems from constituents’ concerns with the 17th amendment, which established the six-year term for U.S. senators.
15: The measure says 25% of "active voters" (Utahns who voted in the last two elections) would have to sign a petition requesting a recall vote.
16: Senators could not be recalled within the first year of their term or within a year of the end of their term.
17: But, if passed, the bill would likely face a constitutional challenge.
18: Some states have recall provisions for state offices such as governor, attorney general or state representatives, but the U.S. Constitution doesn’t provide for the recall of federally elected officials.

gpt4: The claim that Senator Mitt Romney “could be removed from office” over his guilty impeachment vote is false[2].

This misconception might have been precipitated by a viral blog post on Facebook, which discussed a state measure proposed in Utah that could potentially permit voters to recall their senators [2][8].
However, it's worth noting that this is merely a proposal and has not been officially made into a law [9].
Even if this bill were to pass, it would most likely be met with a constitutional challenge [17].

While it's true that some states do have recall provisions for state offices such as governor, attorney general or state representatives, the U.S. Constitution does not provide the same provisions for federally elected officials like Senators [18].
Therefore, the premise of Romney being removed from his senatorial office over his impeachment vote is factually incorrect.

790338470273516d29e29640d761faf2.claim: Nancy Pelosi said, “If the Senate conducts a sham trial, our caucus will just impeach the president again. We have no shortage of impeachment offenses. This president is a criminal.”
790338470273516d29e29640d761faf2.label: false
790338470273516d29e29640d761faf2.passage:
0: The Senate acquitted President Donald Trump of charges of abuse of power and obstruction on Feb. 5, but an old Facebook post suggests he could soon face another impeachment trial.
1: The Jan. 19 post has this quote over a photo of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi: "If the Senate conducts a sham trial, our caucus will just impeach the president again.
2: We have no shortage of impeachment offenses.
3: This president is a criminal."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: Searching online and on the Nexis news archive we found no evidence that Pelosi said that.
7: And while Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., warned that Trump would "continue to try to cheat" if the Senate didn’t convict  him, it doesn’t appear that Pelosi vowed to impeach him again.
8: On Dec. 23, Politico reported that lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee said in a court filing that the House could impeach Trump again if it discovers new evidence that Trump tried to obstruct investigations into his actions.
9: But as this Feb. 6 Washington Post analysis notes , it could be too risky for the Democrats to try again.
10: "The political cost of being seen as relentlessly trying to get the president out of office, especially as the election ticks closer, is just too high," the story says.

gpt4: Upon examination of the claim that Nancy Pelosi stated, "If the Senate conducts a sham trial, our caucus will just impeach the president again.
We have no shortage of impeachment offenses.
This president is a criminal," there is no confirmed evidence to substantiate it.
In-depth searches through both digital and Nexis news archives reveal no instance where Pelosi made such a statement [6].

While it is documented that Representative Adam Schiff, D-Calif., warned about the possibility of Trump attempting to cheat if not convicted by the Senate, there is no recorded utterance from Pelosi promising to impeach the president again [7].
Therefore, the claim is false.

0ab42d5bdaae288e987498995737f55b.claim: North Carolina's Democratic primary is open to ""all registered voters, regardless of registration."""
0ab42d5bdaae288e987498995737f55b.label: false
0ab42d5bdaae288e987498995737f55b.passage:
0: Former New York mayor Mike Bloomberg is trying to boost election participation in North Carolina.
1: But a recent piece of campaign mail offers misleading information about who can vote in North Carolina’s primaries.
2: Bloomberg, who entered the presidential race late, has spent millions of dollars on television ads in an attempt to compete with other Democratic candidates such as Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and others.
3: In the letter obtained by WRAL, Bloomberg criticizes President Donald Trump for creating "chaos" while in office -- and asks the recipient for her support.
4: Bloomberg then closes the letter with this line: "P.S.
5: North Carolina election law allows all registered voters, regardless of registration, to vote in the Democratic Primary."
6: The letter was first reported by The Richmond Observer .
7: So is it true that any registered voter can vote in any party’s primary?
8: No.
9: Semi-closed primary North Carolina has what’s known as a "semi-closed" primary, according to the NC board of elections .
10: This means that anybody who is registered with a specific party can only vote in that party’s primary.
11: Unaffiliated voters can also participate in one party’s primary election -- but only if that party opens its doors to those voters.
12: In North Carolina, political parties aren’t required to open their primaries.
13: Each of North Carolina’s recognized parties has until the first day of December to inform the NC elections board whether it wants to open its primary.
14: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com This year, the Democratic, Republican and Libertarian parties will have open primaries, according to the elections board.
15: In other words: if you are registered as an unaffiliated voter in North Carolina, you can participate in one of their primaries.
16: Meanwhile, the Constitution and Green parties are closed -- meaning you have to be registered with those parties to participate.
17: A follow-up letter It’s unclear how many letters the Bloomberg campaign sent in North Carolina.
18: LaToya Evans, a spokeswoman for Bloomberg, told us that the campaign is working to rectify the situation.
19: "Last week, the campaign sent a letter introducing Mike Bloomberg and his record targeted at Democrats and unaffiliated voters in North Carolina," Evans said in a Feb. 4 email.
20: "These voters can show up on election day and vote in the Democratic primary.
21: We are sending a follow up mailer to those who received the letter to clarify how they can participate in the upcoming primary.
22: We regret any confusion this may have caused."
23: In the meantime, the NC elections board is hoping voters will rely only on official government communications for information.
24: "We always encourage people to rely on county and state elections boards and their materials for reliable information about elections," board spokesman Pat Gannon told PolitiFact.

gpt4: The claim that North Carolina's Democratic primary is open to ""all registered voters, regardless of registration" is false.
This claim has been debunked by a recent piece of campaign mail, offering misleading information about who can vote in North Carolina’s primaries[1].
The North Carolina board of elections states that the state employs a "semi-closed" primary system[9].
This system restricts voting in a party’s primary to only those who are registered with that specific party[10].
Although unaffiliated voters are permitted to participate in one party’s primary, it is only possible if that party chooses to open its doors to those voters[11].
However, political parties in North Carolina are not obligated to open their primaries[12].

Albeit in this year, the Democratic, Republican, and Libertarian parties have decided to have open primaries[14], the Constitution and Green parties have maintained closed primaries and require voters to be registered members in order to participate in their primaries[16].
Therefore, the claim that North Carolina's Democratic primary is open to all registered voters, regardless of registration, is misleading and inaccurate.

f5994385065bb1918fa8f11dc3234755.claim: Mitt Romney voted against convicting President Donald Trump because Burisma board member Joseph Cofer Black “is Romney’s national security advisor” and because of ties to Obama CIA director John Brennan.
f5994385065bb1918fa8f11dc3234755.label: false
f5994385065bb1918fa8f11dc3234755.passage:
0: After Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, joined all Senate Democrats in voting to convict President Donald Trump on an article of impeachment, he became a target of social media ire from Trump allies.
1: One example is a Jan. 31 Facebook post by the Committee to Defend the President , a pro-Trump political action committee that says on its Facebook page, "The Crooked Media has shown us time and time again that they can not be trusted, we will defend him!"
2: The post, which was shared about 8,000 times, features photographs of Romney and two former CIA officials, Joseph Cofer Black and John Brennan.
3: It says: "If you don’t know who the guy in the middle (Black) is, you had better get up to speed, and fast.
4: Joseph Cofer Black is Romney’s national security advisor.
5: He also currently sits on the board of Burisma holdings.
6: JCB joined the CIA in 1974, and was the head of their counter-terrorism center during the 9/11 terror attacks.
7: John Brennan was the CIA station chief in Saudi Arabia who approved the sketchy visas for the 9/11 attackers.
8: He followed JCB as the head of CIA’s counter-terrorism.
9: And this is just scratching the surface of their relationships."
10: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: We found that the post sprinkles a few facts — and a few erroneous assertions — into an unsupported claim.
13: We’ll take the elements one by one.
14: Claim: "Joseph Cofer Black is Romney’s national security advisor."
15: While Joseph Cofer Black has advised Romney in the past, he is not currently his "national security advisor," Romney’s office confirmed.
16: Black served as director of the CIA’s Counterterrorism Center from 1999 to 2002 and as U.S. ambassador-at-large for counterterrorism from 2002 to 2004.
17: Since then, he’s worked in the private sector, including a stint as vice chairman of Blackwater, a controversial security contractor.
18: Black’s relationship with Romney came primarily during Romney’s two presidential campaigns.
19: Black served as senior adviser for counterterrorism and national security on Romney's 2008 presidential campaign , then served as a special adviser for national security and foreign policy on Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign .
20: The 2012 campaign team assembled dozens of foreign policy experts from the party, as is typical for both Republican and Democratic presidential candidates.
21: Claim: Black "currently sits on the board of Burisma holdings."
22: This appears to be correct, according to the Ukranian energy company’s website .
23: When we checked it on Feb. 7, 2020, Black was listed as a director of the company.
24: (The company’s press office did not respond to an inquiry.)
25: In fact, at one point, Black served on the board at the same time as Hunter Biden — the son of former Vice President Joe Biden who became a target of President Donald Trump and whose service on Burisma’s board inspired the actions that led to Trump’s impeachment.
26: Here’s an archived version of the company’s website in 2017, showing both Biden and Black.
27: In a news release about Black’s hiring in 2017, Black is quoted saying, "I was impressed to learn that Burisma Group is the fastest-growing private gas producer in Central Europe.
28: International projects where the Group is involved require a more thorough analysis and risk assessment, not only in terms of conventional risks — financial or political but also in terms of security."
29: Claim: Black was the "head" of the CIA’s "counter-terrorism center during the 9/11 attacks."
30: That’s correct.
31: As the Daily Beast noted in 2012, then-CIA chief George Tenet wrote that after the 9/11 attacks, Black insisted on staying at his office with his staff in a relatively exposed area of the CIA headquarters, rather than moving to a safer location.
32: "Well, they could die," Tenet recalls telling Black about his staff.
33: Black responded, "Well sir, then they are just going to have to die."
34: Claim: "John Brennan was the CIA station chief in Saudi Arabia who approved the sketchy visas for the 9/11 attackers."
35: This is false.
36: First, the CIA does not handle visas — the State Department does.
37: The congressionally authorized 9/11 report went into detail about how each of the plot participants secured their visas.
38: "Individual consular officers (were) involved with the adjudication of visas to the hijackers," the report said .
39: Second, during the time that Brennan was posted in Saudi Arabia, only a few of the visas were granted to the plotters (and not all of the terrorists got their visas in Saudi Arabia).
40: Shortly after the plot quietly went into motion in 1999, President George W. Bush tapped Brennan to serve as chief of staff to Tenet at CIA headquarters, so Brennan was in the United States for most of the time the attack’s planning was underway.
41: He was named the CIA’s deputy executive director in 2001, serving through 2003.
42: "He never approved a single U.S. visa," said Nick Shapiro, a spokesman for Brennan.
43: Claim: Brennan followed Black "as the head of CIA’s counter-terrorism."
44: This is false, although similar names have tripped up some non-experts.
45: Black was head of the CIA’s counter-terrorism center, commonly known as CTC, from 1999 to 2002.
46: The center is a part of the CIA.
47: Brennan, by contrast, was named by Bush as interim director of the National Counterterrorism Center, an inter-agency group under the umbrella of the Director of National Intelligence.
48: Brennan served in the post from 2004 to 2005.
49: Claim: Brennan has been close to Romney.
50: This is ironic, since during the 2012 presidential campaign, Black was working on behalf of Romney, the Republican challenger, while Brennan was working in the administration of the incumbent, President Barack Obama.
51: The 2012 Daily Beast article specifically pairs the two as combatants.
52: Black, the article said, was Romney’s "trusted man inside the intel community," while Brennan’s role for Obama in the administration was "so powerful that many senior spies complain that Brennan is the de facto CIA chief."
53: (He would later be named CIA director by Obama.)
54: "I am not aware of any connection between Gov.
55: Romney and John Brennan, nor can I imagine any, since Brennan was with Obama," Andrew Natsios, a professor at Texas A&M’s Bush School of Government and Public Service, told PolitiFact.
56: Natsios is also a former administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development who served on the same 2012 Romney advisory panel as Black did.
57: That said, times have changed in the Trump era, as Brennan has praised Romney for his stance on impeachment.
58: In October, Brennan tweeted , "How many other Republican Senators are ready to show the courage, integrity, & principled position of Senator Romney?
59: Thank you, Senator, for putting our Nation & our Constitution above party politics & the corrupt behavior of Donald Trump."
60: The implication: Romney voted to convict Trump in order to protect Black.
61: Foreign policy experts said it is unlikely that Romney was thinking of protecting an adviser from eight years ago when weighing one of the most important votes he would ever cast in the Senate.
62: Romney laid out his reasoning for voting to convict in his widely noted Senate floor speech .
63: "Given that in neither the case of the father nor the son was any evidence presented by the president’s counsel that a crime had been committed, the president’s insistence that they be investigated by the Ukrainians is hard to explain other than as a political pursuit," Romney said.
64: He continued: "The grave question the Constitution tasks senators to answer is whether the President committed an act so extreme and egregious that it rises to the level of a "high crime and misdemeanor.
65: Yes, he did."
66: The Committee to Defend the President did not respond to an inquiry for this article.

gpt4: The claim that Mitt Romney voted against convicting President Donald Trump because Burisma board member Joseph Cofer Black “is Romney’s national security advisor” and because of ties to Obama CIA director John Brennan is false[35][44].
While Joseph Cofer Black did advise Romney in the past, he is not currently Romney's "national security advisor," as confirmed by Romney’s office [15].
Furthermore, any alleged connection between Romney and John Brennan was refuted by Andrew Natsios, a professor at Texas A&M’s Bush School of Government and Public Service [55].
Foreign policy experts also mentioned that it would be unlikely for Romney to consider preserving an eight-year-old advisory tie when casting such a critical Senate vote [61].

25bfc6da7cef99cd9c45d6f8c207ea76.claim: ""Donald Trump sued the City of Palm Beach when he bought a segregated club, Mar A Lago, to open it to Jews & Blacks."""
25bfc6da7cef99cd9c45d6f8c207ea76.label: false
25bfc6da7cef99cd9c45d6f8c207ea76.passage:
0: A years-old pro-Trump Facebook post that’s still viral shows a photo of a young Donald Trump with the headline: "So You Think You Know The Real Donald Trump?"
1: The post claims that Trump did good deeds for five individuals, and it makes a claim of one larger gesture, saying: "Donald Trump sued the City of Palm Beach when he bought a segregated club, Mar A Lago, to open it to Jews & Blacks."
2: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Trump did accept African Americans and Jews at Mar-a-Lago at a time when most private clubs in Palm Beach, Fla., were not open to them.
5: But it was a business move, not a crusade, and he did not sue in court to do so.
6: Reviewing history Here’s what happened, based on reports from the Washington Post, the Wall Street Journal, Vanity Fair and other media.
7: Mar-a-Lago (in Spanish, sea-to-lake) was a mansion built by cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post in 1927.
8: Trump bought the 128-room, 20-acre estate and its furnishings in 1985, for $9 million .
9: Trump used Mar-a-Lago as a private residence until 1995, when he turned it into a private club, open to anyone who could afford the $100,000 initiation fee.
10: That made his club different from other Palm Beach clubs (only one was open to Jews).
11: Trump’s club was the first to accept African Americans and openly gay couples, according to the Washington Post.
12: Trump lawyer Paul Rampell eventually persuaded Trump of the business value of wider membership by arguing that Palm Beach had many Jewish residents but they had no real club of their own, Laurence Leamer wrote in his book, "Mar-a-Lago: Inside the Gates of Power at Donald Trump’s Presidential Palace."
13: So, what about a lawsuit?
14: Before making Mar-a-Lago a private club, Trump originally wanted to subdivide the land and sell mansions on it.
15: After a year of meetings and hearings, the Palm Beach Town Council voted down the project.
16: After Trump sued the town for $50 million, the town approved the club (the lawsuit was settled), but with restrictions to limit traffic and noise.
17: Trump didn’t invoke African Americans and Jews until he tried to get those restrictions lifted.
18: In December 1996, when the town council refused, he sued , alleging that the town was discriminating against Mar-a-Lago, in part because it was open to Jews and African Americans.
19: The town denied the allegation, saying it was merely deciding a zoning matter.
20: In any case, the lawsuit was not about opening the club to Jews and African Americans; it was already open to them.

gpt4: The claim that Donald Trump sued the City of Palm Beach to open Mar A Lago to African Americans and Jews is incorrect.

While it is true that Trump accepted African American and Jewish members at Mar-a-Lago at a time when it was uncommon for private clubs in Palm Beach, Florida to do so[4], this was not due to a lawsuit against the city.

In actuality, Trump's club was the first to accept African Americans and openly gay couples[11], but this was a business decision, not a legal crusade, and he did not sue in court to effect the change[5].
Trump did file a lawsuit against the town, but this was to dispute restrictions that were put in place to limit traffic and noise after the town approved the club[16].
Interestingly, he invoked the inclusion of African Americans and Jews not in his initial legal action, but later, when he attempted to get those restrictions lifted[17].
The original lawsuit was not about opening the club to Jews and African Americans, as the club was already open to them[20].

a3e4b29c36e0f5a00c3cb8b6e6d2a22f.claim: “Epstein’s recruiter Ghislaine Maxwell’s father Robert Maxwell gave Mitt Romney his first $2M investment and started him in business.”
a3e4b29c36e0f5a00c3cb8b6e6d2a22f.label: false
a3e4b29c36e0f5a00c3cb8b6e6d2a22f.passage:
0: Before Sen. Mitt Romney made history as the lone Republican to vote to convict President Donald Trump at Trump’s impeachment trial, he became the target of social media smears.
1: One attack linked the Utah senator to Ghislaine Maxwell, the woman who allegedly recruited girls and young women for Jeffrey Epstein to sexually abuse.
2: The Jan. 29 post is a screengrab of what appears to be a news story or blog post featuring a photo of Maxwell.
3: It reads, in all-caps: "Epstein’s recruiter Ghislaine Maxwell’s father Robert Maxwell gave Mitt Romney his first $2M investment and started him in business."
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The claim has an element of truth, but is misleading.
7: The body of Robert Maxwell, a British publishing baron, was found floating in the Atlantic after he went missing off his private yacht in November 1991 and the circumstances have remained mysterious.
8: He was an early investor in Romney’s first investment fund at the Bain Capital firm, which was pivotal in Romney’s later political career.
9: But Romney had already established himself in business by the time Robert Maxwell gave him money — and Maxwell’s investment was not the first in the fund.
10: The Epstein connection Epstein, a disgraced financier, was accused of sexually abusing and trafficking underage girls.
11: He committed suicide by hanging himself in a New York City jail cell Aug. 10.
12: Ghislaine Maxwell, a British socialite, is the Oxford-educated daughter of Robert Maxwell.
13: Her father's business empire collapsed following his death, according to ABC News, which did a series on Epstein.
14: Ghislaine Maxwell moved to New York and became Epstein’s girlfriend.
15: Her whereabouts are unknown.
16: Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly helped recruit girls for Epstein and is being sued, along with Epstein’s estate, by three women who say they were among the victims.
17: The Romney connection The post we’re checking shows a headline from an article on JohnBWellsNews.com, whose slogan is "Making The News Great Again."
18: That article links to a July 2012 article in The Telegraph, a London-based news organization.
19: The Telegraph reported that after Romney set up the Boston consulting firm Bain Capital in 1984, Robert Maxwell invested $2 million in Romney's first private equity fund, a fund that "launched (Romney’s) controversial career in finance."
20: The same day, the Los Angeles Times reported that the fund had been seeded with $12 million from Bain partners and that Maxwell’s $2 million was one of the early, but certainly not the first, outside investments.
21: After Maxwell’s death, investigators discovered Maxwell had stolen hundreds of millions of dollars from his company's pension funds.
22: Romney’s fund was invested in startup companies and leveraged buyouts.
23: It paid out an average of 173% in average annual returns over a decade and was the "start of the private equity powerhouse that ultimately fueled Romney’s political career," the Times said.
24: Romney was established in business before starting the fund.
25: He worked for two years at the Boston Consulting Group and six years at the Bain & Company consulting firm before co-founding the new firm-within-a-firm, Bain Capital, in 1984.

gpt4: The claim that Robert Maxwell, Ghislaine Maxwell's father, provided Mitt Romney with his initial investment of $2 million and started him in business is false.
Mitt Romney was already established in the business world by the time Robert Maxwell invested in Romney's fund[24][9].
Maxwell did invest $2 million in Romney's first private equity fund at the Bain Capital firm, but that fund had been seeded prior to Maxwell's investment with $12 million from Bain partners[19][20].
This suggests that Robert Maxwell was one of the early investors, but not the instigator of Romney's business enterprise[20].
Furthermore, Maxwell's investment was not crucial to Romney's later political career, as Romney had previously founded the influential investment fund at Bain Capital[8].

a2686d3489b31f42666d907705f827bf.claim: George Soros was an “SS in the National Socialist German Workers Party. Nazi Party.”
a2686d3489b31f42666d907705f827bf.label: false
a2686d3489b31f42666d907705f827bf.passage:
0: A viral image purporting to link George Soros to Germany’s Nazi Party is picking up new steam on social media.
1: But the photo of a young man wearing glasses and an SS uniform is not the billionaire Democratic donor, despite what some posts would have you believe.
2: "I give you George Soros," the text stamped over the image, which was originally posted to Facebook in 2016 , says.
3: "A(n) SS in the National Socialist German Workers Party.
4: Nazi Party.
5: He served under Adolf Hitler and Heinrich Himmler."
6: The post, which has been shared more than 22,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: We’ve fact-checked a version of the same photo before, as have reporters at Snopes and the Associated Press .
9: The photo isn’t fake or doctored, but it also doesn’t show Soros, despite what the text attached to it says.
10: A quick reverse image search reveals that much.
11: In reality, the photo is of Oskar Gröning , a former SS soldier who was sentenced to four years in prison in 2015 for being complicit in the murder of 300,000 people during the Holocaust.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A screenshot of a Facebook meme wrongly identifying Oskar Gröning as George Soros (PolitiFact).
13: The sentence was handed down when Gröning, who died in 2018, was 94 years old.
14: During the Holocaust, he was a corporal in Hitler’s Waffen SS, according to the New York Times’ obituary .
15: Soros, on the other hand, survived the Holocaust.
16: When the Nazis invaded Hungary, Soros’ father obtained a false identity for Soros and sent him to live with an agricultural official who passed him off as his Christian godson, according to the New York Times .

gpt4: The claim that asserts George Soros was a member of the National Socialist German Workers Party, more commonly known as the Nazi Party, is false.
While an image of a young man wearing glasses and dressed in an SS uniform has been linked to him, this photograph is, in fact, not of the billionaire Democratic donor [1].
The image is neither fake nor doctored, however, it has been falsely attributed to Soros[9].
The person in the photograph is actually Oskar Gröning, a former SS soldier who was sentenced to prison in 2015 for his role in the murder of 300,000 people during the Holocaust [11].
Therefore, the attribution of this image to Soros is incorrect and misleading.

03116e189c391a2ddcff0017937d7e51.claim: Paul Walker was set to come forward to expose “Clinton Foundation crimes against children in Haiti” before he was killed.
03116e189c391a2ddcff0017937d7e51.label: false
03116e189c391a2ddcff0017937d7e51.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post pushes a persistent conspiracy theory that the Clinton family murders their enemies — adding a tragic celebrity twist, again without proof.
1: Sometimes dubbed the "Clinton body count," these baseless claims say that investigators found the remains of missing women in steel barrels on Bill and Hillary Clinton’s property, and that Chelsea Clinton’s bodyguard was found dead in a river after telling "damaging information" about the family.
2: ( Here are some others that we have fact-checked.)
3: This one involves Fast & Furious star Paul Walker, who died in 2013 after the car he was riding in crashed at a speed of more than 100 mph and burst into flames.
4: Both Walker and the driver, Roger Rodas, were pronounced dead at the scene The Facebook post displays a black-and-white image of Walker and says: "Nov 30th 2013, his car hit a tree and caught fire.
5: The video however, looks more like an explosion.
6: He was set to come forward exposing the Clinton Foundations crimes against children in Haiti.
7: He discovered this through his charity work."
8: It also shares a link to this one-minute YouTube video that appears to show footage of the crash from beyond a set of trees.
9: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: Outside of vague, unsourced posts, we couldn’t find any credible details that claim Walker had evidence of wrongdoing by the Clinton Foundation.
12: The article mentions Walker’s charity work.
13: The only connection between Walker and the Clinton Foundation is that both were involved in relief efforts in Haiti.
14: The rest is speculation.
15: Walker founded the nonprofit Reach Out Worldwide after he organized a relief team to respond to the 2010 earthquake that devastated Haiti.
16: Reach Out’s website says that, while on the trip, Walker saw a need for skilled personnel in post-disaster situations and created the charity, which helps bring first responders to disaster areas.
17: There is also no evidence that the car was tampered with.
18: The Los Angeles coroner's office report found that the Porsche Carrera GT was traveling near 100 mph at the time it impacted a power pole and several trees.
19: Investigators determined that the cause of the fatal collision was "unsafe speed for the roadway conditions."
20: Walker’s daughter, Meadow, did file a wrongful death lawsuit against Porsche, claiming that the carmaker took production shortcuts that prevented her father from surviving the crash.
21: The two parties resolved the lawsuit in 2017 and kept the terms of the settlement confidential.

gpt4: The claim that Paul Walker was about to expose alleged crimes by the Clinton Foundation against children in Haiti prior to his death is false.
Although the late Fast & Furious star Paul Walker and the Clinton Foundation were both engaged in relief efforts in Haiti, this is the only known link between them[13].
Furthermore, no credible sources or details substantiate the assertion that Walker had evidence of any wrongdoing by the Clinton Foundation[11].

Walker's fatal accident in 2013, in which the car he was traveling in crashed at a speed exceeding 100 mph and caught fire[3], was investigated and deemed the result of "unsafe speed for the roadway conditions"[19], and no evidence was found that the vehicle had been tampered with[17].

0fc55c62ac111cc39495b214c65aab29.claim: ""Our new (health care) plans are up to 60% less expensive and better"" than Obamacare."
0fc55c62ac111cc39495b214c65aab29.label: false
0fc55c62ac111cc39495b214c65aab29.passage:
0: In his wide-ranging State of the Union address, President Donald Trump returned to a favorite theme: the cost of health insurance.
1: He cited the high cost of premiums for people who buy their coverage through the Affordable Care Act marketplaces and said his administration has provided new, less costly coverage.
2: "I moved quickly to provide affordable alternatives.
3: Our new plans are up to 60% less expensive and better," Trump told the lawmakers gathered at the Capitol.
4: So we wondered, to which new alternatives was he referring?
5: We reached out to the White House to ask.
6: Spokesperson Adam Kennedy responded that the president was talking about short-term, limited-duration plans.
7: But that got us thinking: Are they really less expensive and better?
8: Or simply better than nothing?
9: First, are they new?
10: They are not.
11: As background, short-term insurance plans have been around for decades in various iterations and are generally considered a stopgap solution for people between jobs or attending school.
12: They provide some protections, usually paying a percentage of hospital and doctor bills after the policyholder meets a deductible.
13: But they’ve always been a bit controversial.
14: Unlike the ACA plans now available, short-term plans can bar people with health conditions from enrolling or exclude coverage for specific conditions or treatments.
15: They also offer fewer benefits — meaning they are not required to comply with the health law’s mandated essential benefits requirement.
16: So, for example, they don’t have to cover prescription drugs, or mental health services or substance abuse treatment — and many don’t.
17: In addition, they can set annual or lifetime caps on benefits.
18: Almost all exclude maternity care.
19: If a person develops a health condition during the coverage term, insurers can look through their medical records and, in some cases, retroactively cancel the plans — or refuse to renew the coverage at the end of the policy’s term.
20: The Obama administration restricted these policies, which still cannot be sold on the ACA marketplaces and do not qualify for subsidies, to a maximum coverage period of 90 days, down from the 364 days that applied previously.
21: The Trump administration reversed that time-limit restriction in 2018 and built on it by allowing insurers to offer policies renewable for up to three years .
22: Officials, including Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar, said at the time that these short-term plans provide an alternative but aren’t a good fit for everyone.
23: For instance, the Trump rules require the policies to carry a warning that they aren’t "required to comply with federal requirements for health insurance."
24: They also state that consumers should "check the policy carefully to make sure you understand what the policy does and doesn’t cover."
25: Are these plans less expensive?
26: The White House pointed us toward a January 2019 report produced by the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation as the source for the president’s assertion that these plans are 60% less expensive.
27: It quickly becomes clear that the analysis is very wonky and complex.
28: After all, it’s not easy to project what benefits insurers will include in short-term plans or what they will charge individuals, which can vary based on their health.
29: Even the analysts called the estimating process "challenging."
30: When it came right down to it, they hedged: Short-term plans are likely cheaper than the lowest-cost ACA plan for some consumers, but more expensive for others.
31: For example, people who get a federal tax credit to buy ACA-compliant insurance or those who are older or less healthy would likely pay more in premiums for a traditional short-term plan, the analysts said.
32: Conversely, those without subsidies, especially younger or healthier consumers, might pay as much as 60% less than they would for the lowest-cost plan through the ACA, the analysis concluded.
33: Another study, not cited by the White House but done by the conservative Manhattan Institute, also listed caveats, but more robustly defended the plans as less expensive.
34: Premiums for short-term plans are lower — in some cases, almost half the cost — of ACA plans, it concluded.
35: But critics put these price tags in context.
36: "I don’t have a reason to suspect the 60% is wrong if they’re lining them up against ACA plans, but if you’re a health plan that doesn’t cover much, it’s easy enough to offer a cheap premium," said Sabrina Corlette, research professor and co-director of the Center on Health Insurance Reforms at Georgetown University.
37: So that gets to the question, are they better?
38: The consensus is that the coverage short-term plans provide is not better than that of ACA plans.
39: But it could be better than going without insurance entirely.
40: "Why not throw another option out there?"
41: said Doug Badger, senior fellow at the conservative Galen Institute.
42: "You might say this plan isn’t as good as that plan, but we may both agree that having this one is better than nothing."
43: He said that should be a decision made by consumers, who can weigh the pros and cons: "They know their circumstances and risk tolerance.".
44: Still, it’s a gamble, as no one knows what health conditions might befall them.
45: A plan that doesn’t cover prescription drugs may be fine the first month, but if a serious illness crops up, it suddenly has unexpected costs.
46: Others also note that short-term plans may have wider networks of doctors and hospitals than some ACA plans, giving consumers more options.
47: "In Texas, for example, you cannot buy an ACA plan that covers MD Anderson," the cancer center of the University of Texas, said Brian Blase, CEO of Blase Policy Strategies.
48: Blase has advised Trump on his health policy efforts.
49: "The only way you can have such a plan that includes MD Anderson — unless you have employer coverage — is in a short-term plan."
50: Again, nice to have a wide network.
51: But there’s a conundrum.
52: Someone with cancer — attracted to a network because it includes MD Anderson — would be rejected by most short-term plans.
53: That ability to reject applicants — or seriously limit coverage of their preexisting conditions — helps keep premiums down.
54: But those are also the main reasons experts say the plans are not better than those offered under the ACA, which bars such limits.
55: A preexisting condition is often defined as anything treated — or for which a "prudent person" should have sought treatment — during the previous 12 months to five years, depending on the insurer.
56: "If you have high blood pressure and, while on one of these plans, you have a heart attack, the plan could say that was a preexisting condition," said Corlette.
57: State regulation of such plans varies widely, as do the coverage benefits and limits offered by various insurers.
58: Some have limits listed in the fine print.
59: While short-term plans have been embraced by regulators in some states, nearly half of all states have moved to limit them to less than 12 months.
60: Four — California, Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York — have barred them altogether.
61: Those states cite concerns about the effect on ACA premiums and the risk that consumers could be left hanging by the more limited nature of the short-term plans.

gpt4: The claim that the new health care plans are up to 60% less expensive and better than Obamacare is false.

The claim was based on a January 2019 report produced by the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation, which according to the White House spokesperson Adam Kennedy, referred to short-term, limited-duration plans[26][6].
These insurance plans have been around for decades and are a tempory solution for people between jobs or attending school.
A further analysis concluded that without subsidies, mainly young or healthy consumers might pay as much as 60% less than the lowest-cost plan through the Affordable Care Act (ACA)[11][32].
Despite having lower premiums— almost half the cost of ACA plans— consensus has it that the coverage they provide is not better than that of ACA plans[34][38].
Short-term plans can deny people with health conditions from enrolling or exclude coverage for specific conditions or treatments.
For instance, they are not obligated to cover prescription drugs, mental health services, substance abuse treatment, and almost all exclude maternity care[14][16][18].

Further into these plans, a caveat is that if a person develops a condition during coverage term, insurers can review their medical records and in some occurrences, retroactively cancel plans or deny policy renewal at the end of its term[19].

be209cb7c819b233ffd6c60919a4cb84.claim: ""the coronavirus was engineered by scientists in a lab."""
be209cb7c819b233ffd6c60919a4cb84.label: false
be209cb7c819b233ffd6c60919a4cb84.passage:
0: As the 2019 coronavirus continues to spread around the world, an anti-vaccine website has concocted a conspiracy theory about its source.
1: In a blog post published Feb. 3, Natural News, a website known to promote health misinformation, lays out an "irrefutable" conspiracy that the coronavirus is man-made.
2: "The tools for genetic insertion are still present as remnants in the genetic code.
3: Since these unique gene sequences don’t occur by random chance, they’re proof that this virus was engineered by scientists in a lab," the story reads.
4: The article goes on to say that the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are "covering up this inconvenient fact in order to protect communist China."
5: Natural News does not provide evidence for the claim.
6: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: It has been shared more than 2,700 times.
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Natural News) PolitiFact has fact-checked several hoaxes and conspiracies about the 2019 coronavirus, which has infected more than 37,000 people globally and killed 812 in China.
10: The outbreak started in the central Chinese city of Wuhan in December and has since spread to 24 countries.
11: One of the most popular conspiracies about the coronavirus is that it was created in a lab, possibly as a bioweapon.
12: We’ve previously said those claims are unproven — and the Natural News story has similar shortcomings.
13: The website says that "every virology lab in the world that has run a genomic analysis of the coronavirus now knows that the coronavirus was engineered by human scientists."
14: But none of the researchers that has analyzed the virus has come to that conclusion.
15: According to the CDC , both the agency and Chinese authorities have isolated the genome of the 2019 coronavirus.
16: Their findings suggest "a likely single, recent emergence of this virus from an animal reservoir."
17: We analyzed the eight publications the CDC lists on its landing page about coronavirus.
18: None asserts that the virus was engineered by humans.
19: RELATED: PolitiFact’s coronavirus coverage in one place One study , which analyzed the genetic sequence of the coronavirus, was published Jan. 30 in the journal The Lancet.
20: It says the 2019 coronavirus is a human betacoronavirus similar to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and likely comes from bats.
21: "Although our phylogenetic analysis suggests that bats might be the original host of this virus, an animal sold at the seafood market in Wuhan might represent an intermediate host facilitating the emergence of the virus in humans," the study reads.
22: Early reports on the virus focused on the fact that many patients were linked to the Wuhan market.
23: That suggested animal-to-person spread, according to the CDC , but later, a growing number of patients reported not having any connection to the market.
24: That suggested the coronavirus was spreading person-to-person.
25: Other blogs and social media users have speculated that a lab near Wuhan could be the source of the virus.
26: The Wuhan National Biosafety Laboratory is a maximum-security biolab that deals with some of the world’s most dangerous pathogens, including Ebola and SARS.
27: As of now, however, there is no evidence that the lab is the source of the outbreak.
28: The Natural News article is unsupported by evidence.

gpt4: The claim that "the coronavirus was engineered by scientists in a lab" is false.
The claim lacks empirical evidence as no proofs have been presented that the virus indeed originated from a lab[27].
Furthermore, Natural News, a source of this claim, failed to provide substantial, supporting evidence to back this assertion[5].
Consequently, the claim cannot be established as factual based on the prevailing information available.

d01b52c050a578bada210b44f959beb3.claim: “This is a 1927 News Article showing America was sold to five Billionaires The Rothschild’s, Rockefellers, DuPont’s, Harriman’s and Warburg’s.”
d01b52c050a578bada210b44f959beb3.label: false
d01b52c050a578bada210b44f959beb3.passage:
0: The Facebook post begins with this question: "Do you still think United States is a Country, owned by the people?"
1: The post then shows what appears to be part of the front page of a newspaper, although the name of the paper is not visible.
2: The page includes this headline in all-capital letters: "Billionaires Buy U.S. from Millionaires."
3: The text of the article is too blurry to read.
4: Below that is a caption with grammatical errors that claims: "This is a 1927 News Article showing America was sold to five Billionaires The Rothschild’s, Rockefellers , DuPont’s, Harriman’s and Warburg’s."
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: One of the comments on the post says the newspaper page was produced by The Onion, known for its satirical headlines and stories.
8: That’s correct.
9: On Aug. 24, 2005, under the headline "August 23, 1927," The Onion posted what looks like the front page of a newspaper from the 1920s.
10: The newspaper’s name — The Onion — is clearly visible at the top.
11: Below the main headline are subheads that are further proof that The Onion was merely having fun: "Future of Nation in Yet Wealthier Hands; Rich Will Regulate Government, Citizenry."

gpt4: The claim that a 1927 news article shows America was sold to five billionaires — the Rothschilds, Rockefellers, DuPonts, Harrimans, and Warburgs — is false.
The source of this claim appears to be an image uploaded by The Onion on August 24, 2005, which has been misinterpreted as an authentic historic newspaper front page[9].
In reality, The Onion, which is known for its satirical articles and headlines, had clearly printed its name on the top of said image[10].
This additional information was confirmed by an user comment on the post, revealing that the supposed newspaper page was, in fact, a creation of The Onion[7].
Therefore, the claim, while appearing to be backed by 'historic evidence', is untrue[8].

aa4496fcb53cf8b00026ec65a22dbae9.claim: “Trump’s daughter works at the White House. Her husband works at the White House. Rudy’s son works at the White House. Barr’s son-in-law works at the White House. Barr’s daughter works at Treasury. Trump’s sons do foreign business. Trump’s daughter is getting Chinese patents and Saudi grants.”
aa4496fcb53cf8b00026ec65a22dbae9.label: true
aa4496fcb53cf8b00026ec65a22dbae9.passage:
0: President Donald Trump and his Republican allies have attacked former Vice President Joe Biden’s son Hunter for riding his family name to a fortune in Ukraine.
1: But a viral post floating around social media suggests the same charges should be thrown in Trump’s direction.
2: The picture, a spin-off of a 2016 cartoon showing Trump hoarding bags of cash, tags Trump’s daughter Ivanka, her husband Jared Kushner, and the children of Trump personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani and Attorney General William Barr as benefactors of Trump’s presidency.
3: "Trump’s daughter works at the White House," the text says.
4: "Her husband works at the White House.
5: Rudy’s son works at the White House.
6: Barr’s son-in-law works at the White House.
7: Barr’s daughter works at Treasury.
8: Trump’s sons do foreign business.
9: Trump’s daughter is getting Chinese patents and Saudi grants.
10: But sure, let’s talk about Hunter Biden."
11: The image has been circulating on Facebook and Twitter since at least early December , when the House was moving toward impeaching Trump after a whistleblower complaint sounded alarms about Trump’s efforts to get Ukraine to announce an investigation into the Bidens.
12: One post from Occupy Democrats , a liberal advocacy group, received over 22,000 likes and more than 23,000 shares on Facebook.
13: Actor John Leguizamo also shared the image .
14: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat potential false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
15: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
16: We decided to break down the family claims one by one.
17: Family ties in the White House, U.S. government Trump, Barr and Giuliani all have family members working in top positions at the White House and other government agencies, according to LinkedIn, news reports and the White House’s latest annual report to Congress on its personnel.
18: Here’s what we found: • Ivanka Trump, Donald Trump’s daughter, works as an adviser to the president and makes no salary.
19: • Jared Kushner, Ivanka Trump’s husband, works as an assistant and senior adviser to the president .
20: He also takes no salary.
21: • Andrew Giuliani, Giuliani’s son, works as a special assistant to the president and associate director of the office of public liaison.
22: He’s paid $95,000 per year.
23: • Tyler McGaughey, Barr’s son-in-law, works as an associate in the White House counsel’s office with an annual salary of $125,792.
24: • Mary Daly, Barr’s daughter , works as a senior adviser to the director of the Treasury Department’s financial crimes unit, according to news reports and her LinkedIn profile .
25: Ivanka Trump and Kushner have had White House roles since the early months of Donald Trump’s presidency, with Ivanka Trump formally occupying her position in March 2017 and Kushner swearing in just days after Trump’s inauguration.
26: Kushner’s appointment came after the Justice Department wrote a memo concluding that the White House was exempt from violating federal anti-nepotism laws.
27: Andrew Giuliani, a former Trump campaign volunteer , was first appointed in March 2017 , with a starting salary of $77,000, per the White House’s 2017 report .
28: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Andrew Giuliani and his former girlfriend, Olympic figure skater Sarah Hughes, at the world premiere of 'The Other Guys' in New York on Monday, Aug. 2, 2010.
29: (AP/Agostini) McGaughey, who’s married to Barr’s youngest daughter, and Daly, Barr’s oldest daughter, separately transitioned out of Justice Department jobs as Barr awaited Senate confirmation on his nomination to take over as attorney general, according to CNN .
30: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Mary Daly poses for photographs at the Department of Justice in Washington on April 6, 2018.
31: (AP/Ceneta) Other administrations, including under Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama, have seen relatives of high-ranking party leaders and administration officials in government positions.
32: Foreign business and patents The image also takes aim at Eric and Donald Trump Jr. for their management of the Trump Organization, as well as at Ivanka Trump for her own business interests.
33: In October 2019, Eric Trump said, "When my father became commander in chief of this country, we got out of all international business."
34: We rated that claim Pants on Fire .
35: When Donald Trump became president, he transferred ownership of the Trump Organization to his sons and pledged that "no new deals" would be done during his time in office.
36: But as we’ve documented , the Trump sons have put almost no stops to their overseas business dealings.
37: They have traveled the globe, managing properties and moving on deals they insist were signed or in-the-works before their father moved into the White House.
38: Multiple news outlets and accountability groups have kept track of their international activities, and in some cases, the Trump children have publicly celebrated their endeavors.
39: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com As for Ivanka Trump, it’s misleading to say she’s "getting Chinese patents and Saudi grants."
40: The president’s daughter kept her international fashion business going for 18 months after her father’s election before shutting it down.
41: Amid trade talks with China in 2018, she received a number of trademarks from the country related to her products.
42: She added more in 2019 , as well.
43: Trademarks are slightly different from patents.
44: According to the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office , a trademark protects a symbol, logo, design, name or word meant to identify the person or company behind a product, while a patent protects a person or company’s new invention.
45: In May 2017, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates announced their pledge to contribute $100 million to a World Bank fund meant to help women entrepreneurs and small-business owners around the world, according to reports .
46: The fund was Ivanka Trump’s idea .
47: But as Snopes noted , she does not have a hands-on role with the project, nor is she lining her pockets because of it.

gpt4: The claim that various family members and relations of Trump are employed in the White House and carry out foreign business is true.
Ivanka Trump, President Trump's daughter, works at the White House [3].
Ivanka's husband, Jared Kushner, also works at the White House as an assistant and senior adviser to the president, without drawing a salary [4][19][20].

Additionally, Andrew Giuliani, son of Rudy Giuliani, is employed as a special assistant to the president and associate director of the office of public liaison, with an annual salary of $95,000 [5][21][22].

Furthermore, Barr's family also has connections to the Trump administration, with his son-in-law, Tyler McGaughey, working as an associate in the White House counsel’s office, and his daughter Mary Daly, working as a senior adviser to the director of the Treasury Department’s financial crimes unit [6][23][7][24].

On another note, Trump's sons, Eric and Donald Trump Jr., despite transferring ownership of the Trump Organization back to their father, have continued to conduct overseas business[8][32][33][34][35][36].
Lastly, Ivanka Trump has been involved in securing Chinese patents related to her products during trade talks with China in 2018 and 2019, as well as receiving Saudi grants [9][41][42].

66af23f535bc2f1bd77664734be18c01.claim: Republicans just won two congressional seats in North Carolina “that were not supposed to be won.”
66af23f535bc2f1bd77664734be18c01.label: false
66af23f535bc2f1bd77664734be18c01.passage:
0: After his impeachment acquittal last week, President Donald Trump reminded Republicans of his importance to their success.
1: Trump said during a press conference on Thursday that, with his help, Republicans could take back the Democrat-controlled House of Representatives.
2: "You know, in ’18, we didn’t win.
3: We just won two seats in North Carolina, two wonderful seats in North Carolina, that were not supposed to be won," he said.
4: A video of his speech is available on C-SPAN’s website .
5: Trump continued: "But I went and I made speeches and we had rallies, and we did a great job and we won, and we took two seats.
6: Nobody writes about that.
7: If we lost them, it would have been the biggest story of the year."
8: Trump didn’t mention any other details about the races during his speech, but it’s clear from context that he was referring to North Carolina’s recent special elections.
9: North Carolina last year held elections for two congressional seats: one in the 3rd District and the other in the 9th District.
10: This isn’t the first time Trump has boasted about his supposed influence on the 9th District race.
11: Last year, Trump claimed that the Republican in the 9th District race, Dan Bishop, was "down by 17" points in the polls and then won "by a lot."
12: But the polls didn’t support that statement and the final margin of the race was only 2 points, so PolitiFact rated his claim False .
13: Trump’s claim on Thursday was a little different.
14: He referred to both races, and was speaking more generally about who was expected to win.
15: So is it true that Republicans were underdogs in those races?
16: No.
17: Let’s look at the races, one by one.
18: The 9th District The 9th District race featured Bishop and Democrat Dan McCready.
19: Background: The election was a do-over of the November 2018 contest, when Republican Mark Harris appeared to defeat McCready.
20: But an investigation into the results found absentee ballot fraud, and the alleged leader of the ballot scheme worked for the Harris campaign.
21: So the State Board of Elections called a new election, and Harris dropped out.
22: About the district: The 9th District was home to more registered Democrats than Republicans, said Michael Bitzer, a history and politics professor at Catawba College.
23: About 36 percent of registered voters are Democrats, 32 percent are unaffiliated and 31 percent are Republicans.
24: But that doesn’t mean the district favored Democrats.
25: "While it may seem that party registration favored Democrats, a significant portion of those registered Democrats are in rural counties, which means that they are more likely to be Republican voters," Bitzer said.
26: Indeed, no Democrat had won the seat since 1963, according to the Charlotte Observer .
27: "Polls showed a tight race due to the Democratic-leaning national environment and Dan McCready's strength as a candidate," said Drew Savicki, a freelance political analyst who has written for the Sabato’s Crystal Ball political blog .
28: But, Savicki added: Trump in 2016 won the district by 12 points, and "Democrats only hold a few seats redder than that."
29: Polls and predictions: It’s true that some polls showed McCready with a lead.
30: But some polls showed Bishop with a lead.
31: The website FiveThirtyEight tracked some of the polling of the district.
32: As we’ve previously reported, the most favorable public poll for McCready had him up 5 points and most favorable poll for Bishop showed him up 4 points.
33: Most experts considered the Democrat’s chance to be 50-50, at best.
34: Kyle Kondik of Sabato’s Crystal Ball considered the race a " toss-up ," while Dave Wasserman of the Cook Political Report wrote that a McCready win would be "an upset."
