35: The 3rd District The 3rd District race featured Republican Greg Murphy and Democrat Allen Thomas -- and wasn’t nearly as close as the 9th District race.
36: Background: The special election was ordered after the death of longtime Congressman Walter Jones, a Republican.
37: He had represented the district for more than 24 years .
38: About the district: Voter registration favored Republicans, who had 34 percent of the population to the Democrats’ 32 percent, Bitzer said.
39: In 2016, Jones won with 67 percent of the vote, and Trump carried the district by 23 percent.
40: So the race between Thomas and Murphy wasn’t considered competitive.
41: "No version of the 3rd district has backed a Democrat for President since Carter in 1980," Savicki said.
42: Polls and predictions: The only poll documented on FiveThirtyEight showed Murphy up by 11 percent.
43: Sabato’s blog said the race leaned Republican.
44: And Bitzer said in an email: "I can’t recall any handicapper or political analyst ever thinking that the NC 3rd was in danger of going to Democratic."
45: PolitiFact reached out to the White House and the Trump campaign about his claim, but didn’t hear back.
46: "To say that Republicans were not likely to win either of those seats makes it sound like analysts had both seats rated as Democratic-likely elections," Bitzer said.
47: "To my knowledge, there was no data or polling that would have indicated that scenario."

gpt4: The claim that Republicans won two congressional seats in North Carolina "that were not supposed to be won" is inaccurate.
While it's true that North Carolina held elections for two congressional seats last year[9], the picture is more complicated than presented.
The race involving candidates Thomas and Murphy wasn't competitive, with the latter winning soundly [40].
This is likely due to the fact that no Democrat has won the seat since 1963, according to the Charlotte Observer [26].
The second election was regarded differently.
Kyle Kondik of Sabato’s Crystal Ball deemed the race a "toss-up," while Dave Wasserman of the Cook Political Report indicated that a McCready Democratic win would be "an upset" [34].
This suggests that although it wasn't a guaranteed victory for the Republicans, it wasn't an unexpected result either.
Notably, during President Trump's speech, he didn't specifically dwell on the details of these races, but the context indicated he referred to the North Carolina's recent special elections [8].

cd1dfed0ef7f81554d056925d5ec8fb7.claim: “Over 50% of the people now in the House and state Senate have not been born in Virginia.”
cd1dfed0ef7f81554d056925d5ec8fb7.label: true
cd1dfed0ef7f81554d056925d5ec8fb7.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Denver Riggleman, R-5th, recently accused the newly-elected Democratic majority in the General Assembly of embracing liberal policies that are out of sync with Virginia.
1: Democrats last fall won control of both legislative chambers for the first time this century.
2: Riggleman, during a Jan. 23 radio interview on the John Fredericks Show, said the party has gone "absolutely loco" in passing gun control bills, proposing a gas tax hike to improve roads and backing measures he said will hurt small businesses.
3: He said Democrats could be facing the "shortest tenure ever for a majority, based on the craziness coming out of the state legislature."
4: He added, "Over 50% of the people now in the House and the state Senate have not been born in Virginia.
5: And most of them, completely new.
6: They’re not even Virginians by grace yet."
7: We fact-checked Riggleman’s statistic.
8: We’ll leave it to you to determine what, if anything, qualifies a person to be a "Virginian by grace."
9: The numbers To learn where lawmakers were born, we consulted their  biographies on the House and Senate websites and in General Assembly manuals.
10: In a few cases, we turned to newspaper stories or asked legislative aides.
11: The newly-elected House of Delegates sworn in last month has 52 members born outside Virginia and 48 born inside the state.
12: The newly-elected Senate has 22 members born outside the state and 18 born within.
13: Combining the chambers, 74 legislators were born outside Virginia, 66 inside.
14: That’s a flip from 2019, when Republicans held narrow majorities in both chambers.
15: In the House 52 delegates were born in Virginia, 48 weren’t.
16: In the Senate, 22 were born in Virginia, 18 were not.
17: Combing the chambers, 74 lawmakers were born inside Virginia, 66 outside.
18: In other words, there was a net addition in both chambers of four members born outside the state.
19: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com But these numbers are tricky and don’t suggest - as Riggleman implies - that those born outside Virginia are alien to its culture.
20: Nine current General Assembly members (six senators and three delegates) listed as being born out of state were delivered across the Potomac River in Washington D.C. Their biographies show six of them (four senators and two delegates) graduated from high school or college in Virginia.
21: If counted, Riggleman’s claim about out-of-state majorities would fall.
22: Twelve other legislators were born in states bordering Virginia: North Carolina; Maryland; West Virginia; Kentucky; and Tennessee.
23: Republican Del.
24: Terry Kilgore, for example, has lived in Gate City in Southwest Virginia for all of his life, except when he attended college and law school in other parts of Virginia.
25: But he was born in a hospital 20 miles away in Kingsport, Tenn. and - in Riggleman’s claim - doesn’t count as a native-born Virginian.
26: Demographics So far, we’ve been focusing on the details of numbers between 2019 and 2020 and, by strict count, there has been a transition to where a majority of General Assembly members were born out of Virginia.
27: But a broader trend emerges if we use 1960 as our starting point.
28: The increase in non-Virginia legislators over the past 60 years reflects the increase in non-native-born Virginians living in the state.
29: In 1960, Virginia was in the final years of domination by a political machine controlled by Democratic U.S. Sen. Harry Byrd that was rural in origin and segregationist.
30: The House of Delegates had 96 Democrats and four Republicans; the Senate had 38 Democrats and two Republicans.
31: Eighty-five percent of the legislators were born in Virginia, as was 71% of the state’s population.
32: These days, Virginia’s politics are dominated by a suburban crescent arching from Northern Virginia through Hampton Roads.
33: There’s been a large migration to the state through these suburbs - particularly Northern Virginia - by a professional class of government workers and contractors.
34: The U.S. Census Bureau estimated that 50.5% of the state’s population in 2018 was born outside Virginia.
35: That nearly matches the 52% of legislators this year who were not born in Virginia.
36: "People like to vote for people who reflect them," said Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist.
37: "These legislators reflect the people they represent.
38: Riggleman’s living in the past."
39: "We’ve become a different state," said Bob Holsworth, a political scientist and consultant.
40: "I certainly understand some people who regret that some of the traditions have gone by, but in terms of overall prospects (offered by Virginia), there’s a big difference between now and 65 years ago."
41: By the way Although it’s not part of fact-check rating, we took a quick look at  Riggleman’s contention that most of the out-of-state legislators were elected last year.
42: He’s wrong.
43: Only nine of the 52 non-Virginia born delegates were elected last fall, as were only five of the 22 senators born out of state.

gpt4: The claim that over 50% of the people now in the House of Delegates and the state Senate in Virginia are not native born is indeed true.
The current House of Delegates, which had its members sworn in last month, has 52 members born outside of Virginia, compared to 48 members who were born inside the state[11].
Similarly, in the recently elected Senate, 22 members were born outside the state, while 18 were born within[12].
Consequently, this affirms the statement's accuracy that the majority of these elected officials in Virginia were not born in this state.

36ddaeb9fc6bff33e58449233ad25ba3.claim: “Cocaine kills corona virus, scientists is shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus.”
36ddaeb9fc6bff33e58449233ad25ba3.label: false
36ddaeb9fc6bff33e58449233ad25ba3.passage:
0: The Novel Coronavirus has been surrounded by panic and misinformation since its discovery in December 2019.
1: The most recent false claim is that cocaine is the cure.
2: Images of breaking news stories claiming that cocaine is the newest remedy to coronavirus are being reposted on Twitter and Facebook.
3: One Facebook post from Jan. 30 included an image of a bag of cocaine in the background of a news banner that says "Cocaine kills corona virus" and "Scientists is shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus."
4: No, this grammatically challenged image was not from a real breaking news alert.
5: This image is made by an online news generator.
6: There is still no cure for the coronavirus.
7: This post was flagged by Facebook as part of efforts to combat false news and information on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: The breaking news format of this social media claim came from a website that allows you to create your own breaking news stories by uploading your own image and headline into a generator.
10: The waterstamp "breakyourownnews.com" in the top right corner is blurred out in the Facebook post.
11: In the original image of the bag of cocaine, which can be found on multiple stock image sites , there was no blurry white spot in the corner.
12: This breaking news image is fabricated.
13: If there were a cure for the Novel Coronavirus, we wouldn’t count on it being a stimulant like cocaine.
14: Cocaine is a highly addictive drug that can lead to long-term respiratory problems and movement disorders like Parkinson’s disease, according to the National Institutes of Health .
15: In 2017 there were a total of 13,942 drug overdose deaths in the United States that involved cocaine.
16: There have been 1,016 deaths reported worldwide from the coronavirus as of Feb. 10, none in the United States .
17: We wouldn’t recommend trying a highly addictive drug in hopes of fighting off a viral disease.

gpt4: The claim stating “Cocaine kills corona virus, scientists is shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus” is categorically false.
This most recent false assertion is the result of a myth that cocaine is the cure for the virus, however, this is not grounded in scientific fact [1].
The claim itself seems to have stemmed from a fabricated image made by an online news generator, evidenced by its grammatically incorrect content and unprofessional presentation[5][4].
The image purported to show a breaking news alert but, it is clear the image was not a real breaking news alert and was indeed concocted [12].
In truth, there still isn't a confirmed cure for the coronavirus, reinforcing the fallacy of this claim [6].

13088cf7b7db32a5e902c742dc215e76.claim: “I delivered on my campaign promise for a 10% tax cut for Wisconsin families.”
13088cf7b7db32a5e902c742dc215e76.label: false
13088cf7b7db32a5e902c742dc215e76.passage:
0: Gov.
1: Tony Evers has run into a Republican buzzsaw in attempting to get many of his policies through the state Legislature.
2: But he still identified plenty of progress to celebrate in his latest State of the State speech.
3: He touted changes in education, transportation and healthcare, then circled back to an earlier pledge on taxes.
4: "I delivered on my campaign promise for a 10% tax cut for Wisconsin families," he said Jan. 22, 2020, in the annual address.
5: We’ll need to look back at his promise and forward at tax projections to see if that’s the case.
6: Here we go.
7: The promise Evers’ speech didn’t go into much detail on the nature of that tax cut, but he was quite specific in 2018 on the campaign trail.
8: A news release from his campaign on Oct. 14, 2018, described it this way: Under Evers’ plan, everyone with annual incomes up to $100,000 would receive a 10% tax cut.
9: Evers would also provide the tax cut to families making up to $150,000.
10: Altogether, this cut would reach approximately 86% of tax filers.
11: That news release remained on Evers’ campaign website as of late 2019 but has been removed.
12: A copy is still accessible through archive.org .
13: Regardless, that gives us a firm benchmark to examine Evers’ claim that he "delivered" on that promise.
14: The reality When asked for evidence of Evers’ claim, spokeswoman Melissa Baldauff pointed to Wisconsin Department of Revenue projections for the 2020 tax year .
15: The agency generated projected tax impacts for each income bracket based on the policies written into law through the budget and an accompanying bill (Acts 9 and 10).
16: Department of Revenue spokeswoman Patty Mayers noted these are estimates that can change, but they are the best existing projections for the tax changes passed under Evers.
17: Baldauff highlighted estimates for married filers with incomes between $30,000 and $60,000.
18: Each of the three income brackets in that range are projected to see tax cuts of 10% or more.
19: But Evers promised a tax cut to all families with an income of $150,000 or less, and the full Department of Revenue projections show tax brackets under and over that amount fell well short of that 10% mark.
20: Across all income brackets under $150,000, the changes from Acts 9 and 10 generate an average tax cut of 4.9% for married filers who owe taxes — half of what Evers promised.
21: That works out to about $129 per tax return.
22: If you look at the impact in terms of people, about one-fourth of married filers will see the promised cut of 10% or more, according to the Department of Revenue projections.
23: That’s among the group that owe some amount of taxes and fall in the under-$150,000 bracket Evers referenced.
24: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Baldauff asserted Evers always intended to focus his 10% tax cut on "middle-class" families, meaning the 10% tax cut in the $30,000 to $60,000 fulfilled his promise.
25: But neither his original pledge nor his wording in the State of the State reflected that.
26: In any case, the definition of middle-class offered by Baldauff doesn’t make much sense in a state where the median family income is about $59,000.
27: Her range only goes down from the median, not up.
28: We should also note that we’ve visited this topic before with our Evers-O-Meter, which tracks promises Evers made while seeking the state’s highest office.
29: In July 2019, we rated a promise to cut middle class taxes by 10% as a Compromise, since initial projections showed Evers’ proposed tax break was cut roughly in half by the Republican Legislature.
30: That’s in line with the updated projections.
31: Same story for single filers We focused on married filers since Evers’ speech referred to families, but we should note he also promised a 10% tax cut to "everyone" filing an individual tax return with an income of $100,000 or less.
32: The latest projections for single filers show a similar trend to the married filers in 2020.
33: Those with incomes of $20,000 to $40,000 are expected to see a tax cut of more than 10%, but the reduction is noticeably less for the income brackets above and below that.
34: Overall, single filers with incomes below $100,000 are projected to see an average tax cut of 6.7% under Acts 9 and 10.

gpt4: While Governor Evers indeed made a campaign promise of a 10% tax cut for Wisconsin families[4], a look at the numbers reveals a different story.

Despite Evers' claim during his January 2020 annual address, the changes from Acts 9 and 10 suggest that the average tax cut across all income brackets under $150,000 was only 4.9% for married filers who owed taxes[20].
This falls considerably short of Evers' promised 10% cut.
Furthermore, Evers had specifically pledged a tax cut for all families with an income of $150,000 or less.
However, Department of Revenue projections reveal that tax cuts for brackets under and over that amount did not meet the 10% benchmark[19].
Thus, upon examining these figures against Evers' promise, the claim that he delivered on his 10% tax cut promise is deemed false[13].

c990db68d2aa41975fe79581a158da66.claim: After pushing through a red flag law in the New Mexico Senate, Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham “has had the firearms of her guards and household seized.”
c990db68d2aa41975fe79581a158da66.label: false
c990db68d2aa41975fe79581a158da66.passage:
0: An inaccurate Facebook post goes after New Mexico Gov.
1: Michelle Lujan Grisham over her support of a law that attempts to keep guns away from people who might be dangerous.
2: "In a move some would call ‘stunningly ironic’ Michelle Lujan Grisham (D) has had the firearms of her guards and household seized," says a Feb. 9 Facebook post by the Farmington Tribune .
3: "This comes only days after pushing her party's ‘red flag’ law through the Senate."
4: We don’t call this statement ironic.
5: We call it false.
6: There is no evidence that guns were seized from Lujan Grisham’s home.
7: And the state police officers who protect her remain armed, her spokesman Tripp Stelnicki told PolitiFact.
8: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: The Farmington Tribune Facebook page doesn’t shed much light on its intentions.
11: Some news reports have characterized the Facebook page as satire, but nothing on the site states that.
12: This false story was inspired by Lujan Grisham’s support of the proposed Extreme Risk Firearm Protection Order Act that passed the state Senate on Feb. 7.
13: It passed the House on Feb. 13.
14: Lujan Grisham, who applauded its passage , is expected to sign the bill.
15: About 17 states have similar "red flag" or extreme risk laws.
16: The laws allow police to petition a court to order the temporary removal of firearms from a person who may be dangerous, or to block the person from obtaining a firearm.
17: After a set amount of time, the firearm is either returned to the person or the court order is extended.
18: RELATED: How Florida’s red flag gun law works There is no evidence that guns were seized from Lujan Grisham’s home or from her security detail after passage of the law.

gpt4: The claim that New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham had the firearms of her guards and household seized after a red flag law was passed in the New Mexico Senate is false.
The initial assertion originated from a Feb. 9 Facebook post made by the Farmington Tribune[2].
Contrary to this, there is no evidence to suggest that guns were taken from Lujan Grisham’s residence[6].
Furthermore, the Governor's spokesman, Tripp Stelnicki, confirmed that the state's police officers who are responsible for Grisham's safety continue to be armed[7].

cce2dec554266fb97ed9fa8fdba1e4ca.claim: the coronavirus is “a MILITARY BIO-WEAPON Developed by China's Army.”
cce2dec554266fb97ed9fa8fdba1e4ca.label: false
cce2dec554266fb97ed9fa8fdba1e4ca.passage:
0: A far-right radio host who has supported the rhetoric of white supremacy is spreading misinformation about the origins of the coronavirus outbreak.
1: In an article published Feb. 1, the Hal Turner Radio Show wrote that the 2019 coronavirus is "a military bioweapon developed by China’s army" at the Wuhan Institute of Virology.
2: As evidence, it points to two screenshots from a national database of genetic material.
3: "Somehow, it got out.
4: The world is now facing a massive wipe-out of humanity as a result," the article reads.
5: "The proof that this virus is a genetically-modified Bat-SARS-Like Virus, manipulated by the Chinese Army, appears below.
6: The evidence is irrefutable."
7: The article was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: It has been shared more than 2,000 times.
10: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Hal Turner Radio Show) Since its December outbreak in Wuhan, China, the coronavirus has spread rapidly around the world.
11: According to the World Health Organization , more than 40,000 people have been infected in 24 countries.
12: In China, 909 have died.
13: PolitiFact has fact-checked several conspiracy theories about the source of the coronavirus.
14: Some hoaxes suggested that the virus somehow escaped from the Wuhan lab, which deals with some of the world’s most dangerous pathogens, such as Ebola and the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus.
15: We have found no evidence to back up those claims — and the Hal Turner article is similarly flawed.
16: Genetic material doesn’t prove conspiracy The Hal Turner Radio Show claims that, because two coronavirus entries in a federal database have similar proteins, they are the same virus.
17: That’s unproven.
18: Hal Turner uses internet and radio broadcasts to float conspiracy theories and hate speech.
19: In 2010, he was sentenced to 33 months in prison for threatening three federal judges over their decision to uphold handgun bans in Chicago.
20: The Hal Turner article cites screenshots of two GenBank entries for coronavirus proteins.
21: GenBank is a database maintained by the National Center for Biotechnology Information that lists publicly available DNA sequences.
22: The first screenshot shows an entry for an envelope protein for a "Bat SARS-like coronavirus" that was submitted in 2018 by the Institute of Military Medicine, Nanjing Command.
23: According to the Universal Protein Resource , an envelope protein is a membrane that "forms the outermost layer" of the complete, infective form of certain viruses.
24: The second screenshot is an entry for another envelope protein associated with the "Wuhan seafood market pneumonia virus."
25: It was submitted Jan. 5 by the Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center and School of Public Health at Fudan University.
26: RELATED: PolitiFact’s coronavirus coverage in one place The Hal Turner Radio Show compared the two viral proteins using a NCBI search and found that the two were nearly identical.
27: But there are seven kinds of coronaviruses that can infect humans and they have similar envelope proteins .
28: So the match doesn’t prove the two viruses are the same.
29: "The family of coronaviruses are going to be highly related, just because they are in the same family," said Richard Watanabe, a professor of preventive medicine at the University of California’s Keck School of Medicine, in an email.
30: We ran the same NCBI search as the Hal Turner Radio Show and found 78 entries with envelope proteins similar to the 2019 coronavirus.
31: Bioweapon theory is unfounded The second claim in the Hal Turner Radio Show’s article is that, since Chinese researchers uploaded its genetic information, the 2019 coronavirus is a military bioweapon.
32: That’s unproven.
33: There is a lab near Wuhan that deals with dangerous pathogens — and some have linked it to China’s biological warfare program.
34: The country denies having such a program, but the U.S. State Department has raised concerns about China’s potential noncompliance with the Biological Weapons Convention, which bans the production of such weapons.
35: Officials are still working to determine the source of the coronavirus outbreak.
36: In its most recent situation summary , the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that both it and Chinese authorities had isolated the genome of the 2019 coronavirus.
37: Their findings suggest "a likely single, recent emergence from a virus related to bat coronaviruses and the SARS coronavirus."
38: The disease appears to have originated at a seafood and animal market in Wuhan, and it spread from there to 24 countries.
39: Researchers believe the current outbreak pattern suggests the coronavirus may have spread from animal to human at first, and now from human to human.
40: RELATED: No evidence that Chinese officials will say coronavirus was leaked from a lab There’s no evidence that the coronavirus was developed as a bioweapon.
41: And even if there were, Watanabe said it’s highly unlikely the Chinese military would have uploaded the genetic sequence to a public database maintained by an American government agency.
42: "China, like the other countries including the U.S., have legitimate biomedical research going on at military facilities," Watanabe said.
43: "Just because they uploaded information, doesn’t make it a bioweapon."

gpt4: The claim that the coronavirus is a military bio-weapon developed by China's Army is demonstrably false[15].
This theory, propagated by the Hal Turner Radio Show, has no factual evidence supporting it [15].
Rather than being a bio-weapon, the scientific consensus suggests that the virus has a natural origin.
Research indicates that there was a likely single, recent emergence of the virus from a virus that is related to bat coronaviruses and the SARS coronavirus [37].
Furthermore, there are seven types of coronaviruses that infect humans, all of which have similar envelope proteins [27].
The fact that Chinese researchers uploaded the genetic information of the virus to a public database also does not support the bio-weapon theory.

As pointed out by Watanabe, it is improbable that the Chinese military would upload the genetic sequence of a purported military bio-weapon to a public database maintained by an American government agency [41].

c234a07faef02fb7516052244a9bedfd.label: false
c234a07faef02fb7516052244a9bedfd.passage:
0: A video on Facebook is spinning a conspiracy theory about the effect of the 2019 coronavirus.
1: The nearly 50-minute video plays clips that purportedly show 2019 coronavirus victims.
2: A narrator speaks over them, promoting conspiracies about everything from the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks to the source of the coronavirus.
3: A fake news chyron on the video claims: "Wuhan super virus causes sudden death syndrome."
4: The video was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared hundreds of times.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) There is no evidence to support the video.
8: Most of the deaths caused by the 2019 coronavirus have been associated with respiratory problems, not sudden death syndrome.
9: The video comes from a Facebook page called Stranger Than Fiction News, which is managed by three users in Australia, according to Facebook’s Page Transparency feature.
10: The account in recent weeks has uploaded several videos with unproven or fabricated claims about the coronavirus.
11: Since its December outbreak in Wuhan, China, the 2019 coronavirus has spread rapidly around the world.
12: According to the World Health Organization , more than 43,000 people have been infected in 24 countries.
13: In China, 1,017 have died.
14: Researchers still don’t know much about the clinical severity of the coronavirus.
15: Many people recover within a few days , but some, such as young, elderly or immunocompromised people, may develop more serious infections, like bronchitis or pneumonia.
16: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the 2019 coronavirus causes symptoms like fever, cough and shortness of breath.
17: That’s similar to coronaviruses like Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which causes "rapidly progressive pneumonitis, respiratory failure, septic shock and multi-organ failure resulting in death."
18: RELATED: PolitiFact’s coronavirus coverage in one place Sudden death syndrome, on the other hand, is a "series of cardiac syndromes that cause sudden cardiac arrest and possibly death," according to Healthline .
19: Some syndromes are caused by structural problems in the heart, while others are a result of electrical irregularities.
20: There is no evidence that the coronavirus causes sudden death syndrome.
21: A Jan. 30 study of 99 coronavirus cases found that the virus "can result in severe and even fatal respiratory diseases such as acute respiratory distress syndrome."
22: Three-quarters of the patients in the study showed signs of double pneumonia, and the characteristics of those who died were consistent with a warning model that predicts who’s most likely to die from the disease.
23: Some patients did die after experiencing heart problems, including cardiac arrest, but the study did not establish a link between the virus and sudden death syndrome.
24: The Facebook post is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that the 2019 coronavirus "causes sudden death syndrome" is false.
Primarily, there is no evidence supporting the assertion that the coronavirus leads to sudden death syndrome [20].
Diverse research has found that the majority of deaths resulting from the 2019 coronavirus are linked to respiratory complications rather than sudden death syndrome [8].
Additionally, a particular consideration has been given to cases where patients died due to heart-related issues, including cardiac arrest.
However, there was no established connection between these deaths and sudden death syndrome [23].
Also, it's noteworthy that the claim has been flagged as false content in an attempt by Facebook to curb the spread of misinformation and disinformation on its News Feed [4].

e7aff59a97096e73e2dc6f3a92f7a4da.claim: The widow and son of a deceased military veteran looked on in horror as Speaker Nancy Pelosi ripped up a copy of the State of the Union.
e7aff59a97096e73e2dc6f3a92f7a4da.label: false
e7aff59a97096e73e2dc6f3a92f7a4da.passage:
0: One of the most talked about moments of President Donald Trump’s 2020 State of the Union address came at the end, when House Speaker Nancy Pelosi ripped up a copy of his speech.
1: Republicans called it disrespectful, while Democrats celebrated the moment and said Trump had it coming after he snubbed Pelosi’s offered handshake when he arrived.
2: Several misleading claims about the viral moment have also surfaced online, including one assertion that Pelosi "broke the law" when she ripped up the speech, a false claim that Trump subsequently repeated .
3: Now, a new claim posted on Facebook says a photo of an Army sergeant’s widow and son,  who Trump spoke about during his address, was looking on with tearful eyes as Pelosi ripped up the speech.
4: The post displays a split image of Pelosi tearing the speech and one of Kelli and Gage Hake, the widow and son of Army Staff Sgt.
5: Christopher Hake, who was killed in 2008 while serving his second tour of duty in Iraq.
6: The image shows Kelli wiping her face as her son comforts her.
7: Text below the photos say: "With his widow and son looking on, Speaker Pelosi ripped up the speech containing the name of Army Staff Sergeant Christopher Hake, killed in the line of duty in Iraq."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: The photo of the Hakes was not altered.
11: But the moment did not come when Pelosi was tearing the speech.
12: It came before, when Trump introduced the family and was speaking about Sgt.
13: Hake.
14: A similar photo of Kelli Hake wiping her eyes was taken by the Associated Press at 10:14 p.m. (ET), the time that Trump was speaking about Hake and the roadside bomb that killed him in Baghdad in 2008.
15: While the image is from the same event, and the speech does contain Sgt.
16: Hake’s name, the post makes it look like it’s showing the family’s reaction to Pelosi’s action.
17: That’s incorrect.

gpt4: The claim that the widow and son of a deceased military veteran witnessed in horror as Speaker Nancy Pelosi tore a copy of the State of Union is false.
Misconceptions may have arisen from a post bearing Hake's name, a military veteran, which seemingly illustrated his family's reaction to Pelosi's action [16].
However, this is an incorrect interpretation [17].
In truth, the moment of distress displayed by the family did not align with the timeline of Pelosi tearing the speech [11].

82ca4d34afa242d81ebd4c862c084c96.claim: “House Democrats have passed more than 275 bipartisan bills this Congress."""
82ca4d34afa242d81ebd4c862c084c96.label: true
82ca4d34afa242d81ebd4c862c084c96.passage:
0: In the Democrats’ Spanish-language response to President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address, U.S. Rep. Veronica Escobar of El Paso said the president and his allies are "the biggest threat to our safety and security" because they are "unwilling to take action for our country, acting solely in their own interest."
1: She went on to highlight the actions of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. "Mitch McConnell, the leader of the Senate, is openly stonewalling legislation that would help improve the lives of veterans, women, and families – all of us," Escobar said, according to an English language translation of her remarks provided by her office.
2: "House Democrats have passed more than 275 bipartisan bills this Congress, but these bills are gathering dust on his desk."
3: Michigan Gov.
4: Gretchen Whitmer, who delivered the Democratic Party’s response in English after the State of the Union, cited similar figures when discussing McConnell’s actions: "Those three bills, and more than 275 other bipartisan bills, are just gathering dust on Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell’s desk."
5: The New York Times called Whitmer’s claim "exaggerated," based on an analysis from Factcheck.org of a statement from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi making the same claim .
6: Escobar’s office shared a list of 291 "bipartisan" bills that were approved by the House since the beginning of 2019 but are awaiting action in the Senate, as of Jan. 24.
7: Let’s dive in.
8: No universal definition of ‘bipartisan’ Elizabeth Lopez-Sandoval, spokeswoman for Escobar, said Escobar considered bills as being bipartisan if there was "at least one Republican vote on the House floor," or if the bill was passed by a voice vote and "has at least one Republican cosponsor."
9: "Bills that passed on voice vote but do not have at least one Republican cosponsor were excluded," she said.
10: While there is no singular definition of what constitutes a bipartisan bill, the four political experts we consulted for this piece generally agreed that Escobar used a low bar by which to judge cooperation between political parties.
11: Kirby Goidel, director of the Public Policy Research Institute at Texas A&M University, said the term "bipartisan" has taken on a looser definition in regular usage because it is "advantageous in terms of public support."
12: "It is not unusual to call a bill bipartisan when it only received a single vote from across the aisle, though that runs against our more general understanding of what the term is intended to mean," he said in an email.
13: "It is also easy to imagine individual representatives more willing to compromise because they are Republican representing a Democratic district (or vice versa), so adding one member of the opposition in that context wouldn't strike anyone as ‘bipartisan’."
14: As an example, he added: "(U.S. Sen. Mitt) Romney's vote didn't make the vote for impeachment bipartisan."
15: Goidel said a better definition for bipartisan would be legislation that has "majority support from both parties."
16: "Though ideally we wouldn't include resolutions or other items that generate little or no opposition, because the term also implies that the parties worked together to compromise on an important and potentially controversial issue," he said.
17: For the purposes of this fact-check, we’ll rely on counting the votes, since it is tricky to gauge how much collaboration went into each proposal behind the scenes.
18: Jordan Tama, associate professor at American University who is writing a book about bipartisanship, said it is "less common" to see a truly bipartisan process in today’s Congress, since members tend to develop legislation within their own party and only look to attract support from the other party after the fact.
19: "It is more common to see bipartisanship reflected in voting outcomes, even though in many of these cases the legislation wasn’t developed in a very bipartisan method," Tama said.
20: "You can still call something bipartisan if the votes show support from both parties, even if it wasn’t developed through a highly collaborative process."
21: Members of both parties tend to make claims about bipartisanship based on support from one member of the other party, according to Laura Blessing, senior fellow at Georgetown University’s Government Affairs Institute.
22: "Everybody does this," she said.
23: "This is strategic messaging to a larger audience about the nature of legislation and values of main sponsors in reaching across the aisle, but that doesn’t mean it is a meaningless standard.
24: "There is a spectrum about how we think of measures of bipartisanship, and if these people want to use this, well, people have done this before and they’ll do it again.
25: It is a reasonable standard, but there are higher ones out there."
26: Adding up the numbers When a bill comes before the full House, there are two primary ways the legislative body votes: a roll call vote or a voice vote.
27: In a roll call vote, the names of each legislator are read aloud and their vote is recorded alongside their name.
28: When the body passes a measure in a voice vote, members call out "aye" or "nay" on the question of passage and the presiding officer decides which side prevailed.
29: If there is a dispute over the decision, members stand to get an exact tally of the vote.
30: Of the 291 bills Escobar’s team marked as bipartisan, 116 passed in a roll call vote and 175 passed by a voice vote.
31: Before we get into the votes, here’s a reminder about the party breakdown in the House.
32: There are 232 Democrats, 197 Republicans and one independent.
33: Five seats are vacant.
34: Let’s start with the 116 roll call votes: 71 passed with the support of a majority of Republican members of the House, ranging from 100 votes to 196 votes.
35: Seven bills passed with anywhere from 55 to 93 GOP votes, and 38 passed with fewer than 50 Republican votes — 23 of which passed with fewer than 10 Republican votes.
36: Escobar’s team flagged 175 bills that passed via a voice vote and have at least one Republican co-sponsor.
37: Of those, 63 have Republican sponsors, meaning a Republican introduced the bill, and at least one Democrat as a co-sponsor.
38: Looking at the 112 bills with a Democrat as the sponsor, five have more than 50 Republican co-sponsors and the rest have 32 or fewer Republican co-sponsors.
39: Of those, 95 have fewer than 10 Republican co-sponsors.
40: Tama said he didn’t think it was worth it to split hairs over sponsorships on bills that passed by a voice vote, since that generally indicates that there is support for the bill from both parties.
41: "You can really only use (a voice vote) when the vast majority of members are going to vote for it," he said.
42: "If you imagine a vote where two parties are polarized, you’d have almost as many voting yes and no — you wouldn’t be able to judge the outcome.
43: I think it is safe to say that all of the voice votes involved bipartisan support, even if we can’t know for sure what the result is."
44: Overall, the experts we consulted agreed that, given the various definitions of bipartisan, Escobar’s claim was largely accurate but could use more clarifying details.
45: Sean Theriault, a government professor at the University of Texas, said her use of the term bipartisan is fair.
46: "It’s certainly not telling the whole truth, but a single vote from the other side does indicate that it enjoys support from both parties," he said in an email.
47: "So, of course, we would prefer Escobar to say, ‘275 bills that have received at least support from one Republican are sitting on McConnell’s desk,’ but calling them ‘bipartisan’ is not wrong."

gpt4: The claim that House Democrats have passed more than 275 bipartisan bills in this Congress is considered to be accurate.
Representative Veronica Escobar's office shared data indicating the House had approved 291 bills deemed bipartisan and awaiting Senate action as of January 24, 2019 [6].

However, it is important to note that bipartisan is characterized in this instance by either having at least one Republican vote on the House floor or by being passed with a voice vote and having at least one Republican co-sponsor [8].
A total of 116 of these were passed through roll call votes [30][34], with 38 garnering fewer than 50 Republican votes [35].
Additionally, 175 bills were passed with a voice vote and had at least one Republican co-sponsor [36].

Experts we consulted for this analysis generally agreed that Escobar used a low bar for determining bipartisanship [10], in that a single vote from the other party does indicate some level of cross-party support [46], but ideally, genuine bipartisan legislation involves "majority support from both parties"[15].
Nevertheless, they conclude that the claim was largely accurate, but could benefit from further clarification [44].

8d7f8166c8bb6344d0b8f3c89af32039.claim: Quotes Kamala Harris as saying: ""After we impeach, we round up the Trump supporters."""
8d7f8166c8bb6344d0b8f3c89af32039.label: false
8d7f8166c8bb6344d0b8f3c89af32039.passage:
0: California Sen. Kamala Harris never called on fellow Democrats to "round up the Trump supporters," despite what a repeatedly debunked story says.
1: Trump Train Pro News is the latest site to recycle a bogus quote that purports to show Harris threatening supporters of President Donald Trump.
2: "When he’s gone and we have recaptured our legitimate spot in the White House, watch out in the event that you bolstered him and supported his activities, since we’ll be seeking you next," Harris is falsely quoted as saying.
3: "You will feel the retaliation of a country."
4: The Trump Train Pro News story , posted Feb. 9 on Facebook, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: We debunked a nearly identical made-up quote in November.
7: Reporters at Factcheck.org and Snopes have also checked out similar posts.
8: The Trump Train Pro News story, like the false posts that came before it, lifts almost verbatim from an Aug. 7 satirical article on Bustatroll.org, a website known for publishing fictional content in the name of satire.
9: The Bustatroll.org story shares the same headline, too.
10: Some social media users were fooled into thinking the threat reported on Trump Train Pro News was real.
11: It’s not.

gpt4: The claim that quotes Senator Kamala Harris saying "After we impeach, we round up the Trump supporters" is false[0].
The quote has been circulated by several outlets, the latest being Trump Train Pro News, but there's no record of Harris making such a statement[1].
This fictitious quote seems to be based on a satirical article published on Bustatroll.org on August 7, which was falsely represented as a factual report[8].
The identical claim had also been debunked in November[6].
Therefore, it's safe to conclude that this assertion lacks substantial grounds and is not authentic.

ced3563397491cc5bc36a0aaea98d2f7.claim: Sanders’ “Medicare for All” plan ""would cost more than the entire federal budget that we spend now."""
ced3563397491cc5bc36a0aaea98d2f7.label: false
ced3563397491cc5bc36a0aaea98d2f7.passage:
0: During the Feb. 7 Democratic presidential debate, former Vice President Joe Biden once again questioned the price tag of "Medicare for All," the single-payer health care proposal championed by one of his key rivals, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
1: Biden argued that the plan was fiscally irresponsible and would require raising middle-class taxes.
2: Specifically, he claimed, the plan "would cost more than the entire federal budget that we spend now."
3: Medicare for All’s price — and whether it’s worth it ― is a subject of fierce discussion among Democratic presidential candidates.
4: But we had never heard this figure before.
5: It caught our attention, so we decided to dig in.
6: Biden’s campaign directed us to the 2018 federal budget, which totaled $4.1 trillion.
7: It compared that amount to the estimated cost of Sanders’ single-payer proposal: between $30 trillion and $40 trillion over a decade.
8: The math, they said, shows Medicare for All would cost more than the national budget.
9: But it turns out, based on the numbers and interviews with independent experts, Biden’s comparison of Medicare for All’s price to total federal spending misses the mark because the calculation is flawed.
10: The numbers Sanders has said publicly that economists estimate Medicare for All would cost somewhere between $30 trillion and $40 trillion over 10 years.
11: Research by the nonpartisan Urban Institute, a Washington D.C. think tank, puts the figure in the $32 trillion to $34 trillion range.
12: We pointed out to Biden’s campaign that comparing 10-year spending estimates to one-year budgets is like comparing apples to oranges.
13: The campaign suggested that if you take 10 times the current federal budget, you get a figure smaller than the estimated cost of Medicare for All over that 10-year window.
14: That calculation would lead you to multiply $4.1 trillion by 10 to get $41.1 trillion.
15: That result is close to the high mark Sanders set for his program’s cost but well above the $34 trillion that Urban researchers projected.
16: Still, that’s not the correct way to formulate a comparison, experts say.
17: "That’s not good math," said Marc Goldwein, the senior vice president and senior policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
18: "That’s taking a 2018 number, and multiplying it by 10, whereas the $34 trillion is a 10-year number that assumes a lot of growth."
19: What you would need to do is add up the Congressional Budget Office’s projected budget outlays from 2020 to 2029, and compare the sum to the Medicare for All spending figure.
20: So we spoke to Linda Blumberg, an institute fellow at Urban’s Health Policy Center, who arrived at the $34 trillion estimate.
21: She ran the CBO’s numbers: The next 10 years of on-budget outlay, the government office projects, add up to $44.8 trillion.
22: To be clear, $34 trillion (34 followed by 12 zeros) is no small sum.
23: It accounts for about 75% of that nearly $45 trillion budget estimate and would represent a bigger single increase to the federal budget than we’ve ever experienced, Blumberg said.
24: That raises one point on which Biden may have some ground.
25: Goldwein argued that you would indeed need significant tax increases to finance the Sanders proposal.
26: But its price tag still would be less than the projected budget.
27: "If he said [Medicare for All] was as big as the current federal budget, that would be incorrect," Blumberg said.
28: Goldwein looked at the numbers another way: Including interest, he found, the federal budget would consume about $55 trillion between now and 2030.
29: Again, that’s more than what Medicare for All would cost during the same period.
30: Big picture: No matter how you slice Biden’s math, his numbers are off.
31: "If what he said was Medicare for All will cost as much as the entire rest of the budget, that would be fair," Goldwein said.
32: But that’s not the same thing.

gpt4: The claim that Sanders' "Medicare for All" plan would "cost more than the entire federal budget that we spend now" is erroneous.
The narrative was initially presented by Joe Biden, but his comparison was deemed inaccurate due to a flawed calculation[2].
Comparing 10-year spending estimates to one-year budgets constitute an error of comparison, as it is akin to comparing apples to oranges[12].

This method involves using a 2018 number and multiplying it by ten while the $34 trillion estimate for "Medicare for All" is calculated for a 10-year term taking into account significant growth[17][18].

The correct way to approach this calculation would involve summing up the Congressional Budget Office's projected budget outlays from 2020 to 2029 and then comparing the total to the estimated expenditure for "Medicare for All"[19].
Notably, this sum would still be less than the projected federal budget[26].
Therefore, an assertion that "Medicare for All" would cost as much as the current federal budget would be incorrect[27].

8d4be55e4176091d498e180d5e3fcdec.claim: Gov. Tony Evers ""proposed raising taxes on the agriculture industry to pay for expanded welfare programs."""
8d4be55e4176091d498e180d5e3fcdec.label: half-true
8d4be55e4176091d498e180d5e3fcdec.passage:
0: Wisconsin’s struggling farms were front and center in Gov.
1: Tony Evers’ State of the State address.
2: He celebrated the state’s identity as America’s Dairyland.
3: He bemoaned the loss of family farms in recent years.
4: And he called for a special session of the Legislature to consider a package of agricultural bills.
5: All of which one Republican leader claimed was disingenuous.
6: "Governor Evers’ sudden concern for rural Wisconsin and our agriculture industry is ironic given that just a year ago he proposed raising taxes on the agriculture industry to pay for expanded welfare programs," state Rep. John Nygren , chairman of the powerful Joint Finance Committee, said Jan. 22, 2020 on Twitter and in a later news release .
7: "No amount of rhetoric can cover his failed record of putting rural Wisconsin and our farmer(s) behind liberal special interests."
8: The budget claims from the Marinette Republican caught our eye.
9: Did Evers really try to raise taxes on agriculture to fund welfare?
10: Agriculture affected, but not directly Defending Nygren’s claim, his chief of staff Nathan Schwanz pointed to proposed changes to the Manufacturing and Agriculture Tax Credit.
11: Evers’ budget explicitly changed only half of that credit.
12: He proposed limiting the credit for manufacturing to $300,000 per tax year.
13: But the budget added, "The Governor also recommends leaving the agricultural portion of the credit unchanged compared to current law."
14: The changes would have reduced the tax credit — i.e.
15: raised taxes — by a total of $289 million in 2020 and $237 million in 2021.
16: Schwanz said the proposed cut still would have been a blow to agriculture, however, pointing to a Legislative Fiscal Bureau memo from February 2019.
17: The nonpartisan agency, responding to a request from Nygren, found about 25% of the manufacturing and agriculture tax credits in 2018-19 went to manufacturers "where agricultural products are the primary input."
18: Those were manufacturers of food, beverages, tobacco and basic chemicals.
19: So Evers didn’t propose any direct tax increases to agriculture, but his proposed changes for manufacturers would have reduced their income.
20: Nygren’s argument is that would have then affected agricultural producers by limiting the amount of product manufacturers took in.
21: Budget dynamics a factor in claim Nygren also connected these cuts to welfare.
22: Evers’ proposed budget increased spending for welfare programs, so Schwanz said the proposed cuts to the manufacturing and agriculture credit were among the changes needed to offset that.
23: He summed up the logic this way: "There is no doubt that the Governor’s budget increased General Fund taxes.
24: There is no doubt that his budget expanded welfare and that these tax increases were needed to pay for it."
25: So there’s no direct link between the manufacturing tax credit and welfare.
26: That is, Evers didn’t propose earmarking the credit savings for a welfare program.
27: But broadly speaking, a cut in one area does affect the ability to increase spending in another.
28: The manufacturing tax credit is paid from the General Fund, which is used for all manner of welfare programs.
29: It’s an approach to budgeting that is used by fiscal bureau analysts and others, including Evers.
30: For example, in his 2017 annual education address, Evers, then the schools superintendent, said, "Every dollar we shift from the state coffers to pay for roads, and increasingly, to simply pay for debt, is a dollar we move out of the classroom of a child," the Wisconsin State Journal reported in a Sept. 22, 2017 article.

gpt4: The claim that Governor Tony Evers proposed raising taxes on the agriculture industry to pay for expanded welfare programs is partially accurate.

It is true that Nathan Schwanz, chief of staff for Nygren, stated that Evers had suggested alterations to the Manufacturing and Agriculture Tax Credit, implying an impact on the agriculture sector[10].
However, the suggested changes were primarily targeting the manufacturing industry, not aiming to directly increase taxes on agriculture[19].
Further, Evers's budget specifically urged for the agricultural portion of this credit to remain unaltered[13].

The implication that these changes were proposed to fund expanded welfare programs is suggested because Evers’ budget did propose increased spending on welfare[22], but there is no direct evidence that reductions in the credit would be specifically allocated to fund these welfare programs[26].

4287909591054c0d6c8bf51f69edc6ad.claim: Bill Murray said, “So if we lie to the government, it’s a felony. But if they lie to us it's politics.”
4287909591054c0d6c8bf51f69edc6ad.label: false
4287909591054c0d6c8bf51f69edc6ad.passage:
0: Are we reliving the same day over and over , or are people still sharing apocryphal Bill Murray quotes?
1: Very nearly a year ago, in 2019, we debunked the claim that Murray said the best way to teach kids about taxes is to eat a third of their ice cream.
2: Now, the actor is allegedly weighing in on politics.
3: "So, if we lie to the government, it’s a felony," reads the quote attributed to Murray in this Jan. 26 Facebook post .
4: "But if they lie to us its (sic) politics."
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: Searching online for the quote’s origins, we found no credible source crediting Murray.
8: Barry Popik, an etymologist who studies the origins of terms , has a 2011 post on his website exploring a similar quote: "If we lie to Congress, it’s a felony and if Congress lies to us it’s just politics."
9: According to Popik, Ken Huber wrote that line in an editorial published in the Iosco County News Herald in 2010.
10: Similar sentiments are older, Popkik says in the post, dating back to the late 1980s.
11: But he doesn’t mention Bill Murray.
12: In 2013, however, a parody Bill Murray Twitter account tweeted the quote that appears in the Facebook post, right down to the misspelling of "it’s."
13: "I AM NOT BILL MURRAY," reads the account’s bio.
14: "This is a parody account.
15: This account is not in any way affiliated with the actor Bill Murray."
16: We rate this Facebook post False.

gpt4: The claim that Bill Murray said “So if we lie to the government, it’s a felony.
But if they lie to us it's politics” is false.
The quote actually originated from a parody Bill Murray Twitter account that tweeted the exact quote, including the same grammatical error, back in 2013[12].
This account clearly states in its bio, "I AM NOT BILL MURRAY," emphasizing that it does not stand as a reliable source for the actor's quotes[13].
Furthermore, a comprehensive online search for the origin of this quote did not yield any credible source attributing it to Murray, further evidencing that this claim is not accurate[7].

1541f45a13b29bc0b6f049ca9d5e1cbc.claim: “Colorado school forces students to wear hijabs.”
1541f45a13b29bc0b6f049ca9d5e1cbc.label: false
1541f45a13b29bc0b6f049ca9d5e1cbc.passage:
0: For several years now some Americans have voiced concerns that Islam is creeping into public education .
1: The headline of a recent blog post exploits those fears.
2: "Colorado school forces students to wear hijabs," reads the headline of the Jan. 30 post , which was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: But students were not mandated to "wear hijabs" in the classroom.
5: Even the blog post goes on to say that the Douglas County School District in the Centennial State "informed parents that students would be attending a field trip to the Colorado Muslim Society’s Majif Abu Bakar as well as a synagogue and Greek Orthodox cathedral."
6: Students were instructed to wear "appropriate long pants," the story says, while female students were also told they "must bring scarves or hooded sweatshirts for the mosque."
7: Here’s what you need to know.
8: First, though the blog post being shared on Facebook is from 2020, this story originates in January 2015.
9: That’s when Rocky Heights Middle School in the Douglas County School District offered a voluntary field trip to a Greek Orthodox church, a Jewish temple and a mosque as part of a social studies class about world religions.
10: "It is not mandatory," the school’s principal, Mike Loitz, said in a statement to clarify misinformation about the field trip at the time.
11: "If the decision is made to not participate in a field trip, alternative educational opportunities are provided."
12: Students who choose to attend, Loitz said, "are expected to respect the dress code of the host facility."
13: The school said "all students must wear appropriate long pants.
14: Ankles must be covered.
15: Girls must bring wide scarves or hooded sweatshirts for the mosque."
16: The blog post correctly reported that but its headline gives a different impression, leading readers to believe that a Colorado school district was requiring all female students to wear a Muslim veil.
17: (As this New York Times story explains , "hijab" is not described as an article of clothing in the Koran, but as something like a curtain or "separation" that provides privacy.)
18: What really happened: a Colorado middle school asked female students attending a voluntary field trip to wear cover their heads with a scarf or sweatshirt to abide by the dress code of the mosque they would visit.

gpt4: The claim that a Colorado school forced students to wear hijabs is false.

Dissecting the details, it is true that students were instructed to wear "appropriate long pants" and that female students were also advised to bring "scarves or hooded sweatshirts for the mosque"[6].
However, this was part of respecting the dress code of the host facility during a field trip [12].
Further, it was not a directive targeted at normal classroom setup as students were not required to "wear hijabs" while in the classroom [4].
The school's principal, Mike Loitz, emphasized that the dress code for the field trip was not mandatory[10].
The misunderstanding comes from a blog post with a misleading headline that seemed to suggest that all female students in a Colorado school district were required to wear a Muslim veil [16].

01b31ccada683c73a1d2c991e5d1b1e5.claim: a teenage Pete Buttigieg was arrested in the late 1990s for killing dogs.
01b31ccada683c73a1d2c991e5d1b1e5.label: false
01b31ccada683c73a1d2c991e5d1b1e5.passage:
0: Former South Bend, Ind., mayor Pete Buttigieg is the first openly gay candidate to run for president.
1: He’s also a veteran, a millennial, an Episcopalian and left-handed.
2: But is he a dog killer?
3: No.
4: A fake newspaper clipping, sometimes alongside a photo of a teenage Buttigieg, is going around the internet claiming he was arrested in the late 1990s for killing several dogs.
5: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Several Facebook posts shared the clip and asked: "Why won’t anyone discuss why a teenage Buttigieg strangled 5 dogs?"
6: But the "story" was created using the Newspaper Clipping Generator , an online tool that allows people to produce images of news snippets.
7: In this case, the clip implicates a real news source, the South Bend Tribune, which never published the story.
8: These posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: The phony clip shows an Aug. 30, 1998, date and a headline that reads: "Teen Arrested for Dog Slayin."
11: The snippet says "local teen, Peter Buttigieg, has been arrested on suspicion of the recent killings of at least 5 dogs."
12: The clipping’s creator first shared it on Twitter on Feb. 8 ; it has amassed thousands of retweets.
13: The user, @ComradeCrow, has repeatedly said the story is fake and was intended as a joke.
14: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The Buttigieg campaign did not respond to comment on the fake article, but the South Bend Tribune published a response and said "everything about the image screamed bogus."
15: "Even though that Twitter user admitted Sunday night he intended the fabrication as a joke, The Tribune was still receiving calls and messages Monday afternoon hoping to verify the story.
16: Some thanked us for clarifying it; others angrily denounced us for ‘covering up for Pete,’ " the newspaper wrote .
17: "So let’s just make this perfectly clear: The Tribune did not publish the story making the rounds."

gpt4: The claim that Pete Buttigieg was arrested as a teenager in the late 1990s for killing dogs is false[4].
This claim originated from a fake newspaper clipping disseminated online, which was often posted alongside a photo of a teenage Buttigieg [4].
The counterfeit news story was created using an online tool known as the Newspaper Clipping Generator, which allows individuals to design images of fictitious news snippets [6].
Moreover, the user who originally posted the pretend story, @ComradeCrow, has confirmed on several occasions that the claim was intended to be a joke [13].

This assertion is further supported by the South Bend Tribune, which concluded, "everything about the image screamed bogus."[14] The Buttigieg campaign did not respond to requests for comment on the bogus article, but it's clear that the claim has been disproven and lacks credibility.

a358475f3d7174272c5abfec8a6ac019.claim: An Alton, Ill., man caught a 736-pound Giant Mekong catfish in the Mississippi River.
a358475f3d7174272c5abfec8a6ac019.label: false
a358475f3d7174272c5abfec8a6ac019.passage:
0: An Illinois man’s quest to salvage his grandfather’s reputation led him to catch a 736-pound catfish.
1: That’s according to a four-year-old story that has gotten a lot of recent traffic on Facebook , despite its astonishing claim that this massive fish has been swimming in Mississippi waters for at least 114 years. "
2: Alton resident catches 736-pound catfish in Mississippi River ," reads the headline on the story from Riverbender.com, which appears to share news and headlines from Alton, Ill.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: According to the story, 114 years passed between the time in 1902 when a man named "Red Mudger...discovered the biggest catfish ever known to man" and the day in 2016 when his grandson, Kato "Mudcat" Mudger, felt a tug at his fishing line that turned out to be a 170-year-old Mekong giant catfish — the same one his grandfather had seen in 1902.
6: A couple things stand out about this claim: First, the article was published April 1, 2016, making it likely April Fools’ Day fodder.
7: Second, a picture accompanying the story has been doctored.
8: It shows the supposed 736-pound catfish lying on the ground.
9: Next to it, a fisherman’s torso and legs can be seen, giving the viewer a sense of scale for the giant catfish.
10: But the original fish photo was published in a Smithsonian article from Sept. 25, 2015, and credited to the U.S.
11: Fish and Wildlife Service.
12: The Smithsonian photo shows no sign of a human standing next to the fish and the caption under the picture identifies the fish as a flathead catfish, not a giant Mekong catfish, as the Riverbender story suggests.
13: Flathead catfish are native to the Mississippi River, but they don’t grow heavier than 123 pounds or longer than 5 feet according to FishBase .
14: Mekong catfish can grow to be 650 pounds , which is closer to 736 pounds, but they have never been seen outside of Southeast Asia’s Mekong River.
15: They are endemic to the area and are also categorized as critically endangered .
16: At PolitiFact, we’ve seen before that people get excited about seemingly giant fish , but we have to categorize this story as a tall (and heavy) tale.

gpt4: The claim that a man from Alton, Ill., caught a 736-pound Giant Mekong catfish in the Mississippi River is unequivocally fraudulent.
Several factors decisively undermine the authenticity of the story.
Firstly, the photograph that accompanied the narrative has been manipulated, evident by alterations to the original picture [7].
The legitimate photograph was initially published in a 2015 Smithsonian article, which credits the image to the U.S [10].

Unlike the spurious version, the authentic Smithsonian photo does not depict any human next to the fish, and categorically identifies the fish as a flathead catfish, contradicting the Alton, Ill. man's claim of catching a giant Mekong catfish[12].

Further contradicting the story is the fact that Flathead catfish are native species to the Mississippi River and they are not known to exceed 123 pounds or a length greater than 5 feet, as per FishBase [13].

While giant Mekong catfish have a potential to reach considerable weights upwards of 650 pounds, which is somewhat close to the 736 pounds claimed, these types of fish are geographically exclusive to Southeast Asia's Mekong River and have never been sighted outside of this area[14].
Given this compelling evidence, the veracity of the man's claim is demonstrably false.

faaf14b073c04698cdafebd33f96cd43.claim: a photo shows Joe Biden groping a woman.
faaf14b073c04698cdafebd33f96cd43.label: false
faaf14b073c04698cdafebd33f96cd43.passage:
0: Former Vice President Joe Biden’s presidential campaign has been dogged by allegations that he inappropriately touches women, perhaps explaining why an old, altered photo is now appearing in some social media feeds.
1: "Gropin’ Joe Biden with a woman not his wife," reads the text of a 2017 Facebook post sharing an image that appears to show Biden grabbing a woman’s chest as they pose for a photo.
2: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The real photo from a 2013 holiday party when Biden was vice president shows him with his hands on the waist of Hill reporter Amie Parnes.
5: The image went viral then as Biden drew criticism for how high his hands were — the Daily Caller headline said : "Vice President Joe Biden gropes White House reporter."
6: The World News Bureau, which posts fake news stories, published an article with the doctored photo that appears in the Facebook post.
7: A bottle of Wild Turkey bourbon was also edited into the image so that it appears to be sticking out of his pocket.

gpt4: The claim that a photo exists showing Joe Biden groping a woman is false.
The photo in question, that was shared in a 2017 Facebook post, has been found to be manipulated [1].
In reality, the original photo captured at a 2013 holiday party during Biden's vice-presidential tenure, shows him with his hands on the waist of Hill reporter, Amie Parnes [4].
The image was later distorted by the World News Bureau, known for publishing fake news stories, resulting in the misleading impression visible in the Facebook post [6].

064c274a8b7c7f2a715d9a5c0d39857d.claim: “When using a medical mask you’re supposed to use… white side out (this is the filter part) for when you’re not sick.”
064c274a8b7c7f2a715d9a5c0d39857d.label: false
064c274a8b7c7f2a715d9a5c0d39857d.passage:
0: Don’t take your medical advice from Facebook.
1: It could leave you with the wrong instructions for wearing a medical mask.
2: A Facebook post claimed that a doctor’s office had received the "proper directions" from a mask manufacturer on how to wear medical masks.
3: The post includes two pictures of how to wear the medical masks and explains that you should wear the colored side of the mask on the outside when you are sick and the white side on the outside when you are healthy.
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: We checked in with PriMED, one of the leading medical mask producers.
7: On its FAQ page , it says that "the color always faces out" on a medical mask.
8: The Center for Health Protection , which was established in Hong Kong during the SARS outbreak in 2004, also advises wearers to wear the colored side on the outside.
9: While the Facebook post said that the white side of the mask contains a filter, the center’s illustration of the three-layer design medical mask explains that the white layer is for moisture absorption from your mouth and nose.
10: The San Francisco Department of Public Health ’s website also said that "the colored side of the mask is usually the front and should face away from you, while the white side touches your face."
11: So remember: color-side out, whether you are healthy or sick.
12: One more thing: Americans looking to buy a medical mask to protect themselves against the 2019 novel coronavirus, or COVID-19, should know it isn’t generally necessary .
13: The New York Times interviewed medical care professionals that explained that hoarding medical masks because of the 2019 novel coronavirus panic can lead to shortages in hospitals, clinics, and doctor’s offices.
14: The CDC determined the immediate health risk to Americans as low .
15: Anyways, colored side out.

gpt4: The claim stating that when using a medical mask the white side should be out when not sick is false.
Evidence provided by various sources refutes this statement.
A Facebook post stated that a doctor's office received clear "proper directions" from a mask manufacturer on how to correctly wear medical masks, with pictures attached [2].
The post described that the colored side of the mask should be worn on the outside whether you're sick or healthy[3].
Additionally, the mask manufacturer's FAQ page further clarified that "the color always faces out" on a medical mask, further debunking the claim [7].
The Center for Health Protection in Hong Kong and the San Francisco Department of Public Health’s website have also recommended that the colored side of the mask should be facing outwards [8][10].
These pieces of information collectively invalidate the claim in question.

64023faf0bb8905b09560c5e10bfd116.claim: Elizabeth Warren, asked about the Mollie Tibbetts murder, said “I know this is hard for her family, but they have to remember that we need to focus on real problems, like illegal immigrants not being able to see their kids.”
64023faf0bb8905b09560c5e10bfd116.label: false
64023faf0bb8905b09560c5e10bfd116.passage:
0: The 2018 murder of Mollie Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student, and the subsequent arrest of an undocumented immigrant became a flashpoint in the immigration debate.
1: Strong feelings over the tragedy have targeted Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren.
2: One Facebook post highly and misleadingly edited Warren’s comments about the Tibbetts murder.
3: The post includes two pictures of Tibbetts and has this text: "So Elizabeth Warren was asked about Mollie Tibbetts being murdered by an illegal immigrant…..
4: Her reply was: ‘I know this is hard for her family, but they have to remember that we need to focus on real problems like illegal immigrants not being able to see their kids’ Let that sink in."
5: Anyone reading that could easily see Warren as dismissive of a murder.
6: But that post chopped up her actual response and changed her meaning.
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: In a Aug. 22, 2018, interview, CNN anchor John Berman asked Warren this question: "Mike Pence and the president have suggested the immigration laws need to be stronger so that people like this man who was accused of this murder were not in the country.
10: Your reaction?"
11: Here’s what Warren actually said.
12: (The bolded words are the ones used in the Facebook post.)
13: "I'm so sorry for the family and I know this is hard , not only for the family , but for the people in her community, the people throughout Iowa. "
14: But one of the things we have to remember is we need an immigration system that is effective, that focus es on where real problems are.
15: "Last month, I went down to the border and I saw where children had been taken away from their mothers, I met with those mothers who had been lied to, who didn't know where their children were, who hadn't had a chance to talk to their children, and there was no plan for how they would be reunified with their children.
16: "I think we need immigration laws that focus on people who pose a real threat and I don't think mamas and babies are the place we should be spending our resources.
17: Separating a mama from a baby does not make this country safer."
18: Out of the 157 words Warren said, the post used 16 (17 if you count its shift of "focuses" to "focus").
19: It added words she didn’t say, such as "illegal immigrants not being able to see their kids."
20: It added small words, such as "they" to have her purported quote make grammatical sense and match the meaning the people behind the post wanted to create.
21: The Facebook version omits Warren’s words about focusing "on people who pose a real threat."
22: Warren contrasted enforcement that targets those who have or might commit violence, and enforcement that separates small children from their parents — the " zero tolerance " policy under the Trump administration in 2018.

gpt4: The claim that Elizabeth Warren made the statement, “I know this is hard for her family, but they have to remember that we need to focus on real problems, like illegal immigrants not being able to see their kids,” in response to a question about the Mollie Tibbetts murder is false.
This claim appears to have originated from a highly and misleadingly edited Facebook post that significantly altered Warren’s actual remarks about the incident[2][6].
The Facebook post used only 16 of the original 157 words spoken by Warren, and these chosen words were taken out of context while also manipulating her actual intent[18].
To make the presented quote grammatically correct and fit the misleading narrative, it added minor words like "they"[20].
Furthermore, important parts of Warren's actual response were omitted, such as her comment about concentrating on "people who pose a real threat"[21].
Therefore, the Facebook post significantly misrepresented Senator Warren's response to the Tibbetts murder by altering her meaning and context[11].

339fe1cc78f0b452b53ee3ee05f0316f.claim: “We’ve also seen in the time that he’s (Donald Trump) been president, an increase in carbon emissions going absolutely in the wrong way.”
339fe1cc78f0b452b53ee3ee05f0316f.label: half-true
339fe1cc78f0b452b53ee3ee05f0316f.passage:
0: During a House committee hearing on President Donald Trump’s budget proposal, U.S. Rep. Jan Schakowsky questioned the White House’s acting budget director on major cuts Trump’s plan would make to the Environmental Protection Agency.
1: "Does this budget propose cutting funding for the Environmental Protection Agency?"
2: Schakowsky, an Evanston Democrat, asked Acting Director of the Office of Management and Budget Russell Vought.
3: "It proposes a cut to EPA by about 26% and we believe that we will still be able to fulfill the statutory responsibilities of clean air, clean water, clean —" Vought said, before Schakowsky interjected with a claim that caught our attention: "We’ve also seen in the time that he’s been president, an increase in carbon emissions going absolutely in the wrong way," she said.
4: In 2018, PolitiFact rated Half True a claim from Trump’s EPA that greenhouse emissions were down under the president, finding that while emissions were continuing to fall, the rate of decline had slowed during Trump’s first year in office.
5: The data at that time did not show emissions were rising.
6: So we wanted to find out whether more recent figures support Schakowsky’s claim that emissions have increased under Trump, and whether the changes suggest a trend going "in the wrong way."
7: Overall, emissions are indeed up from 2016 levels following a spike in 2018.
8: After that, carbon emissions again began to decline.
9: Experts interviewed say those incremental changes may have nothing to do with Trump policies.
10: A sharp rise, followed by another drop In response to our inquiry, a spokesman for Schakowsky’s office pointed to reports highlighting a 2018 spike in U.S. carbon dioxide emissions following three years of declines.
11: A report published in May 2019 by the Rhodium Group, an independent research firm, estimated CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion rose 2.7% in 2018.
12: It was the second-largest annual increase since 2000, the group reported, though somewhat smaller than an estimate it made earlier in the year based on preliminary data.
13: The largest increase occurred in 2010 under then-President Barack Obama as the economy began its rebound from the recession, according to the group.
14: In a draft report released this month, the EPA noted a similar uptick in 2018 CO2 emissions, which comprise the vast majority of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.
15: So Schakowsky is correct there was a spike in carbon emissions on Trump’s watch.
16: In 2019, however, U.S. carbon dioxide emissions fell again, according to several recent international reports .
17: And that drop was not a surprise.
18: Indeed, the preliminary Rhodium report for 2018 noted that while the pace of U.S. emissions decline had slowed since 2016, the group did not "expect a repeat" increase the following year.
19: To address that point, Schakowsky’s office sent us a Scientific American article speculating the decline identified in one of the international reports could be "overly optimistic" and a Washington Post story highlighting the Rhodium Group’s lukewarm preliminary findings for U.S. emissions in 2019.
20: While a significant decline in coal consumption last year helped drive the overall drop, Rhodium noted, the United States made little progress in other areas.
21: By their accounting, net greenhouse gas emissions remained slightly higher in 2019 than at the end of 2016.
22: "There are low-cost technology solutions to reduce oil and gas methane emissions," the Rhodium report said.
23: "But their deployment at scale requires strengthening regulations that the Trump Administration instead has been weakening."
