24: It’s also worth noting Rhodium did not attribute any of the emissions changes seen so far to the Trump administration, which has made eliminating federal environmental regulations a priority.
25: Instead, both Rhodium and the federal government pegged the 2018 increase to fluctuations in weather, which drove up heating and cooling needs, and to increased economic growth.
26: "Overall there has indeed been an increase (or at best little or no change) in carbon emissions since Trump has been president," said John Nielsen-Gammon, a climatologist at Texas A&M University, in an email response.
27: "Whether Trump’s policies have had any significant positive or negative effect on U.S. carbon emissions is a separate question."

gpt4: The claim stating that there has been an increase in carbon emissions during Donald Trump's presidency is partially accurate.
U.S carbon emissions did spike in 2018, validating the claim up to that point [7][15].
Yet, the claim does not mention that in 2019, U.S carbon emissions actually decreased, as reported by several international reports [16].
Although there has been an overall increase in emissions during Trump's presidency, the statement did not acknowledge this temporal fluctuation [26].

Additionally, while the Trump administration prioritized eliminating federal environmental regulations, Rhodium, a leading environmental think tank, states that the changes in emissions observed during his presidency cannot be directly attributed to his administration [24].

a0f636588f6a5ed0544c513bc9498445.claim: “Michigan prosecutor looks to release 90 convicted murderers serving life sentences.”
a0f636588f6a5ed0544c513bc9498445.label: false
a0f636588f6a5ed0544c513bc9498445.passage:
0: A Facebook post links to an article that makes an alarming claim about convicted murderers being released from prison: "Michigan prosecutor looks to release 90 convicted murderers serving life sentences" reads the headline on a website called "Law Enforcement Today."
1: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: We’re going to sound an alarm of our own about this post.
4: Overstating prosecutor’s intent The article is about Ingham County Prosecutor Carol Siemon, a Democrat elected in 2016 who campaigned on making progressive changes in the criminal justice system.
5: She previously served for 11 years as an assistant prosecutor in the office.
6: The headline of the article, which blasts Siemon as being "on a mission to empty her community’s local prison," suggests that the prosecutor wants to free the 90 killers and is moving to do so.
7: But the article itself says only that Siemon will begin a review of the 90 cases.
8: The article is based on a story from City Pulse, a news operation based in Lansing, the state capital, which is located partly in Ingham County.
9: (The county seat, Mason, is about 15 miles away.)
10: But the article’s headline goes further, suggesting that the prosecutor is seeking the release of 90 inmates.
11: City Pulse reported: "Siemon — with pro-bono help from former Assistant Attorney General Ron Emery — this year plans to begin a formal review of the 90 convicted murderers serving life in prison without parole in Ingham County.
12: And for a select few, she said she plans to seek a gubernatorial commutation that could get them back out on the streets.
13: Siemon makes a clarification In Michigan, only the governor has the power to commute the inmates’ sentences, if they are recommended for release by the state Parole Board, according to Siemon and news reports .
14: Several days after the City Pulse story was published, Siemon released a statement saying she regretted not speaking beforehand to the families of people who could be affected by her decision to review the cases.
15: But she said she would go ahead with her review, which would focus on cases from the 1970s and 1980s.
16: "I regret that I did not fully take into account the impact on victims and their families when I prematurely discussed the concept of reviewing older cases of life-without-parole," Siemon said.
17: "My intent has always been that the victim’s families or their representatives would get their first notice from trained professionals in our office after any review and before offering support or opposition to any application to commute a sentence.

gpt4: The claim that a Michigan prosecutor, Carol Siemon, is planning to release 90 convicted murderers serving life sentences is not accurate[4].
This allegation seems to primarily stem from a misinterpretation of an article's headline, which implies that Siemon is working to clear out her community's local prison[6].

However, the actual content of the article only mentions that Siemon, who was elected in 2016 and promotes progressive changes in the criminal justice system, will begin a review of these 90 cases[7][4].
She clarified that she is not empowered to commute sentences, a prerogative that rests solely in the hands of the Michigan governor, and only if the state's Parole Board recommends release[13].
Siemon's own words suggest that her review would concentrate on cases from the 1970s and 1980s[15].

1a48a50600650b62e10587f5a6356255.label: false
1a48a50600650b62e10587f5a6356255.passage:
0: A blog post from Nov. 11, 2019, claimed that Dinesh D’Souza, a conservative writer and filmmaker, was found dead in his home two days prior.
1: The post included a vulgar description of how his body was found and an inaccurate representation of his relationship with media mogul Rupert Murdock.
2: D'Souza, however, is very much still alive.
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The day after this blog post was published on a website that appears to be called both " AMERICA NEWS TODAY " and " environmentdepth.org ," D'Souza appeared as a guest on President Donald Trump’s re-election campaign show, "Real News Insights," to discuss the news coverage of the raid that killed Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
6: More recently, D’Souza was on Fox’s "The Ingraham Angle" covering a rally for Democratic presidential hopeful Mike Bloomberg and discussing the controversy surrounding stop-and-frisk policies on Feb. 14, 2020.
7: D'Souza also remains very active on Twitter and has been promoting his new book and documentary release since the beginning of February 2020 .
8: D’Souza is a popular pundit with a dedicated following whose death would certainly merit some legitimate news coverage, of which there has been none.

gpt4: The claim that Dinesh D'Souza has passed away is false.
Evidence shows that D'Souza is very much alive[2].
Further confirmation of his survival evidence is his recent appearance as a guest on President Donald Trump’s re-election campaign show, "Real News Insights," the day after the claim was made[5].

D’Souza also featured on Fox’s "The Ingraham Angle" providing coverage for a rally for Democratic presidential hopeful Mike Bloomberg and discussing the controversy surrounding stop-and-frisk policies on Feb. 14, 2020[6].
Moreover, he continues to be active on Twitter and has been actively promoting his new book and documentary release since early 2020[7].

d1391dd1854921395bb9ca5a11d2ec71.claim: Mike Bloomberg is “a candidate who in 2015 stated, and I quote: ‘I, for example, am not in favor, have never been in favor of raising the minimum wage.’”
d1391dd1854921395bb9ca5a11d2ec71.label: true
d1391dd1854921395bb9ca5a11d2ec71.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders welcomed Democratic rival Mike Bloomberg into the thick of the presidential primary with a slew of attacks on the former New York City mayor’s moderate record.
1: Speaking at a gathering of Democrats in Nevada, Sanders contrasted his own consistent support for raising the minimum wage with Bloomberg’s on-the-record opposition.
2: "We will not defeat Donald Trump with a candidate who in 2015 stated, and I quote: ‘I, for example, am not in favor, have never been in favor of raising the minimum wage,’" Sanders said .
3: We wondered if that was true, and it is.
4: It’s worth clarifying that this is no longer Bloomberg’s position in 2020 .
5: Bloomberg supports raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour, up from $7.25, putting him in line with the rest of his primary opponents .
6: RELATED: Who led the way for a $15 minimum wage in New York?
7: RELATED: Fact-checking Bernie Sanders on a $15 minimum wage Bloomberg preferred tax credit to wage hike In 2015, Bloomberg spoke against raising the minimum wage : "I, for example, am not in favor, have never been in favor of raising the minimum wage," Bloomberg said on the Bloomberg TV channel .
8: (Sanders quoted him accurately.)
9: Bloomberg went on to describe what he would support: raising the Earned Income Tax Credit.
10: Doing so, he said, would reduce the burden on employers and protect jobs.
11: "I think you should raise the income tax credit, which does the same thing for the same people, but it spreads the burden across all the taxpayers rather than just a small number of businesspeople whose inclination would be to cut back employment.
12: Earned Income Tax Credit doesn’t get anybody to cut back, it gets them to hire more people."
13: The federal Earned Income Tax Credit reduces taxes for low- and moderate-income working people.
14: About 29 states have passed their own earned-income tax credit.
15: While mayor in 2004, Bloomberg signed legislation starting a local tax credit .
16: In 2018, Bloomberg again called for using the tax credit rather than hiking the minimum wage.
17: During an interview with Christine Lagarde of the International Monetary Fund, he repeated his concern that a hike in the minimum wage would lead to job losses.
18: (The Congressional Budget Office has found far more people would receive wage hikes than likely lose their jobs under a national increase to $15 an hour.)
19: Bloomberg’s support for the tax credit rather than a rise in the minimum wage is shared by some experts .
20: However, others say the two policies can work in tandem , and both could help poor workers.
21: While Bloomberg spoke broadly against a minimum wage increase, in 2012 he did support raising the minimum wage in New York to $8.25 an hour.
22: Also, Bloomberg had a mixed record on living-wage proposals to lift wages of certain workers who were employed by entities that had city contracts.
23: When Bloomberg opposed such measures, he raised concerns about the cost for the city or the impact on economic development .
24: Bloomberg now supports $15 minimum wage During his 2020 campaign for president , Bloomberg has called for raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour.
25: He also calls for enhancing the tax credit.
26: Bloomberg’s labor plan says he will sign the Raise the Wage Act , which would raise the minimum wage gradually over six years to $15 an hour.
27: The bill passed the House in July 2019 and has not had a vote in the Senate.
28: The Bloomberg campaign did not explain the change of position.
29: Bloomberg has not publicly addressed it, as far as we can tell.

gpt4: The claim that Mike Bloomberg stated in 2015 "I, for example, am not in favor, have never been in favor of raising the minimum wage" is true, as confirmed by independent fact-checking [3].

The quote was accurately cited by Bernie Sanders during an address to Democrats in Nevada, as part of a wider comparison highlighting the differences in their respective positions on raising the minimum wage [1][8].
Bloomberg's opposition to increasing the minimum wage is well documented; for instance, in 2018 he reiterated his preference for utilizing tax credits over wage hikes [16].
However, it should be noted that in 2012, Bloomberg did express support for an increase to New York’s minimum wage, albeit only up to $8.25 an hour [21].

82f2cb3c64ef3da58f0295b90f087d2e.claim: Photo shows Bernie Sanders at the 1969 Stonewall riots.
82f2cb3c64ef3da58f0295b90f087d2e.label: false
82f2cb3c64ef3da58f0295b90f087d2e.passage:
0: Some Instagram users are misrepresenting an old meme to try and make Sen. Bernie Sanders look like a gay icon.
1: A post published Feb. 14 by @indiesauce claims to show the Democratic presidential candidate at the June 1969 Stonewall riots.
2: It depicts a man in a black turtleneck standing alongside four women.
3: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Instagram) The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook , which owns Instagram.)
5: It has more than 7,700 likes.
6: The Stonewall uprising was a series of confrontations between police and LGBTQ people outside the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar in New York City.
7: It is viewed as the catalyst for the modern gay rights movement and the reason that Pride celebrations are typically held in June.
8: No one knows who threw the first brick at Stonewall, but it definitely wasn’t Sanders.
9: The Instagram photo does not depict the Vermont senator, nor does it depict the Stonewall riots — it’s a meme that’s been around since at least 2015.
10: It originally served as a way to make fun of hipsters and Tumblr users.
11: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Sanders is no stranger to protests, though; he was arrested in 1963 during a civil rights demonstration in Chicago.
12: He also has a history of advocating for gay rights.
13: But there’s no evidence that Sanders was at the Stonewall riots.
14: The Instagram post is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows Bernie Sanders at the 1969 Stonewall riots is false.
This claim originates from a post published on Feb. 14 by @indiesauce[1].
However, there’s no clear evidence to support the assertion that Sanders was actually present during the Stonewall riots[13].
Furthermore, a closer examination of the alleged Instagram photo reveals that it neither features the Vermont senator nor portrays the Stonewall riots.
It has been identified as a meme circulating since at least 2015[9].

577a61dd4635ca9d6ff47b2484f3146e.claim: Nancy Pelosi was arrested after ripping a copy of the State of the Union speech.
577a61dd4635ca9d6ff47b2484f3146e.label: false
577a61dd4635ca9d6ff47b2484f3146e.passage:
0: Accompanying an array of images in a recent Facebook post , including photos of civil court filings, screenshots of tweets, and a picture of U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, is one explosive allegation: that the California Democrat was arrested.
1: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: There are screenshots of several tweets from one account in the Facebook post, including these: "BREAKING While leaving the US Capitol nancy Pelosi has been intercepted by US Marshals and ARRESTED (!)
4: under the direct order of President Trump.
5: WH claims ripping up speech was violation of decorum provision of Rule XIX!"
6: "Marshals holding Pelosi are NOT(!)
7: allowing her a phone call or to contact her attorneys.
8: Chuck Schumer is racing back to the US capitol.
9: White House sources say that she will be transported to undisclosed location TONIGHT (!)
10: to face MILITARY TRIBUNAL (!!!)"
11: First of all, Pelosi didn’t break the law when she tore up a copy of President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address on Feb. 4.
12: Trump , among others , wrongly claimed it was illegal.
13: And while some people have signed a Change.org petition calling for her arrest after she ripped up her copy of the president’s speech, no arrest has happened.
14: We found no news coverage online about Pelosi being taken into custody.
15: If she had been arrested, it would have drawn plenty of media attention.

gpt4: The claim that Nancy Pelosi was arrested after tearing up a copy of the State of the Union speech is false.
First, Pelosi did not break any laws when she tore up President Donald Trump's State of the Union address on February 4th[11].
In addition, there is no evidence or news coverage available online that indicates Pelosi was taken into custody [14].
If such an event had occurred, it would have attracted significant media attention[15].
Therefore, the claim is not supported by the listed reasons and is not true.

b9ea41b22f020eff5ea1f09507904630.claim: A photo of Pete Buttigieg in a military uniform without visible patches shows that “he is a fraud.”
b9ea41b22f020eff5ea1f09507904630.label: false
b9ea41b22f020eff5ea1f09507904630.passage:
0: After Pete Buttigieg’s strong showing in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, some social media users went after his military record.
1: One Facebook image published Feb. 12 shows the former South Bend, Ind., mayor in a military uniform surrounded by rugs.
2: His arms and chest are highlighted in certain places by red squares.
3: "No Unit Patch.
4: No Name Tape.
5: No ‘U.S.
6: Army’ Patch.
7: No Deployment/Combat Patch.
8: No American Flag Patch On Right Sleeve.
9: Uniform Clean As a Whistle," the post reads.
10: "This guy is a fraud."
11: Like other false posts about Buttigieg, this one is similarly fabricated.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
13: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
14: It has been shared hundreds of times and copied by several different users.
15: Buttigieg’s military background is part of his argument for becoming commander in chief.
16: He was a Navy intelligence officer in Afghanistan for six months, according to military records sent to PolitiFact by his campaign.
17: Several news outlets have spoken to his commanding officers and fellow soldiers.
18: Buttigieg joined the Navy Reserve in September 2009.
19: He was a lead analyst tracking the flow of money to terrorist cells.
20: Buttigieg did not see any combat, but he did take more than 90 trips outside secured military installations in Afghanistan.
21: Buttigieg was honorably discharged in November 2017.
22: The conspiracy that Buttigieg faked his military experience appears to have originated on 4chan , a fringe forum where users post anonymously.
23: From there, the falsehood spread to Twitter , where conservatives like former White House adviser Sebastian Gorka amplified it .
24: The origin of the photo of Buttigieg in a uniform without military insignia appears to be a 2014 blog post about a column Buttigieg wrote for the South Bend Tribune.
25: The former mayor’s patches are covered up, but there are a variety of photos of Buttigieg serving in Afghanistan that do show patches on his uniform — including one for the International Security Assistance Force , a NATO-led mission.
26: RELATED: The Stump Speech Analyzer: Pete Buttigieg A U.S. Navy official told PolitiFact that Buttigieg could have been working in an environment in which patches were not authorized for some reason.
27: So we asked the Buttigieg campaign for more information.
28: "When they went into bazaars on Fridays they had to remove all forms of identification, such as patches," said Chris Meagher, national press secretary for Buttigieg’s campaign.
29: The Facebook posts are inaccurate and make a ridiculous claim.

gpt4: The claim that a photo of Pete Buttigieg in a military uniform without visible patches indicates that "he is a fraud" is demonstrably false.
Buttigieg did serve as a Navy intelligence officer in Afghanistan for six months, which is verified by military records sent to PolitiFact by his campaign[16].
The photo in question originated from a 2014 blog post about a column Buttigieg wrote for the South Bend Tribune[24], and there's a logical explanation for the absence of patches on his uniform.

According to Chris Meagher, the national press secretary for Buttigieg's campaign, military personnel were required to remove all forms of identification, like patches, when they went into bazaars on Fridays[28].

Furthermore, there are multiple photos available that show Buttigieg in Afghanistan with patches visible on his uniform, including one for the International Security Assistance Force, a NATO-led mission[25].

a18270b80b5b712851bebdf342a9f45c.claim: photos show Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton and Condoleezza Rice posing with Osama bin Laden.
a18270b80b5b712851bebdf342a9f45c.label: false
a18270b80b5b712851bebdf342a9f45c.passage:
0: If you’ve come across images purporting to show President Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton or Condoleezza Rice with former al-Qaida leader Osama bin Laden, you’re probably not alone.
1: These images have been around for years.
2: But they’re photoshopped.
3: "Have they forgotten these pictures," reads the text over a Jan. 24 Facebook post that splices together three separate photos of Obama, Clinton and Rice, each one manipulated to make it appear as though they were posing with bin Laden.
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: We’ve previously debunked the image showing bin Laden shaking hands with Clinton, the former secretary of state and 2016 Democratic nominee for president.
7: Other fact-checkers have, too.
8: That image appeared in a 2007 Photoshop contest on FreakingNews.com and gained traction after a Russian official was duped into talking about it on state TV.
9: The original photo shows Clinton shaking Indian musician Shubhashish Mukherjee’s hand in 2004.
10: Other fact-checkers have also addressed the image of bin Laden with Rice, the former secretary of state and national security adviser to President George W. Bush.
11: That image appeared in an "April Fool's Day" Photoshop contest on FreakingNews.com in 2007.
12: Finally, other fact-checkers have also debunked the third image, which shows Obama wearing a Hawaiian lei and smiling beside a thumbs-up-giving bin Laden.
13: The real photo shows Obama and Hawaii attorney Andre Wooten.
14: The photo appears on Wooten’s website and Facebook page and also on the cover of attorney Daphne Barbee-Wooten’s 2010 book, "African-American Attorneys in Hawaii."
15: According to Andre Wooten’s Facebook page , the photo was taken in December 2005 when Obama, then a U.S. senator representing Illinois, visited Honolulu.
16: Barbee-Wooten told the Daily Caller’s Check Your Fact that she snapped the original photo.

gpt4: The claim that there are photos of Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, and Condoleezza Rice posing with Osama bin Laden is entirely false.
The images circulating on the internet are photoshopped [2].
The photo showing Clinton, the former secretary of state and 2016 Democratic nominee for president, shaking hands with bin Laden has been publicly debunked in the past [6].
The original photo was taken in 2004 and actually shows Clinton shaking hands with Indian musician Shubhashish Mukherjee [9].
Furthermore, the photoshopped image first appeared in an "April Fool's Day" Photoshop contest on FreakingNews.com back in 2007 [11].
In reality, the image that has been altered to show Obama with bin Laden actually shows Obama and Hawaii attorney Andre Wooten[13].

22ed5820b84b8f241fb82eafbdc88546.claim: “Pete Buttigieg is a favorite candidate of Wall Street and the health care industry.”
22ed5820b84b8f241fb82eafbdc88546.label: half-true
22ed5820b84b8f241fb82eafbdc88546.passage:
0: As Pete Buttigieg gained momentum in the Democratic presidential primary race ― finishing second in the New Hampshire primary and a front runner in the Iowa caucuses ― he has increasingly been on the receiving end of shade from his rivals.
1: The campaign of Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., for instance, distributed talking points that zeroed in on fundraising, saying "Pete Buttigieg is a favorite candidate of Wall Street and the health care industry."
2: The former mayor of South Bend, Ind., already faced criticism over his "billionaire donors," which famously manifested during the Dec. 19 Democratic debate.
3: It was then that Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., described a Buttigieg fundraiser as held in "a wine cave full of crystals."
4: Sanders’ comments led us to wonder if Buttigieg really is the sweetheart of the health care industry.
5: We asked the Sanders campaign for its evidence.
6: Staffers pointed us to data from the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that operates the website OpenSecrets.org and tracks money from individuals and political action committees donated to political candidates and members of Congress.
7: The center analyzes Federal Election Commission data and sorts contributions by categories based on the economic sector from which they come.
8: A deep dive into the numbers The Sanders campaign used OpenSecrets data it obtained in December 2019.
9: But the OpenSecrets website has since been updated with fourth-quarter filings, so we couldn’t confirm the figures the campaign cited.
10: Instead, Doug Weber, a senior CRP researcher, pointed to the 2020 presidential race section of OpenSecrets, saying it contains the most accurate data for presidential campaign contributions.
11: It also highlights industry contribution trends focused only on the presidential giving ― in other words, excluding contributions made to Senate campaign accounts.
12: We asked Weber if Sanders’ talking point about Buttigieg is true.
13: That "depends on what you mean by ‘health care industry,’" Weber wrote in an email.
14: OpenSecrets defines its health sector by contributions from PACs and individuals working in various health industries, he said, and "for our data, that's our broadest definition of health care."
15: Based on this sweeping categorization , Sanders is ahead of Buttigieg in health sector donations.
16: The Vermont senator received $2,910,894, while the former South Bend mayor trailed closely behind with $2,713,038.
17: However, when you break down this data by industries within the health sector, Buttigieg comes out ahead of Sanders in contributions from pharmaceutical companies and also for health services/HMOs ― which includes groups like large insurance companies.
18: But even this point is nuanced.
19: Former Vice President Joe Biden has received the most money of any Democratic candidate from the pharmaceuticals and health products sector if contributions from his leadership political action committee are included.
20: Leadership PACs are committees unaffiliated with campaigns that can still receive contributions and financially support candidates.
21: In the health care industry categories of hospitals/nursing homes and health professionals , Sanders has received the most in dollar contributions.
22: When asked to clarify how the Sanders campaign is defining the health care industry, a staffer responded that "Bernie Sanders issued a pledge to not accept money from top officials of the insurance and pharmaceutical industries (as distinct from rank-and-file workers in those industries, which the aggregate data you cite deals with).
23: He asked other candidates to do the same.
24: Pete Buttigieg has refused to take that pledge, and has instead raised money from those top officials...These clear, demonstrable and verifiable facts makes very clear precisely what we are referring to."
25: The Sanders campaign sent us a list of pharmaceutical and health insurance executives that have contributed to Buttigieg, including employees and executives from AbbVie, Aetna, Anthem, Eli Lilly and Co., Merck & Co. and Pfizer.
26: We checked that list against the Federal Election Commission database to ensure its accuracy.
27: In addition, the Sanders’ campaign shared an October 2019 article from Sludge, an investigative journalism outlet focused on money in politics, which estimated Buttigieg’s third-quarter health care industry donations approached $97,000.
28: We also checked in with the Buttigieg campaign for a response, which replied that "more than 800,000 Americans" have donated to its candidate.
29: The campaign’s emailed statement noted that Buttigieg’s "Medicare for All Who Want It" plan draws industry attacks because the health system "will have to provide more affordable coverage and better care or they will lose customers as people enroll in the public option."
30: What does it all mean?
31: It seems the Sanders’ claim is "imprecise," said Robert Maguire, research director at the nonprofit group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) .
32: "Given that the health industry itself is vast, what I assume the Sanders’ campaign … meant to say was that the more corporate aspects of the health industry ― like the pharmaceutical industry and the health insurance industry ― were funding Buttigieg disproportionately to others," he added.
33: Michael Beckel, research director of Issue One , a nonprofit organization focused on transparency and enforcement of campaign finance laws, said the key to understanding this claim is that the Sanders campaign is characterizing money from the health insurance and pharmaceutical industry differently than campaign contributions from individuals, such as nurses and other health professionals.
34: "Rank-and-file employees in one industry don't always express the same political preferences as executives in that industry," Beckel wrote in an email.
35: "Even as he's railed against the pharmaceutical industry and insurance industry, Sen. Sanders has welcomed support from labor unions representing nurses."
36: Michael Malbin, a political science professor at the University at Albany-State University of New York, also took issue with the idea that an individual giving the maximum amount of money to a campaign could sway the candidate’s policies.
37: "Every time election season rolls around, there are stories about individuals employed in one industry favoring one candidate over another, and it could be for whatever reason," said Malbin.
38: "But, you cannot make the inference from industry coding … that they are giving just for a certain economic interest.
39: Let alone that it’s remotely enough money to drive a presidential campaign.
40: … It’s a $2,800 maximum, for crying out loud."
41: The actual composition of donors in the health category can’t be known without analyzing OpenSecrets’ full data set ― which we could not do since it’s not publicly available.
42: OpenSecrets does, however, analyze the percentage of small donor donations (less than $200) and large contributions for each presidential candidate.
43: And 56% of Sanders’ contributions are from small donors, while 45% of Buttigieg’s campaign contributions come from that same group.

gpt4: The claim that Pete Buttigieg is a favorite candidate of Wall Street and the healthcare industry is partly accurate.
The campaign of Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., had stated that Buttigieg has been backed by Wall Street and the healthcare industry [1].

More specifically, upon examining contributions details, it emerges that Buttigieg has indeed received significant funding from pharmaceutical companies and health services, including large insurance companies, even more than Sanders himself [17].

Furthermore, the Sanders campaign revealed that multiple executives and employees from companies such as AbbVie, Aetna, Anthem, Eli Lilly and Co., Merck & Co. and Pfizer have made contributions to Buttigieg's campaign [25].

However, the claim isn't entirely valid as former Vice President Joe Biden has been observed to receive more money than any other Democratic candidate from the pharmaceuticals and health products sector when contributions from his leadership political action committee are taken into account [19].
This introduces a contextual nuance to the assertion tying Buttigieg as a favorite among these indicated sectors.

6e65a83b71f46f48cc0ea6e1aca2037e.claim: “From the moment we passed that signature legislation, Mike (Bloomberg) called it a disgrace.”
6e65a83b71f46f48cc0ea6e1aca2037e.label: true
6e65a83b71f46f48cc0ea6e1aca2037e.passage:
0: UPDATE: This story was updated to include comments from the Bloomberg campaign we received after the story was posted.
1: The comments do not change the rating.
2: Sparring over health care during the Nevada Democratic presidential primary debate, former Vice President Joe Biden took issue with former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s record on the Affordable Care Act.
3: "From the moment we passed that signature legislation, Mike called it a disgrace," Biden said, a claim he repeated another time during the debate.
4: Bloomberg sought to refute that charge, arguing that he defended the law and believed it should be expanded.
5: It was a heated moment.
6: Both candidates are trying to tie themselves to former President Barack Obama, who spearheaded the 2010 legislation.
7: So we decided to dig in.
8: We reached out to both campaigns for comment.
9: The Biden campaign sent a CNN article, which cited a speech Bloomberg gave at the Dartmouth Presidential Lecture in July 2010 — just a few months after the health care legislation was passed in March.
10: In the speech, Bloomberg called the Affordable Care Act "a disgrace."
11: Bloomberg’s campaign directed us to statements he put out in the lead up to the law’s passage, calling for inclusion of a public health insurance option people could buy into.
12: The remarks We found a video of the speech on YouTube.
13: In the video, Bloomberg was unsparing.
14: "We passed a health care bill that does absolutely nothing to fix the big health care problems in this country.
15: It is just a disgrace," he said.
16: "The president, in all fairness, started out by pointing out what the big problems were, but then turned it over to Congress, which didn't pay any attention to any of those big problems and just created another program that's going to cost a lot of money."
17: Those aren’t standalone remarks.
18: As recently as 2014, Bloomberg called the law "really dysfunctional" during a talk he gave at the annual meeting of SIFMA, one of the financial industry’s trade groups.
19: Both times, Bloomberg was still a registered Independent — he didn’t become a Democrat until 2018.
20: It’s also worth noting that Bloomberg wasn’t espousing a minority view.
21: The ACA’s approval rating was underwater until 2017, according to polling by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
22: (KHN is an editorially independent program of the Foundation.)
23: Bloomberg’s response On the debate stage, Bloomberg sought distance from those remarks, saying he is a "fan of Obamacare."
24: "I wrote something supporting it either in the New York Post or the Daily News," he said.
25: Bloomberg’s campaign pointed us to a 2009 New York Daily News op-ed that called for a public option, along with other statements.
26: But those weren’t his only writings on the law.
27: A March 27, 2017, New York Post piece, for instance, also talks about the ACA.
28: But it comes years after Bloomberg’s mayorship ended.
29: And while words like "disgrace" don’t appear, calling the piece a "defense" of the law isn’t entirely fair.
30: In it, Bloomberg noted some key shortcomings — for instance, the health law left 30 million people uninsured.
31: He also argued in support of some ideas more popular with Republicans, such as high-risk insurance pools, as a way to bring down costs.
32: "It’s regrettable that none of these ideas was seriously considered in the rush to repeal ObamaCare," Bloomberg wrote at the time.
33: It is worth noting that Bloomberg’s current health care plan would build on the ACA, largely by increasing subsidies for people buying private insurance on the exchanges, and by installing a Medicare-like public option.
34: (That plan is quite similar to what’s been touted by Biden himself, as well as by candidates like former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg.)

gpt4: The claim that Mike Bloomberg referred to the Affordable Care Act as a "disgrace" from the moment it was passed is accurate.
The Biden campaign provided evidence by sending a CNN article that cited Bloomberg's comments from a speech he gave during the Dartmouth Presidential Lecture in July 2010[9].
This was only a few months following the passage of the healthcare legislation in March that same year[9].
Bloomberg's exact words in his speech were that the Affordable Care Act was "a disgrace"[10], a characterization that Joe Biden then repeated during a debate[3].
Bloomberg's direct quote confirms this claim[15].

982d99462b7f64f9e9b144bf389f1805.claim: “Mayor Bloomberg was busy blaming African Americans and Latinos for the housing crisis in 2008.”
982d99462b7f64f9e9b144bf389f1805.label: false
982d99462b7f64f9e9b144bf389f1805.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., used the Democratic primary debate in Las Vegas to launch attacks against Mike Bloomberg, including his the billionaire’s rhetoric on the collapse of the housing market and financial crisis.
1: "When Mayor Bloomberg was busy blaming African Americans and Latinos for the housing crash of 2008, I was right here in Las Vegas literally just a few blocks down the street holding hearings on the banks that were taking away homes from millions of families," Warren said .
2: Warren was referring to a statement Bloomberg made in 2008 in which he said that the end of redlining — a discriminatory practice in which banks refused certain applicants, often African Americans, loans to live in certain neighborhoods — contributed to the collapse of the housing market.
3: But Bloomberg did not blame African Americans, Latinos or any minority group.
4: What Bloomberg said about the causes of the financial crisis The Warren campaign pointed to what Bloomberg said at a forum in September 2008 at Georgetown University .
5: At various points in the hourlong interview , Bloomberg spoke broadly about loose lending as a factor in the financial crisis.
6: Bloomberg identified pressure by Congress to expand lending after the ban on redlining as one of those causes.
7: The term "redlining" comes from when bankers would draw lines on maps indicating poorer neighborhoods where they would avoid offering mortgages.
8: Those areas often include large minority populations.
9: Bloomberg did not talk about the racial aspects of redlining or bring up any minority groups.
10: Instead, he seemed to define redlining narrowly as excluding loan applicants in poor neighborhoods.
11: And he described a system in which, by enacting a ban on redlining, Congress encouraged banks to give mortgages to people whether or not they could afford them.
12: Here’s what Bloomberg said: "It all started back when there was a lot of pressure on banks to make loans to everyone.
13: Redlining, if you remember, was the term where banks took whole neighborhoods and said, ‘People in these neighborhoods are poor, they’re not going to be able to pay off their mortgages, tell your salesmen don’t go into those areas.’" He continued: "And then Congress got involved — local elected officials, as well — and said, ‘Oh that’s not fair, these people should be able to get credit.’ And once you started pushing in that direction, banks started making more and more loans where the credit of the person buying the house wasn’t as good as you would like."
14: Warren’s argument is essentially that by citing the pushback against redlining as factor in the crisis, Bloomberg was blaming African Americans and Latinos.
15: Bloomberg’s description of redlining may have sounded naive in that he didn’t explicitly acknowledge the discriminatory impact against racial minorities.
16: But that’s a long way from blaming African Americans or Latinos for the housing collapse.
17: In the same interview, Bloomberg cited several other factors that led to the crisis, but he made no mention at all of minorities.
18: Bloomberg talked about how the mortgage crisis accelerated after mortgages were approved too easily for borrowers who didn’t have the means to repay them.
19: "There was pressure to open up the spigot and to sell mortgages to everyone," he said.
20: Bloomberg’s eight-minute answer also lobbed criticism at financial companies, saying that they didn’t understand the risks and volatility of their own products.
21: He said that Bear Stearns, AIG and Lehman Brothers all had reputations for being very aggressive.
22: "They got themselves so far out there that when the mortgage market collapsed, they couldn’t value the things that they owned," he said.
23: "They didn’t know how many mortgages at the very bottom were going to be good."
24: In 2011, Bloomberg repeated his opinion that Congress was to blame for the crisis, because it "pushed the banks to loan to everybody ."
25: In this statement, he appeared to let bankers off the hook.
26: "It was not the banks that created the mortgage crisis," he said.
27: "It was, plain and simple, Congress who forced everybody to go and to give mortgages to people who were on the cusp.
28: Now I’m not so sure that was terrible policy because a lot of those people who got homes still have them, and they wouldn’t have had them without that."
29: RELATED: What caused crisis?
30: No one thing Many experts have pushed back against the idea that eliminating redlining was a culprit for the financial meltdown.
31: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission concluded that the 1977 law against redlining was "not a significant factor in subprime lending or the crisis."
32: When we contacted the Bloomberg campaign, the campaign pointed to other statements Bloomberg made in which he mentioned various factors.
33: Speaking in London in October 2008 , Bloomberg said that automated trading contributed to the market’s volatility.
34: He said that the United States had an "antiquated patchwork of regulatory bodies" that lacked transparency.
35: At that event, Bloomberg was asked to respond to a magazine article suggesting the origins of the subprime mortgage crisis could be traced to the Clinton administration’s anti-discrimination drive that cajoled banks to lend to people who were not creditworthy.
36: Bloomberg said : "I think it might have contributed a little bit, but what happened was fundamentally everybody was doing well.
37: And when everybody’s doing well, we let our guard down, we take risks that we would not otherwise have taken, and what happened plain and simple is that the modeling said these mortgages were going to be paid off."

gpt4: The claim that Mayor Bloomberg blamed African Americans and Latinos for the 2008 housing crisis is false.
Contrary to the claim, Bloomberg did not cast blame on African Americans, Latinos, or any minority group for the crisis [3][16].
Furthermore, regarding redlining, an issue often associated with the crisis, he did not discuss any racial aspects or bring up any minority groups [9].
Instead, he defined redlining narrowly as the practice of excluding loan applicants in poor neighborhoods [10].
He also cited several other factors that contributed to the housing crisis, but none of them involved minorities [17].

bb552d64f9cf94fe787fb5a76e005364.claim: Melania Trump lied under oath in 2013 about graduating from college with a bachelor’s degree in architecture.
bb552d64f9cf94fe787fb5a76e005364.label: true
bb552d64f9cf94fe787fb5a76e005364.passage:
0: Claims about first lady Melania Trump lying under oath about her higher education credentials have resurfaced online.
1: The liberal website "Political Flare" posted a story in February 2020 about an answer Melania Trump gave during a 2013 court deposition that involved her defunct caviar skincare line .
2: Its headline: "BUSTED: Melania Trump Lied Under Oath in 2013 About Graduating From College With a ‘Bachelor’s in Architecture.’" The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: In this case, the headline is accurate, but the news is several years old.
5: Melania previously touted the inaccurate credential on her old website, MelaniaTrump.com, before it was scrubbed in 2016 and its URL rerouted to the Trump Organization website.
6: It now goes to her Facebook page .
7: Racked, a defunct fashion blog, in 2016 investigated what happened to Melania Trump’s skincare line, which disappeared along with the website.
8: Its report unraveled a tale about multiple lawsuits between multiple rich people.
9: The story included detail from the deposition in which Melania again provided a false account of her educational background.
10: A number of reports found that while Melania gained entry to the University of Ljubljana in Slovenia, she dropped out in her first year.
11: Shortly after the 2016 election, a new biography on the future first lady was posted on Trump’s website that said she "paused her studies to advance her modeling career in Milan and Paris."
12: The change was noted in a number of news reports .
13: The current biography of Trump on the White House website does not include anything about her educational background.
14: The 2013 lawsuit that Racked detailed was a result of a business partner feud and the eventual failure of the holding company of Melania’s heavily promoted skincare line that apparently never made it into stores.
15: A screenshot of the court deposition shows that an attorney asks Melania to please "explain to the Judge your formal education including what schools you attended and from which you graduated?"
16: "I attended and graduated from design school, from Fashion and Industrial Design School and also attended, graduated from architecture degree, bachelor degree," she responds.
17: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We reached out to the White House but did not hear back in time for publication.
18: Evidence and previous reporting shows that Melania falsely stated she graduated college with a bachelor’s degree while under oath.
19: But Political Flare’s inflammatory headline, along with others published by left-leaning websites, makes readers believe this is a new piece of information.
20: It isn’t.
21: The statement is accurate but needs clarification or additional information.

gpt4: In a 2013 court deposition regarding her defunct caviar skincare line, Melania Trump maintained under oath that she had graduated from college with a bachelor’s degree in architecture [1][15].

In her exchange with the attorney, Melania was directly asked to state her formal education, to which she responded, "I attended and graduated from design school, from Fashion and Industrial Design School and also attended, graduated from architecture degree, bachelor degree."[16].
However, thorough reporting uncovered that Melania had indeed entered the University of Ljubljana in Slovenia but did not complete her studies, leaving after the first year [10].
This comprehensive evidence revealed that Melania's claims about graduating from college with a bachelor’s degree, made while under oath, were misrepresented and thus untruthful [18].

1420df045728c9f0cd0be4605734a3b0.claim: a photo shows Ilhan Omar without a head scarf.
1420df045728c9f0cd0be4605734a3b0.label: false
1420df045728c9f0cd0be4605734a3b0.passage:
0: A couple of weeks after U.S. Rep. Ayanna Pressley, D-Mass, announced in January that she had alopecia, a meanspirited image appeared on Facebook purporting to show another Democratic congresswoman without hair.
1: "Ilhan Omar hates this picture and she hates when people share it," reads the text above two images of Omar, one in which she’s wearing her usual head scarf and another in which she appears to have two small tufts of hair without it.
2: "Let’s piss her off."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Jeremy Slevin, a spokesman for Omar, told us the image that makes Omar appear as if she were photographed without a headscarf isn’t authentic.
6: Rather, it seems the image was altered using this photo of a man wanted for a parole violation in South Wales.
7: His distinctive hairline was mocked online after police posted his mugshot on Facebook.

gpt4: The claim asserting that a photo shows U.S. Representative Ilhan Omar without a headscarf is false.
According to Jeremy Slevin, a spokesperson for Omar, the image making her appear without a headscarf is not authentic [5].
Furthermore, it appears that the image was allegedly tampered with, using a photo of an individual wanted for parole violation in South Wales as the base [6].

b9631a678a779e0d0f8381f9da621d89.claim: “Violent crime rates increased in all but two Wisconsin cities between 2008 and 2017.”
b9631a678a779e0d0f8381f9da621d89.label: false
b9631a678a779e0d0f8381f9da621d89.passage:
0: One Assembly Republican making the case for a series of tough-on-crime bills says a statewide rise in violent crime shows why the bills are needed.
1: The bills would return more people to prison for probation violations, put more juveniles behind bars and limit early release for inmates.
2: They illuminate a key ideological divide between Republicans seeking more time behind bars for certain offenders and a Democratic governor who has called for cutting the state's prison population in half in the coming years.
3: In the GOP Weekly Radio Address on Feb. 13, 2020, state Rep. Joe Sanfelippo , R-New Berlin, used a series of numbers to support bills he said would "help keep Wisconsin communities safe."
4: "FBI data shows violent crime rates increased in all but two Wisconsin cities between 2008 and 2017," said Sanfelippo.
5: "In fact, when combining Wisconsin’s 10 largest cities, the violent crime rate increased by 24% during that time, while decreasing by 14% on a national average."
6: It’s certainly an eye-catching claim.
7: Is violent crime up in all but two of the hundreds of cities across Wisconsin?
8: We checked it out — and found a case study in how not to use data.
9: Sanfelippo misquoted the stat he was trying to use while constructing an argument riddled with other data-related problems.
10: Let’s see what the data actually tells us.
11: Newer data available Asked for evidence supporting his discussion of violent crime, Sanfelippo’s office pointed us to a policy brief the nonpartisan Wisconsin Policy Forum published in December 2019.
12: Amid a discussion of police spending and staffing, the paper used FBI data to say violent crime had risen in Wisconsin from 2008 to 2017.
13: The FBI gathers crime stats from departments around the country, and reports a "violent crime" tally based on the number of homicides, sexual assaults, robberies and aggravated assaults.
14: (We should point out the Wisconsin Department of Justice also gathers crime data that in some cases varies slightly from the FBI, but we’ll limit our analysis here to the FBI data since that is what is cited by both Sanfelippo and the report he relied on.)
15: Sanfelippo and the paper point to 2017 data.
16: But the 2018 data, which was available at the time,  shows a noteworthy reversal, with the violent crime rate dropping after several years of steady increases.
17: The number of violent crimes Wisconsin law enforcement reported to the FBI fell from 15,931 in 2017 to 15,263 in 2018.
18: But that’s not necessarily a reliable number.
19: Here’s why.
20: Not all data comparable The FBI crime data is difficult to compare year-to-year because it’s not comprehensive.
21: Not every police department reports their data every year.
22: And state and local officials regularly change their reporting practices, changing definitions or other factors in generating counts.
23: To address this, the FBI data notes which agencies have changed reporting practices each year and warns the crime figures are now "not comparable to previous years’ data."
24: This was not taken into account in Sanfelippo’s claim or the memo his office cited as backup.
25: In the 2008 to 2017 period Sanfelippo referenced, the FBI flagged data from 46 Wisconsin municipalities as no longer being comparable to past years.
26: That included three of the 10 largest cities — which you’ll remember Sanfelippo cited specifically as having a 24% increase in violent crime.
27: We’ll also note that while Sanfelippo referred to cities, the FBI data includes cities, towns and villages, so we’ll refer to the group as municipalities here.
28: Key outlier ignored Sanfelippo — like many other Republicans — is using the FBI data to say violent crime is on the rise across Wisconsin.
29: But that's not really what the data shows.
30: More than two-thirds of the violent crimes in Wisconsin take place in Milwaukee, so in large part the statewide trend is just a reflection of what’s happening in the state’s largest city.
31: Violent crime in Milwaukee has edged up and down in recent years, but 2018 was the city’s lowest mark since 2013.
32: Addressing these three data issues (age, comparability and the Milwaukee outlier) lets us bring the state’s actual violent crime trend into clearer focus.
33: And we find there essentially is no trend.
34: Using FBI crime data from 2008 and 2018 and removing the places that changed reporting practices in that span leaves us with 206 municipalities — still a solid sample size.
35: Based on that group, the statewide violent crime rate rose from 4.3 to 4.7 per 1,000 residents from 2008 to 2018.
36: But Milwaukee accounted for all of that change.
37: Remove Milwaukee and the crime rate across the other 205 municipalities went from 1.77 per 1,000 to 1.74 per 1,000 — virtually unchanged.
38: Claim drastically overstated But all of these data mistakes pale in comparison to Sanfelippo’s dramatic misuse of the memo’s description.
39: The memo said — again, based in part on data the FBI warned against comparing — that violent crime rates increased in all but two of the state’s 10 largest cities.
40: Sanfelippo instead claimed the crime rate increased in "all but two Wisconsin cities."
41: That’s not even close to true.
42: Using the 206 municipalities referenced above — those that have data for both 2008 and 2018 and haven’t changed reporting practices — we find the crime rate rose in 98 municipalities, fell in 88 and was unchanged in 20.
43: Sanfelippo acknowledged using the stat incorrectly when questioned by PolitiFact Wisconsin.
44: The reference, which was wrong in both the recorded and written versions of the radio address, came from a script that Sanfelippo said wasn’t written by him or his office.
45: "It wasn’t intentionally done, it was just a mistake," he said.
46: "I should have picked up on that for as much as I have been talking about crime these last few months."

gpt4: The claim made by Sanfelippo that "Violent crime rates increased in all but two Wisconsin cities between 2008 and 2017" is false[41].

Firstly, the reference used to make this claim, both in the recorded and written versions, did not originate from Sanfelippo or his office, but from a misquoted stat, possibly causing a significant distortion of the data[44][9].

Not only did the 2018 data, which was accessible at the time, contradict the claim by showing a decrease in violent crime rates after years of steady increases[16], but a thorough analysis of the municipalities that reported data for both 2008 and 2018 showed that crime rates actually rose in 98 municipalities, fell in another 88, and remained the same in 20[42].

Furthermore, Sanfelippo's claim did not take into account the FBI's warning that the crime figures are now "not comparable to previous years’ data" due to changes in reporting practices in some agencies[23][24].
In the ten-year period specified by Sanfelippo, the FBI indicated that the data from 46 Wisconsin municipalities was no longer comparable to past data[25].
In addition, while Sanfelippo's statement explicitly referred to cities, the FBI data actually includes towns and villages which were not considered in his claim[27].
All these discrepancies indicate that Sanfelippo has dramatically overstated his claim[38].

5a329208786a9319c8dcd3fd449f9af4.claim: a photo shows the height difference between Donald Trump and Mike Bloomberg.
5a329208786a9319c8dcd3fd449f9af4.label: false
5a329208786a9319c8dcd3fd449f9af4.passage:
0: President Donald Trump has aimed his insults at presidential candidate Mike Bloomberg, belittling the former New York City mayor with the moniker "Mini Mike."
1: "Mini Mike is a 5’4" mass of dead energy who does not want to be on the debate stage with these professional politicians," Trump tweeted on Feb. 13.
2: "No boxes please."
3: The Associated Press has already looked into whether Bloomberg’s that short .
4: (He’s not.)
5: But now we’re looking at a photo published on Twitter the same day as Trump’s tweet that appears to show the two men standing together.
6: In the image, Bloomberg’s head doesn’t reach the president’s shoulder.
7: It was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: That’s because while Trump is taller than Bloomberg, this photo has been altered to make him look about half a foot taller.
10: The original photo , taken at the New York Observer’s 25th anniversary in March 2013, shows Bloomberg between Trump and Jared Kusnher, the president’s son-in-law.
11: In the real image, Bloomberg’s head clears Trump’s chin.

gpt4: The claim that a certain photo shows the actual height difference between Donald Trump and Mike Bloomberg is false.

This is premised on the fact that, while Trump is naturally taller than Bloomberg, the particular image in question was digitally manipulated to exaggerate Trump's height advantage to about half a foot more than it really is[9].
The original, unaltered photograph was taken at the New York Observer’s 25th anniversary in March 2013, and it positions Bloomberg standing between Trump and Jared Kushner, Trump’s son-in-law[10].
Contrary to the altered version published on Twitter, in the original photo, Bloomberg's head is clearly above Trump's chin[11].
The image was disseminated on Twitter the same day as Trump's tweet, giving room for possible misconceptions about their actual height difference[5].

7050b0a62e1b7ce21ce43393d9220cfa.claim: a photo shows an elephant carrying a lion cub to a pool of water so it wouldn’t die.
7050b0a62e1b7ce21ce43393d9220cfa.label: false
7050b0a62e1b7ce21ce43393d9220cfa.passage:
0: "It was considered the best photo of this century," the best photo’s caption grandly declares.
1: "A lioness and her cub were crossing the savannah but the heat was excessive and the cub was in great difficulty walking.
2: An elephant realized that the cub would die and carried him in his trunk to a pool of water walking beside his mother.
3: And we call them wild animals."
4: For a couple years now, the image, which shows a lion cub tucked into an elephant’s trunk as the animal walks alongside a lioness, has been shared widely on Facebook.
5: This Feb. 17 post , among others, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: That’s because it’s not the best photo of the century, but maybe one of the best Photoshop jobs of the week.
8: A Twitter account dedicated to helping people spot wildlife at Kruger National Park in South Africa posted the image on April 1, 2018 , with this caption: "We were following a lioness carrying her cub & she was getting really tired.
9: An elephant showed up wanting to help the lioness.
10: The elephant put its trunk down, the cub jumped up & the elephant carried the lion cub!!
11: S28, 3km from S entrance."
12: It also says, "Tinged by Sloof Lirpa," crediting the person responsible for reporting the sighting.
13: But "Sloof Lirpa" is "April Fools" backwards.
14: A post published on the account’s website the following day explained that the photo is indeed a joke.
15: "We had to spend hours perfecting the Photoshop," it says.
16: "We wanted it to be good enough to fool most, yet obvious enough to cause the "Fake" or "Photoshopped" comments to come through."
17: Not everyone got the joke, of course, and people continue to post the image on Facebook believing it’s real.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows an elephant carrying a lion cub to a pool of water so it wouldn’t die is false.
The image, which shows a lion cub appearing to be tucked into an elephant’s trunk while walking alongside a lioness, has been circulating around Facebook for a couple of years[4].
However, this seemingly heartwarming interaction is an artificial creation, cleverly designed using Photoshop, not an authentic image captured in the wild[7].
The source of the doctored image, the "Sloof Lirpa" account, is a giveaway, as the name is simply "April Fools" spelled backwards[13].
Following the dissemination of the image, the account acknowledged on its website that the photo was indeed a prank[14].
The creators explicitly admitted to spending hours perfecting the Photoshop work, to make it appear realistically captivating[15].

fe751314cd0cb480e7c5b7320ea812d0.claim: Kobe Bryant’s eldest daughter, Natalia, left a suicide video after being bullied.
fe751314cd0cb480e7c5b7320ea812d0.label: false
fe751314cd0cb480e7c5b7320ea812d0.passage:
0: We have debunked several pieces of misinformation surrounding the tragic deaths of NBA star Kobe Bryant, his daughter Gianna, and seven others in a helicopter crash on Jan. 26.
1: We’ve noticed a disturbing trend by some websites reporting false suicides of Bryant’s surviving family members.
2: A new one claims to show the BBC reported on the death of Bryant’s eldest daughter, Natalia.
3: The video shows a photo of Natalia with text that says "R.I.P.
4: Natalia Bryant 2003-2020."
5: This is not true.
6: Natalia Bryant’s death has not been reported by any credible news organizations, including the BBC.
7: We previously fact-checked a similar hoax about Bryant’s wife, Vanessa.
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: Despite carrying the BBC logo, this death hoax was shared on Facebook via a suspicious-looking web page called "t0days.gl0ba1newsrep0rt," which is in no way affiliated with the British network.
11: If you click on the video, a clip of a news anchor begins, with the "RIP Natalia Bryant" photo appearing in the corner.
12: The anchor says "the shock is still raw for fans" before cutting out and showing a graphic content warning label.
13: Clicking on the label opens a new window prompting you to share the post on Facebook.
14: Many have done so, helping to spread the reach of the hoax.

gpt4: The claim that Kobe Bryant's eldest daughter, Natalia, left a suicide video after being bullied is false.

The misinformation appears to originate from a deceptive webpage named "t0days.gl0ba1newsrep0rt" that carried the BBC logo to seemingly authenticate its content, despite having no affiliation with the British network[10].
Moreover, a supposed report on Natalia Bryant's death by BBC surfacing online was also identified as being part of the hoax[2].
In reality, no credible news organizations, including the BBC, have reported Natalia Bryant’s death, further discrediting the false claim[6].

2e38ad7bb89b9fd09ffe598054829e3d.claim: “Violent crime in South Bend doubled during Mayor Pete’s tenure.”
2e38ad7bb89b9fd09ffe598054829e3d.label: false
2e38ad7bb89b9fd09ffe598054829e3d.passage:
0: A conservative commentator attacked the mayoral record of Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg, using data to show how the city of South Bend, Ind., became less safe under his watch.
1: "Violent crime in South Bend doubled during Mayor Pete’s tenure," said the headline on Bongino.com, the web home for content shared and created by radio host Dan Bongino.
2: The article was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Bongino uses charts to suggest that violent crime spiked during Buttigieg’s two terms, which ran from Jan. 1, 2012, to Jan. 1, 2020.
5: At first glance the claim appears to be backed up with the gold standard of violent crime statistics — the FBI’s Uniform Crime Report.
6: But there’s more to this story: South Bend changed how it reported the numbers to the FBI, making it appear that violent crime experienced an alarming spike under Buttigieg’s leadership.
7: That isn’t what happened.
8: Let’s take a look.
9: Violent crime defined The FBI says violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder and non-negligent manslaughter, rape, robbery and aggravated assault.
10: South Bend reported 744 violent crimes to the FBI in 2011 — the year before Buttigieg took office.
11: In 2012, Buttigieg’s first year as mayor, the number fell to 622 — a drop of 16%.
12: Then, violent crimes rose in 2013, 2014 and 2015 — but still remained lower than 2011.
13: After that, the numbers get tricky.
14: In 2016, based on advice from the FBI, South Bend police changed how it counted aggravated assaults — and the number of violent crimes reported by South Bend spiked, exceeding 1,000 in 2016, 2017 and 2018, the most recent year for which figures are available.
15: Previously, South Bend had not been counting instances where a weapon was shown or implied as an aggravated assault, said Jeff Asher, data analyst and consultant at AH Datalytics who has written in the New York Times about violent crime in South Bend.
16: "The evidence is telling us that South Bend didn’t become more violent; it simply changed how it counted assaults," he wrote.
17: The FBI noted the issue in comparing annual totals in South Bend from 2016 forward this way:  "Because of changes in" South Bend's "reporting practices, figures are not comparable to previous years' data."
18: Similarly, the FBI changed its definition of rape in 2013, which led to an increase in rape figures nationwide, Asher said.
19: A Wall Street Journal editorial also took Buttigieg to task, saying an increase in violent crime in South Bend outpaced that of Indiana as a whole.
20: But the editorial also noted the change in how South Bend counts violent crimes.

gpt4: The claim that "Violent crime in South Bend doubled during Mayor Pete’s tenure" is inaccurate.
This statement originated from content created by radio host Dan Bongino and was subsequently disseminated on his website [1].
Bongino used charts to indicate a rise in violent crime during Mayor Pete Buttigieg’s terms, from January 1, 2012, to January 1, 2020[4].
However, in 2012, Buttigieg’s first year as mayor, violent crime numbers actually dropped by 16%, to 622 incidents [11].
While violent crimes did rise in 2013, 2014, and 2015, they remained lower than they had been in 2011, prior to Buttigieg's tenure [12].

The sudden spike in violent crimes commencing in 2016, which made it seem like they exceeded 1,000 in 2016, 2017, and 2018, was due to a change in how South Bend police counted aggravated assaults, following advice from the FBI [14].
As such, the perceived increase in violence does not necessarily reflect a rise in actual violent incidents [16].

e9de43e464b2a30e6859c2dd36f932f5.claim: The budget hole in Bernie Sanders’ plans “is bigger than the size of the entire economy of the United States."""
e9de43e464b2a30e6859c2dd36f932f5.label: false
e9de43e464b2a30e6859c2dd36f932f5.passage:
0: Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., leading in the polls heading into the Nevada Democratic caucuses, faced more than a few attacks from his rivals on the debate stage in Nevada.
1: Former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg aimed one at the fiscal realities of Sanders’ many plans.
2: "If you add up all his policies all together, they come to $50 trillion," Buttigieg said.
3: "He's only explained $25 trillion worth of revenue, which means that the hole in there is bigger than the size of the entire economy of the United States."
4: Estimating the future costs of huge plans — such as Medicare for All — and the future revenues from new taxes — such as a wealth tax — is fraught with problems.
5: Buttigieg’s campaign sent us the basis for their numbers, and they are reasonable, if still subject to uncertainty and debate.
6: Medicare for All is a good example of how estimates can vary.
7: The Urban Institute , a Washington think tank, calculated that under Sanders’ plan, overall health spending would rise by 13%.
8: But a new study from policy researchers at Yale, University of Maryland and University of Florida estimated overall spending would fall by 13%.
9: So, treat all projections with caution.
10: But there’s an issue with Buttigieg’s basic comparison of Sanders’ proposals to the U.S. economy.
11: He might have been using a rhetorical flourish to give a sense of scale, but his words muddled the math.
12: The flaw is that he used 10-year cost and revenue estimates for the Sanders plans and stacked them against one year of the nation’s GDP.
13: The U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis put the size of the U.S. economy at $21.4 trillion in 2019.
14: Using Buttigieg’s estimate of the revenue gap, his statement is mathematically correct, but it ignores the different time frames.
15: For a more apples-to-apples comparison (which would come with a host of other analytic issues), you would look at the cumulative value of the economy as projected by the Congressional Budget Office over the next decade.
16: The CBO’s latest estimate amounts to nearly $300 trillion worth of GDP by 2030.
17: In that context, a budget hole of $25 trillion adds up to about 8% of the total.

gpt4: While it is true that former Mayor Pete Buttigieg has raised concerns about the fiscal sustainability of Bernie Sanders' plans, claiming that they would result in a budget gap of $50 trillion[1][2], his statements may not paint the full picture.
Buttigieg has stated that Sanders has only explained $25 trillion worth of revenue, leaving a remaining hole bigger than the size of the US economy [3].
However, this comparison is flawed because it juxtaposes Sanders' 10-year cost and revenue estimates against a single year of the nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP)[12].
From a mathematical standpoint, Buttigieg's claim about the budget gap is accurate, but it doesn't account for the different time frames involved [14].
Taking these differences into account, the perceived $25 trillion budget gap would constitute approximately 8% of the total [17].
Therefore, the claim that the budget gap in Bernie Sanders' plans is larger than the size of the entire US economy is false.

b5d78ca5ab2d7c11e8d7df6883ad450e.claim: if you take the oath of office on the Koran, “then you have committed treason.”
b5d78ca5ab2d7c11e8d7df6883ad450e.label: false
b5d78ca5ab2d7c11e8d7df6883ad450e.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar, a Muslim American Democrat from Minnesota, was sworn into the House of Representatives on Jan. 3, 2019, using the Quran that belonged to her grandfather.
1: A couple weeks later, a Facebook post claimed that she and Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D.-Mich. — who also used a Koran during her swearing-in ceremony — broke the law by doing so.
2: "Let me say about the QURAN, if you take the Oath of Office on a book recognizing Sharia Law swearing to defend honor and uphold the United States Constitution, then you have committed treason," reads the text accompanying a photo of Omar during her swearing-in.
3: "For Sharia Law is a direct violation and conflict of the United States Constitutional Law."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: That’s because the Facebook post is wrong.
7: Article VI of the U.S. Constitution says that U.S. senators and representatives, among others, "shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation, to support this Constitution; but no religious Test shall ever be required as a Qualification to any Office or public Trust under the United States."
8: Representatives usually take an oath — swearing to support and defend the Constitution — on the first day of a new Congress.
9: First, they take the oath as a group together .
10: Around the 2:50 mark here you can watch House Speaker Nancy Pelosi invited the new members of the 116th Congress rise and raise their right hands.
11: She reads the oath, asking if they swear to support and defend the Constitution, and after they all together say "I do," she congratulates them.
12: Ceremonial swearing-ins follow , during which members can take the oath with their hand on a religious text and be photographed with the speaker.
13: Historically, most members of Congress have sworn the oath on a copy of the Bible, but the Constitution doesn’t require it and, as the since-shuttered magazine Pacific Standard reported , the 116th Congress in 2019 was the most diverse Congress ever.
14: More than 12 religious and non-religious texts were used during swearing-in ceremonies.
15: "Though oaths are indeed religious in origin," the Pacific Standard story says, "the Constitution makes clear that the oath can be replaced with an ‘Affirmation,’ which substitutes the religious language (the ‘I swear’ and ‘So help me God’) with secular affirmation (for example: ‘I affirm to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth’)."
16: In 2007, then-Rep.-elect Keith Ellison used former President Thomas Jefferson’s copy of the Koran for his swearing-in ceremony, drawing complaints from conservative Christians who claimed only a Bible could be used for the oath of office.
17: But back in 1825, former President John Quincy Adams swore his oath on a law book.
18: In 2013, U.S. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, a Hindu, swore on a copy of the Bhagavad Gita.
19: The photos showing Ellison, Tlaib and Omar with their hands on Qurans are from ceremonial events, re-enacting their swearing-in.
20: "That’s when you’ll see a hand on a religious text," Fred Beuttler, then the deputy historian of the House, told ABC in 2006.
21: "But that’s an informal ceremony for the members or the members’ own purposes.
22: It’s not the official swearing-in ceremony of the House, when no religious text is used."

gpt4: The claim that taking the oath of office on the Koran is considered treason is false.

As per Article VI of the U.S. Constitution, senators, representatives and other public officials are bound by oath to support the Constitution, but no specific religious text is mandated for this purpose[7].
Historically, while most members of Congress have sworn their oaths on a Bible, it is not a constitutional requirement[13].
Furthermore, during ceremonial swearing-ins, members have the option to take the oath with their hand on a religious text of their choice, and then be photographed with the Speaker[12].
Even the official swearing-in ceremony of the House does not necessitate the use of a religious text[22].
This demonstrates that the choice of religious text for the oath does not constitute an act of treason.

8f637bb5809c636033471a07a71eb49b.claim: ""Yet, for all that spending, health outcomes today on Medicaid are mediocre and many patients have difficulty accessing care.”"
8f637bb5809c636033471a07a71eb49b.label: false
8f637bb5809c636033471a07a71eb49b.passage:
0: The Trump administration’s top Medicaid official has been increasingly critical of the entitlement program she has overseen for three years.
1: Seema Verma, administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, has warned that the federal government and states need to better control spending and improve care to the 70 million people on Medicaid, the state-federal health insurance program for the low-income population.
2: She supports changes to Medicaid that would give states the option to receive capped annual federal funding for some enrollees instead of open-ended payouts based on enrollment and health costs.
3: This would be a departure from how the program has operated since it began in 1965.
4: In an early February speech to the American Medical Association , Verma noted how changes are needed because Medicaid is one of the top two biggest expenses for states, and its costs are expected to increase 500% by 2050.
5: "Yet, for all that spending, health outcomes today on Medicaid are mediocre and many patients have difficulty accessing care," she said.
6: Verma’s sharp comments got us wondering if Medicaid recipients were as bad off as she said.
7: So we asked CMS what evidence it has to back up her views.
8: A CMS spokesperson responded by pointing us to a CMS fact sheet comparing the health status of people on Medicaid to people with private insurance and Medicare.
9: The fact sheet, among other things, showed 43% of Medicaid enrollees report their health as excellent or very good compared with 71% of people with private insurance, 14% on Medicare and 58% who were uninsured.
10: The spokesperson also pointed to a 2017 report by the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC), a congressional advisory board, that noted: "Medicaid enrollees have more difficulty than low-income privately insured individuals in finding a doctor who accepts their insurance and making an appointment; Medicaid enrollees also have more difficulty finding a specialist physician who will treat them."
11: We opted to look at those issues separately.
12: What about health status?
13: Several national Medicaid experts said Verma is wrong to use health status as a proxy for whether Medicaid helps improve health for people.
14: That’s because to be eligible for Medicaid, people must fall into a low-income bracket, which can impact their health in many ways.
15: For example, they may live in substandard housing or not get proper nutrition and exercise.
16: In addition, lack of transportation or child care responsibilities can hamper their ability to visit doctors.
17: Benjamin Sommers, a health economist at Harvard University, said Verma’s comparison of the health status of Medicaid recipients against people with Medicare or private insurance is invalid because the populations are so different and face varied health risks.
18: "This wouldn’t pass muster in a first-year statistics class," he said.
19: Death rates, for example, are higher among people in the Medicare program than those in private insurance or Medicaid, he said, but that’s not a knock on Medicare.
20: It’s because Medicare primarily covers people 65 and older.
21: By definition, Medicaid covers the most vulnerable people in the community, from newborns to the disabled and the poor, said Rachel Nuzum, a vice president with the nonpartisan Commonwealth Fund.
22: "The Medicaid population does not look like the privately insured population."
23: Joe Antos, a health economist with the conservative American Enterprise Institute, also agreed, saying he is leery of any studies or statements that evaluate Medicaid without adjusting for risk.
24: For a better mechanism to gauge health outcomes under Medicaid, experts point to dozens of studies that track what happened in states that chose in the past six years to pursue the Affordable Care Act’s Medicaid expansion.
25: The health law gave states the option to extend Medicaid to everyone with incomes up to 138% of the federal poverty level, or about $17,600 annually for an individual.
26: Thirty-six states and the District of Columbia have adopted the expansion.
