27: "Most research demonstrates that Medicaid expansion has improved access to care, utilization of services, the affordability of care, and financial security among the low-income population," concluded the Kaiser Family Foundation in summarizing findings from more than 300 studies.
28: "Studies show improved self-reported health following expansion and an association between expansion and certain positive health outcomes."
29: (Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
30: Studies found the expansion of Medicaid led to lower mortality rates for people with heart disease and among end-stage renal disease patients initiating dialysis .
31: Researchers also reported that Medicaid expansion was associated with declines in the length of stay of hospitalized patients.
32: One study found a link between expansion and declines in mechanical ventilation rates among patients hospitalized for various conditions.
33: Another recent study compared the health characteristics of low-income residents of Texas, which has not expanded Medicaid, and those of Arkansas and Kentucky, which did.
34: It found that new Medicaid enrollees in the latter two states were 41 percentage points more likely to have a usual source of care and 23 percentage points more likely to say they were in excellent health than a comparable group of Texas residents.
35: Medicaid’s benefits, though, affect far more than the millions of nondisabled adults who gained coverage as a result of the ACA.
36: "Medicaid coverage was associated with a range of positive health behaviors and outcomes, including increased access to care; improved self-reported health status; higher rates of preventive health screenings; lower likelihood of delaying care because of costs; decreased hospital and emergency department utilization; and decreased infant, child, and adult mortality rates," according to a report issued this month by the nonpartisan Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.
37: Children — who make up nearly half of Medicaid enrollees — have also benefited from the coverage, studies find.
38: Some studies report that Medicaid contributes to improved health outcomes, including reductions in avoidable hospitalizations and lower child mortality.
39: Research shows people on Medicaid are generally happy with the coverage.
40: A Commonwealth Fund survey found 90% of adults with Medicaid were satisfied or very satisfied with their coverage, a slightly higher percentage than those with employer coverage.
41: Accessible care?
42: The evidence here is less emphatic.
43: A 2017 study published in JAMA Internal Medicine found 84% of Medicaid recipients felt they were able to get all the medical care they needed in the previous six months.
44: Only 3% said they could not get care because of long wait times or because doctors would not accept their insurance.
45: Verma cites a 2017 MACPAC report that noted some people on Medicaid have issues accessing care.
46: But that report also noted: "The body of work to date by MACPAC and others shows that Medicaid beneficiaries have much better access to care, and much higher health care utilization, than individuals without insurance, particularly when controlling for socioeconomic characteristics and health status."
47: It also notes that "Medicaid beneficiaries also fare as well as or better than individuals with private insurance on some access measures."
48: The report said people with Medicaid are as likely as those with private insurance to have a usual source of care, a doctor visit each year and certain services such as a Pap test to detect cervical cancer.
49: "Medicaid is not great coverage, but it does open the door for health access to help people deal with medical problems before they become acute," Antos said.
50: On the negative side, the report said Medicaid recipients are more likely than privately insured patients to experience longer waiting times to see a doctor.
51: They also are less likely to receive mammograms, colorectal tests and dental visits than the privately insured.
52: "Compared to having no insurance at all, having Medicaid improves access to care and improves health," said Rachel Garfield, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation.
53: "There is pretty strong evidence that Medicaid helps patients get the care they need."

gpt4: The claim that Medicaid yields mediocre health outcomes and limits access to care is not supported by substantial evidence[4][27][36][39][43][47][52].
In her speech to the American Medical Association, Verma discussed the need for reforms as the cost of Medicaid is set to increase 500% by 2050, placing it as one of the top state expenses[4].
However, this doesn't imply reduced care quality or access.

A report by the nonpartisan Robert Wood Johnson Foundation indicated that Medicaid coverage has numerous health advantages, including increased access to medical care, improved health status, higher preventive health screenings, and reduced health care delays due to costs[36].
More so, research shows that most Medicaid participants are satisfied with their coverage[39].
A study by JAMA Internal Medicine highlights that 84% of Medicaid beneficiaries reported receiving all necessary medical care in the past six months[43].
Furthermore, it's noted that Medicaid beneficiaries often fair as well as or better than those with private insurance in terms of access to care[47].
"Comparing these beneficiaries to the uninsured, having Medicaid improves access to care and results in better health," adds Rachel Garfield of Kaiser Family Foundation[52].

This organization has also concluded that research overwhelmingly indicates that the expansion of Medicaid has significantly improved care access, service utilization, affordability and financial security among low-income populations[27].

09fb06c77f3b68a5aa939d7bd40c5a46.claim: “The majority of hunters now want universal background checks, the majority of Trump voters.”
09fb06c77f3b68a5aa939d7bd40c5a46.label: true
09fb06c77f3b68a5aa939d7bd40c5a46.passage:
0: On the heels of a fiesty Democratic debate that touched on everything from health care to former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg’s past comments and positions, Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar joined MSNBC’s "Morning Joe" to talk about an issue that didn’t come up: Guns.
1: Klobuchar said she was "sad" that gun violence wasn’t talked about during the debate in Las Vegas, the location of the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history in 2017.
2: She also lamented the lack of progress in Congress on universal background checks.
3: "The majority of hunters now want universal background checks, the majority of Trump voters," Klobuchar said.
4: "There’s absolutely no reason we shouldn’t be moving on it."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We’ve fact-checked a number of related claims from Democrats about support for universal background checks among groups such as NRA members , gun owners and Republicans .
6: But what about hunters?
7: And what about supporters of President Donald Trump?
8: Klobuchar has made the same claim a few times before, including on ABC’s "The View," so we decided to check it out.
9: We found that her statement lines up with the available polls.
10: RELATED: Do gun background checks work?
11: What the research shows Recap: What are universal background checks?
12: Many Democrats have called for universal background checks, which would require background checks on nearly all gun purchases, including private sales made at events such as gun shows.
13: The Democrat-led House passed a bill in 2019 to ban the private transfer of firearms unless a licensed gun dealer or manufacturer takes possession of the firearm to conduct a background check.
14: But the GOP-led Senate has refused to take it up .
15: Trump, meanwhile, has made inconsistent statements about background checks, often touting the need to strengthen them in the wake of mass shootings only to walk back his support later.
16: Limited polling shows support among Trump voters, hunters When we examined a previous claim about GOP support for universal background checks, we found a number of polls that showed Republican approval floating between 82% and 95%.
17: Not all registered Republicans necessarily voted or are planning to vote for Trump, whose approval rating within the party has generally held within the mid-to-high 80s.
18: But a few polls that have narrowed the scope to Trump voters lend credence to Klobuchar’s claim.
19: The Klobuchar campaign specifically cited an Aug. 14 Fox News poll that asked 1,013 randomly sampled registered voters if they "favor or oppose" proposals "requiring criminal background checks on all gun buyers, including those buying at gun shows and private sales."
20: That poll — conducted shortly after mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas — found support for such proposals from 90% of "Trump voters," with 8% signaling opposition and 2% saying they didn’t know.
21: Similarly, a mid July Marist poll conducted in partnership with NPR and PBS NewsHour asked 1,346 respondents about "background checks for gun purchases at gun shows or other private sales."
22: And 82% of "2016 Trump supporters" said the checks were a "good idea."
23: Still, it’s worth noting that support for background checks doesn’t always line up with voting for specific pieces of legislation.
24: The National Rifle Association has pointed to 2016 referendums in Maine and Nevada that showed lower support for background checks than the national polls .
25: It’s also not clear how many people surveyed as part of the Fox News and Marist polls identified as Trump voters or supporters, although the Marist poll only reported results for subgroups of at least 100 people.
26: Small sample sizes could be misleading, even if a larger number of polls shows high support for background checks among Republicans more generally.
27: But Klobuchar claimed only that a majority of Trump voters want background checks, leaving her wiggle room to account for margins of error or changes in public opinion over time.
28: We follow the facts and share what we learn so you can make your own decisions.
29: Support our mission today.
30: Membership.politifact.com As for hunters, the Klobuchar campaign cited a 2013 Politico article about a poll commissioned by Bull Moose Sportsmen’s Alliance , an advocacy group representing hunters and sportsmen.
31: That poll surveyed 800 hunters and found that 77% support "requiring anyone who wants to purchase a firearm to pass a criminal background check before each potential gun purchase."
32: It also found that 72% of hunters support criminal background checks that allow for exemptions for "gun exchanges between family members, sharing guns on hunting trips and shooting ranges, or sales to those who have concealed carry permits from state government."
33: By now, the poll is almost seven years old.
34: Liam Sullivan, press secretary for Brady United Against Gun Violence, a gun control advocacy group, said the organization was not aware of any other surveys measuring hunters’ support for background checks.
35: We couldn’t find other related polls via Google and Nexis.
36: Neither could Everytown for Gun Safety, another gun control advocacy organization.
37: But Sullivan noted that pollsters — including the Pew Research Center — have found majority support for background checks among gun owners more generally.

gpt4: The statement that "the majority of hunters now want universal background checks, the majority of Trump voters," as claimed by Klobuchar, is true according to several polls.

Klobuchar's campaign referenced a 2013 Politico article about a poll commissioned by the Bull Moose Sportsmen's Alliance, where it was found that 77% of the 800 surveyed hunters supported compulsory criminal background checks before every potential purchase of firearms [30][31].

Similarly, a poll which was held immediately after the mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, showed that 90% of "Trump voters" were supportive of such proposals, only 8% opposed, and 2% were unsure [20].

These findings are consistent with another poll conducted in mid-July by Marist partnered with NPR and PBS NewsHour about **background checks for gun purchases at gun shows or other private sales**[21].
All of these polls corroborate the veracity of Klobuchar's statement, demonstrating that it is indeed accurate [9][3].

3462935f179c08c8b2e00efedc275d53.claim: Maxine Waters tweeted, “Every single gun owner I have talked to has told me, ‘As soon as I walked out of that gun store, I felt a killer growing inside of me.’ When will we acknowledge there is no such thing as a responsible gun owner?”
3462935f179c08c8b2e00efedc275d53.label: false
3462935f179c08c8b2e00efedc275d53.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., has advocated for gun control on Twitter, but she didn’t tweet this message that was shared on Facebook on Feb. 20.
1: "Every single gun owner I have talked to has told me, ‘As soon as I walked out of that gun store, I felt a killer growing inside of me.’" reads the screenshot of a tweet from @MaxinePWaters.
2: "When will we acknowledge there is no such thing as a responsible gun owner?"
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Below the screenshot is a graphic with these words, "I guess we are just making s--- up now."
6: I guess we are!
7: Waters has two verified Twitter accounts.
8: @RepMaxineWaters is her account for her work as a representative , and it features the same user photo as the account featured in the Facebook post.
9: @MaxineWaters is her account for her congressional campaigns .
10: We searched both accounts for the words in the Facebook post and came up empty.
11: @MaxinePWaters, the account in the Facebook post , has been suspended for violating Twitter’s rules.
12: But back in 2018, Snopes fact-checked another such tweet from the account that was fooling people.
13: Snopes then reported that @MaxinePWaters has no connection to the lawmaker.

gpt4: The claim that Maxine Waters tweeted controversial statements about gun owners has been proven to be false.
This conclusion is backed by multiple pieces of evidence, including a comprehensive search of her two verified Twitter accounts, which yielded no signs of the alleged statement [10].
Additionally, the account named in the Facebook post where the claim was made, @MaxinePWaters, has been suspended by Twitter for rule violations [11].
This further raises suspicion since it isn't Waters' verified account.

The legitimacy of @MaxinePWaters, as connected to Waters, was included in an investigative report by fact-checking website Snopes, which concluded there was no connection between the account and the lawmaker [13].
Therefore, the information supports the false nature of the claim.

1a9f89fd03f72e9b1ff4763f53da270e.claim: the United Nations plans to “implant everyone with a biometric ID.”
1a9f89fd03f72e9b1ff4763f53da270e.label: false
1a9f89fd03f72e9b1ff4763f53da270e.passage:
0: What’s more wild than science fiction’s robots, aliens and galaxies far, far away?
1: The internet, that’s what.
2: Word on the world wide web is that the United Nations is scheming to implant "everyone" with a "biometric ID."
3: Say goodbye to your privacy.
4: A story by website truthandaction claims that the United Nations is planning to have "all humans imprinted with biometric identification cards by 2030" as part of its "Global Goals agenda."
5: No.
6: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: This conspiracy theory is an overreach of a system that the UN is using to help identify refugees through biometrics that include facial recognition, fingerprints and iris scans.
9: The truthandaction article points to the UN’s Global Goals initiative that was released in 2015.
10: The agenda comprises 17 goals to achieve around the world by 2030 and includes objectives like no poverty, zero hunger and quality education.
11: But the story zeroes in on a section of goal No.
12: 16, which is called "Peace, justice and strong institutions."
13: The section in question, 16.9, says: "By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration."
14: The idea , though, was to help refugees prove their identities when seeking asylum, and biometrics refers to many different types of identification (not just microchips).
15: As part of the the UNs 2030 goal, companies Accenture and Microsoft unveiled a blockchain ID system prototype in 2017: It "combines a person`s biometric information such as their fingerprint or retina scan with blockchain, the record-keeping technology that underpins cryptocurrencies, to create a legal identity.
16: When operational, the tool will provide refugees with the ability to present their IDs via an app on their smartphones at border crossings to prove they`re coming from a refugee camp and qualify for aid.
17: The app will also enable displaced individuals to share their identities when required to access basic services such as education and healthcare."
18: Since then, biometric technology has been developed to help identify refugee populations (though there have been some concerns about the practice).
19: But the claim that the UN is planning to implant the world’s population with a microchip ID is far off.
20: We found no mention of implanted microchips in the UN’s goals.
21: Even if UN-backed biometric technology is aimed to expand beyond refugee and immigrant populations, this theory is based on speculation and overblows the facts.

gpt4: The claim that the United Nations (UN) plans to "implant everyone with a biometric ID" is false.

This claim appears to originate from a story on the website truthandaction, asserting that the UN intends to imprint all humans with biometric identification cards by 2030 as part of its "Global Goals agenda"[4].
However, this conspiracy theory is an overstretch of the actual system that the UN has been utilizing.
The UN is indeed using biometrics such as facial recognition, fingerprints, and iris scans to help identify refugees[8].

This initiative's primary aim is to assist refugees in proving their identities while seeking asylum, and "biometrics" encompasses various types of identification methods, not exclusively microchips[14].
There is no evidence to support the claim that the UN plans to microchip the entire world's population[19].
Furthermore, no mention of implanted microchips can be found in the UN's published goals[20].

dbce7f1b1425ce5edfbd6454ca71f756.claim: Video shows Democratic presidential candidates speechless for 20 seconds when discussing whether any of them started a business.
dbce7f1b1425ce5edfbd6454ca71f756.label: false
dbce7f1b1425ce5edfbd6454ca71f756.passage:
0: Democratic presidential candidates jumped over each other to land rhetorical punches against Mike Bloomberg at the Las Vegas debate , hitting the billionaire former mayor over redlining , stop and frisk , and his past critiques of Barack Obama .
1: Bloomberg selected a different highlight to share on Twitter the next day.
2: The video starts with Bloomberg on stage saying, "I’m the only one here I think that’s ever started a business.
3: Is that fair?"
4: In the video , Bloomberg’s question is met with silence and blank stares from the other Democrats on stage.
5: The sound of crickets plays in the background.
6: "OK," he says at the end of the 25-second clip.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Bloomberg’s video makes it look like he left the other presidential candidates speechless for 20 seconds.
8: But that’s not what actually happened.
9: In fact, there was a two-second pause between when the former mayor said "Is that fair?"
10: and "OK." Here are Bloomberg’s full remarks , which came in response to a question about his stance on redlining: "I've been well on the record against red-lining since I worked on Wall Street.
11: I was against it during the financial crisis.
12: I've been against it since.
13: "The financial crisis came about because the people that took the mortgages, packaged them, and other people bought them, those were — that's where all the disaster was.
14: Red-lining is still a practice some places, and we've got to cut it out.
15: But it's just not true.
16: "What I was going to say, maybe we want to talk about businesses.
17: I'm the only one here that I think that's ever started a business.
18: Is that fair?
19: OK." His last comment was met with laughter from the audience.
20: The video was selectively edited to make Bloomberg’s debate performance look better than it was — splicing together unrelated moments of expressive faces from his rivals.
21: RELATED: Bloomberg on the defensive, fact-checking the Las Vegas Democratic debate On Twitter, some users took it a step further, saying the clip is a "deepfake" and a violation of the platform’s new policy against manipulated videos.
22: According to Twitter’s policy on "synthetic and manipulated media," the company is only likely to remove videos that have been "significantly and deceptively altered or fabricated," "shared in a deceptive manner" and are "likely to impact public safety or cause serious harm."
23: As of now, Bloomberg’s video does not appear to meet those standards.
24: Twitter may label clips that meet just one of the criteria, but it has not yet done so for Bloomberg’s tweet.
25: A deepfake video is one that uses artificial intelligence to make it look like someone is doing or saying something that never occurred.
26: In contrast, the clip that Bloomberg shared is an example of what the Washington Post calls "splicing," or "editing together disparate videos" that "fundamentally alters the story that is being told."
27: Bloomberg’s video is the latest example of deceptive video editing techniques being used in the 2020 election.
28: On Feb. 6, President Donald Trump tweeted an edited video of his State of the Union address.
29: The clip makes it look like House Speaker Nancy Pelosi ripped up her copy of the speech after Trump introduced each of his guests, which included military families and a young woman receiving a scholarship.
30: In fact, Pelosi waited until the end of the address to rip up her copy.
31: And she stood and clapped for many guests.
32: PolitiFact reached out to Twitter and the Bloomberg campaign for comment, but we haven’t heard back.

gpt4: The claim that a video shows Democratic presidential candidates rendered speechless for 20 seconds when discussing if any of them started a business is untrue.
In actuality, the video was selectively edited to enhance Bloomberg’s debate performance, splicing together unrelated moments of expression from his opponents [20].
This technique, known as "splicing" or "editing together disparate videos", was used to fundamentally alter the story being presented [26].
It is worth noting that Bloomberg's full remarks, which were made in response to a question about his stance on redlining, deviate from what's shown in the clip [10].
Therefore, the claim misrepresents the actual events [8].

dd1b6f76641236daf7e81542e99c42db.claim: “black babies die at rates twice as high as white babies because of a lack of access to affordable health care.”
dd1b6f76641236daf7e81542e99c42db.label: true
dd1b6f76641236daf7e81542e99c42db.passage:
0: At a rally in Houston, Democratic presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg apologized for supporting the stop-and-frisk policy he endorsed while serving as mayor of New York City from 2002 to 2013.
1: Bloomberg told the mostly black audience at the rally that he should have "acted sooner and faster" to stop the policy and said if he were elected, he’d use "the power of the presidency to right the wrongs of institutional racism."
2: He used the rally as an opportunity to unveil a new initiative that he says will address issues specific to the black community in the United States: "Mike for Black America."
3: One issue he highlighted in his address was access to health care.
4: "We will build a future in which we better protect the health of black mothers and their babies," Bloomberg said at the rally.
5: "You should know that black babies die at rates twice as high as white babies because of a lack of access to affordable health care and here, in the wealthiest country in the world, we cannot accept that and we will change that."
6: Bloomberg’s figure is accurate, but is he right in his assessment of the cause of this disparity?
7: His team did not return a request for more information about his claim.
8: Mortality rate higher for black infants The latest statistics on infant mortality from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that there were 22,341 infant deaths reported in the United States in 2017, putting the mortality rate at 5.79 infant deaths per 1,000 live births.
9: Statistics on infant mortality are compiled based on birth and infant death certificates in cases where infants less than a year died during the calendar year.
10: Generally, the infant mortality rate has trended downward since 1995 and has declined 16% since 2005, when the rate was 6.86 deaths per 1,000 live births.
11: The CDC also analyzes the infant mortality rate by race.
12: In 2017, infants born to black women had the highest mortality rate of 10.97 deaths per 1,000 live births.
13: The mortality rate for infants born to non-Hispanic white mothers was 4.67 deaths per 1,000 live births, meaning infants born to black mothers have an infant mortality rate 2.35 times higher than infants born to white mothers, according to the CDC.
14: Bloomberg’s claim wasn’t limited to Texas, but this trend is also visible at the state level.
15: A 2018 report from the CDC looked at infant mortality data from 2013 to 2015 by state and race and found that, in Texas, the mortality rate for infants born to non-Hispanic white women was 5 deaths per 1,000 live births and was 10.52 for infants born to black women.
16: Exploring causes of disparity It’s true that infants born to black mothers have died at rates twice as high as white babies in recent years, but is it true that it is due to a lack of access to affordable health care?
17: It isn’t that simple.
18: The five leading causes of all infant deaths in 2017 identified by the CDC were all health related: Congenital malformations: 21% of infant deaths Disorders related to short gestation and low birthweight: 17% of infant deaths Maternal complications: 6% of infant deaths Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS): 6% of infant deaths Unintentional injuries: 6% of infant deaths In a 2019 report, the CDC noted that infants born to black women had the highest mortality rates for disorders related to short gestation (premature birth) and low birthweight and maternal complications.
19: Numerous academic studies and media investigations have highlighted correlations between access to health care and the disparity in infant and maternal mortality rates between black and white mothers.
20: But access to health care is widely considered to be one of many contributing factors.
21: One 2017 study published in the American Journal of Public Health identified other factors that contribute to the high black infant mortality rate: socioeconomic status, maternal behavior, "exposure to protective and risk factors over the course of a woman’s life," and certain historical factors like segregation, limited educational opportunities, structural racism, and intergenerational poverty.
22: This is not to say that a lack of access to health care is not a significant cause of this disparity.
23: A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association in 2019 explored how state Medicaid expansion associated with changes in low birthweight and preterm birth across different races — which are more likely to affect black mothers and infants than white mothers and infants.
24: The study did not explore the link between Medicaid expansion and reducing infant mortality.
25: Researchers found that overall, Medicaid expansion was not associated with differences in rates of low birth weight or preterm births.
26: However, they identified "significant improvements in relative disparities for black infants compared with white infants in states that expanded Medicaid vs. those that did not."
27: In other words, states that expanded Medicaid saw rates of low birthweight and preterm births decline among black mothers and infants.
28: In general, black mothers were less likely than white mothers to access prenatal care, according to data from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services’s Office of Minority Health.
29: In 2017, black mothers were 2.3 times more likely to receive no prenatal care or late prenatal care than non-Hispanic white mothers.
30: The same year, 66.6% of black mothers received prenatal care during the first trimester, compared to 82.4% of white mothers who accessed early care.

gpt4: The claim that black infants die at twice the rate of white infants due to a lack of access to affordable health care is validated by several reasons [16].

A multitude of academic studies and media analyses have discovered correlations between the discrepancy in infant and maternal mortality rates between black and white mothers and the accessibility to health care [19].
Moreover, according to data from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Minority Health, black mothers are generally less likely than white mothers to obtain prenatal care [28].

This disparity is further emphasized by a 2017 report that uncovered black mothers were 2.3 times more likely to receive no prenatal care or late prenatal care compared to non-Hispanic white mothers [29].
Also in 2017, only 66.6% of black mothers obtained prenatal care during the first trimester in stark contrast to the 82.4% of white mothers who sought early care [30].
These reasons attest to the veracity of the claim.

269c9ad3e761145a1b0a77b5ad3cb812.claim: “Starbucks CEO Has Admitted She Doesnt Like White People”
269c9ad3e761145a1b0a77b5ad3cb812.label: false
269c9ad3e761145a1b0a77b5ad3cb812.passage:
0: Don’t fall for social posts with the headline "NEW Starbucks CEO Has Admitted She Doesnt Like White People."
1: They are not true.
2: For one thing, the executive mentioned in one post , Rosalind Brewer, is the chief operating officer and group president of Starbucks, not the CEO.
3: But the bigger flaw is in its mischaracterization of something Brewer said in 2015, when she worked for another company.
4: In a CNN interview, she expressed a desire for diversity in the workplace and corporate leadership; she never said anything to suggest she has a problem with white people.
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook. )
7: At the time of the CNN interview, Brewer was CEO of Sam’s Club.
8: The interview was primarily about how Sam’s Club employees were affected by various state and city decisions to raise the minimum wage.
9: Near the end of the interview CNN’s Poppy Harlow shifted the conversation.
10: She pointed out that Brewer, as a black woman, was in a unique position as a minority in a corporate executive role.
11: Harlow then asked Brewer whose responsibility it is to make the decisions that increase representation for women like Brewer in corporate leadership positions.
12: "It starts with the top of many companies.
13: It has to start with top leadership," Brewer said.
14: "I can tell you that even with myself, I have to live it also.
15: My executive team is very diverse, and I make that a priority.
16: I demand it of my team and within the structure."
17: Brewer acknowledged that sometimes she considers it her responsibility to use her platform to encourage her partners to think about diversity in hiring.
18: She said she also demands diversity considerations in the hiring process and talks to her suppliers about diversity as well.
19: Then, she brought up one incident in particular.
20: "Just today, we met with a supplier, and the entire other side of the table was all Caucasian males," Brewer said in the interview.
21: "I decided not to talk about it directly with his folks in the room, because there were actually no females, like, levels down.
22: So I’m going to have to place a call to him."
23: Brewer did not say she disliked white people in general, or anyone at all.
24: Neither did she identify the supplier in question, other than mentioning which day the meeting occurred.
25: The post also erroneously says Brewer succeeded Howard Schultz as CEO in 2017.
26: In September 2017 , Starbucks named Brewer its group president and chief operating officer.
27: Kevin Johnson is Starbucks president and CEO, and he has been since April 2017 .

gpt4: The claim that "Starbucks CEO Has Admitted She Doesn't Like White People" is incorrect.
Firstly, it should be noted that the executive in question, Rosalind Brewer, is not the CEO of Starbucks, but the Chief Operating Officer and Group President [2][26].
Additionally, the claim seems to be a misinterpretation or misrepresentation of her views.

Brewer has spoken publicly in an interview with CNN about her commitment to fostering diversity in the workplace and corporate leadership, but she has never made any statement suggesting she has an issue with white people [4].

8aa4c8818508e38f4239132756a8ca8d.claim: “Breaking: UK Prepares For Full Lockdown After Hundreds Of New Cases — Wuhan Super Virus Updates.”
8aa4c8818508e38f4239132756a8ca8d.label: false
8aa4c8818508e38f4239132756a8ca8d.passage:
0: A split-screen video with a chyron broadcasting "Breaking News" exacerbates fears about the 2019 novel coronavirus, circulating mistruths about the state of the virus’ spread through the United Kingdom.
1: The 22-minute video post being shared on Facebook starts by simultaneously rolling three videos under this headline: "Breaking: UK Prepares For Full Lockdown After Hundreds Of New Cases — Wuhan Super Virus Updates."
2: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: It’s not clear where the video clips were shot, but they show a variety of disturbing scenes, including what appear to be four people in hazmat suits loading something into a van; an older Asian man being handcuffed and led away by what appear to be two police officers wearing medical face masks; and a younger Asian man outdoors wearing only underwear being led away by two men wearing uniforms.
5: As the video clips play, a male narrator says officials in the U.K. — which comprises England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland — are desperately searching for hundreds of coronavirus cases.
6: He goes on to share more conspiracy theories about the virus’ origins.
7: But the data doesn't indicate any such panic in the U.K. As of Feb. 24, 2020: The World Health Organization reported only nine confirmed cases of coronavirus in the U.K. (British officials say the number has risen to 13 .)
8: Eight of the people have been treated and discharged, The Telegraph, a British news organization reported .
9: The risk of catching the coronavirus in the U.K. is low, according to the country’s National Health Service.
10: British officials say they are monitoring airports with direct flights from China, and are recommending movement restrictions to residents only if they have been to Wuhan recently or have been to China or nearby countries and have respiratory symptoms.
11: The post was made by STFN Reloaded.
12: We have also rated as False a claim by that group that the coronavirus "causes sudden death syndrome."
13: And the Australian Associated Press said an STFN Reloaded claim that the coronavirus came from a Chinese lab is false.

gpt4: The claim of the U.K. preparing for a full lockdown due to hundreds of new cases of the coronavirus, dubbed as the Wuhan Super Virus, is false.
As reported by The Telegraph, eight of the infected people in the U.K have already been treated and discharged [8].
This is in line with the assertion made by the country's National Health Service that the risk of catching the coronavirus within the U.K. remains low[9].
Moreover, data collected up to February 24, 2020, does not indicate any form of panic in the country that would necessitate a lockdown [7].

British officials are implementing monitoring measures at airports with direct flights from China and only recommending movement restrictions to residents who have either visited Wuhan recently or have been to China or nearby countries and are showing respiratory symptoms [10].

b658620643e31c57d5d572fa6e4ad2ff.claim: ""Not once in his entire career in Washington, D.C., which started way back in 1991, has Democratic Socialist Bernie Sanders ever voted yes on sanctions against Russia."""
b658620643e31c57d5d572fa6e4ad2ff.label: half-true
b658620643e31c57d5d572fa6e4ad2ff.passage:
0: From honeymooning in the Soviet Union in 1988 to getting love from Russia for his presidential bids, Bernie Sanders has an uncommon connection with one of America’s chief adversaries.
1: It’s subjected the Vermont senator to a number of attacks.
2: On Feb. 22, 2020, the day Sanders won the Nevada caucuses and arguably established himself as the frontrunner for the Democratic presidential nomination, a post claimed: "Not once in his entire career in Washington, D.C., which started way back in 1991, has Democratic Socialist Bernie Sanders ever voted yes on sanctions against Russia."
3: Sanders has run as an independent in Vermont, was a member of the U.S. House from 1991 to 2007, and has since been a member of the Senate.
4: He calls himself a democratic socialist.
5: There aren’t many votes to look at when it comes to Russia, and Sanders’ voting history isn’t as clear-cut as the post claims.
6: Sanders’ Russia sanctions votes In recent years, the United States sanctioned Russia in response to allegations of corruption and human rights abuses.
7: It continued sanctions after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
8: Some of the sanctions were imposed by presidential executive order, without any vote in the Senate.
9: Here are the key votes: Dec. 6, 2012: Sanders voted no on the Magnitsky Act, which imposed visa bans and asset freezes on Russian officials linked to the 2009 death in prison of Sergei Magnitsky, a 37-year-old Russian whistleblower.
10: GQ reported on Feb. 23, 2020, that Sanders never explained his vote, but "fellow Dems suggest that it was because a free trade provision had been tucked into the legislative package."
11: Sanders’ campaign emphasized to us that in 2015, the Senate with unanimous consent extended the law to countries other than Russia, and said it was "more robust" than the original law.
12: June 14 and 15, 2017: Sanders votes yes on an amendment to a bill, adding Russia to a bill that was sanctioning Iran.
13: But the next day, Sanders voted no on the overall legislation , which put new sanctions on North Korea, as well as Russia and Iran.
14: On Russia, the bill targeted the country’s aggression in Ukraine and Syria, citing corruption, human rights abuses and weapons sales.
15: Sanders said at the time he feared the bill would endanger the 2015 nuclear deal, which was aimed at curbing Iran’s ability to develop a nuclear weapon.
16: "I am strongly supportive of the sanctions on Russia included in this bill.
17: It is unacceptable for Russia to interfere in our elections here in the United States, or anywhere around the world.
18: There must be consequences for such actions," he said in a statement at the time.
19: Jan. 16, 2019: The Senate failed to stop the Trump administration from easing sanctions on companies linked to Oleg Deripaska, a Russian billionaire with ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin.
20: Sanders missed the vote, but his absence did not affect the outcome.
21: He was meeting with women who accused his 2016 presidential campaign of sexual misconduct.

gpt4: The statement that Democratic Socialist Bernie Sanders has never voted in favor of sanctions against Russia throughout his career in Washington, D.C., is only partially accurate.

Sanders, who has been a member of the U.S House from 1991 to 2007 and the Senate since then, did express strong support for sanctions against Russia included in a specific bill, stating that there must be consequences for their actions[16][18][3].
However, the following day, Sanders voted against the overall legislation, which aimed to impose new sanctions on North Korea, in addition to Russia and Iran[13].
Therefore, while Sanders publicly declared his support for sanctions against Russia at one point, his voting record shows a different stance.

434f423391ea5ec6e9e85a87adc56d5c.claim: “When Fidel Castro came into office, you know what he did? He had a massive literacy program.”
434f423391ea5ec6e9e85a87adc56d5c.label: true
434f423391ea5ec6e9e85a87adc56d5c.passage:
0: Bernie Sanders' past praise for the welfare policies of countries such as Cuba and Nicaragua is front and center as he has moved into the lead in the Democratic primary.
1: In an interview on CBS News’ "60 Minutes," Sanders described what he saw as two sides to the regime of Cuba’s Fidel Castro.
2: "We're very opposed to the authoritarian nature of Cuba but you know, it's unfair to simply say everything is bad," Sanders said Feb. 23 .
3: "When Fidel Castro came into office, you know what he did?
4: He had a massive literacy program.
5: Is that a bad thing?
6: Even though Fidel Castro did it?"
7: Interviewer Anderson Cooper pressed Sanders on the dissidents sent to Cuban jails.
8: "That's right," Sanders said.
9: "And we condemn that."
10: Sanders’ critique of Cuba fell well short for many opponents of the regime.
11: Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, tweeted , "It really makes a difference when those you murder at the firing squad can read and write."
12: U.S. Rep. Donna Shalala , D-Fla., said, "I'm hoping that in the future, Sen. Sanders will take time to speak to some of my constituents before he decides to sing the praises of a murderous tyrant like Fidel Castro."
13: Sanders’ focus on the teaching side of Castro’s campaign downplayed its substantial political overtones.
14: But Castro did significantly expand literacy rates after seizing power.
15: "The academic consensus seems to be that Fidel Castro’s government did increase the literacy rate of the island’s population, at the same time that it clearly used the literacy campaign for propaganda purposes," said Jorge Duany, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University.
16: A 1984 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) report found that in 1959, 23.6% of the population above the age of 10 were illiterate.
17: By 1961, the number had fallen to 3.9%.
18: While health care statistics on Cuba have been questioned, experts we interviewed told us they were not aware of issues with this data.
19: Bringing literacy to Cuba’s peasants was a long-standing policy in Castro’s broader agenda.
20: In his 1957 manifesto , he included: "Immediate initiation of an intensive campaign against illiteracy, and civic education emphasizing the duties and rights of each citizen to his society and fatherland."
21: In 1961, about a quarter of a million teachers fanned out across the island nation.
22: Their ranks included formally trained teachers and members of such groups as the National   Federation of Sugar Workers, the Rebel Youth Association and the Ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces.
23: They identified nearly 1 million illiterate people, and by the end of the year over 700,000 passed a basic literacy test.
24: The teaching materials came with a blunt political message.
25: They were built on 15 lessons with titles that included "Fidel is Our Leader," "The Land is Ours," "Racial Discrimination" and "Housing."
26: The final literacy exam was based on the lesson "The Cuban Fishermen."
27: Education researchers Carolyn Davidson Abel and Charles Frederick Abel at Stephen F. Austin State University looked at whether the Cubans set the literacy bar too low, and found that they used a reasonable benchmark.
28: "We did see evidence of basic literacy development, typical of what we might like to see in first graders here in America," Abel said.
29: Today, the World Bank puts the adult literacy rate in Cuba at 99.8%, about 8 points higher than the average for the Caribbean region.
30: Sanders’ comments about Cuba mirror those of President Barack Obama in 2016 , soon after he had moved to open diplomatic relations with Cuba.
31: Obama spoke to a group of up-and-coming leaders of the Americas, and said their generation had the chance to get beyond old political labels and explore practical solutions.
32: "I said (to Castro), look, you've made great progress in educating young people.
33: Every child in Cuba gets a basic education — that's a huge improvement from where it was."
34: But Obama continued on to describe the benefits of private enterprise and the failures of the Cuban economy.
35: Above all, he urged his audience to be "practical."

gpt4: The claim that Fidel Castro initiated a massive literacy program when he came into power is accurate.
In an interview on CBS News’ "60 Minutes," Sanders acknowledged the two sides of the Castro regime, noting among other things, the existence of this literacy program[1].
Historical data and academic analysis back this assertion as well.
It is reported that after his rise to power, Castro made significant strides in expanding literacy rates across Cuba[14].

The academic community widely concurs, with Jorge Duany, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University, stating that while Castro's government used the literacy campaign for propaganda, it undeniably increased the literacy rate of Cuba's population[15].
UNESCO's 1984 report reveals that the illiteracy rate in 1959 stood at 23.6% for Cubans above the age of 10, which dropped to 3.9% by 1961[16][17].

This transformation can be attributed to the deployment of approximately 250,000 teachers across Cuba in 1961[21], who, within a year, identified and enabled over 700,000 previously illiterate individuals to pass a basic literacy test[23].
Today, according to the World Bank, the adult literacy rate in Cuba is approximately 99.8%, much higher than the average rate in the Caribbean region[29].

382dd1e69b53058dfe4fa8922a57b52c.claim: A photo shows Air Force One at the 2020 Daytona 500.
382dd1e69b53058dfe4fa8922a57b52c.label: false
382dd1e69b53058dfe4fa8922a57b52c.passage:
0: A photo shared on Facebook shows the president’s plane, Air Force One, amid a massive crowd at the Daytona 500, which President Donald Trump attended.
1: Only, it wasn’t taken in 2020 or any time in the last decade.
2: The photo was shared on Feb. 16, the date of the 2020 Daytona 500, with a caption that reads: "What an incredible moment for our President and our country!
3: God Bless the USA!"
4: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The image is authentic , but it’s from 2004 when President George W. Bush attended the event.
7: The photo was taken by photographer Jonathan Ferrey.
8: Its caption says, "Air Force One takes off with U.S. President Geore W. Bush aboard after attending the NASCAR Nextel Cup Daytona 500 on Feb. 15, 2004, at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla." Several commenters believed it showed President Trump’s visit and the crowd during this year’s race, and for good reason.
9: George W. Bush is the only other president to attend the event.
10: Presidents George H.W.
11: Bush and Ronald Reagan attended the Pepsi 400, which is held at the Daytona International Speedway in the summer.
12: Like Trump, the younger Bush served as the race’s grand marshal and was also seeking re-election at the time of his visit.
13: Nevertheless, this photo is missing context: It’s over 15 years old and two presidents removed from Trump.

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows Air Force One at the 2020 Daytona 500 is false.
The image, while authentic, actually dates back to the year 2004, and was taken when the then President, George W. Bush, attended the NASCAR Nextel Cup Daytona 500[6][1].

The confusion likely stemmed from the caption of the photo, which read, "Air Force One takes off with U.S. President George W. Bush aboard after attending the NASCAR Nextel Cup Daytona 500 on Feb. 15, 2004, at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla."
Many commenters mistakenly believed the photo depicted President Trump’s visit and the crowd during the 2020 race [8].

865c14839fb9b4ca5242fc55c044e979.claim: Bernie Sanders would “go beyond reform and reorder the economy in ways most Democrats — let alone most Americans — don’t support."""
865c14839fb9b4ca5242fc55c044e979.label: half-true
865c14839fb9b4ca5242fc55c044e979.passage:
0: In his speech after the Nevada caucuses, Pete Buttigieg took a shot at his rival Bernie Sanders, who had just won a clear victory.
1: "Sen. Sanders sees capitalism as the root of all evil," Buttigieg said .
2: "He’d go beyond reform and reorder the economy in ways most Democrats — let alone most Americans — don’t support."
3: Buttigieg is wrong to say most Democrats don’t support Sanders’ agenda .
4: Polling shows that key elements of Sanders’ economic platform are strongly popular among Democrats.
5: And several of them score majority support among all voters.
6: However, support among all voters for some of Sanders’ proposals declines when poll respondents are told about the costs.
7: And in some cases, less-aggressive policy options — some of them backed by Sanders’ competitors — receive wider support from voters than his proposals do.
8: Would Sanders’ platform "reorder the economy"?
9: We looked at several elements of Sanders’ platform that could potentially have an impact on the economy.
10: They include instituting single-payer health care; the Green New Deal to combat climate change; tuition-free college; student debt forgiveness; a $15 minimum wage; breaking up big banks, and paid family leave.
11: We found broad acceptance among economists that at least some of these policies would qualify as "reordering" the economy.
12: By shifting payments from private insurers to the federal government, single-payer health care would dramatically change the health care sector, which accounts for 17.7% of the nation’s gross domestic product .
13: This policy, and breaking up big banks, "would change things in a major way," said Stanford University economist Roger Noll.
14: "These are huge sectors."
15: The Green New Deal would affect a smaller, but still substantial , share of the economy that relates to energy, by setting aggressive targets for phasing out fossil fuels.
16: The proposal also includes a federal job guarantee.
17: Economists’ views vary on the scale of the other proposals, but some said that changes to the higher-education sector — making college tuition free and forgiving student loan debt — could have a significant impact on the economy.
18: And while the impact of other aspects of Sanders’ plan, such as a $15 minimum wage or paid family leave, might be less dramatic, they could have significant effects on certain regions and employment sectors.
19: "It's quite fair to say he is reordering the economy, given the massive transfer of money from the private sector to the government," said Daniel Mitchell, a pro-free market economist .
20: How popular are Sanders’ proposals?
21: We collected recent poll results on most of these proposals and put them into the chart below.
22: The questions in these polls did not identify the ideas as being backed by Sanders, and they offered basic descriptions of the plans, without mentioning complications, such as the cost involved.
23: The data shows that — contrary to what Buttigieg said — a large share of Democrats support Sanders’ economic proposals, according to polls.
24: Among Democrats, single-payer health care receives upwards of 58% support, the Green New Deal gets 86%, a $15 minimum wage gets 84%, tuition-free college gets 76%, student-loan forgiveness gets 79%, breaking up big banks gets 60%, and paid family leave gets 94%.
25: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Among all Americans, only one of these policies — single-payer health care — gets less than 50% support.
26: Paid family leave got 84% support, while the other policies had support levels in the 53% to 63% range among all voters.
27: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Warning signs That said, other poll results give Buttigieg’s remark some support.
28: First, when we inquired about his comment, the Buttigieg camp pointed to health insurance.
29: As it turns out, Buttigieg’s own policy preference — a public option to buy into Medicare for those who want it — wins majority support from all Americans, a level of support significantly stronger than the 30% to 40% national approval rates for a Sanders-style single-payer system.
30: In February 2020, the Kaiser Family Foundation tracking poll found that 44% of voters preferred a public option, compared to 26% of voters who preferred single-payer and 23% who opposed both.
31: Democrats alone also expressed a preference for the public option, with 51% favoring the public option compared to 39% for single-payer.
32: Second, providing poll respondents with more complete descriptions of a policy option — often including the cost required — usually reduced the levels of support.
33: Here are some examples: • $15 minimum wage .
34: A SurveyMonkey poll conducted for Business Insider asked two questions about the $15 minimum wage.
35: The first was, "Do you support or oppose increasing the federal minimum wage to $15 per hour?"
36: This question elicited 63% support among all respondents.
37: The second question added that the Congressional Budget Office — the non-partisan number-crunching arm of Congress — found that a $15 minimum wage would increase wages for 27 million workers and lift 1.3 million households out of poverty, but could also eliminate 1.3 million jobs.
38: Adding this caveat dropped support levels to just 37%.
39: • Student loan forgiveness .
40: A Quinnipiac University poll in April 2019 asked two questions about a plan for student loan forgiveness.
41: First, the pollsters asked, "Do you support or oppose the federal government forgiving up to $50,000 in student loans for individuals who live in households that make less than $250,000 a year?"
42: This won support from 57% of all Americans, and 79% of Democrats.
43: Then they asked, "Would you support or oppose this plan to forgive student loans if it was paid for by a new tax on wealthy individuals?"
44: On this question, Democratic support remained strong — 72% — but reaction among respondents overall turned negative, with 44% support and 52% opposition.
45: • Paid family leave .
46: A survey sponsored by the libertarian Cato Institute showed strong initial support — 74% among all respondents — for a paid family leave program granting 12 weeks for birth, adoption, or medical need.
47: But support dropped significantly when possible impacts were mentioned.
48: The poll found that only 48% would still support the policy if it cost another $450 a year in taxes.
49: • Green New Deal .
50: A Washington Post-Kaiser Family Foundation poll in July and August 2019 found broad support for individual elements of the Green New Deal, which Sanders backs.
51: These include a jobs guarantee (78%), energy efficiency improvements for existing buildings (70%), a goal of 100 percent of U.S. power coming from emissions-free sources within 10 years (69%), increased federal spending on disaster-prevention infrastructure (67%), new regulations on businesses (61%), and reductions in coal mining jobs (55%).
52: The one unpopular aspect of the plan?
53: Increasing spending by trillions of dollars, which was backed by just 30% of respondents.

gpt4: Bernie Sanders's economic platform includes ambitious proposals that seek to redefine the economy.
Alluding to these, it has been stated Sanders would "go beyond reform and reorder the economy in ways most Democrats — let alone most Americans — don’t support"[2].
Polling results provide somewhat mixed evidence in relation to this claim.
On one hand, key elements of Sanders’ economic platform are popular among Democrats, with several policies gaining majority support among all voters [4][5].
Among Democrats, for example, there is strong support for single-payer health care, the Green New Deal, a $15 minimum wage, tuition-free college, student-loan forgiveness, and paid family leave [24].
This suggests that a significant portion of Democrats indeed support Sanders' economic proposals [23].
This is despite Sanders' proposed policies involving a massive transfer of money from the private sector to the government, as pointed out by a pro-free market economist [19].
Nonetheless, other poll results show that providing more complete descriptions of a policy option, especially mentioning the cost involved, can reduce the level of support for it [32][38][53].
One such poll found that support for a policy fell to 48% if it meant paying an extra $450 in taxes annually [48].
When considering the reaction of overall respondents, not just Democrats, the support for Sanders' economic proposals is not as strong, with more opposing than supporting [44].
Thus, the claim is deemed half-true, as it holds some truth in the broader perspective, though not fully accurate within the Democratic partisan landscape.

840e15e0aee6f64008f597c32417ff88.claim: Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., said “defending Trump is more important than the United States.”
840e15e0aee6f64008f597c32417ff88.label: false
840e15e0aee6f64008f597c32417ff88.passage:
0: A popular Facebook post is putting words in the mouth of Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif.
1: The post , which includes a quote about President Donald Trump alongside an image of Nunes, was shared in a popular liberal Facebook page called Go Left.
2: The post claims to be based on leaked audio from July 2019.
3: "Defending Trump is more important than the United States," the image reads.
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared more than 1,400 times on several social media platforms.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) We reached out to Go Left for its evidence for the post, but we haven’t heard back.
8: As the ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee, Nunes was one of Trump’s staunchest defenders during the president’s impeachment.
9: But the Facebook post is inaccurate — the leaked audio it cites was recorded in July 2018, not 2019.
10: And Nunes didn’t say anything close to the quote Go Left published.
11: The audio was recorded at a private fundraiser for Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, R-Wash., that Nunes attended in July 2018.
12: MSNBC first obtained and aired the clips during the Rachel Maddow Show on Aug. 8, 2018.
13: Nunes’ comments focused on former special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation of 2016 Russian election interference and the role of the Trump campaign.
14: "So therein lies, so it’s like your classic Catch-22 situation where we were at a – this puts us in such a tough spot.
15: If (then-Attorney General Jeff) Sessions won’t unrecuse and Mueller won’t clear the president, we’re the only ones.
16: Which is really the danger," Nunes said in one of the clips that MSNBC published.
17: "That’s why I keep, and thank you for saying it by the way, I mean we have to keep all these seats.
18: We have to keep the majority.
19: If we do not keep the majority, all of this goes away."
20: The audio shows that Nunes was interested in defending Trump from the Mueller investigation to try and keep the Republican majority in Congress ahead of the midterm elections.
21: But none of the four clips that MSNBC published included Nunes saying anything close to "defending Trump is more important than the United States."
22: That distortion was added later by several liberal blogs and YouTube videos .
23: We reached out to Nunes’ press office for comment, but we haven’t heard back.
24: The Facebook post is inaccurate.

gpt4: The claim that Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., stated "defending Trump is more important than the United States" is proven to be false.
First, the Facebook post that initially made this claim is inaccurate as the leaked audio it referred to was recorded in July 2018, not 2019 as implied [9].
Second, the quote attributed to Nunes by Go Left is not aligning with what the representative actually said [10].
Lastly, none of the four clips that MSNBC published included Nunes making a statement that insinuated defending Trump was of more value than the welfare of the United States [21].
Therefore, based on the evidence provided, the claim cannot be substantiated.

837fad0f41601baf2733e18af7c08513.claim: “The mayor of Livermore California explains Trump’s popularity and success.”
837fad0f41601baf2733e18af7c08513.label: false
837fad0f41601baf2733e18af7c08513.passage:
0: We can’t explain how Marshall Kamena, a former mayor of Livermore, Calif., got linked in the first place to an online post defending President Donald Trump.
1: But we know he didn’t write it.
2: "The mayor of Livermore California explains Trump’s popularity and success.
3: This is perhaps the best explanation for Trump's popularity," said the headline of a June 16, 2018, LinkedIn post shared on Facebook.
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The column on Trump was actually written by conservative author Evan Sayet and posted July 13, 2017, on townhall.com.
7: It’s been widely misattributed to Kamena, whose mayoralty ended in late 2011.
8: The current Livermore mayor is John Marchand.
9: Versions of the LinkedIn headline have appeared elsewhere since 2017 (including the website of an Orlando radio station), claiming that Kamena wrote a good read offering a better understanding of Trump and U.S. politics.
10: The posts claim that Kamena is a registered Democrat who "ran on the Democratic ticket," yet is "as conservative as they come."
11: We don’t know Kamena’s political leaning or registration; Livermore local elections are nonpartisan.
12: PolitiFact tried to get in touch with Kamena but didn’t hear back from him.
13: The body of the LinkedIn blog post does not match its headline.
14: The blog post consists of an introductory paragraph followed by the full text of Sayet’s column.
15: In that introduction, the author of the Linked blog post acknowledges in a muddled way that Sayet’s column was "mistakenly attributed" to Kamena.

gpt4: The claim that “The mayor of Livermore California explains Trump’s popularity and success" is false.

A clear indication of this is highlighted in the introduction of a blog post where it's stated in an unclear manner that the column, which discusses Trump's popularity and success, was "mistakenly attributed" to the former mayor of Livermore California, Marshall Kamena[15].
This column was, in fact, composed by conservative writer Evan Sayet and was initially published on July 13, 2017, on townhall.com[6].
Numerous sources have mistakenly attributed the column to Kamena, who served as mayor until the end of 2011[7] despite concrete evidence showing he was not the author[1].

4bc1f679ff7cfe6b56848f9b09d5aaaa.claim: “If you like your private plan, you can keep it.”
4bc1f679ff7cfe6b56848f9b09d5aaaa.label: half-true
4bc1f679ff7cfe6b56848f9b09d5aaaa.passage:
0: As the Democratic presidential campaign moves to the battleground of South Carolina this weekend, candidate Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, is highlighting his health plan as he seeks to slow the momentum of the front-runner, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
1: In a video ad airing across the state, Buttigieg argues that his health plan — called "Medicare for All Who Want It" — offers Americans their choice of insurance plans, in a way he says Sanders’ more sweeping "Medicare for All" plan does not.
2: The Sanders plan would eliminate private insurance and move everyone into a government-run program.
3: Under Buttigieg’s proposal, the ad says, "Everyone gets access to Medicare, if they choose."
4: Specifically, according to campaign documents, people or employers could buy into a government-provided health plan, which the campaign says would provide an "affordable, comprehensive alternative" to what is sold on the private market.
5: But, the voiceover adds, "if you like your private plan, you can keep it."
6: This isn’t the first time a politician has made such a promise.
7: Arguing in favor of the Affordable Care Act, then-President Barack Obama repeatedly said the health law would let people keep their private health plans, if they liked them.
8: That didn’t pan out: Millions of Americans’ plans were canceled, spawning months of controversy.
9: In 2013, PolitiFact rated Obama’s statement the "Lie of the Year."
10: With that context, we decided to look deeper at Buttigieg’s remark.
11: We reached out to his campaign but never heard back.
12: An uncertain market Experts we talked to said the former mayor’s remark is remarkably similar to Obama’s ― right down to the pitfalls it encounters.
13: Those policy analysts said Buttigieg is trying to differentiate his plan from Sanders’ sweeping proposal, arguing his offering is more moderate than Sanders’ and preserves choice.
14: He suggests many Americans would be able to pick between buying private insurance or opting into the government plan.
15: But does that mean that if you like your plan, you can keep it?
16: As the Obama White House learned, not necessarily.
17: "It’s like déjà vu all over again," said Sabrina Corlette, a research professor at Georgetown University’s Center on Health Insurance Reforms.
18: The problem is that private insurance availability isn’t up to the government.
19: To be sure, state and federal regulators have the power to dictate, for example, the inclusion of certain benefits and to set basic consumer protections.
20: But the government cannot specifically require insurance companies to offer plans, and any carrier has the option to stop providing coverage.
21: Already, market forces dictate what health insurance is available from year to year.
22: For example, negotiations between an insurer and physicians could mean that an insurer drops doctors from its network.
23: Changing profit margins could drive a private carrier to exit a certain market.
24: An employer looking to trim expenses might decide to change health insurers, changing coverage offerings for employees.
25: Buttigieg’s health plan — which would more generously subsidize people buying private insurance than the ACA does and create a public health insurance option that individuals and employers could buy ― wouldn’t change any of those economic scenarios.
26: "When you have private plans offered and sold by private companies, those private companies are going to make business decisions that might affect your coverage," Corlette said.
27: "They can opt to get out of the business."
28: That’s been especially clear in the ACA individual marketplace.
29: In many counties, only one private insurer sells coverage on the marketplace.
30: It’s impossible to predict, but a competing public option might change the financial incentives for those plans and push some of those carriers to abandon the exchange.
31: If that happened, people using that plan would lose the insurance they have, regardless of how they feel about it.
32: Put more forcefully, "There’s no way the government can guarantee a private plan will continue, without mandating it will," said Cynthia Cox, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation.
33: So, she added, suggesting that people who like their private plans will have the option to keep them under Buttigieg’s proposal is "probably not true."
34: (KHN is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
35: The employer question This is especially the case when it comes to the nearly 160 million people who get their insurance from an employer.
36: Already, that group experiences volatility when it comes to their health insurance.
37: In 2019, 53% of employers providing coverage considered changing the plan or the carrier they offered, according to a KFF survey .
38: Of that group, almost a fifth — 18% ― ultimately did change insurance carriers.
39: That flux would likely increase under a plan like Buttigieg’s.
40: Already, many employers (particularly smaller ones) indicate frustration with providing a health benefit that is increasingly complex and expensive.
41: If a public option were cheaper, more might shift employees into that pool, dropping private insurance.
42: "Even if you don’t want the public option, your employer might decide that they do," Cox said.
43: How big the change would be is difficult to gauge.
44: It depends, for instance, on how generous the public option is, how much it costs employers and whether current private insurance trends continue.
45: Still, "any change you make to the health care environment would cause changes to reverberate throughout the system," said Sherry Glied, a health economist and dean of New York University’s Wagner School of Public Service.
46: "Any government action will cause change to happen more than they would otherwise."
47: It’s worth noting that many people may not be affected.
48: Under the ACA, for instance, 4 million lost their plans, or fewer than 2% of all people who had coverage.
49: Most people who move from private insurance to the public option would likely have better benefits, said Benjamin Sommers, a health economist at the Harvard T.H.
50: Chan School of Public Health.
51: But, some would be unhappy to lose the existing, private coverage that they know.
52: "The more accurate soundbite would be most people with private insurance would be able to keep it," he added.
53: "That would beg the question of who isn’t included there — and the answer is, we don’t know."
54: And, in contrast with Sanders’ Medicare for All single-payer proposal, Buttigieg’s plan would preserve much of the current private insurance.
55: But Buttigieg suggests that Medicare for All Who Want It — if administered well — could function as a " glide path " to a Medicare for All world, eventually bringing everyone into the public system.
56: "There’s good reason to think some of the private insurance competition won’t fare well against ‘Medicare for All Who Want It,’ " Sommers said.
57: "You might see some of the private plans dropping out.
58: And that may be a sign the policy is working."

gpt4: The claim that "If you like your private plan, you can keep it" is determined to be half-true.
The control over the private insurance availability isn't entirely vested in the government[18].
When private companies offer private medical schemes, they're allowed to decide on the continuity of such plans based on their business requirements[26].
This would mean that the government cannot specifically command insurance companies to offer plans, and these carriers are optional for providing coverage[20].
According to Cynthia Cox, Vice President at the Kaiser Family Foundation, the government cannot guarantee the continuation of a private plan unless it mandates it[32].
To shed light on Buttigieg's proposal, campaign documents clarified that individuals or employers may opt for a government-offered health plan.
This, however, does not guarantee the people who favour their private plans to keep them, which was called "probably not true"[33].
Likewise, there are possibilities that your chosen employer might opt for the public option, even if you desire otherwise[42].

Thus, while the Sanders plan could lead to everyone being encompassed under a government-run insurance program[2], Buttigieg's proposal foresees a significant flux where Americans could pick between private insurance or a government plan[14][39].
However, some may lose their existing private coverage, which could be unsettling[51].

a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.claim: Say Bernie Sanders said, “Italians are gangsters and Irish are drunk and Jews are greedy and black people smell.”
a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.label: false
a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.passage:
0: As U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders has tightened his hold on frontrunner status for the Democratic presidential nomination, having clinched the Nevada caucuses on Feb. 23, his detractors have tapped into an archive of video footage from the longtime lawmaker’s career.
1: "Here are the videos Bernie DOESN’T want you to see," reads the description of a video posted to Facebook on Feb. 19 .
2: It starts by showing what looks like an old clip of Sanders speaking to a class of middle-school children.
3: "What we learned is that black people smell," he says.
4: "All right, what about Jewish people?
5: … How are they different than other people?
6: Their religious beliefs were different but also they were greedy and selfish people, also had strange sexual habits so forth and so on.
7: What does everybody know about the Irish?
8: They …" A student offers: "Get in fights?"
9: "Get in fights because they’re drunk," Sanders says.
10: "All the Irish people do is drink.
11: That’s the Irish.
12: All Italians are gangsters, and Irish are drunk, and Jews are greedy, and black people smell.
13: OK?"
14: Not OK.
15: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
16: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
17: The footage of Sanders is authentic, but it’s been edited to appear that he is offering his derogatory opinions on black, Italian, Irish and Jewish people.
18: (For the record, Sanders is Jewish .)
19: The clips featured in the Facebook post are from a television show called "Bernie Speaks with the Community" that Sanders hosted on a public access channel when he was the mayor of Burlington, Vt.
20: In episode 39 of the show, which aired on Dec. 4, 1987 , Sanders discusses racial stereotypes and the importance of humanizing people who are different from you with a group of schoolchildren.
21: One student talks about how black people were dehumanized during slavery.
22: "What you’re getting at is a word that I will use: stereotype," Sanders replies.
23: "What does the word stereotype mean in the context that you’re talking about it?"
24: After fielding a few answers from the class, Sanders says: "If you want to deal with a group of people, essentially if you want to do bad things to them, you do, what I call, dehumanize them.
25: You make them less than human beings.
26: And what you do therefore is you develop a stereotypical image of them.
27: A stereotype.
28: … What about black people?
29: What’s the stereotype that we know about black people?
30: … When I was a young person, what we learned is that black people smell.
31: They had a special odor.
32: That was what went all around, that black people smelled and that they were pretty stupid.
33: Over the course of the nearly hourlong segment, Sanders engages with the class, asking questions, listening to the students’ answers and sharing his own experiences.
34: Within the scope of the show, it’s clear that he’s criticizing racial stereotypes, not professing them as his own opinions about Italians, Irish, Jews and others.
35: But that context does not appear in the seconds of footage that appears on Facebook.
36: "The Daily Show" host Trevor Noah covered the comments in May 2019 after the public access channel released recordings of Sanders’ show.
37: On YouTube, the Daily Show describes Sanders as "giving Vermont children head-scratching lessons on stereotypes."

gpt4: The claim that Bernie Sanders made derogatory statements about Italians, Irish, Jews, and black people is false.
The footage utilized as proof is authentic but was intentionally edited to misrepresent Sanders' original message [17].
This misleading footage was part of a Facebook post which was flagged in an effort to address false news and misinformation [15].
The actual origins of this footage stem from a television show called "Bernie Speaks with the Community", which Sanders hosted during his tenure as the mayor of Burlington, Vermont [19].

Contextually, within the show, specifically in episode 39 which aired on December 4, 1987, Sanders discussed racial stereotypes and emphasized the significance of understanding and accepting people who are different from oneself [20].

The seconds of the footage published on Facebook do not include this broader context [35] and it is clear that within the programme, Sanders' intent was to critique and confront harmful racial stereotypes, rather than endorsing them as his personal opinions [34].

b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.claim: 20 million Chinese converted to Islam after it’s proven that the coronavirus doesn’t affect Muslims.
b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.label: false
b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.passage:
0: Amid fears about the coronavirus disease , a YouTube video offers a novel way to inoculate yourself: convert to Islam.
1: "20m Chinese gets converted to Islam after it is proven that corona virus did not affect the Muslims," reads the title of a video posted online Feb. 18 .
2: The footage shows a room full of men raising an index finger and reciting what sounds like the Shahadah , a statement of faith in Islam.
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: That’s because the footage is from at least as far back as May 26, 2019, when it was posted on Facebook with this caption: "Alhamdulillah welcome to our brothers in faith."
6: On Nov. 7, 2019, it was posted on YouTube with this title: "MashaaAllah hundreds converted to Islam in Philippines."
7: Both posts appeared online before the current outbreak of the new coronavirus, COVID-19, was first reported in Wuhan, China, on Dec. 31, 2019.
8: But even if the footage followed the outbreak, Muslims are not immune to COVID-19, as the Facebook post claims.
9: After China, Iran has emerged as the second focal point for the spread of COVID-19, the New York Times reported on Feb. 24 .
10: "The Middle East is in many ways the perfect place to spawn a pandemic, experts say, with the constant circulation of both Muslim pilgrims and itinerant workers who might carry the virus."
11: On Feb. 18, Newsweek reported that coronavirus "poses a serious risk to millions of inmates in China’s Muslim prison camps."

gpt4: The claim that 20 million Chinese people converted to Islam after it was allegedly proven that the coronavirus does not affect Muslims is false.
This incompatible assertion was flagged as part of Facebook's initiatives to combat the spread of fake news and misinformation on its News Feed [3].
The footage that is referenced to in this claim actually dates back to at least May 26, 2019, well before the outbreak of the coronavirus [5].
This proves that both posts surfaced online before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first reported in Wuhan, China, on December 31, 2019 [7].
