16: "This patient was admitted to our facility in late February, and remains in our care," the letter reads.
17: "Upon recognizing that the patient was a potential COVID-19 case, Doctors Hospital of Sarasota immediately and appropriately activated all protocols for handling potential COVID-19 cases, including immediate isolation."
18: YourContent cites the letter in its story.
19: But the letter does not say anything about additional cases of the coronavirus or how many people may have been exposed to the infected patient.
20: We reached out to Doctors Hospital and YourContent for comment, but we haven’t heard back.
21: Since its outbreak in Wuhan, China, in December, the 2019 coronavirus has infected more than 87,000 people in 58 countries.
22: In the United States, there have been 43 confirmed cases and six deaths , as of March 2, not including those repatriated to the country.
23: The Florida hospital mentioned in the article did not "report a coronavirus ‘infestation’ with multiple confirmed patients."

gpt4: The claim that a Florida hospital reported a coronavirus 'infestation' with multiple confirmed patients is false.

The information appears to have originated from a website operated by Nikolaos Hatziefstathiou, a man from Pennsylvania who has previously been accused of creating fake documents, impersonating journalists, and producing false news stories [8].

No confirmation of this claim has been provided by pertinent authorities such as the state, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, or the hospital alleged to have reported this infestation[7].

On March 1, the Florida Department of Health released a press statement confirming two presumptive cases of the virus in Florida [11], with no mention of an 'infestation' or any extensive exposed population segment mentioned in the letter the false claim was based on[19].

e18a61f69136d4c282b2ee9edbf3b262.claim: Democratic members of Congress who represent Cuban Americans in Florida and have been critical of Sanders “just so happen to be supporting other candidates.”
e18a61f69136d4c282b2ee9edbf3b262.label: half-true
e18a61f69136d4c282b2ee9edbf3b262.passage:
0: Weeks before Florida’s March 17 primary, U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders finds himself in hot water with some Democratic members of Congress over his comments about Cuba.
1: On "60 Minutes," Sanders said not everything Fidel Castro did was bad when he took power, singling out a literacy campaign .
2: The criticism came fast, including from Florida’s Republican Sens.
3: Marco Rubio and Rick Scott and some prominent Democrats.
4: CNN anchor Chris Cuomo asked Sanders about the reaction in a town hall the next day: "Now Democratic members of Congress who represent Cuban Americans in Florida — obviously you've got to win there — they're attacking your comment as ‘absolutely unacceptable,’ singing the praises of a murderous tyrant.
5: Response?"
6: Sanders dismissed the criticism from fellow Democrats during their back and forth .
7: "By the way, all of those congresspeople that you mentioned just so happen to be supporting other candidates, just accidentally, no doubt, coincidentally," Sanders said.
8: Sanders claim suggests — but doesn’t specify names — that the members of Congress prefer other candidates.
9: They do seem to prefer anyone but Sanders, but they haven’t made specific endorsements, and they’re officially neutral.
10: It was easy to narrow down where the criticism was coming from.
11: There are two Democratic congresswomen from South Florida who had tough words for Sanders, and both used just the words Cuomo described.
12: They are South Florida Reps. Debbie Mucarsel-Powell and Donna Shalala.
13: Mucarsel-Powell called Sanders’ comments "absolutely unacceptable."
14: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Shalala tweeted , "I'm hoping that in the future, Senator Sanders will take time to speak to some of my constituents before he decides to sing the praises of a murderous tyrant like Fidel Castro."
15: div class='artembed'>See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com In 2018, both women won Miami-Dade districts that were previously held by Republicans and face competitive contests this year.
16: Both Shalala (District 27) and Mucarsel-Powell (District 26) represent districts that have a majority Hispanic population, and around 38% of the population is Cuban.
17: RELATED: Fact-checking Bernie Sanders' claim on Cuba literacy under Castro Shalala has donated to Sanders’ opponents Shalala and Mucarsel-Powell have indicated that they are neutral in the primary .
18: However, both have been skeptical about the possibility of Sanders becoming the party’s nominee.
19: "He’s not going to be the nominee," Shalala told the Miami Herald in mid February when asked if she would campaign for Sanders should he win the nomination.
20: "That’s a hypothetical question, and since I don’t think he’s going to be the nominee, I don’t have to answer the question."
21: Mucarsel-Powell was more forceful in her response to the Herald: "I’m seriously considering endorsing another candidate, that’s my answer to you."
22: A spokesman for Shalala said she will not endorse anyone until after the Florida primary.
23: But she has not held back on donations.
24: FEC records show that Shalala gave $1,000 to Sen. Amy Klobuchar’s presidential campaign in recent months, half in December and half in September.
25: She also gave $500 to former Vice President Joe Biden in September.
26: In September 2019, both Shalala and Mucarsel-Powell appeared at a Biden campaign event for Latino voters in Little Havana, a Miami neighborhood.
27: Shalala also attended events in Miami-Dade County for Klobuchar and Bloomberg.
28: (Shalala has long-standing relationships with many Democrats.
29: She was President Bill Clinton’s former Health and Human Services secretary.)
30: Mucarsel-Powell also has no plans to endorse and remains undecided, her spokesman told us.
31: She has not made any donations to presidential candidates.

gpt4: The claim that Democratic members of Congress who represent Cuban Americans in Florida and have been critical of Sanders are supporting other candidates is partially accurate.
Sanders himself acknowledged in a statement that these congresspeople "just so happen to be supporting other candidates" and he suggests that this isn't a coincidence[7].
However, it's important to note that this doesn't necessarily mean they are exclusively preferring individuals other than Sanders, and nor have they made any specific endorsements.
These representatives are maintaining an official neutrality in the presidential endorsement process[9].
As such, it would be a half-truth to imply or conclude that their criticism of Sanders is solely due to their support for other candidates.

e2be407bed46a5905024b4b2d17cc2b9.claim: the media cut out his request of Russian hackers to find Hillary Clinton’s emails “right at the end so that you don’t see the laughter, the joke.”
e2be407bed46a5905024b4b2d17cc2b9.label: false
e2be407bed46a5905024b4b2d17cc2b9.passage:
0: It was one of the most memorable quotes from the 2016 presidential campaign, and President Donald Trump said the media got it all wrong.
1: In his Conservative Political Action Conference speech, Trump accused the media of being "dishonest" in its coverage of him inviting Russia to find Hillary Clinton’s emails in a July 2016 press conference.
2: "Remember this thing, ‘Russia, if you're listening’?’ Remember, it was a big thing, in front of 25,000 people.
3: ‘Russia if you're…’ It was all said in a joke," Trump said Feb. 29.
4: "They cut it off right at the end so that you don't then see the laughter, the joke.
5: And they said, ‘He asked.
6: He asked for help.’ Right?"
7: Trump continued: "Russia, if you're listening… A very famous — they cut that thing so quick at the end because they didn't want to hear the laughter in the place and me laughing.
8: It was just ‘boom.’ These are really dishonest people."
9: Just like at the 2019 CPAC, where he used a similar line , Trump was not being honest about what happened July 27, 2016, at his Doral, Fla., resort.
10: RELATED: Hillary Clinton claims Donald Trump invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to hack Americans Subhead: What Trump said at his July 2016 press conference in Doral about Russia Trump’s retelling made it sound like the Russia line happened at a big rally with "25,000 people."
11: But it emerged during a one-hour press conference at his Doral resort.
12: Trump talked about Clinton’s emails several times, and at no point did he indicate he was joking.
13: (That excuse was televised the next day.)
14: "Russia, if you’re listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing," Trump told a roomful of TV cameras and reporters (including this fact-checker ).
15: "I think you will probably be rewarded mightily by our press.
16: Let’s see if that happens."
17: Trump delivered his comment (around minute 13:30 on the C-SPAN video ) with a straight face.
18: We didn’t hear any laughter after what he said; it was news.
19: The Q&A continued with Trump calling on a reporter who asked about the minimum wage .
20: In the same press conference, Trump said , "By the way, they hacked — they probably have her 33,000 emails.
21: I hope they do.
22: They probably have her 33,000 emails that she lost and deleted because you'd see some beauties there.
23: So let's see."
24: And when NBC reporter Katy Tur asked whether he was encouraging a foreign country to hack into emails, he said, "Now, if Russia or China or any other country has those emails, I mean, to be honest with you, I'd love to see them."
25: Trump tweeted a similar statement after the news conference (with still no trace of an LOL).
26: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Trump cast the comment as a joke later in the day, amid criticism of his request.
27: Fox News’ Brian Kilmeade interviewed Trump the same day for a segment to run the next morning on "Fox and Friends."
28: He asked Trump, "Were you being sarcastic?"
29: Trump replied: "Of course, I'm being sarcastic."
30: Trump’s response caught on with supporters Rudy Giuliani and Newt Gingrich who said the media missed the joke.
31: There’s no way to know what was going through Trump’s mind when he made the comment.
32: Our job is to look for whether people laughed, and whether the media deceptively left that out (and neither happened).
33: The same day as Trump’s press conference, Russians launched their first email spear-phishing campaign of emails used by Clinton’s personal office.

gpt4: The claim that the media omitted evidence of laughter following Donald Trump's request for Russian hackers to find Hillary Clinton’s emails, suggesting it was a joke, is false.
Trump indeed requested Russian entities to find the missing emails from Hillary Clinton's server in several instances, and at no point was it implied that he was joking [12][14].
His comments were received and handled as serious news, and no laughter followed his remarks [18].
His continued discourse later, when a reporter asked him whether he was inciting foreign countries to intrude digitally, confirmed his initial statement was not made in jest [24].
Also, a thorough review of the reactions and media coverage showed no signs of deception or factual manipulation related to omitting any laughter or suggesting that his statement was a joke [32].

eddb49d3e69da1f55220b51500a9fa78.claim: the Vatican confirmed that Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
eddb49d3e69da1f55220b51500a9fa78.label: false
eddb49d3e69da1f55220b51500a9fa78.passage:
0: Pope Francis recently canceled some engagements after he was seen coughing and sneezing during an Ash Wednesday mass in Rome.
1: The rare cancellations came as the coronavirus outbreak in Italy has infected more than 1,600 people , mostly in the northern region, and has people questioning whether the pope himself has contracted the virus.
2: One YouTube video takes the rumor further by stating that the Vatican confirmed "Pope Francis and two aides" tested positive for the coronavirus.
3: This isn’t true.
4: There has been no official confirmation that the 83-year-old Catholic leader, or any of his aides, tested positive for the virus.
5: The video was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: We could find no credible sources that say the pope — who lost part of a lung to an illness as a young man — was tested for the current coronavirus , or that he tested positive.
8: The Vatican has repeatedly denied the claims and described his condition as a "slight illness" without giving more details.
9: Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni dismissed the coronavirus speculation, telling journalists that there’s "no evidence that would lead to diagnosing anything but a mild indisposition."
10: The pope appeared at the Vatican Apostolic Palace window on March 1 to address thousands in St Peter’s Square in his first public appearance in days.

gpt4: The claim that the Vatican confirmed Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus is inaccurate.

The assertion seems to be fueled by a YouTube video[2], but there has been no official confirmation that the 83-year-old Catholic leader or any of his aides returned a positive result for the virus[4].
Instead, the Vatican, through spokesman Matteo Bruni, has dismissed such speculation.
Bruni has stated unequivocally that there is "no evidence that would lead to diagnosing anything but a mild indisposition"[9].
The Vatican has also described Pope Francis's condition as a "slight illness" and has not provided further details[8].
Direct denials from the Vatican have refuted the claim that Pope Francis and his two aides were infected with the coronavirus, rendering the claim false.

451f276cc933d1849f164af9023674a7.claim: ”America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years, yet the news tells you it’s new and gunna kill you all so go buy mask.”
451f276cc933d1849f164af9023674a7.label: false
451f276cc933d1849f164af9023674a7.passage:
0: The fact that there’s already a coronavirus vaccine for cattle should make you doubt claims that the virus causing the current human outbreak is new and deadly.
1: That’s what a Facebook post would lead you to believe.
2: It adds to a long list of misleading claims about the virus that, as of March 1, 2020, had hit 59 countries.
3: "Just in case you are wondering how much the media controls people, America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years," the Feb. 27, 2020, post claims, "yet the news tells you it’s new and gunna kill you all so go buy mask."
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The post shows a photo of a bottle with labeling that includes, "Bovine Rotavirus-Coronavirus Vaccine" and "For veterinary use only."
7: (The image and the post were deleted in the course of our reporting, but we found similar posts showing the image elsewhere along with similar claims.)
8: The vaccine pictured, called ScourGuard 4K, is made by animal drug manufacturer Zoetis and is real.
9: And we found products with similar labeling available for sale online.
10: But the vaccine is, according to the drug manufacturer, "effective as an aid in preventing diarrhea caused by bovine rotavirus (serotypes G6 and G10), bovine coronavirus, and E. coli in calves of vaccinated dams."
11: It won’t help humans, at least not now.
12: Why it won’t help "The coronavirus used in the Bovine Rotavirus-Coronavirus Vaccine is distinct from the current coronavirus," said Ming Tan, a faculty member of the Division of Infectious Diseases at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.
13: "The antibodies produced by the Bovine Rotavirus-Coronavirus Vaccine will not recognize the current" coronavirus "and thus will not protect humans from infection."
14: Studies would need to be done to determine whether the bovine vaccine could provide any help with the current coronavirus, said Amesh Adalja, senior scholar at Johns Hopkins University’s Center for Health Security.
15: "The bovine vaccine may be formulated in a manner that is not conducive to humans," he said.
16: There is a "very remote" chance a bovine vaccine might work in humans, said Richard Watanabe, professor of preventive medicine at the University of Southern California, but "the possibility it would work is low enough that it is more efficient to design a vaccine specifically for COVD-19."
17: Sorting out terms It helps to differentiate some terms being used in the news and social media.
18: Many reports refer to the coronavirus.
19: But coronavirus is a general term; there are different coronaviruses out there.
20: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses which may cause illness in animals or humans.
21: They’ve been around for a long time, but there are different strains.
22: More specific terms relating to the current situation include: 2019 novel coronavirus — novel, as in, new.
23: SARS-CoV-2 — the technical name of the new virus.
24: COVID-19 — the name of the disease caused by the new coronavirus, as in "coronavirus disease, 2019."
25: All three of those terms refer specifically to the coronavirus that was discovered in late 2019 in Wuhan, China, and has spread around the world.
26: Unfortunately, there is no vaccine for COVID-19 and none is expected soon.
27: One of the leading American experts on coronavirus, Anthony Fauci, who is director of the federal government’s National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told Fox News on Feb. 27, 2020, his team is working with a drugmaker and expects to begin a clinical trial within the "next month and a half."
28: "That whole process is going to take about a year to a year and a half.
29: Even though we are going as fast as you possibly can, it's still going to take a good year, year and a half to see if we have a vaccine that works," he said.

gpt4: The claim that America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus, implying that it is being misleadingly reported as a new disease, is false.
True, the ScourGuard 4K vaccine, produced by animal drug manufacturer Zoetis, does vaccinate cattle against a type of coronavirus[8].
This vaccine is specifically formulated to prevent diarrhea caused by bovine rotavirus, bovine coronavirus, and E. coli in calves[10].

However, Ming Tan at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center clarified that the coronavirus strain used in the Bovine Rotavirus-Coronavirus Vaccine is significantly different from the current, widely reported coronavirus[12].
The vaccine-produced antibodies in cattle will not recognize, nor provide protection against the current virus in humans[13].
The term "coronavirus" that is currently making news refers specifically to the COVID-19 strain, which was first discovered in Wuhan, China, in late 2019[25].
As of now, there is no available vaccine for COVID-19[26].

15b67f9dcd7e9001772e7cb7a39f1d19.claim: “While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls.”
15b67f9dcd7e9001772e7cb7a39f1d19.label: half-true
15b67f9dcd7e9001772e7cb7a39f1d19.passage:
0: In the most recent Democratic presidential debate, U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota said she didn’t want to keep rehashing the past.
1: Instead, she said, she’s focused on the way forward.
2: Klobuchar then went on to outline a series of issues she believes demand attention.
3: One of them was voting rights, and she used Wisconsin to underscore her point.
4: "While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls," she said Feb. 25, 2020 in South Carolina .
5: Wisconsin’s voter rolls have been front and center in recent months after the state Election Commission sent letters to 234,000 voters it believed may have moved, asking them to update their registrations if relevant.
6: The plan was to remove them from the rolls in 2021.
7: That prompted a lawsuit from a conservative law group contending those voters should be taken off the rolls now.
8: The matter ultimately may go to the state Supreme Court .
9: Klobuchar’s campaign said she was referring to voter purges in 2017 and 2018 — not those at the center of the lawsuit.
10: But that doesn’t explain why she implied it was happening right then.
11: (Note: Klobuchar dropped out of the presidential campaign March 2, 2020, after a sixth-place finish in South Carolina , as we were working on this fact-check.
12: We decided to complete it, since removal of voters from the state’s rolls is an ongoing issue.)
13: Let’s see where Klobuchar’s claim lands.
14: Changes to Wisconsin’s voter rolls When asked for evidence for Klobuchar’s claim, a staffer pointed to a 2018 report from the left-leaning Center for Media and Democracy that indicated nearly 700,000 voters had been removed from the rolls since 2016.
15: This included 44,000 voters in Milwaukee alone .
16: The decline stemmed from two separate actions in 2017 and 2018, according to Reid Magney, public information officer for the Wisconsin Elections Commission.
17: To meet a requirement under state law, the commission in 2017 removed more than 351,000 voters who hadn’t voted in four years and didn’t respond to a mailed notice to continue their registrations.
18: Over half of those voters didn’t respond, and roughly 43% of the notices were returned as undeliverable.
19: Some people had died or were deactivated for other reasons.
20: Then, in 2018, the commission canceled the registrations of more than 300,000 voters after the agency’s Electronic Registration Information Center, or ERIC, identified voters who had become inactive or needed to update their registration.
21: Once officials realized there were problems with accuracy of that list, they implemented a supplemental poll book to ensure anyone incorrectly removed could vote without reregistering.
22: The commission later said it found few examples of voters who were removed inappropriately.
23: So, the commission did deactivate hundreds of thousands of voters in 2017 and 2018.
24: But by saying they were "kicked off," Klobuchar suggests the motive was voter suppression.
25: Magney disputes that.
26: In any case, Wisconsin has same-day registration, so removal from the rolls does not prevent people from voting, as it might in some states if done too close to election day.
27: The latest election saga There is another problem with Klobuchar’s statement: She said Wisconsin has purged voters "while we are all sitting here debating."
28: That suggests the issue is immediate — not one from several years ago.
29: As we noted, Wisconsin is currently in the throes of a controversy over its voter rolls.
30: The conservative Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty , representing three suburban Milwaukee men, filed a lawsuit arguing that 234,000 voters who may have moved and received notices in the mail should be removed from the rolls within 30 days if they don’t respond.
31: The commission had said it wouldn’t suspend registrations until after April 2021.
32: Critics of the lawsuit believe any voter purge would be an affront to the democratic process and could inadvertently affect voters who didn’t even move.
33: The case has drawn heightened attention because of Wisconsin’s pivotal role in this year’s presidential race.
34: In December 2019, an Ozaukee County judge sided with the Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty and ordered the election commission to remove those people from the voter rolls .

gpt4: The claim made by Amy Klobuchar on Feb. 25, 2020 in South Carolina, stating that "While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls" is partially true[4].
It is accurate that the Wisconsin commission did deactivate hundreds of thousands of voters in 2017 and 2018[23].
However, Klobuchar's use of the term "kicked off" implies a motive of voter suppression[24].
While this might impose voting obstacles in some states, in Wisconsin, removal from voting rolls does not obstruct people from voting because of its same-day registration policy[26].
Therefore, the claim holds some truth but isn't entirely accurate due to the implications of the phrasing used.

80ad80b82cdc784964242a464be496aa.claim: ""Sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus."""
80ad80b82cdc784964242a464be496aa.label: false
80ad80b82cdc784964242a464be496aa.passage:
0: Health officials say one of the best ways Americans can prevent the spread of the 2019 coronavirus is to clean their hands.
1: But should they use hand sanitizer?
2: One popular image on Facebook says no.
3: "Hand sanitizer is anti-bacterial.
4: The coronavirus is a virus," reads the post, which is a screenshot of a March 1 tweet .
5: "A bacteria and a virus is not (sic) the same.
6: Wash your hands.
7: Sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) The post is wrong — health officials recommend the use of hand sanitizer to kill the coronavirus, known officially as COVID-19.
11: The original Twitter user clarified that in a follow-up tweet, but the context was lost on Facebook.
12: On its list of ways to prevent coronavirus infection, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says to "wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing."
13: If soap and water are not accessible, the CDC recommends using hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.
14: Although hand sanitizers are not effective against all viruses, the ones with high alcohol content have proven effective against some.
15: Several studies indicate that alcohol-based sanitizers are effective against "enveloped viruses," which include human coronaviruses.
16: Since its outbreak in Wuhan, China, in December, the 2019 coronavirus has infected more than 88,000 people in 64 countries.
17: In the United States, there have been 43 confirmed cases and six deaths , as of March 2, not including those repatriated to the country.
18: So continue washing your hands, and using hand sanitizer with a high alcohol content when you aren’t near soap and water.
19: The post telling you hand sanitizer will "do nothing" to stop the coronavirus is wrong.

gpt4: The claim that "sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus" is false, as indicated by several pieces of evidence.
Firstly, health officials have recommended the use of hand sanitizer to combat the virus, which is officially known as COVID-19[10].
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also advises that when soap and water are not readily available, sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol content should be used[13].
This recommendation is supported by several studies, indicating that alcohol-based sanitizers are indeed effective against "enveloped viruses" such as human coronaviruses[15].

4cb7fe2dfb58d174858d4596b3aec6a2.claim: “In ‘Resident Evil’ the Umbrella Corporation releases a virus that infects the people of Raccoon City. A biological research lab with the exact same logo as the Umbrella Corporation can be found in the city where the coronavirus outbreak originated.”
4cb7fe2dfb58d174858d4596b3aec6a2.label: false
4cb7fe2dfb58d174858d4596b3aec6a2.passage:
0: An image making the rounds on social media draws a supposedly eerie connection between the outbreak of the coronavirus in Wuhan, China, and the fictional virus that triggers the dangerous mutations at the center of the plot for "Resident Evil," a Japanese video-game series.
1: The image says that the fictional lab responsible for the virus in the "Resident Evil" franchise has the same logo as a real-life lab in Wuhan, where the coronavirus was first detected.
2: The problem with that claim: The Chinese lab with that logo is actually based in Shanghai, a roughly nine-hour drive from Wuhan.
3: "In ‘Resident Evil’ the Umbrella Corporation releases a virus that infects the people of Raccoon City," the image, posted to Facebook as early as Jan. 27, says.
4: "A biological research lab with the exact same logo as the Umbrella Corporation can be found in the city where the coronavirus outbreak originated.
5: Corona is an anagram for Racoon."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A screenshot of a Facebook post about the coronavirus and a fictional lab from the "Resident Evil" video game.
7: We rate this claim False.
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: Without getting too far into the details of "Resident Evil," it’s clear that the post is inaccurate, as other fact-checkers have noted .
11: In fact, the post gives itself away.
12: Beneath the logo for the biological research lab identified in the image is the company’s real name, Shang Hai Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited.
13: The company does have a blue-and-white logo that closely resembles the red-and-white logo from the fictional lab in "Resident Evil."
14: But according to the company’s website , the lab is based in Shanghai, which is more than 500 miles by car away from Wuhan, per Google Maps .
15: What’s more, there’s no evidence that the novel 2019 coronavirus was created in a lab.
16: We’ve debunked a number of claims — like the Facebook post in question — that suggested the new virus was artificially made in Wuhan or elsewhere .
17: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention , the new coronavirus is a "beta coronavirus" similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, and Middle East respiratory syndrome, or MERS.
18: All three viruses are believed to have their origins in bats.

gpt4: The claim that a biological research lab in Wuhan, where the coronavirus outbreak originated, has the same logo as the fictional Umbrella Corporation from the "Resident Evil" series is false.
While an image circulates implying this connection, the lab in question is actually named Shang Hai Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited, as seen beneath the logo in the identified image[12].
Furthermore, despite the image suggesting a Wuhan connection, the company's website clarifies that the lab is based in Shanghai, over 500 miles away from Wuhan according to Google Maps[14][1].
Therefore, the lab's location and identity do not corroborate the claim.

2b60062e440ab5ec59135567b0e8bf56.claim: “I certainly supported Barack Obama and Joe Biden. ... I was there both times for them.”
2b60062e440ab5ec59135567b0e8bf56.label: half-true
2b60062e440ab5ec59135567b0e8bf56.passage:
0: The fact that Mike Bloomberg hasn’t been a Democrat his whole life keeps coming up in his 2020 presidential bid.
1: At a CNN town hall, host Anderson Cooper asked Bloomberg why Democrats should trust him to lead their party.
2: Bloomberg acknowledged his past as a Republican and an Independent.
3: But he argued that he isn’t such a Democratic outsider if you look at who he supported.
4: "But if you want to know my Democratic credentials, I spoke for Hillary Clinton at the DNC Convention in Philadelphia in 2016," Bloomberg said at the Feb. 26 forum.
5: "I certainly supported Barack Obama and Joe Biden, (Biden) says no, but I was there both times for them, thank you very much."
6: Was Bloomberg really there for Obama and Biden in their 2008 and 2012 campaigns for the White House?
7: It would be a stretch to say he was an enthusiastic Obama supporter.
8: Bloomberg did not endorse Obama’s 2008 run, and while he did endorse him in 2012, that happened a week before the November election in an opinion piece that also criticized Obama’s record.
9: "Mike said he supported Obama both times.
10: He voted for him both times," said Stu Loeser, a Bloomberg campaign spokesman.
11: RELATED : Bloomberg is registered as a Democrat, but is he accepted as one?
12: Bloomberg in June 2008: He defended Obama but stayed neutral Obama’s 2008 bid was plagued with rumors that he was secretly a Muslim with anti-Israel views.
13: Bloomberg, who is Jewish, flew to Florida in June 2008 to defend Obama.
14: Bloomberg at that time was mayor of New York City.
15: The rumors about Obama were lies, Bloomberg told the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, "wedge politics at its worst, and we have to reject it — loudly, clearly and unequivocally."
16: Bloomberg told the audience he had not decided whom to support, the New York Times reported.
17: When he was asked whether he would become an ambassador to Jews for Obama, Bloomberg said he would "speak out against intolerance for both candidates," including Republican nominee Sen. John McCain.
18: In a July 2008 speech to the Independence Party of Minnesota, Bloomberg spoke about both Obama and McCain, without picking a side.
19: "Now, we're lucky this year: we have two candidates who have shown, on at least some issues, that they are capable of thinking and acting independently of the special interests," Bloomberg said.
20: Overall, Bloomberg delivered a largely neutral stance in 2008.
21: He did not endorse either of the party candidates.
22: Bloomberg in 2012: He endorsed a ‘divisive’ Obama Bloomberg endorsed Obama Nov. 1, 2012, in a Bloomberg.com post headlined, "A vote for a president to lead on climate change."
23: Bloomberg lauded Obama’s efforts to reduce carbon consumption, for setting higher fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks, and for adopting tighter controls on mercury emissions.
24: But he also said Obama had not done enough to build a coalition of centrists, "which doomed hope for any real progress on illegal guns, immigration, tax reform, job creation and deficit reduction."
25: "And rather than uniting the country around a message of shared sacrifice, he engaged in partisan attacks and has embraced a divisive populist agenda focused more on redistributing income than creating it," Bloomberg wrote in his endorsement.
26: Loeser told PolitiFact that Bloomberg’s endorsement was "designed to flip or lock down voters who still hadn't committed to Obama-Biden by the last days of the campaign."

gpt4: The claim made by Bloomberg that he "certainly supported Barack Obama and Joe Biden...I was there both times for them," is partially true.

While it's acknowledged that Bloomberg has had political affiliations as a Republican and an Independent, he stated at a forum held on February 26 that he had endorsed Hillary Clinton at the 2016 DNC convention in Philadelphia, showcasing his Democratic credentials [2][4].
Moreover, it's confirmed by Stu Loeser, a Bloomberg campaign spokesman, that Bloomberg voted for Obama in both election cycles [10].
However, endorsement is not synonymous with voting.
Bloomberg did not openly endorse Obama during his 2008 run and only endorsed him a week before the November 2012 election[8][21].

While Bloomberg expressed appreciation for Obama's efforts to reduce carbon consumption, set higher fuel-efficiency standards, and adopt tighter controls on mercury emissions, he also criticized Obama for an alleged lack of coalition-building, decrying a perceived focus on income redistribution over job creation[23][24][25].
Therefore, while there is evidence to support Bloomberg's claim of backing Obama, his public criticism and delayed endorsement complicates this narrative, making the claim half-true.

a020dac9dcff53d143165d7a465aa0f9.claim: a photo shows a man wearing a “government issue Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”
a020dac9dcff53d143165d7a465aa0f9.label: false
a020dac9dcff53d143165d7a465aa0f9.passage:
0: The photo in a Facebook post shows someone wearing what looks like a poor-man’s Walter White Halloween costume .
1: Between the mitts, hood jumpsuit and face mask, no bare skin is visible.
2: "Doctor’s Hospital of Sarasota has been notified by the National Center for DIsease Control & Public Health, Georgia (NCDC & PH) that they have a patient that has tested positive for COVID-19 (Coronavirus)," reads the March 1 post published by an account called Sarasota County.
3: "Doctor’s Hospital takes the safety of their employees and caregivers very seriously and has placed the infected in isolation until they can repair the furnace in the morgue that will be used for treatment.
4: Pictured below is our newest intern, Carlos, wearing our government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit which can be purchased directly from their website or on sale from Alibaba.com with discount code ‘SRQ69’ while supplies last."
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed, and Facebook users flagged the post as potentially false news.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: The post is false.
8: It’s a bad attempt at a joke that uses real information to heighten fears about the new coronavirus.
9: The Florida Department of Health announced on March 1 that there are two presumptive cases of COVID-19 in Florida, including one patient being treated at Doctors Hospital in Sarasota County.
10: A letter Doctors Hospital sent to patients and staff on March 1 says that the hospital "has been notified by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) that we have a patient in our facility who presumptively tested positive for COVID-19."
11: There is, of course, no mention of a furnace or a morgue.
12: The post from the page "Sarasota County" could easily be misinterpreted to be a real update about the situation at Doctors Hospital.
13: And while the text is a bit odd, you’d have to visit the page’s About section to find that it’s a self-described parody account.
14: Sarasota County’s actual Facebook page is here .
15: But the post on parody account blends factual information with jokes that not everyone is getting, especially as the post is reshared on other Facebook pages.
16: The "intern" in the photograph appears to actually be a taxi driver in Siberia who donned the protective gear to help make people laugh amid global panic over the coronavirus, the Siberian Times reported .

gpt4: The claim that a photo shows a man wearing a "government issue Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit" is false.
The image in fact depicts an individual in what seems to be a comical take on a Walter White Halloween costume, as seen in a Facebook post [0].

Furthermore, the alleged "intern" in the image is actually a cab driver in Siberia, employing the humorous outfit to elicit laughter amid the global anxiety driven by the coronavirus pandemic, according to a report by the Siberian Times [16].

The text accompanying the post, flaunting a discount code to purchase the supposed Saint Laurent protective suit, might seem bizarre but its context can be clarified when one checks the About section of the page where the post originates.
The page identifies itself as a parody account [13], which further underlines the inaccuracy of the claim.
Lastly, the Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit referenced in the post can be traced back to Alibaba.com as a purchasable item making it rather unlikely that it is a government issued model [4].

5d8f28f1ea509f6061e752fed84ce382.claim: “The coronavirus has made it to Mississippi and the lady that caught it wasn’t around nobody with it which means it is airborne. That means if the wind blows it your direction you’ll have it also.”
5d8f28f1ea509f6061e752fed84ce382.label: false
5d8f28f1ea509f6061e752fed84ce382.passage:
0: As the novel coronavirus spreads in the United States, so does misinformation.
1: More than 5,000 people have shared a Feb. 28 Facebook post , for example, that warns "the coronavirus has made it to Mississippi."
2: "And the lady that caught it wasn’t around nobody with it which means it is airborne," the post continues.
3: "That means if the wind blows it your direction you’ll have it also."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: First of all, as of March 3, it doesn’t appear that there are any confirmed cases in Mississippi of COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
7: The Mississippi State Department of Health website says "there are currently no cases of COVID-19 in Mississippi."
8: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that there are 60 confirmed cases in the U.S. in 12 states as of March 3, but Mississippi is not one of them.
9: Because COVID-19 is a new disease, researchers are still learning about how it spreads .
10: But according to the CDC, the virus is thought to spread mainly from person to person, either between people within sixfeet of each other or through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
11: It’s also possible that someone could get COVID-19 by touching something that has the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose or eyes, but the CDC says this isn’t the main way the virus spreads.
12: Noreen Hynes, director of the John Hopkins Geographic Medicine Center, told PolitiFact in an email that talking — especially when saying words with the letters "t" or "d" — could also spread the droplets that can cause infection when they come into contact with the mucous membranes of someone’s eyes, nose or mouth.
13: The spread of coronavirus via such droplets has been documented.
14: Airborne transmission has not been documented but, Hynes said, it "has been hypothesized to occur."
15: Hynes explained that "airborne transmission" refers to when residue from evaporated respiratory droplets contains a microorganism and can linger suspended in the air for a long time.
16: "The organism on such droplet nuclei, as they are called, must be capable of surviving for a long time outside the body and must be resistant to drying," Hynes said.
17: "Such droplet nuclei act like a gas, allowing organisms to enter both the upper and lower respiratory tract.
18: Diseases associated with airborne transmission include measles, chickenpox and tuberculosis."
19: But the University of California San Francisco says in a Feb. 13 post on its website that the new coronavirus "isn’t believed to be an airborne virus, like measles or smallpox, that can circulate through the air."
20: Charles Chiu, a doctor who studies infectious diseases at the university, is quoted in the post as saying: "If you have an infected person in the front of the plane, for instance, and you’re in the back of the plane, your risk is close to zero simply because the area of exposure is thought to be roughly six feet from the infected person."
21: There’s a difference between viruses that are transmitted by droplets and things that are aerosolized and float around in the air, according to University of Chicago Medicine.
22: The school puts it like this : "Think of droplets as small bits of fluid that you can see and feel when someone sneezes.
23: You sneeze or cough and these droplets get on surfaces and then you touch them and get them on your hands, or they can fly right into your mouth or nose or eyes.
24: That’s how most coronaviruses are transmitted and that’s how we think this one is too."
25: Now consider an aerosol — like hairspray.
26: You may still be able to smell it a while after someone has used it because it’s lingering in the air, according to the school: "Obviously we’re learning a lot about this virus, but most coronaviruses aren’t airborne this way.
27: Generally speaking, there may be times when some of these droplets or particles are airborne, but it’s limited."

gpt4: The claim that the coronavirus has reached Mississippi and that it is airborne, is false.

This misinformation appears to have gained traction through social media, as evidenced by a February 28 Facebook post that warns about the arrival of the virus in Mississippi which has been shared by more than 5,000 users[1].
However, as of March 3, there were no confirmed cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, in Mississippi [6].

This has been officially confirmed by both the Mississippi State Department of Health [7] and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), neither of which include Mississippi in the list of 12 states with confirmed cases [8].
Furthermore, the claim that the virus could be airborne, suggesting it could be spread by the wind, is also inaccurate.
The CDC states that the virus is thought to primarily spread through close person-to-person contact or via respiratory droplets from an infected person who coughs or sneezes [10].

This understanding is also echoed by the University of California San Francisco, which in contradistinction to diseases like measles or smallpox, does not consider the novel coronavirus to be airborne [19].
In conclusion, this claim is both factually and scientifically incorrect.

898cf5f1aa59c0bfdf9bbb18d0c7a6e6.claim: President Donald Trump spawned the “Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name ‘zyphr.’”
898cf5f1aa59c0bfdf9bbb18d0c7a6e6.label: false
898cf5f1aa59c0bfdf9bbb18d0c7a6e6.passage:
0: As the United States preps for the spread of the coronavirus, a conspiracy video on social media makes claims that President Donald Trump helped create the virus.
1: The video has been viewed around 6,000 times on a YouTube channel called "stranger than fiction news."
2: Its title reads: "BREAKING: TRUMP SPAWNED WUHAN SUPER VIRUS OUTBREAK UNDER CODE NAME ‘ZYPHR’ ACCORDING TO DOCUMENTS."
3: The video was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: This is a hoax.
6: There are no "documents," or any other sort of evidence, that support the theory that Trump is behind the creation of the coronavirus, which had killed six people in the U.S. as of March 3, 2020.
7: The video, narrated in a male voice, says "top secret documents" predict that a flu-like pandemic would strike America and kill millions of people.
8: While the narrator claims the documents are apparently going around "U.S. establishments," there are no credible reports that reflect this information, and the video provides no links or evidence that it exists.
9: This conspiracy theory is based on speculation and contains zero evidence that Trump has anything to do with the the creation of the coronavirus.
10: The video was shared by STFN Reloaded, which has posted other coronavirus-related claims that we have rated False.

gpt4: The claim that President Donald Trump is responsible for the creation of the coronavirus, known as the "Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name 'zyphr,'" is false.
This conspiracy theory is based on speculation without any valid evidence to substantiate such accusations against Trump[9].
In fact, no documents or other forms of evidence have been found to support this misleading theory[6].
It is, therefore, clear that this claim is merely a baseless hoax designed to mislead the public[5].

763b8dd67e19770e1f749fcb770eb55a.claim: “Shands Hospital of Gainesville Florida has confirmed its first case of coronavirus.”
763b8dd67e19770e1f749fcb770eb55a.label: false
763b8dd67e19770e1f749fcb770eb55a.passage:
0: Wash your hands and beware suspicious-looking posts on social media claiming the novel coronavirus has arrived in your community.
1: "CNN Breaking News Update," reads the text of what looks like a screenshot published on Facebook on March 1 .
2: "Shands Hospital of Gainesville Florida confirmed its first case of coronavirus."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Florida is among 12 states reporting cases of COVID-19 , the disease caused by the coronavirus.
6: As of March 2, 2020, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have confirmed two cases in Hillsborough and Manatee counties.
7: Gainesville is in Alachua County.
8: Shands Hospital in Gainesville is part of the the University of Florida Health medical network.
9: A spokesman for UF Health did not immediately return PolitiFact’s call about the Facebook post.

gpt4: The claim that the Shands Hospital of Gainesville, Florida has confirmed its first case of coronavirus is false.
Gainesville, which is in Alachua County, has not reported any instances of the virus at the Shands Hospital according to a UF Health's communications team member.
In a direct response to the Facebook post containing this claim, the team member stated definitively that they "have no cases of the 2019 novel coronavirus to date"[10][7].
Furthermore, the post was subsequently flagged in Facebook’s ongoing efforts to combat the spread of fake news and misinformation on its News Feed [3].

3ab0424d0a2fafa0e86f84cbe8cc41cb.claim: no one has died from the coronavirus in the United States.
3ab0424d0a2fafa0e86f84cbe8cc41cb.label: false
3ab0424d0a2fafa0e86f84cbe8cc41cb.passage:
0: An Instagram post making a political point about abortion in the United States muffs the landing by claiming that no one has died from COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
1: "Death toll in America," the March 1 post says.
2: "Coronavirus 0, abortion 63,000,000."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Though any count of abortions in the United States can’t be precise, the abortion number seems to be a reasonable estimate.
6: (Read our 2012 fact-check for details.)
7: But for COVID-19, the post is simply wrong.
8: As of March 3, there have been nine deaths from COVID-19 in the United States.
9: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have reported six deaths on their website while the Seattle Times reported three more deaths that afternoon.
10: The victims were all in Washington state .
11: Of course, the Instagram post was published on March 1.
12: But the first death was reported on Feb. 29 .
13: Officials announced four more deaths on March 2.

gpt4: The claim that no one has died from the coronavirus in the United States is false.
The first death was reported on February 29[12].
Four additional deaths were announced by officials on March 2[13].
As of March 3, the death toll from COVID-19 in the U.S had risen to nine [8].
This was confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reported six deaths on its website, while The Seattle Times reported an additional three deaths that same afternoon [9].
Hence, the post claiming that no one has died from the disease in the U.S is simply incorrect [7].
